 1: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Cell 2002 Mar;13(3):854-65 
 
 <Capitalized> Endoplasmic reticulum dynamics, inheritance, and cytoskeletal interactions in budding yeast. 
 
 <Capitalized> Fehrenbacher <AllCaps> KL, <PERSON  Davis> <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Wu> <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Boldogh <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Pon <LOCATION  LA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Anatomy and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Physicians and <Capitalized> Surgeons, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10032. 
 
 <Capitalized> The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae consists of a reticulum underlying the plasma membrane (cortical ER) and <AllCaps> ER associated with the nuclear envelope (nuclear ER). <Capitalized> We used a Sec63p-green fluorescent protein fusion protein to study motility events associated with inheritance of cortical <AllCaps> ER and nuclear <AllCaps> ER in living yeast cells. <Capitalized> During <AllCaps> M phase before nuclear migration, we observed thick, apparently rigid tubular extensions emanating from the nuclear <AllCaps> ER that elongate, undergo sweeping motions along the cell cortex, and shorten. <Capitalized> Two findings support a role for microtubules in this process. <Capitalized> First, extension of tubular structures from the nuclear <AllCaps> ER is inhibited by destabilization of microtubules. <Capitalized> Second, astral microtubules, structures that undergo similar patterns of extension, cortical surveillance and retraction, colocalize with nuclear <AllCaps> ER extensions. <Capitalized> During <PERSON  S> and G(2) phases of the cell cycle, we observed anchorage of the cortical <AllCaps> ER at the site of bud emergence and apical bud growth. <Capitalized> Thin tubules of the <AllCaps> ER that extend from the anchored cortical <AllCaps> ER display undulating, apparently random movement and move into the bud as it grows. <Capitalized> Finally, we found that cortical <AllCaps> ER morphology is sensitive to a filamentous actin-destabilizing drug, latrunculin-A, and to mutations in the actin-encoding <EndsInDigit> ACT1 gene. <Capitalized> Our observations support 1) different mechanisms and cytoskeletal mediators for the inheritance of nuclear and cortical <AllCaps> ER elements and 2) a mechanism for cortical <AllCaps> ER inheritance that is cytoskeleton dependent but relies on anchorage, not directed movement.

 2: <Capitalized> Genetics 2002 Mar;160(3):923-34 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Novel <Capitalized> Adaptor <Capitalized> Protein, Mti1p, and Vrp1p, a <Capitalized> Homolog of Wiskott-Aldrich <Capitalized> Syndrome Protein-Interacting <Capitalized> Protein (WIP), <PERSON  May> <Capitalized> Antagonistically <Capitalized> Regulate <Capitalized> Type <AllCaps> I <Capitalized> Myosins in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <Capitalized> Mochida <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Yamamoto <PERSON  T,> Fujimura-Kamada <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Tanaka <AllCaps> K. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Interaction, <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Genetic <Capitalized> Medicine, <Capitalized> Hokkaido <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> Graduate <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  Sapporo,> <Capitalized> Hokkaido, 060-0815, <LOCATION Japan> 
 
 <Capitalized> Type <AllCaps> I myosins in yeast, Myo3p and Myo5p (Myo3/5p), are involved in the reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain of Myo5p regulates the polymerization of actin through interactions with both Las17p, a homolog of mammalian Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), and Vrp1p, a homolog of WASP-interacting protein (WIP). Vrp1p is required for both the localization of Myo5p to cortical patch-like structures and the ATP-independent interaction between the Myo5p tail region and actin filaments. <Capitalized> We have identified and characterized a new adaptor protein, Mti1p (Myosin tail region-interacting protein), which interacts with the <EndsInDigit> SH3 domains of Myo3/5p. Mti1p co-immunoprecipitated with Myo5p and Mti1p-GFP co-localized with cortical actin patches. <AllCaps> A null mutation of <EndsInDigit> MTI1 exhibited synthetic lethal phenotypes with mutations in <EndsInDigit> SAC6 and SLA2, which encode actin-bundling and cortical actin-binding proteins, respectively. <Capitalized> Although the mti1 null mutation alone did not display any obvious phenotype, it suppressed vrp1 mutation phenotypes, including temperature-sensitive growth, abnormally large cell morphology, defects in endocytosis and salt-sensitive growth. <Capitalized> These results suggest that Mti1p and Vrp1p antagonistically regulate type <AllCaps> I myosin functions.

 3: <AllCaps> J <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol 2002 <PERSON  Mar> 8;316(5):1071-81 
 
 <Capitalized> Mechanistic <Capitalized> Implications for <Capitalized> Escherichia coli Cofactor-dependent <Capitalized> Phosphoglycerate <Capitalized> Mutase <Capitalized> Based on the High-resolution <Capitalized> Crystal <Capitalized> Structure of a <Capitalized> Vanadate Complex. 
 
 <PERSON  Bond> <AllCaps> CS, <PERSON  White> <AllCaps> MF, <PERSON  Hunter> <AllCaps> WN. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> Wellcome <Capitalized> Trust <Capitalized> Biocentre, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Dundee, <Capitalized> Dundee, <EndsInDigit> DD1 5EH, <LOCATION  UK> 
 
 <Capitalized> The structure of <Capitalized> Escherichia coli cofactor-dependent phosphoglycerate mutase (dPGM), complexed with the potent inhibitor vanadate, has been determined to a resolution of 1.30A (R-factor 0.159; R-free 0.213). <Capitalized> The inhibitor is present in the active site, principally as divanadate, but with evidence of additional vanadate moieties at either end, and representing a different binding mode to that observed in the structural homologue prostatic acid phosphatase. <Capitalized> The analysis reveals the enzyme-ligand interactions involved in inhibition of the mutase activity by vanadate and identifies a water molecule, observed in the native E.coli <MixedCase> dPGM structure which, once activated by vanadate, may dephosphorylate the active protein. <Capitalized> Rather than reflecting the active conformation previously observed for E.coli dPGM, the inhibited protein's conformation resembles that of the inactive dephosphorylated <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae dPGM. <Capitalized> The provision of a high-resolution structure of both active and inactive forms of <MixedCase> dPGM from a single organism, in conjunction with computational modelling of substrate molecules in the active site provides insight into the binding of substrates and the specific interactions necessary for three different activities, mutase, synthase and phosphatase, within a single active site. <Capitalized> The sequence similarity of E.coli and human <MixedCase> dPGMs allows us to correlate stucture with clinical pathology. <Capitalized> Copyright 2002 <PERSON  Elsevier> <Capitalized> Science Ltd.

 <Capitalized> Implications for the <Capitalized> Ubiquitination <Capitalized> Reaction of the Anaphase-promoting <Capitalized> Complex from the <Capitalized> Crystal <Capitalized> Structure of the Doc1/Apc10 Subunit. 
 
 <Capitalized> Au <AllCaps> SW, <Capitalized> Leng <PERSON  X,> <PERSON  Harper> <AllCaps> JW, <PERSON  Barford> <AllCaps> D. 
 
 <Capitalized> Section of <Capitalized> Structural <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Chester> <PERSON  Beatty> <Capitalized> Laboratories, <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research, 237 <Capitalized> Fulham <Capitalized> Road, <LOCATION  London,> <EndsInDigit> SW3 6JB, <LOCATION  UK> 
 
 <Capitalized> The anaphase-promoting complex (APC) is a multi-subunit <EndsInDigit> E3 protein ubiquitin ligase that is responsible for the metaphase to anaphase transition and the exit from mitosis. <Capitalized> One of the subunits of the <AllCaps> APC that is required for its ubiquitination activity is Doc1/Apc10, a protein composed of a Doc1 homology domain that has been identified in a number of diverse putative <EndsInDigit> E3 ubiquitin ligases. <Capitalized> Here, we present the crystal structure of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Doc1/Apc10 at 2.2A resolution. <Capitalized> The Doc1 homology domain forms a beta-sandwich structure that is related in architecture to the galactose-binding domain of galactose oxidase, the coagulation factor <EndsInDigit> C2 domain and a domain of XRCC1. <Capitalized> Residues that are invariant amongst Doc1/Apc10 sequences, including a temperature-sensitive mitotic arrest mutant, map to a beta-sheet region of the molecule, whose counterpart in galactose oxidase, the coagulation factor <EndsInDigit> C2 domains and XRCC1, mediate bio-molecular interactions. <Capitalized> This finding suggests the identification of the functionally important and conserved region of Doc1/Apc10 and, since invariant residues of Doc1/Apc10 colocalise with conserved residues of other Doc1 homology domains, we propose that the Doc1 homology domains perform common ubiquitination functions in the <AllCaps> APC and other <EndsInDigit> E3 ubiquitin ligases. <Capitalized> Copyright 2002 <PERSON  Elsevier> <Capitalized> Science Ltd.

 <Capitalized> Interactions among the protein and <AllCaps> RNA subunits of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae nuclear RNase <PERSON  P.> 
 
 Houser-Scott <AllCaps> F, <Capitalized> Xiao <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Millikin> <AllCaps> CE, <Capitalized> Zengel <AllCaps> JM, <Capitalized> Lindahl <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Engelke> <AllCaps> DR. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor,> <AllCaps> MI 48109-0606; and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> University of Maryland--Baltimore <Capitalized> County, <LOCATION  Baltimore,> <AllCaps> MD 21250. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ribonuclease <PERSON  P> (RNase P) is a ubiquitous endoribonuclease that cleaves precursor <MixedCase> tRNAs to generate mature 5prime prime or minute termini. <Capitalized> Although RNase <PERSON  P> from all kingdoms of life have been found to have essential <AllCaps> RNA subunits, the number and size of the protein subunits ranges from one small protein in bacteria to at least nine proteins of up to 100 kDa. <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae nuclear RNase <PERSON  P,> the enzyme is composed of ten subunits: a single <AllCaps> RNA and nine essential proteins. <Capitalized> The spatial organization of these components within the enzyme is not yet understood. <Capitalized> In this study we examine the likely binary protein--protein and protein--RNA subunit interactions by using directed two- and three-hybrid tests in yeast. <Capitalized> Only two protein subunits, Pop1p and Pop4p, specifically bind the <AllCaps> RNA subunit. Pop4p also interacted with seven of the other eight protein subunits. <Capitalized> The remaining protein subunits all showed one or more specific protein--protein interactions with the other integral protein subunits. <Capitalized> Of particular interest was the behavior of Rpr2p, the only protein subunit found in RNase <PERSON  P> but not in the closely related enzyme, RNase <AllCaps> MRP. Rpr2p interacts strongly with itself as well as with Pop4p. <Capitalized> Similar interactions with self and Pop4p were also detected for Snm1p, the only unique protein subunit so far identified in RNase <AllCaps> MRP. <Capitalized> This observation is consistent with Snm1p and Rpr2p serving analogous functions in the two enzymes. <Capitalized> This study provides a low-resolution map of the multisubunit architecture of the ribonucleoprotein enzyme, nuclear RNase <PERSON  P> from <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae.

 <Capitalized> Transcription activator interactions with multiple SWI/SNF subunits. 
 
 <PERSON  Neely> <AllCaps> KE, <PERSON  Hassan> <AllCaps> AH, <PERSON  Brown> <AllCaps> CE, <PERSON  Howe> <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Workman> <AllCaps> JL. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Howard> <PERSON  Hughes> <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> The <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> University <PERSON  Park,> <AllCaps> PA 16802, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> We have previously shown that the yeast SWI/SNF complex stimulates in vitro transcription from chromatin templates in an ATP-dependent manner. SWI/SNF function in this regard requires the presence of an activator with which it can interact directly, linking activator recruitment of SWI/SNF to transcriptional stimulation. <Capitalized> In this study, we determine the SWI/SNF subunits that mediate its interaction with activators. <Capitalized> Using a photo-cross-linking label transfer strategy, we show that the Snf5, Swi1, and Swi2/Snf2 subunits are contacted by the yeast acidic activators, Gcn4 and Hap4, in the context of the intact native SWI/SNF complex. <Capitalized> In addition, we show that the same three subunits can interact individually with acidic activation domains, indicating that each subunit contributes to binding activators. <Capitalized> Furthermore, mutations that reduce the activation potential of these activators also diminish its interaction with each of these SWI/SNF subunits. <PERSON  Thus,> three distinct subunits of the SWI/SNF complex contribute to its interactions with activation domains.

 <Capitalized> Solution structures of two FHA1-phosphothreonine peptide complexes provide insight into the structural basis of the ligand specificity of <EndsInDigit> FHA1 from yeast Rad53. 
 
 <Capitalized> Yuan <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Yongkiettrakul <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Byeon <AllCaps> IJ, <Capitalized> Zhou <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Tsai <AllCaps> MD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> The <LOCATION  Ohio> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Columbus> <AllCaps> OH 43210, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Rad53, a yeast checkpoint protein involved in regulating the repair of <AllCaps> DNA damage, contains two forkhead-associated domains, <EndsInDigit> FHA1 and FHA2. <Capitalized> Previous combinatorial library screening has shown that <EndsInDigit> FHA1 strongly selects peptides containing a <MixedCase> pTXXD motif. <Capitalized> Subsequent location of this motif within the sequence of Rad9, the target protein, coupled with spectroscopic analysis has led to identification of a tight binding sequence that is likely the binding site of FHA1: (188)SLEV(pT)EADATFVQ(200). <Capitalized> We present solution structures of <EndsInDigit> FHA1 in complex with this pT-peptide and with another Rad9-derived pT-peptide that has ca 30-fold lower affinity, (148)KKMTFQ(pT)PTDPLE(160). <PERSON  Both> complexes showed intermolecular NOEs predominantly between three peptide residues (pT, +1, and +2 residues) and five <EndsInDigit> FHA1 residues (S82, R83, S85, T106, and N107). <Capitalized> Furthermore, the following interactions were implicated on the basis of chemical shift perturbations and structural analysis: the phosphate group of the <MixedCase> pT residue with the side-chain amide group of <EndsInDigit> N86 and the guanidino group of R70, and the carboxylate group of <PERSON  Asp> (at the +3 position) with the guanidino group of R83. <Capitalized> The generated structures revealed a similar binding mode adopted by these two peptides, suggesting that <MixedCase> pT and the +3 residue <PERSON  Asp> are the major contributors to binding affinity and specificity, while +1 and +2 residues could provide additional fine-tuning. <Capitalized> It was also shown that <EndsInDigit> FHA1 does not bind to the corresponding pS-peptides or a related pY-peptide. <Capitalized> We suggest that differentiation between <MixedCase> pT and pS-peptides by <EndsInDigit> FHA1 can be attributed to hydrophobic interactions between the methyl group of the <MixedCase> pT residue and the aliphatic protons of R83, S85, and <EndsInDigit> T106 from FHA1. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Functional and physical interactions between components of the Prp19p-associated complex. 
 
 <Capitalized> Chen <AllCaps> CH, <PERSON  Yu> <AllCaps> WC, <Capitalized> Tsao <AllCaps> TY, <PERSON  Wang> <AllCaps> LY, <Capitalized> Chen <AllCaps> HR, <Capitalized> Lin <AllCaps> JY, <Capitalized> Tsai <AllCaps> WY, <Capitalized> Cheng <AllCaps> SC. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Academia <Capitalized> Sinica, <Capitalized> Nankang, <LOCATION  Taiwan,> <Capitalized> Republic of <LOCATION China> 
 
 <Capitalized> The Prp19p-associated complex is essential for the yeast pre-mRNA splicing reaction. <Capitalized> The complex consists of at least eight protein components, but is not tightly associated with spliceosomal snRNAs. <Capitalized> By a combination of genetic and biochemical methods we previously identified four components of this complex, Ntc25p, Ntc85p, Ntc30p and Ntc20p, all of them being novel splicing factors. <Capitalized> We have now identified three other components of the complex, Ntc90p, Ntc77p and Ntc31p. <Capitalized> These three proteins were also associated with the spliceosome during the splicing reaction in the same manner as Prp19p, concurrently with or immediately after dissociation of <EndsInDigit> U4 snRNA. Two-hybrid analysis revealed that none of these proteins interacted with Prp19p or Ntc25p, but all interacted with Ntc85p. <Capitalized> An interaction network between the identified components of the Prp19p-associated complex is demonstrated. <Capitalized> Biochemical analysis revealed that Ntc90p, Ntc31p, Ntc30p and Ntc20p form a subcomplex, which, through interacting with Ntc85p and Ntc77p, can associate with Prp19p and Ntc25p to form the Prp19p-associated complex. <Capitalized> Genetic analysis suggests that Ntc31p, Ntc30p and Ntc20p may play roles in modulating the function of Ntc90p.

 9: <Capitalized> Biochemistry 2002 <Capitalized> Feb 19;41(7):2409-20 
 
 <Capitalized> Novel interactions of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae type 1 protein phosphatase identified by single-step affinity purification and mass spectrometry. 
 
 <PERSON  Walsh> <AllCaps> EP, <PERSON  Lamont> <AllCaps> DJ, <PERSON  Beattie> <AllCaps> KA, <PERSON  Stark> <AllCaps> MJ. 
 
 <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Life <Capitalized> Sciences <Capitalized> Biocentre, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Dundee, <Capitalized> Dundee <EndsInDigit> DD1 5EH, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The catalytic subunit of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae type 1 protein phosphatase (PP1(C)) is encoded by the essential gene <EndsInDigit> GLC7 and is involved in regulating diverse cellular processes. <Capitalized> To identify potential regulatory or targeting subunits of yeast PP1(C), we tagged Glc7p at its amino terminus with protein <AllCaps> A and affinity-purified Glc7p protein complexes from yeast. <Capitalized> The purified proteins were separated by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and identified by peptide mass fingerprint analysis using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) mass spectrometry. <Capitalized> To confirm the accuracy of our identifications, peptides from some of the proteins were also sequenced using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) coupled to tandem mass spectrometry. <Capitalized> Only four of the Glc7p-associated proteins that we identified (Mhp1p, Bni4p, Ref2p, and Sds22p) have previously been shown to interact with Glc7p, and multiple components of the <AllCaps> CPF (cleavage and polyadenylation factor) complex involved in messenger <AllCaps> RNA 3'-end processing were present as major components in the Glc7p-associated protein fraction. <Capitalized> To confirm the interaction of Glc7p with this complex, we used the same approach to purify and characterize the components of the yeast <AllCaps> CPF complex using protein A-tagged Pta1p. <PERSON  Six> known components of the yeast (CPF) complex, together with Glc7p, were identified among the Pta1p-associated polypeptides using peptide mass fingerprint analysis. <PERSON  Thus> Glc7p is a novel component of the <AllCaps> CPF complex and may therefore be involved regulating <MixedCase> mRNA 3'-end processing.

 <Capitalized> Recovery of recombinant cutinase using detergent foam. 
 
 <Capitalized> Fernandes <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Mattiasson <AllCaps> B, Hatti-Kaul <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Chemistry & <Capitalized> Chemical <Capitalized> Engineering, <PERSON  Lund> <Capitalized> University, P.O. <PERSON  Box> 124, S-221 00 <PERSON  Lund,> <LOCATION Sweden> 
 
 <Capitalized> Foam generated by vigorous stirring of a nonionic detergent, <Capitalized> Triton X-114, was used for the recovery of recombinant cutinase expressed by <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The enzyme with a hydrophobic fusion tag, (Trp-Pro)(4), was recovered with a higher yield as compared to the wild-type cutinase, indicating the involvement of hydrophobic interactions in protein isolation with the foam. <Capitalized> The influence of various factors including volume, dilution, pH, different additives, and cell concentration in the medium on enzyme recovery was investigated. <Capitalized> Interaction of the enzyme with detergent was monitored using fluorescence spectroscopy. <Capitalized> No significant changes in protein conformation after the isolation procedure were observed using circular dichroism.

 <Capitalized> Probing protein conformational changes in living cells by using designer binding proteins: application to the estrogen receptor. 
 
 <Capitalized> Koide <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Abbatiello <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Rothgery <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Koide <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Biophysics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Rochester> <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine and <Capitalized> Dentistry, 601 <Capitalized> Elmwood <Capitalized> Avenue, <LOCATION  Rochester,> <LOCATION  NY> 14642, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <AllCaps> A challenge in understanding the mechanism of protein function in biology is to establish the correlation between functional form in the intracellular environment and high-resolution structures obtained with in vitro techniques. <Capitalized> Here we present a strategy to probe conformational changes of proteins inside cells. <Capitalized> Our method involves: (i) engineering binding proteins to different conformations of a target protein, and (ii) using them to sense changes in the surface property of the target in cells. <Capitalized> We probed ligand-induced conformational changes of the estrogen receptor alpha (ER alpha) ligand-binding domain (LBD). <Capitalized> By using yeast two-hybrid techniques, we first performed combinatorial library screening of "monobodies" (small antibody mimics using the scaffold of a fibronectin type <AllCaps> III domain) for clones that bind to <AllCaps> ER alpha and then characterized their interactions with <AllCaps> ER alpha in the nucleus, the native environment of <AllCaps> ER alpha, in the presence of various ligands. <AllCaps> A library using a highly flexible loop yielded monobodies that specifically recognize a particular ligand complex of <AllCaps> ER alpha, and the pattern of monobody specificity was consistent with the structural differences found in known crystal structures of <AllCaps> ER alpha-LBD. <AllCaps> A more restrained loop library yielded clones that bind both agonist- and antagonist-bound <AllCaps> ER alpha. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we found that a deletion of the <AllCaps> ER alpha <AllCaps> F domain that is C-terminally adjacent to the <AllCaps> LBD increased the crossreactivity of monobodies to the apo-ER alpha-LBD, suggesting a dynamic nature of the <AllCaps> ER alpha-LBD conformation and a role of the <AllCaps> F domain in restraining the <AllCaps> LBD in an inactive conformation.

 12: <AllCaps> J <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol 2002 <PERSON  Jan> 25;315(4):809-18 
 
 Protein-protein interactions of hCsl4p with other human exosome subunits. 
 
 <PERSON  Raijmakers> <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Noordman> <AllCaps> YE, van <Capitalized> Venrooij <AllCaps> WJ, <PERSON  Pruijn> <AllCaps> GJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Nijmegen,> <LOCATION  Nijmegen,> <Capitalized> The <LOCATION Netherlands> 
 
 <Capitalized> The exosome is a complex of 3'-->5' exoribonucleases, which functions in a variety of cellular processes, all requiring the processing or degradation of <AllCaps> RNA. <Capitalized> We demonstrate that the two human proteins hCsl4p and hRrp42p, which have been identified on the basis of their sequence homology with <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae proteins, are associated with the human exosome. <Capitalized> By mammalian two-hybrid and <AllCaps> GST pull-down assays, we show that the hCsl4p protein interacts directly with two other exosome proteins, hRrp42p and hRrp46p. <Capitalized> Mutants of hCsl4p that fail to interact with either hRrp42p or hRrp46p are also not able to associate with exosome complexes in vivo. <Capitalized> These results indicate that the association of hCsl4p with the exosome is mediated by protein-protein interactions with hRrp42p and hRrp46p. <Capitalized> Copyright 2002 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 13: <Capitalized> Nature 2002 <PERSON  Jan> 10;415(6868):180-3

 <Capitalized> Systematic identification of protein complexes in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae by mass spectrometry. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ho <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Gruhler <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Heilbut> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Bader> <AllCaps> GD, <PERSON  Moore> <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Adams> <AllCaps> SL, <PERSON  Millar> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Taylor> <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Bennett> <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Boutilier <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Yang <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Wolting <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Donaldson> <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Schandorff <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Shewnarane <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Vo <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Taggart> <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Goudreault <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Muskat <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Alfarano <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Dewar> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Lin <PERSON  Z,> <Capitalized> Michalickova <AllCaps> K, <PERSON  Willems> <AllCaps> AR, <Capitalized> Sassi <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Nielsen> <AllCaps> PA, <PERSON  Rasmussen> <AllCaps> KJ, <PERSON  Andersen> <AllCaps> JR, <PERSON  Johansen> <AllCaps> LE, <PERSON  Hansen> <AllCaps> LH, <Capitalized> Jespersen <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Podtelejnikov <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Nielsen> <AllCaps> E, <PERSON  Crawford> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Poulsen> <PERSON  V,> <PERSON  Sorensen> <AllCaps> BD, <Capitalized> Matthiesen <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Hendrickson> <AllCaps> RC, <Capitalized> Gleeson <AllCaps> F, <PERSON  Pawson> <PERSON  T,> <PERSON  Moran> <AllCaps> MF, <Capitalized> Durocher <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Mann> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Hogue> <AllCaps> CW, <Capitalized> Figeys <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Tyers <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <AllCaps> MDS <Capitalized> Proteomics, 251 <PERSON  Attwell> <Capitalized> Drive, <LOCATION  Toronto,> <LOCATION  Canada> M9W 7H4, and <Capitalized> Staermosegaardsvej 6, DK-5230 <LOCATION  Odense> <AllCaps> M, <LOCATION Denmark> 
 
 <Capitalized> The recent abundance of genome sequence data has brought an urgent need for systematic proteomics to decipher the encoded protein networks that dictate cellular function. <Capitalized> To date, generation of large-scale protein-protein interaction maps has relied on the yeast two-hybrid system, which detects binary interactions through activation of reporter gene expression. <Capitalized> With the advent of ultrasensitive mass spectrometric protein identification methods, it is feasible to identify directly protein complexes on a proteome-wide scale. <Capitalized> Here we report, using the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a test case, an example of this approach, which we term high-throughput mass spectrometric protein complex identification (HMS-PCI). <Capitalized> Beginning with 10% of predicted yeast proteins as baits, we detected 3,617 associated proteins covering 25% of the yeast proteome. <Capitalized> Numerous protein complexes were identified, including many new interactions in various signalling pathways and in the <AllCaps> DNA damage response. <Capitalized> Comparison of the <ContainsHyphen> HMS-PCI data set with interactions reported in the literature revealed an average threefold higher success rate in detection of known complexes compared with large-scale two-hybrid studies. <PERSON  Given> the high degree of connectivity observed in this study, even partial <ContainsHyphen> HMS-PCI coverage of complex proteomes, including that of humans, should allow comprehensive identification of cellular networks.

 <Capitalized> Cellzome <AllCaps> AG, <Capitalized> Meyerhofstrasse 1, 69117 <Capitalized> Heidelberg, <LOCATION Germany> anne-claude.gavin@cellzome.com 
 
 <PERSON  Most> cellular processes are carried out by multiprotein complexes. <Capitalized> The identification and analysis of their components provides insight into how the ensemble of expressed proteins (proteome) is organized into functional units. <Capitalized> We used tandem-affinity purification (TAP) and mass spectrometry in a large-scale approach to characterize multiprotein complexes in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> We processed 1,739 genes, including 1,143 human orthologues of relevance to human biology, and purified 589 protein assemblies. <Capitalized> Bioinformatic analysis of these assemblies defined 232 distinct multiprotein complexes and proposed new cellular roles for 344 proteins, including 231 proteins with no previous functional annotation. <Capitalized> Comparison of yeast and human complexes showed that conservation across species extends from single proteins to their molecular environment. <Capitalized> Our analysis provides an outline of the eukaryotic proteome as a network of protein complexes at a level of organization beyond binary interactions. <Capitalized> This higher-order map contains fundamental biological information and offers the context for a more reasoned and informed approach to drug discovery.

 <Capitalized> Composition and functional characterization of the yeast spliceosomal penta-snRNP. 
 
 <PERSON  Stevens> <AllCaps> SW, <PERSON  Ryan> <AllCaps> DE, <Capitalized> Ge <AllCaps> HY, <PERSON  Moore> <AllCaps> RE, <PERSON  Young> <AllCaps> MK, <PERSON  Lee> <AllCaps> TD, <Capitalized> Abelson <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <LOCATION  California> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Technology, <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Biology 147-75, <LOCATION  Pasadena,> <AllCaps> CA 91125, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Pre-mRNA introns are spliced in a macromolecular machine, the spliceosome. <Capitalized> For each round of splicing, the spliceosome assembles de novo in a series of ATP-dependent steps involving numerous changes in <ContainsHyphen> RNA-RNA and RNA-protein interactions. <Capitalized> As currently understood, spliceosome assembly proceeds by addition of discrete U1, U2, and U4/U6*U5 <MixedCase> snRNPs to a pre-mRNA substrate to form functional splicing complexes. <Capitalized> We characterized a 45S yeast penta-snRNP which contains all five spliceosomal <MixedCase> snRNAs and over 60 pre-mRNA splicing factors. <Capitalized> The particle is functional in extracts and, when supplied with soluble factors, is capable of splicing pre-mRNA. <Capitalized> We propose that the spliceosomal <MixedCase> snRNPs associate prior to binding of a pre-mRNA substrate rather than with pre-mRNA via stepwise addition of discrete snRNPs.

 <Capitalized> Peggie <AllCaps> MW, MacKelvie <AllCaps> SH, <Capitalized> Bloecher <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Knatko <AllCaps> EV, <Capitalized> Tatchell <AllCaps> K, <PERSON  Stark> <AllCaps> MJ.

Temperature-sensitive (Ts(-)) <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae sds22 mutants show profound chromosome instability at elevated growth temperatures but do not confer a cell cycle stage-specific arrest. <Capitalized> In the sds22-6 Ts(-) mutant, nuclear Glc7p is both reduced in level and aberrantly localized at 37 degrees <AllCaps> C and the interaction between Glc7p and Sds22p in vitro is reduced at higher temperatures, consistent with the in vivo Ts(-) growth defect. <PERSON  Like> some glc7 mutations, sds22-6 can suppress the Ts(-) growth defect associated with ipl1-2, a loss of function mutation in a protein kinase that is known to work in opposition to <EndsInDigit> PP1 on at least two nuclear substrates. <Capitalized> This, together with reciprocal genetic interactions between <EndsInDigit> GLC7 and SDS22, suggests that Sds22p functions positively with Glc7p to promote dephosphorylation of nuclear substrates required for faithful transmission of chromosomes during mitosis, and this role is at least partly mediated by effects of Sds22p on the nuclear distribution of Glc7p

 17: <Capitalized> Genome <Capitalized> Inform <Capitalized> Ser <Capitalized> Workshop <Capitalized> Genome <Capitalized> Inform 2001;12:123-34 
 
 <Capitalized> The potential use of <AllCaps> SUISEKI as a protein interaction discovery tool. 
 
 <Capitalized> Blaschke <AllCaps> C, <LOCATION  Valencia> <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Design <Capitalized> Group, CNB/CSIC, <Capitalized> Campus <Capitalized> Universidad <Capitalized> Autonoma, 28049 <LOCATION  Madrid,> <PERSON Spain> blaschke@cnb.uam.es 
 
 <Capitalized> Relevant information about protein interactions is stored in textual sources. <Capitalized> This sources are commonly used not only as archives of what is already known but also as information for generating new knowledge, particularly to pose hypothesis about new possible interactions that can be inferred from the existing ones. <Capitalized> This task is the more creative part of scientific work in experimental systems. <Capitalized> We present a large-scale analysis for the prediction of new interactions based on the interaction network for the ones already known and detected automatically in the literature. <Capitalized> During the last few years it has became clear that part of the information about protein interactions could be extracted with automatic tools, even if these tools are still far from perfect and key problems such as detection of protein names are not completely solved. <Capitalized> We have developed a integrated automatic approach, called <AllCaps> SUISEKI (System for <Capitalized> Information <Capitalized> Extraction on Interactions), able to extract protein interactions from collections of <Capitalized> Medline abstracts. <Capitalized> Previous experiments with the system have shown that it is able to extract almost 70% of the interactions present in relatively large text corpus, with an accuracy of approximately 80% (for the best defined interactions) that makes the system usable in real scenarios, both at the level of extraction of protein names and at the level of extracting interaction between them. <Capitalized> With the analysis of the interaction map of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae we show that interactions published in the years 2000/2001 frequently correspond to proteins or genes that were already very close in the interaction network deduced from the literature published before these years and that they are often connected to the same proteins. <Capitalized> That is, discoveries are commonly done among highly connected entities. <Capitalized> Some biologically relevant examples illustrate how interactions described in the year 2000 could have been proposed as reasonable working hypothesis with the information previously available in the automatically extracted network of interactions. 
 
 PMID: 11791231 [PubMed - in process]

(1999) <AllCaps> J. Biol. Chem. 272, 26991-26998]. <Capitalized> In this study we demonstrate that the yeast counterpart of <EndsInDigit> PRA1 interacts with <Capitalized> Rab proteins and with Yip1p, a membrane protein of unknown function that has been reported to interact specifically with the <Capitalized> Rab proteins Ypt1p and Ypt31p. <Capitalized> Yeast Pra1p/Yip3p is a factor capable of biochemical interaction with a panel of different <Capitalized> Rab proteins and does not show in vitro specificity for any particular Rab. <Capitalized> The interactions between Pra1p/Yip3p and <Capitalized> Rab proteins are dependent on the presence of the <Capitalized> Rab protein C-terminal cysteines and require C-terminal prenylation.

 <Capitalized> We have discovered a novel cortical patch structure in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae defined by a family of integral plasma membrane proteins, including Sur7p, Ynl194p, and Ydl222p. Sur7p-family patches localized as cortical patches that were immobile and stable. <Capitalized> These patches were polarized to regions of the cell with a mature cell wall; they were absent from small buds and the tips of many medium-sized buds. <Capitalized> These patches were distinct from other known cortical structures. <Capitalized> Digestion of the cell wall caused Sur7p patches to disassemble, indicating that Sur7p requires cell wall-dependent extracellular interactions for its localization as patches. sur7Delta, ydl222Delta, and ynl194Delta mutants had reduced sporulation efficiencies. <EndsInDigit> SUR7 was originally described as a multicopy suppressor of rvs167, whose product is an actin patch component. <Capitalized> This suppression is probably mediated by sphingolipids, since deletion of SUR7, YDL222, and <EndsInDigit> YNL194 altered the sphingolipid content of the yeast plasma membrane, and other <AllCaps> SUR genes suppress rvs167 via effects on sphingolipid synthesis. <Capitalized> In particular, the sphingoid base length and number of hydroxyl groups in inositol phosphorylceramides were altered in sur7Delta, ydl222Delta, and yne194Delta strains.

 <PERSON  Davie> <AllCaps> JK, <Capitalized> Trumbly <AllCaps> RJ, <PERSON  Dent> <AllCaps> SY. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <AllCaps> M. <AllCaps> D. <PERSON  Anderson> <Capitalized> Cancer <PERSON  Center,> <PERSON  Houston,> <LOCATION  Texas> 77030, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The Tup1-Ssn6 complex regulates diverse classes of genes in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and serves as a model for corepressor functions in many organisms. Tup1-Ssn6 does not directly bind <AllCaps> DNA but is brought to target genes through interactions with sequence-specific <AllCaps> DNA binding factors. <Capitalized> Full repression by Tup1-Ssn6 appears to require interactions with both the histone tails and components of the general transcription machinery, although the relative contribution of these two pathways is not clear. <Capitalized> Here, we map Tup1 locations on two classes of Tup1-Ssn6-regulated genes in vivo via chromatin immunoprecipitations. <Capitalized> Distinct profiles of Tup1 are observed on a cell-specific genes and <AllCaps> DNA damage-inducible genes, suggesting that alternate repressive architectures may be created on different classes of repressed genes. <Capitalized> In both cases, decreases in acetylation of histone <EndsInDigit> H3 colocalize with Tup1. <Capitalized> Strikingly, although loss of the Srb10 mediator protein had no effect on Tup1 localization, both histone tail mutations and histone deacetylase mutations crippled the association of Tup1 with target loci. <Capitalized> Together with previous findings that Tup1-Ssn6 physically associates with histone deacetylase activities, these results indicate that the repressor complex alters histone modification states to facilitate interactions with histones and that these interactions are required to maintain a stable repressive state.

 <Capitalized> Domains rich in alternating arginine and serine residues (RS domains) are frequently found in metazoan proteins involved in pre-mRNA splicing. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> RS domains of splicing factors associate with each other and are important for the formation of protein-protein interactions required for both constitutive and regulated splicing. <Capitalized> The prevalence of the <AllCaps> RS domain in splicing factors suggests that it might serve as a useful signature for the identification of new proteins that function in pre-mRNA processing, although it remains to be determined whether <AllCaps> RS domains also participate in other cellular functions. <Capitalized> Using database search and sequence clustering methods, we have identified and categorized <AllCaps> RS domain proteins encoded within the entire genomes of <Capitalized> Homo sapiens, <Capitalized> Drosophila melanogaster, <Capitalized> Caenorhabditis elegans, and <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> This genome-wide survey revealed a surprising complexity of <AllCaps> RS domain proteins in metazoans with functions associated with chromatin structure, transcription by <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II, cell cycle, and cell structure, as well as pre-mRNA processing. <Capitalized> Also identified were <AllCaps> RS domain proteins in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae with functions associated with cell structure, osmotic regulation, and cell cycle progression. <Capitalized> The results thus demonstrate an effective strategy for the genomic mining of <AllCaps> RS domain proteins. <Capitalized> The identification of many new proteins using this strategy has provided a database of factors that are candidates for forming <AllCaps> RS domain-mediated interactions associated with different steps in pre-mRNA processing, in addition to other cellular functions.

 <Capitalized> Gendrel <AllCaps> CG, <Capitalized> Dutreix <AllCaps> M.

 <Capitalized> Sequence divergence reduces the frequency of recombination, a process that is dependent on the activity of the mismatch repair system. <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, repair of mismatches results in gene conversion or restoration, whereas failure to repair mismatches results in postmeiotic segregation (PMS). <Capitalized> By examining the conversion and <AllCaps> PMS in yeast strains deficient in various <AllCaps> MMR genes and heterozygous for large inserts (107 bp) with either a mixed sequence or a 39 (CA/TG) repetitive microsatellite sequence, we demonstrate that: (1) the inhibition of conversion by large inserts depends upon a complex containing both Msh2 and Pms1 proteins; (2) conversion is not inhibited if the single-stranded <AllCaps> DNA loop in the heteroduplex is the microsatellite sequence; and (3) large heteroduplex loops with random sequence or repetitive sequence might be repaired by two complexes, containing either Msh2 or Pms1. <Capitalized> Our results suggest that inhibition of recombination by heterologous inserts and large loop repair are not processed by the same <AllCaps> MMR complexes. <Capitalized> We propose that the inhibition of conversion by large inserts is due to recognition by the Msh2/Pms1 complex of mismatches created by intrastrand interactions in the heteroduplex loop.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Ophthalmology and <Capitalized> Visual <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Illinois> at <LOCATION  Chicago> <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  Chicago,> <LOCATION  Illinois> 60612, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 PURPOSE: <Capitalized> To identify factors that interact in vivo with myocilin, a glaucoma gene product. METHODS: <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid system with myocilin as the bait and a human skeletal muscle <MixedCase> cDNA library as the prey was used to identify potential factors that interact with myocilin. <Capitalized> Interactions were also examined in bovine trabecular meshwork (TM) cells through a mammalian two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> Biochemical coimmunoprecipitation from both human <AllCaps> TM cell lysate and in vitro translated proteins was also used to confirm results obtained from yeast analysis. RESULTS: <Capitalized> Twenty positive clones isolated through yeast two-hybrid screening were deemed potential myocilin partners. <Capitalized> Sequence analysis determined that two of them encoded for myocilin from amino acids 64 to 268. <Capitalized> Myocilin was also found to interact with a component of the myosin motor protein, myosin regulatory light chain (RLC). <Capitalized> The myocilin-myocilin and myocilin-RLC interactions revealed by the yeast system were further confirmed and demonstrated in cultured <AllCaps> TM cells, by means of a mammalian two-hybrid system, and through biochemical coimmunoprecipitation, subcellular fractionation, immunofluorescence, and immunogold double labeling. CONCLUSIONS: <Capitalized> These results indicate that myocilin can form homomultimers in vivo, independent of the olfactomedin-like domain. <PERSON  Further> analysis established that the leucine zipper motif of myocilin may be necessary for the myocilin-RLC interaction. <Capitalized> The interaction of myocilin with <AllCaps> RLC, a component of the myosin motor protein complex, implies a role for myocilin in the actomyosin system, linking in turn this novel protein to functional status of the <AllCaps> TM.

 <Capitalized> Phosphorylation states of Cdc42 and RhoA regulate their interactions with <Capitalized> Rho <AllCaps> GDP dissociation inhibitor and their extraction from biological membranes. 
 
 <PERSON  Forget> <AllCaps> MA, <Capitalized> Desrosiers <AllCaps> RR, <PERSON  Gingras> <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Beliveau> <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Laboratoire de medecine moleculaire, <Capitalized> Hopital Sainte-Justine-Universite du <Capitalized> Quebec a <LOCATION  Montreal,> P.O. <PERSON  Box> 8888, Centre-ville station, <LOCATION  Montreal,> <Capitalized> Quebec, <LOCATION  Canada> H3C 3P8. 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Rho <AllCaps> GDP dissociation inhibitor (RhoGDI) regulates the activation-inactivation cycle of <Capitalized> Rho small GTPases, such as Cdc42 and RhoA, by extracting them from the membrane. <Capitalized> To study the roles of Mg(2+), phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP(2)), ionic strength and phosphorylation on the interactions of RhoGDI with Cdc42 and RhoA, we developed a new, efficient and reliable method to produce prenylated <Capitalized> Rho proteins using the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> It has been previously reported that protein kinase <AllCaps> A (PKA)-treatment of isolated membranes increased RhoA extraction from membranes by RhoGDI [Lang, <Capitalized> Gesbert, Delespine-Carmagnat, <Capitalized> Stancou, <Capitalized> Pouchelet and <Capitalized> Bertoglio (1996) <AllCaps> EMBO <AllCaps> J. 16, 510-519]. <Capitalized> In the present study, we used an in vitro affinity chromatography system to show that phosphorylation of RhoA and Cdc42 significantly increased their interaction with RhoGDI under physiological conditions of ionic strength. <Capitalized> This increase was independent of the nucleotide (GDP or guanosine 5'-[gamma-thio]triphosphate) loaded on to the <Capitalized> Rho proteins, as well as of Mg(2+) and PIP(2). <Capitalized> Moreover, dephosphorylation of rat brain membranes by alkaline phosphatase significantly decreased the extraction of RhoA and Cdc42 by RhoGDI. <Capitalized> Subsequent re-phosphorylation by <AllCaps> PKA restored the extraction levels, indicating the reversibility of this process. <Capitalized> These results clearly demonstrate that the phosphorylation states of Cdc42 and RhoA regulate their interactions with RhoGDI and, consequently, their extraction from rat brain membranes. <Capitalized> We therefore suggest that phosphorylation is a mechanism of regulation of Cdc42 and RhoA activity that is independent of <ContainsHyphen> GDP-GTP cycling.

 <Capitalized> Active site mutations in <AllCaps> DNA topoisomerase <AllCaps> I distinguish the cytotoxic activities of camptothecin and the indolocarbazole, rebeccamycin. 
 
 <Capitalized> Woo <AllCaps> MH, <PERSON  Vance> <AllCaps> JR, <Capitalized> Marcos <AllCaps> AR, <PERSON  Bailly> <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Bjornsti <AllCaps> MA.

 <AllCaps> DNA topoisomerase <AllCaps> I (Top1p) catalyzes topological changes in <AllCaps> DNA and is the cellular target of the antitumor agent camptothecin (CPT). Non-CPT drugs that target Top1p, such as indolocarbazoles, are under clinical development. <Capitalized> However, whether the cytotoxicity of indolocarbazoles derives from Top1p poisoning remains unclear. <Capitalized> To further investigate indolocarbazole mechanism, rebeccamycin R-3 activity was examined in vitro and in yeast. <Capitalized> Using a series of Top1p mutants, where substitution of residues around the active site tyrosine has well-defined effects on enzyme catalysis, we show that catalytically active, CPT-resistant enzymes remain sensitive to R-3. <Capitalized> This indolocarbazole did not inhibit yeast Top1p activity, yet was effective in stabilizing Top1p-DNA complexes. <Capitalized> Similar results were obtained with human Top1p, when <Capitalized> Ser or <Capitalized> His were substituted for Asn-722. <Capitalized> The mutations altered enzyme function and sensitivity to <AllCaps> CPT, yet R-3 poisoning of Top1p was unaffected. <Capitalized> Moreover, top1delta, rad52delta yeast cells expressing human Top1p, but not catalytically inactive Top1Y723Fp, were sensitive to R-3. <Capitalized> These data support hTop1p as the cellular target of R-3 and indicate that distinct drug-enzyme interactions at the active site are required for efficient poisoning by R-3 or <AllCaps> CPT. <Capitalized> Furthermore, resistance to one poison may potentiate cell sensitivity to structurally distinct compounds that also target Top1p.

 <Capitalized> Identification of yeast cofilin residues specific for actin monomer and <EndsInDigit> PIP2 binding. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ojala <AllCaps> PJ, <Capitalized> Paavilainen <PERSON  V,> <Capitalized> Lappalainen <PERSON  P.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Program in <Capitalized> Cellular <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Helsinki,> P.O. <PERSON  Box> 56, 00014 <LOCATION  Helsinki,> <LOCATION Finland> 
 
 Cofilin/ADF is a ubiquitous actin-binding protein that is important for rapid actin dynamics in vivo. <Capitalized> The long alpha-helix (helix 3 in yeast cofilin) forms the most highly conserved region in cofilin/ADF proteins, and residues in the NH2-terminal half of this alpha-helix have been shown to be essential for actin binding in cofilin/ADF. <Capitalized> Recent studies also suggested that the basic residues in the COOH-terminal half of this alpha-helix would play an important role in F-actin binding. <Capitalized> In contrast to these studies, we show here that the charged residues in the COOH-terminal half of helix 3 are not important for actin filament binding in yeast cofilin. <Capitalized> Mutations in these residues, however, result in a small defect in actin monomer interactions. <Capitalized> We also show that yeast cofilin can differentiate between various phosphatidylinositides, and mapped the PI(4,5)P2 binding site by using a collection of cofilin mutants. <Capitalized> The PI(4,5)P2 binding site of yeast cofilin is a large positively charged surface that consists of residues in helix 3 as well as residues in other parts of the cofilin molecule. <Capitalized> This suggests that cofilin/ADF proteins probably interact simultaneously with more than one PI(4,5)P2 molecule. <Capitalized> The PI(4,5)P2-binding site overlaps with areas that are important for F-actin binding, explaining why the actin-related activities of cofilin/ADF are inhibited by PI(4,5)P2. <Capitalized> The biological roles of actin and PI(4,5)P2 interactions of cofilin are discussed in light of phenotypes of specific yeast strains carrying mutations in residues that are important for actin and PI(4,5)P2 binding.

 <Capitalized> Qian <PERSON  X,> <PERSON  Hou> <PERSON  W,> <Capitalized> Zhengang <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Sha <AllCaps> B.

 Heat-shock protein 40 (Hsp40) enables Hsp70 to play critical roles in a number of cellular processes, such as protein folding, assembly, degradation and translocation in vivo. Hsp40 recognizes and binds non-native polypeptides and delivers them to Hsp70. <Capitalized> Then Hsp40 stimulates the ATPase activity of Hsp70 to fold the polypeptides. <Capitalized> By using yeast Hsp40 Sis1 and yeast Hsp70 Ssa1 as our model proteins, we found that the Sis1 peptide-binding fragment interacts directly with the full-length Ssa1 in vitro. <PERSON  Further> studies showed that the C-terminal lid domain of Ssa1 could interact with Sis1 peptide-binding domain physically in vitro. <Capitalized> The Sis1 peptide-binding fragment forms a stable complex with the Ssa1 C-terminal lid domain in solution. <Capitalized> The interactions between these two proteins appear to be charge-charge interactions because high-ionic-strength buffer can dissociate the complex. <PERSON  Further> mapping studies showed that the Sis1 peptide-binding fragment binds the extreme C-terminal 15 amino acid residues of Ssa1. <AllCaps> A flexible glycine-rich region is followed by these 15 residues in the Ssa1 primary sequence. <Capitalized> Atomic force microscopy of the Sis1-Ssa1 complex showed that only one end of the Ssa1 lid domain binds the Sis1 peptide-binding-fragment dimer at the upper level of the huge groove within the Sis1 dimer. <Capitalized> Based on the data, we propose an "anchoring and docking" model to illustrate the mechanisms by which Hsp40 interacts with Hsp70 and delivers the non-native polypeptide to Hsp70.

 <Capitalized> Shinyashiki <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Pan> <AllCaps> CJ, <PERSON  Switzer> <AllCaps> CH, <Capitalized> Fukuto <AllCaps> JM.

 <Capitalized> Nitric oxide (NO) has been found to inhibit the copper-responsive yeast transcription factor Ace1 in an oxygen-dependent manner. <Capitalized> However, the mechanism responsible for NO-dependent inhibition of Ace1 remains unestablished. <Capitalized> In the present study, the chemical interaction of nitrogen oxide species with Ace1 was examined using a yeast reporter system. <Capitalized> Exposure of yeast to various nitrogen oxides, under a variety of conditions, revealed that the oxygen-dependent inhibition of Ace1 is due to the reaction of <AllCaps> NO with O(2). <Capitalized> The nitrosating nitrogen oxide species N(2)O(3) is likely to be the disrupter of Ace1 activity. <Capitalized> Considering the similarity of metal-thiolate ligation in Ace1 with other mammalian metalloproteins such as metallothionein, metal chaperones, and zinc-finger proteins, these results help to understand the biochemical interactions of <AllCaps> NO with those mammalian metalloproteins.

 <Capitalized> Beyond synexpression relationships: local clustering of time-shifted and inverted gene expression profiles identifies new, biologically relevant interactions. 
 
 <Capitalized> Qian <AllCaps> J, Dolled-Filhart <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Lin <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Yu> <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Gerstein <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biophysics and <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <PERSON  Yale> <Capitalized> University, 266 <PERSON  Whitney> <Capitalized> Avenue, <AllCaps> PO <PERSON  Box> 208114, <LOCATION  New Haven,> <AllCaps> CT 06520-8114, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The complexity of biological systems provides for a great diversity of relationships between genes. <Capitalized> The current analysis of whole-genome expression data focuses on relationships based on global correlation over a whole time-course, identifying clusters of genes whose expression levels simultaneously rise and fall. <Capitalized> There are, of course, other potential relationships between genes, which are missed by such global clustering. <Capitalized> These include activation, where one expects a time-delay between related expression profiles, and inhibition, where one expects an inverted relationship. <Capitalized> Here, we propose a new method, which we call local clustering, for identifying these time-delayed and inverted relationships. <Capitalized> It is related to conventional gene-expression clustering in a fashion analogous to the way local sequence alignment (the Smith-Waterman algorithm) is derived from global alignment (Needleman-Wunsch). <Capitalized> An integral part of our method is the use of random score distributions to assess the statistical significance of each cluster. <Capitalized> We applied our method to the yeast cell-cycle expression dataset and were able to detect a considerable number of additional biological relationships between genes, beyond those resulting from conventional correlation. <Capitalized> We related these new relationships between genes to their similarity in function (as determined from the <AllCaps> MIPS scheme) or their having known protein-protein interactions (as determined from the large-scale two-hybrid experiment); we found that genes strongly related by local clustering were considerably more likely than random to have a known interaction or a similar cellular role. <Capitalized> This suggests that local clustering may be useful in functional annotation of uncharacterized genes. <Capitalized> We examined many of the new relationships in detail. <Capitalized> Some of them were already well-documented examples of inhibition or activation, which provide corroboration for our results. <Capitalized> For instance, we found an inverted expression profile relationship between genes <EndsInDigit> YME1 and YNT20, where the latter has been experimentally documented as a bypass suppressor of the former. <Capitalized> We also found new relationships involving uncharacterized yeast genes and were able to suggest functions for many of them. <Capitalized> In particular, we found a time-delayed expression relationship between <EndsInDigit> J0544 (which has not yet been functionally characterized) and four genes associated with the mitochondria. <Capitalized> This suggests that <EndsInDigit> J0544 may be involved in the control or activation of mitochondrial genes. <Capitalized> We have also looked at other, less extensive datasets than the yeast cell-cycle and found further interesting relationships. <Capitalized> Our clustering program and a detailed website of clustering results is available at http://www.bioinfo.mbb.yale.edu/expression/cluster (or http://www.genecensus.org/expression/cluster). <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press. 
 
 PMID: 11743722 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <Capitalized> Tong <AllCaps> AH, <PERSON  Evangelista> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Parsons> <AllCaps> AB, <Capitalized> Xu <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Bader> <AllCaps> GD, <PERSON  Page> <AllCaps> N, <PERSON  Robinson> <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Raghibizadeh <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Hogue> <AllCaps> CW, <PERSON  Bussey> <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Andrews> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Tyers <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Boone> <AllCaps> C. 
 
 <Capitalized> Banting and <PERSON  Best> <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Research, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Toronto,> <LOCATION  Toronto> <AllCaps> ON, <LOCATION  Canada> M5G 1L6. 
 
 <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, more than 80% of the approximately 6200 predicted genes are nonessential, implying that the genome is buffered from the phenotypic consequences of genetic perturbation. <Capitalized> To evaluate function, we developed a method for systematic construction of double mutants, termed synthetic genetic array (SGA) analysis, in which a query mutation is crossed to an array of approximately 4700 deletion mutants. <Capitalized> Inviable double-mutant meiotic progeny identify functional relationships between genes. <AllCaps> SGA analysis of genes with roles in cytoskeletal organization (BNI1, ARP2, ARC40, BIM1), <AllCaps> DNA synthesis and repair (SGS1, RAD27), or uncharacterized functions (BBC1, NBP2) generated a network of 291 interactions among 204 genes. <Capitalized> Systematic application of this approach should produce a global map of gene function.

 <Capitalized> The 26S proteasome plays a major role in eukaryotic protein breakdown, especially for ubiquitin-tagged proteins. <Capitalized> Substrate specificity is conferred by the regulatory particle (RP), which can dissociate into stable lid and base subcomplexes. <Capitalized> To help define the molecular organization of the <AllCaps> RP, we tested all possible paired interactions among subunits from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae by yeast two-hybrid analysis. <Capitalized> Within the base, a Rpt4/5/3/6 interaction cluster was evident. <Capitalized> Within the lid, a structural cluster formed around Rpn5/11/9/8. <Capitalized> Interactions were detected among synonymous subunits (Csn4/5/7/6) from the evolutionarily related <EndsInDigit> COP9 signalosome (CSN) from <Capitalized> Arabidopsis, implying a similar quaternary arrangement. <Capitalized> No paired interactions were detected between lid, base or core particle subcomplexes, suggesting that stable contacts between them require prior assembly. <Capitalized> Mutational analysis defined the ATPase, coiled-coil, <AllCaps> PCI and <AllCaps> MPN domains as important for <AllCaps> RP assembly. <AllCaps> A single residue in the <MixedCase> vWA domain of Rpn10 is essential for amino acid analog resistance, for degrading a ubiquitin fusion degradation substrate and for stabilizing lid-base association. <Capitalized> Comprehensive subunit interaction maps for the 26S proteasome and <AllCaps> CSN support the ancestral relationship of these two complexes.

 <Capitalized> Targeting an <MixedCase> mRNA for decapping: displacement of translation factors and association of the Lsm1p-7p complex on deadenylated yeast mRNAs. 
 
 <Capitalized> Tharun <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Parker> <PERSON  R.>

 <Capitalized> The major pathway of eukaryotic <MixedCase> mRNA decay involves deadenylation-dependent decapping followed by 5' to 3' exonucleolytic degradation. <Capitalized> By examining interactions among <MixedCase> mRNA decay factors, the mRNA, and key translation factors, we have identified a critical transition in <MixedCase> mRNP organization that leads to decapping and degradation of yeast mRNAs. <Capitalized> This transition occurs after deadenylation and includes loss of Pab1p, eIF4E, and eIF4G from the <MixedCase> mRNA and association of the decapping activator complex, Lsm1p-7p, which enhances the coimmunoprecipitation of a decapping enzyme complex (Dcp1p and Dcp2p) with the mRNA. <Capitalized> These results define an important rearrangement in <MixedCase> mRNP organization and suggest that deadenylation promotes <MixedCase> mRNA decapping by both the loss of Pab1p and the recruitment of the Lsm1p-7p complex.

 36: <Capitalized> Genome <Capitalized> Res 2001 Dec;11(12):1971-3 
 
 <Capitalized> Is there a bias in proteome research? 
 
 <Capitalized> Mrowka <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Patzak <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Herzel <AllCaps> H. 
 
 Johannes-Muller-Institut fur <Capitalized> Physiologie, Humboldt-Universitat zu <LOCATION  Berlin,> <LOCATION  Berlin,> <LOCATION Germany> mrowka@rz.hu-berlin.de 
 
 <Capitalized> Advances in technology have enabled us to take a fresh look at data acquired by traditional single experiments and to compare them with genomewide data. <Capitalized> The differences can be tremendous, as we show here, in the field of proteomics. <Capitalized> We have compared data sets of protein-protein interactions in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae that were detected by an identical underlying technical method, the yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> We found that the individually identified protein-protein interactions are considerably different from those identified by two genomewide scans. <Capitalized> Interacting proteins in the pooled database from single publications are much more closely related to each other with respect to transcription profiles when compared to genomewide data. <Capitalized> This difference may have been introduced by two factors: by a selection process in individual publications and by false positives in the whole-genome scans. <Capitalized> If we assume that the differences are a result of false positives in the whole-genome data, the scans would contain 47%, 44%, and 91% of false positives for the <AllCaps> UETZ, ITO-core, and ITO-full data, respectively. <Capitalized> If, however, the true fraction of false positives is considerably lower than estimated here, the data from hypothesis-driven experiments must have been subjected to a serious selection process. 
 
 PMID: 11731485 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 37: <Capitalized> Microbiol <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Rev 2001 Dec;65(4):570-94, table of contents 
 
 <Capitalized> Transport into and out of the nucleus. 
 
 <Capitalized> Macara <AllCaps> IG. 
 
 <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Signaling, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Virginia,> <Capitalized> Charlottesville, <LOCATION  Virginia> 22908-0577, <LOCATION  USA.> imacara@virginia.edu 
 
 <AllCaps> A defining characteristic of eukaryotic cells is the possession of a nuclear envelope. <Capitalized> Transport of macromolecules between the nuclear and cytoplasmic compartments occurs through nuclear pore complexes that span the double membrane of this envelope. <Capitalized> The molecular basis for transport has been revealed only within the last few years. <Capitalized> The transport mechanism lacks motors and pumps and instead operates by a process of facilitated diffusion of soluble carrier proteins, in which vectoriality is provided by compartment-specific assembly and disassembly of cargo-carrier complexes. <Capitalized> The carriers recognize localization signals on the cargo and can bind to pore proteins. <Capitalized> They also bind a small GTPase, <Capitalized> Ran, whose GTP-bound form is predominantly nuclear. Ran-GTP dissociates import carriers from their cargo and promotes the assembly of export carriers with cargo. <Capitalized> The ongoing discovery of numerous carriers, Ran-independent transport mechanisms, and cofactors highlights the complexity of the nuclear transport process. <Capitalized> Multiple regulatory mechanisms are also being identified that control cargo-carrier interactions. <Capitalized> Circadian rhythms, cell cycle, transcription, <AllCaps> RNA processing, and signal transduction are all regulated at the level of nucleocytoplasmic transport. <Capitalized> This review focuses on recent discoveries in the field, with an emphasis on the carriers and cofactors involved in transport and on possible mechanisms for movement through the nuclear pores. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Academic 
 
 PMID: 11729264 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <Capitalized> Probabilistic prediction of unknown metabolic and signal-transduction networks. 
 
 <PERSON  Gomez> <AllCaps> SM, <Capitalized> Lo <AllCaps> SH, <Capitalized> Rzhetsky <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> Genome <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10032, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Regulatory networks provide control over complex cell behavior in all kingdoms of life. <Capitalized> Here we describe a statistical model, based on representing proteins as collections of domains or motifs, which predicts unknown molecular interactions within these biological networks. <Capitalized> Using known protein-protein interactions of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae as training data, we were able to predict the links within this network with only 7% false-negative and 10% false-positive error rates. <Capitalized> We also use <Capitalized> Markov chain <Capitalized> Monte <PERSON  Carlo> simulation for the prediction of networks with maximum probability under our model. <Capitalized> This model can be applied across species, where interaction data from one (or several) species can be used to infer interactions in another. <Capitalized> In addition, the model is extensible and can be analogously applied to other molecular data (e.g., <AllCaps> DNA sequences).

 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Rho family GTPase Cdc42 is a key regulator of cell polarity and cytoskeletal organization in eukaryotic cells. <Capitalized> In yeast, the role of Cdc42 in polarization of cell growth includes polarization of the actin cytoskeleton, which delivers secretory vesicles to growth sites at the plasma membrane. <Capitalized> We now describe a novel temperature-sensitive mutant, cdc42-6, that reveals a role for Cdc42 in docking and fusion of secretory vesicles that is independent of its role in actin polarization. cdc42-6 mutants can polarize actin and deliver secretory vesicles to the bud, but fail to fuse those vesicles with the plasma membrane. <Capitalized> This defect is manifested only during the early stages of bud formation when growth is most highly polarized, and appears to reflect a requirement for Cdc42 to maintain maximally active exocytic machinery at sites of high vesicle throughput. <Capitalized> Extensive genetic interactions between cdc42-6 and mutations in exocytic components support this hypothesis, and indicate a functional overlap with Rho3, which also regulates both actin organization and exocytosis. <Capitalized> Localization data suggest that the defect in cdc42-6 cells is not at the level of the localization of the exocytic apparatus. <Capitalized> Rather, we suggest that Cdc42 acts as an allosteric regulator of the vesicle docking and fusion apparatus to provide maximal function at sites of polarized growth.

 Site-specific mutations in the myosin binding sites of actin affect structural transitions that control myosin binding. 
 
 <Capitalized> Prochniewicz <AllCaps> E, <PERSON  Thomas> <AllCaps> DD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, and <Capitalized> Biophysics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Minnesota,> <LOCATION  Minneapolis> 55455, <LOCATION  USA.> ewa@ddt.biochem.umn.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> We have examined the effects of actin mutations on myosin binding, detected by cosedimentation, and actin structural dynamics, detected by spectroscopic probes. <Capitalized> Specific mutations were chosen that have been shown to affect the functional interactions of actin and myosin, two mutations (4Ac and E99A/E100A) in the proposed region of weak binding to myosin and one mutation (I341A) in the proposed region of strong binding. <Capitalized> In the absence of nucleotide and salt, <EndsInDigit> S1 bound to both wild-type and mutant actins with high affinity (K(d) < microM), but either <AllCaps> ADP or increased ionic strength decreased this affinity. <Capitalized> This decrease was more pronounced for actins with mutations that inhibit functional interaction with myosin (E99A/E100A and I341A) than for a mutation that enhances the interaction (4Ac). <Capitalized> The mutations E99A/E100A and I341A affected the microsecond time scale dynamics of actin in the absence of myosin, but the 4Ac mutation did not have any effect. <Capitalized> The binding of myosin eliminated these effects of mutations on structural dynamics; i.e., the spectroscopic signals from mutant actins bound to <EndsInDigit> S1 were the same as those from wild-type actin. <Capitalized> These results indicate that mutations in the myosin binding sites affect structural transitions within actin that control strong myosin binding, without affecting the structural dynamics of the strongly bound actomyosin complex.

 <Capitalized> Nuclear <MixedCase> mRNA metabolism relies on the interplay between transcription, processing, and nuclear export. <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II transcripts experience major rearrangements within the nucleus, which include alterations in the structure of the <MixedCase> mRNA precursors as well as the addition and perhaps even removal of proteins prior to transport across the nuclear membrane. <Capitalized> Such mRNP-remodeling steps are thought to require the activity of <AllCaps> RNA helicases/ATPases. <Capitalized> One such protein, the <AllCaps> DECD box RNA-dependent ATPase Sub2p/UAP56, is involved in both early and late steps of spliceosome assembly. <Capitalized> Here, we report a more general function of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Sub2p in <MixedCase> mRNA nuclear export. <Capitalized> We observe a rapid and dramatic nuclear accumulation of poly(A)(+) <AllCaps> RNA in strains carrying mutant alleles of sub2. <Capitalized> Strikingly, an intronless transcript, HSP104, also accumulates in nuclei, suggesting that Sub2p function is not restricted to splicing events. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> HSP104 transcripts are localized in a single nuclear focus that is suggested to be at or near their site of transcription. <Capitalized> Intriguingly, Sub2p shows strong genetic and functional interactions with the <AllCaps> RNA polymerase II-associated DNA/DNA:RNA helicase Rad3p as well as the nuclear <AllCaps> RNA exosome component Rrp6p, which was independently implicated in the retention of <MixedCase> mRNAs at transcription sites. <Capitalized> Taken together, our data suggest that Sub2p functions at an early step in the <MixedCase> mRNA export process.

 <Capitalized> Correlation between transcriptome and interactome mapping data from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ge <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Liu> <PERSON  Z,> <PERSON  Church> <AllCaps> GM, <PERSON  Vidal> <AllCaps> M.

 <Capitalized> Genomic and proteomic approaches can provide hypotheses concerning function for the large number of genes predicted from genome sequences. <Capitalized> Because of the artificial nature of the assays, however, the information from these high-throughput approaches should be considered with caution. <Capitalized> Although it is possible that more meaningful hypotheses could be formulated by integrating the data from various functional genomic and proteomic projects, it has yet to be seen to what extent the data can be correlated and how such integration can be achieved. <Capitalized> We developed a 'transcriptome-interactome correlation mapping' strategy to compare the interactions between proteins encoded by genes that belong to common expression-profiling clusters with those between proteins encoded by genes that belong to different clusters. <Capitalized> Using this strategy with currently available data sets for <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, we provide the first global evidence that genes with similar expression profiles are more likely to encode interacting proteins. <Capitalized> We show how this correlation between transcriptome and interactome data can be used to improve the quality of hypotheses based on the information from both approaches. <Capitalized> The strategy described here may help to integrate other functional genomic and proteomic data, both in yeast and in higher organisms.

 <Capitalized> The yeast actin-regulating kinases Ark1p and Prk1p are signaling proteins localized to cortical actin patches, which may be sites of endocytosis. <Capitalized> Interactions between the endocytic proteins Pan1p and End3p may be regulated by Prk1p-dependent threonine phosphorylation of Pan1p within the consensus sequence [L/I]xxQxTG. <Capitalized> We identified two Prk1p phosphorylation sites within the Pan1p-binding protein Ent1p, a yeast epsin homologue, and demonstrate Prk1p-dependent phosphorylation of both threonines. <Capitalized> Converting both threonines to either glutamate or alanine mimics constitutively phosphorylated or dephosphorylated Ent1p, respectively. <Capitalized> Synthetic growth defects were observed in a pan1-20 ENT1(EE) double mutant, suggesting that Ent1p phosphorylation negatively regulates the formation/activity of a Pan1p-Ent1p complex. <Capitalized> Interestingly, pan1-20 ent2 <Capitalized> Delta but not pan1-20 ent1 <Capitalized> Delta double mutants had improved growth and endocytosis over the pan1-20 mutant. <Capitalized> We found that actin-regulating Ser/Thr kinase (ARK) mutants exhibit endocytic defects and that overexpressing either wild-type or alanine-substituted Ent1p partially suppressed phenotypes associated with loss of <AllCaps> ARK kinases, including growth, endocytosis, and actin localization defects. <Capitalized> Consistent with synthetic growth defects of pan1-20 ENT1(EE) cells, overexpressing glutamate-substituted Ent1p was deleterious to <AllCaps> ARK mutants. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, overexpressing the related Ent2p protein could not suppress <AllCaps> ARK kinase mutant phenotypes. <Capitalized> These results suggest that Ent1p and Ent2p are not completely redundant and may perform opposing functions in endocytosis. <Capitalized> These data support the model that, as for clathrin-dependent recycling of synaptic vesicles, yeast endocytic protein phosphorylation inhibits endocytic functions.

 <Capitalized> Initiation of transcriptional silencing at mating type loci and telomeres in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae requires the recruitment of a Sir2/3/4 (silent information regulator) protein complex to the chromosome, which occurs at least in part through its association with the silencer- and telomere-binding protein Rap1p. JAC1, an ortholog of hscB, and SSQ1, a paralog of hscA, have been shown to be required for iron-sulfur cluster assembly in mitochondria of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Combining data on the co-occurrence of genes in genomes with experimental and predicted cellular localization data of their proteins supports the hypothesis that frataxin is directly involved in iron-sulfur cluster protein assembly. <Capitalized> They indicate that frataxin is specifically involved in the same sub-process as HSP20/Jac1p.
