 <Capitalized> Yeast pyruvate kinase (YPK) is regulated by intermediates of the glycolytic pathway [e.g., phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP), fructose 1,6-bisphosphate (FBP), and citrate] and by the <AllCaps> ATP charge of the cell. <Capitalized> Recent kinetic and thermodynamic data with Mn(2+)-activated <AllCaps> YPK show that Mn(2+) mediates the allosteric communication between the substrate, <AllCaps> PEP, and the allosteric effector, <AllCaps> FBP [Mesecar, A., and <Capitalized> Nowak, <PERSON  T.> (1997) <Capitalized> Biochemistry 36, 6792, 6803]. <Capitalized> These results indicate that divalent cations modulate multiligand interactions, and hence cooperativity with <AllCaps> YPK. <Capitalized> The nature of multiligand interactions on <AllCaps> YPK was investigated in the presence of the physiological divalent activator Mg(2+). <Capitalized> The binding interactions of <AllCaps> PEP, Mg(2+), and <AllCaps> FBP were monitored by fluorescence spectroscopy. <Capitalized> The binding data were subject to thermodynamic linked-function analysis to determine the magnitudes of the multiligand interactions governing the allosteric activation of <AllCaps> YPK. <Capitalized> The two ligand coupling free energies between <AllCaps> PEP and Mg(2+), <AllCaps> PEP and <AllCaps> FBP, and <AllCaps> FBP and Mg(2+) are 0.88, -0.38, and -0.75 kcal/mol, respectively. <Capitalized> The two-ligand coupling free energies between <AllCaps> PEP and Mn(2+) and <AllCaps> FBP and Mn(2+) are more negative than those with Mg(2+) as the cation. <Capitalized> This indicates that the interactions between the divalent cation and <AllCaps> PEP with <AllCaps> YPK are different for Mg(2+) and Mn(2+) and that the interaction is not simply electrostatic in nature, as originally hypothesized. <Capitalized> The magnitude of the heterotropic interaction between the metal and <AllCaps> FBP is similar with Mg(2+) and Mn(2+). <Capitalized> The simultaneous binding of Mg(2+), <AllCaps> PEP, and <AllCaps> FBP to <AllCaps> YPK is favored by 3.21 kcal/mol compared to independent binding. <Capitalized> This complex is destabilized by 3.30 kcal/mol relative to the analogous YPK-Mn(2+)-PEP-FDP complex. <Capitalized> Interpretation of K(d) values when cooperative binding occurs must be done with care as these are not simple thermodynamic constants. <Capitalized> These data demonstrate that the divalent metal, which activates phosphoryl transfer in <AllCaps> YPK, plays a key role in modulating the various multiligand interactions that define the overall allosteric properties of the enzyme.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular, <Capitalized> Cell and <Capitalized> Developmental <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  Santa Cruz,> 95064, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Genetic and biochemical studies have identified many factors thought to be important for transcription elongation. <Capitalized> We investigated relationships between three classes of these factors: (1) transcription elongation factors Spt4-Spt5, <AllCaps> TFIIS, and Spt16; (2) the C-terminal heptapeptide repeat domain (CTD) of <AllCaps> RNA polymerase II; and (3) protein kinases that phosphorylate the <AllCaps> CTD and a phosphatase that dephosphorylates it. <Capitalized> We observe that spt4 and spt5 mutations cause strong synthetic phenotypes in combination with mutations that shorten or alter the composition of the CTD; affect the Kin28, Bur1, or Ctk1 <AllCaps> CTD kinases; and affect the <AllCaps> CTD phosphatase Fcp1. <Capitalized> We show that Spt5 co-immunoprecipitates with <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II that has either a hyper- or a hypophosphorylated <AllCaps> CTD. <Capitalized> Furthermore, mutation of the <AllCaps> CTD or of <AllCaps> CTD modifying enzymes does not affect the ability of Spt5 to bind <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II. <Capitalized> We find a similar set of genetic interactions between the <AllCaps> CTD, <AllCaps> CTD modifying enzymes, and <AllCaps> TFIIS. <Capitalized> In contrast, an spt16 mutation did not show these interactions. <Capitalized> These results suggest that the <AllCaps> CTD plays a key role in modulating elongation in vivo and that at least a subset of elongation factors are dependent upon the <AllCaps> CTD for their normal function.

 65: <Capitalized> Biochemistry 2001 <Capitalized> Oct 23;40(42):12704-11 
 
 MDP-1 is a new and distinct member of the haloacid dehalogenase family of aspartate-dependent phosphohydrolases. 
 
 <Capitalized> Selengut <AllCaps> JD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> National <PERSON  Heart,> <PERSON  Lung> and <PERSON  Blood> <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> Building 50-2347, <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> Institutes of <Capitalized> Health, 50 <PERSON  South> <Capitalized> Drive, <Capitalized> Bethesda, <Capitalized> Maryland 20892-8012, <LOCATION  USA.> selengut@nih.gov 
 
 MDP-1 is a eukaryotic magnesium-dependent acid phosphatase with little sequence homology to previously characterized phosphatases. <Capitalized> The presence of a conserved motif (Asp-X-Asp-X-Thr) in the <AllCaps> N terminus of MDP-1 suggested a relationship to the haloacid dehalogenase (HAD) superfamily, which contains a number of magnesium-dependent acid phosphatases. <Capitalized> These phosphatases utilize an aspartate nucleophile and contain a number of conserved active-site residues and hydrophobic patches, which can be plausibly aligned with conserved residues in MDP-1. <Capitalized> Seven site-specific point mutants of MDP-1 were produced by modifying the catalytic aspartate, serine, and lysine residues to asparagine or glutamate, alanine, and arginine, respectively. <Capitalized> The activity of these mutants confirms the assignment of MDP-1 as a member of the <AllCaps> HAD superfamily. <Capitalized> Detailed comparison of the sequence of the 15 MDP-1 sequences from various organisms with other <AllCaps> HAD superfamily sequences suggests that MDP-1 is not closely related to any particular member of the superfamily. <Capitalized> The crystal structures of several <AllCaps> HAD family enzymes identify a domain proximal to the active site responsible for important interactions with low molecular weight substrates. <Capitalized> The absence of this domain or any other that might perform the same function in MDP-1 suggests an "open" active site capable of interactions with large substrates such as proteins. <Capitalized> This suggestion was experimentally confirmed by demonstration that MDP-1 is competent to catalyze the dephosphorylation of tyrosine-phosphorylated proteins.

 66: <AllCaps> EMBO <AllCaps> J 2001 <Capitalized> Oct 15;20(20):5626-35

 <Capitalized> The import of proteins into the mitochondrial intermembrane space differs in various aspects from the classical import pathway into the matrix. <Capitalized> Apocytochrome c defines one of several pathways known to reach the intermembrane space, yet the components and pathways involved in outer membrane translocation are poorly defined. <Capitalized> Here, we report the reconstitution of the apocytochrome c import reaction using proteoliposomes harbouring purified components. <Capitalized> Import specifically requires the protease-resistant part of the <AllCaps> TOM complex and is driven by interactions of the apoprotein with internal parts of the complex (involving Tom40) and the 'trans-side receptor' cytochrome c haem lyase. <Capitalized> Despite the necessity of <AllCaps> TOM complex function, the translocation pathway of apocytochrome c does not overlap with that of presequence-containing preproteins. <Capitalized> We conclude that the <AllCaps> TOM complex is a universal preprotein translocase that mediates membrane passage of apocytochrome c and other preproteins along distinct pathways. <Capitalized> Apocytochrome c may provide a paradigm for the import of other small proteins into the intermembrane space such as factors used in apoptosis and protection from stress.

 <AllCaps> A two-hybrid screen against an activation domain array of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae proteins was carried out for 31 yeast proteasome proteins. Fifty-five putative interactions were identified: 21 between components of the proteasome complex and 34 between proteasome proteins and other proteins. <Capitalized> Many of these latter interactions involved either proteins of the ubiquitin pathway, cell cycle proteins, protein kinases or a translation initiation factor subunit. <Capitalized> The role of eleven proteins associated with proteasome function by these screens was analyzed by examining the corresponding deletion strains for temperature sensitivity and canavanine sensitivity and for the stability of a ubiquitin-beta-galactosidase fusion protein. <Capitalized> These assays additionally implicated three proteins, Bim1, Ump1, and YKL171W, in proteasome function. <Capitalized> This study demonstrates the utility of genome-wide two-hybrid assays as an entry point for the further analysis of a large protein complex.

 68: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2001 <Capitalized> Dec 14;276(50):46745-50

 <Capitalized> Polarized delivery and incorporation of proteins and lipids to specific domains of the plasma membrane is fundamental to a wide range of biological processes such as neuronal synaptogenesis and epithelial cell polarization. <Capitalized> The exocyst complex is specifically localized to sites of active exocytosis and plays essential roles in secretory vesicle targeting and docking at the plasma membrane. Sec3p, a component of the exocyst, is thought to be a spatial landmark for polarized exocytosis. <Capitalized> In a search for proteins that regulate the localization of the exocyst in the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, we found that certain cdc42 mutants affect the polarized localization of the exocyst proteins. <Capitalized> In addition, we found that these mutant cells have a randomized protein secretion pattern on the cell surface. <Capitalized> Biochemical experiments indicated that Sec3p directly interacts with Cdc42 in its GTP-bound form. <Capitalized> Genetic studies demonstrated synthetically lethal interactions between cdc42 and several exocyst mutants. <Capitalized> These results have revealed a role for Cdc42 in exocytosis. <Capitalized> We propose that Cdc42 coordinates the vesicle docking machinery and the actin cytoskeleton for polarized secretion.

 BACKGROUND: Ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes (E2s) are central enzymes involved in ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation. <Capitalized> During this process, ubiquitin (Ub) and the <EndsInDigit> E2 protein form an unstable E2-Ub thiolester intermediate prior to the transfer of ubiquitin to an E3-ligase protein and the labeling of a substrate for degradation. <AllCaps> A series of complex interactions occur among the target substrate, ubiquitin, E2, and <EndsInDigit> E3 in order to efficiently facilitate the transfer of the ubiquitin molecule. <Capitalized> However, due to the inherent instability of the E2-Ub thiolester, the structural details of this complex intermediate are not known. RESULTS: <AllCaps> A three-dimensional model of the E2-Ub thiolester intermediate has been determined for the catalytic domain of the <EndsInDigit> E2 protein Ubc1 (Ubc1(Delta450)) and ubiquitin from <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The interface of the E2-Ub intermediate was determined by kinetically monitoring thiolester formation by 1H-(15)N <AllCaps> HSQC spectra by using combinations of 15N-labeled and unlabeled Ubc1(Delta450) and <Capitalized> Ub proteins. <Capitalized> By using the surface interface as a guide and the X-ray structures of <Capitalized> Ub and the 1.9 <AllCaps> A structure of Ubc1(Delta450) determined here, docking simulations followed by energy minimization were used to produce the first model of a E2-Ub thiolester intermediate. CONCLUSIONS: <Capitalized> Complementary surfaces were found on the <EndsInDigit> E2 and <Capitalized> Ub proteins whereby the <AllCaps> C terminus of <Capitalized> Ub wraps around the <EndsInDigit> E2 protein terminating in the thiolester between <EndsInDigit> C88 (Ubc1(Delta450)) and <EndsInDigit> G76 (Ub). <Capitalized> The model supports in vivo and in vitro experiments of <EndsInDigit> E2 derivatives carrying surface residue substitutions. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the model provides insights into the arrangement of <Capitalized> Ub, E2, and <EndsInDigit> E3 within a ternary targeting complex.

 75: <Capitalized> Genome <Capitalized> Biol 2001;2(9):RESEARCH0039

 <Capitalized> Agencourt <Capitalized> Bioscience <Capitalized> Corporation, 100 <PERSON  Cummings> <PERSON  Center,> <PERSON  Suite> 107J, <PERSON  Beverly,> <AllCaps> MA 01915, <LOCATION  USA.> jamalek@agencourt.com 
 
 BACKGROUND: <Capitalized> Conserved domains in proteins have crucial roles in protein interactions, <AllCaps> DNA binding, enzyme activity and other important cellular processes. <Capitalized> It will be of interest to determine the proportions of genes containing such domains in the proteomes of different eukaryotes. RESULTS: <Capitalized> The average proportion of conserved domains in each of five eukaryote genomes was calculated. <Capitalized> In pairwise genome comparisons, the ratio of genes containing a given conserved domain in the two genomes on average reflected the ratio of the predicted total gene numbers of the two genomes. <Capitalized> These ratios have been verified using a repository of databases and one of its subdivisions of conserved domains. CONCLUSIONS: <Capitalized> Many conserved domains occur as a constant proportion of proteome size across the five sequenced eukaryotic genomes. <Capitalized> This raises the possibility that this proportion is maintained because of functional constraints on interacting domains. <Capitalized> The universality of the ratio in the five eukaryotic genomes attests to its potential importance.

 <Capitalized> The 2.6 <AllCaps> A resolution crystal structure of an inactive complex between yeast tRNA(Asp) and <Capitalized> Escherichia coli aspartyl-tRNA synthetase reveals the molecular details of a tRNA-induced mechanism that controls the specificity of the reaction. <Capitalized> The dimer is asymmetric, with only one of the two bound <MixedCase> tRNAs entering the active site cleft of its subunit. <Capitalized> However, the flipping loop, which controls the proper positioning of the amino acid substrate, acts as a lid and prevents the correct positioning of the terminal adenosine. <Capitalized> The structure suggests that the acceptor stem regulates the loop movement through sugar phosphate backbone- protein interactions. <Capitalized> Solution and cellular studies on mutant <MixedCase> tRNAs confirm the crucial role of the <MixedCase> tRNA three-dimensional structure versus a specific recognition of bases in the control mechanism.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Colorado> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University, <PERSON  Fort> <PERSON  Collins,> <AllCaps> CO 80523-1870, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Chromatin is composed of nucleosomes, the universally repeating protein-DNA complex in eukaryotic cells. <Capitalized> The crystal structure of the nucleosome core particle from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae reveals that the structure and function of this fundamental complex is conserved between single-cell organisms and metazoans. <Capitalized> Our results show that yeast nucleosomes are likely to be subtly destabilized as compared with nucleosomes from higher eukaryotes, consistent with the idea that much of the yeast genome remains constitutively open during much of its life cycle. <Capitalized> Importantly, minor sequence variations lead to dramatic changes in the way in which nucleosomes pack against each other within the crystal lattice. <Capitalized> This has important implications for our understanding of the formation of higher order chromatin structure and its modulation by post-translational modifications. <Capitalized> Finally, the yeast nucleosome core particle provides a structural context by which to interpret genetic data obtained from yeast. <Capitalized> Coordinates have been deposited with the <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Data <PERSON  Bank> under accession number 1ID3. 
 
 PMID: 11566884 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <EndsInDigit> GCN5 is a histone acetyltransferase (HAT) originally identified in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and required for transcription of specific genes within chromatin as part of the <AllCaps> SAGA (SPT-ADA-GCN5 acetylase) coactivator complex. <Capitalized> Mammalian cells have two distinct <EndsInDigit> GCN5 homologs (PCAF and GCN5L) that have been found in three different SAGA-like complexes (PCAF complex, <AllCaps> TFTC [TATA-binding-protein-free TAF(II)-containing complex], and <AllCaps> STAGA [SPT3-TAF(II)31-GCN5L acetylase]). <Capitalized> The composition and roles of these mammalian <AllCaps> HAT complexes are still poorly characterized. <Capitalized> Here, we present the purification and characterization of the human <AllCaps> STAGA complex. <Capitalized> We show that <AllCaps> STAGA contains homologs of most yeast <AllCaps> SAGA components, including two novel human proteins with histone-like folds and sequence relationships to yeast <EndsInDigit> SPT7 and ADA1. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we demonstrate that <AllCaps> STAGA has acetyl coenzyme A-dependent transcriptional coactivator functions from a chromatin-assembled template in vitro and associates in HeLa cells with spliceosome-associated protein 130 (SAP130) and DDB1, two structurally related proteins. <EndsInDigit> SAP130 is a component of the splicing factor SF3b that associates with <EndsInDigit> U2 <MixedCase> snRNP and is recruited to prespliceosomal complexes. <EndsInDigit> DDB1 (p127) is a UV-damaged-DNA-binding protein that is involved, as part of a complex with <EndsInDigit> DDB2 (p48), in nucleotide excision repair and the hereditary disease xeroderma pigmentosum. <Capitalized> Our results thus suggest cellular roles of <AllCaps> STAGA in chromatin modification, transcription, and transcription-coupled processes through direct physical interactions with sequence-specific transcription activators and with components of the splicing and <AllCaps> DNA repair machineries.

 <Capitalized> Mechanisms controlling differential promoter-occupancy by the yeast forkhead proteins Fkh1p and Fkh2p: implications for regulating the cell cycle and differentiation. 
 
 <Capitalized> Hollenhorst <AllCaps> PC, <Capitalized> Pietz <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Fox> <AllCaps> CA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biomolecular <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Wisconsin,> <PERSON  Madison,> <LOCATION  Wisconsin> 53706, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The roles of <AllCaps> DNA and Mcm1p interactions in determining the overlapping and distinct functions of the yeast cell cycle regulatory transcription factors Fkh1p and Fkh2p were examined. Full-length recombinant Fkh1p and Fkh2p were purified and their binding to bona fide promoters examined in vitro. <Capitalized> Each protein bound a variety of target promoters with similar specificity in vitro, consistent with the observation that these proteins bind common promoters in vivo. <Capitalized> However, in vivo, the Fkh1p and Fkh2p occupied different target promoters to different extents, suggesting that each was primarily responsible for controlling a different set of genes. <Capitalized> Additional in vitro studies provided a mechanistic explanation for this differential promoter-occupancy. <Capitalized> Specifically, the Fkh2p, but not the Fkh1p, was capable of binding cooperatively with Mcm1p. <Capitalized> The Mcm1p-Fkh2p cooperative binding was enhanced by, but did not require, the presence of a Mcm1p-binding site within a target promoter. <Capitalized> Consistent with these data, Mcm1p was present at Fkh-controlled promoters in vivo regardless of whether they contained Mcm1p-binding sites, suggesting a role for Mcm1p at promoters not thought previously to be under Mcm1p control. <Capitalized> Analysis of Fkh1p and Fkh2p binding to promoter targets in vivo by use of mutant strains indicated that the two proteins compete for promoter-occupancy at a number of target promoters. <Capitalized> We postulate that Fkh1p and a stable Fkh2p/Mcm1p complex compete for binding to target promoters and that the levels and/or binding activity of Fkh1p, but not Fkh2p, are most limiting for promoter-occupancy in vivo. <Capitalized> Interestingly, the in vitro DNA-binding assays, using a variety of promoter targets, revealed that bona fide <Capitalized> Fkh target promoters contained two or more Fkh-binding sites that allowed the Fkh1p and Fkh2p proteins to form multiple protein-DNA complexes in vitro. <Capitalized> Multiple Fkh-binding sites may be a distinguishing feature of bona fide <Capitalized> Fkh promoters in yeast and other organisms.

 Stu2p is a member of a conserved family of microtubule-binding proteins and an essential protein in yeast. <Capitalized> Here, we report the first in vivo analysis of microtubule dynamics in cells lacking a member of this protein family. <Capitalized> For these studies, we have used a conditional Stu2p depletion strain expressing alpha-tubulin fused to green fluorescent protein. <Capitalized> Depletion of Stu2p leads to fewer and less dynamic cytoplasmic microtubules in both <EndsInDigit> G1 and preanaphase cells. <Capitalized> The reduction in cytoplasmic microtubule dynamics is due primarily to decreases in both the catastrophe and rescue frequencies and an increase in the fraction of time microtubules spend pausing. <Capitalized> These changes have significant consequences for the cell because they impede the ability of cytoplasmic microtubules to orient the spindle. <Capitalized> In addition, recovery of fluorescence after photobleaching indicates that kinetochore microtubules are no longer dynamic in the absence of Stu2p. <Capitalized> This deficiency is correlated with a failure to properly align chromosomes at metaphase. <PERSON  Overall,> we provide evidence that Stu2p promotes the dynamics of microtubule plus-ends in vivo and that these dynamics are critical for microtubule interactions with kinetochores and cortical sites in the cytoplasm.

 <Capitalized> Gupta <AllCaps> MK, <PERSON  Geller> <AllCaps> DH, <Capitalized> Auchus <AllCaps> RJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Endocrinology and <Capitalized> Metabolism, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Internal <Capitalized> Medicine, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Southwestern <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <PERSON  Dallas,> <LOCATION  Texas> 75390-8857, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The cytochrome P450c17 enzyme system performs both the 17alpha-hydroxylase and 17,20-lyase reactions in the human adrenal glands and gonads. <Capitalized> This 17,20-lyase activity is required for the biosynthesis of dehydroepiandrosterone, the C(19) precursor of sex steroids. <Capitalized> Considerable evidence supports the idea that the 17,20-lyase activity of this system is particularly sensitive to alterations in the interactions between P450c17 and its cofactor proteins P450-oxidoreductase and cytochrome b(5). <Capitalized> We have described two patients with the clinical phenotype of isolated 17,20-lyase deficiency in whom single amino acid replacement mutations in the redox partner binding site of P450c17 (R347H and R358Q) selectively ablate 17,20-lyase activity while preserving most 17alpha-hydroxylase activity. <Capitalized> We have shown by computer modeling and detailed biochemical studies that mutations R347H and R358Q impair the interactions of P450c17 with P450-oxidoreductase and cytochrome b(5) (redox partners). <Capitalized> Another mutation reported to cause isolated 17,20-lyase deficiency (F417C) does not map within the redox partner binding site, but might nonetheless alter the interaction of the mutant protein with redox partners. <Capitalized> To study the interaction of the F417C mutation with <EndsInDigit> P450 oxidoreductase and cytochrome b(5), we expressed the <MixedCase> cDNA for this protein in yeast microsomes, a heterologous expression system in which the composition of redox partner proteins can be varied systematically. <Capitalized> Although the full-length protein was expressed in quantities comparable to those of wild-type P450c17 in this system, the F417C mutation did not form a classical <EndsInDigit> P450 difference spectrum and was devoid of both 17alpha-hydroxylase and 17,20-lyase activities. <Capitalized> To ensure that this result was not unique to the yeast expression system, we also expressed wild-type P450c17 and the F417C mutation in COS-7 cells, and we again found that the F417C mutation was expressed, but was not active. <Capitalized> To conclusively demonstrate that a particular mutation in P450c17 causes isolated 17,20-lyase deficiency, accurate enzymatic studies of the mutant protein must reproducibly show activities consistent with the diagnosis. <Capitalized> Mutations R347H and R358Q are the only two such mutations found in humans proven to cause isolated 17,20-lyase deficiency.

 <PERSON  Gast> <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Siemer <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Zirwer <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Damaschun <AllCaps> G.

 <Capitalized> The conformational transitions of bovine beta-lactoglobulin <AllCaps> A and phosphoglycerate kinase from yeast induced by hexafluoroisopropanol (HFIP) and trifluoroethanol (TFE) have been studied by dynamic light scattering and circular dichroism spectroscopy in order to elucidate the potential of fluoroalcohols to bring about structural changes of proteins. <Capitalized> Moreover, pure fluoroalcohol-water mixed solvents were investigated to prove the relation between cluster formation and the effects on proteins. <Capitalized> The results demonstrate that cluster formation is mostly an accompanying phenomenon because important structural changes of the proteins occur well below the critical concentration of fluoroalcohol at which the formation of clusters sets in. <Capitalized> According to our light scattering experiments, the remarkable potential of <AllCaps> HFIP is a consequence of extensive preferential binding. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, preferential binding seems to play a vanishing role in the case of <AllCaps> TFE. <Capitalized> However, the comparable <PERSON  Stokes> radii of both proteins in the highly helical state induced by either <AllCaps> HFIP or <AllCaps> TFE point to a similar degree of solvation in both mixed solvents. <Capitalized> This shows that direct binding or an indirect mechanism must be equally taken into consideration to explain the effects of alcohols on proteins. <Capitalized> The existence of a compact helical intermediate with non-native secondary structure on the transition of beta-lactoglobulin <AllCaps> A from the native to the highly helical state is clearly demonstrated.

 <Capitalized> The E4orf4 protein of human adenovirus induces p53-independent apoptosis, a process that may promote cell death and viral spread. <Capitalized> When expressed alone, E4orf4 kills transformed cells but not normal human cells. <Capitalized> The only clear target of E4orf4 in mammalian cells is the <Capitalized> Balpha (B55) subunit of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A), a member of one of three classes of regulatory <AllCaps> B subunits. <Capitalized> Here we report the effects of E4orf4 in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which encodes two PP2A regulatory <AllCaps> B subunits, <EndsInDigit> CDC55 and RTS1, that share homology with mammalian <AllCaps> B and B' subunits, respectively. E4orf4 expression was found to be toxic in yeast, resulting in the accumulation of cells in G2/M phase that failed to grow upon removal of E4orf4. E4orf4-expressing yeast also displayed an elongated cell morphology similar to cdc55 deletion strains. E4orf4 required <EndsInDigit> CDC55 to elicit its effect, whereas <EndsInDigit> RTS1 was dispensable. <Capitalized> The recruitment of the PP2A holoenzyme by E4orf4 was entirely dependent on Cdc55. <Capitalized> These studies indicate that E4orf4-induced apoptosis in mammalian cells and cell death in yeast require functional interactions with B-type subunits of PP2A. <Capitalized> However, some inhibition of growth by E4orf4 was observed in the cdc55 strain and with an E4orf4 mutant that fails to interact with Cdc55, indicating that E4orf4 may possess a second Cdc55-independent function affecting cell growth.

 <Capitalized> The mechanism underlying the tumour-suppressor activity of the neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) gene product, merlin, is largely undefined but there is evidence that the biological function of the protein might be mediated partly through interactions with the cytoskeleton. <PERSON  Merlin> is expressed predominantly as two isoforms that differ at their C-termini owing to alternative splicing of exon 16. <Capitalized> By expressing merlin isoform <AllCaps> I as bait in a yeast two-hybrid screen, we isolated a clone encoding a region of the cytoskeletal protein beta-fodrin. <Capitalized> Confirmation of the merlin-fodrin interaction was provided by using the mammalian two-hybrid system and binding assays in vitro. <Capitalized> In addition, these assays and co-immunoprecipitation from mammalian cells revealed that the binding site for fodrin is located in the C-terminal half of merlin at a site that is masked in the native protein.  <Capitalized> Zhang <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Dawson> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Finnegan> <AllCaps> DJ.

 Mos1 is a member of the mariner/Tc1 family of transposable elements originally identified in <Capitalized> Drosophila mauritiana. <Capitalized> It has 28 bp terminal inverted repeats and like other elements of this type it transposes by a cut and paste mechanism, inserts at <AllCaps> TA dinucleotides and codes for a transposase. <Capitalized> This is the only protein required for transposition in vitro. <Capitalized> We have investigated the <AllCaps> DNA binding properties of Mos1 transposase and the role of transposase-transposase interactions in transposition. <Capitalized> Purified transposase recognises the terminal inverted repeats of Mos1 due to a DNA-binding domain in the N-terminal 120 amino acids. <Capitalized> This requires a putative helix-turn-helix motif between residues 88 and 108. <Capitalized> Binding is preferentially to the right hand end, which differs at four positions from the repeat at the left end. <Capitalized> Cleavage of Mos1 by transposase is also preferentially at the right hand end. Wild-type transposase monomers interact with each other in a yeast two-hybrid assay and we have used this to isolate mutations resulting in reduced interaction. <Capitalized> These mutations lie along the length of the protein, indicating that transposase-transposase interactions are not due to a single interaction domain. <Capitalized> One such mutation which retains both DNA-binding and catalytic activity has greatly reduced ability to excise Mos1 from plasmid <AllCaps> DNA through coordinate cleavage of the two ends and transposition in vitro is lowered to a level 20-fold below that of the wild-type. <Capitalized> This suggests that transposase-transposase interaction is required to form a synaptic complex necessary for coordinate cleavage at the ends of Mos1 during transposition. <Capitalized> This mutant enzyme allows insertion at dinucleotides other than <AllCaps> TA, including sequences with <AllCaps> GC base pairs. <Capitalized> This is the first example of a mariner/Tc1 transposase with altered target specificity.

 <Capitalized> Grigoriev <AllCaps> A.

 <Capitalized> The relationship between the similarity of expression patterns for a pair of genes and interaction of the proteins they encode is demonstrated both for the simple genome of the bacteriophage <EndsInDigit> T7 and the considerably more complex genome of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Statistical analysis of large-scale gene expression and protein interaction data shows that protein pairs encoded by co-expressed genes interact with each other more frequently than with random proteins. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the mean similarity of expression profiles is significantly higher for respective interacting protein pairs than for random ones. <Capitalized> Such coupled analysis of gene expression and protein interaction data may allow evaluation of the results of large-scale gene expression and protein interaction screens as demonstrated for several publicly available datasets. <Capitalized> The role of this link between expression and interaction in the evolution from monomeric to oligomeric protein structures is also discussed.

 <Capitalized> Sheluho <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Ackerman> <AllCaps> SH.

 Atp11p is a soluble protein of mitochondria that binds unassembled beta subunits of the F(1)-ATPase and prevents them from aggregating in the matrix. <Capitalized> In this report, we show that Atp11p protects the insulin <AllCaps> B chain from aggregating in vitro and therefore acts as a molecular chaperone. <Capitalized> The chaperone action of Atp11p is mediated by hydrophobic interactions. <Capitalized> An accessible hydrophobic surface in Atp11p was identified with the environment-sensitive fluorescent probe 1,1'-bis(4-anilino-5-napththalenesulfonic acid (bis-ANS). <Capitalized> The spectral changes of bis-ANS in the presence of Atp11p indicate that the probe binds to a nonpolar region of the protein. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the dye quenches the fluorescence of Atp11p tryptophan residues in a concentration-dependent manner. <Capitalized> Although up to three molecules of bis-ANS can bind cooperatively to Atp11p, the binding of only one dye molecule is sufficient to virtually eliminate the chaperone activity of the protein.

 <Capitalized> Analysis of suppressor mutation reveals long distance interactions in the bc(1) complex of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <PERSON  Brasseur> <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Di <PERSON  Rago> <AllCaps> JP, <Capitalized> Slonimski <AllCaps> PP, Lemesle-Meunier <AllCaps> D.

 <Capitalized> Four totally conserved glycines are involved in the packing of the two cytochrome b hemes, b(L) and b(H), of the bc(1) complex. <Capitalized> The conserved glycine 131 is involved in the packing of heme b(L) and is separated by only 3 <AllCaps> A from this heme in the bc(1) complex structure. <Capitalized> The cytochrome b respiratory deficient mutant G131S is affected in the assembly of the bc(1) complex. <Capitalized> An intragenic suppressor mutation was obtained at position 260, in the ef loop, where a glycine was replaced by an alanine. <Capitalized> This respiratory competent revertant exhibited a low bc(1) complex activity and was affected in the electron transfer at the Q(P) site. <Capitalized> The k(min) for the substrate DBH(2) was diminished by an order of magnitude and <AllCaps> EPR spectra showed a partially empty Q(P) site. <Capitalized> However, the binding of the Q(P) site inhibitors stigmatellin and myxothiazol remained unchanged in the suppressor strain. <Capitalized> Optical spectroscopy revealed that heme b(L) is red shifted by 0.8 nm and that the E(m) of heme b(L) was slightly increased (+20 mV) in the revertant strain as compared to wild type strain values. <Capitalized> Addition of a methyl group at position 260 is thus sufficient to allow the assembly of the bc(1) complex and the insertion of heme b(L) despite the presence of the serine at position 131. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, reversion at position 260 was located 13 <AllCaps> A away from the original mutation and revealed a long distance interaction in the yeast bc(1) complex.

 107: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2001 <Capitalized> Oct 19;276(42):38394-9 
 
 <Capitalized> Differential utilization of enzyme-substrate interactions for acylation but not deacylation during the catalytic cycle of Kex2 protease. 
 
 <PERSON  Rockwell> <AllCaps> NC, <PERSON  Fuller> <AllCaps> RS. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor,> <LOCATION  Michigan> 48109, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Kex2 protease from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae is the prototype for a family of eukaryotic proprotein processing proteases belonging to the subtilase superfamily of serine proteases. Kex2 can be distinguished from degradative subtilisins on the basis of stringent substrate specificity and distinct pre-steady-state behavior. <Capitalized> To better understand these mechanistic differences, we have examined the effects of substrate residues at P(1) and P(4) on individual steps in the Kex2 catalytic cycle with a systematic series of isosteric peptidyl amide and ester substrates. <Capitalized> The results demonstrate that substrates based on known, physiological cleavage sites exhibit high acylation rates (> or =550 s(-1)) with Kex2. <Capitalized> Substitution of <Capitalized> Lys for the physiologically correct <Capitalized> Arg at P(1) resulted in a > or =200-fold drop in acylation rate with almost no apparent effect on binding or deacylation. <Capitalized> In contrast, substitution of the physiologically incorrect <Capitalized> Ala for <Capitalized> Nle at P(4) resulted in a much smaller defect in acylation and a modest but significant effect on binding with <Capitalized> Lys at P(1). <Capitalized> This substitution also had no effect on deacylation. <Capitalized> These results demonstrate that Kex2 utilizes enzyme-substrate interactions in different ways at different steps in the catalytic cycle, with the S(1)-P(1) contact providing a key specificity determinant at the acylation step.

 <Capitalized> The structures of 5-aminolaevulinic acid dehydratase complexed with two irreversible inhibitors (4-oxosebacic acid and 4,7-dioxosebacic acid) have been solved at high resolution. <PERSON  Both> inhibitors bind by forming a <PERSON  Schiff> base link with <Capitalized> Lys 263 at the active site. <Capitalized> Previous inhibitor binding studies have defined the interactions made by only one of the two substrate moieties (P-side substrate) which bind to the enzyme during catalysis. <Capitalized> The structures reported here provide an improved definition of the interactions made by both of the substrate molecules (A- and P-side substrates). <Capitalized> The most intriguing result is the novel finding that 4,7-dioxosebacic acid forms a second <PERSON  Schiff> base with the enzyme involving <Capitalized> Lys 210. <Capitalized> It has been known for many years that P-side substrate forms a <PERSON  Schiff> base (with <Capitalized> Lys 263) but until now there has been no evidence that binding of A-side substrate involves formation of a <PERSON  Schiff> base with the enzyme. <AllCaps> A catalytic mechanism involving substrate linked to the enzyme through <PERSON  Schiff> bases at both the A- and P-sites is proposed.

 112: <Capitalized> Biometals 2001 Jun;14(2):99-112 
 
 <PERSON  Old> iron, young copper: from <COMPANY  Mars>> to Venus. 
 
 <PERSON  Crichton> <AllCaps> RR, <PERSON  Pierre> <AllCaps> JL. 
 
 <PERSON  Unite> de <Capitalized> Biochimie, <Capitalized> Universite <Capitalized> Catholique de <Capitalized> Louvain, <LOCATION Belgium> Crichton@bioc.ucl.ac.be 
 
 <PERSON  Iron> and copper are metals which play an important role in the living world. <Capitalized> From a brief consideration of their chemistry and biochemistry we conclude that the early chemistry of life used water soluble ferrous iron while copper was in the water-insoluble Cu(I) state as highly insoluble sulphides. <Capitalized> The advent of oxygen was a catastrophic event for most living organisms, and can be considered to be the first general irreversible pollution of the earth. <Capitalized> In contrast to the oxidation of iron and its loss of bioavailability as insoluble Fe(III), the oxidation of insoluble Cu(I) led to soluble Cu(II). <AllCaps> A new iron biochemistry became possible after the advent of oxygen, with the development of chelators of Fe(III), which rendered iron once again accessible, and with the control of the potential toxicity of iron by its storage in a water soluble, non-toxic, bio-available storage protein (ferritin). <Capitalized> Biology also discovered that whereas enzymes involved in anaerobic metabolism were designed to operate in the lower portion of the redox spectrum, the arrival of dioxygen created the need for a new redox active metal which could attain higher redox potentials. <PERSON  Copper,> now bioavailable, was ideally suited to exploit the oxidizing power of dioxygen. <Capitalized> The arrival of copper also coincided with the development of multicellular organisms which had extracellular cross-linked matrices capable of resisting attack by oxygen free radicals. <Capitalized> After the initial 'iron age' subsequent evolution moved, not towards a 'copper age', but rather to an 'iron-copper' age. <Capitalized> In the second part of the review, this symbiosis of iron and copper is examined in yeast. <Capitalized> We then briefly consider iron and copper metabolism in mammals, before looking at iron-copper interactions in mammals, particularly man, and conclude with the reflection that, as in <PERSON  Greek> and <Capitalized> Roman mythology, a better understanding of the potentially positive interactions between <COMPANY  Mars>> (iron) and <Capitalized> Venus (copper) can only be to the advantage of our species. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial

 <Capitalized> Using yeast forward and reverse two-hybrid analysis and biochemical techniques, we present novel and definitive in vivo and in vitro evidence that both the N-terminal domain <AllCaps> I and C-terminal domain <AllCaps> IV of the host-encoded DnaA initiator protein of <Capitalized> Escherichia coli interact physically with plasmid-encoded RepA initiator of pSC101. <Capitalized> The N-terminal, but not the C-terminal, region of RepA interacted with DnaA in vitro. <Capitalized> These protein-protein interactions are critical for two very early steps of replication initiation, namely origin unwinding and helicase loading. <Capitalized> Neither domain <AllCaps> I nor <AllCaps> IV of DnaA could individually collaborate with RepA to promote pSC101 replication. <Capitalized> However, when the two domains are co-expressed within a common cell milieu and allowed to associate non-covalently with each other via a pair of leucine zippers, replication of the plasmid was supported in vivo. <PERSON  Thus,> the result shows that physical tethering, either non-covalent or covalent, of domain <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> IV of DnaA and interaction of both domains with RepA, are critical for replication initiation. <Capitalized> The results also provide the molecular basis for a novel, potential, replication-based bacterial two-hybrid system.

 <Capitalized> Many genes required for cell polarity development in budding yeast have been identified and arranged into a functional hierarchy. <Capitalized> Core elements of the hierarchy are widely conserved, underlying cell polarity development in diverse eukaryotes. <Capitalized> To enumerate more fully the protein-protein interactions that mediate cell polarity development, and to uncover novel mechanisms that coordinate the numerous events involved, we carried out a large-scale two-hybrid experiment. 68 Gal4 <AllCaps> DNA binding domain fusions of yeast proteins associated with the actin cytoskeleton, septins, the secretory apparatus, and Rho-type GTPases were used to screen an array of yeast transformants that express approximately 90% of the predicted <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae open reading frames as Gal4 activation domain fusions. 191 protein-protein interactions were detected, of which 128 had not been described previously. 44 interactions implicated 20 previously uncharacterized proteins in cell polarity development. <PERSON  Further> insights into possible roles of 13 of these proteins were revealed by their multiple two-hybrid interactions and by subcellular localization. <Capitalized> Included in the interaction network were associations of Cdc42 and Rho1 pathways with proteins involved in exocytosis, septin organization, actin assembly, microtubule organization, autophagy, cytokinesis, and cell wall synthesis. <Capitalized> Other interactions suggested direct connections between Rho1- and Cdc42-regulated pathways; the secretory apparatus and regulators of polarity establishment; actin assembly and the morphogenesis checkpoint; and the exocytic and endocytic machinery. <Capitalized> In total, a network of interactions that provide an integrated response of signaling proteins, the cytoskeleton, and organelles to the spatial cues that direct polarity development was revealed.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <AllCaps> UCLA <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  Los Angeles,> <AllCaps> CA 90095-1737, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Heterotetrameric adaptor (AP) complexes are thought to coordinate cargo recruitment and clathrin assembly during clathrin-coated vesicle biogenesis. <Capitalized> We have identified, and characterized the physiological significance of clathrin-binding activities in the two large subunits of the AP-1 complex in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Using GST-fusion chromatography, two clathrin-binding sites were defined in the beta1 subunit that match consensus clathrin-binding sequences in other mammalian and yeast clathrin-binding proteins. <Capitalized> Clathrin interactions were also identified with the C-terminal region of the gamma subunit. <Capitalized> When introduced into chromosomal genes, point mutations in the beta1 clathrin-binding motifs, or deletion of the gamma C-terminal region, reduced association of AP-1 with clathrin in coimmunoprecipitation assays. <Capitalized> The beta1 mutations or the gamma truncation individually produced minor effects on AP-1 distribution by subcellular fractionation. <Capitalized> However, when beta1 and gamma mutations were combined, severe defects were observed in AP-1 association with membranes and incorporation into clathrin-coated vesicles. <Capitalized> The combination of subunit mutations accentuated growth and alpha-factor pheromone maturation defects in chc1-ts cells, though not to the extent caused by complete loss of AP-1 activity. <Capitalized> Our results suggest that both the beta1 and gamma subunits contribute interactions with clathrin that are important for stable assembly of AP-1 complexes into clathrin coats in vivo.

 <Capitalized> The ICA512/IA-2 molecule, a protein with similarity to receptor-type protein tyrosine phosphatases, was discovered during studies to identify autoantigens in <Capitalized> Type 1 diabetes. <Capitalized> The biological function of ICA512/IA-2 is unknown. <Capitalized> We describe striking effects of ICA512/IA-2 on viability and growth of both yeast cells and cultured mammalian cells. <Capitalized> In transformed yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells, expression of ICA512/IA-2 induced growth retardation as judged by measurements of optical density and counts of colony-forming units. <Capitalized> In contrast, expression of the intracellular domain (amino acids 600-979) of ICA512/IA-2 in yeast or mammalian cells had no such effects. <Capitalized> In investigations on apoptosis, expression of ICA512/IA-2 in yeast cells caused loss of plasma membrane asymmetry, but not release of cytochrome c from mitochondria which did occur in a control system after expression of the pro-apoptotic molecule <PERSON Bax> <Capitalized> Possible interactions between ICA512/IA-2 and components of the cytoskeleton were not supported by studies on staining of fixed yeast cells with phalloidin-Texas Red. <Capitalized> With transfected mammalian cell lines COS-7 and NIH3T3, expression of ICA512/IA-2 likewise induced growth arrest, with some of the morphological features of apoptosis. <PERSON  Thus> obligatory expression of ICA512/IA-2 in eukaryotic cells causes disruption of cellular activities, with growth arrest in yeast and nuclear pycnosis/fragmentation in mammalian cells. <AllCaps> A possible explanation is that growth inhibition reflects a part of the presently unknown function of ICA512/IA-2. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

<Capitalized> Cadena and <PERSON  Gill> (1996) <Capitalized> Science 272, 1008-1010]. <Capitalized> Searches of human expressed sequence tag databases with <EndsInDigit> SNX1 revealed eleven related  <Capitalized> In vitro homotypic fusion of yeast vacuoles occurs in three stages: priming, the Sec18 (NSF)-mediated changes that precede vacuole association; docking, the Ypt7 and SNARE-mediated pairing of vacuoles; and fusion, mediated by calmodulin/V0/t-SNARE interactions. <Capitalized> Defects in catalysts of each stage result in fragmented (unfused) vacuoles. <Capitalized> Strains with deletions in any of <AllCaps> ERG genes 3-6, lacking normal ergosterol biosynthesis, have fragmented vacuoles. <Capitalized> The ergosterol ligands filipin, nystatin and amphotericin <AllCaps> B block the in vitro fusion of vacuoles from wild-type cells. <Capitalized> Each of these inhibitors acts at the priming stage to inhibit Sec17p release from vacuoles. <AllCaps> A reversible delay in Sec18p action prevents vacuoles from acquiring resistance to any of these three drugs, confirming that their action is on the normal fusion pathway. <Capitalized> Ergosterol or cholesterol delivery to wild-type vacuoles stimulates their in vitro fusion, and the in vitro fusion of <MixedCase> ergDelta vacuoles requires added sterol. <Capitalized> The need for ergosterol for vacuole priming underscores the role of lipids in organizing the membrane elements of this complex reaction.

These results reveal important genetic interactions between <EndsInDigit> PSD1 and <EndsInDigit> MCD4 genes, and provide evidence that Mcd4p can modulate aminoglycerophospholipid metabolism, in a way  <Capitalized> The thermal denaturation of the dimeric enzyme triosephosphate isomerase (TIM) from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae was studied by spectroscopic and calorimetric methods. <Capitalized> At low protein concentration the structural transition proved to be reversible in thermal scannings conducted at a rate greater than 1.0 degrees <AllCaps> C min(-1). <Capitalized> Under these conditions, however, the denaturation-renaturation cycle exhibited marked hysteresis. <Capitalized> The use of lower scanning rates lead to pronounced irreversibility. <Capitalized> Kinetic studies indicated that denaturation of the enzyme likely consists of an initial first-order reaction that forms thermally unfolded (U) <AllCaps> TIM, followed by irreversibility-inducing reactions which are probably linked to aggregation of the unfolded protein. <Capitalized> As judged from <AllCaps> CD measurements, <PERSON  U> possesses residual secondary structure but lacks most of the tertiary interactions present in native <AllCaps> TIM. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the large increment in heat capacity upon denaturation suggests that extensive exposure of surface area occurs when <PERSON  U> is formed. <Capitalized> Above 63 degrees <AllCaps> C, reactions leading to irreversibility were much slower than the unfolding process; as a result, <PERSON  U> was sufficiently long-lived as to allow an investigation of its refolding kinetics. <Capitalized> We found that <PERSON  U> transforms into nativelike <AllCaps> TIM through a second-order reaction in which association is coupled to the regain of secondary structure. <Capitalized> The rate constants for unfolding and refolding of <AllCaps> TIM displayed temperature dependences resembling those reported for monomeric proteins but with considerably larger activation enthalpies. <Capitalized> Such large temperature dependences seem to be determinant for the occurrence of kinetically controlled transitions and thus constitute a simple explanation for the hysteresis observed in thermal scannings.

domain interacts physically with a central region located between the two catalytic domains. <Capitalized> Our results suggest that the N-terminal 45 <MixedCase> kDa domain of Dna2 plays a critical  147: <Capitalized> Bioinformatics 2001 Jul;17(7):608-21 
 
 <Capitalized> Identifying target sites for cooperatively binding factors. 
 
 GuhaThakurta <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Stormo <AllCaps> GD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Genetics, <LOCATION  Washington> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, 4566 <PERSON  Scott> <Capitalized> Avenue, <Capitalized> Campus Box: 8232, <Capitalized> St <PERSON  Louis,> <AllCaps> MO 63110, <LOCATION  USA.> dg@genetics.wustl.edu 
 
 MOTIVATION: <Capitalized> Transcriptional activation in eukaryotic organisms normally requires combinatorial interactions of multiple transcription factors. <Capitalized> Though several methods exist for identification of individual protein binding site patterns in <AllCaps> DNA sequences, there are few methods for discovery of binding site patterns for cooperatively acting factors. <Capitalized> Here we present an algorithm, Co-Bind (for COperative BINDing), for discovering <AllCaps> DNA target sites for cooperatively acting transcription factors. <Capitalized> The method utilizes a <PERSON  Gibbs> sampling strategy to model the cooperativity between two transcription factors and defines position weight matrices for the binding sites. <Capitalized> Sequences from both the training set and the entire genome are taken into account, in order to discriminate against commonly occurring patterns in the genome, and produce patterns which are significant only in the training set. RESULTS: <Capitalized> We have tested Co-Bind on semi-synthetic and real data sets to show it can efficiently identify <AllCaps> DNA target site patterns for cooperatively binding transcription factors. <Capitalized> In cases where binding site patterns are weak and cannot be identified by other available methods, Co-Bind, by virtue of modeling the cooperativity between factors, can identify those sites efficiently. <Capitalized> Though developed to model protein-DNA interactions, the scope of Co-Bind may be extended to combinatorial, sequence specific, interactions in other macromolecules. AVAILABILITY: <Capitalized> The program is available upon request from the authors or may be downloaded from http://ural.wustl.edu.

 <PERSON  Harger> <AllCaps> JW, <Capitalized> Meskauskas <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Nielsen> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Justice> <AllCaps> MC, <Capitalized> Dinman <AllCaps> JD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> Graduate <Capitalized> Program in <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biosciences at UMDNJ/Rutgers <Capitalized> Universities, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Institute of <LOCATION  New Jersey,> <Capitalized> Piscataway, <LOCATION  New Jersey> 08854, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Programmed ribosomal frameshifting is utilized by a number of <AllCaps> RNA viruses to ensure the correct ratio of viral structural to enzymatic proteins for viral particle assembly. <Capitalized> Altering frameshifting efficiencies upsets this ratio, inhibiting virus propagation. <Capitalized> Two yeast viruses that induce host cell ribosomes to shift translational reading frame were used as tools to explore the interactions between viruses and host cellular protein synthetic machinery. <Capitalized> Previous studies showed that the ribosome-inactivating protein pokeweed antiviral protein specifically inhibited propagation of the Ty1 retrotransposable element of yeast as a consequence of inhibition of programmed +1 ribosomal frameshifting. <Capitalized> Here, complementary genetic and pharmacological approaches were employed to test whether inhibition of Ty1 retrotransposition is a general feature of alterations in the translocation step of elongation and +1 frameshifting. <Capitalized> The results demonstrate that cells harboring a variety of mutant alleles of two host-encoded proteins that are involved in translocation, eukaryotic elongation factor-2 and the ribosome-associated protein RPP0, have Ty1 propagation defects. <Capitalized> We also show that sordarin, a fungus-specific inhibitor of eEF-2 function, specifically inhibits programmed +1 ribosomal frameshifting and Ty1 retrotransposition. <Capitalized> These findings serve to link inhibition of Ty1 retrotransposition and +1 frameshifting to changes in the translocation step of elongation. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> The Hsp90 dimer is a molecular chaperone with an unusual N-terminal <AllCaps> ATP binding site. <Capitalized> The structure of the <AllCaps> ATP binding site makes it a member of a new class of ATP-hydrolyzing enzymes, known as the <AllCaps> GHKL family. <Capitalized> While for some of the family members structural data on conformational changes occurring after <AllCaps> ATP binding are available, these are still lacking for Hsp90. <Capitalized> Here we set out to investigate the correlation between dimerization and <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis by Hsp90. <Capitalized> The dimerization constant of wild type (WT) Hsp90 was determined to be 60 nm. <Capitalized> Heterodimers of <AllCaps> WT Hsp90 with fragments lacking the <AllCaps> ATP binding domain form readily and exhibit dimerization constants similar to full-length Hsp90. <Capitalized> However, the ATPase activity of these heterodimers was significantly lower than that of the wild type protein, indicating cooperative interactions in the N-terminal part of the protein that lead to the activation of the ATPase activity. <Capitalized> To further address the contribution of the N-terminal domains to the ATPase activity, we used an Hsp90 point mutant that is unable to bind <AllCaps> ATP. <Capitalized> Since heterodimers between the <AllCaps> WT protein and this mutant showed <AllCaps> WT ATPase activity, this mutant, although unable to bind <AllCaps> ATP, still has the ability to stimulate the activity in its <AllCaps> WT partner domain. <PERSON  Thus,> contact formation between the N-terminal domains might not depend on <AllCaps> ATP bound to both domains. <Capitalized> Together, these results suggest a mechanism for coupling the hydrolysis of <AllCaps> ATP to the opening-closing movement of the Hsp90 molecular chaperone.

dsRNAs to two dsRNA-binding domains (dsRBDs) in <AllCaps> PKR leads to relief of an inhibitory region and activation of eIF2 kinase activity. <Capitalized> Interestingly, while deletion of the regulatory region of <AllCaps> PKR significantly induces activity in vitro, the truncated kinase does not inhibit translation in vivo, suggesting that these sequences carry out additional functions transient protein-protein interactions and that trans-autophosphorylation is the final step in the mechanism of activation of <AllCaps> PKR.

 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae genes RAD5, RAD18, and <EndsInDigit> SRS2 are proposed to act in post-replicational repair of <AllCaps> DNA damage. <Capitalized> We have investigated the genetic interactions between mutations in these genes with respect to cell survival and ectopic gene conversion following treatment of logarithmic and early stationary cells with UV- and gamma-rays. <Capitalized> We find that the genetic interaction between the rad5 and rad18 mutations depends on <AllCaps> DNA damage type and position in the cell cycle at the time of treatment. <Capitalized> Inactivation of <EndsInDigit> SRS2 suppresses damage sensitivity both in rad5 and rad18 mutants, but only when treated in logarithmic phase. <Capitalized> When irradiated in stationary phase, the srs2 mutation enhances the sensitivity of rad5 mutants, whereas it has no effect on rad18 mutants. <Capitalized> Irrespective of the growth phase, the srs2 mutation reduces the frequency of damage-induced ectopic gene conversion in rad5 and rad18 mutants. <Capitalized> In addition, we find that srs2 mutants exhibit reduced spontaneous and UV-induced sister chromatid recombination (SCR), whereas rad5 and rad18 mutants are proficient for <AllCaps> SCR. <Capitalized> We propose a model in which the Srs2 protein has pro-recombinogenic or anti-recombinogenic activity, depending on the context of the <AllCaps> DNA damage.

 <AllCaps> A conserved pseudouridine modification in eukaryotic <EndsInDigit> U2 <MixedCase> snRNA induces a change in branch-site architecture. 
 
 <PERSON  Newby> <AllCaps> MI, <Capitalized> Greenbaum <AllCaps> NL. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biophysics, <LOCATION  Florida> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Tallahassee> 32306-4380, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The removal of noncoding sequences (introns) from eukaryotic precursor <MixedCase> mRNA is catalyzed by the spliceosome, a dynamic assembly involving specific and sequential <ContainsHyphen> RNA-RNA and RNA-protein interactions. <Capitalized> An essential <ContainsHyphen> RNA-RNA pairing between the <EndsInDigit> U2 small nuclear (sn)RNA and a complementary consensus sequence of the intron, called the branch site, results in positioning of the 2'OH of an unpaired intron adenosine residue to initiate nucleophilic attack in the first step of splicing. <Capitalized> To understand the structural features that facilitate recognition and chemical activity of the branch site, duplexes representing the paired <EndsInDigit> U2 <MixedCase> snRNA and intron sequences from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae were examined by solution <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy. <Capitalized> Oligomers were synthesized with pseudouridine (psi) at a conserved site on the <EndsInDigit> U2 <MixedCase> snRNA strand (opposite an <ContainsHyphen> A-A dinucleotide on the intron strand, one of which forms the branch site) and with uridine, the unmodified analog. <Capitalized> Data from <AllCaps> NMR spectra of nonexchangeable protons demonstrated A-form helical backbone geometry and continuous base stacking throughout the unmodified molecule. <Capitalized> Incorporation of psi at the conserved position, however, was accompanied by marked deviation from helical parameters and an extrahelical orientation for the unpaired adenosine. <Capitalized> Incorporation of psi also stabilized the branch-site interaction, contributing -0.7 kcal/mol to duplex <MixedCase> deltaG degrees 37. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that the presence of this conserved <EndsInDigit> U2 <MixedCase> snRNA pseudouridine induces a change in the structure and stability of the branch-site sequence, and imply that the extrahelical orientation of the branch-site adenosine may facilitate recognition of this base during splicing.

 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> C <Capitalized> Vps complex, consisting of Vps11, Vps16, Vps18, and Vps33, is required for SNARE-mediated membrane fusion at the lysosome-like yeast vacuole. <Capitalized> However, <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> C vps mutants display more severe and pleiotropic phenotypes than mutants specifically defective in endosome-to-vacuole transport, suggesting that there are additional functions for the <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> C <Capitalized> Vps complex. <AllCaps> A <AllCaps> SNARE double mutant which is defective for both Golgi-to-endosome and endosome-to-vacuole trafficking replicates many of the phenotypes observed in <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> C vps mutants. <Capitalized> We show that genetic interactions exist between <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> C vps alleles and alleles of the <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> D vps group, which are defective in the docking and fusion of Golgi-derived vesicles at the endosome. <Capitalized> Moreover, the <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> D protein Vac1 was found to physically bind to the <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> C <Capitalized> Vps complex through a direct association with Vps11. <Capitalized> Finally, using a random mutagenic screen, a temperature-conditional allele which shares many of the phenotypes of mutants which are selectively defective in Golgi-to-endosome trafficking was isolated (vps11-3ts). <Capitalized> Collectively, these results indicate that the <Capitalized> Class <AllCaps> C <Capitalized> Vps complex plays essential roles in the processes of membrane docking and fusion at both the Golgi-to-endosome and endosome-to-vacuole stages of transport.

 162: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Evol 2001 Jul;18(7):1283-92 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast protein interaction network evolves rapidly and contains few redundant duplicate genes. 
 
 <PERSON  Wagner> <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  New> <LOCATION  Mexico,> <Capitalized> Albequerque, <PERSON  New> <LOCATION  Mexico> 87131-1091, <LOCATION  USA.> wagnera@unm.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> In this paper, the structure and evolution of the protein interaction network of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae is analyzed. <Capitalized> The network is viewed as a graph whose nodes correspond to proteins. <Capitalized> Two proteins are connected by an edge if they interact. <Capitalized> The network resembles a random graph in that it consists of many small subnets (groups of proteins that interact with each other but do not interact with any other protein) and one large connected subnet comprising more than half of all interacting proteins. <Capitalized> The number of interactions per protein appears to follow a power law distribution. <Capitalized> Within approximately 200 <Capitalized> Myr after a duplication, the products of duplicate genes become almost equally likely to (1) have common protein interaction partners and (2) be part of the same subnetwork as two proteins chosen at random from within the network. <Capitalized> This indicates that the persistence of redundant interaction partners is the exception rather than the rule. <Capitalized> After gene duplication, the likelihood that an interaction gets lost exceeds 2.2 x 10(-3)/Myr. <PERSON  New> interactions are estimated to evolve at a rate that is approximately three orders of magnitude smaller. <PERSON  Every> 300 <Capitalized> Myr, as many as half of all interactions may be replaced by new interactions. 
 
 PMID: 11420367 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <EndsInDigit> GCN5 dependence of chromatin remodeling and transcriptional activation by the <EndsInDigit> GAL4 and <EndsInDigit> VP16 activation domains in budding yeast. 
 
 <PERSON  Stafford> <AllCaps> GA, <PERSON  Morse> <AllCaps> RH. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biomedical <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  New York> at <Capitalized> Albany <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Public <Capitalized> Health, <Capitalized> Albany, <LOCATION  New York> 12201-2002, <LOCATION  USA.>

Mini-GAL4 derivatives having weakened interactions with TATA-binding protein and <AllCaps> TFIIB exhibit a strong dependence on <EndsInDigit> GCN5 for both transcriptional activation and <AllCaps> TALS remodeling not seen for native GAL4. <Capitalized> These results indicate that <EndsInDigit> GCN5 can contribute to chromatin remodeling at activator binding sites and that dependence on coactivator function for a given activator can vary according to the type and strength of contacts that it makes with other factors. <Capitalized> We also found a weaker dependence for chromatin remodeling on <EndsInDigit> SPT7 than on GCN5, indicating that <EndsInDigit> GCN5 can function via pathways independent of the <AllCaps> SAGA complex. <Capitalized> Finally, we examine dependence on <EndsInDigit> GCN5 and <ContainsHyphen> SWI-SNF at two model promoters and find that although these two chromatin-remodeling and/or modification activities may sometimes work together, in other instances they act in complementary fashion.

 <Capitalized> The rat luminal endoplasmic-recticulum calcium-binding proteins 1 and 2 (CaBP1 and CaBP2 respectively) are members of the protein disulphide-isomerase (PDI) family. <Capitalized> They contain two and three thioredoxin boxes (Cys-Gly-His-Cys) respectively and, like <AllCaps> PDI, may be involved in the folding of nascent proteins. <Capitalized> We demonstrate here that CaBP1, similar to <AllCaps> PDI and CaBP2, can complement the lethal phenotype of the disrupted <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> PDI gene, provided that the natural C-terminal Lys-Asp-Glu-Leu sequence is replaced by His-Asp-Glu-Leu. <PERSON  Both> the in vitro RNase AIII-re-activation assays and in vivo pro-(carboxypeptidase Y) processing assays using CaBP1 and CaBP2 thioredoxin (trx)-box mutants revealed that, whereas the three trx boxes in CaBP2 seem to be functionally equivalent, the first trx box of CaBP1 is significantly more active than the second trx box. <Capitalized> Furthermore, only about 65% re-activation of denatured reduced RNase <AllCaps> AIII could be obtained with CaBP1 or CaBP2 compared with <AllCaps> PDI, and the yield of PDI-catalysed reactions was significantly reduced in the presence of either CaBP1 or CaBP2. <Capitalized> In contrast with <AllCaps> PDI, neither CaBP1 nor CaBP2 could catalyse the renaturation of denatured glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), which is a redox-independent process, and neither protein had any effect on the PDI-catalysed refolding of <AllCaps> GAPDH. <Capitalized> Furthermore, although <AllCaps> PDI can bind peptides via its b' domain, a property it shares with PDIp, the pancreas-specific <AllCaps> PDI homologue, and although <AllCaps> PDI can bind malfolded proteins such as 'scrambled' ribonuclease, no such interactions could be detected for CaBP2. <Capitalized> We conclude that: (1) both CaBP2 and CaBP1 lack peptide-binding activity for <AllCaps> GAPDH attributed to the C-terminal region of the a' domain of PDI; (2) CaBP2 lacks the general peptide-binding activity attributed to the b' domain of PDI; (3) interaction of CaBP2 with substrate (RNase AIII) is different from that of <AllCaps> PDI and substrate; and (4) both CaBP2 and CaBP1 may promote oxidative folding by different kinetic pathways.

 <Capitalized> The detection of physical interaction between two or more molecules of interest can be facilitated if the act of association between the interactive partners leads to the production of a readily observed biological or physical readout. <Capitalized> Many interacting molecule pairs (X, Y) can be made to induce such a readout if <PERSON  X> and <PERSON  Y> are each fused to defined protein elements with desired properties. <Capitalized> For example, in the yeast forward two-hybrid system, <PERSON  X> is synthesized as a translational fusion to a DNA-binding domain (DBD), <PERSON  Y> is synthesized as a fusion to a transcriptional activation domain (AD), and coexpression of <ContainsHyphen> DBD-X and <ContainsHyphen> AD-Y induces transcription of easily scored responsive reporters. <Capitalized> Other approaches use paradigms based on the artificial production of two, hybrid, molecules, but substitute a variety of readouts including the repression of transcription, activation of signal transduction pathways, or reconstitution of a disrupted enzymatic activity. <Capitalized> In this article, we summarize a number of two-hybrid-based approaches, and detail the use of the forward yeast two-hybrid system in a screen to identify novel interacting partners for a protein of interest. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> The model eukaryote <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae has two distinct peptide transport mechanisms, one for di-/tripeptides (the <AllCaps> PTR system) and another for tetra-/pentapeptides (the <AllCaps> OPT system). <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> PTR system consists of three genes, PTR1, <EndsInDigit> PTR2 and PTR3. <Capitalized> The transporter (Ptr2p), encoded by the gene PTR2, is a 12 transmembrane domain (TMD) integral membrane protein that translocates di-/tripeptides. <Capitalized> Homologues to Ptr2p have been identified in virtually all organisms examined to date and comprise the <AllCaps> PTR family of transport proteins. <Capitalized> In <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae, the expression of <EndsInDigit> PTR2 is highly regulated at the cellular level by complex interactions of many genes, including PTR1, PTR3, <EndsInDigit> CUP9 and SSY1. <Capitalized> Oligopeptides, consisting of four to five amino acids, are transported by the 12-14 <AllCaps> TMD integral membrane protein Opt1p. <Capitalized> Unlike Ptr2p, distribution of this protein appears limited to fungi and plants, and there appears to be three paralogues in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. <Capitalized> This transporter has an affinity for enkephalin, an endogenous mammalian pentapeptide, as well as for glutathione. <Capitalized> Although it is known that <EndsInDigit> OPT1 is normally expressed only during sporulation, to date little is known about the genes and proteins involved in the regulation of <EndsInDigit> OPT1 expression.

 173: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 2001 Jul;21(13):4233-45 
 
 <PERSON  New> function of <EndsInDigit> CDC13 in positive telomere length regulation. 
 
 <PERSON  Meier> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Driller <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Jaklin <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Feldmann> <AllCaps> HM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Munich> (LMU), D-81377 <LOCATION  Munich,> <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Two roles for the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Cdc13 protein at the telomere have previously been characterized: it recruits telomerase to the telomere and protects chromosome ends from degradation. <Capitalized> In a synthetic lethality screen with YKU70, the 70-kDa subunit of the telomere-associated <Capitalized> Yku heterodimer, we identified a new mutation in CDC13, cdc13-4, that points toward an additional regulatory function of CDC13. <Capitalized> Although <EndsInDigit> CDC13 is an essential telomerase component in vivo, no replicative senescence can be observed in cdc13-4 cells. <Capitalized> Telomeres of cdc13-4 mutants shorten for about 150 generations until they reach a stable level. <PERSON  Thus,> in cdc13-4 mutants, telomerase seems to be inhibited at normal telomere length but fully active at short telomeres. <Capitalized> Furthermore, chromosome end structure remains protected in cdc13-4 mutants. <Capitalized> Progressive telomere shortening to a steady-state level has also been described for mutants of the positive telomere length regulator TEL1. <Capitalized> Strikingly, cdc13-4/tel1Delta double mutants display shorter telomeres than either single mutant after 125 generations and a significant amplification of Y' elements after 225 generations. <Capitalized> Therefore CDC13, TEL1, and the <Capitalized> Yku heterodimer seem to represent distinct pathways in telomere length maintenance. <Capitalized> Whereas several <EndsInDigit> CDC13 mutants have been reported to display elongated telomeres indicating that Cdc13p functions in negative telomere length control, we report a new mutation leading to shortened and eventually stable telomeres. <Capitalized> Therefore we discuss a key role of <EndsInDigit> CDC13 not only in telomerase recruitment but also in regulating telomerase access, which might be modulated by protein-protein interactions acting as inhibitors or activators of telomerase activity.

Steady-state levels of the enzyme were found to be strongly reduced, the total amount of assembled complex being approximately 30% of control. <Capitalized> The presence of a significant amount of holo-COX in the SHY1-disruptant strain suggests that Shy1p may either facilitate assembly of the enzyme, or increase its stability. <Capitalized> However, our observations, based on 2D-PAGE analysis of mitochondria labelled in vitro, now provide the first direct evidence that <AllCaps> COX assembly is impaired in a Deltashy1 strain. <AllCaps> COX enzyme assembled in the absence of Shy1p appears to be structurally and enzymically normal. <Capitalized> The in vitro labelling studies additionally indicate that mitochondrial translation is significantly increased in the shy1 null mutant strain, possibly reflecting a compensatory mechanism for reduced respiratory capacity. <Capitalized> Protein interactions of both Shy1p and Surf1p are implied by their appearance in a high molecular weight complex of about 250 kDa, as shown by 2D-PAGE.

 <PERSON  Powell> <AllCaps> RM, <PERSON  Parkhurst> <AllCaps> KM, <Capitalized> Brenowitz <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Parkhurst> <AllCaps> LJ.

 <Capitalized> Binding of the TATA-binding protein (TBP) to promoter <AllCaps> DNA bearing the <AllCaps> TATA sequence is an obligatory initial step in <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II transcription initiation. <Capitalized> The interactions of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> TBP with the <EndsInDigit> E4 (TATATATA) and adenovirus major late (TATAAAAG) promoters have been modeled via global analysis of kinetic and thermodynamic data obtained using fluorescence resonance energy transfer. <AllCaps> A linear two-intermediate kinetic mechanism describes the reaction of both of these consensus strong promoters with <AllCaps> TBP. <Capitalized> Qualitative features common to both interactions include tightly bound <ContainsHyphen> TBP-DNA complexes with similar solution geometries, simultaneous <AllCaps> DNA binding and bending, and the presence of intermediate <ContainsHyphen> TBP-DNA conformers at high mole fraction throughout most of the reaction and at equilibrium. <Capitalized> Despite very similar energetic changes overall, the stepwise entropic and enthalpic compensations along the two pathways differ markedly following the initial binding/bending event. <Capitalized> Furthermore, TBP-E4 dissociation ensues from both replacement and displacement processes, in contrast to replacement alone for TBP-adenovirus major late promoter. <AllCaps> A model is proposed that explicitly correlates these similarities and differences with the sequence-specific structural properties inherent to each promoter. <Capitalized> This detailed mechanistic comparison of two strong promoters interacting with <AllCaps> TBP provides a foundation for subsequent comparison between consensus and variant promoter sequences reacting with <AllCaps> TBP.
