 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae nuclear pore complex is a supramolecular assembly of 30 nucleoporins that cooperatively facilitate nucleocytoplasmic transport. <Capitalized> Thirteen nucleoporins that contain <AllCaps> FG peptide repeats (FG Nups) are proposed to function as stepping stones in karyopherin-mediated transport pathways. <Capitalized> Here, protein interactions that occur at individual <AllCaps> FG <Capitalized> Nups were sampled using immobilized nucleoporins and yeast extracts. <Capitalized> We find that many proteins bind to <AllCaps> FG <Capitalized> Nups in highly reproducible patterns. <Capitalized> Among 135 proteins identified by mass spectrometry, most were karyopherins and nucleoporins. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> PSFG nucleoporin Nup42p and the <AllCaps> GLFG nucleoporins Nup49p, Nup57p, Nup100p, and Nup116p exhibited generic interactions with karyopherins; each bound 6--10 different karyopherin betas, including importins as well as exportins. <Capitalized> Unexpectedly, the same <Capitalized> Nups also captured the hexameric Nup84p complex and Nup2p. <Capitalized> In contrast, the <AllCaps> FXFG nucleoporins Nup1p, Nup2p, and Nup60p were more selective and captured mostly the Kap95p.Kap60p heterodimer. <Capitalized> When the concentration of Gsp1p-GTP was elevated in the extracts to mimic the nucleoplasmic environment, the patterns of interacting proteins changed; exportins exhibited enhanced binding to <AllCaps> FG <Capitalized> Nups, and importins exhibited reduced binding. <Capitalized> The results demonstrate a global role for Gsp1p-GTP on karyopherin-nucleoporin interactions and provide a rudimentary map of the routes that karyopherins take as they cross the nuclear pore complex.

 <Capitalized> The availability of complete genome sequences now permits the development of tools for functional biology on a proteomic scale. <Capitalized> Several experimental approaches or in silico algorithms aim at clustering proteins into networks with biological significance. <Capitalized> Among those, the yeast two-hybrid system is the technology of choice to detect protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> Recently, optimized versions were applied at a genomic scale, leading to databases on the web. <Capitalized> However, as with any other 'genetic' assay, yeast two-hybrid assays are prone to false positives and false negatives. <Capitalized> Here we discuss these various technologies, their general limitations and the potential advances they make possible, especially when in combination with other functional genomics or bioinformatics analyses.

receptor-expressing yeast strains (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) that required arginine vasopressin-dependent receptor/G protein coupling for cell growth. <EndsInDigit> V2 receptors heterologously expressed in yeast were unable to productively interact with the endogenous yeast <AllCaps> G protein alpha subunit, Gpa1p, or a mutant Gpa1p subunit containing the C-terminal <AllCaps> G alpha(q) sequence (Gq5). <Capitalized> In contrast, the <EndsInDigit> V2 receptor efficiently coupled to a Gpa1p/G alpha(s) hybrid subunit containing the C-terminal <AllCaps> G alpha(s) sequence (Gs5), indicating that the <EndsInDigit> V2 receptor retained proper <AllCaps> G protein coupling selectivity in yeast. <Capitalized> To gain insight into the molecular basis underlying the selectivity of receptor function. <Capitalized> These findings highlight the usefulness of combining receptor random mutagenesis and yeast expression technology to study mechanisms governing receptor/G protein  <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Advanced <Capitalized> Centre for <Capitalized> Biochemical <Capitalized> Engineering, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemical <Capitalized> Engineering, <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> College <LOCATION  London,> <Capitalized> Torrington <PERSON  Place,> <LOCATION  London> WC1E 7JE, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> This article describes the rapid prediction of recovery process performance for a new recombinant enzyme product on the basis of a broad portfolio of computer models and highly targeted experimentation. <AllCaps> A process model for the recombinant system was generated by linking unit operation models in an integrated fashion, with required parameter estimation and physical property determination accomplished using data from scale-down studies. <Capitalized> This enabled the generic modeling framework established for processing of a natural enzyme from bakers' yeast to be applied. <Capitalized> An experimental study of the same operations at the pilot scale showed that the process model gave a conservative prediction of recombinant enzyme recovery. <Capitalized> The model successfully captured interactions leading to a low overall product yield and indicated the need for further study of precipitate breakage in the feed zone of a disc stack centrifuge in order to improve performance. <Capitalized> The utility of scale-down units as an aid to fast model generation and the advantage of integrating computer modeling and scale-down studies to accelerate bioprocess development are highlighted. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <PERSON  John> <PERSON  Wiley> & <Capitalized> Sons, Inc.

 184: <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Sci 2001 Jun;10(6):1113-23 
 
 <Capitalized> Environmentally induced reversible conformational switching in the yeast cell adhesion protein alpha-agglutinin. 
 
 <Capitalized> Zhao <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Chen <AllCaps> MH, <Capitalized> Shen <AllCaps> ZM, <PERSON  Kahn> <AllCaps> PC, <Capitalized> Lipke <AllCaps> PN. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences and the <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Biomolecular <Capitalized> Structure and <Capitalized> Function, <PERSON  Hunter> <Capitalized> College of the <Capitalized> City <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10021,USA. 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast cell adhesion protein alpha-agglutinin is expressed on the surface of a free-living organism and is subjected to a variety of environmental conditions. <Capitalized> Circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy shows that the binding region of alpha-agglutinin has a beta-sheet-rich structure, with only approximately 2% alpha-helix under native conditions (15-40 degrees <AllCaps> C at <MixedCase> pH 5.5). <Capitalized> This region is predicted to fold into three immunoglobulin-like domains, and models are consistent with the <AllCaps> CD spectra as well as with peptide mapping and site-specific mutagenesis. <Capitalized> However, secondary structure prediction algorithms show that segments comprising approximately 17% of the residues have high alpha-helical and low beta-sheet potential. <Capitalized> Two model peptides of such segments had helical tendencies, and one of these peptides showed pH-dependent conformational switching. <Capitalized> Similarly, <AllCaps> CD spectroscopy of the binding region of alpha-agglutinin showed reversible conversion from beta-rich to mixed alpha/beta structure at elevated temperatures or when the <MixedCase> pH was changed. <Capitalized> The reversibility of these changes implied that there is a small energy difference between the all-beta and the alpha/beta states. <Capitalized> Similar changes followed cleavage of peptide or disulfide bonds. <Capitalized> Together, these observations imply that short sequences of high helical propensity are constrained to a beta-rich state by covalent and local charge interactions under native conditions, but form helices under non-native conditions.

 Phosphofructokinase-1 from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae is composed of four alpha- and four beta-subunits, each of them carrying catalytic and regulatory bindings sites for MgATP. <Capitalized> In this paper, various photoaffinity labels, such as 8-azidoadenosine 5'-triphosphate, 8-azido-1,N6-ethenoadenosine 5'-triphosphate, and 8-N3-3'(2')-O-biotinyl-8-azidoadenosine 5'-triphosphate have been used to study their interaction with the enzyme in the dark and during irradiation. <Capitalized> All nucleotidetriphosphates function as phosphate donor forming fructose 1,6-bisphosphate from fructose 6-phosphate. <Capitalized> However, the kinetic analysis revealed distinctly differences between them. <Capitalized> Photolabeling causes a decrease in enzyme activity to a similar extent, and <AllCaps> ATP acts as competitive effector to inactivation. <Capitalized> Three bifunctional diazidodiadeninedinucleotides (8-diN3AP4A, monoepsilon-8-diN3AP4A, and diepsilon-8-diN3AP4A) were applied for studying the spatial arrangement of the nucleotide binding sites. <Capitalized> No cross-linking of the subunits was obtained by irradiation of the enzyme with 8-diN3AP4A. <Capitalized> Photolabeling with diepsilon-8-diN3AP4A resulted in the formation of two alpha-beta cross-links with different mobilities in the SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, while monoepsilon-8-diN3AP4A yielded only one alpha-beta cross-link. <Capitalized> Because an interfacial location of the catalytic sites between two subunits is less likely, we suggest that the formation of cross-linked subunits may be the result of specific interactions of the bifunctional photolabels with regulatory sites at the interface of both subunits.

 <Capitalized> Role of nuclear pools of aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases in <MixedCase> tRNA nuclear export. 
 
 <Capitalized> Azad <AllCaps> AK, <PERSON  Stanford> <AllCaps> DR, <Capitalized> Sarkar <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Hopper> <AllCaps> AK. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Medicine, <PERSON  Hershey,> <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> 17033, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Reports of nuclear <MixedCase> tRNA aminoacylation and its role in <MixedCase> tRNA nuclear export (Lund and <PERSON  Dahlberg,> 1998; <Capitalized> Sarkar et al., 1999; <Capitalized> Grosshans et al., 20001) have led to the prediction that there should be nuclear pools of aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases. <Capitalized> We report that in budding yeast there are nuclear pools of tyrosyl-tRNA synthetase, Tys1p. <Capitalized> By sequence alignments we predicted a Tys1p nuclear localization sequence and showed it to be sufficient for nuclear location of a passenger protein. <Capitalized> Mutations of this nuclear localization sequence in endogenous Tys1p reduce nuclear Tys1p pools, indicating that the motif is also important for nucleus location. <Capitalized> The mutations do not significantly affect catalytic activity, but they do cause defects in export of <MixedCase> tRNAs to the cytosol. <Capitalized> Despite export defects, the cells are viable, indicating that nuclear <MixedCase> tRNA aminoacylation is not required for all <MixedCase> tRNA nuclear export paths. <Capitalized> Because the <MixedCase> tRNA nuclear exportin, Los1p, is also unessential, we tested whether <MixedCase> tRNA aminoacylation and Los1p operate in alternative <MixedCase> tRNA nuclear export paths. <Capitalized> No genetic interactions between aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases and Los1p were detected, indicating that <MixedCase> tRNA nuclear aminoacylation and Los1p operate in the same export pathway or there are more than two pathways for <MixedCase> tRNA nuclear export.

 188: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2001 <PERSON  Jul> 13;276(28):26715-23 
 
 <Capitalized> Characterization of <AllCaps> DNA damage-stimulated self-interaction of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae checkpoint protein Rad17p. 
 
 <Capitalized> Zhang <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Zhu> <PERSON  Z,> <Capitalized> Vidanes <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Mbangkollo <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Liu> <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Siede <PERSON  W.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Radiation <Capitalized> Oncology and the <PERSON  Winship> <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Institute, <PERSON  Emory> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  Atlanta,> <LOCATION  Georgia> 30322, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Rad17p is necessary for cell cycle checkpoint arrests in response to <AllCaps> DNA damage. <Capitalized> Its known interactions with the checkpoint proteins Mec3p and Ddc1p in a PCNA-like complex indicate a sensor role in damage recognition. <Capitalized> In a novel application of the yeast two-hybrid system and by immunoprecipitation, we show here that Rad17p is capable of increased self-interaction following <AllCaps> DNA damage introduced by 4-nitroquinoline-N-oxide, camptothecin or partial inactivation of <AllCaps> DNA ligase <AllCaps> I. <Capitalized> Despite overlap of regions required for Rad17p interactions with Rad17p or Mec3p, single amino acid substitutions revealed that Rad17p x Rad17p complex formation is independent of Mec3p. E128K (rad17-1) was found to inhibit Rad17p interaction with Mec3p but not with Rad17p. <Capitalized> On the other hand, Phe-121 is essential for Rad17p self-interaction, and its function in checkpoint arrest but not for Mec3p interaction. <Capitalized> These differential effects indicate that Rad17p-Rad17p interaction plays a role that is independent of the Rad17p x Mec3p x Ddc1p complex, although our results are also compatible with Rad17p-mediated supercomplex formation of the Rad17p x Mec3p x Ddc1p heterotrimer in response to <AllCaps> DNA damage.

 189: <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Radiother 2001 Apr;5(2):109-29 
 
 [Molecular mechanisms controlling the cell cycle: fundamental aspects and implications for oncology] 
 
 [Article in French] 
 
 <Capitalized> Viallard <AllCaps> JF, <Capitalized> Lacombe <AllCaps> F, <Capitalized> Belloc <AllCaps> F, <Capitalized> Pellegrin <AllCaps> JL, <Capitalized> Reiffers <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <Capitalized> Service de medecine interne et maladies infectieuses, centre Francois-Magendie, hopital du Haut-Leveque, 5, avenue <Capitalized> Magellan, 33604 <Capitalized> Pessac, <PERSON France> jean-francois.viallard@chu-bordeaux.fr 
 
 INTRODUCTION: <Capitalized> Comprehension of cell cycle regulation mechanisms has progressed very quickly these past few years and regulators of the cell cycle have gained widespread importance in cancer. <Capitalized> This review first summarizes major advances in the understanding of the control of cell cycle mechanisms. <Capitalized> Examples of how this control is altered in tumoral cells are then described. <AllCaps> CURRENT <AllCaps> KNOWLEDGE <AllCaps> AND <AllCaps> KEY POINTS: <Capitalized> The typical mammalian cell cycle consists of four distinct phases occurring in a well-defined order, each of which should be completed successfully before the next begins. <Capitalized> Progression of eukaryotic cells through major cell cycle transitions is mediated by sequential assembly and activation of a family of serine-threonine protein kinases, the cyclin dependent kinases (CDK). <Capitalized> The timing of their activation is determined by their post-translational modifications (phosphorylations/dephosphorylations), and by the association of a protein called cyclin, which is the regulatory subunit of the kinase complex. <Capitalized> The cyclin family is divided into two main classes. <Capitalized> The 'G1 cyclins' include cyclins <AllCaps> C, D1-3, and <AllCaps> E, and their accumulation is rate-limiting for progression from the <EndsInDigit> G1 to <PERSON  S> phase. <Capitalized> The 'mitotic or <EndsInDigit> G2 cyclins', which include cyclin <AllCaps> A and cyclin <AllCaps> B, are involved in the control of G2/M transition and mitosis. <Capitalized> The cyclins bind to and activate the <AllCaps> CDK, which leads to phosphorylation (and then inhibition) of the tumor suppressor protein, pRb. <MixedCase> pRb controls commitment to progress from the <EndsInDigit> G1 to <PERSON  S> phase, at least in part by repressing the activity of the E2F transcription factors known to promote cell proliferation. <PERSON  Both> the D-type cyclins and their partner kinases CDK4/6 have proto-oncogenic properties, and their activity is carefully regulated at multiple levels including negative control by two families of <AllCaps> CDK inhibitors. <Capitalized> While members of the <EndsInDigit> INK4 family (p16INK4A, p15INK4B, p18INK4C, p19INK4D) interact specifically with <EndsInDigit> CDK4 and CDK6, the CIP/KIP inhibitors p21CIP1/WAF1, p27KIP1 and p57KIP2 inhibit a broader spectrum of <AllCaps> CDK. <Capitalized> The interplay between p16INK4A, cyclin D/CDK, and pRb/E2F together constitute a functional unit collectively known as the 'pRb pathway'. <Capitalized> Each of the major components of this mechanism may become deregulated in cancer, and accumulating evidence points to the 'pRb pathway' as a candidate obligatory target in multistep oncogenesis of possibly all human tumor types. <AllCaps> FUTURE <AllCaps> PROSPECTS <AllCaps> AND PROJECTS: <PERSON  Major> advances in the understanding of cell cycle regulation mechanisms provided a better knowledge of the molecular interactions involved in human cancer. <Capitalized> This progress has led to the promotion of new therapeutic agents presently in clinical trials or under development. <Capitalized> Moreover, the components of the cell cycle are probably involved in other non-cancerous diseases and their role must be defined. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Academic 
 
 PMID: 11355576 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 190: <Capitalized> Biotechniques 2001 May;30(5):984-8 
 
 <Capitalized> Erratum in: <Capitalized> Biotechniques 2001 Sep;31(3):488 
 
 <Capitalized> Rapid selection against truncation mutants in yeast reverse two-hybrid screens. 
 
 <Capitalized> Puthalakath <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Strasser> <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Huang <AllCaps> DC. 
 
 <PERSON  Walter> and <PERSON  Eliza> <PERSON  Hall> <Capitalized> Institute, <LOCATION  Melbourne,> <LOCATION Australia> 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast reverse two-hybrid system is a powerful technique for isolating mutations in a protein that abolish its interaction with a known partner. <Capitalized> Selection is based on abrogation of growth suppression imposed when wild-type interactions confer 5-fluoroorotic acid (5-FOA) sensitivity to yeast cells. <AllCaps> A laborious component of this system is to eliminate those mutations that cause protein truncation. <Capitalized> By fusing the green fluorescent protein (GFP) to the C-terminus of a protein of interest, dynein light chain (LC8), we were able to rapidly isolate mutations that did not result in protein truncation. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Technical <Capitalized> Report 
 
 PMID: 11355361 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 191: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2001 <PERSON  Jul> 13;276(28):26526-33 
 
 <Capitalized> Interaction of gamma 1-syntrophin with diacylglycerol kinase-zeta. <Capitalized> Regulation of nuclear localization by <AllCaps> PDZ interactions. 
 
 <PERSON  Hogan> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Shepherd> <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Chabot> <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Quenneville <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Prescott> <AllCaps> SM, <PERSON  Topham> <AllCaps> MK, <PERSON  Gee> <AllCaps> SH. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cellular and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Medicine, <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Neuromuscular <Capitalized> Disease, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Ottawa,> <LOCATION  Ottawa,> <LOCATION  Ontario> K1H 8M5, <PERSON Canada> 
 
 <Capitalized> Syntrophins are modular adapter proteins that link ion channels and signaling proteins to dystrophin and its homologues. <AllCaps> A yeast two-hybrid screen of a human brain <MixedCase> cDNA library using the <AllCaps> PDZ domain of gamma 1- syntrophin, a recently identified brain-specific isoform, yielded overlapping clones encoding the <AllCaps> C terminus of diacylglycerol kinase-zeta (DGK-zeta), an enzyme that converts diacylglycerol into phosphatidic acid. <Capitalized> In biochemical assays, the <AllCaps> C terminus of DGK-zeta, which contains a consensus PDZ-binding motif, was found to be necessary and sufficient for association with gamma 1-syntrophin. <Capitalized> When coexpressed in HeLa cells, DGK-zeta and gamma 1-syntrophin formed a stable complex that partitioned between the cytoplasm and nucleus. DGK-zeta translocates from the cytosol to the nucleus, a process negatively regulated by protein kinase <AllCaps> C phosphorylation. <Capitalized> We found that DGK-zeta recruits gamma 1-syntrophin into the nucleus and that the PDZ-binding motif is required. <Capitalized> Disrupting the interaction altered the intracellular localization of both proteins; DGK-zeta accumulated in the nucleus, whereas gamma 1-syntrophin remained in the cytoplasm. <Capitalized> The level of endogenous syntrophins in the nucleus of HeLa cells also reflected the amount of nuclear DGK-zeta. <Capitalized> In the brain, DGK-zeta and gamma 1-syntrophin were colocalized in cell bodies and dendrites of cerebellar <Capitalized> Purkinjie neurons and other neuronal cell types, suggesting that their interaction is physiologically relevant. <Capitalized> Moreover, coimmunoprecipitation and pull-down experiments from brain extracts and cells suggest that DGK-zeta, gamma 1-syntrophin, and dystrophin form a ternary complex. <Capitalized> Collectively, our results suggest that gamma 1-syntrophin participates in regulating the subcellular localization of DGK-zeta to ensure correct termination of diacylglycerol signaling.

 192: <AllCaps> RNA 2001 Apr;7(4):565-75 
 
 <Capitalized> An essential protein-binding domain of nuclear RNase <PERSON  P> <AllCaps> RNA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ziehler <AllCaps> WA, <PERSON  Morris> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Scott> <AllCaps> FH, <PERSON  Millikin> <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Engelke> <AllCaps> DR. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor> 48109-0606, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Eukaryotic RNase <PERSON  P> and RNase <AllCaps> MRP are endoribonucleases composed of <AllCaps> RNA and protein subunits. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> RNA subunits of each enzyme share substantial secondary structural features, and most of the protein subunits are shared between the two. <Capitalized> One of the conserved <AllCaps> RNA subdomains, designated P3, has previously been shown to be required for nucleolar localization. <Capitalized> Phylogenetic sequence analysis suggests that the <EndsInDigit> P3 domain interacts with one of the proteins common to RNase <PERSON  P> and RNase <AllCaps> MRP, a conclusion strengthened by an earlier observation that the essential domain can be interchanged between the two enzymes. <Capitalized> To examine possible functions of the <EndsInDigit> P3 domain, four conserved nucleotides in the <EndsInDigit> P3 domain of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae RNase <PERSON  P> <AllCaps> RNA (RPR1) were randomized to create a library of all possible sequence combinations at those positions. <Capitalized> Selection of functional genes in vivo identified permissible variations, and viable clones that caused yeast to exhibit conditional growth phenotypes were tested for defects in RNase <PERSON  P> <AllCaps> RNA and <MixedCase> tRNA biosynthesis. <Capitalized> Under nonpermissive conditions, the mutants had reduced maturation of the <EndsInDigit> RPR1 <AllCaps> RNA precursor, an expected phenotype in cases where RNase <PERSON  P> holoenzyme assembly is defective. <Capitalized> This loss of <EndsInDigit> RPR1 <AllCaps> RNA maturation coincided, as expected, with a loss of pre-tRNA maturation characteristic of RNase <PERSON  P> defects. <Capitalized> To test whether mutations at the conserved positions inhibited interactions with a particular protein, specific binding of the individual protein subunits to the <AllCaps> RNA subunit was tested in yeast using the three-hybrid system. Pop1p, the largest subunit shared by RNases <PERSON  P> and <AllCaps> MRP, bound specifically to <EndsInDigit> RPR1 <AllCaps> RNA and the isolated <EndsInDigit> P3 domain, and this binding was eliminated by mutations at the conserved <EndsInDigit> P3 residues. <Capitalized> These results indicate that Pop1p interacts with the <EndsInDigit> P3 domain common to RNases <PERSON  P> and <AllCaps> MRP, and that this interaction is critical in the maturation of RNase <PERSON  P> holoenzyme.

 <Capitalized> We demonstrate an integrated approach to build, test, and refine a model of a cellular pathway, in which perturbations to critical pathway components are analyzed using <AllCaps> DNA microarrays, quantitative proteomics, and databases of known physical interactions. <Capitalized> Using this approach, we identify 997 messenger RNAs responding to 20 systematic perturbations of the yeast galactose-utilization pathway, provide evidence that approximately 15 of 289 detected proteins are regulated posttranscriptionally, and identify explicit physical interactions governing the cellular response to each perturbation. <Capitalized> We refine the model through further iterations of perturbation and global measurements, suggesting hypotheses about the regulation of galactose utilization and physical interactions between this and a variety of other metabolic pathways.

Nuclear-encoded mitochondrial precursor proteins are first recognized by surface receptors and then pass through the import channel. <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Tom> complex has been purified; however, the protein-protein interactions that drive its assembly and maintain its stability have been difficult to study. <Capitalized> Here we show that <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Tom40p expressed in bacteria and purified to homogeneity associates efficiently with itself. <Capitalized> The self-association is very strong and can withstand up to 4 <AllCaps> M urea or 1 <AllCaps> M salt. <Capitalized> The tight self-association does not require the N-terminal segment of Tom40p. <Capitalized> Furthermore, purified Tom40p preferentially recognizes the targeting sequence of mitochondrial precursor proteins. <Capitalized> Although the binding of the targeting sequence to Tom40p is inhibited by urea concentrations in excess of 1 <AllCaps> M, it is moderately resistant to 1 <AllCaps> M salt. <Capitalized> Simultaneous self-assembly and precursor protein binding suggest that Tom40p contains at least two different domains mediating these processes. <Capitalized> The experimental approach described here should be useful for analysing protein-protein interactions involving individual or groups of components of the mitochondrial import machinery.

 <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> U6 small nuclear ribonucleoprotein is a critical component of the eukaryotic spliceosome. <Capitalized> The first protein that binds the <EndsInDigit> U6 <MixedCase> snRNA is the <Capitalized> La protein, an abundant phosphoprotein that binds the 3' end of many nascent small RNAs. <AllCaps> A complex of seven Sm-like proteins, Lsm2-Lsm8, also binds the 3' end of <EndsInDigit> U6 snRNA. <AllCaps> A mutation within the <Capitalized> Sm motif of Lsm8p causes <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells to require the <Capitalized> La protein Lhp1p to stabilize nascent <EndsInDigit> U6 snRNA. <Capitalized> Here we describe functional interactions between Lhp1p, the <Capitalized> Lsm proteins, and <EndsInDigit> U6 snRNA. <EndsInDigit> LSM2 and LSM4, but not other <AllCaps> LSM genes, act as allele-specific, low-copy suppressors of mutations in Lsm8p. <Capitalized> Overexpression of <EndsInDigit> LSM2 in the lsm8 mutant strain increases the levels of both Lsm8p and <EndsInDigit> U6 snRNPs. <Capitalized> In the presence of extra <EndsInDigit> U6 <MixedCase> snRNA genes, <EndsInDigit> LSM8 becomes dispensable for growth, suggesting that the only essential function of <EndsInDigit> LSM8 is in <EndsInDigit> U6 <AllCaps> RNA biogenesis or function. <Capitalized> Furthermore, deletions of LSM5, LSM6, or <EndsInDigit> LSM7 cause <EndsInDigit> LHP1 to become required for growth. <Capitalized> Our experiments are consistent with a model in which Lsm2p and Lsm4p contact Lsm8p in the Lsm2-Lsm8 ring and suggest that Lhp1p acts redundantly with the entire Lsm2-Lsm8 complex to stabilize nascent <EndsInDigit> U6 snRNA.

 <PERSON  Lee> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Struhl> <AllCaps> K.

 <Capitalized> The TATA-binding protein (TBP) is composed of a highly conserved core domain sufficient for TATA-element binding and preinitiation complex formation as well as a highly divergent N-terminal region that is dispensable for yeast cell viability. <Capitalized> In vitro, removal of the N-terminal region domain enhances <ContainsHyphen> TBP-TATA association and <AllCaps> TBP dimerization. <Capitalized> Here, we examine the effects of truncation of the N-terminal region in the context of yeast <AllCaps> TBP mutants with specific defects in <AllCaps> DNA binding and in interactions with various proteins. <Capitalized> For a subset of mutations that disrupt <AllCaps> DNA binding and the response to transcriptional activators, removal of the N-terminal domain rescues their transcriptional defects. <Capitalized> By contrast, deletion of the N-terminal region is lethal in combination with mutations on a limited surface of <AllCaps> TBP. <Capitalized> Although this surface is important for interactions with <AllCaps> TFIIA and Brf1, <AllCaps> TBP interactions with these two factors do not appear to be responsible for this dependence on the N-terminal region. <Capitalized> Our results suggest that the N-terminal region of <AllCaps> TBP has at least two distinct functions in vivo. <Capitalized> It inhibits the interaction of <AllCaps> TBP with <AllCaps> TATA elements, and it acts positively in combination with a specific region of the <AllCaps> TBP core domain that presumably interacts with another protein(s).

 <Capitalized> Oligopeptide repeats in the yeast protein Sup35p stabilize intermolecular prion interactions. 
 
 <PERSON  Parham> <AllCaps> SN, <LOCATION  Resende> <AllCaps> CG, <PERSON  Tuite> <AllCaps> MF. 
 
 <Capitalized> Research <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Biosciences, <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  Kent,> <PERSON  Canterbury,> <PERSON  Kent> <EndsInDigit> CT2 7NJ, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The nuclear-encoded Sup35p protein is responsible for the prion-like [PSI(+)] determinant of yeast, with Sup35p existing largely as a high molecular weight aggregate in [PSI(+)] strains. <Capitalized> Here we show that the five oligopeptide repeats present at the N-terminus of Sup35p are responsible for stabilizing aggregation of Sup35p in vivo. <Capitalized> Sequential deletion of the oligopeptide repeats prevented the maintenance of [PSI(+)] by the truncated Sup35p, although deletants containing only two repeats could be incorporated into pre-existing aggregates of wild-type Sup35p. <Capitalized> The mammalian prion protein PrP also contains similar oligopeptide repeats and we show here that a human PrP repeat (PHGGGWGQ) is able functionally to replace a Sup35p oligopeptide repeat to allow stable [PSI(+)] propagation in vivo. <Capitalized> Our data suggest a model in which the oligopeptide repeats in Sup35p stabilize intermolecular interactions between Sup35p proteins that initiate establishment of the aggregated state. <Capitalized> Modulating repeat number therefore alters the rate of yeast prion conversion in vivo. <Capitalized> Furthermore, there appears to be evolutionary conservation of function of the N-terminally located oligopeptide repeats in prion propagation.

 <PERSON  Phelps> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Briggs> <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Haefele <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Mincone <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Ligeti <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Wohlrab <AllCaps> H. 
 
 <LOCATION  Boston> <Capitalized> Biomedical <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> Watertown, <LOCATION  Massachusetts> 02472, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The mitochondrial phosphate transport protein (PTP) has six (A--F) transmembrane (TM) helices per subunit of functional homodimer with all mutations referring to the subunit of the homodimer. <Capitalized> In earlier studies, conservative replacements of several residues located either at the matrix end (Asp39/helix <AllCaps> A, Glu137/helix <AllCaps> C, Asp236/helix E) or at the membrane center (His32/helix <AllCaps> A, Glu136/helix C) of <AllCaps> TM helices yielded inactive single mutation PTPs. <Capitalized> Some of these residues were suggested to act as phosphate ligands or as part of the proton cotransport path. <Capitalized> We now show that the mutation Ser158Thr, not part of a <AllCaps> TM helix but located near the center of the matrix loop (Ile141--Ser171) between <AllCaps> TM helices <AllCaps> C and <AllCaps> D, inactivates <AllCaps> PTP and is thus also functionally relevant. <Capitalized> On the other side of the membrane, the single mutation Glu192Asp at the intermembrane space end of <AllCaps> TM helix <AllCaps> D yields a <AllCaps> PTP with 33% wild-type activity. <Capitalized> We constructed double mutants by adding this mutation to the six transport-inactivating mutations. <Capitalized> Transport was detected only in those with Asp39Asn, Glu137Gln, or Ser158Thr. <Capitalized> We conclude that <AllCaps> TM helix <AllCaps> D can interact with <AllCaps> TM helices <AllCaps> A and <AllCaps> C and matrix loop Ile141--Ser171 and that Asp39, Glu137, and Ser158 are not essential for phosphate transport. <Capitalized> Since our results are consistent with residues present in all 12 functionally identified members of the mitochondrial transport protein (MTP) family, they lead to a general rule that specifies <AllCaps> MTP residue types at 7 separate locations. <Capitalized> The conformations of all the double mutation PTPs (except that with the matrix loop Ser158Thr) are significantly different from those of the single mutation PTPs, as indicated by their very low liposome incorporation efficiency and their requirement for less detergent (Triton X-100) to stay in solution. <Capitalized> These dramatic conformational differences also suggest an interaction between <AllCaps> TM helices <AllCaps> D and <AllCaps> E. <Capitalized> The results are discussed in terms of <AllCaps> TM helix movements and changes in the <AllCaps> PTP monomer/dimer ratio.

 <Capitalized> Covariation of a specificity-determining structural motif in an aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase and a <MixedCase> tRNA identity element. 
 
 <Capitalized> Hawko <AllCaps> SA, <PERSON  Francklyn> <AllCaps> CS. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Vermont, <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Sciences <Capitalized> Complex, <LOCATION  Burlington,> <Capitalized> Vermont 05405, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Transfer <AllCaps> RNA (tRNA) identity determinants help preserve the specificity of aminoacylation in vivo, and prevent cross-species interactions. <Capitalized> Here, we investigate covariation between the discriminator base (N73) element in histidine <MixedCase> tRNAs and residues in the histidyl-tRNA synthetase (HisRS) motif 2 loop. <AllCaps> A model of the <Capitalized> Escherichia coli HisRS--tRNA(His) complex predicts an interaction between the prokaryotic conserved glutamine 118 of the motif 2 loop and cytosine 73. <Capitalized> The substitution of <Capitalized> Gln 118 in motif 2 with glutamate decreased discrimination between cytosine and uracil some 50-fold, but left overall rates of adenylation and aminoacylation unaffected. <Capitalized> By contrast, substitutions at neighboring <Capitalized> Glu 115 and <Capitalized> Arg 121 affected both adenylation and aminoacylation, consistent with their predicted involvement in both half-reactions. <Capitalized> Additional evidence for the involvement of the motif 2 loop was provided by functional analysis of a hybrid <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae-- <AllCaps> E. coli HisRS possessing the 11 amino acid motif 2 loop of the yeast enzyme. <Capitalized> Despite an overall decreased activity of nearly 1000-fold relative to the <AllCaps> E. coli enzyme, the chimera nevertheless exhibited a modest preference for the yeast tRNA(His) over the <AllCaps> E. coli tRNA, and preferred wild-type yeast tRNA(His) to a variant with <AllCaps> C at the discriminator position. <Capitalized> These experiments suggest that part of, but not all of, the specificity is provided by the motif 2 loop. <Capitalized> The close interaction between enzyme loop and <AllCaps> RNA sequence elements suggested by these experiments reflects a covariation between enzyme and <MixedCase> tRNA that may have acted to preserve aminoacylation fidelity over evolutionary time.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Medicine, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Colorado> <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Sciences <PERSON  Center,> <Capitalized> Denver, <LOCATION  Colorado,> <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> There is currently a need for vaccines that stimulate cell-mediated immunity-particularly that mediated by CD8+ cytotoxic <PERSON  T> lymphocytes (CTLs)-against viral and tumor antigens. <Capitalized> The optimal induction of cell-mediated immunity requires the presentation of antigens by specialized cells of the immune system called dendritic cells (DCs). DCs are unique in their ability to process exogenous antigens via the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class <AllCaps> I pathway as well as in their ability to activate naive, antigen-specific CD8+ and CD4+ <PERSON  T> cells. <Capitalized> Vaccine strategies that target or activate DCs in order to elicit potent CTL-mediated immunity are the subject of intense research. <Capitalized> We report here that whole recombinant <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast expressing tumor or HIV-1 antigens potently induced antigen-specific, <AllCaps> CTL responses, including those mediating tumor protection, in vaccinated animals. <Capitalized> Interactions between yeast and DCs led to <AllCaps> DC maturation, IL-12 production and the efficient priming of <AllCaps> MHC class I- and class II-restricted, antigen-specific T-cell responses. <Capitalized> Yeast exerted a strong adjuvant effect, augmenting <AllCaps> DC presentation of exogenous whole-protein antigen to <AllCaps> MHC class I- and class II-restricted <PERSON  T> cells. <Capitalized> Recombinant yeast represent a novel vaccine strategy for the induction of broad-based cellular immune responses.

 <Capitalized> The yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae serves as an excellent genetic tool for the analysis of protein +/- protein interactions. <Capitalized> The most common system, used to date, is the two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> Although proven very powerful, the two-hybrid system exhibits several inherent problems and limitations. <Capitalized> Recently, two alternative systems have been described that take advantage of the fact that localization of signal transduction effectors to the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane is absolutely necessary for yeast viability. <Capitalized> These effectors can either be the <PERSON  Ras> guanyl nucleotide exchange factor or <PERSON  Ras> itself. <Capitalized> The yeast strain used in both systems is a temperature-sensitive mutant in the yeast <PERSON  Ras> guanyl nucleotide exchange factor, CDC25. <Capitalized> Membrane localization of these effectors is achieved via protein +/- protein interaction. <Capitalized> Each system can be used to test interaction between known protein pairs, as well as for isolation of novel protein interactions. <Capitalized> Described here are the scientific and technical steps to be considered for both protein recruitment systems. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Vashee <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Simancek <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Challberg <AllCaps> MD, <PERSON  Kelly> <AllCaps> TJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Genetics, <PERSON  Johns> <PERSON  Hopkins> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  Baltimore,> <Capitalized> Maryland 21205, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The six-subunit origin recognition complex (ORC) was originally identified in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Yeast <AllCaps> ORC binds specifically to origins of replication and serves as a platform for the assembly of additional initiation factors, such as Cdc6 and the <Capitalized> Mcm proteins. <PERSON  Human> homologues of all six <AllCaps> ORC subunits have been identified by sequence similarity to their yeast counterparts, but little is known about the biochemical characteristics of human <AllCaps> ORC (HsORC). <Capitalized> We have extracted HsORC from HeLa cell chromatin and probed its subunit composition using specific antibodies. <Capitalized> The endogenous HsORC, identified in these experiments, contained homologues of Orc1-Orc5 but lacked a putative homologue of Orc6. <Capitalized> By expressing HsORC subunits in insect cells using the baculovirus system, we were able to identify a complex containing all six subunits. <Capitalized> To explore the subunit-subunit interactions that are required for the assembly of HsORC, we carried out extensive co-immunoprecipitation experiments with recombinant <AllCaps> ORC subunits expressed in different combinations. <Capitalized> These studies revealed the following binary interactions: HsOrc2-HsOrc3, HsOrc2-HsOrc4, HsOrc3-HsOrc4, HsOrc2-HsOrc6, and HsOrc3-HsOrc6. HsOrc5 did not form stable binary complexes with any other HsORC subunit but interacted with sub-complexes containing any two of subunits HsOrc2, HsOrc3, or HsOrc4. <Capitalized> Complex formation by HsOrc1 required the presence of HsOrc2, HsOrc3, HsOrc4, and HsOrc5 subunits. <Capitalized> These results suggest that the subunits HsOrc2, HsOrc3, and HsOrc4 form a core upon which the ordered assembly of HsOrc5 and HsOrc1 takes place. <Capitalized> The characterization of HsORC should facilitate the identification of human origins of <AllCaps> DNA replication.

 <Capitalized> Hidalgo <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Ansari <AllCaps> AZ, <PERSON  Schmidt> <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Hare> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Simkovich <AllCaps> N, <PERSON  Farrell> <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Shin <AllCaps> EJ, <Capitalized> Ptashne <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Wagner> <AllCaps> G.

 <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> GAL4 dimerization domain (GAL4-dd) is a powerful transcriptional activator when tethered to <AllCaps> DNA in a cell bearing a mutant of the <EndsInDigit> GAL11 protein, named GAL11P. GAL11P (like GAL11) is a component of the RNA-polymerase <AllCaps> II holoenzyme. <Capitalized> Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) studies of GAL4-dd revealed an elongated dimer structure with C(2) symmetry containing three helices that mediate dimerization via coiled-coil contacts. <Capitalized> The two loops between the three coiled coils form mobile bulges causing a variation of twist angles between the helix pairs. <Capitalized> Chemical shift perturbation analysis mapped the GAL11P-binding site to the C-terminal helix alpha3 and the loop between alpha1 and alpha2. <Capitalized> One GAL11P monomer binds to one GAL4-dd dimer rendering the dimer asymmetric and implying an extreme negative cooperativity mechanism. Alanine-scanning mutagenesis of GAL4-dd showed that the NMR-derived GAL11P-binding face is crucial for the novel transcriptional activating function of the GAL4-dd on GAL11P interaction. <Capitalized> The binding of <EndsInDigit> GAL4 to GAL11P, although an artificial interaction, represents a unique structural motif for an activating region capable of binding to a single target to effect gene expression.

 <Capitalized> Inga <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Monti> <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Fronza <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Darden> <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Resnick <AllCaps> MA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Environmental <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Sciences (NIEHS), <AllCaps> PO <PERSON  Box> 12233, <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Triangle <PERSON  Park,> <LOCATION  North Carolina,> <AllCaps> NC 27709, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Changes in promoter specificity and binding affinity that may be associated with p53 mutations or post-translational modifications are useful in understanding p53 structure/function relationships and categorizing tumor mutations. <Capitalized> We have exploited variable expression of human p53 in yeast to identify mutants with novel phenotypes that would correspond to altered promoter selectivity and affinity. <Capitalized> The p53 <MixedCase> cDNA regions coding for the <AllCaps> DNA binding and tetramerization domains were subjected to random <AllCaps> PCR mutagenesis and were cloned directly by recombination in yeast into a vector with a <EndsInDigit> GAL1 promoter whose level of expression could be easily varied. p53 variants exhibiting higher than wild type levels of transactivation (supertrans) for the <AllCaps> RGC responsive element were identified at low level of p53 protein expression. <Capitalized> All the p53 mutants obtained with this screen were located in the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain. <Capitalized> Two out of 17 supertrans mutants have been found in tumors. <PERSON  Six> mutations were in the <EndsInDigit> L1 loop region between amino acids 115 and 124. <Capitalized> The transactivation potential of a panel of supertrans p53 mutants on different promoters was evaluated using the p53 responsive elements, <AllCaps> RGC, PIG3, p21 and bax. <Capitalized> Although all mutants retained some activity with all promoters, we found different patterns of induction based on strength and promoter specificity. <Capitalized> In particular none of the mutants was supertrans for the p21 responsive element. <Capitalized> Interestingly, further analysis in yeast showed that the transactivation function could be retained even in the presence of dominant-negative p53 tumor mutations that could inhibit wild type p53. <Capitalized> Five mutants were also characterized in human cells in terms of growth suppression and transactivation of various promoters. <Capitalized> These novel supertrans p53 mutants may be useful in studies aimed at dissecting p53 downstream pathways, understanding specific interactions between p53 and the <AllCaps> DNA, and could replace wild type p53 in cancer gene therapy protocols. <Capitalized> The approach may also prove useful in identifying p53 tumor mutations.

 Large-scale two-hybrid screens have generated a wealth of information describing potential protein--protein interactions. <Capitalized> When compiled with data from systematic localizations of proteins, mutant screens and other functional tests, a network of interactions among proteins and between proteins and other components of eukaryotic cells can be deduced. <Capitalized> These networks can be viewed as maps of the cell, depicting potential signaling pathways and interactive complexes. <PERSON  Most> importantly, they provide potential clues to the function of previously uncharacterized proteins. <Capitalized> Focusing on recent experiments, we explore these protein-interaction studies and the maps derived from such efforts.

 <PERSON  Provost> <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Doucet> <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Hammarberg <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Gerisch <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Samuelsson> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Radmark <AllCaps> O.

Site-directed mutagenesis suggested an important role for lysine 131 of <AllCaps> CLP in mediating 5LO binding. <Capitalized> In view of the ability of <AllCaps> CLP to bind 5LO and filamentous actin (F-actin), we determined whether <AllCaps> CLP could physically link 5LO to actin filaments. <Capitalized> However, no F-actin-CLP.5LO ternary complex was observed. <Capitalized> In contrast, 5LO appeared to compete with F-actin for the binding of <AllCaps> CLP. <Capitalized> Moreover, 5LO was found to interfere with actin polymerization. <Capitalized> Our results indicate that the 5LO-CLP and CLP-F-actin interactions are mutually exclusive and suggest a modulatory role for 5LO in actin dynamics.

 217: <Capitalized> Appl <Capitalized> Biochem <Capitalized> Biotechnol 2001 Feb;90(2):155-86 
 
 <Capitalized> Thermozymes and their applications: a review of recent literature and patents. 
 
 <PERSON  Bruins> <AllCaps> ME, <PERSON  Janssen> <AllCaps> AE, <PERSON  Boom> <AllCaps> RM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Food <Capitalized> Technology and <Capitalized> Nutritional <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> Wageningen <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> The <LOCATION Netherlands> marieke.bruins@algemeen.pk.wau.nl 
 
 <Capitalized> Enzymes from thermophilic microorganisms, thermozymes, have unique characteristics such as temperature, chemical, and <MixedCase> pH stability. <Capitalized> They can be used in several industrial processes, in which they replace mesophilic enzymes or chemicals. <Capitalized> Thermozymes are often used when the enzymatic process is compatible with existing (high-temperature) process conditions. <Capitalized> The main advantages of performing processes at higher temperatures are reduced risk of microbial contamination, lower viscosity, improved transfer rates, and improved solubility of substrates. <Capitalized> However, cofactors, substrates, or products might be unstable or other side reactions may occur. <Capitalized> Recent developments show that thermophiles are a good source of novel catalysts that are of great industrial interest. <Capitalized> Thermostable polymer-degrading enzymes such as amylases, pullulanases, xylanases, proteases, and cellulases are expected to play an important role in food, chemical, pharmaceutical, paper, pulp, and waste-treatment industries. <Capitalized> Considerable research efforts have been made to better understand the stability of thermozymes. <Capitalized> There are no major conformational differences with mesophilic enzymes, and a small number of extra salt bridges, hydrophobic interactions, or hydrogen bounds seem to confer the extra degree of stabilization. <Capitalized> Currently, overexpression of thermozymes in standard <Capitalized> Escherichia coli allows the production of much larger quantities of enzymes, which are easy to purify by heat treatment. <Capitalized> With wider availability and lower cost, thermophilic enzymes will see more application in industry. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial 
 
 PMID: 11297390 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <Capitalized> Simcha <AllCaps> I, <PERSON  Kirkpatrick> <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Sadot <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Shtutman <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Polevoy <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Geiger> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Peifer <AllCaps> M, Ben-Ze'ev <AllCaps> A.

 <Capitalized> Drosophila <Capitalized> Armadillo and its mammalian homologue beta-catenin are scaffolding proteins involved in the assembly of multiprotein complexes with diverse biological roles. <Capitalized> They mediate adherens junction assembly, thus determining tissue architecture, and also transduce Wnt/Wingless intercellular signals, which regulate embryonic cell fates and, if inappropriately activated, contribute to tumorigenesis. <Capitalized> To learn more about Armadillo/beta-catenin's scaffolding function, we examined in detail its interaction with one of its protein targets, cadherin. <Capitalized> We utilized two assay systems: the yeast two-hybrid system to study cadherin binding in the absence of Armadillo/beta-catenin's other protein partners, and mammalian cells where interactions were assessed in their presence. <Capitalized> We found that segments of the cadherin cytoplasmic tail as small as 23 amino acids bind <Capitalized> Armadillo or beta-catenin in yeast, whereas a slightly longer region is required for binding in mammalian cells. <Capitalized> We used mutagenesis to identify critical amino acids required for cadherin interaction with Armadillo/beta-catenin. <Capitalized> Expression of such short cadherin sequences in mammalian cells did not affect adherens junctions but effectively inhibited beta-catenin-mediated signaling. <Capitalized> This suggests that the interaction between beta-catenin and <PERSON  T> cell factor family transcription factors is a sensitive target for disruption, making the use of analogues of these cadherin derivatives a potentially useful means to suppress tumor progression.

 <Capitalized> The yeast heat shock transcription factor (HSF) belongs to the winged helix family of proteins. <AllCaps> HSF binds <AllCaps> DNA as a trimer, and additional trimers can bind <AllCaps> DNA co-operatively. <Capitalized> Unlike other winged helix-turn-helix proteins, HSF's wing does not appear to contact <AllCaps> DNA, as based on a previously solved crystal structure. <Capitalized> Instead, the structure implies that the wing is involved in protein-protein interactions, possibly within a trimer or between adjacent trimers. <Capitalized> To understand the function of the wing in the <AllCaps> HSF DNA-binding domain, a <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain was created that expresses a wingless <AllCaps> HSF protein. <Capitalized> This strain grows normally at 30 degrees <AllCaps> C, but shows a decrease in reporter gene expression during constitutive and heat-shocked conditions. <Capitalized> Removal of the wing does not affect the stability or trimeric nature of a protein fragment containing the DNA-binding and trimerization domains. <Capitalized> Removal of the wing does result in a decrease in DNA-binding affinity. <Capitalized> This defect was mainly observed in the ability to form the first trimer-bound complex, as the formation of larger complexes is unaffected by the deletion. <Capitalized> Our results suggest that the wing is not involved in the highly co-operative nature of <AllCaps> HSF binding, but may be important in stabilizing the first trimer bound to <AllCaps> DNA.

 <EndsInDigit> CTF4 and <EndsInDigit> CTF18 are required for high-fidelity chromosome segregation. <PERSON  Both> exhibit genetic and physical ties to replication fork constituents. <Capitalized> We find that absence of either <EndsInDigit> CTF4 or <EndsInDigit> CTF18 causes sister chromatid cohesion failure and leads to a preanaphase accumulation of cells that depends on the spindle assembly checkpoint. <Capitalized> The physical and genetic interactions between CTF4, CTF18, and core components of replication fork complexes observed in this study and others suggest that both gene products act in association with the replication fork to facilitate sister chromatid cohesion. <Capitalized> We find that Ctf18p, an RFC1-like protein, directly interacts with Rfc2p, Rfc3p, Rfc4p, and Rfc5p. <Capitalized> However, Ctf18p is not a component of biochemically purified proliferating cell nuclear antigen loading RF-C, suggesting the presence of a discrete complex containing Ctf18p, Rfc2p, Rfc3p, Rfc4p, and Rfc5p. <Capitalized> Recent identification and characterization of the budding yeast polymerase kappa, encoded by TRF4, strongly supports a hypothesis that the <AllCaps> DNA replication machinery is required for proper sister chromatid cohesion. <Capitalized> Analogous to the polymerase switching role of the bacterial and human <ContainsHyphen> RF-C complexes, we propose that budding yeast RF-C(CTF18) may be involved in a polymerase switch event that facilities sister chromatid cohesion. <Capitalized> The requirement for <EndsInDigit> CTF4 and <EndsInDigit> CTF18 in robust cohesion identifies novel roles for replication accessory proteins in this process.

 <AllCaps> A comprehensive two-hybrid analysis to explore the yeast protein interactome. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ito <PERSON  T,> <LOCATION  Chiba> <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Ozawa <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Yoshida <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Hattori <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Sakaki <PERSON  Y.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Genome <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Institute, <LOCATION  Kanazawa> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Kanazawa> 920-0934, <LOCATION Japan> titolab@kenroku.kanazawa-u.ac.jp 
 
 Protein-protein interactions play crucial roles in the execution of various biological functions. <Capitalized> Accordingly, their comprehensive description would contribute considerably to the functional interpretation of fully sequenced genomes, which are flooded with novel genes of unpredictable functions. <Capitalized> We previously developed a system to examine two-hybrid interactions in all possible combinations between the approximately 6,000 proteins of the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Here we have completed the comprehensive analysis using this system to identify 4,549 two-hybrid interactions among 3,278 proteins. <Capitalized> Unexpectedly, these data do not largely overlap with those obtained by the other project [Uetz, <PERSON P.> et al. (2000) <Capitalized> Nature (London) 403, 623-627] and hence have substantially expanded our knowledge on the protein interaction space or interactome of the yeast. <Capitalized> Cumulative connection of these binary interactions generates a single huge network linking the vast majority of the proteins. Bioinformatics-aided selection of biologically relevant interactions highlights various intriguing subnetworks. <Capitalized> They include, for instance, the one that had successfully foreseen the involvement of a novel protein in spindle pole body function as well as the one that may uncover a hitherto unidentified multiprotein complex potentially participating in the process of vesicular transport. <Capitalized> Our data would thus significantly expand and improve the protein interaction map for the exploration of genome functions that eventually leads to thorough understanding of the cell as a molecular system.

 231: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2001 <PERSON  May> 18;276(20):17261-6 
 
 Structure-function analysis of the active site tunnel of yeast <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatase. 
 
 <PERSON  Bisaillon> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Shuman> <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology <Capitalized> Program, Sloan-Kettering <Capitalized> Institute, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10021, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Cet1, the <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatase component of the yeast <MixedCase> mRNA capping apparatus, catalyzes metal-dependent gamma phosphate hydrolysis within the hydrophilic interior of a topologically closed 8-strand beta barrel (the "triphosphate tunnel"). <Capitalized> We used structure-guided alanine scanning to identify 6 side chains within the triphosphate tunnel that are essential for phosphohydrolase activity in vitro and in vivo: Arg393, Glu433, Arg458, Arg469, Asp471 and Thr473. <Capitalized> Alanine substitutions at two positions, Asp377 and Lys409, resulted in partial catalytic defects and a thermosensitive growth phenotype. Structure-function relationships were clarified by introducing conservative substitutions. <Capitalized> Five residues were found to be nonessential: Lys309, Ser395, Asp397, Lys427 Asn431, and Lys474. <Capitalized> The present findings, together with earlier mutational analyses, reveal an unusually complex active site in which 15 individual side chains in the tunnel cavity are important for catalysis, and each of the 8 strands of the beta barrel contributes at least one functional constituent. <Capitalized> The active site residues fall into three classes: (i) those that participate directly in catalysis via coordination of the gamma phosphate or the metal; (ii) those that make critical water-mediated contacts with the gamma phosphate or the metal; and (iii) those that function indirectly via interactions with other essential side chains or by stabilization of the tunnel structure.

 <PERSON  Lehman> <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Ho <AllCaps> CK, <PERSON  Shuman> <PERSON  S.>

 <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatase Cet1 is an essential component of the yeast <MixedCase> mRNA capping apparatus. <Capitalized> The active site of Cet1 resides within a topologically closed hydrophilic beta-barrel (the triphosphate tunnel) that is supported by a globular hydrophobic core. <Capitalized> The homodimeric quaternary structure of Cet1 is formed by a network of contacts between the partner protomers. <Capitalized> By studying the effects of alanine-cluster mutations, we highlight the contributions of two separate facets of the crystallographic dimer interface to Cet1 function in vivo. <Capitalized> One essential facet of the interface entails hydrophobic cross-dimer interactions of Cys(330) and Val(331) and a cross-dimer hydrogen bond of Asp(280) with the backbone amide of Gln(329). <Capitalized> The second functionally relevant dimer interface involves hydrophobic side-chain interactions of Phe(272) and Leu(273). Ala-cluster mutations involving these residues elicited lethal or severe temperature-sensitive phenotypes that were suppressed completely by fusion of the mutated triphosphatases to the guanylyltransferase domain of mammalian capping enzyme. <Capitalized> The recombinant D279A-D280A and F272A-L273A proteins retained phosphohydrolase activity but sedimented as monomers. <Capitalized> These results indicate that a disruption of the dimer interface is uniquely deleterious when the yeast <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatase must function in concert with the endogenous yeast guanylyltransferase. <Capitalized> We also identify key residue pairs in the hydrophobic core of the Cet1 protomer that support the active site tunnel and stabilize the triphosphatase in vivo.

 <Capitalized> The recruitment of ZipA to the septum by FtsZ is an early, essential step in cell division in <Capitalized> Escherichia coli. <Capitalized> We have used polymerase chain reaction-mediated random mutagenesis in the yeast two-hybrid system to analyze this interaction and have identified residues within a highly conserved sequence at the <AllCaps> C terminus of FtsZ as the ZipA binding site. <AllCaps> A search for suppressors of a mutation that causes a loss of interaction (ftsZ(D373G)) identified eight different changes at two residues within this sequence. <Capitalized> In vitro, wild type FtsZ interacted with ZipA with a high affinity in an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, whereas FtsZ(D373G) failed to interact. <Capitalized> Two mutant proteins examined restored this interaction significantly. <Capitalized> In vivo, the alleles tested are significantly more toxic than the wild type <MixedCase> ftsZ and cannot complement a deletion. <Capitalized> We have shown that a fusion, which encodes the last 70 residues of FtsZ in the two-hybrid system, is sufficient for the interaction with FtsA and ZipA. <Capitalized> However, when the wild type sequence is compared with one that encodes FtsZ(D373G), no interaction was seen with either protein. <Capitalized> Mutations surrounding Asp-373 differentially affected the interactions of FtsZ with ZipA and FtsA, indicating that these proteins bind the <AllCaps> C terminus of FtsZ differently.

 244: <AllCaps> J <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol 2001 <PERSON  Mar> 30;307(3):929-38 
 
 <Capitalized> Mapping protein family interactions: intramolecular and intermolecular protein family interaction repertoires in the <AllCaps> PDB and yeast. 
 
 <PERSON  Park> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Lappe> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Teichmann> <AllCaps> SA. 
 
 <Capitalized> European <Capitalized> Bioinformatics <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> Hinxton, <Capitalized> Cambridgeshire, <EndsInDigit> CB10 1SD, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In the postgenomic era, one of the most interesting and important challenges is to understand protein interactions on a large scale. <Capitalized> The physical interactions between protein domains are fundamental to the workings of a cell: in multi-domain polypeptide chains, in multi-subunit proteins and in transient complexes between proteins that also exist independently. <Capitalized> To study the large-scale patterns and evolution of interactions between protein domains, we view interactions between protein domains in terms of the interactions between structural families of evolutionarily related domains. <Capitalized> This allows us to classify 8151 interactions between individual domains in the <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Data <PERSON  Bank> and the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae in terms of 664 types of interactions, between protein families. <Capitalized> At least 51 interactions do not occur in the <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Data <PERSON  Bank> and can only be derived from the yeast data. <Capitalized> The map of interactions between protein families has the form of a scale-free network, meaning that most protein families only interact with one or two other families, while a few families are extremely versatile in their interactions and are connected to many families. <Capitalized> We observe that almost half of all known families engage in interactions with domains from their own family. <Capitalized> We also see that the repertoires of interactions of domains within and between polypeptide chains overlap mostly for two specific types of protein families: enzymes and same-family interactions. <Capitalized> This suggests that different types of protein interaction repertoires exist for structural, functional and regulatory reasons. <Capitalized> Copyright 12001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  North Carolina> at <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <LOCATION  North Carolina> 27599, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The cytoplasm contains high concentrations of cosolutes. <Capitalized> These cosolutes include macromolecules and small organic molecules called osmolytes. <Capitalized> However, most biophysical studies of proteins are conducted in dilute solutions. <Capitalized> Two broad classes of models have been used to describe the interaction between osmolytes and proteins. <Capitalized> One class focuses on excluded volume effects, while the other focuses on binding between the protein and the osmolyte. <Capitalized> To better understand protein--smolyte interactions, we have conducted sedimentation equilibrium analytical ultracentrifugation experiments using ferricytochrome c as a model protein. <Capitalized> From these experiments, we determined the second virial coefficients for a series of osmolytes. <Capitalized> We have interpreted the second virial coefficient as a measure of both excluded volume and protein--osmolyte binding. <Capitalized> We conclude that simple models are not sufficient to understand the interactions between osmolytes and proteins.

 <Capitalized> We are investigating the rules that govern protein-DNA interactions, using a statistical mechanics based formalism that is related to the <Capitalized> Boltzmann <Capitalized> Machine of the neural net literature. <Capitalized> Our approach is data-driven, in which probabilistic algorithms are used to model protein-DNA interactions, given <AllCaps> SELEX and/or phage data as input. <Capitalized> In the current report, we trained the network using <AllCaps> SELEX data, under the "one-to-one" model of interactions (i.e. one amino acid contacts one base). <Capitalized> The trained network was able to successfully identify the wild-type binding sites of <AllCaps> EGR and <AllCaps> MIG protein families. <Capitalized> The predictions using our method are the same or better than that of methods existing in the literature. <Capitalized> However our methodology offers the potential to capitalise in quantitative detail, as well as to be used to explore more general model of interactions, given availability of data.

 <Capitalized> Surfactant proteins <AllCaps> A (SP-A) and <AllCaps> D (SP-D) are members of the collectin family of calcium-dependent lectins and are important pulmonary host defense molecules. <PERSON  Human> <ContainsHyphen> SP-A and <ContainsHyphen> SP-D and rat <ContainsHyphen> SP-D bind to <Capitalized> Aspergillus fumigatus conidia, but the ligand remains unidentified. <Capitalized> To identify a fungal ligand for <ContainsHyphen> SP-A and/or SP-D, we examined the interactions of the proteins with <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <ContainsHyphen> SP-D but not <ContainsHyphen> fumigatus is 1.0 +/- 0.3 <MixedCase> microM glucose equivalents. <Capitalized> Finally, <ContainsHyphen> SP-D showed reduced binding to the beta(1-->6)-glucan-deficient kre6 yeast mutant. <Capitalized> Taken together, these observations demonstrate that beta(1-->6)-glucan is an important fungal ligand for <ContainsHyphen> SP-D and that glycosidic bond patterns alone can determine if an extended carbohydrate polymer is recognized by SP-D.

 253: <Capitalized> Biotechniques 2001 Mar;30(3):634-6, 638, 640 passim 
 
 <Capitalized> Redefinition of the yeast two-hybrid system in dialogue with changing priorities in biological research. 
 
 <Capitalized> Serebriiskii <AllCaps> IG, <Capitalized> Khazak <PERSON  V,> <Capitalized> Golemis <AllCaps> EA. 
 
 <PERSON  Fox> <PERSON  Chase> <Capitalized> Cancer <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Philadelphia,> <AllCaps> PA, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Examination of the pattern of reagent creation and application in the two-hybrid system since 1989 reveals the expansion of a simple core technology to address increasingly sophisticated problems in protein interaction. <Capitalized> As the technology has matured, its clear suitability for large-scale proteomic projects has made a major focus of its application the generation of global organismal protein interaction networks. <Capitalized> In an inversion of emphasis, the increasing availability of such information now provides a master plan with the potential to specify the most promising directions for biological investigations (i.e., by directing the physiological validation of predicted critical protein-protein interactions). <Capitalized> Recent derivatives of the two-hybrid system enable the targeting of such key interactions by facilitating the identification of essential amino acids conferring protein interaction specificity and of small molecules that selectively disrupt defined interaction pairs. <Capitalized> Finally, the creation of mammalian expression systems based on two-hybrid principles became a new tool to create and probe novel biological systems. <Capitalized> Taken in sum, this trajectory emphasizes the point that the creation of tools and the evolution of the idea of what is an interesting biological problem are in intimate dialogue. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial 
 
 PMID: 11252799 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <Capitalized> Dipartimento di <Capitalized> Genetica e <Capitalized> Biologia <Capitalized> Molecolare, <Capitalized> Fondazione <Capitalized> Istituto <PERSON  Pasteur> -Fondazione <Capitalized> Cenci <Capitalized> Bolognetti, <Capitalized> Universita di <PERSON  Roma> <Capitalized> La <Capitalized> Sapienza, <Capitalized> Piazzale <AllCaps> A <PERSON  Moro> 5,00185, <PERSON  Roma,> <LOCATION Italy> 
 
 <Capitalized> The telomeres of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae are structurally and functionally well characterized. <Capitalized> Their telomeric <AllCaps> DNA is packaged by the protein Rap1p (repressor activator protein 1). Rap1p is a multifunctional, sequence-specific, DNA-binding protein which, besides participating in the regulation of telomeres structure and length, is also involved in transcriptional regulation of genes essential for cell growth and in silencing. <Capitalized> Whereas the long tracts of telomeric <AllCaps> DNA repeats of higher eukaryotes are mostly organized in closely spaced canonical nucleosomal arrays, it has been proposed that the 300 base-pairs of <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae telomeric <AllCaps> DNA are organized in a large non-nucleosomal structure that has been called the telosome. <Capitalized> Recently, nucleosomes have been found also in <Capitalized> Tetrahymena thermophila telomeres, suggesting that, in general, telomere structural differences between lower and higher eukaryotes could be quantitative, rather than qualitative. <Capitalized> Using an in vitro model system, we have addressed the question of whether Rap1p can form a stable ternary complex with nucleosomes containing telomeric binding sites, or competes with nucleosome core formation. <Capitalized> The approach we have taken is to place a single Rap1p-binding site at different positions within a nucleosome core and then test the binding of Rap1p and its DNA-binding domain (Rap1p-DBD). <Capitalized> We show here that both proteins are able to specifically recognize their nucleosomal binding site, but that binding is dependent on the location of the site within the nucleosome core structure. <Capitalized> These results show that a ternary complex between a nucleosome and Rap1p is stable and could be a possible intermediate between telomeric nucleosomes and telosomes in the dynamics of <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae telomere organization.

 264: <Capitalized> Biochem <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 2001;79(1):83-91 
 
 <AllCaps> A tale of two charges: distinct roles for an acidic and a basic amino acid in the structure and function of cytochrome c. 
 
 <PERSON  Parrish> <AllCaps> JC, <PERSON  Guillemette> <AllCaps> JG, <PERSON  Wallace> <AllCaps> CJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> Dalhousie <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Halifax, <AllCaps> NS, <PERSON Canada> 
 
 <Capitalized> Cytochrome c is a small electron transport protein found in the intermembrane space of mitochondria. <Capitalized> As it interacts with a number of different physiological partners in a specific fashion, its structure varies little over eukaryotic evolutionary history. <Capitalized> Two highly conserved residues found within its sequence are those at positions 13 and 90 (numbering is based on the standard horse cytochrome c); with single exceptions, residue 13 is either <Capitalized> Lys or <Capitalized> Arg, and residue 90 is either <Capitalized> Glu or <PERSON Asp> <Capitalized> There have been conflicting views on the roles to be ascribed to these residues, particularly residue 13, so the functional properties of a number of site-directed mutants of <Capitalized> Saccaromyces cerevisiae iso-1 cytochrome c have been examined. <Capitalized> Results indicate that the two residues do not interact specifically with each other; however, residue 13 (Arg) is likely to be involved in interactions between cytochrome c and other electrostatically oriented physiological partners (intermolecular), whereas residue 90 (Asp) is involved in maintaining the intrinsic structure and stability of cytochrome c (intramolecular). <Capitalized> This is supported by molecular dynamics simulations carried out for these mutants where removal of the negative charge at position 90 leads to significant shifts in the conformations of neighboring residues, particularly lysine 86. <PERSON  Both> charged residues appear to exert their effects through electrostatics; however, biological activity is significantly more sensitive to substitutions of residue 13 than of residue 90.

 <Capitalized> Identification of a structural motif that confers specific interaction with the <EndsInDigit> WD40 repeat domain of <Capitalized> Arabidopsis COP1. 
 
 <PERSON  Holm> <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Hardtke <AllCaps> CS, <PERSON  Gaudet> <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Deng <AllCaps> XW.

 <Capitalized> Arabidopsis <EndsInDigit> COP1 is a photomorphogenesis repressor capable of directly interacting with the photomorphogenesis-promoting factor HY5. <Capitalized> This interaction between <EndsInDigit> HY5 and <EndsInDigit> COP1 results in targeted deg radation of <EndsInDigit> HY5 by the 26S proteasome. <Capitalized> Here we characterized the <EndsInDigit> WD40 repeat domain-mediated interactions of <EndsInDigit> COP1 with <EndsInDigit> HY5 and two new proteins. <Capitalized> Mutational analysis of those interactive partners revealed a conserved motif responsible for the interaction with the <EndsInDigit> WD40 domain. <Capitalized> This novel motif, with the core sequence V-P-E/D-&phi;-G (&phi; = hydrophobic residue) in conjunction with an upstream stretch of 4-5 negatively charged residues, interacts with a defined surface area of the ss-propeller assembly of the <EndsInDigit> COP1 <EndsInDigit> WD40 repeat domain through both hydrophobic and ionic interactions. <Capitalized> Several residues in the <EndsInDigit> COP1 <EndsInDigit> WD40 domain that are critical for the interaction with this motif have been revealed. <Capitalized> The fact that point mutations either in the <EndsInDigit> COP1 <EndsInDigit> WD40 domain or in the <EndsInDigit> HY5 motif that abolish the interaction between <EndsInDigit> COP1 and <EndsInDigit> HY5 in yeast result in a dramatic reduction of <EndsInDigit> HY5 degradation in transgenic plants validates the biological significance of this defined interaction.

 Forkhead-associated (FHA) domains are modular protein-protein interaction domains of approximately 130 amino acids present in numerous signalling proteins. FHA-domain-dependent protein interactions are regulated by phosphorylation of target proteins and <AllCaps> FHA domains may be multifunctional phosphopeptide-recognition modules. <AllCaps> FHA domains of the budding yeast cell-cycle checkpoint protein kinases Dun1p and Rad53p have been crystallized. <Capitalized> Crystals of the Dun1-FHA domain exhibit the symmetry of the space group P6(1)22 or P6(5)22, with unit-cell parameters a = b = 127.3, c = 386.3 A; diffraction data have been collected to 3.1 <AllCaps> A resolution on a synchrotron source. <Capitalized> Crystals of the N-terminal <AllCaps> FHA domain (FHA1) of Rad53p diffract to 4.0 <AllCaps> A resolution on a laboratory X-ray source and have Laue-group symmetry 4/mmm, with unit-cell parameters a = b = 61.7, c = 104.3 <AllCaps> A.
