 <Capitalized> Genomic binding sites of the yeast cell-cycle transcription factors <AllCaps> SBF and <AllCaps> MBF. 
 
 <Capitalized> Iyer <AllCaps> VR, <Capitalized> Horak <AllCaps> CE, <Capitalized> Scafe <AllCaps> CS, <Capitalized> Botstein <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Snyder> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Brown> <AllCaps> PO. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <PERSON  Stanford> <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  California> 94305, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Proteins interact with genomic <AllCaps> DNA to bring the genome to life; and these interactions also define many functional features of the genome. <AllCaps> SBF and <AllCaps> MBF are sequence-specific transcription factors that activate gene expression during the G1/S transition of the cell cycle in yeast. <AllCaps> SBF is a heterodimer of Swi4 and Swi6, and <AllCaps> MBF is a heterodimer of <Capitalized> Mbpl and Swi6 (refs 1, 3). <Capitalized> The related Swi4 and Mbp1 proteins are the DNA-binding components of the respective factors, and Swi6 mayhave a regulatory function. <AllCaps> A small number of <AllCaps> SBF and <AllCaps> MBF target genes have been identified. <Capitalized> Here we define the genomic binding sites of the <AllCaps> SBF and <AllCaps> MBF transcription factors in vivo, by using <AllCaps> DNA microarrays. <Capitalized> In addition to the previously characterized targets, we have identified about 200 new putative targets. <Capitalized> Our results support the hypothesis that <AllCaps> SBF activated genes are predominantly involved in budding, and in membrane and cell-wall biosynthesis, whereas <AllCaps> DNA replication and repair are the dominant functions among <AllCaps> MBF activated genes. <Capitalized> The functional specialization of these factors may provide a mechanism for independent regulation of distinct molecular processes that normally occur in synchrony during the mitotic cell cycle.

 <Capitalized> Candida albicans: adherence, signaling and virulence. 
 
 <Capitalized> Calderone <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Suzuki <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Cannon> <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Cho <PERSON  T,> <PERSON  Boyd> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Calera <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Chibana <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Herman> <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Holmes> <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Jeng <AllCaps> HW, <Capitalized> Kaminishi <AllCaps> H, <LOCATION  Matsumoto> <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Mikami <PERSON  T,> O'Sullivan <AllCaps> JM, <Capitalized> Sudoh <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Suzuki <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Nakashima> <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Tanaka <PERSON  T,> <PERSON  Tompkins> <AllCaps> GR, <Capitalized> Watanabe <PERSON  T.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Immunology, <LOCATION  Georgetown> <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Washington,> <AllCaps> DC 20007, <LOCATION  USA.> calderor@gunet.georgetown.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> The focus of this symposium was to present new information on the morphogenesis of <Capitalized> Candida albicans, particularly how it relates to signal transduction pathways and other genes involved in the regulation of morphogenesis. <Capitalized> In addition, we discuss the role of adherence and colonization of the oral cavity by the organism and discuss the role of mannan as an adhesin that recognizes the human red blood cell. <AllCaps> C. albicans utilizes at least two signal pathways to regulate its conversion from a yeast form to filamentous growth (hyphae). <Capitalized> One of these two pathways is similar to the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae pseudohyphal/mating pathway, which utilizes the regulatory protein, Cphlp. <Capitalized> The other pathway is not totally defined but requires a second regulatory protein, referred to as Efg1p. <Capitalized> Other signal pathways may exist, which include a two-component histidine kinase and response regulator proteins. <Capitalized> The latter pathway(s) may include proteins such as Chk1p, Ssk1p, Shi1p and Cos1p/Nik1p. <Capitalized> Mutations in strains, which specifically target these proteins, result in morphogenesis defects and avirulence or attenuation of strains. <AllCaps> A growth regulatory gene has also been recently defined whose expression is associated with growth cessation and which appears to be a necessary prerequisite in conversion of the organism to a filamentous growth form. <Capitalized> Starvation of yeast cells induces exponentially grown cells (and usually non-germinative) to germinate. <Capitalized> This phenomenon is also observed in cells that are transiently treated with metabolic inhibitors. <Capitalized> During each of these treatments (starvation, metabolic inhibition), expression of a growth regulatory gene (CGRI) increases. <Capitalized> Adherence of <AllCaps> C. albicans to host cells and tissues is complex; several proteins, which appear to have host recognition functions, have been defined. <Capitalized> In the oral cavity, <AllCaps> C. albicans selectively adheres to salivary proteins, which are absorbed to many oral surfaces. <Capitalized> This mechanism enables the cells to colonize surfaces of the oral cavity. <Capitalized> An understanding of these interactions may lead to strategies to prevent oral disease. <Capitalized> Mannan from <AllCaps> C. albicans may provide a host recognition function for <AllCaps> C. albicans. <Capitalized> Recent experiments indicate that mannan binds to human red blood cells and causes hemolysis. <Capitalized> Binding of mannan to the band 3 protein of human red blood cells has been established. <Capitalized> This activity may be associated with the ability of the organism to utilize hemoglobin (and iron).

OsMADS14 and -15 are highly homologous to the maize <AllCaps> MADS box gene <EndsInDigit> ZAP1 which is an orthologue of the floral homeotic gene <EndsInDigit> APETALA1 (AP1). <Capitalized> Interactions among the three <AllCaps> MADS domain proteins were confirmed by in vitro experiments using GST-fused OsMADS1 expressed in <Capitalized> Escherichia coli and in vitro translated proteins of OsMADS14 and -15. <Capitalized> We determined which domains in OsMADS1, -14, and -15 were required for protein-protein interaction employing the two-hybrid system and pull-down experiments. <Capitalized> While the <AllCaps> K domain was essential for protein-protein interaction, a region preceded by the <AllCaps> K domain augmented this interaction. <Capitalized> Interestingly, the C-terminal region of OsMADS1 functioned as a transcriptional activation domain in yeast and mammalian cells, while, on the other hand, the <AllCaps> C domains of OsMADS14 and -15 exhibited only very weak transcriptional activator functionality, if any at all.

 <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> SOS recruitment system (SRS), a recently developed method for detecting protein-protein interactions, provides an attractive alternative to identify biologically important protein interactions. <Capitalized> In <AllCaps> SRS, the protein-protein interactions take place in the cytoplasm instead of the nucleus, as is the case in the conventional two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> Although the <AllCaps> SRS has overcome some of the disadvantages of the conventional two-hybrid system, it still has several problems and limitations. <Capitalized> Here, we describe a new protocol for <AllCaps> SRS library screening. <AllCaps> A new combination of growth media to avoid the tedious step of replica plating greatly increases the number of independent colonies in a single library screening. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we designed a pair of ras-specific primers and a one-step simple <AllCaps> PCR to rule out the most abundant false positive, the mammalian ras cDNA, in <AllCaps> SRS library screening.

 <Capitalized> Multidrug resistance in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae mainly results from the overexpression of genes coding for the membrane efflux pumps, the major facilitators and the <COMPANY  ABC> binding cassette transporters, under the control of key transcription regulators encoded by the <EndsInDigit> PDR1 and <EndsInDigit> PDR3 genes. Pdr3p transcriptional activator contains a weak activation domain near the N-terminal zinc finger, a central regulatory domain, and a strong activation domain near the carboxyl terminus. <Capitalized> Here we report the results of the mutational analysis of the C-terminal region of Pdr3p. <Capitalized> After in vitro mutagenesis of the <EndsInDigit> PDR3 gene six single amino acid substitutions were identified and resulted in resistance to cycloheximide, sulfomethuron methyl, 4-nitroquinoline oxide, fluconazole, mucidin, chloramphenicol and oligomycin. <Capitalized> All the C-terminal pdr3 mutant alleles also conferred multidrug resistance in the presence of the wild-type <EndsInDigit> PDR3 gene. <Capitalized> The pdr3 mutations resulted in overexpression of both the <EndsInDigit> PDR3 and <EndsInDigit> PDR5 genes as revealed by transactivation experiments involving the PDR3-lacZ and PDR5-lacZ fusion genes and <PERSON  Western> blot analyses using antibodies against Pdr5p. <PERSON  Most> of the C-terminal pdr3 mutations were found in two sequence stretches exhibiting a high degree of amino acid identity with Pdr1p indicating that they might play a significant role in protein-protein interactions during the initiation of transcription of genes involved in multidrug resistance.

 <AllCaps> A CD2-based model of yeast alpha-agglutinin elucidates solution properties and binding characteristics. 
 
 <Capitalized> Grigorescu <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Chen <AllCaps> MH, <Capitalized> Zhao <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Kahn> <AllCaps> PC, <Capitalized> Lipke <AllCaps> PN.

 <Capitalized> We have previously shown that the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell adhesion protein alpha-agglutinin has sequence characteristics of immunoglobulin-like proteins and have successfully modeled residues 200-325, based on the structure of immunoglobulin variable-type domains. <Capitalized> Alignments matching residues 20-200 of alpha-agglutinin with domains <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> II of members of the CD2/CD4 subfamily of the immunoglobulin superfamily showed > 80% conservation of key residues despite low sequence similarity overall. Three-dimensional models of two alpha-agglutinin domains constructed on the basis of these alignments were shown to conform to peptide mapping data and biophysical properties of alpha-agglutinin. <Capitalized> In addition, the residue volume and surface accessibility characteristics of these models resembled those of the well-packed structures of related proteins. Residue-by-residue analysis showed that packing and accessibility anomalies were largely confined to glycosylated and protease-susceptible loop regions of the domains. <Capitalized> Surface accessibility of hydrophobic residues was typical of proteins with extensive domain interactions, a finding compatible with the hydrodynamic properties of alpha -agglutinin and the hydrophobic nature of binding to its peptide ligand alpha-agglutinin. <Capitalized> The procedures used to align the alpha-agglutinin sequence and test the quality of the model may be applicable to other proteins, especially those that resist crystallization because of extensive glycosylation.

 <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid system has provided a convenient means to both screen for proteins that interact with a protein of interest and to characterise the known interaction between two proteins. <Capitalized> Several groups with an interest in the molecular mechanisms that underlie discrete steps along trafficking pathways have exploited the yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> Here, we provide a brief background to the technology, attempt to point out some of the pitfalls and benefits of the different systems that can be employed, and mention some of the areas (within the trafficking field) where yeast two-hybrid interaction assays have been particularly informative.

 <Capitalized> Enteropathogenic <Capitalized> Escherichia coli (EPEC) attaches intimately to mammalian cells via a bacterial outer membrane adhesion molecule, intimin, and its receptor in the host cell membrane, Tir. <Capitalized> Tir is a bacterial protein translocated into the host cell membrane and tyrosine phosphorylated after insertion. Tir-intimin binding induces organized actin polymerization beneath the adherent bacteria, resulting in the formation of pedestal-like structures. <AllCaps> A series of <Capitalized> Tir deletion derivatives were constructed to analyse which <Capitalized> Tir domains are involved in intimin binding. <Capitalized> We have localized the intimin-binding domain (IBD) of <Capitalized> Tir using a yeast two-hybrid system and a gel-overlay approach to a region of 109 amino acids that is predicted to be exposed on the surface of the plasma membrane. <AllCaps> A truncated <Capitalized> Tir protein lacking this domain was translocated to the host cell membrane and tyrosine phosphorylated, but failed to bind intimin or to induce either actin polymerization or <Capitalized> Tir accumulation beneath the bacteria. <Capitalized> These results indicate that only a small region of <Capitalized> Tir is needed to bind intimin and support the predicted topology for <Capitalized> Tir, with both N- and C-terminal regions in the mammalian cell cytosol. <Capitalized> They also confirm that Tir-intimin interactions are needed for cytoskeletal organization. <Capitalized> We have also identified N-terminal regions involved in <Capitalized> Tir stability and <Capitalized> Tir secretion to the media.

(1996) <Capitalized> Cancer Res. 56, 2809-2814]. <Capitalized> Compared to its parent compound, etoposide, TOP-53 is considerably more toxic to non-small cell lung cancer cells, is more active at generating chromosomal breaks, and displays improved cellular uptake and pharmacokinetics in animal lung tissues. <Capitalized> Despite the preclinical success of TOP-53, several questions remain regarding its cytotoxic mechanism. <Capitalized> Therefore, this study characterized the basis for drug action. <Capitalized> Results indicate that topoisomerase <AllCaps> II is the primary cytotoxic target for TOP-53. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the drug kills cells by acting as a topoisomerase <AllCaps> II poison.  Protein-protein interaction plays a major role in all biological processes. <Capitalized> The currently available genetic methods such as the two-hybrid system and the protein recruitment system are relatively limited in their ability to identify interactions with integral membrane proteins. <Capitalized> Here we describe the development of a reverse <PERSON  Ras> recruitment system (reverse RRS), in which the bait used encodes a membrane protein. <Capitalized> The bait is expressed in its natural environment, the membrane, whereas the protein partner (the prey) is fused to a cytoplasmic <PERSON  Ras> mutant. Protein-protein interaction between the proteins encoded by the prey and the bait results in <PERSON  Ras> membrane translocation and activation of a viability pathway in yeast. <Capitalized> We devised the expression of the bait and prey proteins under the control of dual distinct inducible promoters, thus enabling a rapid selection of transformants in which growth is attributed solely to specific protein-protein interaction. <Capitalized> The reverse <AllCaps> RRS approach greatly extends the usefulness of the protein recruitment systems and the use of integral membrane proteins as baits. <Capitalized> The system serves as an attractive approach to explore novel protein-protein interactions with high specificity and selectivity, where other methods fail.

 <Capitalized> Tryptophan fluorescence of yeast actin resolved via conserved mutations. 
 
 <PERSON  Doyle> <AllCaps> TC, <PERSON  Hansen> <AllCaps> JE, <Capitalized> Reisler <AllCaps> E. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry and <Capitalized> Biochemistry and the <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  Los Angeles,> <LOCATION  Los Angeles,> <LOCATION  California> 90095, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Actin contains four tryptophan residues, W79, W86, W340, and W356, all located in subdomain 1 of the protein. <Capitalized> Replacement of each of these residues with either tyrosine (W79Y and W356Y) or phenylalanine (W86F and W340F) generated viable proteins in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which, when purified, allowed the analysis of the contribution of these residues to the overall tryptophan fluorescence of actin. <Capitalized> The sum of the relative contributions of these tryptophans was found to account for the intrinsic fluorescence of wild-type actin, indicating that energy transfer between the tryptophans is not the main determinant of their quantum yield, and that these mutations induce little conformational change to the protein. <Capitalized> This was borne out by virtually identical polymerization rates and similar myosin interactions of each of the mutants and the wild-type actin. <Capitalized> In addition, these mutants allowed the dissection of the microenvironment of each tryptophan as actin undergoes conformational changes upon metal cation exchange and polymerization. <Capitalized> Based on the relative tryptophan contributions determined from single mutants, a triple mutant of yeast actin (W79) was generated that showed small intrinsic fluorescence and should be useful for studies of actin interactions with actin-binding proteins.

 <PERSON  Schirmer> <AllCaps> EC, <PERSON  Ware> <AllCaps> DM, <Capitalized> Queitsch <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Kowal <AllCaps> AS, <Capitalized> Lindquist <AllCaps> SL.

 <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Ligand and <Capitalized> Transcription, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Chonnam <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Kwangju 500-757, Korea. 
 
 ASC-2 is a recently isolated transcriptional cointegrator molecule, which is amplified in human cancers and stimulates transactivation by nuclear receptors, AP-1, nuclear factor <MixedCase> kappaB (NFkappaB), serum response factor (SRF), and numerous other transcription factors. ASC-2 contained two nuclear receptor-interaction domains, both of which are dependent on the integrity of their core <AllCaps> LXXLL sequences. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, the C-terminal <AllCaps> LXXLL motif specifically interacted with oxysterol receptor LXRss, whereas the N-terminal motif bound a broad range of nuclear receptors. <Capitalized> These interactions appeared to be essential because a specific subregion of ASC-2 including the N- or C-terminal <AllCaps> LXXLL motif acted as a potent dominant negative mutant with transactivation by appropriate nuclear receptors. <Capitalized> In addition, the autonomous transactivation domain (AD) of ASC-2 was found to consist of three separable subregions; i.e. AD1, AD2, and AD3. <Capitalized> In particular, <EndsInDigit> AD2 and <EndsInDigit> AD3 were binding sites for <AllCaps> CREB binding protein (CBP), and CBP-neutralizing E1A repressed the autonomous transactivation function of ASC-2. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the receptor transactivation was not enhanced by ASC-2 in the presence of E1A and significantly impaired by overexpressed AD2. <Capitalized> From these results, we concluded that ASC-2 directly binds to nuclear receptors and recruits <AllCaps> CBP to mediate the nuclear receptor transactivation in vivo.

 291: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 2001 <Capitalized> Feb 5;152(3):451-69 
 
 <AllCaps> A novel function of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <EndsInDigit> CDC5 in cytokinesis. 
 
 <PERSON  Song> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Lee> <AllCaps> KS. 
 
 <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Metabolism, <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Basic <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> Institutes of <Capitalized> Health, <Capitalized> Bethesda, <Capitalized> Maryland 20892, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Coordination of mitotic exit with timely initiation of cytokinesis is critical to ensure completion of mitotic events before cell division. <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae polo kinase Cdc5 functions in a pathway leading to the degradation of mitotic cyclin Clb2, thereby permitting mitotic exit. <Capitalized> Here we provide evidence that Cdc5 also plays a role in regulating cytokinesis and that an intact polo-box, a conserved motif in the noncatalytic COOH-terminal domain of Cdc5, is required for this event. <Capitalized> Depletion of Cdc5 function leads to an arrest in cytokinesis. <Capitalized> Overexpression of the COOH-terminal domain of Cdc5 (cdc5DeltaN), but not the corresponding polo-box mutant, resulted in connected cells. <Capitalized> These cells shared cytoplasms with incomplete septa, and possessed aberrant septin ring structures. <Capitalized> Provision of additional copies of endogenous <EndsInDigit> CDC5 remedied this phenotype, suggesting a dominant-negative inhibition of cytokinesis. <Capitalized> The polo-box-dependent interactions between Cdc5 and septins (Cdc11 and Cdc12) and genetic interactions between the dominant-negative cdc5DeltaN and Cyk2/Hof1 or Myo1 suggest that direct interactions between cdc5DeltaN and septins resulted in inhibition of Cyk2/Hof1- and Myo1-mediated cytokinetic pathways. <PERSON  Thus,> we propose that Cdc5 may coordinate mitotic exit with cytokinesis by participating in both anaphase promoting complex activation and a polo-box-dependent cytokinetic pathway.

 <Capitalized> Direct interactions of the five known <Capitalized> Fanconi anaemia proteins suggest a common functional pathway. 
 
 <PERSON  Medhurst> <AllCaps> AL, <PERSON  Huber> <AllCaps> PA, <Capitalized> Waisfisz <PERSON  Q,> de <PERSON  Winter> <AllCaps> JP, <PERSON  Mathew> <AllCaps> CG. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Medical and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, Guy's, King's and <Capitalized> St Thomas' <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, 8th <PERSON  Floor,> Guy's <PERSON  Tower,> Guy's <Capitalized> Hospital, <LOCATION  London> <EndsInDigit> SE1 9RT, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Fanconi anaemia (FA) is an autosomal recessive inherited disorder associated with a progressive aplastic anaemia, diverse congenital abnormalities and cancer. <Capitalized> The condition is genetically heterogeneous, with at least seven complementation groups (A-G) described. <Capitalized> Cells from individuals who are homozygous for mutations in <AllCaps> FA genes are characterized by chromosomal instability and hypersensitivity to <AllCaps> DNA interstrand crosslinking agents. <Capitalized> These features suggest a possible role for the encoded proteins in the recognition or repair of these lesions, but neither their function nor whether they operate in a concerted or discrete functional pathways is known. <Capitalized> The recent cloning of the <AllCaps> FANCF and <AllCaps> FANCE genes has allowed us to investigate the interaction of the proteins encoded by five of the seven complementation groups of <AllCaps> FA. <Capitalized> We used the yeast two-hybrid system and co-immunoprecipitation analysis to test the 10 possible pairs of proteins for direct interaction. <Capitalized> In addition to the previously described binding of <AllCaps> FANCA to <AllCaps> FANCG, we now demonstrate direct interaction of <AllCaps> FANCF with <AllCaps> FANCG, of <AllCaps> FANCC with <AllCaps> FANCE and a weaker interaction of <AllCaps> FANCE with both <AllCaps> FANCA and <AllCaps> FANCG. <Capitalized> These findings show that the newly identified <AllCaps> FANCE protein is an integral part of the <AllCaps> FA pathway, and support the concept of a functional link between all known proteins encoded by the genes that are mutated in this disorder. <Capitalized> These proteins may act either as a multimeric complex or by sequential recruitment of subsets of the proteins in a common pathway that protects the genomic integrity of mammalian cells.

 <Capitalized> Silencing of the cryptic mating-type locus <AllCaps> HMR requires recognition of a small <AllCaps> DNA sequence element, the <ContainsHyphen> HMR-E silencer, by the Sir1p, one of four <Capitalized> Sir proteins required for the assembly of silenced chromatin domains in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The Sir1p recognizes the silencer through interactions with the origin recognition complex (ORC), a protein complex that binds the silencer <AllCaps> DNA directly. Sir1p was physically associated with <AllCaps> HMR in chromatin, and this association required a Sir1p-ORC interaction, suggesting that it reflected the Sir1p silencer-recognition function required for silencing. Sir1p was not associated with nonsilencer replication origins that bind the <AllCaps> ORC, indicating that a Sir1p-ORC interaction is confined to silencers. <Capitalized> Significantly, the other <AllCaps> SIR genes were required for Sir1p's association with <AllCaps> HMR. <PERSON  Thus,> multiple protein contacts required for and unique to silent chromatin may confine a Sir1p-ORC interaction to silencers. <Capitalized> The Sir1p was present at extremely low concentrations in yeast cells yet was associated with <AllCaps> HMR at all stages of the cell cycle examined. <Capitalized> These data provide insights into the mechanisms that establish and restrict the assembly of silenced chromatin to only a few discrete chromosomal domains.

 <LOCATION  Komatsu> <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Tanida <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Ueno <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Ohsumi <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Ohsumi <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Kominami <AllCaps> E. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> Juntendo <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  Tokyo> 113-8421, <LOCATION Japan> 
 
 Apg7p/Cvt2p, a protein-activating enzyme, is essential for both the Apg12p-Apg5p conjugation system and the Apg8p membrane targeting in autophagy and cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Similar to the ubiquitin-conjugating system, both Apg12p and Apg8p are activated by Apg7p, an E1-like enzyme. Apg12p is then transferred to Apg10p, an E2-like enzyme, and conjugated with Apg5p, whereas Apg8p is transferred to Apg3p, another E2-like enzyme, followed by conjugation with phosphatidylethanolamine. <Capitalized> Evidence is presented here that Apg7p forms a homodimer with two active-site cysteine residues via the C-terminal region. <Capitalized> The dimerization of Apg7p is independent of the other <Capitalized> Apg proteins and facilitated by overexpressed Apg12p. <Capitalized> The C-terminal 123 amino acids of Apg7p (residues 508 to 630 out of 630 amino acids) are sufficient for its dimerization, where there is neither an <AllCaps> ATP binding domain nor an active-site cysteine essential for its <EndsInDigit> E1 activity. <Capitalized> The deletion of its carboxyl 40 amino acids (residues 591-630 out of 630 amino acids) results in several defects of not only Apg7p dimerization but also interactions with two substrates, Apg12p and Apg8p and Apg12p-Apg5p conjugation, whereas the mutant Apg7p contains both an <AllCaps> ATP binding domain and an active-site cysteine. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the carboxyl 40 amino acids of Apg7p are also essential for the interaction of Apg7p with Apg3p to form the E1-E2 complex for Apg8p. <Capitalized> These results suggest that Apg7p forms a homodimer via the C-terminal region and that the C-terminal region is essential for both the activity of the <EndsInDigit> E1 enzyme for Apg12p and Apg8p as well as the formation of an E1-E2 complex for Apg8p.

 <Capitalized> Molecular dissection of interactions between Rad51 and members of the recombination-repair group. 
 
 <Capitalized> Krejci <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Damborsky <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Thomsen> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Duno <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Bendixen <AllCaps> C.

 <Capitalized> Recombination is important for the repair of <AllCaps> DNA damage and for chromosome segregation during meiosis; it has also been shown to participate in the regulation of cell proliferation. <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, recombination requires products of the <EndsInDigit> RAD52 epistasis group. <Capitalized> The Rad51 protein associates with the Rad51, Rad52, Rad54, and Rad55 proteins to form a dynamic complex. <Capitalized> We describe a new strategy to screen for mutations which cause specific disruption of the interaction between certain proteins in the complex, leaving other interactions intact. <Capitalized> This approach defines distinct protein interaction domains and protein relationships within the Rad51 complex. <Capitalized> Alignment of the mutations onto the constructed three-dimensional model of the Rad51 protein reveal possible partially overlapping interfaces for the Rad51-Rad52 and the Rad51-Rad54 interactions. Rad51-Rad55 and Rad51-Rad51 interactions are affected by the same spectrum of mutations, indicating similarity between the two modes of binding. <Capitalized> Finally, the detection of a subset of mutations within Rad51 which disrupt the interaction with mutant Rad52 protein but activate the interaction with Rad54 suggests that dynamic changes within the Rad51 protein may contribute to an ordered reaction process.

 <Capitalized> Mitotic spindle integrity and kinetochore function linked by the Duo1p/Dam1p complex. 
 
 <PERSON  Cheeseman> <AllCaps> IM, Enquist-Newman <AllCaps> M, Muller-Reichert <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Drubin <AllCaps> DG, <PERSON  Barnes> <AllCaps> G. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California> at <LOCATION  Berkeley,> <LOCATION  Berkeley,> <LOCATION  California> 94720, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Duo1p and Dam1p were previously identified as spindle proteins in the budding yeast, <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Here, analyses of a diverse collection of duo1 and dam1 alleles were used to develop a deeper understanding of the functions and interactions of Duo1p and Dam1p. <Capitalized> Based on the similarity of mutant phenotypes, genetic interactions between duo1 and dam1 alleles, interdependent localization to the mitotic spindle, and Duo1p/Dam1p coimmunoprecipitation from yeast protein extracts, these analyses indicated that Duo1p and Dam1p perform a shared function in vivo as components of a protein complex. Duo1p and Dam1p are not required to assemble bipolar spindles, but they are required to maintain metaphase and anaphase spindle integrity. <Capitalized> Immunofluorescence and electron microscopy of duo1 and dam1 mutant spindles revealed a diverse variety of spindle defects. <Capitalized> Our results also indicate a second, previously unidentified, role for the Duo1p/Dam1p complex. duo1 and dam1 mutants show high rates of chromosome missegregation, premature anaphase events while arrested in metaphase, and genetic interactions with a subset of kinetochore components consistent with a role in kinetochore function. <Capitalized> In addition, Duo1p and Dam1p localize to kinetochores in chromosome spreads, suggesting that this complex may serve as a link between the kinetochore and the mitotic spindle.

 298: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 2001 <PERSON  Jan> 8;152(1):51-64 
 
 <Capitalized> Membrane recruitment of Aut7p in the autophagy and cytoplasm to vacuole targeting pathways requires Aut1p, Aut2p, and the autophagy conjugation complex. 
 
 <PERSON  Kim> <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Huang <AllCaps> WP, <Capitalized> Klionsky <AllCaps> DJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor,> <LOCATION  Michigan> 48109, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Autophagy is a degradative pathway by which cells sequester nonessential, bulk cytosol into double-membrane vesicles (autophagosomes) and deliver them to the vacuole for recycling. <Capitalized> Using this strategy, eukaryotic cells survive periods of nutritional starvation. <Capitalized> Under nutrient-rich conditions, autophagy machinery is required for the delivery of a resident vacuolar hydrolase, aminopeptidase <AllCaps> I, by the cytoplasm to vacuole targeting (Cvt) pathway. <Capitalized> In both pathways, the vesicle formation process requires the function of the starvation-induced Aut7 protein, which is recruited from the cytosol to the forming <Capitalized> Cvt vesicles and autophagosomes. <Capitalized> The membrane binding of Aut7p represents an early step in vesicle formation. <Capitalized> In this study, we identify several requirements for Aut7p membrane association. <Capitalized> After synthesis in the cytosol, Aut7p is proteolytically cleaved in an Aut2p-dependent manner. <Capitalized> While this novel processing event is essential for Aut7p membrane binding, Aut7p must undergo additional physical interactions with Aut1p and the autophagy (Apg) conjugation complex before recruitment to the membrane. <PERSON  Lack> of these interactions results in a cytosolic distribution of Aut7p rather than localization to forming <Capitalized> Cvt vesicles and autophagosomes. <Capitalized> This study assigns a functional role for the <Capitalized> Apg conjugation system as a mediator of Aut7p membrane recruitment. <PERSON  Further,> we demonstrate that Aut1p, which physically interacts with components of the <Capitalized> Apg conjugation complex and Aut7p, constitutes an additional factor required for Aut7p membrane recruitment. <Capitalized> These findings define a series of steps that results in the modification of Aut7p and its subsequent binding to the sequestering transport vesicles of the autophagy and cytoplasm to vacuole targeting pathways.

 299: <Capitalized> Biochemistry 2001 <PERSON  Jan> 16;40(2):422-8 
 
 <Capitalized> Interactions between yeast iso-1-cytochrome c and its peroxidase. 
 
 <Capitalized> Pielak <AllCaps> GJ, <PERSON  Wang> <PERSON  X.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  North Carolina> at <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <LOCATION  North Carolina> 27599-3290, <LOCATION  USA.> gary_pielak@unc.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> Isothermal titration calorimetry was used to study the formation of 19 complexes involving yeast iso-1-ferricytochrome c (Cc) and ferricytochrome c peroxidase (CcP). <Capitalized> The complexes comprised combinations of the wild-type proteins, six CcP variants, and three <Capitalized> Cc variants. <Capitalized> Sixteen protein combinations were designed to probe the crystallographically defined interface between <Capitalized> Cc and CcP. <Capitalized> The data show that the high-affinity sites on <Capitalized> Cc and CcP coincide with the crystallographically defined sites. <Capitalized> Changing charged residues to alanine increases the enthalpy of complex formation by a constant amount, but the decrease in stability depends on the location of the amino acid substitution. <Capitalized> Deleting methyl groups has a small effect on the binding enthalpy and a larger deleterious effect on the binding free energy, consistent with model studies of the hydrophobic effect, and showing that nonpolar interactions also stabilize the complex. Double-mutant cycles were used to determine the coupling energies for nine Cc-CcP residue pairs. <Capitalized> Comparing these energies to the crystal structure of the complex leads to the conclusion that many of the substitutions induce a rearrangement of the complex.

 <Capitalized> The bI4 group <AllCaps> I intron binds directly to both its protein splicing partners, a <MixedCase> tRNA synthetase and maturase, to facilitate <AllCaps> RNA splicing activity.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  Houston,> <LOCATION  Texas> 77204-5513, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The imported mitochondrial leucyl-tRNA synthetase (NAM2p) and a mitochondrial-expressed intron-encoded maturase protein are required for splicing the fourth intron (bI4) of the yeast cob gene, which expresses an electron transfer protein that is essential to respiration. <Capitalized> However, the role of the <MixedCase> tRNA synthetase, as well as the function of the bI4 maturase, remain unclear. <Capitalized> As a first step towards elucidating the mechanistic role of these protein splicing factors in this group <AllCaps> I intron splicing reaction, we tested the hypothesis that both leucyl-tRNA synthetase and bI4 maturase interact directly with the bI4 intron. <Capitalized> We developed a yeast three-hybrid system and determined that both the <MixedCase> tRNA synthetase and bI4 maturase can bind directly and independently via RNA-protein interactions to the large bI4 group <AllCaps> I intron. <Capitalized> We also showed, using modified two-hybrid and three-hybrid assays, that the bI4 intron bridges interactions between the two protein splicing partners. <Capitalized> In the presence of either the bI4 maturase or the Leu-tRNA synthetase, bI4 intron transcribed recombinantly with flanking exons in the yeast nucleus exhibited splicing activity. <Capitalized> These data combined with previous genetic results are consistent with a novel model for a ternary splicing complex (two protein: one RNA) in which both protein splicing partners bind directly to the bI4 intron and facilitate its self-splicing activity.

 Rsp5p, ubiquitin-protein ligase, an enzyme of the ubiquitination pathway, contains three <AllCaps> WW domains that mediate protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> To determine if these domains adapt Rsp5p to a subset of substrates involved in numerous cellular processes, we generated mutations in individual or combinations of the <AllCaps> WW domains. <Capitalized> The rsp5-w1, rsp5-w2, and rsp5-w3 mutant alleles complement <EndsInDigit> RSP5 deletions at 30 degrees. <PERSON  Thus,> individual <AllCaps> WW domains are not essential. <Capitalized> Each rsp5-w mutation caused temperature-sensitive growth. <Capitalized> Among variants with mutations in multiple <AllCaps> WW domains, only rsp5-w1w2 complemented the deletion. <PERSON  Thus,> the <EndsInDigit> WW3 domain is sufficient for Rsp5p essential functions. <Capitalized> To determine whether rsp5-w mutations affect endocytosis, fluid phase and uracil permease (Fur4p) endocytosis was examined. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> WW3 domain is important for both processes. <EndsInDigit> WW2 appears not to be important for fluid phase endocytosis whereas it is important for Fur4p endocytosis. <Capitalized> In contrast, the <EndsInDigit> WW1 domain affects fluid phase endocytosis, but it does not appear to function in Fur4p endocytosis. <PERSON  Thus,> various <AllCaps> WW domains play different roles in the endocytosis of these two substrates.  <Capitalized> Since the identification of the first histone deacetylase (Taunton et al., <Capitalized> Science 272, 408-411), several new members have been isolated. <Capitalized> They can loosely be separated into entities on the basis of their similarity to various yeast histone deacetylases. <Capitalized> The first class is represented by its closeness to the yeast Rpd3-like proteins, and the second most recently discovered class has similarities to yeast Hda1-like proteins. <Capitalized> However, due to the fact that several different research groups isolated the Hda1-like histone deacetylases independently, there have been various different nomenclatures used to describe the various members, which can lead to confusion in the interpretation of this family's functions and interactions. <Capitalized> With the discovery of another novel murine histone deacetylase, homologous to yeast Sir2, the number of members of this family is set to increase, as 7 human homologues of this gene have been isolated. <Capitalized> In the light of these recent discoveries, we have examined the literature data and conducted a database analysis of the isolated histone deacetylases and potential candidates. <Capitalized> The results obtained suggest that the number of histone deacetylases within the human genome may be as high as 17 and are discussed in relation to their homology to the yeast histone deacetylases. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Mapping the <AllCaps> DNA topoisomerase <AllCaps> III binding domain of the Sgs1 <AllCaps> DNA helicase. 
 
 <PERSON  Fricke> <AllCaps> WM, <Capitalized> Kaliraman <PERSON  V,> <Capitalized> Brill <AllCaps> SJ.

 <Capitalized> Several members of the RecQ family of <AllCaps> DNA helicases are known to interact with <AllCaps> DNA topoisomerase <AllCaps> III (Top3). <Capitalized> Here we show that the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Sgs1 and Top3 proteins physically interact in cell extracts and bind directly in vitro. Sgs1 and Top3 proteins coimmunoprecipitate from cell extracts under stringent conditions, indicating that Sgs1 and Top3 are present in a stable complex. <Capitalized> The domain of Sgs1 which interacts with Top3 was identified by expressing Sgs1 truncations in yeast. <Capitalized> The results indicate that the NH(2)-terminal 158 amino acids of Sgs1 are sufficient for the high affinity interaction between Sgs1 and Top3. <Capitalized> In vitro assays using purified Top3 and NH(2)-terminal Sgs1 fragments demonstrate that at least part of the interaction is through direct protein-protein interactions with these 158 amino acids. <Capitalized> Consistent with these physical data, we find that mutant phenotypes caused by a point mutation or small deletions in the Sgs1 NH(2) terminus can be suppressed by Top3 overexpression. <Capitalized> We conclude that Sgs1 and Top3 form a tight complex in vivo and that the first 158 amino acids of Sgs1 are necessary and sufficient for this interaction. <PERSON  Thus,> a primary role of the Sgs1 amino terminus is to mediate the Top3 interaction.

 <Capitalized> Replication factor <AllCaps> C (RFC) is an essential, multi-subunit ATPase that functions in <AllCaps> DNA replication, <AllCaps> DNA repair, and <AllCaps> DNA metabolism-related checkpoints. <Capitalized> In order to investigate how the individual <AllCaps> RFC subunits contribute to these functions in vivo, we undertook a genetic analysis of <AllCaps> RFC genes from budding yeast. <Capitalized> We isolated and characterized mutations in the <EndsInDigit> RFC5 gene that could suppress the cold-sensitive phenotype of rfc1-1 mutants. <Capitalized> Analysis of the <EndsInDigit> RFC5 suppressors revealed that they could not suppress the elongated telomere phenotype, the sensitivity to <AllCaps> DNA damaging agents, or the mutator phenotype of rfc1-1 mutants. <Capitalized> Unlike the checkpoint-defective rfc5-1 mutation, the <EndsInDigit> RFC5 suppressor mutations did not interfere with the methylmethane sulfonate- or hydroxyurea-induced phosphorylation of Rad53p. <Capitalized> The Rfc5p suppressor substitutions mapped to amino acid positions in the conserved <AllCaps> RFC box motifs IV-VII. <Capitalized> Comparisons of the structures of related <AllCaps> RFC box-containing proteins suggest that these <AllCaps> RFC motifs may function to coordinate interactions between neighboring subunits of multi-subunit ATPases.

 <Capitalized> Cooperative <AllCaps> DNA binding is thought to contribute to the ability of the <Capitalized> Drosophila melanogaster protein, <Capitalized> Bicoid, to stimulate transcription of target genes in precise sub-domains within the embryo. <Capitalized> As a first step toward testing this idea, we devised a genetic screen to isolate mutations in <Capitalized> Bicoid that specifically disrupt cooperative interactions, but do not disrupt <AllCaps> DNA recognition or transcription activation. <Capitalized> The screen was carried out in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and 12 cooperativity mutants were identified. <Capitalized> The mutations map across most of the <Capitalized> Bicoid protein, with some located within the DNA-binding domain (homeodomain). <Capitalized> Four homeodomain mutants were characterized in yeast and shown to activate a single-site reporter gene to levels comparable to that of wild-type, indicating that <AllCaps> DNA binding per se is not affected. <Capitalized> However, these mutants failed to show cooperative coupling between high and low-affinity sites, and showed reduced activation of a reporter gene carrying a natural <Capitalized> Drosophila enhancer. <Capitalized> Homology modeling indicated that none of the four mutations is in residues that contact <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Instead, these residues are likely to interact with other DNA-bound <Capitalized> Bicoid monomers or other parts of the <Capitalized> Bicoid protein. <Capitalized> In vitro, the isolated homeodomains did not show strong cooperativity defects, supporting the idea that other regions of <Capitalized> Bicoid are also important for cooperativity. <Capitalized> This study describes the first systematic screen to identify cooperativity mutations in a eukaryotic DNA-binding protein. <Capitalized> Copyright 2001 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae responds to mating pheromones by activating a receptor-G-protein-coupled mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade that is also used by other signaling pathways. <Capitalized> The activation of the <AllCaps> MAPK cascade may involve conformational changes through prebound receptor and heterotrimeric G-protein. <AllCaps> G beta may then recruit Cdc42-bound <AllCaps> MAPKKKK Ste20 to <AllCaps> MAPKKK Ste11 through direct interactions with Ste20 and the Ste5 scaffold. Ste20 activates Ste11 by derepressing an autoinhibitory domain. <Capitalized> An underlying nuclear shuttling machinery may be required for proper recruitment of Ste5 to <AllCaps> G beta. <Capitalized> Subsequent polarized growth is mediated by a similar mechanism involving Far1, which binds <AllCaps> G beta in addition to Cdc24 and Bem1. Far1 and Cdc24 also undergo nuclear shuttling and the nuclear pool of Far1 may temporally regulate access of Cdc24 to the cell cortex.

 <Capitalized> The 110 <MixedCase> kDa spindle pole body component, Spc110p, is an essential target of calmodulin in budding yeast. <Capitalized> Cells with mutations which reduce calmodulin binding to Spc110p are unable to form a mitotic spindle and die. <Capitalized> Here we show that these effects can be overcome either directly by increasing extracellular calcium or calmodulin expression, which reverse the primary spindle defect, or indirectly through increased extracellular osmolarity or high dosage of <EndsInDigit> MID2 or SLG1/HCS77/WSC1 which preserve viability. <Capitalized> We propose that overcoming a cell integrity defect associated with the mitotic arrest enables the defective spindle pole bodies to provide sufficient function for proliferation of a large proportion of mutant cells. <Capitalized> Our findings demonstrate a role for calcium in the Spc110p-calmodulin interaction in vivo and have important general implications for the interpretation of genetic interactions involving cell integrity genes.

 311: <Capitalized> Biochim <Capitalized> Biophys <Capitalized> Acta 2000 <Capitalized> Dec 11;1499(1-2):63-73 
 
 <Capitalized> Oligomerization properties of the acidic ribosomal P-proteins from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae: effect of P1A protein phosphorylation on the formation of the P1A-P2B hetero-complex. 
 
 <Capitalized> Tchorzewski <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Boguszewska <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Dukowski <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Grankowski <AllCaps> N. 
 
 <PERSON  Maria> Curie-Skllodowska <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Akademicka <PERSON  Street> 19, 20-033, <LOCATION  Lublin,> <PERSON Poland> 
 
 <Capitalized> Acidic ribosomal P-proteins form, in all eukaryotic cells, a lateral protuberance, the so-called 'stalk', which is directly involved in translational activity of the ribosomes. <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells, there are four distinct P-proteins: P1A, P1B, P2A and P2B. <Capitalized> In spite of the high level of their structural homology, they are not completely equivalent and may perform different functions. <Capitalized> As yet, the protein-protein interactions between yeast P-proteins have not been fully defined. <Capitalized> In this paper, the interplay between yeast P-proteins has been investigated by means of a two-hybrid system, chemical cross-linking and gel filtration. <Capitalized> The data presented herein show that all P-proteins are able to form homo-oligomeric complexes. <Capitalized> By analyzing hetero-interactions, we were able to detect strong interactions between P1A and P2B proteins. <Capitalized> Additionally, the pair of P1B and P2A proteins is also able to form a hetero-complex, though at a very low efficiency. <Capitalized> All P-proteins are phosphorylated by numerous protein kinases. <Capitalized> Using the multifunctional protein kinase <AllCaps> CK <AllCaps> II, we have shown that incorporation of phosphate into P1A protein can exert its effect on the hetero-oligomerization process, namely by preventing the formation of the hetero-oligomer P1A-P/P2B. <Capitalized> These findings are the first to show differences in the oligomerization behavior of the yeast P-proteins; moreover, they emphasize a significant impact of the phosphorylation on the formations of P-protein complex.

 <Capitalized> Calcium is a critical component in a number of plant signal transduction pathways. <AllCaps> A new family of calcium sensors called calcineurin B-like proteins (AtCBLs) have been recently identified from Arabidopsis. <Capitalized> These calcium sensors have been shown to interact with a family of protein kinases (CIPKs). <Capitalized> Here we report that each individual member of AtCBL family specifically interacts with a subset of CIPKs and present structural basis for the interaction and for the specificity underlying these interactions. <Capitalized> Although the C-terminal region of CIPKs is responsible for interaction with AtCBLs, the N-terminal region of CIPKs is also involved in determining the specificity of such interaction. <Capitalized> We have also shown that all three EF-hand motifs in AtCBL members are required for the interaction with CIPKs. <Capitalized> Several AtCBL members failed to interact with any of the CIPKs presented in this study, suggesting that these AtCBL members either have other CIPKs as targets or they target distinct proteins other than CIPKs. <Capitalized> These results may provide structural basis for the functional specificity of <AllCaps> CBL family of calcium sensors and their targets.

 <Capitalized> Chial <AllCaps> HJ, Stemm-Wolf <AllCaps> AJ, McBratney <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Winey <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <PERSON  Present> address: <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> St <PERSON  Olaf> <Capitalized> College, <Capitalized> Northfield, <LOCATION  Minnesota> 55057-1098, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <AllCaps> A rate-limiting step during translation initiation in eukaryotic cells involves binding of the initiation factor eIF4E to the 7-methylguanosine-containing cap of mRNAs. <Capitalized> Overexpression of eIF4E leads to malignant transformation [1-3], and eIF4E is elevated in many human cancers [4-7]. <Capitalized> In mammalian cells, three eIF4E-binding proteins each interact with eIF4E and inhibit its function [8-10]. <Capitalized> In yeast, <EndsInDigit> EAP1 encodes a protein that binds eIF4E and inhibits cap-dependent translation in vitro [11]. <AllCaps> A point mutation in the canonical eIF4E-binding motif of Eap1p blocks its interaction with eIF4E [11]. <Capitalized> Here, we characterized the genetic interactions between <EndsInDigit> EAP1 and NDC1, a gene whose function is required for duplication of the spindle pole body (SPB) [12], the centrosome-equivalent organelle in yeast that functions as the centrosome. <Capitalized> We found that the deletion of <EndsInDigit> EAP1 is lethal when combined with the ndc1-1 mutation. <Capitalized> Mutations in <EndsInDigit> NDC1 or altered <EndsInDigit> NDC1 gene dosage lead to genetic instability [13,14]. <Capitalized> Yeast strains lacking <EndsInDigit> EAP1 also exhibit genetic instability. <Capitalized> We tested whether these phenotypes are due to loss of <EndsInDigit> EAP1 function in regulating translation. <Capitalized> We found that both the synthetic lethal phenotype and the genetic instability phenotypes are rescued by a mutant allele of <EndsInDigit> EAP1 that is unable to bind eIF4E. <Capitalized> Our findings suggest that Eap1p carries out an eIF4E-independent function to maintain genetic stability, most likely involving SPBs.

 <Capitalized> Skeletal muscle differentiation is controlled by interactions between myocyte enhancer factor-2 (MEF2) and myogenic basic helix-loop-helix transcription factors. <Capitalized> Association of <EndsInDigit> MEF2 with histone deacetylases (HDAC) -4 and -5 results in repression of <EndsInDigit> MEF2 target genes and inhibition of myogenesis. Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase (CaMK) signaling promotes myogenesis by disrupting MEF2-HDAC complexes and stimulating <AllCaps> HDAC nuclear export. <Capitalized> To further define the mechanisms that confer CaMK responsiveness to <EndsInDigit> HDAC4 and -5, we performed yeast two-hybrid screens to identify HDAC-interacting factors. <Capitalized> These screens revealed interactions between <EndsInDigit> HDAC4 and members of the 14-3-3 family of proteins, which function as signal-dependent intracellular chaperones. <EndsInDigit> HDAC4 binds constitutively to 14-3-3 in yeast and mammalian cells, whereas <EndsInDigit> HDAC5 binding to 14-3-3 is largely dependent on CaMK signaling. CaMK phosphorylates serines -259 and -498 in HDAC5, which subsequently serve as docking sites for 14-3-3. <Capitalized> Our studies suggest that 14-3-3 binding to <EndsInDigit> HDAC5 is required for CaMK-dependent disruption of MEF2-HDAC complexes and nuclear export of HDAC5, and implicate 14-3-3 as a signal-dependent regulator of muscle cell differentiation.

 Nonsense-mediated <MixedCase> mRNA decay (NMD), also called <MixedCase> mRNA surveillance, is an important pathway used by all organisms that have been tested to degrade <MixedCase> mRNAs that prematurely terminate translation and, as a consequence, eliminate the production of aberrant proteins that could be potentially harmful. <Capitalized> In mammalian cells, <AllCaps> NMD appears to involve splicing-dependent alterations to <MixedCase> mRNA as well as ribosome-associated components of the translational apparatus. <Capitalized> To date, human <PERSON (h)> Upf1 protein (p) (hUpf1p), a group 1 <AllCaps> RNA helicase named after its <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae orthologue that functions in both translation termination and <AllCaps> NMD, has been the only factor shown to be required for <AllCaps> NMD in mammalian cells. <Capitalized> Here, we describe human orthologues to <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae Upf2p and <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae Upf3p (Caenorhabditis elegans SMG-4) based on limited amino acid similarities. <Capitalized> The existence of these orthologues provides evidence for a higher degree of evolutionary conservation of <AllCaps> NMD than previously appreciated. <Capitalized> Interestingly, human orthologues to <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae Upf3p (C. elegans SMG-4) derive from two genes, one of which is X-linked and both of which generate multiple isoforms due to alternative pre-mRNA splicing. <Capitalized> We demonstrate using immunoprecipitations of epitope-tagged proteins transiently produced in HeLa cells that hUpf2p interacts with hUpf1p, hUpf3p-X, and hUpf3p, and we define the domains required for the interactions. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we find by using indirect immunofluorescence that hUpf1p is detected only in the cytoplasm, hUpf2p is detected primarily in the cytoplasm, and hUpf3p-X localizes primarily to nuclei. <Capitalized> The finding that hUpf3p-X is a shuttling protein provides additional indication that <AllCaps> NMD has both nuclear and cytoplasmic components.

 <Capitalized> Xie <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Ding> <AllCaps> FX, <PERSON  Schreiber> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Eng <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Liu> <AllCaps> SF, <Capitalized> Arshava <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Arevalo> <AllCaps> E, <PERSON  Becker> <AllCaps> JM, <Capitalized> Naider <AllCaps> F. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Staten <Capitalized> Island <Capitalized> Staten <Capitalized> Island, <LOCATION  New York> 10314, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The Ste2p receptor for alpha-factor, a tridecapeptide mating pheromone of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, belongs to the <AllCaps> G protein-coupled family of receptors. <Capitalized> In this paper we report on the synthesis of peptides corresponding to five of the seven transmembrane domains (M1-M5) and two homologues of the sixth transmembrane domain corresponding to the wild-type sequence and a mutant sequence found in a constitutively active receptor. <Capitalized> The secondary structures of all new transmembrane peptides and previously synthesized peptides corresponding to domains 6 and 7 were assessed using a detailed <AllCaps> CD analysis in trifluoroethanol, trifluoroethanol-water mixtures, sodium dodecyl sulfate micelles, and dimyristoyl phosphatidyl choline bilayers. <Capitalized> Tryptophan fluorescence quenching experiments were used to assess the penetration of the membrane peptides into lipid bilayers. <Capitalized> All peptides were predominantly (40-80%) helical in trifluoroethanol and most trifluoroethanol-water mixtures. <Capitalized> In contrast, two of the peptides M3-35 <Capitalized> Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis showed that these two peptides formed high molecular aggregates in the presence of <AllCaps> SDS whereas all other peptides moved as monomeric species. <Capitalized> The peptide (KKKFDSFHILLIMSAQSLLVLSIIFILAYSLKKKS) corresponding to the sequence in the constitutive mutant was predominantly helical under a variety of conditions, whereas the homologous wild-type sequence (KKKFDSFHILLIMSAQSLLVPSIIFILAYSLKKKS) retained a tendency to form beta-structures. <Capitalized> These results demonstrate a connection between a conformational shift in secondary structure, as detected by biophysical techniques, and receptor function. <Capitalized> The aggregation of particular transmembrane domains may also reflect a tendency for intermolecular interactions that occur in the membrane environment facilitating formation of receptor dimers or multimers.

 318: <Capitalized> Biochim <Capitalized> Biophys <Capitalized> Acta 2000 <Capitalized> Dec 15;1529(1-3):63-88 
 
 <Capitalized> Sterol methyl transferase: enzymology and inhibition. 
 
 <Capitalized> Nes <AllCaps> WD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry and <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Tech <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Lubbock,> <AllCaps> TX, 79409-1061, <LOCATION  USA.> u0nes@ttacs.ttu.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> Sterol C-methylations catalyzed by the (S)-adenosyl-L-methionine: Delta(24)-sterol methyl transferase (SMT) have provided the focus for study of electrophilic alkylations, a reaction type of functional importance in <ContainsHyphen> C-C bond formation of natural products. SMTs occur generally in nature, but do not occur in animal systems, suggesting that the difference in sterol synthetic pathways can be exploited therapeutically and in insect-plant interactions. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> SMT genes from several plants and fungi have been cloned, sequenced and expressed in bacteria or yeast and bioengineered into tobacco or tomato plants. <Capitalized> These enzymes share significant amino acid sequence similarity in the putative sterol and AdoMet binding sites. <Capitalized> Investigations of the molecular recognition of sterol fitness and studies with stereospecifically labeled substrates as well as various sterol analogs assayed with native or mutant SMTs from fungi and plants have been carried out recently in our own and other laboratories. <Capitalized> These analyses have led to an active-site model, referred to as the 'steric-electric plug' model, which is consistent with a non-covalent mechanism involving the intermediacy of a 24beta-methyl (or ethyl) sterol bound to the ternary complex. <Capitalized> Despite the seeming differences between fungal and plant <AllCaps> SMT activities the recent data indicate that a distinct <AllCaps> SMT or family of SMTs exist in these organisms which bind and transform sterols according to a similar mechanistic plan. <Capitalized> Vascular plants have been found to express different complements of C(1)/C(2)-activities in the form of at least three <AllCaps> SMT isoforms. <Capitalized> This enzyme multiplicity can be a target of regulatory control to affect phytosterol homeostasis in transgenic plants. <Capitalized> The state of our current understanding of <AllCaps> SMT enzymology and inhibition is presented.

 <Capitalized> Friedman <AllCaps> N, <Capitalized> Linial <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Nachman <AllCaps> I, Pe'er <AllCaps> D. 
 
 <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Computer <Capitalized> Science and <Capitalized> Engineering, <Capitalized> Hebrew <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Jerusalem, <PERSON Israel> nir@cs.huji.ac.il 
 
 <AllCaps> DNA hybridization arrays simultaneously measure the expression level for thousands of genes. <Capitalized> These measurements provide a "snapshot" of transcription levels within the cell. <AllCaps> A major challenge in computational biology is to uncover, from such measurements, gene/protein interactions and key biological features of cellular systems. <Capitalized> In this paper, we propose a new framework for discovering interactions between genes based on multiple expression measurements. <Capitalized> This framework builds on the use of <Capitalized> Bayesian networks for representing statistical dependencies. <AllCaps> A <Capitalized> Bayesian network is a graph-based model of joint multivariate probability distributions that captures properties of conditional independence between variables. <Capitalized> Such models are attractive for their ability to describe complex stochastic processes and because they provide a clear methodology for learning from (noisy) observations. <Capitalized> We start by showing how <Capitalized> Bayesian networks can describe interactions between genes. <Capitalized> We then describe a method for recovering gene interactions from microarray data using tools for learning <Capitalized> Bayesian networks. <Capitalized> Finally, we demonstrate this method on the <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae cell-cycle measurements of <PERSON  Spellman> et al. (1998).

 <AllCaps> A network of protein-protein interactions in yeast. 
 
 <Capitalized> Schwikowski <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Uetz <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Fields> <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Systems <Capitalized> Biology, 4225 <PERSON  Roosevelt> <PERSON  Way> <AllCaps> NE, <PERSON  Suite> 200, <LOCATION  Seattle,> <AllCaps> WA 98105, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <AllCaps> A global analysis of 2,709 published interactions between proteins of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae has been performed, enabling the establishment of a single large network of 2,358 interactions among 1,548 proteins. <Capitalized> Proteins of known function and cellular location tend to cluster together, with 63% of the interactions occurring between proteins with a common functional assignment and 76% occurring between proteins found in the same subcellular compartment. <Capitalized> Possible functions can be assigned to a protein based on the known functions of its interacting partners. <Capitalized> This approach correctly predicts a functional category for 72% of the 1,393 characterized proteins with at least one partner of known function, and has been applied to predict functions for 364 previously uncharacterized proteins.

 <Capitalized> Computational methods can frequently identify protein-interaction motifs in otherwise uncharacterized open reading frames. <Capitalized> However, the identification of candidate ligands for these motifs (e.g., so that partnering can be determined experimentally in a directed manner) is often beyond the scope of current computational capabilities. <Capitalized> One exception is provided by the coiled-coil interaction motif, which consists of two or more alpha helices that wrap around each other: the ligands for coiled-coil sequences are generally other coiled-coil sequences, thereby greatly simplifying the motif/ligand recognition problem. <Capitalized> Here, we describe a two-step approach to identifying protein-protein interactions mediated by two-stranded coiled coils that occur in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Coiled coils from the yeast genome are first predicted computationally, by using the multicoil program, and associations between coiled coils are then determined experimentally by using the yeast two-hybrid assay. <Capitalized> We report 213 unique interactions between 162 putative coiled-coil sequences. <Capitalized> We evaluate the resulting interactions, focusing on associations identified between components of the spindle pole body (the yeast centrosome).

 329: <Capitalized> Curr <Capitalized> Biol 2000 <Capitalized> Nov 2;10(21):1375-8 
 
 <Capitalized> The spindle checkpoint of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae responds to separable microtubule-dependent events.

 <Capitalized> The spindle checkpoint regulates microtubule-based chromosome segregation and helps to maintain genomic stability [1,2]. <Capitalized> Mutational inactivation of spindle checkpoint genes has been implicated in the progression of several types of human cancer. <Capitalized> Recent evidence from budding yeast suggests that the spindle checkpoint is complex. Order-of-function experiments have defined two separable pathways within the checkpoint. <Capitalized> One pathway, defined by MAD2, controls the metaphase-to-anaphase transition and the other, defined by BUB2, controls the exit from mitosis [3-6]. <Capitalized> The relationships between the separate branches of the checkpoint, and especially the events that trigger the pathways, have not been defined. <Capitalized> We localized a Bub2p-GFP fusion protein to the cytoplasmic side of the spindle pole body and used a kar9 mutant to show that cells with misoriented spindles are arrested in anaphase of mitosis. <Capitalized> We used a kar9 bub2 double mutant to show that the arrest is <EndsInDigit> BUB2 dependent. <Capitalized> We conclude that the separate pathways of the spindle checkpoint respond to different classes of microtubules. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> MAD2 branch of the pathway responds to kinetochore microtubule interactions and the <EndsInDigit> BUB2 branch of the pathway operates within the cytoplasm, responding to spindle misorientation.

 <AllCaps> A fluorescent indicator for detecting protein-protein interactions in vivo based on protein splicing. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ozawa <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Nogami <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Sato> <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Ohya <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Umezawa <PERSON  Y.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Science, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Tokyo,> <LOCATION Japan> 
 
 <Capitalized> We describe a new method with general applicability for monitoring any protein-protein interaction in vivo. <Capitalized> The principle is based on a protein splicing system, which involves a self-catalyzed excision of protein splicing elements, or inteins, from flanking polypeptide sequences, or exteins, leading to formation of a new protein in which the exteins are linked directly by a peptide bond. <Capitalized> As the exteins, split N- and C-terminal halves of enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP) were used. <Capitalized> When a single peptide consisting of an intein derived from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae intervening the split <AllCaps> EGFP was expressed in <Capitalized> Escherichia coli, the two external regions of <AllCaps> EGFP were ligated, thereby forming the <AllCaps> EGFP corresponding fluorophore. <Capitalized> Genetic alteration of the intein, which involved large deletion of the central region encoding 104 amino acids, was performed. <Capitalized> In the expression of the residual N- and C-terminal intein fragments each fused to the split <AllCaps> EGFP exteins, the splicing in trans did not proceed. <Capitalized> However, upon coexpression of calmodulin and its target peptide M13, each connected to the N- and C-terminal inteins, fluorescence of <AllCaps> EGFP was observed. <Capitalized> These results demonstrate that interaction of calmodulin and <EndsInDigit> M13 triggers the refolding of intein, which induces the protein splicing, thereby folding the ligated extein correctly for yielding the <AllCaps> EGFP fluorophore. <Capitalized> This method opens a new way not only to screen protein-protein interactions but also to visualize the interaction in vivo in transgenic animals.

 331: <AllCaps> EMBO <AllCaps> J 2000 <Capitalized> Nov 15;19(22):6141-9 
 
 <Capitalized> The structural basis for the recognition of acetylated histone <EndsInDigit> H4 by the bromodomain of histone acetyltransferase gcn5p. 
 
 <PERSON  Owen> <AllCaps> DJ, <Capitalized> Ornaghi <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Yang <AllCaps> JC, <PERSON  Lowe> <AllCaps> N, <PERSON  Evans> <AllCaps> PR, <Capitalized> Ballario <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Neuhaus> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Filetici <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Travers> <AllCaps> AA. 
 
 <AllCaps> MRC <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Hills> <Capitalized> Road, <LOCATION  Cambridge> <EndsInDigit> CB2 2QH, <LOCATION  UK> and <Capitalized> Centro di studio per gli <Capitalized> Acidi <Capitalized> Nucleici, <AllCaps> CNR, c/o <Capitalized> Dipartimento di <Capitalized> Genetica e <Capitalized> Biologia <Capitalized> Molecolare, <Capitalized> Universita 'La Sapienza', P.le A.Moro 5, 00185 <PERSON  Roma,> <LOCATION Italy> 
 
 <Capitalized> The bromodomain is an approximately 110 amino acid module found in histone acetyltransferases and the ATPase component of certain nucleosome remodelling complexes. <Capitalized> We report the crystal structure at 1.9 <AllCaps> A resolution of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Gcn5p bromodomain complexed with a peptide corresponding to residues 15-29 of histone <EndsInDigit> H4 acetylated at the zeta-N of lysine 16. <Capitalized> We show that this bromodomain preferentially binds to peptides containing an N:-acetyl lysine residue. <Capitalized> Only residues 16-19 of the acetylated peptide interact with the bromodomain. <Capitalized> The primary interaction is the N:-acetyl lysine binding in a cleft with the specificity provided by the interaction of the amide nitrogen of a conserved asparagine with the oxygen of the acetyl carbonyl group. <AllCaps> A network of water-mediated H-bonds with protein main chain carbonyl groups at the base of the cleft contributes to the binding. <Capitalized> Additional side chain binding occurs on a shallow depression that is hydrophobic at one end and can accommodate charge interactions at the other. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that the Gcn5p bromodomain may discriminate between different acetylated lysine residues depending on the context in which they are displayed.

 <Capitalized> Novel Upf2p orthologues suggest a functional link between translation initiation and nonsense surveillance complexes. 
 
 <PERSON  Mendell> <AllCaps> JT, <Capitalized> Medghalchi <AllCaps> SM, <PERSON  Lake> <AllCaps> RG, <Capitalized> Noensie <AllCaps> EN, <PERSON  Dietz> <AllCaps> HC. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Genetic <Capitalized> Medicine, <PERSON  Johns> <PERSON  Hopkins> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  Baltimore,> <Capitalized> Maryland 21205, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Transcripts harboring premature signals for translation termination are recognized and rapidly degraded by eukaryotic cells through a pathway known as nonsense-mediated <MixedCase> mRNA decay (NMD). <Capitalized> In addition to protecting cells by preventing the translation of potentially deleterious truncated peptides, studies have suggested that <AllCaps> NMD plays a broader role in the regulation of the steady-state levels of physiologic transcripts. <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, three trans-acting factors (Upf1p to Upf3p) are required for <AllCaps> NMD. <Capitalized> Orthologues of Upf1p have been identified in numerous species, showing that the <AllCaps> NMD machinery, at least in part, is conserved through evolution. <Capitalized> In this study, we demonstrate additional functional conservation of the <AllCaps> NMD pathway through the identification of Upf2p homologues in <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe and humans (rent2). <Capitalized> Disruption of <PERSON  S.> pombe <EndsInDigit> UPF2 established that this gene is required for <AllCaps> NMD in fission yeast. rent2 was demonstrated to interact directly with rent1, a known trans-effector of <AllCaps> NMD in mammalian cells. <Capitalized> Additionally, fragments of rent2 were shown to possess nuclear targeting activity, although the native protein localizes to the cytoplasmic compartment. <Capitalized> Finally, novel functional domains of Upf2p and rent2 with homology to eukaryotic initiation factor 4G (eIF4G) and other translational regulatory proteins were identified. <Capitalized> Directed mutations within these so-called eIF4G homology (4GH) domains were sufficient to abolish the function of <PERSON  S.> pombe Upf2p. <Capitalized> Furthermore, using the two-hybrid system, we obtained evidence for direct interaction between rent2 and human eIF4AI and Sui1, both components of the translation initiation complex. <Capitalized> Based on these findings, a novel model in which Upf2p and rent2 effects decreased translation and accelerated decay of nonsense transcripts through competitive interactions with eIF4G-binding partners is proposed.

 <Capitalized> Nie <PERSON  Z,> <Capitalized> Xue <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Yang <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Zhou <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Deroo <AllCaps> BJ, <PERSON  Archer> <AllCaps> TK, <PERSON  Wang> <PERSON  W.>

 <Capitalized> The SWI/SNF family of chromatin-remodeling complexes facilitates gene activation by assisting transcription machinery to gain access to targets in chromatin. <Capitalized> This family includes <AllCaps> BAF (also called hSWI/SNF-A) and <AllCaps> PBAF (hSWI/SNF-B) from humans and SWI/SNF and <Capitalized> Rsc from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> However, the relationship between the human and yeast complexes is unclear because all human subunits published to date are similar to those of both yeast SWI/SNF and Rsc. <Capitalized> Also, the two human complexes have many identical subunits, making it difficult to distinguish their structures or functions. <Capitalized> Here we describe the cloning and characterization of BAF250, a subunit present in human <AllCaps> BAF but not <AllCaps> PBAF. <EndsInDigit> BAF250 contains structural motifs conserved in yeast <EndsInDigit> SWI1 but not in any <Capitalized> Rsc components, suggesting that <AllCaps> BAF is related to SWI/SNF. <EndsInDigit> BAF250 is also a homolog of the <Capitalized> Drosophila melanogaster <Capitalized> Osa protein, which has been shown to interact with a SWI/SNF-like complex in flies. <EndsInDigit> BAF250 possesses at least two conserved domains that could be important for its function. <Capitalized> First, it has an AT-rich <AllCaps> DNA interaction-type DNA-binding domain, which can specifically bind a <AllCaps> DNA sequence known to be recognized by a SWI/SNF family-related complex at the beta-globin locus. <Capitalized> Second, <EndsInDigit> BAF250 stimulates glucocorticoid receptor-dependent transcriptional activation, and the stimulation is sharply reduced when the C-terminal region of <EndsInDigit> BAF250 is deleted. <Capitalized> This region of <EndsInDigit> BAF250 is capable of interacting directly with the glucocorticoid receptor in vitro. <Capitalized> Our data suggest that <EndsInDigit> BAF250 confers specificity to the human <AllCaps> BAF complex and may recruit the complex to its targets through either protein-DNA or protein-protein interactions.

 <Capitalized> There has been no unequivocal demonstration that the activator binding targets identified in vitro play a key role in transcriptional activation in vivo. <Capitalized> To examine whether activator-Mediator interactions are required for gene transcription under physiological conditions, we performed functional analyses with <Capitalized> Mediator components that interact specifically with natural yeast activators. <Capitalized> Different activators interact with <Capitalized> Mediator via distinct binding targets. <Capitalized> Deletion of a distinct activator binding region of <Capitalized> Mediator completely compromised gene activation in vivo by some, but not all, transcriptional activators. <Capitalized> These demonstrate that the activator-specific targets in <Capitalized> Mediator are essential for transcriptional activation in living cells, but their requirement was affected by the nature of the activator-DNA interaction and the existence of a postrecruitment activation process.

 <AllCaps> A wide variety of gram-negative bacteria utilize a specialized apparatus called the type <AllCaps> III secretion system (TTSS) to translocate virulence factors directly into the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells. <Capitalized> These translocated effectors contribute to the pathogen's ability to infect and replicate within plant and animal hosts. <Capitalized> The amino terminus of effector proteins contains sequences that are necessary and sufficient for both secretion and translocation by <AllCaps> TTSS. <Capitalized> Portions of these sequences contain binding sites for type <AllCaps> III chaperones, which facilitate efficient secretion and translocation of specific effectors through <AllCaps> TTSS. <Capitalized> In this study, we have utilized the yeast two-hybrid assay to identify protein-protein interactions between effector and chaperone proteins encoded within <Capitalized> Salmonella pathogenicity island 1 (SPI-1). <Capitalized> Several interactions were identified including a novel interaction between the effector protein, SspA (SipA), and a putative chaperone, InvB.
