 <PERSON  Manson> <PERSON McGuire> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Church> <AllCaps> GM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Genetics, <LOCATION  Warren> <PERSON  Alpert> <Capitalized> Building, <Capitalized> Room 513, <Capitalized> Harvard <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> 200 <Capitalized> Longwood <Capitalized> Avenue, <LOCATION  Boston,> <AllCaps> MA 02115, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> We have combined and compared three techniques for predicting functional interactions based on comparative genomics (methods based on conserved operons, protein fusions and correlated evolution) and optimized these methods to predict coregulated sets of genes in 24 complete genomes, including <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, <Capitalized> Caenorhabditis elegans and 22 prokaryotes. <Capitalized> The method based on conserved operons was the most useful for this purpose. <Capitalized> Upstream regions of the genes comprising these predicted regulons were then used to search for regulatory motifs in 22 prokaryotic genomes using the motif-discovery program AlignACE. <Capitalized> Many significant upstream motifs, including five known <Capitalized> Escherichia coli regulatory motifs, were identified in this manner. <Capitalized> The presence of a significant regulatory motif was used to refine the members of the predicted regulons to generate a final set of predicted regulons that share significant regulatory elements.

 <AllCaps> A network of yeast basic helix-loop-helix interactions. 
 
 <PERSON  Robinson> <AllCaps> KA, <Capitalized> Koepke <AllCaps> JI, <Capitalized> Kharodawala <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Lopes> <AllCaps> JM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences, <PERSON  Wayne> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University, 5047 <Capitalized> Gullen <Capitalized> Mall, <PERSON  Detroit,> <AllCaps> MI 48202, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The Ino4 protein belongs to the basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) family of proteins. <Capitalized> It is known to form a dimer with Ino2p, which regulates phospholipid biosynthetic genes. <Capitalized> Mammalian <MixedCase> bHLH proteins have been shown to form multiple dimer combinations. <Capitalized> However, this flexibility in dimerization had not been documented for yeast <MixedCase> bHLH proteins. <Capitalized> Using the yeast two-hybrid assay and a biochemical assay we show that Ino4p dimerizes with the Pho4p, Rtg1p, Rtg3p and Sgc1p <MixedCase> bHLH proteins. <Capitalized> Screening a yeast <MixedCase> cDNA library identified three additional proteins that interact with Ino4p: Bck2p, YLR422W and YNR064C. <Capitalized> The interaction with Bck2p prompted us to examine if any of the Bck2p-associated functions affect expression of phospholipid biosynthetic genes. <Capitalized> We found that hyperosmotic growth conditions altered the growth phase regulation of a phospholipid biosynthetic gene, CHO1. <Capitalized> There are two recent reports of initial whole genome yeast two-hybrid interactions. <Capitalized> Interestingly, one of these reports identified five proteins that interact with Ino4p: Ino2p, Hcs1p, Apl2p, YMR317W and YNL279W. Ino2p is the only protein in common with the data presented here. <Capitalized> Our finding that Ino4p interacts with five <MixedCase> bHLH proteins suggests that Ino4p is likely to be a central player in the coordination of multiple biological processes.

 <EndsInDigit> SEC62 encodes an essential component of the Sec-complex that is responsible for posttranslational protein translocation across the membrane of the endoplasmic 
 
 reticulum in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The specific role of Sec62p in translocation was not known and difficult to identify because it is part of an oligomeric protein complex in the endoplasmic reticulum membrane. <Capitalized> An in vivo competition assay allowed us to characterize and dissect physical and functional interactions between Sec62p and components of the Sec-complex. <Capitalized> We could show that Sec62p binds via its cytosolic N- and C-terminal domains to the Sec-complex. <Capitalized> The N-terminal domain, which harbors the major interaction site, binds directly to the last 14 residues of Sec63p. <Capitalized> The C-terminal binding site of Sec62p is less important for complex stability, but adjoins the region in Sec62p that might be involved in signal sequence recognition.

 344: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Cell 2000 Nov;11(11):3689-702

 <PERSON  Segal> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Bloom> <AllCaps> K, <PERSON  Reed> <AllCaps> SI. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Scripps> <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> La <Capitalized> Jolla, <LOCATION  California> 92037, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In budding yeast, spindle polarity relies on a precise temporal program of cytoplasmic microtubule-cortex interactions throughout spindle assembly. <Capitalized> Loss of Clb5-dependent kinase activity under conditions of attenuated Cdc28 function disrupts this program, resulting in diploid-specific lethality. <Capitalized> Here we show that polarity loss is tolerated by haploids due to a more prominent contribution of microtubule-neck interactions to spindle orientation inherent to haploids. <Capitalized> These differences are mediated by the relative partition of Bud6 between the bud tip and bud neck, distinguishing haploids from diploids. Bud6 localizes initially to the bud tip and accumulates at the neck concomitant with spindle assembly. bud6Delta mutant phenotypes are consistent with Bud6's role as a cortical cue for cytoplasmic microtubule capture. <Capitalized> Moreover, mutations that affect Bud6 localization and partitioning disrupt the sequential program of microtubule-cortex interactions accordingly. <Capitalized> These data support a model whereby Bud6 sequentially cues microtubule capture events at the bud tip followed by capture events at the bud neck, necessary for correct spindle morphogenesis and polarity.

 <Capitalized> Li <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Lee> <AllCaps> GI, <LOCATION  Van> <Capitalized> Doren <AllCaps> SR, <PERSON  Walker> <AllCaps> JC. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of Missouri-Columbia, <LOCATION  Columbia,> <AllCaps> MO 65211, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The forkhead-associated (FHA) domain is a phosphopeptide-binding domain first identified in a group of forkhead transcription factors but is present in a wide variety of proteins from both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. <Capitalized> In yeast and human, many proteins containing an <AllCaps> FHA domain are found in the nucleus and involved in <AllCaps> DNA repair, cell cycle arrest, or pre-mRNA processing. <Capitalized> In plants, the <AllCaps> FHA domain is part of a protein that is localized to the plasma membrane and participates in the regulation of receptor-like protein kinase signaling pathways. <Capitalized> Recent studies show that a functional <AllCaps> FHA domain consists of 120-140 amino acid residues, which is significantly larger than the sequence motif first described. <Capitalized> Although <AllCaps> FHA domains do not exhibit extensive sequence similarity, they share similar secondary and tertiary structures, featuring a sandwich of two anti-parallel (beta)-sheets. <Capitalized> One intriguing finding is that <AllCaps> FHA domains may bind phosphothreonine, phosphoserine and sometimes phosphotyrosine, distinguishing them from other well-studied phosphoprotein-binding domains. <Capitalized> The diversity of proteins containing <AllCaps> FHA domains and potential differences in binding specificities suggest the <AllCaps> FHA domain is involved in coordinating diverse cellular processes.

 <EndsInDigit> CSE4 genetically interacts with the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae centromere <AllCaps> DNA elements <AllCaps> CDE <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> CDE <AllCaps> II but not <AllCaps> CDE <AllCaps> III. <Capitalized> Implications for the path of the centromere dna around a cse4p variant nucleosome.

 <Capitalized> Synthetic interactions of the post-Golgi sec mutations of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <PERSON  Finger> <AllCaps> FP, <Capitalized> Novick <PERSON  P.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Yale> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  New Haven,> <LOCATION  Connecticut> 06520-8002, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, synthetic lethality has been extensively used both to characterize interactions between genes previously identified as likely to be involved in similar processes as well as to uncover new interactions. <Capitalized> We have performed a large study of the synthetic lethal interactions of the post-Golgi sec mutations. <Capitalized> Included in this study are the interactions of the post-Golgi sec mutations with each other, with mutations affecting earlier stages of the secretory pathway, with selected mutations affecting the actin cytoskeleton, and with selected cell division cycle (cdc) mutations affecting processes thought to be important for or involving secretion, such as polarity establishment and cytokinesis. <Capitalized> Synthetic negative interactions of the post-Golgi sec mutations appear (as predicted) to be largely stage specific, although there are some notable exceptions. <Capitalized> The significance of these results is discussed in the context of both secretory pathway function and the utility of synthetic lethality studies and their interpretation.

 <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid system is frequently used to identify protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> The assay is based on the functional reconstitution of a transcriptional activator. <Capitalized> Since an indirect phenotype of the positive clones is the basis for selection of positive interacting clones, the two-hybrid screens are vulnerable to false positives. <Capitalized> Here we report a screening protocol based on the sequential use of the cotransformation approach followed by the genetic method for verifying true two-hybrid interactions. <Capitalized> Using this procedure, we have screened a <MixedCase> cDNA library and have been able to isolate true positives from the yeast two-hybrid screen. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <PERSON  Farley> <AllCaps> RA, <PERSON  Schreiber> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Wang> <AllCaps> SG, Scheiner-Bobis <AllCaps> G. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Physiology and <Capitalized> Biophysics, <PERSON  Keck> <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  Southern> <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  Los Angeles> 90033, <LOCATION  USA.> rfarley@hsc.usc.edu 
 
 Na(+),K(+)-ATPase is inhibited by cardiac glycosides such as ouabain, and palytoxin, which do not inhibit gastric H(+),K(+)-ATPase. <Capitalized> Gastric H(+),K(+)-ATPase is inhibited by SCH28080, which has no effect on Na(+),K(+)-ATPase. <Capitalized> The goal of the current study was to identify amino acid sequences of the gastric proton-potassium pump that are involved in recognition of the pump-specific inhibitor <AllCaps> SCH 28080. <AllCaps> A chimeric polypeptide consisting of the rat sodium pump alpha3 subunit with the peptide Gln(905)-Val(930) of the gastric proton pump alpha subunit substituted in place of the original Asn(886)-Ala(911) sequence was expressed together with the gastric beta subunit in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Yeast cells that express this subunit combination are sensitive to palytoxin, which interacts specifically with the sodium pump, and lose intracellular K(+) ions. <Capitalized> The palytoxin-induced K(+) efflux is inhibited by the sodium pump-specific inhibitor ouabain and also by the gastric proton pump-specific inhibitor <AllCaps> SCH 28080. <Capitalized> The IC(50) for <AllCaps> SCH 28080 inhibition of palytoxin-induced K(+) efflux is 14.3 +/- 2.4 microm, which is similar to the K(i) for <AllCaps> SCH 28080 inhibition of <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis by the gastric H(+),K(+)-ATPase. <Capitalized> In contrast, palytoxin-induced K(+) efflux from cells expressing either the native alpha3 and beta1 subunits of the sodium pump or the alpha3 subunit of the sodium pump together with the beta subunit of the gastric proton pump is inhibited by ouabain but not by <AllCaps> SCH 28080. <Capitalized> The acquisition of <AllCaps> SCH 28080 sensitivity by the chimera indicates that the Gln(905)-Val(930) peptide of the gastric proton pump is likely to be involved in the interactions of the gastric proton-potassium pump with <AllCaps> SCH 28080.

 <EndsInDigit> PMP1 is a 38-residue plasma membrane protein of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae that regulates the activity of the H(+)-ATPase. <Capitalized> The cytoplasmic domain conformation results in a specific interfacial distribution of five basic side chains, thought to strongly interact with anionic phospholipids. <Capitalized> We have used the <EndsInDigit> PMP1 18-38 fragment to carry out a deuterium nuclear magnetic resonance ((2)H-NMR) study for investigating the interactions between the <EndsInDigit> PMP1 cytoplasmic domain and phosphatidylserines. <Capitalized> For this purpose, mixed bilayers of 1-palmitoyl, 2-oleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine (POPC) and 1-palmitoyl, 2-oleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoserine (POPS) were used as model membranes (POPC/POPS 5:1, m/m). <Capitalized> Spectra of headgroup- and chain-deuterated <AllCaps> POPC and <AllCaps> POPS phospholipids, POPC-d4, POPC-d31, POPS-d3, and POPS-d31, were recorded at different temperatures and for various concentrations of the <EndsInDigit> PMP1 fragment. <Capitalized> Data obtained from <AllCaps> POPS deuterons revealed the formation of specific peptide-POPS complexes giving rise to a slow exchange between free and bound <AllCaps> PS lipids, scarcely observed in solid-state <AllCaps> NMR studies of lipid-peptide/protein interactions. <Capitalized> The stoichiometry of the complex (8 <AllCaps> POPS per peptide) was determined and its significance is discussed. <Capitalized> The data obtained with headgroup-deuterated <AllCaps> POPC were rationalized with a model that integrates the electrostatic perturbation induced by the cationic peptide on the negatively charged membrane interface, and a "spacer" effect due to the intercalation of POPS/PMP1f complexes between choline headgroups.

 <PERSON  Richman> <AllCaps> TJ, <PERSON  Johnson> <AllCaps> DI. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and <PERSON  Markey> <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Vermont <LOCATION  Burlington,> <Capitalized> Vermont 05405, <LOCATION  USA.>

 <Capitalized> Nika <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Rippel> <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Hannig <AllCaps> EM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> at <PERSON  Dallas,> <PERSON  Richardson,> <LOCATION  Texas> 75083, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Eukaryotic translation initiation factor eIF2 is a heterotrimer that binds and delivers Met-tRNA(i)(Met) to the 40 <PERSON  S> ribosomal subunit in a GTP-dependent manner. <Capitalized> Initiation requires hydrolysis of eIF2-bound <AllCaps> GTP, which releases an eIF2.GDP complex that is recycled to the <AllCaps> GTP form by the nucleotide exchange factor eIF2B. <Capitalized> The alpha-subunit of eIF2 plays a critical role in regulating nucleotide exchange via phosphorylation at serine 51, which converts eIF2 into a competitive inhibitor of the eIF2B-catalyzed exchange reaction. <Capitalized> We purified a form of eIF2 (eIF2betagamma) completely devoid of the alpha-subunit to further study the role of eIF2alpha in eIF2 function. <Capitalized> These studies utilized a yeast strain genetically altered to bypass a deletion of the normally essential eIF2alpha structural gene (SUI2). <Capitalized> Removal of the alpha-subunit did not appear to significantly alter binding of guanine nucleotide or Met-tRNA(i)(Met) ligands by eIF2 in vitro. <Capitalized> Qualitative assays to detect 43 <PERSON  S> initiation complex formation and eIF5-dependent <AllCaps> GTP hydrolysis revealed no differences between eIF2betagamma and the wild-type eIF2 heterotrimer. <Capitalized> However, steady-state kinetic analysis of eIF2B-catalyzed nucleotide exchange revealed that the absence of the alpha-subunit increased K(m) for eIF2betagamma.GDP by an order of magnitude, with a smaller increase in V(max). <Capitalized> These data indicate that eIF2alpha is required for structural interactions between eIF2 and eIF2B that promote wild-type rates of nucleotide exchange. <Capitalized> We suggest that this function contributes to the ability of the alpha-subunit to control the rate of nucleotide exchange through reversible phosphorylation.

 <Capitalized> Subunit interactions of yeast NAD+-specific isocitrate dehydrogenase. 
 
 <Capitalized> Panisko <AllCaps> EA, McAlister-Henn <AllCaps> L. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Science <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  San Antonio,> <LOCATION  Texas> 78229-3900, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Yeast mitochondrial NAD(+)-specific isocitrate dehydrogenase is an octamer composed of four each of two nonidentical but related subunits designated <EndsInDigit> IDH1 and IDH2. <EndsInDigit> IDH2 was previously shown to contain the catalytic site, whereas <EndsInDigit> IDH1 contributes regulatory properties including cooperativity with respect to isocitrate and allosteric activation by <AllCaps> AMP. <Capitalized> In this study, interactions between <EndsInDigit> IDH1 and <EndsInDigit> IDH2 were detected using the yeast two-hybrid system, but interactions between identical subunit polypeptides were not detected with this or other methods. <AllCaps> A model for heterodimeric interactions between the subunits is therefore proposed for this enzyme. <AllCaps> A corollary of this model, based on the three-dimensional structure of the homologous enzyme from <Capitalized> Escherichia coli, is that some interactions between subunits occur at isocitrate binding sites. <Capitalized> Based on this model, two residues (Lys-183 and Asp-217) in the regulatory <EndsInDigit> IDH1 subunit were predicted to be important in the catalytic site of IDH2. <Capitalized> We found that individually replacing these residues with alanine results in mutant enzymes that exhibit a drastic reduction in catalysis both in vitro and in vivo. <Capitalized> Also based on this model, the two analogous residues (Lys-189 and Asp-222) of the catalytic <EndsInDigit> IDH2 subunit were predicted to contribute to the regulatory site of IDH1. <AllCaps> A K189A substitution in <EndsInDigit> IDH2 was found to produce a decrease in activation of the enzyme by <AllCaps> AMP and a loss of cooperativity with respect to isocitrate. <AllCaps> A D222A substitution in <EndsInDigit> IDH2 produces similar regulatory defects and a substantial reduction in V(max) in the absence of <AllCaps> AMP. <Capitalized> Collectively, these results suggest that the basic structural/functional unit of yeast isocitrate dehydrogenase is a heterodimer of <EndsInDigit> IDH1 and <EndsInDigit> IDH2 subunits and that each subunit contributes to the isocitrate binding site of the other.

 <Capitalized> Phylip <AllCaps> LH, <PERSON  Lees> <AllCaps> WE, <Capitalized> Brownsey <AllCaps> BG, <Capitalized> Bur <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Dunn> <AllCaps> BM, <Capitalized> Winther <AllCaps> JR, <Capitalized> Gustchina <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Li <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Copeland> <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Wlodawer <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Kay> <AllCaps> J.

 <Capitalized> The yeast <EndsInDigit> IA3 polypeptide consists of only 68 residues, and the free inhibitor has little intrinsic secondary structure. <EndsInDigit> IA3 showed subnanomolar potency toward its target, proteinase <AllCaps> A from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and did not inhibit any of a large number of aspartic proteinases with similar sequences/structures from a wide variety of other species. <Capitalized> Systematic truncation and mutagenesis of the <EndsInDigit> IA3 polypeptide revealed that the inhibitory activity is located in the N-terminal half of the sequence. <Capitalized> Crystal structures of different forms of <EndsInDigit> IA3 complexed with proteinase <AllCaps> A showed that residues in the N-terminal half of the <EndsInDigit> IA3 sequence became ordered and formed an almost perfect alpha-helix in the active site of the enzyme. <Capitalized> This potent, specific interaction was directed primarily by hydrophobic interactions made by three key features in the inhibitory sequence. <Capitalized> Whereas <EndsInDigit> IA3 was cut as a substrate by the nontarget aspartic proteinases, it was not cleaved by proteinase <AllCaps> A. <Capitalized> The random coil <EndsInDigit> IA3 polypeptide escapes cleavage by being stabilized in a helical conformation upon interaction with the active site of proteinase <AllCaps> A. <Capitalized> This results, paradoxically, in potent selective inhibition of the target enzyme.

 <PERSON  Burks> <AllCaps> EA, <Capitalized> Bezerra <AllCaps> PP, <Capitalized> Le <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Gallie <AllCaps> DR, <PERSON  Browning> <AllCaps> KS.

 <Capitalized> Eukaryotic initiation factor 3 (eIF3) is a multisubunit complex that is required for binding of <MixedCase> mRNA to 40 <PERSON  S> ribosomal subunits, stabilization of ternary complex binding to 40 <PERSON  S> subunits, and dissociation of 40 and 60 <PERSON  S> subunits. <Capitalized> These functions and the complex nature of eIF3 suggest multiple interactions with many components of the translational machinery. <Capitalized> Recently, the subunits of mammalian and <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae eIF3 were identified, and substantial differences in the subunit composition of mammalian and <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae were observed. <Capitalized> Mammalian eIF3 consists of 11 nonidentical subunits, whereas <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae eIF3 consists of up to eight nonidentical subunits. <Capitalized> Only five of the subunits of mammalian and <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae are shared in common, and these five subunits comprise a "core" complex in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. eIF3 from wheat consists of at least 10 subunits, but their relationship to either the mammalian or <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae eIF3 subunits is unknown. <Capitalized> Peptide sequences derived from purified wheat eIF3 subunits were used to correlate each subunit with mammalian and/or <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae subunits. <Capitalized> The peptide sequences were also used to identify <Capitalized> Arabidopsis thaliana <MixedCase> cDNAs for each of the eIF3 subunits. <Capitalized> We report seven new <MixedCase> cDNAs for <AllCaps> A. thaliana eIF3 subunits. <AllCaps> A. thaliana eIF3 was purified and characterized to confirm that the subunit composition and activity of wheat and <AllCaps> A. thaliana eIF3 were similar. <Capitalized> We report that plant eIF3 closely resembles the subunit composition of mammalian eIF3, having 10 out of 11 subunits in common. <PERSON  Further,> we find a novel subunit in the plant eIF3 complex not present in either mammalian or <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae eIF3. <Capitalized> These results suggest that plant and mammalian eIF3 evolved similarly, whereas <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae has diverged.

 <Capitalized> Cavaletto <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Pessione <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Vanni <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Giunta <AllCaps> C.

 Cobalt-substituted alcohol dehydrogenase 1 was purified from a yeast culture of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Its reactivity towards different transition metals was tested and compared with the native zinc enzyme. <Capitalized> The cobalt enzyme displayed a catalytic efficiency 100-fold higher than that of the zinc enzyme. <PERSON  Copper,> nickel and cadmium exerted a mixed-type inhibition, with a scale of inhibition efficiency: Cu(2+)>Ni(2+)>Cd(2+). <Capitalized> In general, a higher resistance of the modified protein to the inhibitory action of transition metals was observed, with two orders of magnitude for copper I(50). <Capitalized> The presence of nickel in the complexes enzyme-coenzyme-inhibitor-substrate resulted in a decrease of the ampholytic nature of the catalytic site. <Capitalized> On the contrary, cadmium and copper exerted an enhancement of this parameter. <Capitalized> Electrostatic or other types of interactions may be involved in conferring a good resistance in the basic <MixedCase> pH range, making cobalt enzyme very suitable for biotechnological processes.

 <Capitalized> Gurunathan <PERSON  S,> Chapman-Shimshoni <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Trajkovic <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Gerst> <AllCaps> JE.

 <Capitalized> Identification of a new vertebrate nucleoporin, Nup188, with the use of a novel organelle trap assay. 
 
 <PERSON  Miller> <AllCaps> BR, <PERSON  Powers> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Park> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Fischer> <PERSON  W,> <PERSON  Forbes> <AllCaps> DJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California> at <LOCATION  San Diego,> <Capitalized> La <Capitalized> Jolla, <LOCATION  California> 92093, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The study of the nuclear pore in vertebrates would benefit from a strategy to directly identify new nucleoporins and interactions between those nucleoporins. <Capitalized> We have developed a novel two-step "organelle trap" assay involving affinity selection and in vitro pore assembly. <Capitalized> In the first step, soluble proteins derived from <Capitalized> Xenopus egg extracts are applied to a column containing a ligand of interest. <Capitalized> The bound proteins are then tagged by biotinylation and eluted. <Capitalized> In the second step, potential nucleoporins are selected for by virtue of their ability to assemble into annulate lamellae, a cytoplasmic mimic of nuclear pores. <Capitalized> The incorporated proteins are then recognized by their biotin tag. <Capitalized> Here we use the lectin wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) as ligand; <AllCaps> WGA inhibits nuclear transport and has been shown to directly bind three known nucleoporins from <Capitalized> Xenopus extract, Nup62, Nup98, and Nup214, all of which contain N-acetylglucosamine residues. <Capitalized> Under reduced-stringency conditions, three additional proteins bind to WGA-Sepharose and are revealed by the organelle trap assay. <Capitalized> We identified all three as partner nucleoporins. <Capitalized> Two were discovered to be <Capitalized> Xenopus Nup93 and Nup205. <Capitalized> The third is a novel vertebrate nucleoporin, Nup188. <Capitalized> This new vertebrate protein, <Capitalized> Xenopus Nup188, exists in a complex with xNup93 and xNup205. <Capitalized> The Nup93-Nup188-Nup205 complex does not bind directly to <AllCaps> WGA but binds indirectly via the N-acetylglucosamine-modified nucleoporins. <AllCaps> A gene encoding human Nup188 was also identified. <Capitalized> The discovery of vertebrate Nup188, related to a yeast nucleoporin, and its novel protein-protein interactions illustrates the power of the two-step organelle trap assay and identifies new building blocks for constructing the nuclear pore.

 <Capitalized> The cdc45 protein was originally identified in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and shown to be essential for initiation of eukaryotic <AllCaps> DNA replication. <Capitalized> Subsequent isolation and characterisation of the corresponding genes from fission yeast, <Capitalized> Xenopus and mammals also support a replication role for the protein in these species. <Capitalized> They further suggest that during the course of its function cdc45 interacts with a number of other replication proteins, including minichromosome maintenance proteins, the origin recognition complex and <AllCaps> DNA polymerase alpha. <Capitalized> We have cloned the gene coding for cdc45 protein from <Capitalized> Drosophila melanogaster. <Capitalized> We have analysed the expression pattern of the cdc45 protein throughout the cell cycle and the life cycle using a combination of indirect immunofluorescence and subcellular fractionation. <Capitalized> Our data show that cellular localisation and developmental regulation of the protein is consistent with a role in <AllCaps> DNA replication. DmCdc45 is predominantly expressed in proliferating cells. <Capitalized> In addition, its subcellular location is nuclear during interphase and the protein shows association with chromatin. <Capitalized> The chromatin-associated form of the protein shows a post-translational modification, which may be involved in control of the action of the protein. DmCdc45 shows interactions with mcm proteins, however, the interactions detected show some specificity, perhaps suggesting a preferential association with particular mcm proteins. <Capitalized> In addition we show that a stoichiometric mcm interaction may not be obligatory for the function of cdc45 in follicle cell replication, because, unlike the mcm proteins, DmCdc45 localises to the chorion amplification foci in the follicle cells of the ovary.

 <Capitalized> In posttranslational translocation in yeast, completed protein substrates are transported across the endoplasmic reticulum membrane through a translocation channel formed by the <Capitalized> Sec complex. <Capitalized> We have used photo-cross-linking to investigate interactions of cytosolic proteins with a substrate synthesized in a reticulocyte lysate system, before its posttranslational translocation through the channel in the yeast membrane. <Capitalized> Upon termination of translation, the signal recognition particle (SRP) and the nascent polypeptide-associated complex (NAC) are released from the polypeptide chain, and the full-length substrate interacts with several different cytosolic proteins. <Capitalized> At least two distinct complexes exist that contain among other proteins either 70-kD heat shock protein (Hsp70) or tailless complex polypeptide 1 (TCP1) ring complex/chaperonin containing <EndsInDigit> TCP1 (TRiC/CCT), which keep the substrate competent for translocation. <Capitalized> None of the cytosolic factors appear to interact specifically with the signal sequence. <Capitalized> Dissociation of the cytosolic proteins from the substrate is accelerated to the same extent by the <Capitalized> Sec complex and an unspecific GroEL trap, indicating that release occurs spontaneously without the <Capitalized> Sec complex playing an active role. <Capitalized> Once bound to the <Capitalized> Sec complex, the substrate is stripped of all cytosolic proteins, allowing it to subsequently be transported through the membrane channel without the interference of cytosolic binding partners.

 <PERSON  Browning> <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Hayles> <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Mata <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Aveline <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Nurse> <PERSON  P,> <PERSON McIntosh> <AllCaps> JR.

 <Capitalized> Cytoplasmic microtubules are critical for establishing and maintaining cell shape and polarity. <Capitalized> Our investigations of kinesin-like proteins (klps) and morphological mutants in the fission yeast <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe have identified a kinesin-like gene, tea2(+), that is required for cells to generate proper polarized growth. <Capitalized> Cells deleted for this gene are often bent during exponential growth and initiate growth from improper sites as they exit stationary phase. <Capitalized> They have a reduced cytoplasmic microtubule network and display severe morphological defects in genetic backgrounds that produce long cells. <Capitalized> The tip-specific marker, Tea1p, is mislocalized in both tea2-1 and tea2Delta cells, indicating that Tea2p function is necessary for proper localization of Tea1p. Tea2p is localized to the tips of the cell and in a punctate pattern within the cell, often coincident with the ends of cytoplasmic microtubules. <Capitalized> These results suggest that this kinesin promotes microtubule growth, possibly through interactions with the microtubule end, and that it is important for establishing and maintaining polarized growth along the long axis of the cell.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Pittsburgh,> <LOCATION  Pittsburgh,> <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> 15260, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <PERSON  Strong> evidence indicates that transcription elongation by <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II (pol II) is a highly regulated process. <Capitalized> Here we present genetic results that indicate a role for the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Rtf1 protein in transcription elongation. <AllCaps> A screen for synthetic lethal mutations was carried out with an rtf1 deletion mutation to identify factors that interact with Rtf1 or regulate the same process as Rtf1. <Capitalized> The screen uncovered mutations in SRB5, CTK1, FCP1, and POB3. <Capitalized> These genes encode an Srb/mediator component, a <AllCaps> CTD kinase, a <AllCaps> CTD phosphatase, and a protein involved in the regulation of transcription by chromatin structure, respectively. <Capitalized> All of these gene products have been directly or indirectly implicated in transcription elongation, indicating that Rtf1 may also regulate this process. <Capitalized> In support of this view, we show that <EndsInDigit> RTF1 functionally interacts with genes that encode known elongation factors, including SPT4, SPT5, SPT16, and PPR2. <Capitalized> We also show that a deletion of <EndsInDigit> RTF1 causes sensitivity to 6-azauracil and mycophenolic acid, phenotypes correlated with a transcription elongation defect. <Capitalized> Collectively, our results suggest that Rtf1 may function as a novel transcription elongation factor in yeast.

 <Capitalized> The actin cytoskeleton is required for many aspects of cell division in yeast, including mitochondrial partitioning into growing buds (mitochondrial inheritance). <Capitalized> Yeast cells lacking <EndsInDigit> MDM20 function display defects in both mitochondrial inheritance and actin organization, specifically, a lack of visible actin cables and enhanced sensitivity to <Capitalized> Latrunculin <AllCaps> A. mdm20 mutants also exhibit a temperature-sensitive growth phenotype, which we exploited to isolate second-site suppressor mutations. <Capitalized> Nine dominant suppressors selected in an mdm20/mdm20 background rescue temperature-sensitive growth defects and mitochondrial inheritance defects and partially restore actin cables in haploid and diploid mdm20 strains. <Capitalized> The suppressor mutations define new alleles of <EndsInDigit> ACT1 and TPM1, which encode actin and the major form of tropomyosin in yeast, respectively. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> ACT1 mutations cluster in a region of the actin protein predicted to contact tropomyosin, suggesting that they stabilize actin cables by enhancing actin-tropomyosin interactions. <Capitalized> The characteristics of the mutant <EndsInDigit> ACT1 and <EndsInDigit> TPM1 alleles and their potential effects on protein structure and binding are discussed.

 <Capitalized> Aronheim <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, the <AllCaps> B. <PERSON  Rappaport> <Capitalized> Faculty of <Capitalized> Medicine, Technion-Israel <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Technology, <Capitalized> Haifa 31096, <PERSON Israel> aronheim@tx.technion.ac.il 
 
 <Capitalized> Following the completion of genome projects in a number of organisms, it is becoming evident that a relatively large proportion of the genes identified encode for proteins that have no sequence homology with known proteins. <Capitalized> One possible approach towards understanding protein function is to identify the proteins with which a particular protein associates. <Capitalized> Although very powerful, the most commonly used genetic method, the two-hybrid system, is limited in its ability to detect all possible protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> The development of novel approaches, such as the protein recruitment systems, provides attractive alternatives towards identification of protein-protein interactions where other methods have failed to function.

 378: <Capitalized> Biochim <Capitalized> Biophys <Capitalized> Acta 2000 <Capitalized> Aug 15;1459(2-3):316-24 
 
 Haem-polypeptide interactions during cytochrome c maturation. 
 
 Thony-Meyer <AllCaps> L. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Microbiology, <AllCaps> ETH <Capitalized> Zurich, <Capitalized> Schmelzbergstrasse 7, CH-8092, <Capitalized> Zurich, <LOCATION Switzerland> lthoeny@micro.biol.ethz.ch 
 
 <Capitalized> Cytochrome c maturation involves the translocation of a polypeptide, the apocytochrome, and its cofactor, haem, through a membrane, before the two molecules are ligated covalently. <Capitalized> This review article focuses on the current knowledge on the journey of haem during this process, which is known best in the Gram-negative bacterium <Capitalized> Escherichia coli. <Capitalized> As haem always occurs bound to protein, its passage across the cytoplasmic membrane and incorporation into the apocytochrome appears to be mediated by a set of proteinaceous maturation factors, the <Capitalized> Ccm (cytochrome c maturation) proteins. <Capitalized> At least three of them, CcmC, CcmE and CcmF, are thought to interact directly with haem. CcmE binds haem covalently, thus representing an intermediate of the haem trafficking pathway. CcmC is required for binding of haem to CcmE, and CcmF for releasing it from CcmE and transferring it onto the apocytochrome. <Capitalized> The mechanism by which haem crosses the cytoplasmic membrane is currently unknown.

 <PERSON  Bourne> <PERSON  Y,> <PERSON  Watson> <AllCaps> MH, <Capitalized> Arvai <AllCaps> AS, <PERSON  Bernstein> <AllCaps> SL, <PERSON  Reed> <AllCaps> SI, <Capitalized> Tainer <AllCaps> JA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Centre <Capitalized> National de la <Capitalized> Recherche <Capitalized> Scientifique, <LOCATION  Marseille,> <PERSON France> yves@afmb.cnrs-mrs.fr 
 
 BACKGROUND: <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae protein Cks1 (cyclin-dependent kinase subunit 1) is essential for cell-cycle progression. <Capitalized> The biological function of Cks1 can be modulated by a switch between two distinct molecular assemblies: the single domain fold, which results from the closing of a beta-hinge motif, and the intersubunit beta-strand interchanged dimer, which arises from the opening of the beta-hinge motif. <Capitalized> The crystal structure of a cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk) in complex with the human <Capitalized> Cks homolog CksHs1 single-domain fold revealed the importance of conserved hydrophobic residues and charged residues within the beta-hinge motif. RESULTS: <Capitalized> The 3.0 <AllCaps> A resolution Cks1 structure reveals the strict structural conservation of the <Capitalized> Cks alpha/beta-core fold and the beta-hinge motif. <Capitalized> The beta hinge identified in the Cks1 structure includes a novel pivot and exposes a cluster of conserved tyrosine residues that are involved in <Capitalized> Cdk binding but are sequestered in the beta-interchanged <Capitalized> Cks homolog suc1 dimer structure. <Capitalized> This Cks1 structure confirms the conservation of the <Capitalized> Cks anion-binding site, which interacts with sidechain residues from the C-terminal alpha helix of another subunit in the crystal. CONCLUSIONS: <Capitalized> The Cks1 structure exemplifies the conservation of the beta-interchanged dimer and the anion-binding site in evolutionarily distant yeast and human <Capitalized> Cks homologs. <Capitalized> Mutational analyses including in vivo rescue of <EndsInDigit> CKS1 disruption support the dual functional roles of the beta-hinge residue Glu94, which participates in <Capitalized> Cdk binding, and of the anion-binding pocket that is located 22 <AllCaps> A away and on an opposite face to Glu94. <Capitalized> The Cks1 structure suggests a biological role for the beta-interchanged dimer and the anion-binding site in targeting <Capitalized> Cdks to specific phosphoproteins during cell-cycle progression.

 PP2A is a central regulator of eukaryotic signal transduction. <Capitalized> The human catalytic subunit PP2Acalpha functionally replaces the endogenous yeast enzyme, Pph22p, indicating a conservation of function in vivo. <Capitalized> Therefore, yeast cells were employed to explore the role of invariant PP2Ac residues. <Capitalized> The PP2Acalpha Y127N substitution abolished essential PP2Ac function in vivo and impaired catalysis severely in vitro, consistent with the prediction from structural studies that Tyr-127 mediates substrate binding and its side chain interacts with the key active site residues His-118 and Asp-88. <Capitalized> The V159E substitution similarly impaired PP2Acalpha catalysis profoundly and may cause global disruption of the active site. <Capitalized> Two conditional mutations in the yeast Pph22p protein, F232S and P240H, were found to cause temperature-sensitive impairment of PP2Ac catalytic function in vitro. <PERSON  Thus,> the mitotic and cell lysis defects conferred by these mutations result from a loss of PP2Ac enzyme activity. <Capitalized> Substitution of the PP2Acalpha C-terminal Tyr-307 residue by phenylalanine impaired protein function, whereas the Y307D and T304D substitutions abolished essential function in vivo. <Capitalized> Nevertheless, Y307D did not reduce PP2Acalpha catalytic activity significantly in vitro, consistent with an important role for the <AllCaps> C terminus in mediating essential protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> Our results identify key residues important for PP2Ac function and characterize new reagents for the study of PP2A in vivo.

 <Capitalized> Four years of post-genomic life with 6,000 yeast genes. 
 
 <Capitalized> Goffeau <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <PERSON  Unite> de <Capitalized> Biochimie <Capitalized> Physiologique, <Capitalized> Universite <Capitalized> Catholique de <Capitalized> Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, <LOCATION Belgium> goffeau@fysa.ucl.ac.be 
 
 <Capitalized> Four years after disclosure of the full yeast genome sequence, a series of resources including tens of thousands of mutant strains, plasmids bearing isolated genes and disruption cassettes are becoming publicly available. <Capitalized> Deletions of each of the 6,000 putative yeast genes are being screened systematically for dozens of phenotypic traits. <Capitalized> In addition, new global approaches such as <AllCaps> DNA hybridization arrays, quantitative proteomics and two-hybrid interactions are being steadily improved. <Capitalized> They progressively build up an immense computation network of billions of data points which will, within the next decade, characterize all molecular interactions occurring in a simple eukaryotic cell. <Capitalized> In this process of acquisition of new basic knowledge, an international community of over 1,000 laboratories cooperates with a remarkable willingness to share projects and results.

 392: <AllCaps> J <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol 2000 <PERSON  Sep> 1;301(5):1097-112 
 
 <Capitalized> The strength of acidic activation domains correlates with their affinity for both transcriptional and non-transcriptional proteins. 
 
 <Capitalized> Melcher <AllCaps> K. 
 
 <Capitalized> Departments of <Capitalized> Internal <Capitalized> Medicine and <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Southwestern <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> 5323 <PERSON  Harry> <PERSON  Hines> Blvd., <PERSON  Dallas,> <AllCaps> TX, 75235-8573, <LOCATION  USA.> K.Melcher@em.uni-frankfurt.de 
 
 <Capitalized> Activation domains (ADs) appear to work by making specific protein-protein contacts with the transcriptional machinery. <Capitalized> However, ADs show no apparent sequence conservation, they can be functionally replaced by a number of random peptides and unrelated proteins, and their function does not depend on sustaining a complex tertiary structure. <Capitalized> To gain a broader perspective on the nature of interactions between acidic ADs and several of their proposed targets, the in vivo strengths of viral, human, yeast, and artificial activation domains were determined under physiological conditions, and mutant ADs with increased in vivo potencies were selected. <Capitalized> The affinities between ADs and proposed targets were determined in vitro and all interactions were found to be of low-level affinity with dissociation constants above 10(-7)M. <Capitalized> However, in vivo potencies of all ADs correlated nearly perfectly with their affinities for transcriptional proteins. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, the weak interactions of the different ADs with at least two non-transcriptional proteins show the same rank order of binding and <AllCaps> AD mutants selected for increased in vivo strength also have increased affinities to non-transcriptional proteins. <Capitalized> Based on these results, isolated acidic ADs can bind with relatively low-level specificity and affinity to many different proteins and the strength of these semi-specific interactions determine the strength of an <AllCaps> AD. <AllCaps> I suggest that ADs expose flexible hydrophobic elements in an aqueous environment to contact hydrophobic patches over short distances, shifting specificity of activators largely to the <AllCaps> DNA colocalization of arrays of ADs and targets. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press. 
 
 PMID: 10966808 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <Capitalized> The initiation of <AllCaps> DNA replication in eukaryotic cells is tightly controlled to ensure that the genome is faithfully duplicated once each cell cycle. <Capitalized> Genetic and biochemical studies in several model systems indicate that initiation is mediated by a common set of proteins, present in all eukaryotic species, and that the activities of these proteins are regulated during the cell cycle by specific protein kinases. <Capitalized> Here we review the properties of the initiation proteins, their interactions with each other, and with origins of <AllCaps> DNA replication. <Capitalized> We also describe recent advances in understanding how the regulatory protein kinases control the progress of the initiation reaction. <Capitalized> Finally, we describe the checkpoint mechanisms that function to preserve the integrity of the genome when the normal course of genome duplication is perturbed by factors that damage the <AllCaps> DNA or inhibit <AllCaps> DNA synthesis.

 <Capitalized> The process of <MixedCase> mRNA turnover is a critical component of the regulation of gene expression. <Capitalized> In the past few years a discrete set of pathways for the degradation of polyadenylated <MixedCase> mRNAs in eukaryotic cells have been described. <AllCaps> A major pathway of <MixedCase> mRNA degradation in yeast occurs by deadenylation of the mRNA, which leads to a decapping reaction, thereby exposing the <MixedCase> mRNA to rapid 5' to 3' exonucleolytic degradation. <AllCaps> A critical step in this pathway is decapping, since it effectively terminates the existence of the <MixedCase> mRNA and is the site of numerous control inputs. <Capitalized> In this review, we discuss the properties of the decapping enzyme and how its activity is regulated to give rise to differential <MixedCase> mRNA turnover. <AllCaps> A key point is that decapping appears to be controlled by access of the enzyme to the cap structure in a competition with the translation initiation complex. <Capitalized> Strikingly, several proteins required for <MixedCase> mRNA decapping show interactions with the translation machinery and suggest possible mechanisms for the triggering of <MixedCase> mRNA decapping.

 <Capitalized> Precerebellin (Cbln1) is the precursor of the brain-specific hexadecapeptide cerebellin. <Capitalized> Although cerebellin has properties of a conventional neuropeptide, its function is controversial because Cbln1 has structural features characteristic of circulating atypical collagens. Cbln1 is related to the three subunits of the complement C1q complex. <Capitalized> Therefore, we hypothesized that Cbln1 participated in analogous heteromeric complexes with precerebellin-related proteins. <Capitalized> Using LexA-Cbln1 as bait in a yeast two-hybrid screen, we isolated a <MixedCase> cDNA encoding a novel Cbln1-related protein, designated Cbln3. <Capitalized> The gene encoding cbln3 had the same intron-exon structure as cbln1 but mapped to a different mouse chromosome (14). <Capitalized> The deduced amino acid sequence of Cbln3 was 55% identical to Cbln1 and also contained a C1q signature domain and signal sequence for secretion. <Capitalized> In addition to binding avidly to Cbln3, Cbln1 also formed homomeric complexes. <Capitalized> In contrast, Cbln3 homomeric association was weak. <Capitalized> These interactions exhibited specificity because C1qB bound to neither Cbln1 nor Cbln3. <PERSON  Like> cbln1, cbln3 was expressed in the cerebellum and dorsal cochlear nucleus in which it was detected in granule neurons. <Capitalized> Because Cbln1 and Cbln3 are coexpressed in the brain and interact avidly, they may function as a secreted heteromeric complex in vivo.

 <Capitalized> Patel <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Jazrawi <AllCaps> E, <PERSON  Creighton> <AllCaps> AM, <LOCATION  Austin> <AllCaps> CA, <PERSON  Fisher> <AllCaps> LM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics <Capitalized> Group, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Immunology, St. George's <Capitalized> Hospital <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  London,> <LOCATION  London,> <Capitalized> United <PERSON Kingdom> 
 
 <Capitalized> Topoisomerase <AllCaps> II is an ATP-operated protein clamp that captures a <AllCaps> DNA helix and transports it through another <AllCaps> DNA duplex, allowing chromosome segregation at mitosis. <AllCaps> A number of cytotoxic bisdioxopiperazines such as ICRF-193 target topoisomerase <AllCaps> II by binding and trapping the closed enzyme clamp. <Capitalized> To investigate this unusual mode of action, we have used yeast to select plasmid-borne human topoisomerase IIalpha alleles resistant to ICRF-193. <Capitalized> Mutations in topoisomerase IIalpha of Leu-169 to <Capitalized> Phe (L169F) (in the N-terminal ATPase domain) and Ala-648 to <Capitalized> Pro (A648P) (in the core domain) were identified as conferring >50-fold and 5-fold resistance to ICRF-193 in vivo, respectively. <Capitalized> The L169F mutation, located next to the <PERSON  Walker> <AllCaps> A box ATP-binding sequence, resulted in a mutant enzyme displaying ICRF-193-resistant topoisomerase and ATPase activities and whose closed clamp was refractory to ICRF-193-mediated trapping as an annulus on closed circular <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> These data imply that the mutation interferes directly with ICRF-193 binding to the N-terminal ATPase gate. <Capitalized> In contrast, the A648P enzyme displayed topoisomerase activities exhibiting wild-type sensitivity to ICRF-193. <Capitalized> We suggest that the inefficient trapping of the A648P closed clamp results either from the observed increased <AllCaps> ATP requirement, or more likely, from lowered salt stability, perhaps involving destabilization of ICRF-193 interactions with the B'-B' interface in the core domain. <Capitalized> These results provide evidence for at least two different phenotypic classes of ICRF-193 resistance mutations and suggest that bisdioxopiperazine action involves the interplay of both the ATPase and core domains of topoisomerase IIalpha.

 Two-hybrid systems have become favored tools for detection and analysis of protein interactions because of their low cost and ease of use compared to biochemical or biophysical interaction technologies. <Capitalized> It is possible to augment the utility of two-hybrid systems and derivative systems such as dual-bait two-hybrid systems by adapting strategies that speed the analysis of the relative strength of a series of protein-protein associations. <Capitalized> This report describes two simple techniques that employ either a flatbed scanner or a plate reader to quantitate the activity of colorimetric reporters such as LacZ or GusA commonly used in two-hybrid approaches.

 <Capitalized> Loss control of Mcm5 interaction with chromatin in cdc6-1 mutated in <ContainsHyphen> CDC-NTP motif. 
 
 <Capitalized> Feng <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Hu <PERSON  Y,> <PERSON  Wang> <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Wu> <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Jong> <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of Hematology/Oncology, <Capitalized> Childrens <Capitalized> Hospital <LOCATION  Los Angeles,> and <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  Southern> <LOCATION  California,> <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, 90027, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Cdc6 plays an essential role in establishing and maintaining the prereplicative complex (pre-RC) by interacting with the origin recognition complex (ORC) and associating with chromatin origins. <Capitalized> These interactions are required to load minichromosome maintenance proteins (MCMs) and other initiator proteins onto replication origins. <Capitalized> Although the temperature-sensitive cdc6 mutant, cdc6-1, has been widely used for these studies, the molecular mechanism of the cdc6-1 mutation has been unclear. <Capitalized> In this study, we have identified a base substitution at Gly260-->Asp, near the <ContainsHyphen> CDC-NTP motif. <Capitalized> Using a chromatin immunoprecipitation assay (CHIP), we found that cdc6-1 fails to load Mcm5 onto the replication origins. <Capitalized> Chromatin fractions were used to study Mcm5 binding in both the wildtype and mutant background. <Capitalized> These studies indicated that Cdc6 is also involved in unloading Mcm5 from chromatin. <Capitalized> Specifically, the cdc6-1 mutation protein, cdc6(G260D), which failed to load Mcm5 onto replication origins, also failed to unload the Mcm5 protein. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the overexpression of wildtype <EndsInDigit> CDC6 accelerated the unloading of Mcm5 from chromatin fractions. <Capitalized> In the absence of functional Cdc6, the Mcm5 protein showed nonorigin binding to chromatin with the cell cycle arrested at the G1S phase transition. <Capitalized> Our results suggested that the cdc6(G260D) mutant protein fails to assemble an operational replicative complex and that wildtype Cdc6 plays a role in preventing re-replication by controlling the unloading the MCMs from chromatin origins.

 <Capitalized> Vilela <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Velasco <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Ptushkina <AllCaps> M, <PERSON McCarthy> <AllCaps> JE.

Dcp1 interacts with the N-terminal region of eIF4G but does not compete significantly with eIF4E or Pab1 for binding to eIF4G. <PERSON  Most> importantly, eIF4G acts as a function-enhancing recruitment factor for Dcp1. <Capitalized> However, eIF4E blocks this effect as a component of the high affinity cap-binding complex eIF4E-eIF4G. <Capitalized> Indeed, cooperative enhancement of the eIF4E-cap interaction stabilizes yeast <MixedCase> mRNAs in vivo. <Capitalized> These data on interactions at the interface between translation and <MixedCase> mRNA decay suggest how events at the 5' cap and 3' poly(A) tail might be coupled.

 <Capitalized> Structural basis for the species-specific activity of <AllCaps> TFIIS. 
 
 <Capitalized> Shimasaki <AllCaps> NB, <PERSON  Kane> <AllCaps> CM.

 <Capitalized> Many proteins involved in eukaryotic transcription are similar in function and in sequence between organisms. <Capitalized> Despite the sequence similarities, there are many factors that do not function across species. <Capitalized> For example, transcript elongation factor <AllCaps> TFIIS is highly conserved among eukaryotes, and yet the <AllCaps> TFIIS protein from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae cannot function with mammalian <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II and vice versa. <Capitalized> To determine the reason for this species specificity, chimeras were constructed linking three structurally independent regions of the <AllCaps> TFIIS proteins from yeast and human cells. <Capitalized> Two independently folding domains, <AllCaps> II and <AllCaps> III, have been examined previously using <AllCaps> NMR (). <Capitalized> Yeast domain <AllCaps> II alone is able to bind yeast <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II with the same affinity as the full-length <AllCaps> TFIIS protein, and this domain was expected to confer the species selectivity. <Capitalized> Domain <AllCaps> III has previously been shown to be readily exchanged between mammalian and yeast factors. <Capitalized> However, the results presented here indicate that domain <AllCaps> II is insufficient to confer species selectivity, and a primary determinant lies in a 30-amino acid highly conserved linker region connecting domain <AllCaps> II with domain <AllCaps> III. <Capitalized> These 30 amino acids may physically orient domains <AllCaps> II and <AllCaps> III to support functional interactions between <AllCaps> TFIIS and <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II.

 <Capitalized> In the nucleus, transcription factors must contend with the presence of chromatin in order to gain access to their cognate regulatory sequences. <Capitalized> As most nuclear <AllCaps> DNA is assembled into nucleosomes, activators must either invade a stable, preassembled nucleosome or preempt the formation of nucleosomes on newly replicated <AllCaps> DNA, which is transiently free of histones. <Capitalized> We have investigated the mechanism by which heat shock factor (HSF) binds to target nucleosomal heat shock elements (HSEs), using as our model a dinucleosomal heat shock promoter (hsp82-DeltaHSE1). <Capitalized> We find that activated <AllCaps> HSF cannot bind a stable, sequence-positioned nucleosome in G(1)-arrested cells. <Capitalized> It can do so readily, however, following release from G(1) arrest or after the imposition of either an early S- or late G(2)-phase arrest. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, despite the S-phase requirement, <AllCaps> HSF nucleosomal binding activity is restored in the absence of hsp82 replication. <Capitalized> These results contrast with the prevailing paradigm for activator-nucleosome interactions and implicate a nonreplicative, S-phase-specific event as a prerequisite for <AllCaps> HSF binding to nucleosomal sites in vivo.

UAS2, located approximately 250 bp from the transcriptional start site, resembles a <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae stress response element. <EndsInDigit> UAS2 is bound by transcriptional activators and repressors regulated by both the <AllCaps> PKA and <AllCaps> MAPK pathways, although atf1 itself is not present in these complexes. <Capitalized> Transcriptional regulation of fbp1 promoter constructs containing only <EndsInDigit> UAS1 or <EndsInDigit> UAS2 confirms that the <AllCaps> PKA and <AllCaps> MAPK regulation is targeted to both sites. <Capitalized> We conclude that the <AllCaps> PKA and <AllCaps> MAPK signal transduction pathways regulate fbp1 transcription at <EndsInDigit> UAS1 and UAS2, but that the antagonistic interactions between these pathways involve different mechanisms at each site.

 408: <Capitalized> Biochemistry 2000 <Capitalized> Aug 15;39(32):9909-16 
 
 <Capitalized> Effects of 5' leader and 3' trailer structures on pre-tRNA processing by nuclear RNase <PERSON  P.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Ziehler <AllCaps> WA, <PERSON  Day> <AllCaps> JJ, <Capitalized> Fierke <AllCaps> CA, <PERSON  Engelke> <AllCaps> DR. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor,> <LOCATION  Michigan> 48109-0606, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Eukaryotic transfer <AllCaps> RNA precursors (pre-tRNAs) contain a 5' leader preceding the aminoacyl acceptor stem and a 3' trailer extending beyond this stem. <Capitalized> An early step in pre-tRNA maturation is removal of the 5' leader by the endoribonuclease, RNase <PERSON  P.> <Capitalized> Extensive pairing between leader and trailer sequences has previously been demonstrated to block RNase <PERSON  P> cleavage, suggesting that the 5' leader and 3' trailer sequences might need to be separated for the substrate to be recognized by the eukaryotic holoenzyme. <Capitalized> To address whether the nuclear RNase <PERSON  P> holoenzyme recognizes the 5' leader and 3' trailer sequences independently, interactions of RNase <PERSON  P> with pre-tRNA(Tyr) containing either the 5' leader, the 3' trailer, or both were examined. <Capitalized> Kinetic analysis revealed little effect of the 3' trailer or a long 5' leader on the catalytic rate (k(cat)) for cleavage using the various pre-tRNA derivatives. <Capitalized> However, the presence of a 3' trailer that pairs with the 5' leader increases the K(m) of pre-tRNA slightly, in agreement with previous results. <Capitalized> Similarly, competition studies demonstrate that removal of a complementary 3' trailer lowers the apparent K(I), consistent with the structure between these two sequences interfering with their interaction with the enzyme. <Capitalized> Deletion of both the 5' and 3' extensions to give mature termini resulted in the least effective competitor. <PERSON  Further> studies showed that the nuclear holoenzyme, but not the <AllCaps> B. subtilis holoenzyme, had a high affinity for single-stranded <AllCaps> RNA in the absence of attached <MixedCase> tRNA structure. <Capitalized> The data suggest that yeast nuclear RNase <PERSON  P> contains a minimum of two binding sites involved in substrate recognition, one that interacts with <MixedCase> tRNA and one that interacts with the 3' trailer. <Capitalized> Furthermore, base pairing between the 5' leader and 3' trailer hinders recognition.

 <PERSON  Fleischmann> <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Lederer> <AllCaps> F, <PERSON  Muller> <AllCaps> F, <PERSON  Bacher> <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Ruterjans <AllCaps> H. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Biophysikalische <Capitalized> Chemie, J.W. Goethe-Universitat, <Capitalized> Biozentrum N230, <Capitalized> Frankfurt, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <AllCaps> A new procedure was devised for reversibly removing the flavin from flavocytochrome b2. <Capitalized> It allowed reconstitution with selectively enriched 13C- and 15N-labelled <AllCaps> FMN for an <AllCaps> NMR analysis of the chemical shifts of the enriched positions as well as that of 31P. <Capitalized> From these measurements, it was possible to deduce information about the hydrogen-bonding pattern of <AllCaps> FMN in the protein, the hybridization states of the nitrogen atoms and (in part) the pi-electron distribution. <Capitalized> The carbonyl groups at C(2) and C(4) and the nitrogen atoms N(1) and N(5) form hydrogen bonds to the apoenzyme in both redox states. <Capitalized> Nevertheless, according to 15N-chemical shifts, the bond from the protein to N(3) is very weak in both redox states, whereas that to N(5) is strong for the oxidized state, and is weakened upon flavin reduction. <Capitalized> On the other hand, the 13C-NMR results indicate that the C(2) and C(4) carbonyl oxygens form stronger hydrogen bonds with the enzyme than most other flavoproteins in both redox states. <Capitalized> From coupling constant measurements it is shown that the N(3) proton is not solvent accessible. <Capitalized> Although no <ContainsHyphen> N-H coupling constant could be measured for N(5) in the reduced state due to lack of resolution, N(5) is clearly protonated in flavocytochrome b2 as in all other known flavoproteins. <Capitalized> With respect to N(10), it is more sp3-hybridized in the oxidized state than in free <AllCaps> FMN, whereas the other nitrogen atoms show a nearly planar structure. <Capitalized> In the reduced state, N(5) and N(10) in bound <AllCaps> FMN are both more sp3-hybridized than in free <AllCaps> FMN, but N(5) exhibits a higher degree of sp3-hybridization than N(10), which is only slightly shifted out of the isoalloxazine plane. <Capitalized> In addition, two-electron reduction of the enzyme leads to anion formation on N(1), as indicated by its 15N-chemical shift of N(1) and characteristic upfield shifts of the resonances of C(2), C(4) and C(4a) compared to the oxidized state, as observed for most flavoproteins. 31P-NMR measurements show that the phosphate geometry has changed in enzyme bound <AllCaps> FMN compared to the free flavin in water, indicating a strong interaction of the phosphate group with the apoenzyme.  <LOCATION  Boston> <Capitalized> Biomedical <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Institute and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Pharmacology, <Capitalized> Harvard <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <Capitalized> Watertown, <AllCaps> MA 02472, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Mitochondrial transport proteins (MTP) typically are homodimeric with a 30-kDa subunit with six transmembrane helices. <Capitalized> The subunit possesses a sequence motif highly similar to <Capitalized> Pro <PERSON  X> Asp/Glu <PERSON  X> <PERSON  X> Lys/Arg <PERSON  X> <Capitalized> Arg within each of its three similar 10-kDa segments. <Capitalized> Four (YNL083W, YFR045W, YPR021C, YDR470C) of the 35 yeast (S. cerevisiae) <AllCaps> MTP genes were resequenced since the masses of their proteins deviate significantly from the typical 30 kDa. <Capitalized> We now find these four proteins to have 545, 285, 902, and 502 residues, respectively. <Capitalized> Together with only four other MTPs, the sequences of YPR021C and YDR470C show substitutions of some of the five residues that are absolutely conserved among the 12 MTPs with identified transport function and 17 other MTPs. <Capitalized> We do now find these five consensus residues also in the new sequences of YNL083W and YFR045W. <Capitalized> Additional analyses of the 35 yeast MTPs show that the location of transmembrane helix sequences do not correlate with the general consensus residues of the <AllCaps> MTP family; protein segments connecting the six transmembrane helices and facing the intermembrane space are not uniformly short (about 20 residues) or long (about 40 residues) when facing the matrix; most MTPs have at least one transmembrane helix for which the sum of the negative hydropathy values of all residues yields a very small negative value, suggesting a membrane location bordering polar faces of other transmembrane helices or a non-transmembrane location. <Capitalized> The extra residues of the three large MTPs are hydrophilic and at the N-terminal. <Capitalized> The 200-residue N-terminal segment of YNL083W has four putative Ca2+-binding sites. <Capitalized> The 500-residue N-terminal segment of YPR021C shows sequence similarity to enzymes of nucleic acid metabolism. <MixedCase> cDNA microarray data show that YNL083W is expressed solely during sporulation, while the expressions of YFR045W, YPR021C, and YDR470C are induced by various stress situations. <Capitalized> These results also show that the 35 <AllCaps> MTP genes are expressed under a rather diverse set of metabolic conditions that may help identify the function of the proteins. <Capitalized> Interestingly, yeast two-hybrid screens, that will also be useful in identifying the function of MTPs, indicate that MIR1, AAC3, YOR100C, and YPR011C do interact with non-MTPs.

 <Capitalized> The earliest known step in yeast spindle pole body (SPB) duplication requires Cdc31p and Kar1p, two physically interacting <AllCaps> SPB components, and Dsk2p and Rad23p, a pair of ubiquitin-like proteins. <Capitalized> Components of the <EndsInDigit> PKC1 pathway were found to interact with these <AllCaps> SPB duplication genes in two independent genetic screens. <Capitalized> Initially, <EndsInDigit> SLG1 and <EndsInDigit> PKC1 were obtained as high-copy suppressors of dsk2Delta rad23Delta and a mutation in <EndsInDigit> MPK1 was synthetically lethal with kar1-Delta17. <Capitalized> Subsequently, we demonstrated extensive genetic interactions between the <EndsInDigit> PKC1 pathway and the <AllCaps> SPB duplication mutants that affect Cdc31p function. <Capitalized> The genetic interactions are unlikely to be related to the cell-wall integrity function of the <EndsInDigit> PKC1 pathway because the <AllCaps> SPB mutants did not exhibit cell-wall defects. <Capitalized> Overexpression of multiple <EndsInDigit> PKC1 pathway components suppressed the G2/M arrest of the <AllCaps> SPB duplication mutants and mutations in <EndsInDigit> MPK1 exacerbated the cell cycle arrest of kar1-Delta17, suggesting a role for the <EndsInDigit> PKC1 pathway in <AllCaps> SPB duplication. <Capitalized> We also found that mutations in SPC110, which encodes a major <AllCaps> SPB component, showed genetic interactions with both <EndsInDigit> CDC31 and the <EndsInDigit> PKC1 pathway. <Capitalized> In support of the model that the <EndsInDigit> PKC1 pathway regulates <AllCaps> SPB duplication, one of the phosphorylated forms of Spc110p was absent in pkc1 and mpk1Delta mutants.

 <PERSON  Mason> <AllCaps> N, <Capitalized> Ciufo <AllCaps> LF, <PERSON  Brown> <AllCaps> JD.

 <Capitalized> Signal recognition particle (SRP) targets proteins for co-translational insertion through or into the endoplasmic reticulum membrane. <Capitalized> Mammalian <AllCaps> SRP slows nascent chain elongation by the ribosome during targeting in vitro. <Capitalized> This 'elongation arrest' activity requires the SRP9/14 subunit of the particle and interactions of the C-terminus of SRP14. <Capitalized> We have purified <AllCaps> SRP from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and demonstrated that it too has elongation arrest activity. <AllCaps> A yeast <AllCaps> SRP containing Srp14p truncated at its C-terminus (delta C29) did not maintain elongation arrest, was substantially deficient in promoting translocation and interfered with targeting by wild-type <AllCaps> SRP. <Capitalized> In vivo, this mutation conferred a constitutive defect in the coupling of protein translation and translocation and temperature-sensitive growth, but only a slight defect in protein translocation. <Capitalized> In combination, these data indicate that the primary defect in <AllCaps> SRP delta <EndsInDigit> C29 is in elongation arrest, and that this is a physiologically important and conserved function of eukaryotic <AllCaps> SRP.

 <Capitalized> Mismatch repair (MMR) proteins play a critical role in maintaining the mitotic stability of eukaryotic genomes. <AllCaps> MMR proteins repair errors made during <AllCaps> DNA replication and in their absence, mutations accumulate at elevated rates. <Capitalized> In addition, <AllCaps> MMR proteins inhibit recombination between non-identical <AllCaps> DNA sequences, and hence prevent genome rearrangements resulting from interactions between repetitive elements. <Capitalized> This review provides an overview of the anti-mutator and anti-recombination functions of <AllCaps> MMR proteins in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

 <Capitalized> Tying up loose ends: nonhomologous end-joining in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <PERSON  Lewis> <AllCaps> LK, <Capitalized> Resnick <AllCaps> MA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Chromosome <Capitalized> Stability <Capitalized> Group, <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Environmental <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Sciences, <AllCaps> PO <PERSON  Box> 12233, 111 <PERSON  Alexander> <Capitalized> Drive, <AllCaps> NIH, <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Triangle <PERSON  Park,> <AllCaps> NC 27709, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The ends of chromosomal <AllCaps> DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) can be accurately rejoined by at least two discrete pathways, homologous recombination and nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ). <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> NHEJ pathway is essential for repair of specific classes of <AllCaps> DSB termini in cells of the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Endonuclease-induced DSBs retaining complementary single-stranded <AllCaps> DNA overhangs are repaired efficiently by end-joining. <Capitalized> In contrast, damaged <AllCaps> DSB ends (e.g., termini produced by ionizing radiation) are poor substrates for this pathway. <AllCaps> NHEJ repair involves the functions of at least 10 genes, including YKU70, YKU80, DNL4, LIF1, SIR2, SIR3, SIR4, RAD50, MRE11, and XRS2. <PERSON  Most> or all of these genes are required for efficient recombination-independent recircularization of linearized plasmids and for rejoining of EcoRI endonuclease-induced chromosomal DSBs in vivo. <Capitalized> Several <AllCaps> NHEJ mutants also display aberrant processing and rejoining of DSBs that are generated by <AllCaps> HO endonuclease or formed spontaneously in dicentric plasmids. <Capitalized> In addition, all <AllCaps> NHEJ genes except <EndsInDigit> DNL4 and <EndsInDigit> LIF1 are required for stabilization of telomeric repeat sequences. <Capitalized> Each of the proteins involved in <AllCaps> NHEJ appears to bind, directly or through protein associations, with the ends of linear <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Enzymatic and/or structural roles in the rejoining of <AllCaps> DSB termini have been postulated for several proteins within the group. <PERSON  Most> yeast <AllCaps> NHEJ genes have homologues in human cells and many biochemical activities and protein:protein interactions have been conserved in higher eucaryotes. <Capitalized> Similarities and differences between <AllCaps> NHEJ repair in yeast and mammalian cells are discussed.

 <Capitalized> Many researchers have explored the extent to which yeast can be used to dissect the mechanisms of programmed cell death in higher cells. <Capitalized> Yeast has been used as a system to analyze protein-protein interactions and structure-function relationships, and as a cloning tool to identify novel higher eukaryote regulators of apoptosis. <Capitalized> In addition, classic genetic strategies in yeast have been used to analyze the mechanisms of action of core pathway members. <Capitalized> The purpose of this chapter is to describe the strategies pursued and act as a source for the technical details necessary to exploit the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe in the context of programmed cell death.

 <PERSON  Davie> <AllCaps> JK, <PERSON  Kane> <AllCaps> CM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  Berkeley,> <LOCATION  California> 94720-3202, <LOCATION  USA.>

 <Capitalized> Evidence for interaction of yeast protein kinase <AllCaps> C with several subunits of oligosaccharyl transferase.

 422: <Capitalized> Structure <Capitalized> Fold <PERSON  Des> 2000 <PERSON  Jul> 15;8(7):751-62 
 
 X-ray structure of <Capitalized> Escherichia coli pyridoxine 5'-phosphate oxidase complexed with <AllCaps> FMN at 1.8 <AllCaps> A resolution. 
 
 <Capitalized> Safo <AllCaps> MK, <PERSON  Mathews> <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Musayev <AllCaps> FN, di <Capitalized> Salvo <AllCaps> ML, <PERSON  Thiel> <AllCaps> DJ, <PERSON  Abraham> <AllCaps> DJ, <Capitalized> Schirch <PERSON  V.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Structural <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Drug <Capitalized> Discovery, <LOCATION  Virginia> <Capitalized> Commonwealth <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Richmond,> <AllCaps> VA 23219, <LOCATION  USA.> msafo@hsc.vcu.edu 
 
 BACKGROUND: <Capitalized> Escherichia coli pyridoxine 5'-phosphate oxidase (PNPOx) catalyzes the terminal step in the biosynthesis of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP), a cofactor used by many enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism. <Capitalized> The enzyme oxidizes either the 4'-hydroxyl group of pyridoxine 5'-phosphate (PNP) or the 4'-primary amine of pyridoxamine 5'-phosphate (PMP) to an aldehyde. PNPOx is a homodimeric enzyme with one flavin mononucleotide (FMN) molecule non-covalently bound to each subunit. <AllCaps> A high degree of sequence homology among the 15 known members of the PNPOx family suggests that all members of this group have similar three-dimensional folds. RESULTS: <Capitalized> The crystal structure of PNPOx from <AllCaps> E. coli has been determined to 1.8 <AllCaps> A resolution. <Capitalized> The monomeric subunit folds into an eight-stranded beta sheet surrounded by five alpha-helical structures. <Capitalized> Two monomers related by a twofold axis interact extensively along one-half of each monomer to form the dimer. <Capitalized> There are two clefts at the dimer interface that are symmetry-related and extend from the top to the bottom of the dimer. <Capitalized> An <AllCaps> FMN cofactor that makes interactions with both subunits is located in each of these two clefts. CONCLUSIONS: <Capitalized> The structure is quite similar to the recently deposited 2.7 <AllCaps> A structure of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae PNPOx and also, remarkably, shares a common structural fold with the FMN-binding protein from <Capitalized> Desulfovibrio vulgaris and a domain of chymotrypsin. <Capitalized> This high-resolution <AllCaps> E. coli PNPOx structure permits predictions to be made about residues involved in substrate binding and catalysis. <Capitalized> These predictions provide testable hypotheses, which can be answered by making site-directed mutants.
