 <Capitalized> The amino acid sequence of rainbow trout estrogen receptor (rtER) is highly conserved in the <AllCaps> C domain but presents few similarities in the A/B and <AllCaps> E domains with human estrogen receptor alpha (hER) [NR3A1]. <AllCaps> A previous study has shown that <MixedCase> rtER and <MixedCase> hER have differential functional activities in yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> To determine the domain(s) responsible for these differences, chimeric human/rainbow trout estrogen receptors were constructed. <Capitalized> The A/B, C/D or E/F regions of <MixedCase> rtER were replaced by corresponding regions of <MixedCase> hER and expressed in yeast cells. Ligand-binding and transcription activation abilities of these hybrid receptors were compared with those of wild-type <MixedCase> rtER or hER. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, our data revealed that the human C/D domains play an important role in the magnitude of transactivation of <AllCaps> ER. <Capitalized> Two other chimeric ERs carrying either a <AllCaps> C or <AllCaps> D domain of <MixedCase> hER showed that the <AllCaps> C domain was responsible for this effect whereas the <AllCaps> D domain did not affect hybrid receptor activities. <Capitalized> Moreover, a chimeric <MixedCase> hER carrying the <AllCaps> C domain of <MixedCase> rtER showed maximal transcriptional activity similar to that observed with rtER. <Capitalized> Gel shift assays showed that, whereas <MixedCase> rtER and <MixedCase> hER present a similar binding affinity to an estrogen response element (ERE) element, the <MixedCase> rtER <AllCaps> C domain is responsible for a weaker <AllCaps> DNA binding stability compared to those of hER. <Capitalized> In addition, the human <AllCaps> C domain allows approximately 2 times faster association of <AllCaps> ER to an <AllCaps> ERE. <Capitalized> Utilization of reporter genes containing one or three EREs confirms that <MixedCase> rtER requires protein-protein interactions for its stabilization on <AllCaps> DNA and that the <AllCaps> C domain is involved in this stabilization. <Capitalized> Moreover, AF-1 may be implicated in this synergistic effect of EREs. <Capitalized> Interestingly, although <AllCaps> E domains of these two receptors are much less conserved, replacement of this domain in <MixedCase> rtER by its human counterpart resulted in higher estradiol sensitivity but no increase in the magnitude of transactivation. <Capitalized> Data from the chimeric receptors, rtER(hC) and hER(rtC), demonstrated that <MixedCase> rtER AF-1 and AF-2 activation domains activated transcription in the presence of estradiol similar to both AF-1 and AF-2 hER. <Capitalized> This implies that these domains, which show poor sequence homology, may interact with similar basal transcription factors.

 <Capitalized> Palfi <PERSON  Z,> <PERSON  Lucke> <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Lahm <AllCaps> HW, <PERSON  Lane> <AllCaps> WS, <Capitalized> Kruft <PERSON  V,> Bragado-Nilsson <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Seraphin <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Bindereif <AllCaps> A.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Ludwig> <Capitalized> Boltzmann <Capitalized> Forschungsstelle, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Vienna,> <PERSON Austria> 
 
 <Capitalized> Many cell-cycle-specific events are supported by stage-specific gene expression. <Capitalized> In budding yeast, at least three different nuclear factors seem to cooperate in the periodic activation of G2/M-specific genes. <Capitalized> Here we show, by using chromatin immunoprecipitation polymerase chain reaction assays, that a positive regulator, Ndd1, becomes associated with G2/M promoter regions in manner that depends on the stage in cell cycle. <Capitalized> Its recruitment depends on a permanent protein-DNA complex consisting of the <AllCaps> MADS box protein, Mcm1, and a recently identified partner Fkh2, a forkhead/winged helix related transcription factor. <Capitalized> The lethality of Ndd1 depletion is suppressed by fkh2 null mutations, which indicates that Fkh2 may also have a negative regulatory role in the transcription of G2/M-induced RNAs. <Capitalized> We conclude that Ndd1-Fkh2 interactions may be the transcriptionally important process targeted by <Capitalized> Cdk activity.

 <Capitalized> Glowczewski <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Yang <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Kalashnikova <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Santisteban <AllCaps> MS, <PERSON  Smith> <AllCaps> MM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Cancer <PERSON  Center,> <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Virginia,> <Capitalized> Charlottesville, <LOCATION  Virginia> 22908, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Cse4p is a structural component of the core centromere of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and is a member of the conserved <ContainsHyphen> CENP-A family of specialized histone <EndsInDigit> H3 variants. <Capitalized> The histone <EndsInDigit> H4 allele hhf1-20 confers defects in core centromere chromatin structure and mitotic chromosome transmission. <Capitalized> We have proposed that Cse4p and histone <EndsInDigit> H4 interact through their respective histone fold domains to assemble a nucleosome-like structure at centromeric <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> To test this model, we targeted random mutations to the Cse4p histone fold domain and isolated three temperature-sensitive cse4 alleles in an unbiased genetic screen. <Capitalized> Two of the cse4 alleles contain mutations at the Cse4p-H4 interface. <Capitalized> One of these requires two widely separated mutations demonstrating long-range cooperative interactions in the structure. <Capitalized> The third cse4 allele is mutated at its helix 2-helix 3 interface, a region required for homotypic <EndsInDigit> H3 fold dimerization. <Capitalized> Overexpression of wild-type Cse4p and histone <EndsInDigit> H4 confer reciprocal allele-specific suppression of cse4 and hhf1 mutations, providing strong evidence for Cse4p-H4 protein interaction. <Capitalized> Overexpression of histone <EndsInDigit> H3 is dosage lethal in cse4 mutants, suggesting that histone <EndsInDigit> H3 competes with Cse4p for histone <EndsInDigit> H4 binding. <Capitalized> However, the relative resistance of the Cse4p-H4 pathway to <EndsInDigit> H3 interference argues that centromere chromatin assembly must be highly regulated.

 <Capitalized> Investigations of the active site of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae dolichyl-phosphate-mannose synthase using fluorescent labeled dolichyl-phosphate derivatives. 
 
 <Capitalized> Xing <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Forsee <AllCaps> WT, <Capitalized> Lamani <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Maltsev <AllCaps> SD, <Capitalized> Danilov <AllCaps> LL, <Capitalized> Shibaev <AllCaps> VN, <Capitalized> Schutzbach <AllCaps> JS, <Capitalized> Cheung <AllCaps> HC, <Capitalized> Jedrzejas <AllCaps> MJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Alabama at <LOCATION  Birmingham,> 933 19th <PERSON  Street> <PERSON  South,> <LOCATION  Birmingham,> <Capitalized> Alabama 35295-2041, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Dolichol-phosphate mannose (Dol-P-Man) is a key mannosyl donor for the biosynthesis of N-linked oligosaccharides as well as for O-linked oligosaccharides on yeast glycoproteins, and for the synthesis of the glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol anchor found on many cell surface glycoproteins. <Capitalized> It is synthesized by Dol-P-Man synthase which is the only glycosyltransferase in the dolichol pathway that has been expressed as an active protein, solubilized and purified in large enough quantities for structural investigations. <Capitalized> Earlier studies showed that the enzyme is closely associated with membranes of endoplasmic reticulum with unique lipid requirements for its maximal activity. <Capitalized> This potential target of antibiotic therapy is now being investigated at the molecular level to establish information about the structure of the enzyme as well as determine the nature and properties of the enzyme-phospholipid interactions. <Capitalized> In this paper, we have determined the activities of the fluorescent labeled dolichyl-phosphate derivatives as well as the intramolecular distances between amino acid residues near the active site and/or the fluorophores of the substrate derivatives using fluorescence energy resonance transfer. <Capitalized> These results also show that the conserved consensus sequence is not required by Dol-P-Man synthase neither for the recognition of Dol-P nor for the catalytic activity.

 <PERSON  Fast,> isotope-free methods for the assay of thiamine-binding proteins and for the determination of their affinities to thiamine-related compounds. 
 
 <Capitalized> Mickowska <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Dulinski <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Kozik <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Jan> <Capitalized> Zurzycki <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Jagiellonian <Capitalized> University, Al. <Capitalized> Mickiewicza 3, 31-120, <Capitalized> Krakow, <PERSON Poland> 
 
 <AllCaps> A fast, isotope-free method for the determination of parameters for the interactions of proteins with thiamine and related compounds was developed. <Capitalized> The free and bound forms of a ligand (thiamine or a fluorogenic analogue) were separated by ultrafiltration using commercially available centrifugal protein microconcentrators (Nanosep, <Capitalized> Pall Filtron). <Capitalized> The free thiamine concentration in the filtrate was analysed by (i) a pre-column derivatisation of thiamine to thiochrome with the use of alkaline potassium hexacyanoferrate(III) followed by reverse-phase <AllCaps> HPLC (isocratic, analytical <AllCaps> ODS column, 10 <MixedCase> mM potassium phosphate, <MixedCase> pH 7.8, 5% tetrahydrofuran) with fluorometric detection (excitation at 365 nm, emission at 430 nm), or (ii) an ion-pair reverse-phase <AllCaps> HPLC (isocratic, <AllCaps> ODS column, 0.08% trifluoroacetic acid-0.08% sodium octanesulfonate-25% tetrahydrofuran) with post-column derivatisation and fluorometric detection. <Capitalized> The 'saturation-binding' version (single ligand added in increasing doses to the protein samples) of this method allowed the determination of low micromolar concentrations of thiamine-binding proteins and of the dissociation constants of their complexes with thiamine or fluorogenic thiamine analogues in the range of 0.3-10 microM. <Capitalized> Using the other, 'competitive displacement' version (constant amount of thiamine plus increasing doses of a competing ligand), dissociation constants at least one order of magnitude higher could successfully be determined.

 <PERSON  Petersen> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Hawkes> <AllCaps> TR, <PERSON  Lowe> <AllCaps> DJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Nitrogen <Capitalized> Fixation <Capitalized> Laboratory, <PERSON  John> <PERSON  Innes> <Capitalized> Centre, <LOCATION  Norwich,> <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Imidazole glycerol phosphate dehydratase (IGPD) catalyses the dehydration of imidazole glycerol phosphate to imidazole acetol phosphate, an important late step in the biosynthesis of histidine. <AllCaps> IGPD, isolated as a low molecular weight and inactive apo-form, assembles with specific divalent metal cations to form a catalytically active high molecular weight metalloenzyme. Oxo-vanadium ions also assemble the protein into, apparently, the same high molecular weight form but, uniquely, yield a protein without catalytic activity. <Capitalized> The VO2+ derivative of <AllCaps> IGPD has been investigated by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), electron nuclear double resonance (ENDOR) and electron spin echo envelope modulation (ESEEM) spectroscopy. <Capitalized> The spin <Capitalized> Hamiltonian parameters indicate the presence of multiple 14N nuclei in the inner coordination sphere of VO2+ which is corroborated by <AllCaps> ENDOR and <AllCaps> ESEEM spectra showing resonances attributable to interactions with 14N nuclei. <Capitalized> The isotropic superhyperfine coupling component of about 7 MHz determined by <AllCaps> ENDOR is consistent with a nitrogen of coordinated histidine imidazole(s). <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> ESEEM Fourier-transform spectra further support the notion that the VO2+ substituted enzyme contains inner-sphere nitrogen ligands. <Capitalized> The isotropic and anisotropic 14N superhyperfine coupling components are similar to those reported for other equatorially coordinated enzymatic histidine imidazole systems. <AllCaps> ESEEM resonances from axial 14N ligands are discussed.

 <Capitalized> Noubhani <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Bunoust <AllCaps> O, <Capitalized> Rigoulet <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Thevelein <AllCaps> JM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Laboratorium voor <Capitalized> Moleculaire <Capitalized> Celbiologie, <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Botany and <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> Katholieke <Capitalized> Universiteit <PERSON  Leuven,> <PERSON  Flanders,> <LOCATION Belgium> 
 
 <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, TPS1-encoded trehalose-6-phosphate synthase (TPS) exerts an essential control on the influx of glucose into glycolysis, presumably by restricting hexokinase activity. <Capitalized> Deletion of <EndsInDigit> TPS1 results in severe hyperaccumulation of sugar phosphates and near absence of ethanol formation. <Capitalized> To investigate whether trehalose 6-phosphate (Tre6P) is the sole mediator of hexokinase inhibition, we have reconstituted ethanolic fermentation from glucose in permeabilized spheroplasts of the wild-type, tps1Delta and tps2Delta (Tre6P phosphatase) strains. <Capitalized> For the tps1Delta strain, ethanol production was significantly lower and was associated with hyperaccumulation of Glu6P and Fru6P. <AllCaps> A tps2Delta strain shows reduced accumulation of Glu6P and Fru6P both in intact cells and in permeabilized spheroplasts. <Capitalized> These results are not consistent with Tre6P being the sole mediator of hexokinase inhibition. <Capitalized> Reconstitution of ethanolic fermentation in permeabilized spheroplasts with glycolytic intermediates indicates additional target site(s) for the Tps1 control. <Capitalized> Addition of Tre6P partially shifts the ethanol production rate and the metabolite pattern in permeabilized tps1Delta spheroplasts to those of the wild-type strain, but only with glucose as substrate. <Capitalized> This is observed at a very high ratio of glucose to Tre6P. <Capitalized> Inhibition of hexokinase activity by Tre6P is less efficiently counteracted by glucose in permeabilized spheroplasts compared to cell extracts, and this effect is largely abolished by deletion of <EndsInDigit> TPS2 but not TPS1. <Capitalized> In permeabilized spheroplasts, hexokinase activity is significantly lower in a tps2Delta strain compared to a wild-type strain and this difference is strongly reduced by additional deletion of TPS1. <Capitalized> These results indicate that Tps1-mediated protein-protein interactions are important for control of glucose influx into yeast glycolysis, that Tre6P inhibition of hexokinase might not be competitive with respect to glucose in vivo and that also Tps2 appears to play a role in the control of hexokinase activity.

 439: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2000 <PERSON  Sep> 15;275(37):28816-25 
 
 <Capitalized> Subunit interactions within the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> DNA polymerase epsilon (pol epsilon ) complex. <Capitalized> Demonstration of a dimeric pol epsilon. 
 
 <PERSON  Dua> <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Edwards> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Levy> <AllCaps> DL, <PERSON  Campbell> <AllCaps> JL. 
 
 <PERSON  Braun> <Capitalized> Laboratories, <LOCATION  California> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Technology, <LOCATION  Pasadena,> <LOCATION  California> 91125, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> DNA polymerase epsilon (pol epsilon) is essential for chromosomal replication. <AllCaps> A major form of pol epsilon purified from yeast consists of at least four subunits: Pol2p, Dpb2p, Dpb3p, and Dpb4p. <Capitalized> We have investigated the protein/protein interactions between these polypeptides by using expression of individual subunits in baculovirus-infected Sf9 insect cells and by using the yeast two-hybrid assay. <Capitalized> The essential subunits, Pol2p and Dpb2p, interact directly in the absence of the other two subunits, and the C-terminal half of POL2, the only essential portion of Pol2p, is sufficient for interaction with Dpb2p. Dpb3p and Dpb4p, non-essential subunits, also interact directly with each other in the absence of the other two subunits. <Capitalized> We propose that Pol2p.Dpb2p and Dpb3p.Dpb4p complexes interact with each other and document several interactions between individual members of the two respective complexes. <Capitalized> We present biochemical evidence to support the proposal that pol epsilon may be dimeric in vivo. <Capitalized> Gel filtration of the Pol2p.Dpb2p complexes reveals a novel heterotetrameric form, consisting of two heterodimers of Pol2p.Dpb2p. Dpb2p, but not Pol2p, exists as a homodimer, and thus the Pol2p dimerization may be mediated by Dpb2p. <Capitalized> The pol2-E and pol2-F mutations that cause replication defects in vivo weaken the interaction between Pol2p and Dpb2p and also reduce dimerization of Pol2p. <Capitalized> This suggests, but does not prove, that dimerization may also occur in vivo and be essential for <AllCaps> DNA replication.

 <PERSON  Shannon> <AllCaps> KB, <Capitalized> Li <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Harvard <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Boston,> <LOCATION  Massachusetts> 02115, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Cytokinesis in animal cells is accomplished through constriction of an actomyosin ring [1] [2] [3], which must assemble at the correct time and place in order to ensure proper division of genetic material and organelles. <Capitalized> Budding yeast is a useful model system for determining the biochemical pathway of contractile ring assembly. <Capitalized> The budding yeast IQGAP-like protein, Cyk1/Iqg1p, has multiple roles in the assembly and contraction of the actomyosin ring [4] [5] [6]. <Capitalized> Previously, the <AllCaps> IQ motifs of Cyk1/Iqg1p were shown to be required for the localization of this protein at the bud neck [6]. <Capitalized> We have investigated the binding partner of the <AllCaps> IQ motifs, which are predicted to interact with calmodulin-like proteins. Mlc1p was originally identified as a light chain for a type <PERSON  V> myosin, Myo2p; however, a cytokinesis defect associated with disruption of the <EndsInDigit> MLC1 gene suggested that the essential function of Mlc1p may involve interactions with other proteins [7]. <Capitalized> We show that Mlc1p binds the <AllCaps> IQ motifs of Cyk1/Iqg1p and present evidence that this interaction recruits Cyk1/Iqg1p to the bud neck. <Capitalized> Immunofluorescence staining shows that Mlc1p is localized to sites of polarized cell growth as well as the bud neck before and independently of Cyk1p. <Capitalized> These results demonstrate that Mlc1p is important for the assembly of the actomyosin ring in budding yeast and that this function is mediated through interaction with Cyk1/Iqg1p. 
 
 PMID: 10873803 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 442: <Capitalized> Annu <Capitalized> Rev <Capitalized> Biochem 1999;68:649-86 
 
 <AllCaps> MCM proteins in <AllCaps> DNA replication. 
 
 <PERSON  Tye> <AllCaps> BK. 
 
 <Capitalized> Section of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Cornell> <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Ithaca, <LOCATION  New York> 14853-2703, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> MCM proteins are essential replication initiation factors originally identified as proteins required for minichromosome maintenance in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The best known among them are a family of six structurally related proteins, MCM2-7, which are evolutionally conserved in all eukaryotes. <Capitalized> The MCM2-7 proteins form a hexameric complex. <Capitalized> This complex is a key component of the prereplication complex that assembles at replication origins during early <EndsInDigit> G1 phase. <PERSON  New> evidence suggests that the MCM2-7 proteins may be involved not only in the initiation but also in the elongation of <AllCaps> DNA replication. <Capitalized> Orchestration of the functional interactions between the MCM2-7 proteins and other components of the prereplication complex by cell cycle-dependent protein kinases results in initiation of <AllCaps> DNA synthesis once every cell cycle.

 <AllCaps> A regulatory shortcut between the Snf1 protein kinase and <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II holoenzyme. 
 
 <Capitalized> Kuchin <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Treich <AllCaps> I, <PERSON  Carlson> <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Development and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Microbiology, <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  NY> 10032, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II holoenzymes respond to activators and repressors that are regulated by signaling pathways. <Capitalized> Here we present evidence for a "shortcut" mechanism in which the Snf1 protein kinase of the glucose signaling pathway directly regulates transcription by the yeast holoenzyme. <Capitalized> In response to glucose limitation, the Snf1 kinase stimulates transcription by holoenzyme that has been artificially recruited to a reporter by a LexA fusion to a holoenzyme component. <Capitalized> We show that Snf1 interacts physically with the Srb/mediator proteins of the holoenzyme in both two-hybrid and coimmunoprecipitation assays. <Capitalized> We also show that a catalytically hyperactive Snf1, when bound to a promoter as a LexA fusion protein, activates transcription in a glucose-regulated manner; moreover, this activation depends on the integrity of the Srb/mediator complex. <Capitalized> These results suggest that direct regulatory interactions between signal transduction pathways and <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II holoenzyme provide a mechanism for transcriptional control in response to important signals.

 444: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 2000 Jul;20(14):5321-9 
 
 <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> C terminus of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae alpha-factor receptor contributes to the formation of preactivation complexes with its cognate <AllCaps> G protein. 
 
 <Capitalized> Dosil <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Schandel <AllCaps> KA, <Capitalized> Gupta <AllCaps> E, <PERSON  Jenness> <AllCaps> DD, <Capitalized> Konopka <AllCaps> JB. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  New York,> <Capitalized> Stony <PERSON  Brook,> <LOCATION  New York> 11794-5222, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Binding of the alpha-factor pheromone to its G-protein-coupled receptor (encoded by STE2) activates the mating pathway in MATa yeast cells. <Capitalized> To investigate whether specific interactions between the receptor and the <AllCaps> G protein occur prior to ligand binding, we analyzed dominant-negative mutant receptors that compete with wild-type receptors for <AllCaps> G proteins, and we analyzed the ability of receptors to suppress the constitutive signaling activity of mutant <Capitalized> Galpha subunits in an alpha-factor-independent manner. <Capitalized> Although the amino acid substitution L236H in the third intracellular loop of the receptor impairs G-protein activation, this substitution had no influence on the ability of the dominant-negative receptors to sequester <AllCaps> G proteins or on the ability of receptors to suppress the GPA1-A345T mutant <Capitalized> Galpha subunit. <Capitalized> In contrast, removal of the cytoplasmic C-terminal domain of the receptor eliminated both of these activities even though the C-terminal domain is unnecessary for G-protein activation. <Capitalized> Moreover, the alpha-factor-independent signaling activity of ste2-P258L mutant receptors was inhibited by the coexpression of wild-type receptors but not by coexpression of truncated receptors lacking the C-terminal domain. <Capitalized> Deletion analysis suggested that the distal half of the C-terminal domain is critical for sequestration of <AllCaps> G proteins. <Capitalized> The C-terminal domain was also found to influence the affinity of the receptor for alpha-factor in cells lacking <AllCaps> G proteins. <Capitalized> These results suggest that the C-terminal cytoplasmic domain of the alpha-factor receptor, in addition to its role in receptor downregulation, promotes the formation of receptor-G-protein preactivation complexes.

 <Capitalized> The TATA-binding protein-associated factor yTafII19p functionally interacts with components of the global transcriptional regulator Ccr4-Not complex and physically interacts with the Not5 subunit. 
 
 <PERSON  Lemaire> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Collart> <AllCaps> MA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Departement de <Capitalized> Biochimie <Capitalized> Medicale, <Capitalized> Centre <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Universitaire, 1 rue <PERSON  Michel> <Capitalized> Servet, 1211 <PERSON  Geneva> 4, <LOCATION Switzerland> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <EndsInDigit> HIS3 gene is a model system to characterize transcription initiation from different types of core promoters. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> NOT genes were identified by mutations that preferentially increased transcription of the <EndsInDigit> HIS3 promoter lacking a canonical <AllCaps> TATA sequence. <Capitalized> They encode proteins associated in a complex that also contains the Caf1 and Ccr4 proteins. <Capitalized> It has been suggested that the Ccr4-Not complex represses transcription by inhibiting factors more specifically required for promoters lacking a <AllCaps> TATA sequence. <AllCaps> A potential target is the yTaf(II)19 subunit of <AllCaps> TFIID, which, when depleted, leads to a preferential decrease of <EndsInDigit> HIS3 TATA-less transcription. <Capitalized> We isolated conditional taf19 alleles that display synthetic growth phenotypes when combined with not4 or specific not5 alleles. <Capitalized> Inactivation of yTaf(II)19p by shifting these mutants to the restrictive temperature led to a more rapid and striking decrease in transcription from promoters that do not contain a canonical <AllCaps> TATA sequence. <Capitalized> We demonstrated by the two-hybrid assay and directly in vitro that yTaf(II)19p and Not5p could interact. <Capitalized> Finally, we found by the two-hybrid assay that yTaf(II)19p also interacted with many components of the Ccr4-Not complex. <Capitalized> Taken together, our results provide evidence that interactions between Not5p and yTaf(II)19p may be involved in transcriptional regulation by the Ccr4-Not complex.

 <AllCaps> A compact monomeric intermediate identified by <AllCaps> NMR in the denaturation of dimeric triose phosphate isomerase. 
 
 <PERSON  Morgan> <AllCaps> CJ, <PERSON  Wilkins> <AllCaps> DK, <PERSON  Smith> <AllCaps> LJ, <Capitalized> Kawata <PERSON  Y,> <PERSON  Dobson> <AllCaps> CM.

 <Capitalized> The denaturation of triose phosphate isomerase (TIM) from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae by guanidine hydrochlorids at <MixedCase> pH 7.2 has been monitored by <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy in conjunction with optical spectroscopy. <Capitalized> In the absence of denaturant, the hydrodynamic radius of 29.6(+/-0.25) <AllCaps> A and the substantial chemical shift dispersion evident in the <AllCaps> NMR spectrum are consistent with the highly structured dimeric native state of the protein. <Capitalized> On the addition of 2. 2 <AllCaps> M guanidine hydrochloride the effective hydrodynamic radius increases to 51.4(+/-0.43) <AllCaps> A, consistent with that anticipated for the polypeptide chain in a highly unstructured random coil state. <Capitalized> In 1.1 <AllCaps> M guanidine hydrochloride, however, the effective hydrodynamic radius is 24.0(+/-0.25) <AllCaps> A, a value substantially decreased relative to that of the native dimeric state but very close to that anticipated for a monomeric species with native-like compaction (23. 5 A). <Capitalized> The lack of chemical shift dispersion indicates, however, that few tertiary interactions persist within this species. <Capitalized> Far <AllCaps> UV <AllCaps> CD and intrinsic fluorescence measurements show that this compact intermediate retains significant secondary structure and that on average the fluorophores are partially excluded from solvent. <Capitalized> Such a species could be important in the formation of dimeric <AllCaps> TIM from its unfolded state. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <PERSON  Hallows> <AllCaps> KR, <Capitalized> Raghuram <PERSON  V,> <PERSON  Kemp> <AllCaps> BE, <PERSON  Witters> <LOCATION  LA,> <PERSON  Foskett> <AllCaps> JK.

 <Capitalized> The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is an ATP-gated Cl(-) channel that regulates other epithelial transport proteins by uncharacterized mechanisms. <Capitalized> We employed a yeast two-hybrid screen using the COOH-terminal 70 residues of <AllCaps> CFTR to identify proteins that might be involved in such interactions. <Capitalized> The alpha1 (catalytic) subunit of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) was identified as a dominant and novel interacting protein. <Capitalized> The interaction is mediated by residues 1420-1457 in <AllCaps> CFTR and by the COOH-terminal regulatory domain of alpha1-AMPK. <Capitalized> Mutations of two protein trafficking motifs within the 38-amino acid region in <AllCaps> CFTR each disrupted the interaction. GST-fusion protein pull-down assays in vitro and in transfected cells confirmed the CFTR-alpha1-AMPK interaction and also identified alpha2-AMPK as an interactor with <AllCaps> CFTR. <AllCaps> AMPK is coexpressed in CFTR-expressing cell lines and shares an apical distribution with <AllCaps> CFTR in rat nasal epithelium. <AllCaps> AMPK phosphorylated full-length <AllCaps> CFTR in vitro, and <AllCaps> AMPK coexpression with <AllCaps> CFTR in XENOPUS: oocytes inhibited cAMP-activated <AllCaps> CFTR whole-cell Cl(-) conductance by approximately 35-50%. <Capitalized> Because <AllCaps> AMPK is a metabolic sensor in cells and responds to changes in cellular <AllCaps> ATP, regulation of <AllCaps> CFTR by <AllCaps> AMPK may be important in inhibiting <AllCaps> CFTR under conditions of metabolic stress, thereby linking transepithelial transport to cell metabolic state.

 <Capitalized> Mutational analysis of the karmellae-inducing signal in Hmg1p, a yeast HMG-CoA reductase isozyme. 
 
 <Capitalized> Profant <AllCaps> DA, <PERSON  Roberts> <AllCaps> CJ, <PERSON  Wright> <AllCaps> RL. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Zoology, <PERSON  Box> 351800, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Washington,> <LOCATION  Seattle,> <AllCaps> WA 98195, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In response to elevated levels of HMG-CoA reductase, an integral endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane protein, cells assemble novel <AllCaps> ER arrays. <Capitalized> These membranes provide useful models for exploration of <AllCaps> ER structure and function, as well as general features of membrane biogenesis and turnover. <Capitalized> Yeast express two functional HMG-CoA reductase isozymes, Hmg1p and Hmg2p, each of which induces morphologically different <AllCaps> ER arrays. Hmg1p induces stacks of paired nuclear-associated membranes called karmellae. <Capitalized> In contrast, Hmg2p induces peripheral <AllCaps> ER membrane arrays and short nuclear-associated membrane stacks. <Capitalized> In spite of their ability to induce different cellular responses, both Hmg1p and Hmg2p have similar structures, including a polytopic membrane domain containing eight predicted transmembrane helices. <Capitalized> By examining a series of recombinant HMG-CoA reductase proteins, our laboratory previously demonstrated that the last ER-lumenal loop (Loop G) of the Hmg1p membrane domain contains a signal needed for proper karmellae assembly. <Capitalized> Our goal was to examine the primary sequence requirements within <PERSON  Loop> <AllCaps> G that were critical for proper function of this signal. <Capitalized> To this end, we randomly mutagenized the <PERSON  Loop> <AllCaps> G sequence, expressed the mutagenized Hmg1p in yeast, and screened for inability to generate karmellae at wild-type levels. <Capitalized> Out of approximately 4000 strains with <PERSON  Loop> <AllCaps> G mutations, we isolated 57 that were unable to induce wild-type levels of karmellae assembly. Twenty-nine of these mutants contained one or more point mutations in the <PERSON  Loop> <AllCaps> G sequence, including nine single point mutants, four of which had severe defects in karmellae assembly. <Capitalized> Comparison of these mutations to single point mutations that did not affect karmellae assembly did not reveal obvious patterns of sequence requirements. <Capitalized> For example, both conservative and non-conservative changes were present in both groups and changes that altered the total charge of the <PERSON  Loop> <AllCaps> G region were observed in both groups. <Capitalized> Our hypothesis is that <PERSON  Loop> <AllCaps> G serves as a karmellae-inducing signal by mediating protein-protein or protein-lipid interactions and that amino acids revealed by this analysis may be important for maintaining the proper secondary structure needed for these interactions. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <PERSON  John> <PERSON  Wiley> & <Capitalized> Sons, Ltd.

 <Capitalized> The Rad54 protein is an important component of the recombinational <AllCaps> DNA repair pathway in vegetative <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells. <Capitalized> Unlike those in other members of the <EndsInDigit> RAD52 group, the meiotic defect in rad54 is rather mild, reducing spore viability only to 26%-65%. <AllCaps> A consistently greater requirement for Rad54p during meiosis was observed in hybrid strains, suggesting that Rad54p has a certain role in interhomolog interactions. <Capitalized> Such a role is probably minor as no recombination defects were found in the surviving gametes in three genetic intervals on chromosome <PERSON  V.> <Capitalized> Also, the spore viability pattern in tetrads did not reflect an increase in nondisjunction at meiosis <AllCaps> I indicative of a meiotic recombination defect. <Capitalized> We suggest that the meiotic defect of rad54 cells lies in the failure to repair meiosis-specific double-strand breaks outside the context of the highly differentiated pathway leading to interhomolog joint molecules and meiotic crossovers that ensure accurate segregation at meiosis <AllCaps> I.

 451: <Capitalized> Gene 2000 <PERSON  May> 30;250(1-2):1-14 
 
 <Capitalized> The continued evolution of two-hybrid screening approaches in yeast: how to outwit different preys with different baits. 
 
 <Capitalized> Fashena <AllCaps> SJ, <Capitalized> Serebriiskii <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Golemis <AllCaps> EA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Basic <Capitalized> Science, <PERSON  Fox> <PERSON  Chase> <Capitalized> Cancer <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Philadelphia,> <AllCaps> PA 19111, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The original two-hybrid system, an experimental approach designed to detect protein interactions, exploited the modular nature of many transcription factors. <Capitalized> It has provided the intellectual and technical seed for the evolution of an array of innovative approaches, the application of which broadens the scope of experimentally feasible questions to include the interaction of proteins with diverse binding partners. <Capitalized> The available array of modified and alternative approaches facilitates the analysis of complex cellular machinery and signaling networks that rely on multiple protein interactions. <Capitalized> Such advances have facilitated the functional analysis of proteins on the genome level, a feat considered untenable a decade ago. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial

 <Capitalized> Systematic and large-scale two-hybrid screens. 
 
 <Capitalized> Uetz <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Hughes> <AllCaps> RE. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Washington,> <PERSON  Box> 357360, <LOCATION  Seattle,> <AllCaps> WA 98195-7360, <LOCATION  USA.> uetz@u.washington.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> The increasing rate at which complete genome sequences become available necessitates rapid and robust methods for investigating the functions of their encoded proteins. <Capitalized> Efforts have been made to study protein function by systematically screening large sets of proteins using the two-hybrid method. <Capitalized> Analyses of the complete proteomes of baceriophage T7, the mammalian viruses hepatitis <AllCaps> C and vaccinia, as well as of several protein complexes including <AllCaps> RNA splicing proteins and <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> III from yeast, have been undertaken. <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae has been studied extensively by two-hybrid methods, with more than 2500 protein-protein interactions described. <Capitalized> Systematic studies on metazoan proteomes are, however, still in their infancy.

 <Capitalized> The proteins commonly referred to as 14-3-3s have recently come to prominence in the study of protein:protein interactions, having been shown to act as allosteric or steric regulators and possibly scaffolds. <Capitalized> The binding of 14-3-3 proteins to the regulatory phosphorylation site of nitrate reductase (NR) was studied in real-time by surface plasmon resonance, using primarily an immobilized synthetic phosphopeptide based on spinach NR-Ser543. <PERSON  Both> plant and yeast 14-3-3 proteins were shown to bind the immobilized peptide ligand in a Mg2+-stimulated manner. <Capitalized> Stimulation resulted from a reduction in <AllCaps> KD and an increase in steady-state binding level (Req). <Capitalized> As shown previously for plant 14-3-3s, fluorescent probes also indicated that yeast <EndsInDigit> BMH2 interacted directly with cations, which bind and affect surface hydrophobicity. <Capitalized> Binding of 14-3-3s to the phosphopeptide ligand occurred in the absence of divalent cations when the <MixedCase> pH was reduced below neutral, and the basis for enhanced binding was a reduction in K(D). <Capitalized> At <MixedCase> pH 7.5 (+Mg2+), <AllCaps> AMP inhibited binding of plant 14-3-3s to the <AllCaps> NR based peptide ligand. <Capitalized> The binding of <AllCaps> AMP to 14-3-3s was directly demonstrated by equilibrium dialysis (plant), and from the observation that recombinant plant 14-3-3s have a low, but detectable, <AllCaps> AMP phosphatase activity.

 454: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cells 2000 <Capitalized> Apr 30;10(2):232-5 
 
 <Capitalized> Random changes of amino acid residues with expected frequency by saturated point mutagenesis. 
 
 <PERSON  Kim> <AllCaps> SJ, <PERSON  Park> <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Kim> <AllCaps> JK, <PERSON  Lee> <AllCaps> JY, <PERSON  Ahn> <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Choe <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Choi <AllCaps> YJ, <PERSON  Kim> <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <Capitalized> Graduate <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <Capitalized> Korea <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION Seoul> 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast transcriptional activator protein, Gcn4p from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae binds to the specific sequence in the promoters of many amino acid biosynthetic genes for general control. <AllCaps> A new random saturation mutagenesis method was developed to isolate Gcn4p derivatives with only one or two mutations in the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain without using radioactive isotope. <Capitalized> This will be used to identify the amino acids of Gcn4p involved in protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> Saturation mutagenesis in the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain of Gcn4p was performed using spiked degenerate oligonucleotides containing randomized codon bases designed specifically for only one or two base changes in the mutagenized area. <Capitalized> These oligonucleotides were synthesized to have two flanking restriction enzyme sites for cloning to the appropriate vector. <Capitalized> The 3' ends were mutually primed after hybridization via the palindromic sequences of the restriction enzyme sites. <Capitalized> These molecules were then converted to double stranded <AllCaps> DNA upon treatment with <AllCaps> DNA polymerase. <Capitalized> Here, a library collection of 100,680 in an altered Gcn4p pool was generated by cloning a mixed-base oligonucleotide in the place of the sequence coding for the <AllCaps> DNA binding domains. <Capitalized> The quality of the library was examined by <AllCaps> DNA sequencing and found to be in good agreement with the expected statistical values. <Capitalized> Calculated mutation frequency was 66% of mutant nucleotide rate and actual sequencing data revealed 68% mutant nucleotide rates from the sequenced library. <PERSON  Thus,> among 21 mutants, 16 had one point mutations and 5 had two point mutations. <Capitalized> This approach appears to be an effective and general tool for creating proteins with one or two amino acid change(s) in their molecules.

 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae zip1 mutant, which exhibits defects in synaptonemal complex formation and meiotic recombination, triggers a checkpoint that causes cells to arrest at the pachytene stage of meiotic prophase. <Capitalized> Overproduction of either the meiotic chromosomal protein Red1 or the meiotic kinase Mek1 bypasses this checkpoint, allowing zip1 cells to sporulate. Red1 or Mek1 overproduction also promotes sporulation of other mutants (zip2, dmc1, hop2) that undergo checkpoint-mediated arrest at pachytene. <Capitalized> In addition, Red1 overproduction antagonizes interhomolog interactions in the zip1 mutant, substantially decreasing double-strand break formation, meiotic recombination, and homologous chromosome pairing. Mek1 overproduction, in contrast, suppresses checkpoint-induced arrest without significantly decreasing meiotic recombination. <Capitalized> Cooverproduction of Red1 and Mek1 fails to bypass the checkpoint; moreover, overproduction of the meiotic chromosomal protein Hop1 blocks the Red1 and Mek1 overproduction phenotypes. <Capitalized> These results suggest that meiotic chromosomal proteins function in the signaling of meiotic prophase defects and that the correct stoichiometry of Red1, Mek1, and Hop1 is needed to achieve checkpoint-mediated cell cycle arrest at pachytene.

 <Capitalized> Building a protein interaction map: research in the post-genome era. 
 
 <Capitalized> Chen <PERSON  Z,> <PERSON  Han> <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <PERSON  Howard> <PERSON  Hughes> <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Colorado> at <LOCATION  Boulder,> <LOCATION  Boulder,> <LOCATION Colorado> 
 
 <Capitalized> With the extensive amount of information generated by genome-wide sequencing, the entire set of gene products in an organism can now be predicted. <Capitalized> The challenge of understanding the function of each gene in the genome has led to the development of many large-scale and high-throughput experimental techniques. <Capitalized> Recently, two papers, <Capitalized> Walhout et al.(1) and <Capitalized> Uetz et al.,(2) have described studies that add a new functional dimension to research conducted on a genome-wide scale. <Capitalized> These two groups have utilized the yeast two-hybrid system to identify interactions among the entire complement of proteins encoded by the <Capitalized> Caenorhabditis elegans and the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae genomes, respectively. <Capitalized> Using a set of 29 genes that have been previously characterized, <Capitalized> Walhout et al. demonstrated the feasibility and efficiency of this technique by building an interaction matrix among a large number of proteins. <Capitalized> On an even larger scale, <Capitalized> Uetz et al. conducted two-hybrid analyses using proteins that represent over 87% of the total gene products in yeast and identified interactions for about 15% of the total yeast proteins. BioEssays 22:503-506, 2000. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <PERSON  John> <PERSON  Wiley> & <Capitalized> Sons, Inc.

 Rap1p-binding sites in the saccharomyces cerevisiae <EndsInDigit> GPD1 promoter are involved in its response to NaCl. 
 
 <PERSON  Eriksson> <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Alipour <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Adler> <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Blomberg> <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell and <Capitalized> Molecular Biology-Microbiology, <PERSON  Lundberg> <Capitalized> Laboratory, <Capitalized> Goteborg <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Medicinaregatan 9C, S-413 90 <Capitalized> Goteborg, <LOCATION Sweden> 
 
 <Capitalized> Mechanisms involved in transcriptional regulation of the osmotically controlled <EndsInDigit> GPD1 gene in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae were investigated by promoter analysis. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> GPD1 gene encodes NAD(+)-dependent glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, a key enzyme in the production of the compatible solute glycerol. <Capitalized> By analysis of promoter deletions, we identified a region at nucleotides -478 to -324, in relation to start of translation, to be of great importance for both basal activity and osmotic induction of GPD1. <Capitalized> Electrophoretic mobility shift and DNase <AllCaps> I footprint analyses demonstrated protein binding to parts of this region that contain three consensus sequences for Rap1p (repressor activator protein 1)-binding sites. <Capitalized> Actual binding of Rap1p to this region was confirmed by demonstrating enhanced electrophoretic mobility of the protein-DNA complex with extracts containing an N-terminally truncated version of Rap1p. <Capitalized> The detected Rap1p-DNA interactions were not affected by changes in the osmolarity of the growth medium. <Capitalized> Specific inactivation of the Rap1p-binding sites by a C-to-A point mutation in the core of the consensus showed that this factor is a major determinant of <EndsInDigit> GPD1 expression since mutations in all three putative binding sites for Rap1p strongly hampered osmotic induction and drastically lowered basal activity. <Capitalized> We also show that the Rap1p-binding sites appear functionally distinct; the most distal site (core of the consensus at position -386) exhibited the highest affinity for Rap1p and was strictly required for low salt induction (< or =0.6 m NaCl), but not for the response at higher salinities (> or =0.8 m NaCl). <Capitalized> This indicates tha different molecular mechanisms might be operational for low and high salt responses of the <EndsInDigit> GPD1 promoter.

Mad1p forms a tight complex with Mad2p [7], and has been shown to recruit Mad2p to kinetochores [8]. <Capitalized> Similarly, Bub3p binds to Bub1p [9] and may target it to kinetochores [10]. <Capitalized> Here, we show that budding yeast Mad1p has a regulated association with Bub1p and Bub3p during a normal cell cycle and that this complex is found at significantly higher levels once the spindle checkpoint is activated. <Capitalized> We find that formation of this complex requires Mad2p and Mps1p but not Mad3p or Bub2p. <Capitalized> In addition, we identify a conserved motif within Mad1p that is essential for Mad1p-Bub1p-Bub3p complex formation. <Capitalized> Mutation of this motif abolishes checkpoint function, indicating that formation of the Mad1p-Bub1p-Bub3p complex is a crucial step in the spindle checkpoint mechanism.

 <Capitalized> We have investigated the structural basis for the differential catalytic function of the yeast Gcn5p-containing histone acetyltransferase (HAT) <EndsInDigit> A2 complex and free recombinant yeast Gcn5p (rGcn5p). <AllCaps> HAT <EndsInDigit> A2 is shown to be a unique complex that contains Gcn5p, Ada2p, and Ada3p, but not proteins specific to other related <AllCaps> HAT <AllCaps> A complexes, e.g. <AllCaps> ADA, <AllCaps> SAGA. <Capitalized> Nevertheless, <AllCaps> HAT <EndsInDigit> A2 produces the same unique polyacetylation pattern of nucleosomal substrates reported previously for <AllCaps> ADA and <AllCaps> SAGA, demonstrating that proteins specific to the <AllCaps> ADA and <AllCaps> SAGA complexes do not influence the enzymatic activity of Gcn5p within the <AllCaps> HAT <EndsInDigit> A2 complex. <Capitalized> To investigate the role of substrate interactions in the differential behavior of free and complexed Gcn5p, sucrose density gradient centrifugation was used to characterize the binding of <AllCaps> HAT <EndsInDigit> A2 and free rGcn5p to intact and trypsinized nucleosomal arrays, H3/H4 tetramer arrays, and nucleosome core particles. <Capitalized> We find that <AllCaps> HAT <EndsInDigit> A2 forms stable complexes with all nucleosomal substrates tested. <Capitalized> In distinct contrast, rGcn5p does not interact stably with nucleosomal arrays, despite being able to specifically monoacetylate the <EndsInDigit> H3 <AllCaps> N terminus of nucleosomal substrates. <Capitalized> Our data suggest that the ability of the <AllCaps> HAT <EndsInDigit> A2 complex to bind stably to nucleosomal arrays is functionally related to both local and global acetylation by the complexed and free forms of Gcn5p.

 Bloom's syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by genomic instability and predisposition to cancer. <AllCaps> BLM, the gene defective in Bloom's syndrome, encodes a 159-kDa protein possessing DNA-stimulated ATPase and ATP-dependent <AllCaps> DNA helicase activities. <Capitalized> We have examined mechanistic aspects of the catalytic functions of purified recombinant <AllCaps> BLM protein. <Capitalized> Through analyzing the effects of different lengths of <AllCaps> DNA cofactor on ATPase activity, we provide evidence to suggest that <AllCaps> BLM translocates along single-stranded <AllCaps> DNA in a processive manner. <Capitalized> The helicase reaction catalyzed by <AllCaps> BLM protein was examined as a function of duplex <AllCaps> DNA length. <Capitalized> We show that <AllCaps> BLM catalyzes unwinding of short <AllCaps> DNA duplexes (</=71 base pairs (bp)) but is severely compromised on longer <AllCaps> DNA duplexes (>/=259-bp). <Capitalized> The presence of the human single-stranded DNA-binding protein (human replication protein <AllCaps> A (hRPA)) stimulates the <AllCaps> BLM unwinding reaction on the 259-bp partial duplex <AllCaps> DNA substrate. <Capitalized> Heterologous single-stranded DNA-binding proteins fail to stimulate similarly the helicase activity of <AllCaps> BLM protein. <Capitalized> This is the first demonstration of a functional interaction between <AllCaps> BLM and another protein. <Capitalized> Consistent with a functional interaction between <MixedCase> hRPA and the <AllCaps> BLM helicase, we demonstrate a direct physical interaction between the two proteins mediated by the 70-kDa subunit of <AllCaps> RPA. <Capitalized> The interactions between <AllCaps> BLM and <MixedCase> hRPA suggest that the two proteins function together in vivo to unwind <AllCaps> DNA duplexes during replication, recombination, or repair.

 471: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 2000 <PERSON  May> 15;149(4):863-74 
 
 <Capitalized> Microtubule interactions with the cell cortex causing nuclear movements in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <Capitalized> Adames <AllCaps> NR, <PERSON  Cooper> <AllCaps> JA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Physiology, <LOCATION  Washington> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, St. <PERSON  Louis,> <LOCATION  Missouri> 63110, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> During mitosis in budding yeast the nucleus first moves to the mother-bud neck and then into the neck. <PERSON  Both> movements depend on interactions of cytoplasmic microtubules with the cortex. <Capitalized> We investigated the mechanism of these movements in living cells using video analysis of GFP-labeled microtubules in wild-type cells and in <EndsInDigit> EB1 and Arp1 mutants, which are defective in the first and second steps, respectively. <Capitalized> We found that nuclear movement to the neck is largely mediated by the capture of microtubule ends at one cortical region at the incipient bud site or bud tip, followed by microtubule depolymerization. <Capitalized> Efficient microtubule interactions with the capture site require that microtubules be sufficiently long and dynamic to probe the cortex. <Capitalized> In contrast, spindle movement into the neck is mediated by microtubule sliding along the bud cortex, which requires dynein and dynactin. <PERSON  Free> microtubules can also slide along the cortex of both bud and mother. Capture/shrinkage of microtubule ends also contributes to nuclear movement into the neck and can serve as a backup mechanism to move the nucleus into the neck when microtubule sliding is impaired. <Capitalized> Conversely, microtubule sliding can move the nucleus into the neck even when capture/shrinkage is impaired.

 473: <Capitalized> Biochem <Capitalized> Pharmacol 2000 <PERSON  Jan> 15;59(2):177-85 
 
 <Capitalized> Agonistic and synergistic activity of tamoxifen in a yeast model system. 
 
 <Capitalized> Graumann <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Jungbauer <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Applied <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> University of the <Capitalized> Agricultural <Capitalized> Sciences, <LOCATION  Vienna,> <PERSON Austria> 
 
 <Capitalized> The background of agonist/antagonist behaviour of the non-steroidal antiestrogen tamoxifen is still not fully understood. <Capitalized> Depending on cell type, its activities range from full agonistic to antagonistic in different tissues. <Capitalized> We investigated the transactivational properties of tamoxifen in a basic yeast model system which reconstitutes ligand-dependent human estrogen receptor-alpha (hER alpha) gene activation. <Capitalized> Tamoxifen exerted low agonist activity in this system compared to 17 beta-estradiol (E2). <Capitalized> Efficiencies and potencies of several isomers were calculated by fitting experimental data with a logistic dose-response function. Cis-, trans- and cis-transtamoxifen and trans-4-hydroxytamoxifen (4-OHT) showed comparable efficiencies and potencies in yeast. <Capitalized> When subeffective doses of trans-, cis-/trans-, or trans-4-OH tamoxifen were combined with increasing 17 beta-estradiol concentrations, even a synergistic increase in efficiencies could be observed. <Capitalized> Interestingly, the cis-isomer did not show this synergistic effect. <Capitalized> Mutation of the N-terminus of the estrogen receptor changed the transactivational behaviour of tamoxifen and abolished the synergistic action with 17 beta-estradiol. <Capitalized> Except for 4-OHT, the potencies of the investigated isomers, defined as ligand concentrations with half-maximal response, highly correlated with the binding affinities to <MixedCase> hER alpha. <Capitalized> Therefore, cis-, trans-, and cis-/trans-tamoxifen could be regarded as full agonists in yeast, while 4-OHT was regarded as a partial antagonist in yeast. <Capitalized> Furthermore, these results indicate that the functional difference between trans-tamoxifen and trans-4-OHT is not due to their different affinities for the receptor protein.

 <Capitalized> The activation domain of the yeast Gal4 protein binds specifically to the Gal80 repressor and is also thought to associate with one or more coactivators in the <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II holoenzyme and chromatin remodeling machines. <Capitalized> This is a specific example of a common situation in biochemistry where a single protein domain can interact with multiple partners. <Capitalized> Are these different interactions related chemically? <Capitalized> To probe this point, phage display was employed to isolate peptides from a library based solely on their ability to bind Gal80 protein in vitro. Peptide-Gal80 protein association is shown to be highly specific and of moderate affinity. <Capitalized> The Gal80 protein-binding peptides compete with the native activation domain for the repressor, suggesting that they bind to the same site. <Capitalized> It was then asked if these peptides could function as activation domains in yeast when tethered to a <AllCaps> DNA binding domain. <Capitalized> Indeed, this is the case. <Capitalized> Furthermore, one of the Gal80-binding peptides binds directly to a domain of the Gal11 protein, a known coactivator. <Capitalized> The fact that Gal80-binding peptides are functional activation domains argues that repressor binding and activation/coactivator binding are intimately related properties. <Capitalized> This peptide library-based approach should be generally useful for probing the chemical relationship of different binding interactions or functions of a given native domain.

 <Capitalized> Eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2B (eIF2B) is the guanine nucleotide exchange factor for protein synthesis initiation factor 2 (eIF2). <Capitalized> Composed of five subunits, it converts eIF2 from a GDP-bound form to the active eIF2-GTP complex. <Capitalized> This is a regulatory step of translation initiation. <Capitalized> In vitro, eIF2B catalytic function can be provided by the largest (epsilon) subunit alone (eIF2Bepsilon). <Capitalized> This activity is stimulated by complex formation with the other eIF2B subunits. <Capitalized> We have analyzed the roles of different regions of eIF2Bepsilon in catalysis, in eIF2B complex formation, and in binding to eIF2 by characterizing mutations in the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene encoding eIF2Bepsilon (GCD6) that impair the essential function of eIF2B. <Capitalized> Our analysis of nonsense mutations indicates that the <AllCaps> C terminus of eIF2Bepsilon (residues 518 to 712) is required for both catalytic activity and interaction with eIF2. <Capitalized> In addition, missense mutations within this region impair the catalytic activity of eIF2Bepsilon without affecting its ability to bind eIF2. <Capitalized> Internal, in-frame deletions within the N-terminal half of eIF2Bepsilon disrupt eIF2B complex formation without affecting the nucleotide exchange activity of eIF2Bepsilon alone. <Capitalized> Finally, missense mutations identified within this region do not affect the catalytic activity of eIF2Bepsilon alone or its interactions with the other eIF2B subunits or with eIF2. <Capitalized> Instead, these missense mutations act indirectly by impairing the enhancement of the rate of nucleotide exchange that results from complex formation between eIF2Bepsilon and the other eIF2B subunits. <Capitalized> This suggests that the N-terminal region of eIF2Bepsilon is an activation domain that responds to eIF2B complex formation.

 <Capitalized> An actin subdomain 2 mutation that impairs thin filament regulation by troponin and tropomyosin. 
 
 <PERSON  Korman> <AllCaps> VL, <PERSON  Hatch> <PERSON  V,> <PERSON  Dixon> <AllCaps> KY, <PERSON  Craig> <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Lehman> <PERSON  W,> <Capitalized> Tobacman <AllCaps> LS.

 <PERSON  Ryan> <AllCaps> KJ, <PERSON  Wente> <AllCaps> SR. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Physiology, <LOCATION  Washington> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <PERSON  Box> 8228, <Capitalized> St <PERSON  Louis,> <AllCaps> MO 63110, <LOCATION  USA.> kryan@cellbio. wustl.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> Compositional analysis of nuclear pore complexes (NPCs) is nearing completion, and efforts are now focused on understanding how these protein machines work. <Capitalized> Recent analysis of soluble transport factor interactions with <AllCaps> NPC proteins reveals distinct and overlapping pathways for movement between the nucleus and cytoplasm. <PERSON  New> fluorescence- and microscopy-based strategies have been used to monitor the pathway of <AllCaps> NPC assembly and to reveal the dynamics of the <AllCaps> NPC during transport.

 482: <Capitalized> Biochem <Capitalized> Biophys <Capitalized> Res <Capitalized> Commun 2000 <PERSON  May> 10;271(2):464-8 
 
 <Capitalized> Purification and polymerization properties of two lethal yeast actin mutants. 
 
 <Capitalized> Frieden <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Du <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Schriefer <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Buzan <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biophysics, <LOCATION  Washington> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, St. <PERSON  Louis,> <LOCATION  Missouri,> 63110, <LOCATION  USA.> frieden@biochem.wustl.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> The budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae contains a single actin gene and the gene product, actin, is essential for growth. <Capitalized> Two mutants of yeast actin that do not support yeast growth were prepared from yeast by coexpressing the mutant and a 6-histidine-tagged wild-type actin followed by separation of the wild-type and mutant actin using Ni-NTA chromatography as described elsewhere [Buzan, J., <Capitalized> Du, J., <Capitalized> Karpova, <PERSON T.> and <Capitalized> Frieden, <AllCaps> C. (1999) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. <LOCATION  USA> 96, 2823-2827]. <Capitalized> The mutations, in muscle actin numbering, were at positions 334 (Glu334Lys) and 168 (Gly168Arg) and were chosen based on phenotypic changes observed in the behavior of actin mutants of <Capitalized> Caenorhabditis elegans. Glu334 is located on the surface of actin between subdomains 1 and 3 while Gly168 is located in a region near actin-actin contacts in the actin filament. <Capitalized> The Glu334Lys mutant polymerized slightly faster than wild-type yeast actin, suggesting that loss of interactions with some actin binding protein, rather than loss of actin-actin contacts, was responsible for its inability to support yeast growth. <Capitalized> The Gly168Arg mutant polymerized at a rate similar to wild-type but the extent was considerably less, kinetic characteristics suggesting a high critical concentration (ca. 4 microM) without a large change in the ability to form nuclei for the nucleation-elongation process. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 483: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Cell 2000 May;11(5):1753-64 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast heat shock transcription factor changes conformation in response to superoxide and temperature. 
 
 <PERSON  Lee> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Carlson> <PERSON  T,> <PERSON  Christian> <AllCaps> N, <PERSON  Lea> <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Kedzie <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Reilly> <AllCaps> JP, <PERSON  Bonner> <AllCaps> JJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Departments of <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Chemistry, <LOCATION  Indiana> <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Bloomington, <LOCATION  Indiana> 47405-3700, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In vitro DNA-binding assays demonstrate that the heat shock transcription factor (HSF) from the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae can adopt an altered conformation when stressed. <Capitalized> This conformation, reflected in a change in electrophoretic mobility, requires that two <AllCaps> HSF trimers be bound to <AllCaps> DNA. <PERSON  Single> trimers do not show this change, which appears to represent an alteration in the cooperative interactions between trimers. <AllCaps> HSF isolated from stressed cells displays a higher propensity to adopt this altered conformation. <Capitalized> Purified <AllCaps> HSF can be stimulated in vitro to undergo the conformational change by elevating the temperature or by exposing <AllCaps> HSF to superoxide anion. <Capitalized> Mutational analysis maps a region critical for this conformational change to the flexible loop between the minimal DNA-binding domain and the flexible linker that joins the DNA-binding domain to the trimerization domain. <Capitalized> The significance of these findings is discussed in the context of the induction of the heat shock response by ischemic stroke, hypoxia, and recovery from anoxia, all known to stimulate the production of superoxide.

(1996) <PERSON  Plant> <Capitalized> Cell, 8: 2079-20911. <EndsInDigit> PRA2 from pea <Capitalized> Pisum sativum encodes an interesting <Capitalized> Rab GTPase whose expression is regulated by light [Yoshida, <AllCaps> K. et al. (1993) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. <LOCATION  USA,> 90: 6636-6640]. <Capitalized> We examined whether <EndsInDigit> PRA2 complements any of the yeast ypt mutants and found again that <EndsInDigit> PRA2 does not complement but rather confers the growth defect to some of the ypt mutants. <Capitalized> No growth defect was observed when <EndsInDigit> PRA2 was expressed in the wild-type yeast cells. <Capitalized> Unlike the case of Ara4, neither <Capitalized> Arabidopsis nor yeast <AllCaps> GDI remedied the growth defect by Pra2, indicating that the mechanism of the exacerbation is different. <Capitalized> Mutational analysis of <EndsInDigit> PRA2 suggests that the growth inhibition can be ascribed to unidentified factor(s) which prefers the GTP-bound form of Pra2. <Capitalized> This yeast system will be useful for identifying such putative regulatory factor(s) from yeast and plants and analyzing their interactions with Pra2.

 <Capitalized> Genetic interactions between GLC7, <EndsInDigit> PPZ1 and <EndsInDigit> PPZ2 in saccharomyces cerevisiae.

 <EndsInDigit> GLC7 encodes an essential serine/threonine protein type <AllCaps> I phosphatase in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Three other phosphatases (Ppz1p, Ppz2p, and Sal6p) share >59% identity in their catalytic region with Glc7p. ppz1 ppz2 null mutants have no apparent growth defect on rich media. <Capitalized> However, null alleles of <EndsInDigit> PPZ1 and PPZ2, in combination with mutant alleles of GLC7, confer a range of growth defects varying from slow growth to lethality. <Capitalized> These results indicate that Glc7p, Ppz1p, and Ppz2p may have overlapping functions. <Capitalized> To determine if this overlap extends to interaction with targeting subunits, Glc7p-binding proteins were tested for interaction in the two-hybrid system with the functional catalytic domain of Ppz1p.  <AllCaps> REF, an evolutionary conserved family of hnRNP-like proteins, interacts with TAP/Mex67p and participates in <MixedCase> mRNA nuclear export.

 <Capitalized> Pierrat <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Ito <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Hinz <PERSON  W,> <Capitalized> Simonen <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Erdmann> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Chiesi <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Heim> <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <COMPANY  Novartis> <Capitalized> Pharma Inc., <Capitalized> Basle, <LOCATION Switzerland> 
 
 <Capitalized> Uncoupling proteins (UCPs) are members of the superfamily of the mitochondrial anion carrier proteins (MATP). <Capitalized> Localized in the inner membrane of the organelle, they are postulated to be regulators of mitochondrial uncoupling. <EndsInDigit> UCP2 and 3 may play an important role in the regulation of thermogenesis and, thus, on the resting metabolic rate in humans. <Capitalized> To identify interacting proteins that may be involved in the regulation of the activity of UCPs, the yeast two-hybrid system was applied. <Capitalized> Segments of hUCP2 containing the hydrophilic loops facing the intermembrane space, or combinations of these, were used to screen an adipocyte activation domain (AD) fusion library. <Capitalized> The 14.3.3 protein isoforms theta, beta, zeta were identified as possible interacting partners of hUCP2. <Capitalized> Screening of a human skeletal muscle <AllCaps> AD fusion library, on the other hand, yielded several clones all of them encoding the gamma isoform of the 14.3.3 family. <Capitalized> Mapping experiments further revealed that all these 14.3.3 proteins interact specifically with the C-terminal intermembrane space domain of both hUCP2 and hUCP3 whereas no interactions could be detected with the C-terminal part of hUCP1. <Capitalized> Direct interaction between <EndsInDigit> UCP3 and 14.3.3 theta could be demonstrated after in vitro translation by coimmunoprecipitation. <Capitalized> When coexpressed in a heterologous yeast system, 14.3.3 proteins potentiated the inhibitory effect of <EndsInDigit> UCP3 overexpression on cell growth. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that 14.3.3 proteins could be involved in the targeting of UCPs to the mitochondria.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  New York> University/Mount <Capitalized> Sinai <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10029, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <EndsInDigit> RSP5 is an essential gene in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and was recently shown to form a physical and functional complex with <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II (RNA pol II). <Capitalized> The amino-terminal half of Rsp5 consists of four domains: a <EndsInDigit> C2 domain, which binds membrane phospholipids; and three <AllCaps> WW domains, which are protein interaction modules that bind proline-rich ligands. <Capitalized> The carboxyl-terminal half of Rsp5 contains a <AllCaps> HECT (homologous to E6-AP carboxyl terminus) domain that catalytically ligates ubiquitin to proteins and functionally classifies Rsp5 as an <EndsInDigit> E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> C2 and <AllCaps> WW domains are presumed to act as membrane localization and substrate recognition modules, respectively. <Capitalized> We report that the second (and possibly third) Rsp5 <AllCaps> WW domain mediates binding to the carboxyl-terminal domain (CTD) of the <AllCaps> RNA pol <AllCaps> II large subunit. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> CTD comprises a heptamer (YSPTSPS) repeated 26 times and a <AllCaps> PXY core that is critical for interaction with a specific group of <AllCaps> WW domains. <Capitalized> An analysis of synthetic peptides revealed a minimal <AllCaps> CTD sequence that is sufficient to bind to the second Rsp5 <AllCaps> WW domain (Rsp5 WW2) in vitro and in yeast two-hybrid assays. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we found that specific "imperfect" <AllCaps> CTD repeats can form a complex with Rsp5 WW2. <Capitalized> In addition, we have shown that phosphorylation of this minimal <AllCaps> CTD sequence on serine, threonine and tyrosine residues acts as a negative regulator of the Rsp5 WW2-CTD interaction. <Capitalized> In view of the recent data pertaining to phosphorylation-driven interactions between the <AllCaps> RNA pol <AllCaps> II <AllCaps> CTD and the <AllCaps> WW domain of Ess1/Pin1, we suggest that <AllCaps> CTD dephosphorylation may be a prerequisite for targeted <AllCaps> RNA pol <AllCaps> II degradation.

Pat1p contributes to the efficiency of translation in a yeast cell-free system. <Capitalized> However, the synergy between the cap structure and the poly(A) tail is maintained in vitro in the absence of Pat1p. <Capitalized> Analysis of translation initiation intermediates on gradients indicates that Pat1p acts at a step before or during the recruitment of the 40S ribosomal subunit by the mRNA, a step which may be independent of that involving Pab1p. <Capitalized> We conclude that Pat1p is a new factor involved in protein synthesis and that Pat1p might be required for promoting the formation or the stabilization of the preinitiation translation complexes.

 492: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2000 <Capitalized> Apr 28;275(17):12926-33

 <Capitalized> Velot <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Srere <AllCaps> PA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Service of the <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Veterans <Capitalized> Affairs <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <PERSON  Dallas,> <LOCATION  Texas> 75216, <LOCATION  USA.> poffenb1@airmail.net 
 
 <Capitalized> The enzymes of the <PERSON  Krebs> tricarboxylic acid cycle in mitochondria are proposed to form a supramolecular complex, in which there is channeling of intermediates between enzyme active sites. <Capitalized> While interactions have been demonstrated in vitro between most of the sequential tricarboxylic acid cycle enzymes, no direct evidence has been obtained in vivo for such interactions. <Capitalized> We have isolated, in the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene encoding the tricarboxylic acid cycle enzyme citrate synthase Cit1p, an "assembly mutation," i.e. a mutation that causes a tricarboxylic acid cycle deficiency without affecting the citrate synthase activity. <Capitalized> We have shown that a 15-amino acid peptide from wild type Cit1p encompassing the mutation point inhibits the tricarboxylic acid cycle in a dominant manner, and that the inhibitory phenotype is overcome by a co-overexpression of Mdh1p, the mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase. <Capitalized> These data provide the first direct in vivo evidence of interaction between two sequential tricarboxylic acid cycle enzymes, Cit1p and Mdh1p, and indicate that the characterization of assembly mutations by the reversible transdominant inhibition method may be a powerful way to study multienzyme complexes in their physiological context.

 <PERSON  Suter> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Wellinger <AllCaps> RE, <Capitalized> Thoma <AllCaps> F.

Site-specific heterogeneity of repair was observed for both pathways. <Capitalized> This heterogeneity was different for <AllCaps> NER and photoreactivation and it was altered in a minichromosome where <EndsInDigit> ARS1 was transcribed. <Capitalized> The results indicate distinct inter-actions of the repair systems with protein complexes bound in the <AllCaps> ARS region (ORC, Abf1) and a predominant role of photolyase in <AllCaps> CPD repair of an origin of replication.

 <Capitalized> Marintchev <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Robertson> <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Dimitriadis <AllCaps> EK, <Capitalized> Prasad <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Wilson> <AllCaps> SH, <PERSON  Mullen> <AllCaps> GP.

 <EndsInDigit> XRCC1 (X-ray cross-complementing group 1) is a <AllCaps> DNA repair protein that forms complexes with <AllCaps> DNA polymerase beta (beta-Pol), <AllCaps> DNA ligase <AllCaps> III and poly-ADP-ribose polymerase in the repair of <AllCaps> DNA single strand breaks. <Capitalized> The domains in <EndsInDigit> XRCC1 have been determined, and characterization of the domain-domain interaction in the XRCC1-beta-Pol complex has provided information on the specificity and mechanism of binding. <Capitalized> The domain structure of XRCC1, determined using limited proteolysis, was found to include an N-terminal domain (NTD), a central <ContainsHyphen> BRCT-I (breast cancer susceptibility protein-1) domain and a C-terminal <ContainsHyphen> BRCT-II domain. <Capitalized> The BRCT-I-linker-BRCT-II C-terminal fragment and the linker-BRCT-II C-terminal fragment were relatively stable to proteolysis suggestive of a non-random conformation of the linker. <AllCaps> A predicted inner domain was found not to be stable to proteolysis. <Capitalized> Using cross-linking experiments, <EndsInDigit> XRCC1 was found to bind intact beta-Pol and the beta-Pol 31 <MixedCase> kDa domain. <Capitalized> The XRCC1-NTD(1-183)(residues 1-183) was found to bind beta-Pol, the beta-Pol 31 <MixedCase> kDa domain and the beta-Pol C-terminal palm-thumb (residues 140-335), and the interaction was further localized to XRCC1-NTD(1-157)(residues 1-157). <Capitalized> The XRCC1-NTD(1-183)-beta-Pol 31 <MixedCase> kDa domain complex was stable at high salt (1 <AllCaps> M NaCl) indicative of a hydrophobic contribution. <Capitalized> Using a yeast two-hybrid screen, polypeptides expressed from two <EndsInDigit> XRCC1 constructs, which included residues 36-355 and residues 1-159, were found to interact with beta-Pol, the beta-Pol 31 <MixedCase> kDa domain, and the beta-Pol C-terminal thumb-only domain polypeptides expressed from the respective beta-Pol constructs. <Capitalized> Neither the XRCC1-NTD(1-159), nor the XRCC1(36-355)polypeptide was found to interact with a beta-Pol thumbless polypeptide. <AllCaps> A third <EndsInDigit> XRCC1 polypeptide (residues 75-212) showed no interaction with beta-Pol. <Capitalized> In quantitative gel filtration and analytical ultracentrifugation experiments, the XRCC1-NTD(1-183)was found to bind beta-Pol and its 31 <MixedCase> kDa domain in a 1:1 complex with high affinity (K(d) of 0.4-2.4 microM). <Capitalized> The combined results indicate a thumb-domain specific 1:1 interaction between the XRCC1-NTD(1-159)and beta-Pol that is of an  <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> The <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Medicine, <PERSON  Hershey,> <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> 17033, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The association of monomeric <AllCaps> TATA binding protein with promoter <AllCaps> DNA is an essential first step in many current models of eukaryotic transcription initiation. <Capitalized> This step is followed by others in which additional transcription factors, and finally <AllCaps> RNA polymerase, assemble at the promoter. <Capitalized> Here we characterize the
