which <MixedCase> yTBP monomers equilibrate with tetramers and octamers over a broad span of temperatures (4 degrees <AllCaps> C </= <PERSON  T> </= 37 degrees C) and salt concentrations (60 <MixedCase> mM </= [KCl] </= 1 M), that includes the physiological range. <Capitalized> Association is highly cooperative, with octamer formation favored by approximately 9 kcal/mol over tetramer formation. <Capitalized> Changes in association constant with [KCl] are consistent with an assembly-linked release of ions at low salt and an assembly-linked uptake of ions at high salt, for both monomer right arrow over left arrow tetramer and tetramer right arrow over left arrow octamer reaction steps. <Capitalized> Fluorescence emission spectra and steady-state anisotropies reveal that the amino-terminal domain changes conformation and dynamics at both association steps and that the polarity of the environment near tryptophan 26 is sensitive to changes in [KCl] in the monomeric and tetrameric states but not the octameric state. <Capitalized> These results are consistent with a [salt]-dependent change in the assembly mechanism near 300 <MixedCase> mM KCl and suggest that the amino-terminal domain may modulate the self-association of the full-length protein. <AllCaps> TBP self-association may regulate many of its cellular functions, including transit of the nuclear membrane and participation in transcription initiation.

ScPmt1p forms a complex with ScPmt2p that is required for maximum transferase activity. <Capitalized> Recently, we proposed a seven-transmembrane structural model for ScPmt1p. <AllCaps> A large, hydrophilic, endoplasmic reticulum-oriented segment is flanked by five amino-terminal and two carboxyl-terminal membrane-spanning domains. <Capitalized> Based on this model, a structure-function analysis of ScPmt1p was performed. <Capitalized> Deletion mutagenesis identified the N-terminal third of the transferase as being essential for the formation of a functional ScPmt1p-ScPmt2p complex. <Capitalized> Deletion of the central hydrophilic loop eliminates mannosyltransferase activity, but not ScPmt1p-ScPmt2p interactions. <Capitalized> Alignment of all fully characterized <AllCaps> PMT family members revealed that this central loop region contains three highly conserved peptide motifs, which can be considered as signatures of the <AllCaps> PMT family. <Capitalized> In addition, a number of invariant amino acid residues were identified throughout the entire protein sequence. <Capitalized> In order to evaluate the functional significance of these conserved residues site-directed mutagenesis was performed. <Capitalized> We show that several amino acid substitutions in the conserved motifs significantly reduce ScPmt1p activity. <PERSON  Further,> the invariant residues Arg-64, Glu-78, Arg-138, and Leu-408 are essential for ScPmt1p function. <Capitalized> In particular, Arg-138 is crucial for ScPmt1p-ScPmt2p complex formation.

 <Capitalized> Complementation of deletion mutants in the genes encoding the F1-ATPase by expression of the corresponding bovine subunits in yeast <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. 
 
 Lai-Zhang <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Mueller> <AllCaps> DM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> The <LOCATION  Chicago> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Chicago,> <AllCaps> IL 60064, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> F1F0 <AllCaps> ATP synthase is composed of the F1-ATPase which is bound to F0, in the inner membrane of the mitochondrion. <Capitalized> Assembly and function of the enzyme is a complicated task requiring the interactions of many proteins for the folding, import, assembly, and function of the enzyme. <Capitalized> The F1-ATPase is a multimeric enzyme composed of five subunits in the stoichiometry of alpha3beta3gammadeltaepsilon. <Capitalized> This study demonstrates that four of the five bovine subunits of the F1-ATPase can be imported and function in an otherwise yeast enzyme effectively complementing mutations in the genes encoding the corresponding yeast ATPase subunits. <Capitalized> In order to demonstrate this, the coding regions of each of the five genes were separately deleted in yeast providing five null mutant strains. <Capitalized> All of the strains displayed negative or a slow growth phenotype on medium containing glycerol as the carbon source and strains with a null mutation in the gene encoding the gamma-, delta- or epsilon-gene became completely, or at a high frequency, cytoplasmically petite. <Capitalized> The subunits of bovine <EndsInDigit> F1 were expressed individually in the yeast strains with the corresponding null mutations and targeted to the mitochondrion using a yeast mitochondrial leader peptide. <Capitalized> Expression of the bovine alpha-, beta-, gamma-, and epsilon-, but not the delta-, subunit complemented the corresponding null mutations in yeast correcting the corresponding negative phenotypes. <Capitalized> These results indicate that yeast is able to import, assemble subunits of bovine F1-ATPase in mitochondria and form a functional chimeric yeast/bovine enzyme complex.

 <Capitalized> Phagocytosis of yeast: a method for concurrent quantification of binding and internalization using differential interference contrast microscopy. 
 
 <PERSON  Bos> <AllCaps> H, de <PERSON  Souza> <PERSON  W.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Laboratorio de <Capitalized> Biologia <Capitalized> Celular e <Capitalized> Tecidual, <Capitalized> Centro de <Capitalized> Biociencias e <Capitalized> Biotecnologia, <Capitalized> Universidade <Capitalized> Estadual do <Capitalized> Norte <Capitalized> Fluminense, <PERSON  Campos,> <LOCATION Brazil> 
 
 <Capitalized> In studies of phagocytosis there is a need to distinguish targets that are internalized by the cell from those that are bound to the cell surface. <Capitalized> The present work describes a simple method by which internalized and surface-bound yeast particles can be identified by differential interference contrast microscopy, using trypan blue to stain surface-bound yeast particles. <Capitalized> The method has the advantage that both internalized and surface-bound particles can be visualized without the need to switch the illumination source and/or filter sets, thus facilitating concurrent quantitation of binding and internalization. <Capitalized> The method was evaluated with the phagocytosis-modulating agents horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and cytochalasin <AllCaps> D, using adherent resident macrophages as phagocytic cells. <Capitalized> When macrophages are challenged with a particular type of target, they usually bind many more targets than they ingest. <Capitalized> It was shown that yeast particles were arrested in the initial binding phase of phagocytosis depending on the region of macrophage plasma membrane where binding sites were formed. <Capitalized> Failure of surface-bound yeast particles to trigger internalization was not due to modifications of the yeast particle surface. <Capitalized> Nor was it due to binding to non-phagocytic receptors, or low-affinity receptor-ligand interactions. <Capitalized> The glycoprotein <AllCaps> HRP inhibited only the binding stage of phagocytosis, whereas cytochalasin <AllCaps> D, a drug that affects actin polymerization, inhibited both binding and internalization. <Capitalized> However, when the yeast particles were pre-incubated in fresh mouse serum, cytochalasin <AllCaps> D inhibited only the internalization step. <Capitalized> The assay described here may be useful in studies concerned with the function and expression of phagocytosis-mediating surface lectins.

 504: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Chromatogr <AllCaps> A 2000 <PERSON  Mar> 24;873(2):195-208 
 
 <Capitalized> The influence of cell adsorbent interactions on protein adsorption in expanded beds. 
 
 Fernandez-Lahore <AllCaps> HM, <Capitalized> Geilenkirchen <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Boldt> <AllCaps> K, <PERSON  Nagel> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Kula> <AllCaps> MR, <Capitalized> Thommes <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Enzymtechnologie, Heinrich-Heine <Capitalized> Universitat <Capitalized> Dusseldorf, <Capitalized> Julich, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Expanded bed adsorption (EBA) is a primary recovery operation allowing the adsorption of proteins directly from unclarified feedstock, e.g. culture suspensions, homogenates or crude extracts. <PERSON  Thus> solid-liquid separation is combined with adsorptive purification in a single step. <Capitalized> The concept of integration requires that the solid components of the feed solution are regarded as a part of the process, which influences stability, reproducibility, and overall performance. <Capitalized> This aspect is investigated here at the example of the influence of presence and concentration of intact yeast cells (S. cerevisiae) on the adsorption of model proteins (hen egg white lysozyme and bovine serum albumin) to various stationary phases (cation and anion-exchange, hydrophobic interaction, immobilised metal affinity). <Capitalized> The interaction of the cells with the adsorbents is determined qualitatively and quantitatively by a pulse response method as well as by a finite bath technique under different operating conditions. <Capitalized> The consequence of these interactions for the stability of expanded beds in suspensions of varying cell concentration is measured by residence time distributions (RTDs) after tracer pulse injection (NaBr, LiCl). <Capitalized> Analysis of the measured <AllCaps> RTD by the <AllCaps> PDE model allows the calculation of the fraction of perfectly fluidised bed (phi), a parameter which may be regarded as a critical quantity for the estimation of the quality of fluidisation of adsorbents in cell containing suspensions. <Capitalized> The correlation between bed stability and performance is made by analysing the breakthrough of model proteins during adsorption from unclarified yeast culture broth. <AllCaps> A clear relationship is found between the degree of cell/adsorbent interaction, bed stability in terms of the phi parameter, and the sorption efficiency. <Capitalized> Only beds characterised by a phi value larger than 0.8 in the presence of cells will show a conserved performance compared to adsorption from cell free solutions. <AllCaps> A drop in phi, which is due to interactions of the fluidised adsorbent particles with cells from the feed, will directly result in a reduced breakthrough efficiency. <Capitalized> The data presented highlight the importance of including the potential interaction of solid feedstock components and the expanded adsorbents into the design of <AllCaps> EBA processes, as the interrelation found here is a key factor for the overall performance of <AllCaps> EBA as a truly integrated operation.

Ypt51 is an important regulator involved in the endocytic membrane traffic of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The structure reveals small but significant structural differences compared with H-Ras p21. <Capitalized> The effector loop and the catalytic loop are well defined and stabilized by extensive hydrophobic interactions. <Capitalized> The switch <AllCaps> I and switch <AllCaps> II regions form a well-defined epitope for hypothetical effector protein binding. <Capitalized> Sequence comparisons between the different isoforms Ypt51, Ypt52 and Ypt53 provide the first insights into determinants for specific effector binding and for fine-tuning of the intrinsic GTP-hydrolysis rate. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <PERSON  Schild> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Lio <PERSON  Y,> <PERSON  Collins> <AllCaps> DW, <Capitalized> Tsomondo <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Chen <AllCaps> DJ.

 <Capitalized> We have probed the association of <Capitalized> Flp recombinase with its <AllCaps> DNA target using protein footprinting assays. <Capitalized> The results are consistent with the domain organization of the <Capitalized> Flp protein and with the general features of the protein-DNA interactions revealed by the crystal structures of the recombination intermediates formed by <Capitalized> Cre, the Flp-related recombinase. <Capitalized> The similarity in the organization of the <Capitalized> Flp and <Capitalized> Cre target sites and in their recognition by the respective recombinases implies that the overall DNA-protein geometry during strand cleavage in the two systems must also be similar. <Capitalized> Within the functional recombinase dimer, it is the interaction between two recombinase monomers bound on either side of the strand exchange region (or spacer) that provides the allosteric activation of a single active site. <Capitalized> Whereas <Capitalized> Cre utilizes the cleavage nucleophile (the active site tyrosine) in cis, <Capitalized> Flp utilizes it in trans (one monomer donating the tyrosine to its partner). <Capitalized> By using synthetic <Capitalized> Cre and <Capitalized> Flp <AllCaps> DNA substrates that are geometrically restricted in similar ways, we have mapped the positioning of the active and inactive tyrosine residues during cis and trans cleavage events. <Capitalized> We find that, for a fixed substrate geometry, <Capitalized> Flp and <Capitalized> Cre cleave the labile phosphodiester bond at the same spacer end, not at opposite ends. <Capitalized> Our results provide a model that accommodates local heterogeneities in peptide orientations in the two systems while preserving the global functional architecture of the reaction complex.

 <Capitalized> Architectural principles for the structure and function of the glucocorticoid receptor tau 1 core activation domain. 
 
 <Capitalized> Warnmark <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Gustafsson> <AllCaps> JA, <PERSON  Wright> <AllCaps> AP. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biosciences, <Capitalized> Karolinska <Capitalized> Institutet, <Capitalized> Novum, <Capitalized> Huddinge S-141 57, <LOCATION Sweden> anette.warnmark@cbt.ki.se 
 
 <AllCaps> A 58-amino acid region mediates the core transactivation activity of the glucocorticoid receptor tau1 activation domain. <Capitalized> This tau1 core domain is unstructured in aqueous buffers, but in the presence of trifluoroethanol three alpha-helical segments are induced. <Capitalized> Two of these putative structural modules have been tested in different combinations with regard to transactivation potential in vivo and binding capacity to the coactivators in vitro. <Capitalized> The results show that whereas single modules are not transcriptionally active, any combination of two or three modules is sufficient, with trimodular constructs having the highest activity. <Capitalized> However, proteins containing one, two, or three segments bind Ada2 and cAMP-response element-binding protein with similar affinity. <AllCaps> A single segment is thus able to bind a target factor but cannot transactivate target genes significantly. <Capitalized> The results are consistent with models in which activation domains are comprised of short activation modules that allow multiple interactions with coactivators. <Capitalized> Our results also suggest that an increased number of modules may not result in correspondingly higher affinity but instead that the concentration of binding sites is increased, which gives rise to a higher association rate. <Capitalized> This is consistent with a model where the association rate for activator-target factor interactions rather than the equilibrium constant is the most relevant measure of activator potency.

been investigated by a combination of methods. <Capitalized> An approximately 100 residue region of sequence homology at the N-termini of Mbp1 and Swi4 is necessary but not sufficient for full <AllCaps> DNA binding activity. <Capitalized> Unexpectedly, nonconserved residues C-terminal to the core domain are essential for <AllCaps> DNA binding. <Capitalized> Proteolysis of Mbp1 and Swi4 been produced. <Capitalized> The extended Mbp1 and Swi4 proteins bind to their cognate sites with similar affinity [K(A) approximately (1-4) x 10(6) M(-)(1)] and with a 1:1 stoichiometry. <Capitalized> However, alanine substitution of two lysine residues (116 and 122) within the C-terminal extension (tail) of Mbp1 considerably reduces the apparent affinity for an <AllCaps> MCB (MluI cell-cycle box) containing oligonucleotide. <PERSON  Both> Mbp1 and Swi4 are specific for their cognate sites with respect to nonspecific <AllCaps> DNA but exhibit similar affinities for the <AllCaps> SCB (Swi4/Swi6 cell-cycle box) and <AllCaps> MCB consensus elements. <Capitalized> Circular dichroism and (1)H <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy reveal that complex formation results in substantial perturbations of base stacking interactions upon <AllCaps> DNA binding. <Capitalized> These are localized to a central 5'-d(C-A/G-CG)-3' region common to both <AllCaps> MCB and <AllCaps> SCB sequences consistent with the observed pattern of specificity. <Capitalized> Changes in the backbone amide proton and nitrogen chemical shifts upon <AllCaps> DNA binding have enabled us to experimentally define a DNA-binding surface on the core N-terminal domain of Mbp1 that is associated with a putative winged helix-turn-helix motif. <Capitalized> Furthermore, significant chemical shift differences occur within the C-terminal tail of Mbp1, supporting the notion of two structurally distinct DNA-binding regions within these proteins.

 <Capitalized> Proteins of the closely related homeodomain-leucine zipper (HD-Zip) families <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> II in plants are putative transcription factors that interact with similar pseudopalindromic <AllCaps> DNA recognition sites. <Capitalized> We have previously described the Oshox1 gene from rice, which encodes an HD-Zip <AllCaps> II protein. <Capitalized> To identify further rice HD-Zip proteins, one-hybrid screens were performed in yeast strains containing a <EndsInDigit> HIS3 reporter gene with upstream HD-Zip recognition sites. <Capitalized> This resulted in the isolation of six new <MixedCase> cDNAs encoding HD-Zip proteins belonging to family <AllCaps> I (Oshox4, -5, -6) or family <AllCaps> II (Oshox2, -3, -7). <Capitalized> In transient assays, using rice suspension-cultured cells transformed by particle bombardment, we showed previously that Oshox1 can transcriptionally repress the activity of reporter gene constructs with upstream HD-Zip binding sites. <Capitalized> Here, we confirm the repression properties of Oshox1 by showing that the repression function can be conferred on a heterologous DNA-binding domain. <Capitalized> This portable functional domain (residues 1-155) is located proximal to the HD-Zip domain. <Capitalized> In yeast, the same region of the Oshox1 protein was found to confer transcriptional activation instead of repression, pointing to the possibility that cell type-specific factors may determine the functional properties of the Oshox1 protein in rice. <PERSON  Like> Oshox1, another HD-Zip family <AllCaps> II protein (Oshox3) was also found to function as a transcriptional repressor in rice cells. <Capitalized> In contrast, two HD-Zip <AllCaps> I family proteins (Oshox4 and -5) appeared to act as activators in both rice and yeast cells. <Capitalized> Results of two-hybrid assays and electrophoretic mobility shift assays strongly suggest that all HD-Zip proteins of families <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> II can form homodimers and also heterodimers with all HD-Zip proteins of the same family. <Capitalized> Heterodimerization across the HD-Zip families <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> II apparently does not to occur.

 <Capitalized> The hepatitis <AllCaps> C virus (HCV) causes severe liver disease, including liver cancer. <AllCaps> A vaccine preventing <AllCaps> HCV infection has not yet been developed, and, given the increasing number of infected people, this virus is now considered a major public-health problem. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> HCV genome is a plus-stranded <AllCaps> RNA that encodes a single polyprotein processed into at least 10 mature polypeptides. <Capitalized> So far, only the interaction between the protease <EndsInDigit> NS3 and its cofactor, NS4A, which is involved in the processing of the non-structural region, has been extensively studied. <Capitalized> Our work was aimed at constructing a protein interaction map of <AllCaps> HCV. <AllCaps> A classical two-hybrid system failed to detect any interactions between mature <AllCaps> HCV polypeptides, suggesting incorrect folding, expression or targetting of these proteins. <Capitalized> We therefore developed a two-hybrid strategy, based on exhaustive screens of a random genomic <AllCaps> HCV library. <Capitalized> Using this method, we found known interactions, such as the capsid homodimer and the protease dimer, NS3-NS4A, as well as several novel interactions such as NS4A-NS2. <PERSON  Thus,> our results are consistent with the idea that the use of a random genomic <AllCaps> HCV library allows the selection of correctly folded viral protein fragments. <Capitalized> Interacting domains of the viral polyprotein are identified, opening the possibility of developing specific anti-viral agents, based on their ability to modulate these interactions.

 <Capitalized> Chromosome replication is not a uniform and continuous process. <Capitalized> Replication forks can be slowed down or arrested by <AllCaps> DNA secondary structures, specific protein-DNA complexes, specific <ContainsHyphen> DNA-RNA hybrids, or interactions between the replication and transcription machineries. <Capitalized> Replication arrest has important implications for the topology of replication intermediates and can trigger homologous and illegitimate recombination. <PERSON  Thus,> replication arrest may be a key factor in genome instability. <Capitalized> Several examples of these phenomena are reviewed here.

 <Capitalized> Rules for <AllCaps> DNA target-site recognition by a lactococcal group <AllCaps> II intron enable retargeting of the intron to specific <AllCaps> DNA sequences. 
 
 <PERSON  Mohr> <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Smith> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Belfort <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Lambowitz <AllCaps> AM.

 <Capitalized> Group <AllCaps> II intron homing occurs primarily by a mechanism in which the intron <AllCaps> RNA reverse splices into a <AllCaps> DNA target site and is then reverse transcribed by the intron-encoded protein. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> DNA target site is recognized by an <AllCaps> RNP complex containing the intron-encoded protein and the excised intron <AllCaps> RNA. <Capitalized> Here, we analyzed <AllCaps> DNA target-site requirements for the <Capitalized> Lactococcus lactis Ll.LtrB group <AllCaps> II intron in vitro and in vivo. <Capitalized> Our results suggest a model similar to yeast <MixedCase> mtDNA introns, in which the intron-encoded protein first recognizes a small number of nucleotide residues in double-stranded <AllCaps> DNA and causes <AllCaps> DNA unwinding, enabling the intron <AllCaps> RNA to base-pair with the <AllCaps> DNA for reverse splicing. Antisense-strand cleavage requires additional interactions between the protein and 3' exon. <PERSON  Key> nucleotide residues are recognized directly by the intron-encoded protein independent of sequence context, and there is a stringent requirement for fixed spacing between target site elements recognized by the protein and <AllCaps> RNA components of the endonuclease. <Capitalized> Experiments with <AllCaps> DNA substrates containing GC-clamps or "bubbles" indicate a requirement for <AllCaps> DNA unwinding in the 3' exon but not the distal 5' exon region. <Capitalized> Finally, by applying the target-site recognition rules, we show that the L1.LtrB intron can be modified to insert at new sites in a plasmid-borne <MixedCase> thyA gene in <Capitalized> Escherichia coli. <Capitalized> This strategy should be generally applicable to retargeting group <AllCaps> II introns and to delivering foreign sequences to specific sites in heterologous genomes.

 <Capitalized> Cell wall biogenesis of <Capitalized> Blastomyces dermatitidis. <Capitalized> Evidence for a novel mechanism of cell surface localization of a virulence-associated adhesin via extracellular release and reassociation with cell wall chitin. 
 
 <Capitalized> Brandhorst <PERSON  T,> <PERSON  Klein> <AllCaps> B. 
 
 <Capitalized> Departments of <Capitalized> Pediatrics, <Capitalized> Internal <Capitalized> Medicine, and <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Immunology, and the <Capitalized> Comprehensive <Capitalized> Cancer <PERSON  Center,> <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Wisconsin> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <PERSON  Madison,> <LOCATION  Wisconsin> 53792, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Pathogenic yeast of <Capitalized> Blastomyces dermatitidis express a surface protein adhesin, WI-1. <PERSON  Due> to the crucial role of WI-1 in adherence and disease pathogenesis, we investigated how the protein localizes to the surface of <AllCaps> B. dermatitidis. WI-1 released extracellularly by wild-type yeast coated the surfaces of co-cultured knockout yeast within 3 h of incubation, implying that secreted WI-1 provides a pathway for loading the protein onto the yeast cell wall. <Capitalized> In radioligand binding assays, purified WI-1 bound saturably, specifically, and with high affinity (K(d) = 8.3 x 10(-9)) to the cell surface of knockout yeast devoid of WI-1. WI-1 added exogenously, in vitro, to knockout yeast was indistinguishable from native cell surface WI-1 by fluorescence staining and restored adhesivity to the knockout yeast in macrophage binding and phagocytosis assays. <Capitalized> Analysis of interactions between WI-1 and elements of the yeast cell wall identified chitin as the anchor point for WI-1. <Capitalized> This interaction was shown to hinge on the 24-amino acid tandem repeat sequence of WI-1. <Capitalized> Efforts to extract surface WI-1 from the yeast demonstrated that it is fastened to the wall by non-covalent interactions and covalent links between cysteine residues. <Capitalized> We conclude that the yeast cell surface adhesin WI-1 localizes to the cell wall, in part, through extracellular release followed by high affinity binding back onto exposed chitin fibrils. <Capitalized> These findings point to a novel pathway of cell wall biogenesis in yeast and an unanticipated role for chitin in anchoring and displaying a surface adhesin and virulence determinant.

 <Capitalized> Genes regulated cooperatively by one or more transcription factors and their identification in whole eukaryotic genomes. 
 
 <PERSON  Wagner> <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  New> <LOCATION  Mexico,> <LOCATION  Albuquerque,> <LOCATION  USA.> wagnera@unm.edu 
 
 MOTIVATION: <Capitalized> The question addressed here is how cooperative interactions among transcription factors (TFs), a very frequent phenomenon in eukaryotic transcriptional regulation, can be used to identify genes that are regulated by one or more TFs with known <AllCaps> DNA binding specificities. <Capitalized> Cooperativity may be homotypic, involving binding of only one transcription factor to multiple sites in a gene's regulatory region. <Capitalized> It may also be heterotypic, involving binding of more than one <AllCaps> TF. <PERSON  Both> types of cooperativity have in common that the binding sites for the respective TFs form tightly linked 'clusters', groups of binding sites often more closely associated than expected by chance alone. RESULTS: <AllCaps> A statistical technique suitable for the identification of statistically significant homotypic or heterotypic <AllCaps> TF binding site clusters in whole eukaryotic genomes is presented. <Capitalized> It can be used to identify genes likely to be regulated by the TFs. <Capitalized> Application of the technique is illustrated with two transcription factors involved in the cell cycle and mating control of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, indicating that the results obtained are biologically meaningful. <Capitalized> This rapid and inexpensive computational method of generating hypotheses about gene regulation thus generates information that may be used to guide subsequent costly and laborious experimental approaches, and that may aid in the assignment of biological functions to putative open reading frames.

 Spo11p is a key mediator of interhomolog interactions during meiosis. <Capitalized> Deletion of the <EndsInDigit> SPO11 gene decreases the length of <PERSON  S> phase by approximately 25%. Rec8p is a key coordinator of meiotic interhomolog and intersister interactions. <Capitalized> Deletion of the <EndsInDigit> REC8 gene increases S-phase length, by approximately 10% in wild-type and approximately 30% in a spo11Delta background. <PERSON  Thus,> the progression of <AllCaps> DNA replication is modulated by interchromosomal interaction proteins. <Capitalized> The spo11-Y135F <AllCaps> DSB (double strand break) catalysis-defective mutant is normal for S-phase modulation and DSB-independent homolog pairing but is defective for later events, formation of DSBs, and synaptonemal complexes. <PERSON  Thus,> earlier and later functions of Spo11 are defined. <Capitalized> We propose that meiotic S-phase progression is linked directly to development of specific chromosomal features required for meiotic interhomolog interactions and that this feedback process is built upon a more fundamental mechanism, common to all cell types, by which S-phase progression is coupled to development of nascent intersister connections and/or related aspects of chromosome morphogenesis. <Capitalized> Roles for Rec8 and/or Spo11 in progression through other stages of meiosis are also revealed.

 <Capitalized> The Ogg1 protein of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae belongs to a family of <AllCaps> DNA glycosylases and apurinic/apyrimidinic site (AP) lyases, the signature of which is the alpha-helix-hairpin-alpha-helix-Gly/Pro-Asp (HhH-GPD) active site motif together with a conserved catalytic lysine residue, to which we refer as the HhH-GPD/K family. <Capitalized> In the yeast Ogg1 protein, yOgg1, the HhH-GPD/K motif spans residues 225-260 and the conserved lysine is K241. <Capitalized> In this study, we have purified the K241R and K241Q mutant proteins and compared their catalytic and <AllCaps> DNA binding properties to that of the wild-type yOgg1. <Capitalized> The results show that the K241R mutation greatly impairs both the <AllCaps> DNA glycosylase and the <AllCaps> AP lyase activities of yOgg1. <Capitalized> Specificity constants for cleavage of a 34mer oligodeoxyribonucleotide containing a 7,8-dihydro-8-oxoguanine (8-OxoG) paired with a cytosine, [8-OxoG.C], are 56 x 10(-)(3) and 5 x 10(-)(3) min(-)(1) nM(-)(1) for the wild-type and the K241R protein, respectively. <Capitalized> On the other hand, the K241Q mutation abolishes the <AllCaps> DNA glycosylase and <AllCaps> AP lyase activities of yOgg1. <Capitalized> In contrast, the K241R and K241Q proteins have conserved wild-type <AllCaps> DNA binding properties. K(dapp) values for binding of [8-OxoG.C] are 6.9, 7.4, and 4.8 <MixedCase> nM for the wild-type, K241R, and K241Q proteins, respectively. <Capitalized> The results also show that <AllCaps> AP site analogues such as 1, 3-propanediol (Pr), tetrahydrofuran (F), or cyclopentanol (Cy) are not substrates but constitute good inhibitors of the wild-type yOgg1. <Capitalized> Therefore, we have used a 59mer [Pr.C] duplex to further analyze the <AllCaps> DNA binding properties of the wild-type, K241R, and K241Q proteins. <Capitalized> Hydroxyl radical footprints of the wild-type yOgg1 show strong protection of six nucleotides centered around the <Capitalized> Pr lesion in the damaged strand. <Capitalized> On the complementary strand, only the cytosine placed opposite <Capitalized> Pr was strongly protected. <Capitalized> The same footprints were observed with the K241R and K241Q proteins, confirming their wild-type <AllCaps> DNA binding properties. <Capitalized> These results indicate that the K241Q mutant protein can be used to study interactions between yOgg1 and <AllCaps> DNA containing metabolizable substrates such as 8-OxoG or an <AllCaps> AP site.

 <PERSON  Klein> <Capitalized> Gunnewiek <AllCaps> JM, <Capitalized> Hussein <AllCaps> RI, van <PERSON  Aarssen> <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Palacios <AllCaps> D, de <PERSON  Jong> <PERSON  R,> van <Capitalized> Venrooij <AllCaps> WJ, <Capitalized> Gunderson <AllCaps> SI.

 <Capitalized> It was previously shown that the human U1A protein, one of three <EndsInDigit> U1 small nuclear ribonucleoprotein-specific proteins, autoregulates its own production by binding to and inhibiting the polyadenylation of its own pre-mRNA. <Capitalized> The U1A autoregulatory complex requires two molecules of U1A protein to cooperatively bind a 50-nucleotide polyadenylation-inhibitory element (PIE) <AllCaps> RNA located in the U1A 3' untranslated region. <Capitalized> Based on both biochemical and nuclear magnetic resonance structural data, it was predicted that protein-protein interactions between the N-terminal regions (amino acids [aa] 1 to 115) of the two U1A proteins would form the basis for cooperative binding to <AllCaps> PIE <AllCaps> RNA and for inhibition of polyadenylation. <Capitalized> In this study, we not only experimentally confirmed these predictions but discovered some unexpected features of how the U1A autoregulatory complex functions. <Capitalized> We found that the U1A protein homodimerizes in the yeast two-hybrid system even when its ability to bind <AllCaps> RNA is incapacitated.  <Capitalized> Uetz <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Giot <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Cagney <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Mansfield> <AllCaps> TA, <PERSON  Judson> <AllCaps> RS, <PERSON  Knight> <AllCaps> JR, <Capitalized> Lockshon <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Narayan <PERSON  V,> <Capitalized> Srinivasan <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Pochart <PERSON  P,> Qureshi-Emili <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Li <PERSON  Y,> <PERSON  Godwin> <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Conover> <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Kalbfleisch <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Vijayadamodar <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Yang <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Johnston> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Fields> <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Rothberg <AllCaps> JM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Washington,> <LOCATION  Seattle> 98195-7360, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Two large-scale yeast two-hybrid screens were undertaken to identify protein-protein interactions between full-length open reading frames predicted from the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae genome sequence. <Capitalized> In one approach, we constructed a protein array of about 6,000 yeast transformants, with each transformant expressing one of the open reading frames as a fusion to an activation domain. <Capitalized> This array was screened by a simple and automated procedure for 192 yeast proteins, with positive responses identified by their positions in the array. <Capitalized> In a second approach, we pooled cells expressing one of about 6,000 activation domain fusions to generate a library. <Capitalized> We used a high-throughput screening procedure to screen nearly all of the 6,000 predicted yeast proteins, expressed as Gal4 DNA-binding domain fusion proteins, against the library, and characterized positives by sequence analysis. <Capitalized> These approaches resulted in the detection of 957 putative interactions involving 1,004 <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae proteins. <Capitalized> These data reveal interactions that place functionally unclassified proteins in a biological context, interactions between proteins involved in the same biological function, and interactions that link biological functions together into larger cellular processes. <Capitalized> The results of these screens are shown here.

 538: <Capitalized> Biopolymers 2000 <Capitalized> Apr 5;53(4):293-307 
 
 Osmolyte-induced changes in protein conformational equilibria. 
 
 <PERSON  Saunders> <AllCaps> AJ, Davis-Searles <AllCaps> PR, <PERSON  Allen> <AllCaps> DL, <Capitalized> Pielak <AllCaps> GJ, <Capitalized> Erie <AllCaps> DA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Biophysics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  North Carolina> at <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <AllCaps> NC 27599, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Examining solute-induced changes in protein conformational equilibria is a long-standing method for probing the role of water in maintaining protein stability. <Capitalized> Interpreting the molecular details governing the solute-induced effects, however, remains controversial. <Capitalized> We present experimental and theoretical data for osmolyte-induced changes in the stabilities of the <AllCaps> A and <AllCaps> N states of yeast iso-1-ferricytochrome c. <Capitalized> Using polyol osmolytes of increasing size, we observe that osmolytes alone induce A-state formation from acid-denatured cytochrome c and <AllCaps> N state formation from the thermally denatured protein. <Capitalized> The stabilities of the <AllCaps> A and <AllCaps> N states increase linearly with osmolyte concentration. <Capitalized> Interestingly, osmolytes stabilize the <AllCaps> A state to a greater degree than the <AllCaps> N state. <Capitalized> To interpret the data, we divide the free energy for the reaction into contributions from nonspecific steric repulsions (excluded volume effects) and from binding interactions. <Capitalized> We use scaled particle theory (SPT) to estimate the free energy contributions from steric repulsions, and we estimate the contributions from water-protein and osmolyte-protein binding interactions by comparing the <AllCaps> SPT calculations to experimental data. <Capitalized> We conclude that excluded volume effects are the primary stabilizing force, with changes in water-protein and solute-protein binding interactions making favorable contributions to stability of the <AllCaps> A state and unfavorable contributions to the stability of the <AllCaps> N state. <Capitalized> The validity of our interpretation is strengthened by analysis of data on osmolyte-induced protein stabilization from the literature, and by comparison with other analyses of solute-induced changes in conformational equilibria.  <Capitalized> We have identified a 74 <MixedCase> kDa double-stranded (ds)RNA-binding protein that shares extensive homology with the mouse spermatid perinuclear RNA-binding (Spnr) protein. p74 contains two dsRNA-binding motifs (dsRBMs) that are essential for preferential binding to dsRNA. <Capitalized> Previously, dsRNA-binding proteins were shown to undergo homo- and heterodimerization, raising the possibility that regulation of activity could be controlled by interactions between different family members. <Capitalized> Homodimerization is required to activate the dsRNA-dependent protein kinase <AllCaps> PKR, whereas hetero-dimerization between <AllCaps> PKR and other dsRNA-binding proteins can inhibit kinase activity. <Capitalized> We have found that p74 also interacts with <AllCaps> PKR, both the wild-type enzyme and a catalytically defective mutant (K296R). <Capitalized> While co-expression of p74 and wild-type <AllCaps> PKR in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae did not alter <AllCaps> PKR activity, co-expression of p74 and the catalytically defective K296R mutant surprisingly resulted in abnormal morphology and cell death in transformants that maintained a high level of p74 expression. <Capitalized> These transformants could be rescued by overexpression of the alpha-subunit of wild-type eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2 (eIF2alpha), one of the known substrates for <AllCaps> PKR. <Capitalized> We hypothesize that competing heterodimers between p74-K296R <AllCaps> PKR and eIF2alpha-K296R <AllCaps> PKR may control cell growth such that stabilization of the p74-K296R <AllCaps> PKR heterodimer induces abnormal morphology and cell death.

 <Capitalized> Saparbaev <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Mani <AllCaps> JC, <LOCATION  Laval> <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <Capitalized> Groupe 'Reparation des lesions Radio- et Chimio-Induites', <AllCaps> UMR 8532 <AllCaps> CNRS, <Capitalized> Institut <Capitalized> Gustave <Capitalized> Roussy, 94805 <Capitalized> Villejuif <Capitalized> Cedex, <PERSON France> 
 
 <Capitalized> In <AllCaps> DNA, the deamination of <MixedCase> dAMP generates 2'-deoxy-inosine 5'-monophosphate (dIMP). <Capitalized> Hypoxanthine (HX) residues are mutagenic since they give rise to A.T-->G.C transition. <Capitalized> They are excised, although with different efficiencies, by an activity of the 3-methyl-adenine (3-meAde)-DNA glycosylases from <Capitalized> Escherichia coli (AlkA protein), human cells (ANPG protein), rat cells (APDG protein) and yeast (MAG protein). <Capitalized> Comparison of the kinetic constants for the excision of <AllCaps> HX residues by the four enzymes shows that the E.coli and yeast enzymes are quite inefficient, whereas for the <AllCaps> ANPG and the <AllCaps> APDG proteins they repair the <AllCaps> HX residues with an efficiency comparable to that of alkylated bases, which are believed to be the primary substrates of these <AllCaps> DNA glycosylases. <Capitalized> Since the use of various substrates to monitor the activity of <ContainsHyphen> HX-DNA glycosylases has generated conflicting results, the efficacy of the four 3-meAde-DNA glycosylases of different origin was compared using three different substrates. <Capitalized> Moreover, using oligo-nucleotides containing a single <MixedCase> dIMP residue, we investigated a putative sequence specificity of the enzymes involving the bases next to the <AllCaps> HX residue. <Capitalized> We found up to 2-5-fold difference in the rates of <AllCaps> HX excision between the various sequences of the oligonucleotides studied. <Capitalized> When the <MixedCase> dIMP residue was placed opposite to each of the four bases, a preferential recognition of dI:T over dI:dG, dI:dC and dI:dA mismatches was observed for both human (ANPG) and E.coli (AlkA) proteins. <Capitalized> At variance, the yeast <AllCaps> MAG protein removed more efficiently <AllCaps> HX from a dI:dG over dI:dC, dI:T and dI:dA mismatches.

 <Capitalized> Anatomy of a proficient enzyme: the structure of orotidine 5'-monophosphate decarboxylase in the presence and absence of a potential transition state analog. 
 
 <PERSON  Miller> <AllCaps> BG, <PERSON  Hassell> <AllCaps> AM, <Capitalized> Wolfenden <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Milburn> <AllCaps> MV, <PERSON  Short> <AllCaps> SA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  North Carolina,> <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <AllCaps> NC 27599, <LOCATION  USA.> <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Triangle <PERSON  Park,> <AllCaps> NC 27709, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase produces the largest rate enhancement that has been reported for any enzyme. <Capitalized> The crystal structure of the recombinant <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae enzyme has been determined in the absence and presence of the proposed transition state analog 6-hydroxyuridine 5'-phosphate, at a resolution of 2.1 <AllCaps> A and 2.4 <AllCaps> A, respectively. <Capitalized> Orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase folds as a TIM-barrel with the ligand binding site near the open end of the barrel. <Capitalized> The binding of 6-hydroxyuridine 5'-phosphate is accompanied by protein loop movements that envelop the ligand almost completely, forming numerous favorable interactions with the phosphoryl group, the ribofuranosyl group, and the pyrimidine ring. Lysine-93 appears to be anchored in such a way as to optimize electrostatic interactions with developing negative charge at C-6 of the pyrimidine ring, and to donate the proton that replaces the carboxylate group at C-6 of the product. <Capitalized> In addition, H-bonds from the active site to O-2 and O-4 help to delocalize negative charge in the transition state. <Capitalized> Interactions between the enzyme and the phosphoribosyl group anchor the pyrimidine within the active site, helping to explain the phosphoribosyl group's remarkably large contribution to catalysis despite its distance from the site of decarboxylation.

(1996. <Capitalized> Genetics 144, 1425-1436). <Capitalized> The endoplasmic reticulum protein <Capitalized> Slslp was then used as a bait in a functional test of the library. <Capitalized> Indeed, we previously showed that the <EndsInDigit> SLS1 gene product is involved in protein translocation across the endoplasmic reticulum membrane and interacts physically in a two-hybrid assay with Kar2p, an essential luminal member of the <EndsInDigit> HSP70 family (Boisrame et al., 1998. <AllCaps> J. Biol. Chem. 273, 30 903-30 908). <Capitalized> We developed a mating strategy similar to that used for the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> FRYL library (Fromont-Racine et al., 1997. Nat. <PERSON Genet> 16, 277-282). <Capitalized> No other partner than Kar2p was identified in this screen. <Capitalized> As an interesting result, Kar2p interacts with <Capitalized> Slslp through its ATPase domain, supporting our hypothesis that <Capitalized> Slslp is a cofactor of the chaperone protein, modulating its activity during the <EndsInDigit> HSP70 cycle. <Capitalized> Our results indicate that we have constructed a new and powerful tool for the study of <Capitalized> Yarrowia lipolytica, which we believe is a good alternative model to investigate such complex biological processes as secretion pathways.

 <Capitalized> Identification of connexin-interacting proteins: application of the yeast two-hybrid screen. 
 
 <Capitalized> Jin <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Lau> <AllCaps> AF, <PERSON  Martyn> <AllCaps> KD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Carcinogenesis, <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research <PERSON  Center> of <Capitalized> Hawaii, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Hawaii at <Capitalized> Manoa, 1236 <Capitalized> Lauhala <PERSON  Street,> <Capitalized> Room 304, <Capitalized> Honolulu, <Capitalized> Hawaii 96813, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Protein-protein interactions are recognized as one of the fundamental mechanisms for relaying the intra- and intercellular signals that are required for normal cellular activities affecting growth, development, and maintenance of homeostasis in tissues and organs. <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid screen has become a valuable tool for identifying protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> The gap junction protein connexin 43 (Cx43) has been implicated in a number of biological processes including development and cellular growth control. <Capitalized> To further advance our understanding of the ways in which Cx43 may influence these cellular activities, and to extend our knowledge of the regulation of Cx43 function and/or processing, we have employed the yeast two-hybrid screen technique to identify Cx43-interacting proteins. <Capitalized> We present detailed methods for the yeast two-hybrid screen of a mouse embryonic <MixedCase> cDNA library using the <AllCaps> C terminus of Cx43 as "bait." <Capitalized> We also describe additional methods to confirm the interactions between Cx43 and the identified proteins. <Capitalized> These methods include in vitro binding assays, coimmunoprecipitation, and subcellular localization using immunofluorescence microscopy. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 547: <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Cell 1999 Dec;91(9):649-63 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Cdc14 phosphatase is implicated in the structural organization of the nucleolus. 
 
 de <Capitalized> Almeida <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Raccurt <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Peyrol <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Charbonneau> <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <AllCaps> UMR CNRS/ENS no 5665, <Capitalized> Ecole <Capitalized> Normale <Capitalized> Superieure, <LOCATION  Lyon,> <PERSON France> 
 
 Cdc14, a dual-specificity protein phosphatase, has been previously implicated in triggering exit from mitosis in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Using immunofluorescence microscopy and immunogold labeling, we demonstrate that a functional HA-tagged version of the phosphatase Cdc14 localizes to the nucleolus. <Capitalized> Moreover, Cdc14-HA co-localized with the nucleolar <EndsInDigit> NOP2 and <EndsInDigit> GAR1 proteins. <Capitalized> By immunofluorescence, Cdc14-HA was found in the nucleolus during most of the mitotic cell cycle, except during anaphase-telophase when it redistributed along the mitotic spindle. <Capitalized> While this work was in progress, the same pattern of Cdc14 localization was described by others (Visintin et al, <Capitalized> Nature 398 (1999) 818). <Capitalized> Constitutive overexpression of <EndsInDigit> CDC14 was toxic and led to cell cycle arrest of cells, mainly in G1. <Capitalized> This correlated with the appearance of abnormal nuclear structures. <AllCaps> A genetic search for suppressors of the lethality associated with <EndsInDigit> CDC14 overexpression identified YJL076W. <Capitalized> Because overproduction of Yj1076w buffered the toxic effect of Cdc14 overproduction, this suggested that it might be a substrate of Cdc14. <Capitalized> This has indeed been found to be the case by others who recently described Yj1076w/Netl as a nucleolar protein that physically associates with Cdc14 (Shou et al, <Capitalized> Cell 97 (1999) 233). <Capitalized> The present data confirm several recently uncovered aspects of the regulation of Cdc14 localization and activity and suggest that the level of expression of <EndsInDigit> CDC14 influences the structural organization of the nucleolus.

 <AllCaps> A chimeric protein containing the <AllCaps> N terminus of the adeno-associated virus <PERSON  Rep> protein recognizes its target site in an in vivo assay.

 <Capitalized> The Rep78 and Rep68 proteins of adeno-associated virus (AAV) type 2 are involved in <AllCaps> DNA replication, regulation of gene expression, and targeting site-specific integration. <Capitalized> They bind to a specific <PERSON  Rep> recognition sequence (RRS) found in both the viral inverted terminal repeats and the <EndsInDigit> AAVS1 integration locus on human chromosome 19. <Capitalized> Previous in vitro studies implied that an N-terminal segment of <PERSON  Rep> is involved in <AllCaps> DNA recognition, while additional domains might stabilize binding and mediate multimerization. <Capitalized> In order to define the minimal requirements for <PERSON  Rep> to recognize its target site in the human genome, we developed one-hybrid assays in which DNA-protein interactions are detected in vivo. <Capitalized> Chimeric proteins consisting of the <AllCaps> N terminus of <PERSON  Rep> fused to different oligomerization motifs and a transcriptional activation domain were analyzed for oligomerization, <AllCaps> DNA binding, and activation of reporter gene expression. <Capitalized> Expression of reporter genes was driven from <AllCaps> RRS motifs cloned upstream of minimal promoters and examined in mammalian cells from transfected plasmids and in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae from a reporter cassette integrated into the yeast genome. <Capitalized> Our results show for the first time that chimeric proteins containing the amino-terminal 244 residues of <PERSON  Rep> are able to target the <AllCaps> RRS in vitro and in vivo when incorporated into artificial multimers. <Capitalized> These studies suggest that chimeric proteins may be used to harness the unique targeting feature of <AllCaps> AAV for gene therapy applications.

 <Capitalized> Two paralogs involved in transcriptional silencing that antagonistically control yeast life span. 
 
 <PERSON  Roy> <AllCaps> N, <PERSON  Runge> <AllCaps> KW. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Lerner> <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Institute, <LOCATION  Cleveland> <Capitalized> Clinic <Capitalized> Foundation, <LOCATION  Cleveland,> <AllCaps> OH 44195, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, one determinant of aging or life span is the accumulation of extrachromosomal copies of <MixedCase> rDNA circles in old mother cells [1]. <Capitalized> The production of <MixedCase> rDNA circles depends upon intrachromosomal recombination within the <MixedCase> rDNA tandem array, a process regulated by the protein Sir2 (Sir2p). <Capitalized> Together with Sir1p, Sir3p, Sir4p and Orc1p, Sir2p is also involved in transcriptional silencing of genes at the silent mating-type cassettes, in the <MixedCase> rDNA array, and at telomeres. <Capitalized> Using a 'triple silencer' strain that can monitor an increase or decrease in gene expression at these three loci, we found that deletion of the <EndsInDigit> ZDS1 gene caused an increase in silencing in the <MixedCase> rDNA and at a silent mating-type cassette at the expense of telomere silencing. <Capitalized> The zds1 deletion also resulted in an increase in life span and a decrease in Sir3p phosphorylation. <Capitalized> In contrast, deletion of its paralog <EndsInDigit> ZDS2 caused a decrease in <MixedCase> rDNA silencing, a decrease in life span and an increase in Sir3p phosphorylation. <Capitalized> As Zds2p, but not Zds1p, had strong two-hybrid interactions with Orc1p and the four <Capitalized> Sir proteins, Zds1p might indirectly control Sir3p through a Sir3p kinase.

 <Capitalized> The genome organization of the mite-transmitted wheat streak mosaic virus (WSMV) appears to parallel that of members of the <Capitalized> Potyviridae with monopartite genomes, but there are substantial amino acid dissimilarities with other potyviral polyproteins. <Capitalized> To initiate studies on the functions of WSMV-encoded proteins, a protein interaction map was generated using a yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> Because the pathway of proteolytic maturation of the <AllCaps> WSMV polyprotein has not been experimentally determined, random libraries of <AllCaps> WSMV <MixedCase> cDNA were made both in DNA-binding domain and activation domain plasmid vectors and introduced into yeast. <Capitalized> Sequence analysis of multiple interacting pairs revealed that interactions largely occurred between domains within two groups of proteins. <Capitalized> The first involved interactions among nuclear inclusion protein a, nuclear inclusion protein b, and coat protein (CP), and the second involved helper component-proteinase (HC-Pro) and cylindrical inclusion protein (CI). <PERSON  Further> immunoblot and deletion mapping analyses of the interactions suggest that subdomains of <AllCaps> CI, HC-Pro, and <EndsInDigit> P1 interact with one another. <Capitalized> The two-hybrid assay was then performed using full-length genes of <AllCaps> CI, HC-Pro, P1, P3, and <AllCaps> CP, but no heterologous interactions were detected. <Capitalized> In vitro binding assay using glutathione-S-transferase fusion proteins and in vitro translation products, however, revealed mutual interactions among <AllCaps> CI, HC-Pro, P1, and P3. <Capitalized> The failure to detect interactions between full-length proteins by the two-hybrid assay might be due to adverse effects of expression of viral proteins in yeast cells. <Capitalized> The capacity to participate in multiple homomeric and heteromeric molecular interactions is consistent with the pleiotropic nature of many potyviral gene mutants and suggests mechanisms for regulation of various viral processes via a network of viral protein complexes. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized>  <Capitalized> Coordinated spindle assembly and orientation requires Clb5p-dependent kinase in budding yeast. 
 
 <PERSON  Segal> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Clarke> <AllCaps> DJ, <PERSON  Maddox> <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Salmon> <AllCaps> ED, <PERSON  Bloom> <AllCaps> K, <PERSON  Reed> <AllCaps> SI.

 <Capitalized> The orientation of the mitotic spindle along a polarity axis is critical in asymmetric cell divisions. <Capitalized> In the budding yeast, <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, loss of the S-phase B-type cyclin Clb5p under conditions of limited cyclin-dependent kinase activity (cdc28-4 clb5Delta cells) causes a spindle positioning defect that results in an undivided nucleus entering the bud. <Capitalized> Based on time-lapse digital imaging microscopy of microtubules labeled with green fluorescent protein fusions to either tubulin or dynein, we observed that the asymmetric behavior of the spindle pole bodies during spindle assembly was lost in the cdc28-4 clb5Delta cells. <Capitalized> As soon as a spindle formed, both poles were equally likely to interact with the bud cell cortex. <Capitalized> Persistent dynamic interactions with the bud ultimately led to spindle translocation across the bud neck. <PERSON  Thus,> the mutant failed to assign one spindle pole body the task of organizing astral microtubules towards the mother cell. <Capitalized> Our data suggest that Clb5p-associated kinase is required to confer mother-bound behavior to one pole in order to establish correct spindle polarity. <Capitalized> In contrast, B-type cyclins, Clb3p and Clb4p, though partially redundant with Clb5p for an early role in spindle morphogenesis, preferentially promote spindle assembly.

Epitope-tagged Slg1p cofractionated with the plasma membrane, suggesting that <Capitalized> Slglp may function by integrating external cues and relaying them to the interior of the cell. <Capitalized> We propose that <EndsInDigit> SLG1 plays a regulatory role in bud emergence or stationary phase.

 <Capitalized> Domain <AllCaps> III of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae 25 <PERSON  S> <MixedCase> rRNA contains the recognition site for the primary rRNA-binding ribosomal protein L25, which belongs to the functionally conserved EL23/L25 family of ribosomal proteins. <Capitalized> The EL23/L25 binding region is very complex, consisting of several irregular helices held together by long-distance secondary and tertiary interactions. <Capitalized> Moreover, it contains the eukaryote-specific <EndsInDigit> V9 (D7a) expansion segment. <Capitalized> Functional characterisation of the structural elements of this site by a detailed in vitro and in vivo mutational analysis indicates the presence of two separate regions that are directly involved in <EndsInDigit> L25 binding. <Capitalized> In particular, mutation of either of two conserved nucleotides in the loop of helix 49 significantly reduces in vitro <EndsInDigit> L25 binding, thus strongly supporting their role as attachment sites for the r-protein. <Capitalized> Two other helices appear to be primarily required for the correct folding of the binding site. <Capitalized> Mutations that abolish in vitro binding of <EndsInDigit> L25 block accumulation of 25 <PERSON  S> <MixedCase> rRNA in vivo because they stall pre-rRNA processing at the level of its immediate precursor, the 27 S(B) pre-rRNA. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, several mutations that do not significantly affect <EndsInDigit> L25 binding in vitro cause the same lethal defect in 27 S(B) pre-rRNA processing. <Capitalized> Deletion of the <EndsInDigit> V9 expansion segment also leads to under-accumulation of mature 25 <PERSON  S> <MixedCase> rRNA and a twofold reduction in growth rate. <Capitalized> We conclude that an intact domain <AllCaps> III, including the <EndsInDigit> V9 expansion segment, is essential for normal processing and assembly of 25 <PERSON  S> rRNA. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <PERSON  Albert> <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Yenush <AllCaps> L, Gil-Mascarell <AllCaps> MR, <LOCATION  Rodriguez> <AllCaps> PL, <Capitalized> Patel <PERSON  S,> Martinez-Ripoll <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Blundell> <AllCaps> TL, <Capitalized> Serrano <PERSON  R.>

 <Capitalized> The product of the yeast <EndsInDigit> HAL2 gene (Hal2p) is an in vivo target of sodium and lithium toxicity and its overexpression improves salt tolerance in yeast and plants. Hal2p is a metabolic phosphatase which catalyses the hydrolysis of 3'-phosphoadenosine-5'-phosphate (PAP) to <AllCaps> AMP. <Capitalized> It is, the prototype of an evolutionarily conserved family of <AllCaps> PAP phosphatases and the engineering of sodium insensitive enzymes of this group may contribute to the generation of salt-tolerant crops. <Capitalized> We have solved the crystal structure of Hal2p in complex with magnesium, lithium and the two products of <AllCaps> PAP hydrolysis, <AllCaps> AMP and <Capitalized> Pi, at 1.6 <AllCaps> A resolution. <AllCaps> A functional screening of random mutations of the <EndsInDigit> HAL2 gene in growing yeast generated forms of the enzyme with reduced cation sensitivity. <Capitalized> Analysis of these mutants defined a salt bridge (Glu238 ellipsis Arg152) and a hydrophobic bond (Va170 ellipsis Trp293) as important framework interactions determining cation sensitivity. Hal2p belongs to a larger superfamily of lithium-sensitive phosphatases which includes inositol monophosphatase. <Capitalized> The hydrophobic interaction mutated in Hal2p is conserved in this superfamily and its disruption in human inositol monophosphatase also resulted in reduced cation sensitivity. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Toward a protein-protein interaction map of the budding yeast: <AllCaps> A comprehensive system to examine two-hybrid interactions in all possible combinations between the yeast proteins. 
 
 <Capitalized> Ito <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Tashiro <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Muta <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Ozawa <PERSON  R,> <LOCATION  Chiba> <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Nishizawa <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Yamamoto <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Kuhara <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Sakaki <PERSON  Y.> 
 
 <PERSON  Human> <Capitalized> Genome <PERSON  Center,> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Science, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Tokyo,> 4-6-1 <Capitalized> Shirokanedai, Minato-ku, <LOCATION  Tokyo> 108-8639, <LOCATION Japan> tito@ims.u-tokyo.ac.jp 
 
 Protein-protein interactions play pivotal roles in various aspects of the structural and functional organization of the cell, and their complete description is indispensable to thorough understanding of the cell. <Capitalized> As an approach toward this goal, here we report a comprehensive system to examine two-hybrid interactions in all of the possible combinations between proteins of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> We cloned all of the yeast ORFs individually as a DNA-binding domain fusion ("bait") in a MATa strain and as an activation domain fusion ("prey") in a MATalpha strain, and subsequently divided them into pools, each containing 96 clones. <Capitalized> These bait and prey clone pools were systematically mated with each other, and the transformants were subjected to strict selection for the activation of three reporter genes followed by sequence tagging. <Capitalized> Our initial examination of approximately 4 x 10(6) different combinations, constituting approximately 10% of the total to be tested, has revealed 183 independent two-hybrid interactions, more than half of which are entirely novel. <Capitalized> Notably, the obtained binary data allow us to extract more complex interaction networks, including the one that may explain a currently unsolved mechanism for the connection between distinct steps of vesicular transport. <Capitalized> The approach described here thus will provide many leads for integration of various cellular functions and serve as a major driving force in the completion of the protein-protein interaction map.

 557: <Capitalized> Genetics 2000 Feb;154(2):557-71

Temperature-sensitive alleles of <EndsInDigit> NAB3 are suppressed by deletion of CTK1, a kinase that has been shown to phosphorylate the <AllCaps> CTD and increase elongation efficiency in vitro. <Capitalized> This set of genetic and physical interactions suggests a role for yeast RNA-binding proteins in transcriptional regulation.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> Harvard <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Boston,> <LOCATION  Massachusetts> 02115, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Many eukaryotic RNA-binding proteins are modified by methylation of arginine residues. <Capitalized> The yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae contains one major arginine methyltransferase, Hmt1p/Rmt1p, which is not essential for normal cell growth. <Capitalized> However, cells missing <EndsInDigit> HMT1 and also bearing mutations in the mRNA-binding proteins Npl3p or Cbp80p can no longer survive, providing genetic backgrounds in which to study Hmt1p function. <Capitalized> We now demonstrate that the catalytically active form of Hmt1p is required for its activity in vivo. <Capitalized> Amino acid changes in the putative Hmt1p S-adenosyl-L-methionine-binding site were generated and shown to be unable to catalyze methylation of Npl3p in vitro and in vivo or to restore growth to strains that require HMT1. <Capitalized> In addition these mutations affect nucleocytoplasmic transport of Npl3p. <AllCaps> A cold-sensitive mutant of Hmt1p was generated and showed reduced methylation of Npl3p, but not of other substrates, at 14 degrees <AllCaps> C. <Capitalized> These results define new aspects of Hmt1 and reveal the importance of its activity in vivo.

 <PERSON  Huber> <AllCaps> PA, <PERSON  Medhurst> <AllCaps> AL, <Capitalized> Youssoufian <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Mathew> <AllCaps> CG.

 <Capitalized> Fanconi anemia is a chromosomal breakage disorder with eight complementation groups (A-H), and three genes (FANCA, <AllCaps> FANCC, and FANCG) have been identified. <Capitalized> Initial investigations of the interaction between <AllCaps> FANCA and <AllCaps> FANCC, principally by co-immunoprecipitation, have proved controversial. <Capitalized> We used the yeast two-hybrid assay to test for interactions of the <AllCaps> FANCA, <AllCaps> FANCC, and <AllCaps> FANCG proteins. <Capitalized> No activation of the reporter gene was observed in yeast co-expressing <AllCaps> FANCA and <AllCaps> FANCC as hybrid proteins, suggesting that <AllCaps> FANCA does not directly interact with <AllCaps> FANCC. <Capitalized> However, a high level of activation was found when <AllCaps> FANCA was co-expressed with <AllCaps> FANCG, indicating strong, direct interaction between these proteins. <PERSON  Both> <AllCaps> FANCA and <AllCaps> FANCG show weak but consistent interaction with themselves, suggesting that their function may involve dimerisation. <Capitalized> The site of interaction of <AllCaps> FANCG with <AllCaps> FANCA was investigated by analysis of 12 mutant fragments of <AllCaps> FANCG. <Capitalized> Although both N- and C-terminal fragments did interact, binding to <AllCaps> FANCA was drastically reduced, suggesting that more than one region of the <AllCaps> FANCG protein is required for proper interaction with <AllCaps> FANCA. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 560: <Capitalized> Eur <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biochem 2000 Feb;267(3):861-8 
 
 <Capitalized> The structural basis of substrate activation in yeast pyruvate decarboxylase. <AllCaps> A crystallographic and kinetic study. 
 
 <Capitalized> Lu <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Dobritzsch <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Baumann> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Schneider> <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Konig> <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Biophysics, <Capitalized> Karolinska <Capitalized> Institutet, <LOCATION  Stockholm,> <LOCATION Sweden> 
 
 <Capitalized> The crystal structure of the complex of the thiamine diphosphate dependent tetrameric enzyme pyruvate decarboxylase (PDC) from brewer's yeast strain with the activator pyruvamide has been determined to 2.4 <AllCaps> A resolution. <Capitalized> The asymmetric unit of the crystal contains two subunits, and the tetrameric molecule is generated by crystallographic symmetry. <Capitalized> Structure analysis revealed conformational nonequivalence of the active sites. <Capitalized> One of the two active sites in the asymmetric unit was found in an open conformation, with two active site loop regions (residues 104-113 and 290-304) disordered. <Capitalized> In the other subunit, these loop regions are well-ordered and shield the active site from the bulk solution. <Capitalized> In the closed enzyme subunit, one molecule of pyruvamide is bound in the active site channel, and is located in the vicinity of the thiazolium ring of the cofactor. <AllCaps> A second pyruvamide binding site was found at the interface between the <Capitalized> Pyr and the <PERSON  R> domains of the subunit in the closed conformation, about 10 <AllCaps> A away from residue C221. <Capitalized> This second pyruvamide molecule might function in stabilizing the unique orientation of the <PERSON  R> domain in this subunit which in turn is important for dimer-dimer interactions in the activated tetramer. <Capitalized> No difference electron density in the close vicinity of the side chain of residue <EndsInDigit> C221 was found, indicating that this residue does not form a covalent adduct with an activator molecule. <Capitalized> Kinetic experiments showed that substrate activation was not affected by oxidation of cysteine residues and therefore does not seem to be dependent on intact thiol groups in the enzyme. <Capitalized> The results suggest that a disorder-order transition of two active-site loop regions is a key event in the activation process triggered by the activator pyruvamide and that covalent modification of <EndsInDigit> C221 is not required for this transition to occur. <Capitalized> Based on these findings, a possible mechanism for the activation of <AllCaps> PDC by its substrate, pyruvate, is proposed.

 <Capitalized> Yeast meiosis-specific protein Hop1 binds to <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA and promotes its formation. 
 
 <Capitalized> Muniyappa <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Anuradha <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Byers> <AllCaps> B. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> Indian <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Science, <LOCATION  Bangalore> 560012, <LOCATION India> 
 
 <AllCaps> DNA molecules containing stretches of contiguous guanine residues can assume a stable configuration in which planar quartets of guanine residues joined by <Capitalized> Hoogsteen pairing appear in a stacked array. <Capitalized> This conformation, called <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA, has been implicated in several aspects of chromosome behavior including immunoglobulin gene rearrangements, promoter activation, and telomere maintenance. <Capitalized> Moreover, the ability of the yeast <EndsInDigit> SEP1 gene product to cleave <AllCaps> DNA in a G4-DNA-dependent fashion, as well as that of the <EndsInDigit> SGS1 gene product to unwind <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA, has suggested a crucial role for this structure in meiotic synapsis and recombination. <Capitalized> Here, we demonstrate that the <EndsInDigit> HOP1 gene product, which plays a crucial role in the formation of synaptonemal complex in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, binds robustly to <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> The apparent dissociation constant for interaction with <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA is 2 x 10(-10), indicative of binding that is about 1,000-fold stronger than to normal duplex <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Oligonucleotides of appropriate sequence bound Hop1 protein maximally if the <AllCaps> DNA was first subjected to conditions favoring the formation of <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Furthermore, incubation of unfolded oligonucleotides with Hop1 led to their transformation into <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Methylation interference experiments confirmed that modifications blocking <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA formation inhibit Hop1 binding. <Capitalized> In contrast, neither bacterial RecA proteins that preferentially interact with GT-rich <AllCaps> DNA nor histone <EndsInDigit> H1 bound strongly to <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA or induced its formation. <Capitalized> These findings implicate specific interactions of Hop1 protein with <EndsInDigit> G4 <AllCaps> DNA in the pathway to chromosomal synapsis and recombination in meiosis.

 <Capitalized> Regulatory interactions between the Reg1-Glc7 protein phosphatase and the Snf1 protein kinase. 
 
 <Capitalized> Sanz <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Alms <AllCaps> GR, <Capitalized> Haystead <AllCaps> TA, <PERSON  Carlson> <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Departments of <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Development and <Capitalized> Microbiology, <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10032, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Protein phosphatase 1, comprising the regulatory subunit Reg1 and the catalytic subunit Glc7, has a role in glucose repression in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Previous studies showed that Reg1 regulates the Snf1 protein kinase in response to glucose. <Capitalized> Here, we explore the functional relationships between Reg1, Glc7, and Snf1. <Capitalized> We show that different sequences of Reg1 interact with Glc7 and Snf1. <Capitalized> We use a mutant Reg1 altered in the Glc7-binding motif to demonstrate that Reg1 facilitates the return of the activated Snf1 kinase complex to the autoinhibited state by targeting Glc7 to the complex. <Capitalized> Genetic evidence indicated that the catalytic activity of Snf1 negatively regulates its interaction with Reg1. <Capitalized> We show that Reg1 is phosphorylated in response to glucose limitation and that this phosphorylation requires Snf1; moreover, Reg1 is dephosphorylated by Glc7 when glucose is added. <Capitalized> Finally, we show that hexokinase <AllCaps> PII (Hxk2) has a role in regulating the phosphorylation state of Reg1, which may account for the effect of Hxk2 on Snf1 function. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that the phosphorylation of Reg1 by Snf1 is required for the release of Reg1-Glc7 from the kinase complex and also stimulates the activity of Glc7 in promoting closure of the complex.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, Queen's <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Kingston,> <LOCATION  Ontario,> K7L 3N6, <PERSON Canada> 
 
 <Capitalized> Type <AllCaps> I myosins are highly conserved actin-based molecular motors that localize to the actin-rich cortex and participate in motility functions such as 
 
 endocytosis, polarized morphogenesis, and cell migration. <Capitalized> The COOH-terminal tail of yeast myosin-I proteins, Myo3p and Myo5p, contains an <Capitalized> Src homology domain 3 (SH3) followed by an acidic domain. <Capitalized> The myosin-I <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain interacted with both Bee1p and Vrp1p, yeast homologues of human <AllCaps> WASP and <AllCaps> WIP, adapter proteins that link actin assembly and signaling molecules. <Capitalized> The myosin-I acidic domain interacted with Arp2/3 complex subunits, Arc40p and Arc19p, and showed both sequence similarity and genetic redundancy with the COOH-terminal acidic domain of Bee1p (Las17p), which controls Arp2/3-mediated actin nucleation. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that myosin-I proteins may participate in a diverse set of motility functions through a role in actin assembly.

 BACKGROUND: <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> HRDC (helicase and RNaseD C-terminal) domain is found at the <AllCaps> C terminus of many RecQ helicases, including the human <PERSON  Werner> and <PERSON  Bloom> syndrome proteins. RecQ helicases have been shown to unwind <AllCaps> DNA in an ATP-dependent manner. <Capitalized> However, the specific functional roles of these proteins in <AllCaps> DNA recombination and replication are not known. <Capitalized> An <AllCaps> HRDC domain exists in both of the human RecQ homologues that are implicated in human disease and may have an important role in their function. RESULTS: <Capitalized> We have determined the three-dimensional structure of the <AllCaps> HRDC domain in the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae RecQ helicase Sgs1p by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. <Capitalized> The structure resembles auxiliary domains in bacterial <AllCaps> DNA helicases and other proteins that interact with nucleic acids. <Capitalized> We show that a positively charged region on the surface of the Sgs1p <AllCaps> HRDC domain can interact with <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Structural similarities to bacterial <AllCaps> DNA helicases suggest that the <AllCaps> HRDC domain functions as an auxiliary domain in RecQ helicases. <Capitalized> Homology models of the <PERSON  Werner> and <PERSON  Bloom> <AllCaps> HRDC domains show different surface properties when compared with Sgs1p. CONCLUSIONS: <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> HRDC domain represents a structural scaffold that resembles auxiliary domains in proteins that are involved in nucleic acid metabolism. <Capitalized> In Sgs1p, the <AllCaps> HRDC domain could modulate the helicase function via auxiliary contacts to <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> However, in the <PERSON  Werner> and <PERSON  Bloom> syndrome helicases the <AllCaps> HRDC domain may have a role in their functional differences by mediating diverse molecular interactions.

 <Capitalized> Kinetic analysis of a molecular model of the budding yeast cell cycle. 
 
 <Capitalized> Chen <AllCaps> KC, Csikasz-Nagy <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Gyorffy <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Val> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Novak> <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Tyson> <AllCaps> JJ.

 <Capitalized> The molecular machinery of cell cycle control is known in more detail for budding yeast, <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, than for any other eukaryotic organism. <Capitalized> In recent years, many elegant experiments on budding yeast have dissected the roles of cyclin molecules (Cln1-3 and Clb1-6) in coordinating the events of <AllCaps> DNA synthesis, bud emergence, spindle formation, nuclear division, and cell separation. <Capitalized> These experimental clues suggest a mechanism for the principal molecular interactions controlling cyclin synthesis and degradation. <Capitalized> Using standard techniques of biochemical kinetics, we convert the mechanism into a set of differential equations, which describe the time courses of three major classes of cyclin-dependent kinase activities. <Capitalized> Model in hand, we examine the molecular events controlling "Start" (the commitment step to a new round of chromosome replication, bud formation, and mitosis) and "Finish" (the transition from metaphase to anaphase, when sister chromatids are pulled apart and the bud separates from the mother cell) in wild-type cells and 50 mutants. <Capitalized> The model accounts for many details of the physiology, biochemistry, and genetics of cell cycle control in budding yeast.
