 <PERSON  Hopkinson> <AllCaps> SB, <PERSON  Jones> <AllCaps> JC. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Northwestern <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Chicago,> <LOCATION  Illinois> 60611, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In epidermal cells, the keratin cytoskeleton interacts with the elements in the basement membrane via a multimolecular junction called the hemidesmosome. <AllCaps> A major component of the hemidesmosome plaque is the 230-kDa bullous pemphigoid autoantigen (BP230/BPAG1), which connects directly to the keratin-containing intermediate filaments of the cytoskeleton via its <AllCaps> C terminus. <AllCaps> A second bullous pemphigoid antigen of 180 <MixedCase> kDa (BP180/BPAG2) is a type <AllCaps> II transmembrane component of the hemidesmosome. <Capitalized> Using yeast two-hybrid technology and recombinant proteins, we show that an N-terminal fragment of <EndsInDigit> BP230 can bind directly to an N-terminal fragment of BP180. <Capitalized> We have also explored the consequences of expression of the <EndsInDigit> BP230 <AllCaps> N terminus in 804G cells that assemble hemidesmosomes in vitro. <Capitalized> Unexpectedly, this fragment disrupts the distribution of <EndsInDigit> BP180 in transfected cells but has no apparent impact on the organization of endogenous <EndsInDigit> BP230 and alpha6beta4 integrin. <Capitalized> We propose that the <EndsInDigit> BP230 <AllCaps> N terminus competes with endogenous <EndsInDigit> BP230 protein for <EndsInDigit> BP180 binding and inhibits incorporation of <EndsInDigit> BP180 into the cell surface at the site of the hemidesmosome. <Capitalized> These data provide new insight into those interactions of the molecules of the hemidesmosome that are necessary for its function in integrating epithelial and connective tissue types.

 572: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 2000 <PERSON  Jan> 21;275(3):2191-8 
 
 Lipid-dependent targeting of <AllCaps> G proteins into rafts. 
 
 <PERSON  Moffett> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Brown> <AllCaps> DA, <PERSON  Linder> <AllCaps> ME. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Physiology, <LOCATION  Washington> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, St. <PERSON  Louis,> <LOCATION  Missouri> 63110, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Domains rich in sphingolipids and cholesterol, or rafts, may organize signal transduction complexes at the plasma membrane. <Capitalized> Raft lipids are believed to exist in a state similar to the liquid-ordered phase. <Capitalized> It has been proposed that proteins with a high affinity for an ordered lipid environment will preferentially partition into rafts (Melkonian, <AllCaps> K. A., <PERSON  Ostermeyer,> <AllCaps> A. G., <Capitalized> Chen, <AllCaps> J. Z., <PERSON  Roth,> <AllCaps> M. G., and <PERSON  Brown,> <AllCaps> D. <AllCaps> A. (1999) <AllCaps> J. Biol. Chem. 274, 3910-3917). <Capitalized> We investigated the possibility that lipid-lipid interactions between lipid-modified proteins and raft lipids mediate targeting of proteins to these domains. <AllCaps> G protein monomers or trimers were reconstituted in liposomes, engineered to mimic raft domains. <Capitalized> Assay for partitioning of <AllCaps> G proteins into rafts was based on <Capitalized> Triton X-100 insolubility. <Capitalized> Myristoylation and palmitoylation of Galpha(i) were necessary and sufficient for association with liposomes and partitioning into rafts. <Capitalized> Strikingly, the amount of fatty-acylated Galpha(i) in rafts was significantly reduced when myristoylated Galpha(i) was thioacylated with cis-unsaturated fatty acids instead of saturated fatty acids such as palmitate. <Capitalized> Prenylated betagamma subunits were excluded from rafts, whether reconstituted alone or with fatty-acylated alpha subunits. <Capitalized> These results suggest that the structural difference between lipids that modify proteins is one basis for the selectivity of protein targeting to rafts.

 <Capitalized> Protein <EndsInDigit> P0 interacts with proteins P1alpha, P1beta, P2alpha, and P2beta, and forms the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae ribosomal stalk. <Capitalized> The capacity of <EndsInDigit> RPP0 genes from <Capitalized> Aspergillus fumigatus, <Capitalized> Dictyostelium discoideum, <Capitalized> Rattus norvegicus, <Capitalized> Homo sapiens, and <Capitalized> Leishmania infantum to complement the absence of the homologous gene has been tested. <Capitalized> In <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae W303dGP0, a strain containing standard amounts of the four P1/P2 protein types, all heterologous genes were functional except the one from <AllCaps> L. infantum, some of them inducing an osmosensitive phenotype at 37 degrees <AllCaps> C. <Capitalized> The polymerizing activity and the elongation factor-dependent functions but not the peptide bond formation capacity is affected in the heterologous <EndsInDigit> P0 containing ribosomes. <Capitalized> The heterologous <EndsInDigit> P0 proteins bind to the yeast ribosomes but the composition of the ribosomal stalk is altered. <Capitalized> Only proteins P1alpha and P2beta are found in ribosomes carrying the <AllCaps> A. fumigatus, <PERSON  R.> norvegicus, and <AllCaps> H. sapiens proteins. <Capitalized> When the heterologous genes are expressed in a conditional null-P0 mutant whose ribosomes are totally deprived of P1/P2 proteins, none of the heterologous <EndsInDigit> P0 proteins complemented the conditional phenotype. <Capitalized> In contrast, chimeric <EndsInDigit> P0 proteins made of different amino-terminal fragments from mammalian origin and the complementary carboxyl-terminal fragments from yeast allow W303dGP0 and D67dGP0 growth at restrictive conditions. <Capitalized> These results indicate that while the <EndsInDigit> P0 protein RNA-binding domain is functionally conserved in eukaryotes, the regions involved in protein-protein interactions with either the other stalk proteins or the elongation factors have notably evolved.

 <Capitalized> Recruitment of the yeast MADS-box proteins, ArgRI and Mcm1 by the pleiotropic factor ArgRIII is required for their stability. 
 
 <Capitalized> El <Capitalized> Bakkoury <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Dubois> <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Messenguy <AllCaps> F. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut de <Capitalized> Recherches <Capitalized> Microbiologiques J-M. <Capitalized> Wiame, and <Capitalized> Laboratoire de <Capitalized> Microbiologie de l'Universit inverted question marke <Capitalized> Libre de <Capitalized> Bruxelles, <Capitalized> Avenue <AllCaps> E. <Capitalized> Gryzon, 1, B-1070 <LOCATION  Brussels,> <LOCATION Belgium> 
 
 <Capitalized> Regulation of arginine metabolism requires the integrity of four regulatory proteins, ArgRI, ArgRII, ArgRIII and Mcm1. <Capitalized> To characterize further the interactions between the different proteins, we used the two-hybrid system, which showed that ArgRI and Mcm1 interact together, and with ArgRII and ArgRIII, without an arginine requirement. <Capitalized> To define the interacting domains of ArgRI and Mcm1 with ArgRIII, we fused portions of ArgRI and Mcm1 to the DNA-binding domain of Gal4 (GBD) and created mutations in GBD-ArgRI and GBD-Mcm1. <Capitalized> The putative alpha helix present in the MADS-box domain of ArgRI and Mcm1 is their major region of interaction with ArgRIII. <Capitalized> Interactions between the two MADS-box proteins and ArgRIII were confirmed using affinity chromatography. <Capitalized> The requirement for ArgRIII in the control of arginine metabolism can be bypassed in vitro as well as in vivo by overproducing ArgRI or Mcm1, which indicates that ArgRIII is not present in the protein complex formed with the 'arginine boxes'. <Capitalized> We show that the impairment of arginine regulation in an <MixedCase> argRIII deletant strain is a result of a lack of stability of ArgRI and Mcm1. <AllCaps> A mutation in ArgRI, impairing its interaction with ArgRIII, leads to an unstable ArgRI protein in a wild-type strain. ArgRIII integrity is crucial for Mcm1 function, as shown by the marked decreased expression of five genes controlled by Mcm1. <Capitalized> However, ArgRIII is likely to recruit other proteins in the yeast cell, as overexpression of Mcm1 does not compensate some physiological defects observed in an <MixedCase> argRIII deletant strain.

 <AllCaps> YPD, PombePD and WormPD: model organism volumes of the BioKnowledge library, an integrated resource for protein information. 
 
 <Capitalized> Costanzo <AllCaps> MC, <PERSON  Crawford> <AllCaps> ME, <PERSON  Hirschman> <AllCaps> JE, <PERSON  Kranz> <AllCaps> JE, <PERSON  Olsen> <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Robertson> <AllCaps> LS, <Capitalized> Skrzypek <AllCaps> MS, <PERSON  Braun> <AllCaps> BR, <PERSON  Hopkins> <AllCaps> KL, <Capitalized> Kondu <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Lengieza <AllCaps> C, Lew-Smith <AllCaps> JE, <Capitalized> Tillberg <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Garrels <AllCaps> JI. 
 
 <Capitalized> Proteome, Inc., 100 <PERSON  Cummings> <PERSON  Center,> <PERSON  Suite> 435M, <PERSON  Beverly,> <AllCaps> MA 01915, <LOCATION  USA.> mcc@proteome.com 
 
 <Capitalized> The BioKnowledge <Capitalized> Library is a relational database and web site (http://www.proteome.com) composed of protein-specific information collected from the scientific literature. <Capitalized> Each <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Report on the web site summarizes and displays published information about a single protein, including its biochemical function, role in the cell and in the whole organism, localization, mutant phenotype and genetic interactions, regulation, domains and motifs, interactions with other proteins and other relevant data. <Capitalized> This report describes four species-specific volumes of the BioKnowledge <Capitalized> Library, concerned with the model organisms <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae (YPD), <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe (PombePD) and <Capitalized> Caenorhabditis elegans (WormPD), and with the fungal pathogen <Capitalized> Candida albicans (CalPD). <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Reports of each species are unified in format, easily searchable and extensively cross-referenced between species. <Capitalized> The relevance of these comprehensively curated resources to analysis of proteins in other species is discussed, and is illustrated by a survey of model organism proteins that have similarity to human proteins involved in disease.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  Los Angeles,> <LOCATION  California> 90095, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Clathrin is involved in selective protein transport at the <Capitalized> Golgi apparatus and the plasma membrane. <Capitalized> To further understand the molecular mechanisms underlying clathrin-mediated protein transport pathways, we initiated a genetic screen for mutations that display synthetic growth defects when combined with a temperature-sensitive allele of the clathrin heavy chain gene (chc1-521) in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Mutations, when present in cells with wild-type clathrin, were analyzed for effects on mating pheromone alpha-factor precursor maturation and sorting of the vacuolar protein carboxypeptidase <PERSON  Y> as measures of protein sorting at the yeast trans-Golgi network (TGN) compartment. <Capitalized> By these criteria, two classes of mutants were obtained, those with and those without defects in protein sorting at the <AllCaps> TGN. <Capitalized> One mutant with unaltered protein sorting at the <AllCaps> TGN contains a mutation in PTC1, a type 2c serine/threonine phosphatase with widespread influences. <Capitalized> The collection of mutants displaying <AllCaps> TGN sorting defects includes members with mutations in previously identified vacuolar protein sorting genes (VPS), including the dynamin family member VPS1. <Capitalized> Striking genetic interactions were observed by combining temperature-sensitive alleles of <EndsInDigit> CHC1 and VPS1, supporting the model that Vps1p is involved in clathrin-mediated vesicle formation at the <AllCaps> TGN. <Capitalized> Also in the spectrum of mutants with <AllCaps> TGN sorting defects are isolates with mutations in the following: RIC1, encoding a product originally proposed to participate in ribosome biogenesis; LUV1, encoding a product potentially involved in vacuole and microtubule organization; and INP53, encoding a synaptojanin-like inositol polyphosphate 5-phosphatase. <Capitalized> Disruption of INP53, but not the related <EndsInDigit> INP51 and <EndsInDigit> INP52 genes, resulted in alpha-factor maturation defects and exacerbated alpha-factor maturation defects when combined with chc1-521. <Capitalized> Our findings implicate a wide variety of proteins in clathrin-dependent processes and provide evidence for the selective involvement of Inp53p in clathrin-mediated protein sorting at the <AllCaps> TGN.

 Ben-Yehuda <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Russell> <AllCaps> CS, <PERSON  Dix> <AllCaps> I, <PERSON  Beggs> <AllCaps> JD, <Capitalized> Kupiec <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <LOCATION  Tel Aviv> <Capitalized> University, <Capitalized> Ramat <Capitalized> Aviv 69978, <PERSON Israel>

 <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid assay was used to study the dimerization of engineered and naturally occurring variants of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) protease (PR) monomers. <Capitalized> Defective monomers that were previously shown to exhibit a dominant-negative (D-N) effect in cultured mammalian cells were tested for their ability to interact in the two-hybrid assay. <Capitalized> Similarly, monomers with dimer-interface substitutions and monomers harboring in vivo selected mutations that confer multidrug resistance (mdr) in an <AllCaps> AIDS patient were tested for interaction in yeast. <Capitalized> Dimer formation between wt monomers with catalytic aspartates was not detected in yeast, whereas the dimerization of <AllCaps> PR monomers harboring the acid active site substitution D25N was readily demonstrated. <Capitalized> The use of inactive monomers harboring the D25N substitution as a genetic background for studying additional <AllCaps> HIV <AllCaps> PR mutations allowed for the probing of interactions between monomers with mdr-associated mutations with those based on the HIV-1 HXB2R sequence. <Capitalized> The HTLVIII/HIV-1 HXB2R clone has been the basis for a large number of HIV-related plasmids, primers, antibodies, and other specific reagents throughout the <AllCaps> HIV research community. <Capitalized> The results of our assay suggest that HXB2R-based <ContainsHyphen> D-N <AllCaps> PR inhibitors associate with variant monomers based on the recently obtained nucleotide sequence from an <AllCaps> AIDS patient with a multidrug-resistant virus. <Capitalized> These results further encourage the use of <ContainsHyphen> D-N <AllCaps> PR inhibitors as antiviral agents which may complement existing small-molecule combination therapies. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <PERSON  Hardy> <AllCaps> JA, <PERSON  Walsh> <AllCaps> ST, <PERSON  Nelson> <AllCaps> HC. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  Berkeley,> <AllCaps> CA, 94720-3206, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The heat shock transcription factor (HSF) is the master transcriptional regulator of the heat shock response. <Capitalized> The identity of a majority of the genes controlled by <AllCaps> HSF and the circumstances under which <AllCaps> HSF becomes induced are known, but the details of the mechanism by which <AllCaps> HSF is able to sense and respond to heat remains an enigma. <Capitalized> For example, it is unclear whether <AllCaps> HSF senses the heat shock directly or requires ancillary interactions from a heat-induced signaling pathway. <Capitalized> We present the analysis of a series of mutations in an alpha-helical bulge in the DNA-binding domain of <AllCaps> HSF. <Capitalized> Deletion of residues in this bulged region increases the overall activity of the protein. <Capitalized> Yeast containing the deletion mutant <AllCaps> HSF are able to survive growth temperatures that are lethal to yeast containing wild-type <AllCaps> HSF, and they are also constitutively thermotolerant. <Capitalized> The increase in activity can be measured as an increase in both constitutive and induced transcriptional activity. <Capitalized> The mutant proteins bind <AllCaps> DNA more tightly than the wild-type protein does, but this is unlikely to account fully for the increase in transcriptional activity as yeast <AllCaps> HSF is constitutively bound to its binding site in vivo. <Capitalized> The stability of the mutant proteins to thermal denaturation is lower than wild-type, though their native-state structures are still well-folded. <Capitalized> Therefore, the mutants may be structurally analogous to the heat-induced state of <AllCaps> HSF, and suggest that the DNA-binding domain of <AllCaps> HSF may be capable of sensing heat shock directly. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 580: <Capitalized> Biotechnol <Capitalized> Bioeng 2000 <Capitalized> Feb 5;67(3):300-11 
 
 <Capitalized> Performance modeling and simulation of biochemical process sequences with interacting unit operations. 
 
 <Capitalized> Groep <AllCaps> ME, <PERSON  Gregory> <AllCaps> ME, <Capitalized> Kershenbaum <AllCaps> LS, <PERSON  Bogle> <AllCaps> ID. 
 
 <Capitalized> Centre for <Capitalized> Process <Capitalized> Systems <Capitalized> Engineering, <Capitalized> Imperial <Capitalized> College, <LOCATION  London> <EndsInDigit> SW7 2BY. 
 
 <Capitalized> Many biochemical processes consist of a sequence of operations for which optimal operating conditions (setpoints) have to be determined. <Capitalized> If such optimization is performed for each operation separately with respect to objectives defined for each operation individually, overall process performance is likely to be suboptimal. <Capitalized> Interactions between unit operations have to be considered, and a unique objective has to be defined for the whole process. <Capitalized> This paper shows how a suitable optimization problem can be formulated and solved to obtain the best overall set of operating conditions for a process. <AllCaps> A typical enzyme production process has been chosen as an example. <Capitalized> In order to arrive at a demonstrative model for the entire sequence of unit operations, it is shown how interaction effects may be accommodated in the models. <Capitalized> Optimal operating conditions are then determined subject to a global process objective and are shown to be different from those resulting from optimization of each separate operation. <Capitalized> As this strategy may result in an economic benefit, it merits further research into interaction modeling and performance optimization. <Capitalized> Copyright 2000 <PERSON  John> <PERSON  Wiley> & <Capitalized> Sons, Inc.

 <Capitalized> The synthesis of a series of 5-thio-D-glucopyranosylarylamines by reaction of 5-thio-D-glucopyranose pentaacetate with the corresponding arylamine and mercuric chloride catalyst is reported. <Capitalized> The products were obtained as anomeric mixtures of the tetraacetates which can be separated and crystallized. <Capitalized> The tetraacetates were deprotected to give alpha/beta mixtures of the parent compounds which were evaluated as inhibitors of the hydrolysis of maltose by glucoamylase <EndsInDigit> G2 (GA). <AllCaps> A transferred <AllCaps> NOE <AllCaps> NMR experiment with an alpha/beta mixture of 7 in the presence of <AllCaps> GA showed that only the alpha isomer is bound by the enzyme. <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Ki values, calculated on the basis of specific binding of the alpha isomers, are 0.47 <MixedCase> mM for p-methoxy-N-phenyl-5-thio-D-glucopyranosylamine (7), 0.78 <MixedCase> mM for N-phenyl-5-thio-D-glucopyranosylamine (8), 0.27 <MixedCase> mM for p-nitro-N-phenyl-5-thio-D-glucopyranosylamine (9) and 0.87 <MixedCase> mM for p-trifluoromethyl-N-phenyl-5-thio-D-glucopyranosylamine (10), and the K(m) values for the substrates maltose and p-nitrophenyl alpha-D-glucopyranoside are 1.2 and 3.7 mM, respectively. <Capitalized> Methyl 4-amino-4-deoxy-4-N-(5'-thio-alpha-D-glucopyranosyl)-alpha-D-glucopyrano side (11) is a competitive inhibitor of <AllCaps> GA wild-type (Ki 4 microM) and the active site mutant Trp120-->Phe <AllCaps> GA (Ki 0.12 mM). <Capitalized> Compounds 7, 8, and 11 are also competitive inhibitors of alpha-glucosidase from brewer's yeast, with <Capitalized> Ki values of 1.05 mM, > 10 mM, and 0.5 mM, respectively. <Capitalized> Molecular modeling of the inhibitors in the catalytic site of <AllCaps> GA was used to probe the ligand-enzyme complementary interactions and to offer insight into the differences in inhibitory potencies of the ligands.

 Max-Planck-Institute for <Capitalized> Biochemistry, 82152 <Capitalized> Martinsried, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Here, we describe the isolation of adenine nucleotide translocase-1 (ANT-1) in a screen for dominant, apoptosis-inducing genes. ANT-1 is a component of the mitochondrial permeability transition complex, a protein aggregate connecting the inner with the outer mitochondrial membrane that has recently been implicated in apoptosis. ANT-1 expression led to all features of apoptosis, such as phenotypic alterations, collapse of the mitochondrial membrane potential, cytochrome c release, caspase activation, and <AllCaps> DNA degradation. <PERSON  Both> point mutations that impair ANT-1 in its known activity to transport <AllCaps> ADP and <AllCaps> ATP as well as the NH(2)-terminal half of the protein could still induce apoptosis. <Capitalized> Interestingly, ANT-2, a highly homologous protein could not lead to cell death, demonstrating the specificity of the signal for apoptosis induction. <Capitalized> In contrast to <PERSON  Bax,> a proapoptotic Bcl-2 gene, ANT-1 was unable to elicit a form of cell death in yeast. <Capitalized> This and the observed repression of apoptosis by the ANT-1-interacting protein cyclophilin <AllCaps> D suggest that the suicidal effect of ANT-1 is mediated by specific protein-protein interactions within the permeability transition pore.

 <Capitalized> Organelle transport has been proposed to proceed in two steps: long-range transport along microtubules and local delivery via actin filaments. <Capitalized> This model is supported by recent studies of pigment transport in several cell types and transport in neurons, and in several cases, class <PERSON  V> myosin has been implicated as the actin-based motor. <Capitalized> Mutations in mice (dilute) and yeast (myo2) have also implicated this class of myosin in organelle transport, and genetic interactions in yeast have indicated that a kinesin-related protein (Smy1p) plays a supporting role. <Capitalized> This link between members of two different motor superfamilies has now taken a surprising turn: <Capitalized> There is evidence for a physical interaction between class <PERSON  V> myosins and kinesin or Smy1p in both mice and yeast.

 <Capitalized> Display of <PERSON  Ras> on filamentous phage through cysteine replacement. 
 
 <Capitalized> Wind <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Kjaer <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Clark> <AllCaps> BF. 
 
 <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Aarhus, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Structural <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION Denmark> 
 
 <Capitalized> Phage display technology has been used in a variety of contexts to understand and manipulate biomolecular interactions between proteins and other biomolecules. <Capitalized> In this paper we describe the establishment of a phage display system for elucidation of the interactions between the GTPase <PERSON  Ras> and its panel of effectors. <Capitalized> It is shown how technical problems associated with phage display of a protein with unpaired cysteines, likely to be caused by the oxidizing environment of the bacterial periplasm into which the protein is directed, can be overcome by cysteine replacement based on functional and structural studies. <Capitalized> First, the catalytic domain (residues 1-166) of mammalian H-Ras (Ras) was observed to be displayed on phage in an incorrect conformation not detectable by antibodies recognizing conformational epitopes on <PERSON Ras> <Capitalized> Although truncation of the phage coat protein used as fusion partner (g3p) resulted in minor improvements in the display, <PERSON  Ras> was tailored for phage display by cysteine replacement. <Capitalized> By replacing the three cysteines at positions 51, 80 and 118 of <PERSON  Ras> with the corresponding residues in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae RAS1, the resulting fusion-phage is recognized by the conformation-dependent anti-Ras antibodies. <Capitalized> Furthermore, display of cysteine-free <PERSON  Ras> is demonstrated by GTP-analogue dependent binding to the Ras-binding domain of the Ras-effector Raf1. <Capitalized> These data pave the way for analysis of Ras-effector interactions using phage display technology yet demonstrate that phage display of proteins with normally reduced cysteines should be approached with caution.

 <Capitalized> The two-hybrid system has proved to be a facile method for detecting and analyzing protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> An expanded application of this system, protein linkage mapping, provides a means of identifying interactions on a global scale and should prove a powerful tool in analyzing whole genomes as their sequences become available. <Capitalized> To overcome some of the inherent difficulties in such a large-scale approach, we have constructed a set of new strains and vectors that will allow for more efficient screening. <Capitalized> The strains contain a GAL1-URA3 reporter for positive and negative selection, as well as a UAS(G)-lacZ reporter. <Capitalized> The strains are of opposite mating types, permitting libraries present in one strain to be easily screened against a second library in the companion strain. <Capitalized> We also constructed a family of CEN-based vectors for expression of both Gal4 DNA-binding and activation domain fusions. <Capitalized> These plasmids include a hemagglutinin epitope tag and different polylinkers to increase the ease of subcloning. CEN-based vectors are maintained at 1-2 copies per cell, limiting the number of individual cells containing multiple plasmids that can confuse further analyses, and ensuring that fusions are not expressed at toxic levels. <Capitalized> Using these vectors, both homo- and heterodimeric interactions resulted in up to 10-fold higher reporter gene transcription than obtained with 2micro;-based plasmids, despite significantly lower protein levels. <Capitalized> In addition to protein linkage mapping, these reagents should be generally useful in standard two-hybrid applications. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <PERSON  John> <PERSON  Wiley> & <Capitalized> Sons, Ltd.

 <Capitalized> Laboratoire de <Capitalized> Biologie <Capitalized> Moleculaire et de <Capitalized> Sequencage, <AllCaps> UPR <AllCaps> CNRS 9026, <COMPANY  BP> 64, 146 rue <PERSON  Leo> <Capitalized> Saignat, 33076 <LOCATION  Bordeaux> cedex, <PERSON France> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> RGD1 gene was identified during systematic genome sequencing of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> To further understand Rgd1p function, we set up a synthetic lethal screen for genes interacting with RGD1. <Capitalized> Study of one lethal mutant made it possible to identify the <EndsInDigit> SLG1 and <EndsInDigit> MID2 genes. <Capitalized> The gene SLG1/HCS77/WSC1 was mutated in the original synthetic lethal strain, whereas MID2/SMS1 acted as a monocopy suppressor. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> SLG1 gene has been described to be an upstream component in the yeast <AllCaps> PKC pathway and encodes a putative cell surface sensor for the activation of cell integrity signalling. <Capitalized> First identified by viability loss of shmoos after pheromone exposure, and since found in different genetic screens, <EndsInDigit> MID2 was recently reported as also encoding an upstream activator of the <AllCaps> PKC pathway. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> RGD1 gene showed genetic interactions with both sensors of cell integrity pathway. <Capitalized> The rgd1 slg1 synthetic lethality was rescued by osmotic stabilization, as expected for mutants altered in cell wall integrity. <Capitalized> The slight viability defect of rgd1 in minimal medium, which was exacerbated by mid2, was not osmoremediated. <Capitalized> As for mutants altered in <AllCaps> PKC pathway, the accumulation of small-budded dead cells in slg1, rgd1 and mid2 after heat shock was prevented by 1 <AllCaps> M sorbitol. <Capitalized> In addition, the rgd1 strain also displayed dead shmoos after pheromone treatment, like mid2. <Capitalized> Taken together, the present results indicate close functional links between RGD1, <EndsInDigit> MID2 and <EndsInDigit> SLG1 and suggest that <EndsInDigit> RGD1 and <EndsInDigit> MID2 interact in a cell integrity signalling functionally linked to the <AllCaps> PKC pathway. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999  <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Rho GTPase Rho3 has a direct role in exocytosis that is distinct from its role in actin polarity. 
 
 <Capitalized> Adamo <AllCaps> JE, <PERSON  Rossi> <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Brennwald <PERSON  P.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, and <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> Weill <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> College of <PERSON  Cornell> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10021, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Budding yeast grow asymmetrically by the polarized delivery of proteins and lipids to specific sites on the plasma membrane. <Capitalized> This requires the coordinated polarization of the actin cytoskeleton and the secretory apparatus. <Capitalized> We identified Rho3 on the basis of its genetic interactions with several late-acting secretory genes. <Capitalized> Mutational analysis of the Rho3 effector domain reveals three distinct functions in cell polarity: regulation of actin polarity, transport of exocytic vesicles from the mother cell to the bud, and docking and fusion of vesicles with the plasma membrane. <Capitalized> We provide evidence that the vesicle delivery function of Rho3 is mediated by the unconventional myosin Myo2 and that the docking and fusion function is mediated by the exocyst component Exo70. <Capitalized> These data suggest that Rho3 acts as a key regulator of cell polarity and exocytosis, coordinating several distinct events for delivery of proteins to specific sites on the cell surface.

 598: <Capitalized> Biochem <AllCaps> J 1999 <Capitalized> Dec 15;344 <Capitalized> Pt 3:633-42 
 
 <Capitalized> Polyamine transport in bacteria and yeast. 
 
 <Capitalized> Igarashi <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Kashiwagi <AllCaps> K. 
 
 <Capitalized> Faculty of <Capitalized> Pharmaceutical <Capitalized> Sciences, <LOCATION  Chiba> <Capitalized> University, 1-33 Yayoi-cho, Inage-ku, <LOCATION  Chiba> 263-8522, <LOCATION Japan> iga16077@p.chiba-u.ac.jp 
 
 <Capitalized> The polyamine content of cells is regulated by biosynthesis, degradation and transport. <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Escherichia coli, the genes for three different polyamine transport systems have been cloned and characterized. <Capitalized> Two uptake systems (putrescine-specific and spermidine-preferential) were <COMPANY  ABC> transporters, each consisting of a periplasmic substrate-binding protein, two transmembrane proteins and a membrane-associated ATPase. <Capitalized> The crystal structures of the substrate-binding proteins (PotD and PotF) have been solved. <Capitalized> They consist of two domains with an alternating beta-alpha-beta topology, similar to other periplasmic binding proteins. <Capitalized> The polyamine-binding site is in a cleft between the two domains, as determined by crystallography and site-directed mutagenesis. <Capitalized> Polyamines are mainly recognized by aspartic acid and glutamic acid residues, which interact with the NH(2)- (or NH-) groups, and by tryptophan and tyrosine residues that have hydrophobic interactions with the methylene groups of polyamines. <Capitalized> The precursor of one of the substrate binding proteins, PotD, negatively regulates transcription of the operon for the spermidine-preferential uptake system, thus providing another level of regulation of cellular polyamines. <Capitalized> The third transport system, catalysed by PotE, mediates both uptake and excretion of putrescine. <Capitalized> Uptake of putrescine is dependent on membrane potential, whereas excretion involves an exchange reaction between putrescine and ornithine. <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the gene for a polyamine transport protein (TPO1) was identified. <Capitalized> The properties of this protein are similar to those of PotE, and <EndsInDigit> TPO1 is located on the vacuolar membrane.

 599: <Capitalized> Anal <Capitalized> Biochem 1999 <Capitalized> Dec 1;276(1):18-26 
 
 <Capitalized> Usefulness of statistic experimental designs in enzymology: example with recombinant hCYP3A4 and 1A2. 
 
 <Capitalized> Bournique <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Petry> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Gousset> <AllCaps> G. 
 
 Rhone-Poulenc <PERSON  Rorer,> <Capitalized> Drug <Capitalized> Metabolism and <Capitalized> Pharmacokinetics, and <Capitalized> Pharmaceutical <Capitalized> Sciences, 13 <Capitalized> Quai <Capitalized> Jules <Capitalized> Guesdes, <Capitalized> Vitry s/Seine <Capitalized> Cedex, 94403, <PERSON France> bruno.bournique@rp-rorer.fr 
 
 <Capitalized> First, the effects of 10 incubation factors were screened altogether on nifedipine dehydrogenase (NIF) and methoxyresorufin O-deethylase (MROD) activities catalyzed by recombinant human <EndsInDigit> CYP3A4 and 1A2, respectively. <Capitalized> Using a statistic experimental design, only 36 assays were needed to be exhaustive. <Capitalized> Eight factors influenced CYP3A4-mediated <AllCaps> NIF activity: buffer type, pH, temperature, Mg/EDTA, cytochrome b5, NADPH-P450 reductase, <AllCaps> NADH, and solvent. <Capitalized> Two factors had no significant effect: total ionic concentration and catalase/reduced glutathione. <PERSON  Six> factors influenced CYP1A2-mediated <AllCaps> MROD rates: buffer type, pH, temperature, Mg/EDTA, <AllCaps> NADH, and glycerol. <Capitalized> Four factors had no significant effect: total ionic concentration, cytochrome b5, reductase, and NAD+. <Capitalized> Secondly, the combined effects of ionic strength and <Capitalized> Mg concentration on NIF/CYP3A4 were studied and easily modeled using another statistic experimental design. <Capitalized> The effect of <Capitalized> Mg was strong at a constant ionic strength of 100 <MixedCase> mM and negligible at a constant ionic strength of 500 mM. <Capitalized> Thirdly, the effects of influencing factors and their interactions on MROD/CYP1A2 were modeled after 40 assays using a third statistic experimental design. <Capitalized> Later experiments confirmed the predictivity of the models and the efficiency of optimized conditions. <Capitalized> This approach can be applied to other biochemistry areas. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology of the <Capitalized> Cell <AllCaps> II, <PERSON  German> <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research <PERSON  Center,> Heidelberg. 
 
 <Capitalized> Transcription termination by <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> I (Pol I) is a stepwise process. <Capitalized> First the elongating <AllCaps> RNA polymerase is forced to pause by DNA-bound transcription termination factor (TTF-I). <Capitalized> Then the ternary transcription complex is dissociated by <AllCaps> PTRF, a novel factor that promotes release of both nascent transcripts and <PERSON  Pol> <AllCaps> I from the template. <Capitalized> In this study we have investigated the ability of <AllCaps> PTRF to liberate transcripts from ternary transcription complexes isolated from yeast and mouse. <Capitalized> Using immobilized, tailed templates that contain terminator sequences from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and mouse, respectively, we demonstrate that <AllCaps> PTRF promotes release of terminated transcripts, irrespective of whether mouse <PERSON  Pol> <AllCaps> I has interacted with the murine termination factor <ContainsHyphen> TTF-I or its yeast homolog Reb1p. <Capitalized> In contrast, mouse <PERSON  Pol> <AllCaps> I paused by the lac repressor remains bound to the template both in the presence and absence of <AllCaps> PTRF. <Capitalized> We demonstrate that <AllCaps> PTRF interacts with the largest subunit of murine <PERSON  Pol> <AllCaps> I, with <ContainsHyphen> TTF-I and Reb1p, but not the lac repressor. <Capitalized> The results imply that <PERSON  Pol> <AllCaps> I transcription termination in yeast and mouse is mediated by conserved interactions between <PERSON  Pol> <AllCaps> I, Reb1p/TTF-I and <AllCaps> PTRF.

 601: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Gen <PERSON  Genet> 1999 Oct;262(3):473-80 
 
 <Capitalized> Budding yeast Cdc6p induces re-replication in fission yeast by inhibition of SCF(Pop)-mediated proteolysis. 
 
 <PERSON  Wolf> <AllCaps> DA, McKeon <AllCaps> F, <PERSON  Jackson> <AllCaps> PK. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Harvard <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Public <Capitalized> Health, <LOCATION  Boston,> <AllCaps> MA 02115, <LOCATION  USA.> dwolf@hsph.harvard.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> In fission yeast, overexpression of the replication initiator protein Cdc18p induces re-replication, a phenotype characterized by continuous <AllCaps> DNA synthesis in the absence of cell division. <Capitalized> In contrast, overexpression of Cdc6p, the budding yeast homolog of Cdc18p, does not cause re-replication in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. <Capitalized> However, we have found that Cdc6p has the ability to induce rereplication in fission yeast. Cdc6p cannot functionally replace Cdc18p, but instead interferes with the proteolysis of both Cdc18p and Rum1p, the inhibitor of the protein kinase Cdc2p. <Capitalized> This activity of Cdc6p is entirely contained within a short N-terminal peptide, which forms a tight complex with Cdc2p and the F-box/WD-repeat protein Sud1p/Pop2p, a component of the SCF(Pop) ubiquitin ligase in fission yeast. <Capitalized> These interactions are mediated by two distinct regions within the N-terminal region of Cdc6p and depend on the integrity of its Cdc2p phosphorylation sites. <Capitalized> The data suggest that disruption of re-replication control by overexpression of Cdc6p in fission yeast is a consequence of sequestration of Cdc2p and Pop2p, two factors involved in the negative regulation of Rum1p, Cdc18p and potentially other replication proteins.

 <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatase is an essential <MixedCase> mRNA processing enzyme that catalyzes the first step in cap formation. <Capitalized> The 2.05 <AllCaps> A crystal structure of yeast <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatase Cet1p reveals a novel active site fold whereby an eight-stranded beta barrel forms a topologically closed triphosphate tunnel. <Capitalized> Interactions of a sulfate in the center of the tunnel with a divalent cation and basic amino acids projecting into the tunnel suggest a catalytic mechanism that is supported by mutational data. <Capitalized> Discrete surface domains mediate Cet1p homodimerization and Cet1p binding to the guanylyltransferase component of the capping apparatus. <Capitalized> The structure and mechanism of fungal <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatases are completely different from those of mammalian <MixedCase> mRNA capping enzymes. <Capitalized> Hence, <AllCaps> RNA triphosphatase presents an ideal target for structure-based antifungal drug discovery.

 Self-association of the alpha subunit of phosphorylase kinase as determined by two-hybrid screening. 
 
 <PERSON  Ayers> <AllCaps> NA, <PERSON  Wilkinson> <AllCaps> DA, <PERSON  Fitzgerald> <AllCaps> TJ, <PERSON  Carlson> <AllCaps> GM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Missouri,> <LOCATION  Kansas> <Capitalized> City, <LOCATION  Missouri> 64110-2499, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The structural organization of the (alphabetagammadelta)(4) phosphorylase kinase complex has been studied using the yeast two-hybrid screen for the purpose of elucidating regions of alpha subunit interactions. <Capitalized> By screening a rabbit skeletal muscle <MixedCase> cDNA library with residues 1-1059 of the alpha subunit of phosphorylase kinase, we have isolated 16 interacting, independent, yet overlapping transcripts of the alpha subunit containing its C-terminal region. <Capitalized> Domain mapping of binary interactions between alpha constructs revealed two regions involved in the self-association of the alpha subunit: residues 833-854, a previously unrecognized leucine zipper, and an unspecified region within residues 1015-1237. <Capitalized> The cognate binding partner for the latter domain has been inferred to lie within the stretch from residues 864-1059. <Capitalized> Indirect evidence from the literature suggests that the interacting domains contained within the latter two, overlapping regions may be further narrowed to the stretches from 1057 to 1237 and from 864 to 971. Cross-linking of the nonactivated holoenzyme with N-(gamma-maleimidobutyroxy)sulfosuccin-imide ester produced intramolecularly cross-linked alpha-alpha dimers, consistent with portions of two alpha subunits in the holoenyzme being in sufficient proximity to associate. <Capitalized> This is the first report to identify potential areas of contact between the alpha subunits of phosphorylase kinase. <Capitalized> Additionally, issues regarding the general utility of two-hybrid screening as a method for studying homodimeric interactions are discussed.

 <Capitalized> Mao <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  White> <AllCaps> SA, <PERSON  Williamson> <AllCaps> JR. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <LOCATION  Massachusetts> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Technology, <LOCATION  Cambridge,> <LOCATION  Massachusetts> 02139, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae ribosomal protein <EndsInDigit> L30 negatively autoregulates its production by binding to a helix-loop-helix structure formed in its pre-mRNA and its mRNA. <AllCaps> A three-dimensional solution structure of the <EndsInDigit> L30 protein in complex with its regulatory <AllCaps> RNA has been solved using <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy. <Capitalized> In the complex, the helix-loop-helix <AllCaps> RNA adopts a sharply bent conformation at the internal loop region. <Capitalized> Unusual <AllCaps> RNA features include a purine stack, a reverse <Capitalized> Hoogsteen base pair (G11anti-G56syn) and highly distorted backbones. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> L30 protein is folded in a three-layer alpha/beta/alpha sandwich topology, and three loops at one end of the sandwich make base-specific contacts with the <AllCaps> RNA internal loop. <Capitalized> The protein-RNA binding interface is divided into two clusters, including hydrophobic and aromatic stacking interactions centering around G56, and base-specific hydrogen-bonding contacts to A57, <EndsInDigit> G58 and G10-U60 wobble base pair. <PERSON  Both> the protein and the <AllCaps> RNA exhibit a partially induced fit for binding, where loops in the protein and the internal loop in the <AllCaps> RNA become more ordered upon complex formation. <Capitalized> The specific interactions formed between loops on <EndsInDigit> L30 and the internal loop on the <MixedCase> mRNA constitute a novel loop-loop recognition motif where an intimate RNA-protein interface is formed between regions on both molecules that lack regular secondary structure.

 <Capitalized> Thevissen <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Terras <AllCaps> FR, <Capitalized> Broekaert <AllCaps> WF. 
 
 <AllCaps> F. <AllCaps> A. <PERSON  Janssens> <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> Katholieke <Capitalized> Universiteit <PERSON  Leuven,> B-3001 Heverlee-Leuven, <LOCATION Belgium> 
 
 <Capitalized> We used an assay based on the uptake of <AllCaps> SYTOX <PERSON  Green,> an organic compound that fluoresces upon interaction with nucleic acids and penetrates cells with compromised plasma membranes, to investigate membrane permeabilization in fungi. <Capitalized> Membrane permeabilization induced by plant defensins in <Capitalized> Neurospora crassa was biphasic, depending on the plant defensin dose. <Capitalized> At high defensin levels (10 to 
 
 40 microM), strong permeabilization was detected that could be strongly suppressed by cations in the medium. <Capitalized> This permeabilization appears to rely on direct peptide-phospholipid interactions. <Capitalized> At lower defensin levels (0.1 to 1 microM), a weaker, but more cation-resistant, permeabilization occurred at concentrations that correlated with the inhibition of fungal growth. Rs-AFP2(Y38G), an inactive variant of the plant defensin Rs-AFP2 from <Capitalized> Raphanus sativus, failed to induce cation-resistant permeabilization in <AllCaps> N. crassa. Dm-AMP1, a plant defensin from <Capitalized> Dahlia merckii, induced cation-resistant membrane permeabilization in yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) which correlated with its antifungal activity. <Capitalized> However, Dm-AMP1 could not induce cation-resistant permeabilization in the Dm-AMP1-resistant <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae mutant DM1, which has a drastically reduced capacity for binding Dm-AMP1. <Capitalized> We think that cation-resistant permeabilization is binding site mediated and linked to the primary cause of fungal growth inhibition induced by plant defensins.

 608: <AllCaps> EMBO <AllCaps> J 1999 <Capitalized> Dec 1;18(23):6672-81 
 
 Gal83 mediates the interaction of the Snf1 kinase complex with the transcription activator Sip4. 
 
 <PERSON  Vincent> <AllCaps> O, <PERSON  Carlson> <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Departments of <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Development, <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> University, 701 <PERSON  West> 168th <PERSON  Street,> <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  NY> 10032, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The Snf1/AMPK protein kinase family is widely conserved in eukaryotes. <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the Snf1 kinase is an essential element of the glucose response pathway and has diverse regulatory roles. <Capitalized> The Snf1 complex contains one of the related proteins Sip1, Sip2 and Gal83, which are also conserved in higher eukaryotes. <Capitalized> Previous studies showed that the Sip1/Sip2/Gal83 component plays a structural role in the complex. <Capitalized> We present evidence that this component also mediates the interaction of the Snf1 kinase complex with specific targets. <Capitalized> We show that Gal83 mediates the association of the kinase with Sip4, a Snf1-regulated transcription activator of gluconeogenic genes.  <PERSON McCann> <AllCaps> RO, <PERSON  Craig> <AllCaps> SW.

 <Capitalized> The I/LWEQ module is a conserved sequence that we have identified as an actin-binding motif in the metazoan focal adhesion protein talin and the yeast protein Sla2p. <PERSON  Both> of these proteins are associated with the actin cytoskeleton in cells. <Capitalized> To better establish the value of the I/LWEQ module for prediction of actin-binding function, we have applied a functional genomics approach. <Capitalized> Analysis of the 23 available I/LWEQ module sequences supports the division of I/LWEQ protein superfamily into four groups: (1) metazoan talin, (2) <Capitalized> Dictyostelium discoideum talin homologs TalA/B, (3) metazoan Hip1p, and (4) yeast Sla2p. <Capitalized> We show here that I/LWEQ modules from each major group bind to F-actin in vitro and that GFP-fusion proteins of the I/LWEQ modules of talin and Sla2p bind to F-actin in vivo. <Capitalized> Therefore, the presence of an I/LWEQ module is strongly predictive of protein-actin interactions. <Capitalized> The structural and functional conservation of the I/LWEQ module across the phylogenetic distance between cellular slime molds and mammals implies that the role of the I/LWEQ module is to connect diverse proteins involved in distinct cellular processes, including cell adhesion, cytoskeletal organization, and cell differentiation, to the actin cytoskeleton. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 611: <AllCaps> RNA 1999 Nov;5(11):1509-16 
 
 StreptoTag: a novel method for the isolation of RNA-binding proteins. 
 
 <Capitalized> Bachler <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Schroeder> <PERSON  R,> von <Capitalized> Ahsen <PERSON  U.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Microbiology & <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Vienna,> <PERSON Austria> 
 
 <Capitalized> We describe a fast and simple one-step affinity-purification method for the isolation of specific RNA-binding proteins. <Capitalized> An in vitro-transcribed hybrid <AllCaps> RNA consisting of an aptamer sequence with high binding specificity to the antibiotic streptomycin and a putative protein-binding <AllCaps> RNA sequence is incubated with crude extract. <Capitalized> After complex formation, the sample is applied to an affinity column containing streptomycin immobilized to Sepharose. <Capitalized> The binding of the in vitro-assembled RNA-protein complex to streptomycin-Sepharose is mediated by the aptamer <AllCaps> RNA and the specifically bound proteins are recovered from the affinity matrix by elution with the antibiotic. <Capitalized> Employing two well-characterized RNA-protein interactions, we tested the performance of this new method. <Capitalized> The spliceosomal U1A protein and the bacteriophage <EndsInDigit> MS2 coat protein could be isolated via their appropriate <AllCaps> RNA motif containing hybrid <AllCaps> RNA from crude yeast extracts in high yield and purity after only one round of affinity purification. <Capitalized> As the purification principle is independent of the extract source, this new affinity chromatography strategy that makes use of an in vitro-selected antibiotic-binding <AllCaps> RNA as a tag, "StreptoTag," should be applicable to extracts from other organisms as well. <Capitalized> Therefore, we propose StreptoTag to be a versatile tool for the isolation of unknown RNA-binding proteins.

 613: <Capitalized> Front <Capitalized> Biosci 1999 <Capitalized> Dec 1;4:D824-33 
 
 <Capitalized> Transcription factors in <AllCaps> DNA replication. 
 
 <Capitalized> Murakami <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Ito <PERSON  Y.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Viral <Capitalized> Oncology, <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Virus <Capitalized> Research, <LOCATION  Kyoto> <Capitalized> University, Sakyo-ku, <LOCATION  Kyoto> 606-8507, <LOCATION Japan> yota@virus.kyoto-u.ac.jp 
 
 <Capitalized> Accumulating evidence suggests the involvement of transcription factors in the regulation of <AllCaps> DNA replication in eukaryotic cells. <Capitalized> Almost all eukaryotic <AllCaps> DNA viruses contain binding sites for transcription factors which function as auxiliary elements for <AllCaps> DNA replication initiation at replication origins, and, indeed, the binding of transcription factors to these elements has been shown to stimulate <AllCaps> DNA replication. <Capitalized> Transcription factors also regulate some of the chromosome <AllCaps> DNA replication origins of budding yeast, indicating that transcription factor involvement in <AllCaps> DNA replication is not restricted to viruses. <Capitalized> Consistent with this notion, recently determined replication origins of higher eukaryotes have been found occasionally to associate with transcription factor binding sites, although there is no direct evidence for the involvement of the factors that bind to these sequences in <AllCaps> DNA replication. <Capitalized> Analyses using viral and yeast systems have suggested that transcription factors stimulate the formation of the replication initiation complex by engaging in specific interactions with proteins of the initiation complex and/or by modulating the repressive chromatin structure around origins of replication. <Capitalized> These mechanisms are analogous to those advanced to explain stimulation of transcription by transcription factors. <Capitalized> The accumulated data suggests that transcription factors play a general role in the formation of functional complexes on chromosomes.

 <Capitalized> In vitro assembly of yeast 5S <MixedCase> rRNA and a fusion protein containing ribosomal protein <EndsInDigit> L5 and maltose binding protein. 
 
 <Capitalized> Pakhomova <AllCaps> ON, <Capitalized> Yeh <AllCaps> LC, <Capitalized> Monette <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Lee> <AllCaps> JC. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Science <PERSON  Center> at <LOCATION  San Antonio,> 7703 <PERSON  Floyd> <PERSON  Curl> <Capitalized> Drive, <LOCATION  San Antonio,> <AllCaps> TX 78284-7760 <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Binding of yeast ribosomal protein <EndsInDigit> L5 with 5S <MixedCase> rRNA has long been considered a promising model for studying molecular mechanisms of protein-RNA interactions. <Capitalized> However, in vitro assembly of a ribonucleoprotein (RNP) complex from purified yeast ribosomal protein <EndsInDigit> L5 (also known as L1, L1a, or YL3) and 5S <MixedCase> rRNA proved to be difficult, thus limiting the utility of this model. <Capitalized> In the present report, we present data on the successful in vitro assembly of a <AllCaps> RNP complex using a fusion (MBP-L5) protein consisting of the yeast ribosomal protein <EndsInDigit> L5 fused to the carboxyl terminus of the <AllCaps> E. coli maltose-binding protein (MBP). <Capitalized> We demonstrated that: 1) the MBP-L5 protein binds yeast 5S <MixedCase> rRNA but not 5.8S <MixedCase> rRNA in vitro; 2) the <AllCaps> MBP protein itself does not bind yeast 5S rRNA; 3) formation of the <AllCaps> RNP complex is proportional to the concentration of MBP-L5 protein and 5S rRNA; and 4) the <AllCaps> MBP moiety of the fusion protein in the <AllCaps> RNP complex can be removed with factor Xa. <Capitalized> The electrophoretic mobility of the resultant <AllCaps> RNP complex is indistinguishable from that of L5-5S <MixedCase> rRNA complex isolated from the ribosome. <Capitalized> Using this new experimental approach, we further showed that the <AllCaps> RNA binding capability of a mutant <EndsInDigit> L5 protein is decreased by 60% compared to the wild-type protein. <Capitalized> Additionally, the mutant <AllCaps> RNP complex migrates slower than the wild-type <AllCaps> RNP complex suggesting that the mutant <AllCaps> RNP complex has a less compact conformation. <Capitalized> The finding provides a probable explanation for an earlier observation that the 60S ribosomal subunit containing the mutant protein is unstable.

 <PERSON  Krol> <AllCaps> MA, <PERSON  Olson> <AllCaps> NH, <PERSON  Tate> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Johnson> <AllCaps> JE, <PERSON  Baker> <AllCaps> TS, <Capitalized> Ahlquist <PERSON  P.>

 <Capitalized> Repeated, specific interactions between capsid protein (CP) subunits direct virus capsid assembly and exemplify regulated protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> The results presented here reveal a striking in vivo switch in <AllCaps> CP assembly. <Capitalized> Using cryoelectron microscopy, three-dimensional image reconstruction, and molecular modeling, we show that brome mosaic virus (BMV) <AllCaps> CP can assemble in vivo two remarkably distinct capsids that selectively package BMV-derived RNAs in the absence of <AllCaps> BMV <AllCaps> RNA replication: a 180-subunit capsid indistinguishable from virions produced in natural infections and a previously unobserved <AllCaps> BMV capsid type with 120 subunits arranged as 60 <AllCaps> CP dimers. <Capitalized> Each such dimer contains two CPs in distinct, nonequivalent environments, in contrast to the quasi-equivalent <AllCaps> CP environments throughout the 180-subunit capsid. <Capitalized> This 120-subunit capsid utilizes most of the <AllCaps> CP interactions of the 180-subunit capsid plus nonequivalent <ContainsHyphen> CP-CP interactions. <PERSON  Thus,> the <AllCaps> CP of <AllCaps> BMV, and perhaps other viruses, can encode <ContainsHyphen> CP-CP interactions that are not apparent from mature virions and may function in assembly or disassembly. <Capitalized> Shared structural features suggest that the 120- and 180-subunit capsids share assembly steps and that a common pentamer of <AllCaps> CP dimers may be an important assembly intermediate. <Capitalized> The ability of a single <AllCaps> CP to switch between distinct capsids by means of alternate interactions also implies reduced evolutionary barriers between different capsid structures. <Capitalized> The in vivo switch between alternate <AllCaps> BMV capsids is controlled by the <AllCaps> RNA packaged: a natural <AllCaps> BMV genomic <AllCaps> RNA was packaged in 180-subunit capsids, whereas an engineered <MixedCase> mRNA containing only the <AllCaps> BMV <AllCaps> CP gene was packaged in 120-subunit capsids. <AllCaps> RNA features can thus direct the assembly of a ribonucleoprotein complex between alternate structural pathways.

 TAS-103 is a novel anticancer drug that kills cells by increasing levels of <AllCaps> DNA cleavage mediated by topoisomerase <AllCaps> II. <Capitalized> While most drugs that stimulate topoisomerase II-mediated <AllCaps> DNA scission (i.e., topoisomerase <AllCaps> II poisons) also inhibit the catalytic activity of the enzyme, they typically do so only at concentrations above the clinical range. TAS-103 is unusual in that it reportedly inhibits the catalytic activity of both topoisomerase <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> II and does so at physiologically relevant concentrations [Utsugi, <PERSON T.> et al. (1997) Jpn. <AllCaps> J. <Capitalized> Cancer Res. 88, 992-1002]. <Capitalized> Without a topoisomerase activity to relieve accumulating torsional stress, the <AllCaps> DNA tracking systems that promote the action of TAS-103 as a topoisomerase <AllCaps> II poison would be undermined. <Capitalized> Therefore, the effects of TAS-103 on the catalytic activity of topoisomerase <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> II were characterized. <AllCaps> DNA binding and unwinding assays indicate that the drug intercalates into <AllCaps> DNA with an apparent dissociation constant of approximately 2.2 microM. <Capitalized> Furthermore, <AllCaps> DNA strand passage assays with mammalian topoisomerase <AllCaps> I indicate that TAS-103 does not inhibit the catalytic activity of the type <AllCaps> I enzyme. <Capitalized> Rather, the previously reported inhibition of topoisomerase I-catalyzed <AllCaps> DNA relaxation results from a drug-induced alteration in the apparent topology of the nucleic acid substrate.  <Capitalized> Elaboration of conjugative (F) pili by F+ strains of <Capitalized> Escherichia coli requires the activities of over a dozen F-encoded <AllCaps> DNA transfer (Tra) proteins. <Capitalized> The organization and functions of these proteins are largely unknown. <Capitalized> Using the yeast two-hybrid assay, we have begun to analyse binary interactions among the <Capitalized> Tra proteins required for F-pilus formation. <Capitalized> We focus here on interactions involving F-pilin, the only known F-pilus subunit. <Capitalized> Using a library of <AllCaps> F tra <AllCaps> DNA fragments that contained all the <AllCaps> F genes required for <AllCaps> F pilus formation in a yeast <EndsInDigit> GAL4 activation domain vector (pACTII), we transformed yeast containing a plasmid (pAS1CYH2traA) encoding a <EndsInDigit> GAL4 DNA-binding domain-F-pilin fusion. <Capitalized> Doubly transformed cells were screened for GAL4-dependent gene expression. <Capitalized> This screen repeatedly identified only a single <Capitalized> Tra protein, TraQ, previously identified as a likely F-pilin chaperone. <Capitalized> The F-pilin-TraQ interaction appeared to be specific, as no transcriptional activation was detected in yeast transformants containing <MixedCase> pACTIItraQ plasmids and the <Capitalized> Salmonella typhi pED208 <MixedCase> traA gene cloned in pAS1CYH2. <Capitalized> Two <MixedCase> traQ segments isolated in the screen against F-pilin were tested for complementation of a <MixedCase> traQ null allele in <AllCaps> E. coli. <Capitalized> One, lacking the first 11 (of 94) TraQ amino acids, restored <AllCaps> DNA donor activity, donor-specific bacteriophage sensitivity and membrane F-pilin accumulation to wild-type levels. <Capitalized> The second, lacking the first 21 amino acids, was much less effective in these assays. <PERSON  Both> TraQ polypeptides accumulated in <AllCaps> E. coli as transmembrane proteins. <Capitalized> The longer, biologically active segment was fused to the <EndsInDigit> GAL4 DNA-binding domain gene of pAS1CYH2 and used to screen the tra fragment library. <Capitalized> The only positives from this screen identified <MixedCase> traA segments. <Capitalized> The fusion sites between the <MixedCase> traA and <EndsInDigit> GAL4 segments identified the hydrophobic, C-terminal domain <AllCaps> IV of F-pilin as sufficient for the interaction. <Capitalized> As TraQ is the only <Capitalized> Tra protein required for the accumulation of inner membrane F-pilin, the interaction probably reflects a specific, chaperone-like function for TraQ in <AllCaps> E. coli. <Capitalized> Attempts to isolate an F-pilin-TraQ complex from <AllCaps> E. coli were unsuccessful, suggesting that the interaction between the two is normally transient, as expected from previous studies of the kinetics of TraA membrane insertion and processing to F-pilin.

 <Capitalized> Gilstring <AllCaps> CF, Melin-Larsson <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Ljungdahl <AllCaps> PO. 
 
 <PERSON  Ludwig> <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research, S-171 77 <LOCATION  Stockholm,> <LOCATION Sweden> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> SHR3 gene of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae encodes an integral membrane component of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) with four membrane-spanning segments and a hydrophilic, cytoplasmically oriented carboxyl-terminal domain. <Capitalized> Mutations in <EndsInDigit> SHR3 specifically impede the transport of all 18 members of the amino acid permease (aap) gene family away from the <AllCaps> ER. Shr3p does not itself exit the <AllCaps> ER. <Capitalized> Aaps fully integrate into the <AllCaps> ER membrane and fold properly independently of Shr3p. Shr3p physically associates with the general aap Gap1p but not Sec61p, Gal2p, or Pma1p in a complex that can be purified from N-dodecylmaltoside-solubilized membranes. Pulse-chase experiments indicate that the Shr3p-Gap1p association is transient, a reflection of the exit of Gap1p from the <AllCaps> ER. <Capitalized> The ER-derived vesicle <AllCaps> COPII coatomer components Sec13p, Sec23p, Sec24p, and Sec31p but not Sar1p bind Shr3p via interactions with its carboxyl-terminal domain. <Capitalized> The mutant shr3-23p, a nonfunctional membrane-associated protein, is unable to associate with aaps but retains the capacity to bind <AllCaps> COPII components. <Capitalized> The overexpression of either Shr3p or shr3-23p partially suppresses the temperature-sensitive sec12-1 allele. <Capitalized> These results are consistent with a model in which Shr3p acts as a packaging chaperone that initiates ER-derived transport vesicle formation in the proximity of aaps by facilitating the membrane association and assembly of <AllCaps> COPII coatomer components.

 <AllCaps> A specific protein-protein interaction accounts for the in vivo substrate selectivity of Ptp3 towards the Fus3 <AllCaps> MAP kinase. 
 
 <Capitalized> Zhan <AllCaps> XL, <Capitalized> Guan <AllCaps> KL. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor,> <LOCATION  Michigan> 48109-0606, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) play critical roles in many signal transduction processes. <Capitalized> Several MAPKs have been found in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, including Fus3 in the mating pathway and Hog1 in the osmotic-stress response pathway. <Capitalized> Cells lacking Fus3 or Hog1 activity are deficient in mating or adaptation to osmotic shock, respectively. <Capitalized> However, constitutive activation of either Fus3 or Hog1 is lethal. <Capitalized> Therefore, yeast cells have to tightly regulate both the activation and inactivation of Fus3 and Hog1 MAPKs, which are controlled mainly by phosphorylation and dephosphorylation. <Capitalized> Previous studies have shown that Fus3 activity is negatively regulated by protein tyrosine phosphatase Ptp3. <Capitalized> In contrast, the Hog1 <AllCaps> MAPK is mainly dephosphorylated by Ptp2 even though the two phosphatases share a high degree of sequence similarity. <Capitalized> To understand the mechanisms of <AllCaps> MAPK regulation, we examined the molecular basis underlying the in vivo substrate specificity between phosphatases and MAPKs. <Capitalized> We observed that the amino-terminal noncatalytic domain of Ptp3 directly interacts with Fus3 via <EndsInDigit> CH2 (Cdc25 homology) domain conserved among yeast PTPases and mammalian <AllCaps> MAP kinase phosphatases and is responsible for the in vivo substrate selectivity of the phosphatase. <Capitalized> Interaction between Ptp3 and Fus3 is required for dephosphorylation and inactivation of Fus3 under physiological conditions. <Capitalized> Mutations in either Ptp3 or Fus3 that abolish this interaction cause a dysregulation of the Fus3 <AllCaps> MAPK. <Capitalized> Our data demonstrate that the specificity of <AllCaps> MAP kinase inactivation in vivo by phosphatases is determined by specific protein-protein interactions outside of the phosphatase catalytic domain.

 <Capitalized> The dimerization/repression domain of <EndsInDigit> RFX1 is related to a conserved region of its yeast homologues Crt1 and Sak1: a new function for an ancient motif. 
 
 Katan-Khaykovich <PERSON  Y,> <PERSON  Spiegel> <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Shaul <PERSON  Y.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Weizmann <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Science, <LOCATION  Rehovot,> 76100, <PERSON Israel> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> RFX protein family includes members from yeast to humans, which function in various biological systems, and share a DNA-binding domain and a conserved C-terminal region. <Capitalized> In the human transcription regulator RFX1, the conserved <AllCaps> C terminus is an independent functional domain, which mediates dimerization and transcriptional repression. <Capitalized> This dimerization domain has a unique ability to mediate the formation of two alternative homodimeric DNA-protein complexes, the upper of which has been linked to repression. <Capitalized> Here, we localize the complex formation capacity to several different <EndsInDigit> RFX1 C-terminal subregions, each of which can function independently to generate the upper complex and repress transcription, thus correlating complex formation with repression. <Capitalized> To gain an evolutionary perspective, we have examined whether the different properties of the <EndsInDigit> RFX1 <AllCaps> C terminus exist in the two yeast <AllCaps> RFX proteins, which are involved in signaling pathways. <Capitalized> Replacement of the <EndsInDigit> RFX1 <AllCaps> C terminus with those of Sak1 and Crt1, its orthologues from <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe and <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, respectively, and analysis of fusions with the Gal4 DNA-binding domain, revealed that the ability to generate the two alternative complexes is conserved in the <AllCaps> RFX family, from <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae to man. <Capitalized> While sharing this unique biochemical property, the three <AllCaps> C termini differed from each other in their ability to mediate dimerization and transcriptional repression. <Capitalized> In both functions, RFX1, Sak1, and Crt1 showed high capacity, moderate capacity, and no capacity, respectively. <Capitalized> This comparative analysis of the <AllCaps> RFX proteins, representing different evolutionary stages, suggests a gradual development of the conserved <AllCaps> C terminus, from the appearance of the ancestral motif (Crt1), to the later acquisition of the dimerization/repression functions (Sak1), and finally to the enhancement of these functions to generate a domain mediating highly stable protein-protein interactions and potent transcriptional repression (RFX1). <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 628: <Capitalized> Biochim <Capitalized> Biophys <Capitalized> Acta 1999 <Capitalized> Nov 16;1422(3):235-54 
 
 <Capitalized> Mechanisms of protein translocation into mitochondria. 
 
 <Capitalized> Voos <PERSON  W,> <PERSON  Martin> <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Krimmer <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Pfanner <AllCaps> N. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Biochemie und <Capitalized> Molekularbiologie, <Capitalized> Universitat <Capitalized> Freiburg, Hermann-Herder-Str. 7, D-79104, <Capitalized> Freiburg, <LOCATION Germany> voos@ruf.uni-freiburg.de 
 
 <Capitalized> Mitochondrial biogenesis utilizes a complex proteinaceous machinery for the import of cytosolically synthesized preproteins. <Capitalized> At least three large multisubunit protein complexes, one in the outer membrane and two in the inner membrane, have been identified. <Capitalized> These translocase complexes cooperate with soluble proteins from the cytosol, the intermembrane space and the matrix. <Capitalized> The translocation of presequence-containing preproteins through the outer membrane channel includes successive electrostatic interactions of the charged mitochondrial targeting sequence with a chain of import components. <Capitalized> Translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane utilizes the energy of the proton motive force of the inner membrane and the hydrolysis of <AllCaps> ATP. <Capitalized> The matrix chaperone system of the mitochondrial heat shock protein 70 forms an ATP-dependent import motor by interaction with the polypeptide chain in transit and components of the inner membrane translocase. <Capitalized> The precursors of integral inner membrane proteins of the metabolite carrier family interact with newly identified import components of the intermembrane space and are inserted into the inner membrane by a second translocase complex. <AllCaps> A comparison of the full set of import components between the yeast <Capitalized> Sacccharomyces cerevisiae and the nematode <Capitalized> Caenorhabditis elegans demonstrates an evolutionary conservation of most components of the mitochondrial import machinery with a possible greater divergence for the import pathway of the inner membrane carrier proteins. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial

 629: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Sci 1999 Nov;112 ( <Capitalized> Pt 22):4123-34 
 
 <Capitalized> Genetic interactions of Hrd3p and Der3p/Hrd1p with Sec61p suggest a retro-translocation complex mediating protein transport for <AllCaps> ER degradation. 
 
 <Capitalized> Plemper <AllCaps> RK, <Capitalized> Bordallo <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Deak <AllCaps> PM, <Capitalized> Taxis <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Hitt> <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Wolf> <AllCaps> DH. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Biochemie, <Capitalized> Universitat <LOCATION  Stuttgart,> D-70569 <LOCATION  Stuttgart,> <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> The endoplasmic reticulum contains a quality control system that subjects misfolded or unassembled secretory proteins to rapid degradation via the cytosolic ubiquitin proteasome system. <Capitalized> This requires retrograde protein transport from the endoplasmic reticulum back to the cytosol. <Capitalized> The Sec61 pore, the central component of the protein import channel into the endoplasmic reticulum, was identified as the core subunit of the retro-translocon as well. <Capitalized> As import of mutated proteins into the endoplasmic reticulum lumen is successfully terminated, a new targeting mechanism must exist that mediates re-entering of misfolded proteins into the Sec61 pore from the lumenal side de novo. <Capitalized> The previously identified proteins Der3p/Hrd1p and, as we show here, Hrd3p of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, are localised in the endoplasmic reticulum membrane and are essential for the degradation of several substrates of the endoplasmic reticulum degradation machinery. <Capitalized> Based on genetic studies we demonstrate that they functionally interact with each other and with Sec61p, probably establishing the central part of the retro-translocon. <Capitalized> In the absence of Hrd3p, the otherwise stable protein Der3p/Hrd1p becomes rapidly degraded. <Capitalized> This depends on a functional ubiquitin proteasome system and the presence of substrate molecules of the endoplasmic reticulum degradation system. <Capitalized> When overexpressed, Der3p/Hrd1p accelerates CPY* degradation in Delta(hrd3) cells. <Capitalized> Our data suggest a recycling process of Der3p/Hrd1p through Hrd3p. <Capitalized> The retro-translocon seems to be build up at least by the Sec61 pore, Der3p/Hrd1p and Hrd3p and mediates both retrograde transport and ubiquitination of substrate molecules.

 <PERSON  Greene> <AllCaps> AL, <PERSON  Snipe> <AllCaps> JR, <Capitalized> Gordenin <AllCaps> DA, <Capitalized> Resnick <AllCaps> MA.

 <Capitalized> The flap endonuclease, FEN1, is an evolutionarily conserved component of <AllCaps> DNA replication from archaebacteria to humans. <Capitalized> Based on in vitro results, it processes <LOCATION  Okazaki> fragments during replication and is involved in base excision repair. <EndsInDigit> FEN1 removes the last primer ribonucleotide on the lagging strand and it cleaves a 5' flap that may result from strand displacement during replication or during base excision repair. <Capitalized> Its biological importance has been revealed largely through studies in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae where deletion of the homologous gene <EndsInDigit> RAD27 results in genome instability and mutagen sensitivity. <Capitalized> While the in vivo function of Rad27 has been well characterized through genetic and biochemical approaches, little is understood about the in vivo functions of human FEN1. <Capitalized> Guided by our recent results with yeast RAD27, we explored the function of human <EndsInDigit> FEN1 in yeast. <Capitalized> We found that the human <EndsInDigit> FEN1 protein complements a yeast rad27 null mutant for a variety of defects including mutagen sensitivity, genetic instability and the synthetic lethal interactions of a rad27 rad51 and a rad27 pol3-01 mutant. <Capitalized> Furthermore, a mutant form of <EndsInDigit> FEN1 lacking nuclease function exhibits dominant-negative effects on cell growth and genome instability similar to those seen with the homologous yeast rad27 mutation. <Capitalized> This genetic impact is stronger when the human and yeast PCNA-binding domains are exchanged. <Capitalized> These data indicate that the human <EndsInDigit> FEN1 and yeast Rad27 proteins act on the same substrate in vivo. <Capitalized> Our study defines a sensitive yeast system for the identification and characterization of mutations in FEN1.

 <AllCaps> DNA replication of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) during the productive phase of the life cycle of this herpesvirus depends on the cis-acting element oriLyt. <Capitalized> It consists of two essential domains, the upstream and the downstream component. <Capitalized> Whereas the upstream component contains several DNA-binding motifs for the viral activator protein BZLF1, the downstream component is known to be the binding site of several cellular proteins. <Capitalized> We identified cellular transcription factors that bind synergistically to a functionally relevant subsequence of the downstream component, the <AllCaps> TD element. <Capitalized> Two of these transcription factors, ZBP-89 and Sp1, stimulate replication as shown by protein fusions with the <EndsInDigit> GAL4 DNA-binding domain and a single <EndsInDigit> GAL4 DNA-binding motif inserted into the <AllCaps> TD element. <Capitalized> In protein binding assays, we observed an interaction of Sp1 and ZBP-89 with the viral <AllCaps> DNA polymerase and its processivity factor. <Capitalized> Our data indicate that cellular transcriptional activators tether viral replication proteins to the lytic origin via direct protein-protein interactions to assemble the viral replication complex at oriLyt.

 <Capitalized> An optimized signal transduction pathway that reproduces the response of human aryl hydrocarbon (Ah) receptor to ligands has been established in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Ligand treatment induced a 50-fold increase in beta-galactosidase activity from a reporter plasmid in yeast engineered to express human <Capitalized> Ah receptor and <Capitalized> Ah nuclear translocator (Arnt) proteins. <Capitalized> The archetypal <Capitalized> Ah receptor ligand, 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo(p)dioxin, activated <Capitalized> Ah receptor and induced <MixedCase> lacZ reporter activity at concentrations of >/=0.3 nM. <Capitalized> Mixtures of halogenated and nonhalogenated <Capitalized> Ah receptor ligands produced additive signaling responses in this yeast bioassay. <Capitalized> These results were consistent with the existence of a common binding site and mechanism of ligand-mediated <Capitalized> Ah receptor activation. <Capitalized> Although yeast have no natural counterpart to the <Capitalized> Ah receptor pathway, expression of human <Capitalized> Ah receptor and <Capitalized> Arnt under the appropriate conditions provides a functional model system for studying <Capitalized> Ah receptor activation and signal transduction. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.
