 633: <Capitalized> Curr <Capitalized> Biol 1999 <Capitalized> Oct 7;9(19):1111-4 
 
 <AllCaps> A retention mechanism for distribution of mitochondria during cell division in budding yeast. 
 
 <Capitalized> Yang <AllCaps> HC, <Capitalized> Palazzo <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Swayne> <AllCaps> TC, <Capitalized> Pon <LOCATION  LA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Anatomy and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Physicians and <Capitalized> Surgeons <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York,> 10032, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Mitochondria are indispensable for normal eukaryotic cell function. <Capitalized> As they cannot be synthesized de novo and are self-replicating, mitochondria must be transferred from mother to daughter cells. <Capitalized> Studies in the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae indicate that mitochondria enter the bud immediately after bud emergence, interact with the actin cytoskeleton for linear, polarized movement of mitochondria from mother to bud, but are equally distributed among mother and daughter cells [1] [2] [3]. <Capitalized> It is not clear how the mother cell maintains its own supply of mitochondria. <Capitalized> Here, we found that mother cells retain mitochondria by immobilization of some mitochondria in the 'retention zone', the base of the mother cell distal to the bud. <Capitalized> Retention requires the actin cytoskeleton as mitochondria colocalized with actin cables in the retention zone, and mutations that perturb actin dynamics or actin-mitochondrial interactions produced retention defects. <Capitalized> Our results support the model that equal distribution of mitochondria during cell division is a consequence of two actin-dependent processes: movement of some mitochondria into the daughter bud and immobilization of others in the mother cell.

 634: <Capitalized> Appl <Capitalized> Microbiol <Capitalized> Biotechnol 1999 Sep;52(3):311-20 
 
 <Capitalized> Yeast cells as tools for target-oriented screening. 
 
 <Capitalized> Munder <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Hinnen <AllCaps> A. 
 
 Hans-Knoll-Institut fur Naturstoff-Forschung e <PERSON  V.> <Capitalized> Jena, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Information about biomolecular interaction networks is crucial for understanding cellular functions and the development of disease processes. <Capitalized> Many diseases are known to be based on aberrations of <AllCaps> DNA sequences encoding proteins with key functions in the cellular metabolism. <Capitalized> Alterations in the respective proteins often lead to disturbances in biomolecular interactions caused by unbalanced stoichiometries, and thus result in alterations of molecule fluxes, cell architecture and signalling pathways. <Capitalized> Drug discovery programmes have been designed to find promising chemical lead structures with the help of target-oriented bioassay systems. <Capitalized> These are, in most cases, based upon the interaction of small molecules to specific macromolecular targets in vivo or in vitro, as exemplified by enzyme assays or small-ligand-based receptor systems. <Capitalized> In addition, interactions between large biomolecules, such as proteins or nucleic acids, offer a huge arsenal of potential drug targets that can be addressed by small chemical compounds. <Capitalized> This latter approach is gaining considerable attention because many potential target structures are becoming available through genomic research. <Capitalized> Funnelling these new targets into high-throughput screening programs represents a major challenge for today's pharmaceutical research. <Capitalized> An important outcome of the ongoing genome projects is the fact that the basic cellular structures, pathways and signalling principles show a high degree of conservation. <Capitalized> Model organisms that are easily approachable by genetic, biochemical and physiological means can thus play an important role in the design of target-oriented screening systems. <Capitalized> They offer the possibility to express individual proteins, nucleic acids or even more complex aggregates of biomolecules such as protein-interaction networks or transcription-initiation complexes, which can be addressed by small effector molecules in vivo. <Capitalized> Combining these targets with biological signalling systems is an attractive way of creating robust cellular assay systems. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial 
 
 PMID: 10531642 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 635: <Capitalized> Infect <Capitalized> Immun 1999 Nov;67(11):6040-7 
 
 <Capitalized> Overexpression of the <Capitalized> Candida albicans <EndsInDigit> ALA1 gene in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae results in aggregation following attachment of yeast cells to extracellular matrix proteins, adherence properties similar to those of <Capitalized> Candida albicans. 
 
 <Capitalized> Gaur <AllCaps> NK, <PERSON  Klotz> <AllCaps> SA, <PERSON  Henderson> <AllCaps> RL. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Research, <Capitalized> Veterans <Capitalized> Affairs <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Kansas> <Capitalized> City, <LOCATION  Missouri> 64128, <LOCATION  USA.> nkgaur@kuhub.cc.ukans.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> Candida albicans maintains a commensal relationship with human hosts, probably by adhering to mucosal tissue in a variety of physiological conditions. <Capitalized> We show that adherence due to the <AllCaps> C. albicans gene <EndsInDigit> ALA1 when transformed into <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, is comprised of two sequential steps. <Capitalized> Initially, <AllCaps> C. albicans rapidly attaches to extracellular matrix (ECM) protein-coated magnetic beads in small numbers (the attachment phase). <Capitalized> This is followed by a relatively slower step in which cell-to-cell interactions predominate (the aggregation phase). <Capitalized> Neither of these phases is observed in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. <Capitalized> However, expression of the <AllCaps> C. albicans <EndsInDigit> ALA1 gene from a low-copy vector causes <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae transformants to attach to ECM-coated magnetic beads without appreciable aggregation. <Capitalized> Expression of <EndsInDigit> ALA1 from a high-copy vector results in both attachment and aggregation. <Capitalized> Moreover, transcriptional fusion of <EndsInDigit> ALA1 with the galactose-inducible promoters <AllCaps> GALS, <AllCaps> GALL, and GAL1, allowing for low, moderate, and high levels of inducible transcription, respectively, causes attachment and aggregation that correlates with the strength of the <AllCaps> GAL promoter. <Capitalized> The adherence of <AllCaps> C. albicans and <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae overexpressing <EndsInDigit> ALA1 to a number of protein ligands occurs over a broad <MixedCase> pH range, is resistant to shear forces generated by vortexing, and is unaffected by the presence of sugars, high salt levels, free ligands, or detergents. <Capitalized> Adherence is, however, inhibited by agents that disrupt hydrogen bonds. <Capitalized> The similarities in the adherence and aggregation properties of <AllCaps> C. albicans and <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae overexpressing  636: <Capitalized> Methods 1999 Oct;19(2):338-49 
 
 <Capitalized> Genetic approaches to the study of protein-protein interactions. 
 
 <Capitalized> Appling <AllCaps> DR. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry and <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Biochemical <Capitalized> Institute, <LOCATION  Austin,> <LOCATION  Texas> 78712, <LOCATION  USA.> dappling@mail.utexas.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> This article describes genetic approaches to the study of heterologous protein-protein interactions, focusing on the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a useful eukaryotic model system. <Capitalized> Several methods are described that can be used to search for new interactions, including extragenic suppression, multicopy suppression, synthetic lethality, and transdominant inhibition. <Capitalized> Strategies for screening, genetic characterization, and clone identification are described, along with recent examples from the literature. <Capitalized> In addition, genetic methods are discussed that can be used to further characterize a newly discovered protein-protein interaction. <Capitalized> These include the creation of mutant libraries of a given protein by chemical mutagenesis or polymerase chain reaction, the production of dominant-negative mutants, and strategies for introducing these mutant alleles back into yeast for analysis. <Capitalized> Although these genetic methods are quite powerful, they are often just a starting point for further biochemical or cell biological experiments. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 637: <Capitalized> Methods 1999 Oct;19(2):330-7 
 
 <Capitalized> Applications of the yeast two-hybrid system. 
 
 McAlister-Henn <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Gibson> <AllCaps> N, <Capitalized> Panisko <AllCaps> E. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Science <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  San Antonio,> <LOCATION  Texas> 78284-7760, <LOCATION  USA.> henn@uthscsa.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> In recent years, the yeast two-hybrid system has become the method of choice for detection and analysis of protein-protein interactions in an in vivo context. <Capitalized> This system, which capitalizes on the significant genetic history and ease of protocols for manipulation of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, is accessible to most laboratories and is applicable to the pursuit of a large variety of experimental goals. <Capitalized> To date, the two-hybrid system has seen widespread application for identification of interaction partners by screening methods using a particular protein of interest as a "bait." Large-scale ventures are also in progress, for example, a cataloging of interactions among the cellular proteins in yeast. <Capitalized> However, this method also has tremendous potential for more focused analyses of specific proteins and should become more routine as an alternative or adjunct approach for many structure-function investigations. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 638: <Capitalized> Mutat <Capitalized> Res 1999 <PERSON  Sep> 13;435(1):23-33

 <Capitalized> Protein complexes in nucleotide excision repair. 
 
 <Capitalized> Araujo <AllCaps> SJ, <PERSON  Wood> <AllCaps> RD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Imperial <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Fund, <PERSON  Clare> <PERSON  Hall> <Capitalized> Laboratories, <PERSON  South> <PERSON  Mimms,> <Capitalized> Hertfordshire, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The main pathway by which mammalian cells remove <AllCaps> DNA damage caused by <AllCaps> UV light and some other mutagens is nucleotide excision repair (NER). <Capitalized> The best characterised components of the human <AllCaps> NER process are those proteins defective in the inherited disorder xeroderma pigmentosum (XP). <Capitalized> The proteins known to be involved in the first steps of the <AllCaps> NER reaction (damage recognition and incision-excision) are heterotrimeric <AllCaps> RPA, <AllCaps> XPA, the 6 to 9 subunit <AllCaps> TFIIH, XPC-hHR23B, <AllCaps> XPG, and ERCC1-XPF. <Capitalized> Many interactions between these proteins have been found in recent years using different methods both in mammalian cells and for the homologous proteins in yeast. <Capitalized> There are virtually no quantitative measurements of the relative strengths of these interactions. <PERSON  Higher> order associations between these proteins in solution and even the existence of a complete "repairosome" complex have been reported, which would have implications both for the mechanism of repair and for the interplay between <AllCaps> NER and other cellular processes. <Capitalized> Nevertheless, evidence for a completely pre-assembled functional repairosome in solution is inconclusive and the order of action of repair factors on damaged <AllCaps> DNA is uncertain.

 <Capitalized> Xiao <PERSON  W,> <PERSON  Chow> <AllCaps> BL, <Capitalized> Fontanie <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Ma <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Bacchetti <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Hryciw <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Broomfield <PERSON  S.>

 <LOCATION  Kota> <AllCaps> RS, <PERSON  Runge> <AllCaps> KW.

 <Capitalized> The telomeres of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae consist of a duplex region of TG(1-3) repeats that acquire a single-stranded 3' extension of the TG(1-3) strand at the end of S-phase. <Capitalized> The length of these repeats is kept within a defined range by regulators such as the TEL2-encoded protein (Tel2p). <Capitalized> Here we show that Tel2p can specifically bind to single-stranded TG(1-3). Tel2p bound to single-stranded substrates that were at least 19 bases in length and contained 14 bases of TG(1-3), and also to double-stranded/single-stranded hybrid substrates with a 3' TG(1-3) overhang. Tel2p binding to a hybrid substrate with a 24 base single-stranded TG(1-3) extension also produced a band characteristic of G-G-mediated secondary structures. <Capitalized> These data suggest that Tel2p could regulate telomeric length by binding to the 3' single-stranded TG(1-3) extension present at yeast telomeres.

 <Capitalized> An internal targeting signal directing proteins into the mitochondrial intermembrane space. 
 
 <Capitalized> Diekert <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Kispal <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Guiard> <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Lill> <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Zytobiologie und <Capitalized> Zytopathologie der Philipps-Universitat <Capitalized> Marburg, Robert-Koch-Strasse 5, 35033 <Capitalized> Marburg, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Import of most nucleus-encoded preproteins into mitochondria is mediated by N-terminal presequences and requires a membrane potential and <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis. <PERSON  Little> is known about the chemical nature and localization of other mitochondrial targeting signals or of the mechanisms by which they facilitate membrane passage. <Capitalized> Mitochondrial heme lyases lack N-terminal targeting information. <Capitalized> These proteins are localized in the intermembrane space and are essential for the covalent attachment of heme to c type cytochromes. <Capitalized> For import of heme lyases, the translocase of the mitochondrial outer membrane complex is both necessary and sufficient. <Capitalized> Here, we report the identification of the targeting signal of mitochondrial heme lyases in the third quarter of these proteins. <Capitalized> The targeting sequence is highly conserved among all known heme lyases. <Capitalized> Its chemical character is hydrophilic because of a large fraction of both positively and negatively charged amino acid residues. <Capitalized> These features clearly distinguish this signal from classical presequences. <Capitalized> When inserted into a cytosolic protein, the targeting sequence directs the fusion protein into the intermembrane space, even in the absence of a membrane potential or <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis. <Capitalized> The heme lyase targeting sequence represents the first topogenic signal for energy-independent transport into the intermembrane space and harbors two types of information. <Capitalized> It assures accurate recognition and translocation by the translocase of the mitochondrial outer membrane complex, and it is responsible for driving the import reaction by undergoing high-affinity interactions with components of the intermembrane space.

 <Capitalized> Zhou <AllCaps> YH, Titchener-Hooker <AllCaps> NJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Advanced <Capitalized> Centre for <Capitalized> Biochemical <Capitalized> Engineering, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemical <Capitalized> Engineering, <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> College <LOCATION  London,> <Capitalized> Torrington <PERSON  Place,> <LOCATION  London> WC1E 7JE, <LOCATION  UK.> y.zhou@ucl.ac.uk 
 
 <Capitalized> This paper demonstrates a simple graphical approach for the design and analysis of a bioprocess flowsheet in which process interactions are significant. <Capitalized> Results are presented showing how the feasible space for operation can be simulated and used both to address key design and operating decisions and to identify suitable trade-offs between operating variables, such as fermentation growth rate and disruption conditions, in order to achieve prespecified levels of process performance. <Capitalized> Using verified models to describe the production and isolation of an intracellular protein alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) in yeast as a test bed, a series of so-called "windows of operation" are developed at growth rates in the range of 0.06-0.28 h(-1) and for a range of overall process specifications. <Capitalized> The effects of altering the process design performance specification as defined by the level of cell debris removal and the overall process productivity on the size and position of the feasible space were investigated to demonstrate the sensitivity of the flowsheet to changes in process objectives. <Capitalized> Using the approach it has been possible to visualise the processing trade-offs required to increase performance in terms of the level of cell debris removal by 50% and the overall process productivity by 400% from a defined base level. <Capitalized> The approach provides a convenient tool when designing integrated bioprocesses by enabling process options to be compared visually and can help in achieving better process designs and accelerating process development for the biological process industry. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <PERSON  John> <PERSON  Wiley> & <Capitalized> Sons, Inc.

 <Capitalized> The hormone receptor-like protein Gpr1p physically interacts with phosphatidylinositol-specific phospholipase <AllCaps> C (Plc1p) and with the <Capitalized> Galpha protein Gpa2p, as shown by two-hybrid assays and co-immune precipitation of epitope-tagged proteins.  <Capitalized> An <AllCaps> NMR analysis of ubiquitin recognition by yeast ubiquitin hydrolase: evidence for novel substrate recognition by a cysteine protease.

 <Capitalized> Yeast ubiquitin hydrolase 1 (YUH1), a cysteine protease that catalyzes the removal of ubiquitin C-terminal adducts, is important for the generation of monomeric ubiquitin. <Capitalized> Heteronuclear <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy has been utilized to map the <EndsInDigit> YUH1 binding surface on ubiquitin. <Capitalized> When <EndsInDigit> YUH1 was titrated into a sample of ubiquitin, approximately 50% of the (1)H-(15)N correlation peaks of ubiquitin were affected to some degree, as a result of binding to YUH1. <Capitalized> It is noteworthy that the amide resonances of the basic residues (Arg42, Lys48, Arg72, and Lys74) were highly perturbed. <Capitalized> These positively charged basic residues may be involved in direct interactions with the negatively charged acidic residues on YUH1. <Capitalized> In addition to the electrostatic surface, the hydrophobic surfaces on ubiquitin (Leu8, Ile44, Phe45, Val70, Leu71, and Leu73) and <EndsInDigit> YUH1 are also likely to contribute to the binding interaction. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the amide resonances of Ile13, Leu43, Leu50, and Leu69, the side chains of which are not on the surface, were also highly perturbed, indicating substrate-induced changes in the environments of these residues as well. <Capitalized> These large changes, observed from residues located throughout the five-stranded beta-sheet surface and the C-terminus, suggest that substrate recognition by <EndsInDigit> YUH1 involves a wider area on ubiquitin.

to determine the effect the protein environment may exercise on spectral properties. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> MCD spectrum of each derivative is directly compared to those of analogous forms of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and myoglobin (Mb), two well-characterized histidine-ligated heme proteins. <Capitalized> The ferric azide adduct of <AllCaps> CCP is a hexacoordinate, largely low-spin species with an <AllCaps> MCD spectrum very similar to that of ferric azide <AllCaps> HRP. <Capitalized> This complex displays an <AllCaps> MCD spectrum dissimilar from that of the <Capitalized> Mb derivative, possibly because of the stabilizing interaction between the azide ligand and the distal arginine of <AllCaps> CCP (Arg 48). <Capitalized> For the ferric fluoride derivative all three proteins display varied <AllCaps> MCD data, indicating that the differences in the distal pocket of each protein influences their respective <AllCaps> MCD characteristics. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> MCD data for the cyanoferric complexes are similar for all three proteins, demonstrating that a strong field ligand bound in the sixth axial position dominates the <AllCaps> MCD characteristics of the derivative. <Capitalized> Similarly, the ferric <AllCaps> NO complexes of the three proteins show <AllCaps> MCD spectra similar in feature position and shape, but vary somewhat in intensity. <Capitalized> Reduction of <AllCaps> CCP at neutral <MixedCase> pH yields a typical pentacoordinate high-spin complex with an <AllCaps> MCD spectrum similar to that of deoxyferrous <AllCaps> HRP. <Capitalized> Formation of the <AllCaps> NO and cyanide complexes of ferrous <AllCaps> CCP gives derivatives with <AllCaps> MCD spectra similar to the analogous forms of <AllCaps> HRP and <Capitalized> Mb in both feature position and shape. <Capitalized> Addition of <AllCaps> CO to deoxyferrous <AllCaps> CCP results in a ferrous-CO complex with <AllCaps> MCD spectral similarity to that of ferrous-CO <AllCaps> HRP but not <Capitalized> Mb, indicating that interactions between the ligand and the distal residues affects the <AllCaps> MCD characteristics. <Capitalized> Examination of alkaline (pH 9.7) deoxyferrous <AllCaps> CCP indicates that a <MixedCase> pH dependent conformational change has occurred, leading to a coordination structure similar to that of ferrous cytochrome b5, a known bis-histidine complex. <Capitalized> Exposure of this complex to <AllCaps> CO further confirms that a conformational change has taken place in that the <AllCaps> MCD spectral characteristics of the resulting complex are similar to those of ferrous-CO <Capitalized> Mb but not ferrous-CO <AllCaps> HRP.

 659: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Inorg <Capitalized> Chem 1999 Apr;4(2):209-19 
 
 X-ray crystal structures of active site mutants of the vanadium-containing chloroperoxidase from the fungus <Capitalized> Curvularia inaequalis. 
 
 Macedo-Ribeiro <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Hemrika <PERSON  W,> <Capitalized> Renirie <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Wever> <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Messerschmidt> <AllCaps> A. 
 
 Max-Planck <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Biochemie, <Capitalized> Abteilung <Capitalized> Strukturforschung, <Capitalized> Martinsried, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> The X-ray structures of the chloroperoxidase from <Capitalized> Curvularia inaequalis, heterologously expressed in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, have been determined both in its apo and in its holo forms at 1.66 and 2.11 <AllCaps> A resolution, respectively. <Capitalized> The crystal structures reveal that the overall structure of this enzyme remains nearly unaltered, particularly at the metal binding site. <Capitalized> At the active site of the apo-chloroperoxidase structure a clearly defined sulfate ion was found, partially stabilised through electrostatic interactions and hydrogen bonds with positively charged residues involved in the interactions with the vanadate in the native protein. <Capitalized> The vanadate binding pocket seems to form a very rigid frame stabilising oxyanion binding. <Capitalized> The rigidity of this active site matrix is the result of a large number of hydrogen bonding interactions involving side chains and the main chain of residues lining the active site. <Capitalized> The structures of single site mutants to alanine of the catalytic residue His404 and the vanadium protein ligand His496 have also been analysed. <Capitalized> Additionally we determined the structural effects of mutations to alanine of residue Arg360, directly involved in the compensation of the negative charge of the vanadate group, and of residue Asp292 involved in forming a salt bridge with Arg490 which also interacts with the vanadate. <Capitalized> The enzymatic chlorinating activity is drastically reduced to approximately 1% in mutants D292A, H404A and H496A. <Capitalized> The structures of the mutants confirm the view of the active site of this chloroperoxidase as a rigid matrix providing an oxyanion binding site. <Capitalized> No large changes are observed at the active site for any of the analysed mutants. <Capitalized> The empty space left by replacement of large side chains by alanines is usually occupied by a new solvent molecule which partially replaces the hydrogen bonding interactions to the vanadate. <Capitalized> The new solvent molecules additionally replace part of the interactions the mutated side chains were making to other residues lining the active site frame. <Capitalized> When this is not possible, another side chain in the proximity of the mutated residue moves in order to satisfy the hydrogen bonding potential of the residues located at the active site frame.

Species-specific differences were observed for calcium-promoted <AllCaps> DNA cleavage. <Capitalized> Similarities and differences in <AllCaps> DNA cleavage patterns and nucleic acid sequence preferences were also observed between the human, yeast, and <AllCaps> E. coli top2 enzymes in the presence of the non-intercalators fluoroquinolone CP-115,953, etoposide, and azatoxin and the intercalators amsacrine and mitoxantrone. <Capitalized> Additional base preferences were generally observed for the yeast when compared with the human top2alpha enzyme. <Capitalized> Preferences in the immediate flanks of the top2-mediated <AllCaps> DNA cleavage sites are, however, consistent with the drug stacking model for both enzymes. <Capitalized> We also analyzed and compared homologous mutations in yeast and human top2, i.e. Ser(740) --> <Capitalized> Trp and Ser(763) --> <Capitalized> Trp, respectively. <PERSON  Both> mutations decreased the reversibility of the etoposide-stabilized cleavage sites and produced consistent base sequence preference changes. <Capitalized> These data demonstrate similarities and differences between human and yeast top2 enzymes. <Capitalized> They also indicate that the structure of the enzyme/DNA interface plays a key role in determining the specificity of top2 poisons and cleavage sites for both the intercalating and non-intercalating drugs.

 <Capitalized> Baetz <AllCaps> K, <PERSON  Andrews> <AllCaps> B. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Toronto,> <LOCATION  Toronto,> <LOCATION  Ontario,> <LOCATION  Canada> M5S 1A8. 
 
 <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, two transcription factors, <AllCaps> SBF (SCB binding factor) and <AllCaps> MBF (MCB binding factor), promote the induction of gene expression at the G(1)/S-phase transition of the mitotic cell cycle. Swi4 and Mbp1 are the <AllCaps> DNA binding components of <AllCaps> SBF and <AllCaps> MBF, respectively. <Capitalized> The Swi6 protein is a common subunit of both transcription factors and is presumed to play a regulatory role. <AllCaps> SBF binding to its target sequences, the SCBs, is a highly regulated event and requires the association of Swi4 with Swi6 through their C-terminal domains. Swi4 binding to SCBs is restricted to the late <AllCaps> M and G(1) phases, when Swi6 is localized to the nucleus. <Capitalized> We show that in contrast to Swi6, Swi4 remains nuclear throughout the cell cycle. <Capitalized> This finding suggests that the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain of Swi4 is inaccessible in the full-length protein when not complexed with Swi6. <Capitalized> To explore this hypothesis, we expressed Swi4 and Swi6 in insect cells by using the baculovirus system. <Capitalized> We determined that partially purified Swi4 cannot bind SCBs in the absence of Swi6. <Capitalized> However, Swi4 derivatives carrying point mutations or alterations in the extreme <AllCaps> C terminus were able to bind <AllCaps> DNA or activate transcription in the absence of Swi6, and the <AllCaps> C terminus of Swi4 inhibited Swi4 derivatives from binding <AllCaps> DNA in trans. Full-length Swi4 was determined to be monomeric in solution, suggesting an intramolecular mechanism for auto-inhibition of binding to <AllCaps> DNA by Swi4. <Capitalized> We detected a direct in vitro interaction between a C-terminal fragment of Swi4 and the N-terminal 197 amino acids of Swi4, which contain the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain. <Capitalized> Together, our data suggest that intramolecular interactions involving the C-terminal region of Swi4 physically prevent the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain from binding SCBs. <Capitalized> The interaction of the carboxy-terminal region of Swi4 with Swi6 alleviates this inhibition, allowing Swi4 to bind <AllCaps> DNA.

 <Capitalized> Theoretical mechanisms of proton translocation by the vacuolar H(+)-ATPase require that a transmembrane acidic residue of the multicopy 16-kDa proteolipid subunit be exposed at the exterior surface of the membrane sector of the enzyme, contacting the lipid phase. <Capitalized> However, structural support for this theoretical mechanism is lacking. <Capitalized> To address this, we have used cysteine mutagenesis to produce a molecular model of the 16-kDa proteolipid complex. <Capitalized> Transmembrane helical contacts were determined using oxidative cysteine cross-linking, and accessibility of cysteines to the lipid phase was determined by their reactivity to the lipid-soluble probe N-(1-pyrenyl)maleimide. <AllCaps> A single model for organization of the four helices of each monomeric proteolipid was the best fit to the experimental data, with helix 1 lining a central pore and helix 2 and helix 3 immediately external to it and forming the principal intermolecular contacts. <Capitalized> Helix 4, containing the crucial acidic residue, is peripheral to the complex. <Capitalized> The model is consistent not only with theoretical proton transport mechanisms, but has structural similarity to the dodecameric ring complex formed by the related 8-kDa proteolipid of the F(1)F(0)-ATPase. <Capitalized> This suggests some commonality between the proton translocating mechanisms of the vacuolar and F(1)F(0)-ATPases.

 673: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Sci 1999 Sep;112 <Capitalized> Pt 18:3103-14 
 
 <Capitalized> The <PERSON  S.> pombe zfs1 gene is required to prevent septation if mitotic progression is inhibited.

 <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe cdc16p is required to limit the cell to forming a single division septum per cell cycle; the heat-sensitive loss-of-function mutant cdc16-116 completes mitosis, and then undergoes multiple rounds of septum formation without cell cleavage. cdc16p is a homologue of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae BUB2p, and has also been implicated in the spindle assembly checkpoint function in <PERSON  S.> pombe. <Capitalized> To identify other proteins involved in regulating septum formation, we have screened for multicopy suppressors of the cdc16-116 mutation. <Capitalized> In this paper, we describe one of these suppressors, zfs1. <Capitalized> The null allele (zfs1-D1) is viable. <Capitalized> However, at low temperatures it divides at a reduced size, while at higher temperatures, it partially suppresses heat sensitive mutants in genes signalling the onset of septum formation.  <Capitalized> Rozovskaia <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Tillib <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Smith> <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Sedkov <PERSON  Y,> Rozenblatt-Rosen <AllCaps> O, <Capitalized> Petruk <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Yano <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Nakamura <PERSON  T,> Ben-Simchon <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Gildea> <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Croce <AllCaps> CM, <Capitalized> Shearn <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Canaani <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Mazo <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Weizmann <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Science, <LOCATION  Rehovot,> <PERSON Israel> 
 
 <Capitalized> Trithorax (TRX) and <EndsInDigit> ASH1 belong to the trithorax group (trxG) of transcriptional activator proteins, which maintains homeotic gene expression during <Capitalized> Drosophila development. <AllCaps> TRX and <EndsInDigit> ASH1 are localized on chromosomes and share several homologous domains with other chromatin-associated proteins, including a highly conserved <AllCaps> SET domain and <AllCaps> PHD fingers. <Capitalized> Based on genetic interactions between trx and ash1 and our previous observation that association of the <AllCaps> TRX protein with polytene chromosomes is ash1 dependent, we investigated the possibility of a physical linkage between the two proteins. <Capitalized> We found that the endogenous <AllCaps> TRX and <EndsInDigit> ASH1 proteins coimmunoprecipitate from embryonic extracts and colocalize on salivary gland polytene chromosomes. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we demonstrated that <AllCaps> TRX and <EndsInDigit> ASH1 bind in vivo to a relatively small (4 kb) bxd subregion of the homeotic gene <Capitalized> Ultrabithorax (Ubx), which contains several trx response elements. <Capitalized> Analysis of the effects of ash1 mutations on the activity of this regulatory region indicates that it also contains ash1 response element(s). <Capitalized> This suggests that <EndsInDigit> ASH1 and <AllCaps> TRX act on <Capitalized> Ubx in relatively close proximity to each other. <Capitalized> Finally, <AllCaps> TRX and <EndsInDigit> ASH1 appear to interact directly through their conserved <AllCaps> SET domains, based on binding assays in vitro and in yeast and on coimmunoprecipitation assays with embryo extracts. <Capitalized> Collectively, these results suggest that <AllCaps> TRX and <EndsInDigit> ASH1 are components that interact either within <MixedCase> trxG protein complexes or between complexes that act in close proximity on regulatory <AllCaps> DNA to maintain <Capitalized> Ubx transcription.

 675: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 1999 Sep;19(9):6110-9 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast trimeric guanine nucleotide-binding protein alpha subunit, Gpa2p, controls the meiosis-specific kinase Ime2p activity in response to nutrients. 
 
 <Capitalized> Donzeau <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Bandlow <PERSON  W.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Genetik und <Capitalized> Mikrobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitat <PERSON  Munchen,> D-80638 <LOCATION  Munich,> <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Gpa2p, the alpha subunit of a heterotrimeric guanine nucleotide-binding protein (G protein), is involved in the regulation of vegetative growth and pseudohyphal development. <Capitalized> Here we report that Gpa2p also controls sporulation by interacting with the regulatory domain of Ime2p (Sme1p), a protein kinase essential for entrance of meiosis and sporulation. Protein-protein interactions between Gpa2p and Ime2p depend on the GTP-bound state of Gpa2p and correlate with down-regulation of Ime2p kinase activity in vitro. <Capitalized> Overexpression of Ime2p inhibits pseudohyphal development and enables diploid cells to sporulate even in the presence of glucose or nitrogen. <Capitalized> In contrast, overexpression of Gpa2p in cells simultaneously overproducing Ime2p results in a drastic reduction of sporulation efficiency, demonstrating an inhibitory effect of Gpa2p on Ime2p function. <Capitalized> Furthermore, deletion of <EndsInDigit> GPA2 accelerates sporulation on low-nitrogen medium. <Capitalized> These observations are consistent with the following model. <Capitalized> In glucose-containing medium, diploid cells do not sporulate because Ime2p is inactive or expressed at low levels. <Capitalized> Upon starvation, expression of Gpa2p and Ime2p is induced but sporulation is prevented as long as nitrogen is present in the medium. <Capitalized> The negative control of Ime2p kinase activity is exerted at least in part through the activated form of Gpa2p and is released as soon as nutrients are exhausted. <Capitalized> This model attributes a switch function to Gpa2p in the meiosis-pseudohyphal growth decision.

 676: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 1999 Sep;19(9):6065-75 
 
 <Capitalized> Interactions of <EndsInDigit> TLC1 (which encodes the <AllCaps> RNA subunit of telomerase), TEL1, and <EndsInDigit> MEC1 in regulating telomere length in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <PERSON  Ritchie> <AllCaps> KB, <PERSON  Mallory> <AllCaps> JC, <Capitalized> Petes <AllCaps> TD. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  North Carolina> at <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <Capitalized> Chapel <PERSON  Hill,> <LOCATION  North Carolina> 27599-3280, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, chromosomes terminate with a repetitive sequence [poly(TG(1-3))] 350 to 500 bp in length. <Capitalized> Strains with a mutation of TEL1, a homolog of the human gene (ATM) mutated in patients with ataxia telangiectasia, have short but stable telomeric repeats. <Capitalized> Mutations of <EndsInDigit> TLC1 (encoding the <AllCaps> RNA subunit of telomerase) result in strains that have continually shortening telomeres and a gradual loss of cell viability; survivors of senescence arise as a consequence of a Rad52p-dependent recombination events that amplify telomeric and subtelomeric repeats. <Capitalized> We show that a mutation in <EndsInDigit> MEC1 (a gene related in sequence to <EndsInDigit> TEL1 and ATM) reduces telomere length and that tel1 mec1 double mutant strains have a senescent phenotype similar to that found in tlc1 strains. <Capitalized> As observed in tlc1 strains, survivors of senescence in the tel1 mec1 strains occur by a Rad52p-dependent amplification of telomeric and subtelomeric repeats. <Capitalized> In addition, we find that strains with both tel1 and tlc1 mutations have a delayed loss of cell viability compared to strains with the single tlc1 mutation. <Capitalized> This result argues that the role of Tel1p in telomere maintenance is not solely a direct activation of telomerase.

 <Capitalized> Yeast aspartyl-tRNA synthetase residues interacting with tRNA(Asp) identity bases connectively contribute to tRNA(Asp) binding in the ground and transition-state complex and discriminate against non-cognate tRNAs. 
 
 <Capitalized> Eriani <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Gangloff <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <AllCaps> UPR 9002 <AllCaps> SMBMR du <AllCaps> CNRS, <Capitalized> Institut de <Capitalized> Biologie <Capitalized> Moleculaire et <Capitalized> Cellulaire, 15, rue <PERSON  Rene> <Capitalized> Descartes, <LOCATION  Strasbourg,> 67084, <PERSON France> 
 
 <Capitalized> Crystallographic studies of the aspartyl-tRNA synthetase-tRNA(Asp)complex from yeast identified on the enzyme a number of residues potentially able to interact with tRNA(Asp). <Capitalized> Alanine replacement of these residues (thought to disrupt the interactions) was used in the present study to evaluate their importance in tRNA(Asp)recognition and acylation. <Capitalized> The results showed that contacts with the acceptor <AllCaps> A of tRNA(Asp)by amino acid residues interacting through their side-chain occur only in the acylation transition state, whereas those located near the <EndsInDigit> G73 discriminator base occur also during initial binding of tRNA(Asp). <Capitalized> Interactions with the anticodon bases provide the largest free energy contribution to stability of the enzyme-tRNA complex in its ground state. <Capitalized> These contacts also favour catalysis, by acting connectively with each other and with those of G73, as shown by multiple mutant analysis. <Capitalized> This implies structural communication transmitting the anticodon recognition signal to the distally located acylation site. <Capitalized> This signal might be conveyed via tRNA(Asp)as suggested by the observed conformational change of this molecule upon interaction with AspRS. <Capitalized> From binding free energy values corresponding to the different AspRS-tRNA(Asp)interaction domains, it might be concluded that upon complex formation, the anticodon interacts first. <Capitalized> Finally, acylation efficiencies of AspRS mutants in the presence of pure tRNA(Asp)and non-fractionated <MixedCase> tRNAs indicate that residues involved in the binding of identity bases also discriminate against non-cognate tRNAs. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Resumption of rapid proliferation from lag phase in cultures of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae in poor nutrient conditions. <Capitalized> Effect of surface and intracellular signalling mechanisms. 
 
 <Capitalized> Overgaard <AllCaps> AK, <Capitalized> Kierklo <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Christiansen> <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Chrois <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Rasmussen> <AllCaps> L, <PERSON  Friis> <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Anatomy and <Capitalized> Cytology, <LOCATION  Odense> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Odense> <AllCaps> M, 5230, <LOCATION Denmark> 
 
 <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae was inoculated into a dilute synthetic minimal medium with glycerol as the carbon source. <Capitalized> The number of live cells in the cultures was determined by colony counts on agar plates. <Capitalized> Untreated control cells had doubled in number about once at the end of the first week and had gone through eight doublings by the end of the second week. <Capitalized> Addition of either 8-bromo-cyclic guanosine monophosphate (8-bromo-cGMP) or human recombinant insulin, made the cells go through 12 and 10 doublings, respectively, by the end of the first week. <Capitalized> In contrast, 8-bromo-cyclic adenosine monophosphate (8-bromo-cAMP) had only slight stimulating effects on cell multiplication, but if it was combined with phorbol-12-myristate-13-acetate (PMA) the cells went through about 12 doublings during the first week. <Capitalized> Addition of <AllCaps> LY 83583, an inhibitor of soluble guanylate cyclase, prevented cell proliferation. <PERSON  Further> addition of 8-bromo-cGMP bypassed this inhibition. <Capitalized> Singly, bradykinin or <AllCaps> PMA did not affect cell multiplication. <Capitalized> However, when these two compounds were combined, the cells went through about 10 doublings during the first week. <Capitalized> Neither bradykinin, nor <AllCaps> PMA had any releasing effect on the inhibition of <AllCaps> LY 83583. <Capitalized> These results indicate the existence of several routes leading to cell proliferation in wildtype <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae cells. <Capitalized> Copyright 1998 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 679: <AllCaps> J <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol 1999 <Capitalized> Aug 20;291(3):715-25 
 
 <Capitalized> Proteins can adopt totally different folded conformations. 
 
 <Capitalized> Damaschun <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Damaschun <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Gast> <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Zirwer <AllCaps> D. 
 
 Humboldt-Universitat zu <LOCATION  Berlin,> <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Biologie, c/o Max-Delbruck-Centrum fur <Capitalized> Molekulare <Capitalized> Medizin, Robert-Rossle-Strasse 10, <LOCATION  Berlin,> <AllCaps> PF 740238, D-13092, <LOCATION Germany> gdamasc@mdc-berlin.de 
 
 <Capitalized> The three-dimensional structure of a protein is determined by interactions between its amino acids and by interactions of the amino acids with molecules of the environment. <Capitalized> The great influence of the latter interactions is demonstrated for the enzyme phosphoglycerate kinase from yeast (PGK). <Capitalized> In the native state, <AllCaps> PGK is a compact, bilobal molecule; 35% and 13% of its amino acids are organised in the form of alpha-helices and beta-sheets, respectively. <Capitalized> The molecules unfold at acidic <MixedCase> pH and low ionic strength forming random-walk structures with a persistence length of 3 nm. <PERSON  More> than 90% of the amino acid residues of the ensemble have phi,psi-angles corresponding to those of a straight beta-chain. <Capitalized> Upon addition of 50% (v/v) trifluoroethanol to the acid-unfolded protein, the entire molecule is transformed into a rod-like, flexible alpha-helix. <Capitalized> Addition of anions, such as chloride or trichloroacetate, to the acid-unfolded protein leads to the formation of amyloid-like fibres over a period of many hours when the anion concentration exceeds a critical limit. <Capitalized> Half of the amino acid residues are then organised in beta-sheets. <PERSON  Both> of the non-natively folded states of <AllCaps> PGK contain more regular secondary structure than the native one. <Capitalized> The misfolding starts in both cases from the acid-unfolded state, in which the molecules are essentially more expanded than in other denatured states, e.g. those effected by temperature or guanidine hydrochloride. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press. 
 
 PMID: 10448049 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 680: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Bioenerg <Capitalized> Biomembr 1999 Apr;31(2):95-104 
 
 <Capitalized> The role of the amino-terminal beta-barrel domain of the alpha and beta subunits in the yeast F1-ATPase. 
 
 <LOCATION  Yao> <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Mueller> <AllCaps> DM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> The <LOCATION  Chicago> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Illinois> 60064, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The crystal structure of mitochondrial F1-ATPase indicates that the alpha and beta subunits fold into a structure defined by three domains: the top beta-barrel domain, the middle nucleotide-binding domain, and the C-terminal alpha-helix bundle domain (Abrahams et al., 1994); <Capitalized> Bianchet et al., 1998). <Capitalized> The beta-barrel domains of the alpha and beta subunits form a crown structure at the top of F1, which was suggested to stabilize it (Abrahams et al. 1994). <Capitalized> In this study, the role of the beta-barrel domain in the alpha and beta subunits of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae F1, with regard to its folding and assembly, was investigated. <Capitalized> The beta-barrel domains of yeast F1alpha and beta subunits were expressed individually and together in <Capitalized> Escherichia coli. <Capitalized> When expressed separately, the beta-barrel domain of the beta subunit formed a large aggregate structure, while the domain of the alpha subunit was predominately a monomer or dimer. <Capitalized> However, coexpression of the beta-barrel domain of alpha subunit with the beta-barrel domain of beta subunit, greatly reduced the aggregation of the beta subunit domain. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the two domains copurified in complexes with the major portion of the complex found in a small molecular weight form. <Capitalized> These results indicate that the beta-barrel domain of the alpha and beta subunits interact specifically with each other and that these interactions prevent the aggregation of the beta-barrel domain of the beta subunit. <Capitalized> These results mimic in vivo results and suggest that the interactions of the beta-barrel domains may be critical during the folding and assembly of F1.

 <Capitalized> Characterization of the role played by the <EndsInDigit> RAD59 gene of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae in ectopic recombination. 
 
 <Capitalized> Jablonovich <PERSON  Z,> <Capitalized> Liefshitz <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Steinlauf <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Kupiec <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Biotechnology, 
 
 <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> RAD52 group of genes in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae controls the repair of <AllCaps> DNA damage by a recombinational mechanism. <Capitalized> Despite the growing evidence for physical and biochemical interactions between the proteins of this repair group, mutations in individual genes show very different effects on various types of recombination. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> RAD59 gene encodes a protein with similarity to Rad52p which plays a role in the repair of damage caused by ionizing radiation. <Capitalized> In the present study we have examined the role played by the Rad59 protein in mitotic ectopic recombination and analyzed the genetic interactions with other members of the repair group. <Capitalized> We found that Rad59p plays a role in ectopic gene conversion that depends on the presence of Rad52p but is independent of the function of the RecA homologue Rad51p and of the Rad57 protein. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> RAD59 gene product also participates in the RAD1-dependent pathway of recombination between direct repeats. <Capitalized> We propose that Rad59p may act in a salvage mechanism that operates when the Rad51 filament is not functional.

 <Capitalized> Half of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae carbamoyl phosphate synthetase produces and channels carbamoyl phosphate to the fused aspartate transcarbamoylase domain. 
 
 <Capitalized> Serre <PERSON  V,> <PERSON  Guy> <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Penverne <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Lux> <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Rotgeri <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Evans> <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Herve> <AllCaps> G. 
 
 <Capitalized> Laboratoire de <Capitalized> Biochimie des <Capitalized> Signaux <Capitalized> Regulateurs <Capitalized> Cellulaires et <Capitalized> Moleculaires, <AllCaps> UMR 7631 CNRS-Universite <PERSON  Pierre> et <PERSON  Marie> <PERSON  Curie,> 96 <Capitalized> Bd <Capitalized> Raspail 75006 <LOCATION  Paris,> <PERSON France> 
 
 <Capitalized> The first two steps of the de novo pyrimidine biosynthetic pathway in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae are catalyzed by a 240-kDa bifunctional protein encoded by the ura2 locus. <Capitalized> Although the constituent enzymes, carbamoyl phosphate synthetase (CPSase) and aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) function independently, there are interdomain interactions uniquely associated with the multifunctional protein. <PERSON  Both> CPSase and ATCase are feedback inhibited by <AllCaps> UTP. <Capitalized> Moreover, the intermediate carbamoyl phosphate is channeled from the CPSase domain where it is synthesized to the ATCase domain where it is used in the synthesis of carbamoyl aspartate. <Capitalized> To better understand these processes, a recombinant plasmid was constructed that encoded a protein lacking the amidotransferase domain and the amino half of the CPSase domain, a 100-kDa chain segment. <Capitalized> The truncated complex consisted of the carboxyl half of the CPSase domain fused to the ATCase domain via the <MixedCase> pDHO domain, an inactive dihydroorotase homologue that bridges the two functional domains in the native molecule. <Capitalized> Not only was the "half CPSase" catalytically active, but it was regulated by <AllCaps> UTP to the same extent as the parent molecule. <Capitalized> In contrast, the ATCase domain was no longer sensitive to the nucleotide, suggesting that the two catalytic activities are controlled by distinct mechanisms. <PERSON  Most> remarkably, isotope dilution and transient time measurements showed that the truncated complex channels carbamoyl phosphate. <Capitalized> The overall CPSase-ATCase reaction is much less sensitive than the parent molecule to the ATCase bisubstrate analogue, N-phosphonacetyl-L-aspartate (PALA), providing evidence that the endogenously produced carbamoyl phosphate is sequestered and channeled to the ATCase active site.

 <Capitalized> Molecular modelling of lanosterol 14 alpha-demethylase (CYP51) from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae via homology with CYP102, a unique bacterial cytochrome <EndsInDigit> P450 isoform: quantitative structure-activity relationships (QSARs) within two related series of antifungal azole derivatives. 
 
 <PERSON  Lewis> <AllCaps> DF, <PERSON  Wiseman> <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Tarbit <AllCaps> MH. 
 
 <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Surrey,> <PERSON  Guildford,> <LOCATION  UK.> d.lewis@surrey.ac.uk 
 
 <Capitalized> The construction of a three-dimensional molecular model of the fungal form of cytochrome <EndsInDigit> P450 (CYP51) from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, based on homology with the haemoprotein domain of <EndsInDigit> CYP102 from <Capitalized> Bacillus megaterium (a unique bacterial <EndsInDigit> P450 of known crystal structure) is described. <Capitalized> It is found that the endogenous substrate, lanosterol, can readily occupy the putative active site of the <EndsInDigit> CYP51 model such that the known mono-oxygenation reaction, leading to C14-demethylation of lanosterol, is the preferred route of metabolism for this particular substrate. <PERSON  Key> amino acid contacts within the <EndsInDigit> CYP51 active site appear to orientate lanosterol for oxidative attack at the C14-methyl group, and the position of the substrate relative to the haem moiety is consistent with the phenyl-iron complexation studies reported by <PERSON  Tuck> et al. [J. Biol. Chem., 267, 13175-13179 (1992)]. <Capitalized> Typical azole inhibitors, such as ketoconazole, are able to fit the putative active site of <EndsInDigit> CYP51 by a combination of haem ligation, hydrogen bonding, pi-pi stacking and hydrophobic interactions within the enzyme's haem environment. <Capitalized> The mode of action of azole antifungals, as described by the modelling studies, is supported by quantitative structure-activity relationship (QSAR) analyses on two groups of structurally related fungal inhibitors. <Capitalized> Moreover, the results of molecular electrostatic isopotential (EIP) energy calculations are compatible with the proposed mode of binding between azole antifungal agents and the putative active site of CYP51, although membrane interactions may also have a role in the antifungal activity of azole derivatives.

 684: <Capitalized> Genes <Capitalized> Dev 1999 <Capitalized> Aug 1;13(15):1983-93 
 
 <Capitalized> Functional interactions of Prp8 with both splice sites at the spliceosomal catalytic center. 
 
 <Capitalized> Siatecka <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Reyes> <AllCaps> JL, <Capitalized> Konarska <AllCaps> MM. 
 
 <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Rockefeller> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10021, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <AllCaps> A <EndsInDigit> U5 <MixedCase> snRNP protein, hPrp8, interacts closely with the <AllCaps> GU dinucleotide at the 5' splice site (5'SS), forming a specific UV-inducible cross-link. <Capitalized> To test if this physical contact between the 5'SS and the carboxy-terminal region of Prp8 reflects a functional recognition of the 5'SS during spliceosome assembly, we mutagenized the corresponding region of yeast Prp8 and screened the resulting mutants for suppression of 5'SS mutations in vivo. <Capitalized> All of the isolated prp8 alleles not only suppress 5'SS but also 3'SS mutations, affecting the second catalytic step. <Capitalized> Suppression of the 5'SS mutations by prp8 alleles was also tested in the presence of U1-7U snRNA, a predicted suppressor of the U+2A mutation. <Capitalized> As expected, U1-7U efficiently suppresses prespliceosome formation, and the first, but not the second, step of U+2A pre-mRNA splicing. <Capitalized> Independently, Prp8 functionally interacts with both splice sites at the later stage of splicing, affecting the efficiency of the second catalytic step. <Capitalized> The striking proximity of two of the prp8 suppressor mutations to the site of the 5'SS:hPrp8 cross-link suggests that some protein:5'SS contacts made before the first step may be subsequently extended to accommodate the 3'SS for the second catalytic step. <Capitalized> Together, these results strongly implicate Prp8 in specific interactions at the catalytic center of the spliceosome.

 685: <Capitalized> Genes <Capitalized> Dev 1999 <Capitalized> Aug 1;13(15):1970-82 
 
 Allele-specific genetic interactions between Prp8 and <AllCaps> RNA active site residues suggest a function for Prp8 at the catalytic core of the spliceosome.

 <Capitalized> The highly conserved spliceosomal protein Prp8 is known to cross-link the critical sequences at both the 5' (GU) and 3' (YAG) ends of the intron. <Capitalized> We have identified prp8 mutants with the remarkable property of suppressing exon ligation defects due to mutations in position 2 of the 5' <AllCaps> GU, and all positions of the 3' <AllCaps> YAG. <Capitalized> The prp8 mutants also suppress mutations in position <EndsInDigit> A51 of the critical <AllCaps> ACAGAG motif in <EndsInDigit> U6 snRNA, which has been observed previously to cross-link position 2 of the 5' <AllCaps> GU. <Capitalized> Other mutations in the 5' splice site, branchpoint, and neighboring residues of the <EndsInDigit> U6 <AllCaps> ACAGAG motif are not suppressed. <Capitalized> Notably, the suppressed residues are specifically conserved from yeast to man, and from U2- to U12-dependent spliceosomes. <Capitalized> We propose that Prp8 participates in a previously unrecognized tertiary interaction between <EndsInDigit> U6 <MixedCase> snRNA and both the 5' and 3' ends of the intron. <Capitalized> This model suggests a mechanism for positioning the 3' splice site for catalysis, and assigns a fundamental role for Prp8 in pre-mRNA splicing.

 686: <Capitalized> Dev <PERSON  Genet> 1999;25(2):168-79 
 
 <Capitalized> Enhancer of split [E(spl)(D)] is a gro-independent, hypermorphic mutation in Drosophila. 
 
 <PERSON  Nagel> <AllCaps> AC, <PERSON  Yu> <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Preiss <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Universitat <Capitalized> Hohenheim, <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Genetik, <LOCATION  Stuttgart,> <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Enhancer of split [E(spl)] refers to a gene complex in <Capitalized> Drosophila melanogaster, which contains a number of target genes of the <Capitalized> Notch signaling pathway. <Capitalized> The complex was originally identified by a dominant mutation E(spl)(D) that displays allele-specific interactions with a recessive mutation in the <Capitalized> Notch locus called split (N(spl)). <Capitalized> The spl phenotype is characterized by smaller eyes with irregularly spaced ommatidia, and it is strongly enhanced by E(spl)(D). <Capitalized> This enhancement is correlated with a truncation of one of the E(spl) <MixedCase> bHLH genes, m8, causing an increased stability of the mutant transcripts and an altered C-terminus in the mutant M8* protein. <Capitalized> Concurrently, an insertion of a middle repetitive element in the adjacent groucho (gro) gene was observed. <Capitalized> In this work, three different E(spl)(D) revertants (BE22, BE25, BX37), which have lost the ability to enhance N(spl) completely, were analyzed at the molecular level. <Capitalized> In each case, the structure of the mutant M8* protein was affected, suggesting a specific involvement of the aberrant protein in the enhancement of the spl phenotype. <Capitalized> This hypothesis is supported by the finding that a perfect phenocopy of spl enhancement can be achieved with hybrid constructs, where the altered C-terminus of M8* was fused to other E(spl) <MixedCase> bHLH proteins. <PERSON  Thus,> the ability to interact with N(spl) is not restricted to M8* but instead can be induced by an appropriate mutation in other E(spl) <MixedCase> bHLH genes within the context of N(spl). <Capitalized> In a N(spl) background, E(spl)(D) behaves like a hyperactive <EndsInDigit> M8 mutation. <Capitalized> However, the mutant M8* protein has lost the ability of binding to the corepressor <PERSON  Gro,> which is an essential feature for normal E(spl) activity. <Capitalized> Yet, other protein interactions, notably those with other <MixedCase> bHLH proteins of either E(spl) or proneural family, are still observed. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that the structural changes associated with the E(spl)(D) mutant protein are the primary cause for the phenotypic interactions with the recessive <Capitalized> Notch mutation N(spl). <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

 <Capitalized> Arshava <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Breslav <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Antohi <AllCaps> O, <PERSON  Stark> <AllCaps> RE, <Capitalized> Garbow <AllCaps> JR, <PERSON  Becker> <AllCaps> JM, <Capitalized> Naider <AllCaps> F. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Staten <Capitalized> Island and the <Capitalized> Graduate <PERSON  School> of the <Capitalized> City <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  New York,> 10314, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The utility of rotational echo double resonance (REDOR) <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy for determining the conformations of linear peptides has been examined critically using a series of crystalline and amorphous samples. <Capitalized> The focus of the present work was the evaluation of long-distance (> 5 A) interactions using 13C-15N dephasing. <Capitalized> Detailed studies of specifically labeled melanostatin and synthetic analogs of the alpha-factor yeast mating hormone show that nitrogen-dephased, carbon-observe <AllCaps> REDOR measurements are reliable for distances up to 6.0 <AllCaps> A, and that dipolar interactions can be detected for distances up to 7 <AllCaps> A. <Capitalized> By contrast, nitrogen-observe <AllCaps> REDOR gives reliable results only for distances shorter than 5.0 <AllCaps> A. <Capitalized> To measure distances accurately, <AllCaps> REDOR data must be corrected for the effects of natural-abundance spins. <Capitalized> These corrections are particularly important for measuring long distances, which are of the greatest value for determining peptide secondary structure. <Capitalized> We have developed a spherical shell model for calculating the effect of these background spins. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> REDOR studies also indicate that in a lyophilized powder, the tridecapeptide alpha-factor mating pheromone from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae (WHWLQLKPGQPMY) probably exists as a distribution of different turn structures around the <AllCaps> KPGQ region. <Capitalized> This finding revises previous solid-state <AllCaps> NMR studies on this peptide, which concluded alpha-factor assumes a distorted type-I beta-turn in the Pro-Gly central region of the molecule [J.R. <Capitalized> Garbow, <AllCaps> M. <Capitalized> Breslav, <AllCaps> O. <Capitalized> Antohi, <AllCaps> F. <Capitalized> Naider, <Capitalized> Biochemistry, 33 (1994) 10094].

 <Capitalized> The mushroom-producing fungus <Capitalized> Schizophyllum commune has thousands of mating types defined, in part, by numerous lipopeptide pheromones and their <AllCaps> G protein-linked receptors. <Capitalized> Compatible combinations of pheromones and receptors encoded by different mating types regulate a pathway of sexual development leading to mushroom formation and meiosis. <AllCaps> A complex set of pheromone-receptor interactions maximizes the likelihood of outbreeding; for example, a single pheromone can activate more than one receptor and a single receptor can be activated by more than one pheromone. <Capitalized> The current study demonstrates that the sex pheromones and receptors of <Capitalized> Schizophyllum, when expressed in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, can substitute for endogenous pheromone and receptor and induce the yeast pheromone response pathway through the yeast <AllCaps> G protein. <Capitalized> Secretion of active <Capitalized> Schizophyllum pheromone requires some, but not all, of the biosynthetic machinery used by the yeast lipopeptide pheromone a-factor. <Capitalized> The specificity of interaction among pheromone-receptor pairs in <Capitalized> Schizophyllum was reproduced in yeast, thus providing a powerful system for exploring molecular aspects of pheromone-receptor interactions for a class of seven-transmembrane-domain receptors common to a wide range of organisms.

(1994) <Capitalized> Biochemistry 33, 5630-5635; <Capitalized> Baburina, I., et al. (1996) <Capitalized> Biochemistry 35, 10249-10255], that information, via the substrate bound at C221, is transmitted to <EndsInDigit> H92 on the alpha domain, across the domain divide from <EndsInDigit> C221 [Baburina, <AllCaps> I. <COMPANY > et al. (1998) <Capitalized> Biochemistry 37, 1235-1244], thence to <EndsInDigit> E91 on the alpha domain, and then on to <EndsInDigit> W412 on the gamma domain [Li, H., and <LOCATION  Jordan,> <AllCaps> F. (1999) <Capitalized> Biochemistry 38, 10004-10012] and to the active site thiamin diphosphate located at the interface of the alpha and gamma domains [Arjunan, D., et al. (1996) <AllCaps> J. <PERSON Mol> Biol. 256, 590-600]. <Capitalized> Substitution at <EndsInDigit> E91 with <PERSON  Q,> <AllCaps> D, or <AllCaps> A led to modest reductions in the specific activity (4-, 5-, and 30-fold), as well as in both the turnover number and the catalytic efficiency, in that order. <Capitalized> Interestingly, the <PERSON  Hill> coefficient was only slightly reduced for the E91D variant, but cooperativity was virtually abolished for the E91Q and E91A variants. <Capitalized> The thermal stability of the variants was reduced in the following order: wild type > E91Q > E91D > E91A; circular dichroism and fluorescence experiments also demonstrated that the tertiary structure of the enzyme was affected by these substitutions. <Capitalized> The variants could be purified as apoenzymes, demonstrating their impaired ability to bind thiamin diphosphate. <Capitalized> Apparently, the charge at residue 91 is quite important for maintaining optimal cooperativity. <Capitalized> To maintain strong domain-domain interactions, the length of the side chain at position 91 with hydrogen bonding potential to <EndsInDigit> W412 is sufficient.

Sec7p itself has an important role in the yeast secretory pathway. <Capitalized> However, its mechanism of action is not yet understood. <Capitalized> We show that all members of the Sec7-domain family exhibit distinct genetic interactions with the <AllCaps> YPT genes. <Capitalized> Biochemical assays demonstrate that, although the homology between the members of the Sec7-domain family is relatively low (20-35%) and limited to a small domain, they all can act as guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) for <Capitalized> Arf proteins, but not for <Capitalized> Ypt GTPases. <Capitalized> The Sec7-domain of Sec7p is sufficient for this activity. <Capitalized> Interestingly, the Sec7 domain activity is inhibited by brefeldin <AllCaps> A (BFA), a fungal metabolite that inhibits some of the Arf-GEFs, indicating that this domain is a target for <AllCaps> BFA. <Capitalized> These results demonstrate that the ability to act as Arf-GEFs is a general property of all Sec7-domain proteins in yeast. <Capitalized> The genetic interactions observed between <Capitalized> Arf GEFs and <Capitalized> Ypt GTPases suggest the existence of a Ypt-Arf GTPase cascade in the secretory pathway.

ubiquitin protein has been studied by heteronuclear multidimensional <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy. <Capitalized> Chemical shift perturbation of backbone (1)H(N), (15)N, and (13)C(alpha) resonances of couple <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis to the vectorial ion transport are not yet understood, but unveiling structures that participate in <AllCaps> ATP binding and in the formation of the ionophore might help to gain insight into this process. <Capitalized> Looking at the alpha- and beta-phosphates of <AllCaps> ATP as a pyrophosphate molecule, we found that peptides highly conserved among all soluble inorganic pyrophosphatases are also present in ion-transporting ATPases. <Capitalized> Included therein are Glu48 and Lys56 of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae pyrophosphatase (SCE1-PPase) that are essential for the activity of this enzyme and have been shown in crystallographic analysis to interact with phosphate molecules. <Capitalized> To test the hypothesis that equivalent amino acids are also essential for the activity of ion-transporting ATPases, Glu472 and Lys480 of the sodium pump alpha 1 subunit corresponding to Glu48 and Lys56 of SCE1-PPase were mutated to various amino acids. <Capitalized> Mutants of the sodium pump alpha1 subunit were expressed in yeast and analyzed for their ATPase activity and their ability to bind ouabain in the presence of either <AllCaps> ATP, Mg2+, and Na+ or phosphate and Mg2+. <Capitalized> All four mutants investigated, Glu472Ala, Glu472Asp, Lys480Ala, and Lys480Arg, display only a fraction of the ATPase activity obtained with the wild-type enzyme. <Capitalized> The same applies with respect to their ability to bind ouabain, where maximum ouabain binding to the mutants accounts for only about 10% of the binding obtained with the wild-type enzyme. <Capitalized> On the basis of our results, we conclude that Glu472 and Lys480 are essential for the activity of the sodium pump. <Capitalized> Their function is probably to arrest the alpha- and beta-phosphate groups of <AllCaps> ATP in a proper position prior to hydrolysis of the gamma-phosphate group. <Capitalized> The identification of these amino acids as essential components of the ATP-recognizing mechanism of the pump has resulted in a testable hypothesis for the initial interactions of the sodium pump, and possibly of other P-type ATPases, with <AllCaps> ATP.  <PERSON  Geyer> <AllCaps> CR, Colman-Lerner <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Brent> <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Sciences <Capitalized> Institute, 2168 <PERSON  Shattuck> <Capitalized> Avenue, <LOCATION  Berkeley,> <AllCaps> CA 94704, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> We selected peptide aptamers from combinatorial libraries that disrupted cell-cycle arrest caused by mating pheromone in yeast. <Capitalized> We used these aptamers as baits in two-hybrid hunts to identify genes involved in cell-cycle arrest. <Capitalized> These experiments identified genes known to function in the pathway, as well as a protein kinase, the <EndsInDigit> CBK1 product, whose function was not known. <Capitalized> We used a modified two-hybrid system to identify specific interactions disrupted by these aptamers. <Capitalized> These experiments demonstrate a means to perform "genetics" on the protein complement of a cell without altering its genetic material. <Capitalized> Peptide aptamers can be identified that disrupt a process. <Capitalized> These aptamers can then be used as affinity reagents to identify individual proteins and protein interactions needed for the process. <PERSON  Forward> genetic analysis with peptide aptamer "mutagens" should be particularly useful in elucidating genetic networks in organisms and processes for which classical genetics is not feasible.

 <Capitalized> The two-hybrid system in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae is a genetic approach for the detection of of protein-protein interactions in vivo. <Capitalized> This technology relies on the the activity of separated DNA-binding and transactivation domains of specific transcription factors to reconstitute an active transcription factor complex if interacting proteins are fused to these domains. <Capitalized> Interactions are consequently detected through the activity of reporter genes. <Capitalized> The two-hybrid technology has been successfully applied for the determination of interactions between numerous proteins of several organisms. <Capitalized> Conventional reporter systems, such as the beta-galacatosidase from <Capitalized> Escherichia coli, suffer from a variety of drawbacks, including the requirement for external substrates. <Capitalized> In this report, we describe an alternative version of the two hybrid system using the combined advantages of the copper-inducible transcription factor <Capitalized> Acel together with the yeast metallothionein gene <EndsInDigit> CUP1 and the green fluorescence protein from aquatic invertebrates as reporters. <Capitalized> This technique allows the copper-dependent monitoring of protein-protein interactions in living yeast cells.

 <Capitalized> Transcriptional activation of the <AllCaps> HIV type 1 (HIV-1) long terminal repeat (LTR) promoter element by the viral <Capitalized> Tat protein is an essential step in the HIV-1 life cycle. <Capitalized> Tat function is mediated by the <AllCaps> TAR <AllCaps> RNA target element encoded within the <AllCaps> LTR and is known to require the recruitment of a complex consisting of <Capitalized> Tat and the cyclin <EndsInDigit> T1 (CycT1) component of positive transcription elongation factor b (P-TEFb) to <AllCaps> TAR. <Capitalized> Here, we demonstrate that both <AllCaps> TAR and <Capitalized> Tat become entirely dispensable for activation of the HIV-1 <AllCaps> LTR promoter when CycT1/P-TEFb is artificially recruited to a heterologous promoter proximal <AllCaps> RNA target. <Capitalized> The level of activation observed was indistinguishable from the level induced by <Capitalized> Tat and was neither inhibited nor increased when <Capitalized> Tat was expressed in trans. <Capitalized> Activation by artificially recruited CycT1 depended on the ability to bind the <EndsInDigit> CDK9 component of P-TEFb. <Capitalized> In contrast, although binding to both <Capitalized> Tat and <AllCaps> TAR was essential for the ability of CycT1 to act as a <Capitalized> Tat cofactor, these interactions became dispensable when CycT1 was directly recruited to the <AllCaps> LTR. <Capitalized> Importantly, activation of the <AllCaps> LTR both by <Capitalized> Tat and by directly recruited CycT1 was found to be at the level of transcription elongation. <Capitalized> Together, these data demonstrate that recruitment of CycT1/P-TEFb to the HIV-1 <AllCaps> LTR is fully sufficient to activate this promoter element and imply that the sole role of the Tat/TAR axis in viral transcription is to permit the recruitment of CycT1/P-TEFb.

 712: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 1999 <PERSON  Jul> 9;274(28):19617-22 
 
 N-terminal tail export from the mitochondrial matrix. <Capitalized> Adherence to the prokaryotic "positive-inside" rule of membrane protein topology. 
 
 <Capitalized> Rojo <AllCaps> EE, <PERSON  Guiard> <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Neupert <PERSON  W,> <PERSON  Stuart> <AllCaps> RA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Physiologische <Capitalized> Chemie der <Capitalized> Universitat <PERSON  Munchen,> <Capitalized> Goethestrasse 33, 80336 <PERSON  Munchen,> <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Export of N-terminal tails of mitochondrial inner membrane proteins from the mitochondrial matrix is a membrane potential-dependent process, mediated by the Oxa1p translocation machinery. <Capitalized> The hydrophilic segments of these membrane proteins, which undergo export, display a characteristic charge profile where intermembrane space-localized segments bear a net negative charge, whereas those remaining in the matrix have a net positive one. <Capitalized> Using a model protein, preSu9(1-112)-dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which undergoes Oxa1p-mediated N-tail export, we demonstrate here that the net charge of N- and C-flanking regions of the transmembrane domain play a critical role in determining the orientation of the insertion process. <Capitalized> The N-tail must bear a net negative charge to be exported to the intermembrane space. <Capitalized> Furthermore, a net positive charge of the C-terminal region supports this N-tail export event. <Capitalized> These data provide experimental evidence that protein export in mitochondria adheres to the "positive-inside" rule, described for sec-independent sorting of membrane proteins in prokaryotes. <Capitalized> We propose here that the importance of a charge profile reflects a need for specific protein-protein interactions to occur in the export reaction, presumably at the level of the Oxa1p export machinery.

 <Capitalized> In vivo analysis of the domains of yeast Rvs167p suggests Rvs167p function is mediated through multiple protein interactions. 
 
 <PERSON  Colwill> <AllCaps> K, <PERSON  Field> <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Moore> <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Friesen <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Andrews> <AllCaps> B. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Toronto,> <LOCATION  Toronto,> <LOCATION  Ontario> M5S 1A8, <PERSON Canada> 
 
 <Capitalized> Morphological changes during cell division in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae are controlled by cell-cycle regulators. <Capitalized> The Pcl-Pho85p kinase complex has been implicated in the regulation of the actin cytoskeleton at least in part through Rvs167p. Rvs167p consists of three domains called <AllCaps> BAR, <AllCaps> GPA, and SH3. <Capitalized> Using a two-hybrid assay, we demonstrated that each region of Rvs167p participates in protein-protein interactions: the <AllCaps> BAR domain bound the <AllCaps> BAR domain of another Rvs167p protein and that of Rvs161p, the <AllCaps> GPA region bound Pcl2p, and the <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain bound Abp1p. <Capitalized> We identified Rvs167p as a Las17p/Bee1p-interacting protein in a two-hybrid screen and showed that Las17p/Bee1p bound the <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain of Rvs167p. <Capitalized> We tested the extent to which the Rvs167p protein domains rescued phenotypes associated with deletion of RVS167: salt sensitivity, random budding, and endocytosis and sporulation defects. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> BAR domain was sufficient for full or partial rescue of all rvs167 mutant phenotypes tested but not required for the sporulation defect for which the <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain was also sufficient. <Capitalized> Overexpression of Rvs167p inhibits cell growth. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> BAR domain was essential for this inhibition and the <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain had only a minor effect. Rvs167p may link the cell cycle regulator Pcl-Pho85p kinase and the actin cytoskeleton. <Capitalized> We propose that Rvs167p is activated by phosphorylation in its <AllCaps> GPA region by the Pcl-Pho85p kinase. <Capitalized> Upon activation, Rvs167p enters a multiprotein complex, making critical contacts in its <AllCaps> BAR domain and redundant or minor contacts with its <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain.
