 <Capitalized> Equilibrium folding properties of the yeast prion protein determinant Ure2. 
 
 <PERSON  Perrett> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Freeman> <AllCaps> SJ, <PERSON  Butler> <AllCaps> PJ, <Capitalized> Fersht <AllCaps> AR. 
 
 
 
 <Capitalized> Centre for <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Engineering, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Cambridge,> <Capitalized> Lensfield <Capitalized> Road, <LOCATION  Cambridge,> <EndsInDigit> CB2 1EW, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast non-Mendelian factor [URE3] propagates by a prion-like mechanism, involving aggregation of the chromosomally encoded protein Ure2. <Capitalized> The [URE3] phenotype is equivalent to loss of function of Ure2, a protein involved in regulation of nitrogen metabolism. <Capitalized> The prion-like behaviour of Ure2 in vivo is dependent on the first 65 amino acid residues of its N-terminal region which contains a highly repetitive sequence rich in asparagine. <Capitalized> This region has been termed the prion-determining domain (PrD). <Capitalized> Removal of as little as residues 2-20 of the protein is sufficient to prevent occurrence of the [URE3] phenotype. <Capitalized> Removal of the PrD does not affect the regulatory activity of Ure2. <Capitalized> The C-terminal portion of the protein has homology to glutathione <PERSON  S> -transferases, which are dimeric proteins. <Capitalized> We have produced the Ure2 protein to high yield in <Capitalized> Escherichia coli from a synthetic gene. <Capitalized> The recombinant purified protein is shown to be a dimer. <Capitalized> The stability, folding and oligomeric state of Ure2 and a series of N-terminally truncated or deleted variants were studied and compared. <Capitalized> The stability of Ure2, DeltaGD-N, H2O, determined by chemical denaturation and monitored by fluorescence, is 12.1(+/-0.4) kcal mol-1at 25 degrees <AllCaps> C and <MixedCase> pH 8.4. <AllCaps> A range of structural probes show a single, coincident unfolding transition, which is invariant over a 550-fold change in protein concentration. <Capitalized> The stability is the same within error for Ure2 variants lacking all or part of the prion-determining domain. <Capitalized> The data indicate that in the folded protein the PrD is in an unstructured conformation and does not form specific intra- or intermolecular interactions at micromolar protein concentrations. <Capitalized> This suggests that the C-terminal domain may stabilise the PrD against prion formation by steric means, and implies that the PrD does not induce prion formation by altering the thermodynamic stability of the folded protein. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 715: <Capitalized> Biochemistry 1999 <Capitalized> Jun 22;38(25):8138-49 
 
 <Capitalized> Thermal versus guanidine-induced unfolding of ubiquitin. <Capitalized> An analysis in terms of the contributions from charge-charge interactions to protein stability. 
 
 Ibarra-Molero <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Loladze <AllCaps> VV, <Capitalized> Makhatadze <AllCaps> GI, Sanchez-Ruiz <AllCaps> JM. 
 
 <Capitalized> Facultad de <Capitalized> Ciencias, <Capitalized> Departamento de <Capitalized> Quimica <Capitalized> Fisica, <Capitalized> Universidad de <PERSON  Granada,> <PERSON Spain> 
 
 <Capitalized> We have characterized the guanidine-induced unfolding of both yeast and bovine ubiquitin at 25 degrees <AllCaps> C and in the acidic <MixedCase> pH range on the basis of fluorescence and circular dichroism measurements. <Capitalized> Unfolding <PERSON  Gibbs> energy changes calculated by linear extrapolation from high guanidine unfolding data are found to depend very weakly on pH. <AllCaps> A simple explanation for this result involves the two following assumptions: (1) charged atoms of ionizable groups are exposed to the solvent in native ubiquitin (as supported by accessible surface area calculations), and <PERSON  Gibbs> energy contributions associated with charge desolvation upon folding (a source of <MixedCase> pK shifts) are small; (2) charge-charge interactions (another source of <MixedCase> pK shifts upon folding) are screened out in concentrated guanidinium chloride solutions. <Capitalized> We have also characterized the thermal unfolding of both proteins using differential scanning calorimetry. <Capitalized> Unfolding <PERSON  Gibbs> energy changes calculated from the calorimetric data do depend strongly on pH, a result that we attribute to the <MixedCase> pH dependence of charge-charge interactions (not eliminated in the absence of guanidine). <Capitalized> In fact, we find good agreement between the difference between the two series of experimental unfolding <PERSON  Gibbs> energy changes (determined from high guanidine unfolding data by linear extrapolation and from thermal denaturation data in the absence of guanidine) and the theoretical estimates of the contribution from charge-charge interactions to the <PERSON  Gibbs> energy change for ubiquitin unfolding obtained by using the solvent-accessibility-corrected Tanford-Kirkwood model, together with the Bashford-Karplus (reduced-set-of-sites) approximation. <Capitalized> This contribution is found to be stabilizing at neutral pH, because most charged groups on the native protein interact mainly with groups of the opposite charge, a fact that, together with the absence of large charge-desolvation contributions, may explain the high stability of ubiquitin at neutral pH. <Capitalized> In general, our analysis suggests the possibility of enhancing protein thermal stability by adequately redesigning the distribution of solvent-exposed, charged residues on the native protein surface.

 716: <Capitalized> Protein <Capitalized> Sci 1999 Jun;8(6):1250-6 
 
 <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Schiff> base complex of yeast 5-aminolaevulinic acid dehydratase with laevulinic acid. 
 
 <PERSON  Erskine> <AllCaps> PT, <PERSON  Newbold> <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Roper> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Coker> <AllCaps> A, <LOCATION  Warren> <AllCaps> MJ, Shoolingin-Jordan <AllCaps> PM, <PERSON  Wood> <AllCaps> SP, <PERSON  Cooper> <AllCaps> JB.

 <Capitalized> The X-ray structure of the complex formed between yeast 5-aminolaevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) and the inhibitor laevulinic acid has been determined at 2.15 <AllCaps> A resolution. <Capitalized> The inhibitor binds by forming a <PERSON  Schiff> base link with one of the two invariant lysines at the catalytic center: Lys263. <Capitalized> It is known that this lysine forms a <PERSON  Schiff> base link with substrate bound at the enzyme's so-called P-site. <Capitalized> The carboxyl group of laevulinic acid makes hydrogen bonds with the side-chain-OH groups of Tyr329 and Ser290, as well as with the main-chain >NH group of Ser290. <Capitalized> The aliphatic moiety of the inhibitor makes hydrophobic interactions with surrounding aromatic residues in the protein including Phe219, which resides in the flap covering the active site. <Capitalized> Our analysis strongly suggests that the same interactions will be made by P-side substrate and also indicates that the substrate that binds at the enzyme's A-site will interact with the enzyme's zinc ion bound by three cysteines (133, 135, and 143). <Capitalized> Inhibitor binding caused a substantial ordering of the active site flap (residues 217-235), which was largely invisible in the native electron density map and indicates that this highly conserved yet flexible region has a specific role in substrate binding during catalysis.

 <Capitalized> Melin <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Schnurer <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Wagner> <AllCaps> EG.

 <Capitalized> In natural environments bacteria and filamentous fungi often compete for the same resources. <Capitalized> Consequently, production of antibiotic secondary metabolites and defence mechanisms against these compounds have evolved in these organisms. <Capitalized> An experimental model has been developed to study the response in fungi exposed to one such antibiotic. <Capitalized> The filamentous fungus <Capitalized> Aspergillus nidulans was treated with bafilomycin B1, a Streptomyces-produced antibiotic which reduces radial growth rate and induces morphological changes in fungi. <MixedCase> mRNA differential display was used to study changes in fungal gene expression. <Capitalized> For five genes, changes in abundance of the corresponding mRNAs, directly or indirectly caused by bafilomycin, were observed. <Capitalized> Of these, three were up-regulated and two repressed. <Capitalized> With four of these the change in <MixedCase> mRNA abundance measured ranged from 10- to 60-fold. <Capitalized> However, for one gene the <MixedCase> mRNA was only detected after bafilomycin treatment. <Capitalized> One of the down-regulated <MixedCase> mRNAs encodes ASPND1, a glycoprotein that belongs to a known family of antigens identified in aspergilloma patients. <Capitalized> One up-regulated <MixedCase> mRNA shows sequence similarities, at the amino acid level, with a cell-wall protein of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The remaining three genes were also cloned and sequenced; their sequences do not correspond to known genes in <AllCaps> A. nidulans, and no similarities with published nucleotide or protein sequences in other organisms were found. <Capitalized> These results indicate the feasibility of using <MixedCase> mRNA differential display to study interactions between bacteria and filamentous fungi.

 <Capitalized> Wahle <AllCaps> E, <Capitalized> Ruegsegger <PERSON  U.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Biochemie, Martin-Luther-Universitat Halle-Wittenberg, <LOCATION Germany> ewahle@biochemtech.uni-halle.de 
 
 3'-Ends of almost all eukaryotic <MixedCase> mRNAs are generated by endonucleolytic cleavage and addition of a poly(A) tail. <Capitalized> In mammalian cells, the reaction depends on the sequence <AllCaps> AAUAAA upstream of the cleavage site, a degenerate GU-rich sequence element downstream of the cleavage site and stimulatory sequences upstream of <AllCaps> AAUAAA. <PERSON  Six> factors have been identified that carry out the two reactions. <Capitalized> With a single exception, they have been purified to homogeneity and <MixedCase> cDNAs for 11 subunits have been cloned. <Capitalized> Some of the cooperative RNA-protein and protein-protein interactions within the processing complex have been analyzed, but many details, including the identity of the endonuclease, remain unknown. <Capitalized> Several examples of regulated polyadenylation are being analyzed at the molecular level. <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, sequences directing cleavage and polyadenylation are more degenerate than in metazoans, and a downstream element has not been identified. <Capitalized> The list of processing factors may be complete now with approximately a dozen polypeptides, but their functions in the reaction are largely unknown. 3'-Processing is known to be coupled to transcription. <Capitalized> This connection is thought to involve interactions of processing factors with the <MixedCase> mRNA cap as well as with <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II.

 <PERSON  Frankel> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Clarke> <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry & <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology <Capitalized> Institute, <AllCaps> UCLA, <LOCATION  Los Angeles,> <LOCATION  California> 90095-1569, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Type <AllCaps> I protein arginine N-methyltransferases catalyze the formation of omega-NG-monomethylarginine and asymmetric omega-NG, NG-dimethylarginine residues using S-adenosyl-l-methionine as the methyl donor. <Capitalized> In vitro these enzymes can modify a number of soluble methyl-accepting substrates in yeast and mammalian cell extracts including several species that interact with <AllCaps> RNA. <Capitalized> We treated normal and hypomethylated <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and <EndsInDigit> RAT1 cell extracts with RNase prior to in vitro methylation by recombinant protein N-arginine methyltransferases and found that the methylation of certain polypeptides is enhanced up to 12-fold whereas that of others is diminished. 2-D gel electrophoresis of RNase-treated yeast extracts allowed us to tentatively identify the glycine- and arginine-rich (GAR) domain-containing proteins Gar1, Nop1, Sbp1, and Npl3 as major methyl-acceptors based on their known isoelectric points and apparent molecular weights. <Capitalized> These results suggest that the methylation and RNA-binding of <AllCaps> GAR domain-containing proteins in vivo may regulate protein-nucleic acid or protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Modulation of human heat shock factor trimerization by the linker domain. 
 
 <PERSON  Liu> <AllCaps> PC, <PERSON  Thiele> <AllCaps> DJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor,> <LOCATION  Michigan> 48109-0606, <LOCATION  USA.> dthiele@umich.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> Heat shock transcription factors (HSFs) are stress-responsive proteins that activate the expression of heat shock genes and are highly conserved from bakers' yeast to humans. <Capitalized> Under basal conditions, the human <EndsInDigit> HSF1 protein is maintained as an inactive monomer through intramolecular interactions between two coiled-coil domains and interactions with heat shock proteins; upon environmental, pharmacological, or physiological stress, <EndsInDigit> HSF1 is converted to a homotrimer that binds to its cognate <AllCaps> DNA binding site with high affinity. <Capitalized> To dissect regions of <EndsInDigit> HSF1 that make important contributions to the stability of the monomer under unstressed conditions, we have used functional complementation in bakers' yeast as a facile assay system. <Capitalized> Whereas wild-type human <EndsInDigit> HSF1 is restrained as an inactive monomer in yeast that is unable to substitute for the essential yeast <AllCaps> HSF protein, mutations in the linker region between the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain and the first coiled-coil allow <EndsInDigit> HSF1 to homotrimerize and rescue the viability defect of a <MixedCase> hsfDelta strain. <PERSON  Fine> mapping by functional analysis of HSF1-HSF2 chimeras and point mutagenesis revealed that a small region in the amino-terminal portion of the <EndsInDigit> HSF1 linker is required for maintenance of <EndsInDigit> HSF1 in the monomeric state in both yeast and in transfected human 293 cells. <Capitalized> Although linker regions in transcription factors are known to modulate <AllCaps> DNA binding specificity, our studies suggest that the human <EndsInDigit> HSF1 linker plays no role in determining <EndsInDigit> HSF1 binding preferences in vivo but is a critical determinant in regulating the <EndsInDigit> HSF1 monomer-trimer equilibrium.

 <AllCaps> A two-hybrid dual bait system to discriminate specificity of protein interactions. 
 
 <Capitalized> Serebriiskii <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Khazak <PERSON  V,> <Capitalized> Golemis <AllCaps> EA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Basic <Capitalized> Science, <PERSON  Fox> <PERSON  Chase> <Capitalized> Cancer <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Philadelphia,> <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> 19111, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Biological regulatory systems require the specific organization of proteins into multicomponent complexes. <Capitalized> Two hybrid systems have been used to identify novel components of signaling networks based on interactions with defined partner proteins. <Capitalized> An important issue in the use of two-hybrid systems has been the degree to which interacting proteins distinguish their biological partner from evolutionarily conserved related proteins and the degree to which observed interactions are specific. <Capitalized> We adapted the basic two-hybrid strategy to create a novel dual bait system designed to allow single-step screening of libraries for proteins that interact with protein 1 of interest, fused to <AllCaps> DNA binding domain <AllCaps> A (LexA), but do not interact with protein 2, fused to <AllCaps> DNA binding domain <AllCaps> B (lambda cI). <Capitalized> Using the selective interactions of <PERSON  Ras> and Krev-1(Rap1A) with <Capitalized> Raf, RalGDS, and Krit1 as a model, we systematically compared LexA- and cI-fused baits and reporters. <Capitalized> The LexA and <MixedCase> cI baitr reporter systems are well matched for level of bait expression and sensitivity range for interaction detection and allow effective isolation of specifically interacting protein pairs against a nonspecific background. <Capitalized> These reagents should prove useful to refine the selectivity of library screens, to reduce the isolation of false positives in such screens, and to perform directed analyses of sequence elements governing the interaction of a single protein with multiple partners.

 <Capitalized> The Cdc42p GTPase is involved in a G2/M morphogenetic checkpoint regulating the apical-isotropic switch and nuclear division in yeast. 
 
 <PERSON  Richman> <AllCaps> TJ, <PERSON  Sawyer> <AllCaps> MM, <PERSON  Johnson> <AllCaps> DI. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and the <PERSON  Markey> <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Vermont, <LOCATION  Burlington,> <Capitalized> Vermont 05405, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The Cdc42p GTPase is involved in the signal transduction cascades controlling bud emergence and polarized cell growth in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Cells expressing the cdc42(V44A) effector domain mutant allele displayed morphological defects of highly elongated and multielongated budded cells indicative of a defect in the apical-isotropic switch in bud growth. <Capitalized> In addition, these cells contained one, two, or multiple nuclei indicative of a G2/M delay in nuclear division and also a defect in cytokinesis and/or cell separation. <Capitalized> Actin and chitin were delocalized, and septin ring structure was aberrant and partially delocalized to the tips of elongated cdc42(V44A) cells; however, Cdc42(V44A)p localization was normal. Two-hybrid protein analyses showed that the V44A mutation interfered with Cdc42p's interactions with Cla4p, a p21(Cdc42/Rac)-activated kinase (PAK)-like kinase, and the novel effectors Gic1p and Gic2p, but not with the Ste20p or Skm1p PAK-like kinases, the Bni1p formin, or the Iqg1p <AllCaps> IQGAP homolog. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the cdc42(V44A) morphological defects were suppressed by deletion of the Swe1p cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitory kinase and by overexpression of Cla4p, Ste20p, the Cdc12 septin protein, or the guanine nucleotide exchange factor Cdc24p. <Capitalized> In sum, these results suggest that proper Cdc42p function is essential for timely progression through the apical-isotropic switch and G2/M transition and that Cdc42(V44A)p differentially interacts with a number of effectors and regulators.

 Homo- and heterodimerization of synapsins. 
 
 <Capitalized> Hosaka <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Sudhof <AllCaps> TC. 
 
 <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Basic <Capitalized> Neuroscience and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <PERSON  Howard> <PERSON  Hughes> <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Southwestern <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <PERSON  Dallas,> <LOCATION  Texas> 75235, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In vertebrates, synapsins constitute a family of synaptic vesicle proteins encoded by three genes. <Capitalized> Synapsins contain a central ATP-binding domain, the C-domain, that is highly homologous between synapsins and evolutionarily conserved in invertebrates. <Capitalized> The crystal structure of the C-domain from synapsin <AllCaps> I revealed that it constitutes a large (>300 amino acids), independently folded domain that forms a tight dimer with or without bound <AllCaps> ATP. <Capitalized> We now show that the C-domains of all synapsins form homodimers, and that in addition, C-domains from different synapsins associate into heterodimers. <Capitalized> This conclusion is based on four findings: 1) in yeast two-hybrid screens with full-length synapsin IIa as a bait, the most frequently isolated prey <MixedCase> cDNAs encoded the C-domain of synapsins; 2) quantitative yeast two-hybrid protein-protein binding assays demonstrated pairwise strong interactions between all synapsins; 3) immunoprecipitations from transfected <AllCaps> COS cells confirmed that synapsin <AllCaps> II heteromultimerizes with synapsins <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> III in intact cells, and similar results were obtained with bacterial expression systems; and 4) quantification of the synapsin <AllCaps> III level in synapsin I/II double knockout mice showed that the level of synapsin <AllCaps> III is decreased by 50%, indicating that heteromultimerization of synapsin <AllCaps> III with synapsins <AllCaps> I or <AllCaps> II occurs in vivo and is required for protein stabilization. <Capitalized> These data suggest that synapsins coat the surface of synaptic vesicles as homo- and heterodimers in which the C-domains of the various subunits have distinct regulatory properties and are flanked by variable C-terminal sequences. <Capitalized> The data also imply that synapsin <AllCaps> III does not compensate for the loss of synapsins <AllCaps> I and <AllCaps> II in the double knockout mice.

 <Capitalized> Vilela <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Ramirez> <AllCaps> CV, <LOCATION  Linz> <AllCaps> B, Rodrigues-Pousada <AllCaps> C, <PERSON McCarthy> <AllCaps> JE.

 <AllCaps> A novel form of post-transcriptional control is described. <Capitalized> The 5' untranslated region (5'UTR) of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene encoding the AP1-like transcription factor Yap2 contains two upstream open reading frames (uORF1 and uORF2). <Capitalized> The YAP2-type of <MixedCase> uORF functions as a cis-acting element that attenuates gene expression at the level of <MixedCase> mRNA turnover via termination-dependent decay. <Capitalized> Release of post-termination ribosomes from the <EndsInDigit> YAP2 5'UTR causes accelerated decay which is largely independent of the termination modulator gene UPF1. <PERSON  Both> of the <EndsInDigit> YAP2 <MixedCase> uORFs contribute to the destabilization effect. <AllCaps> A G/C-rich stop codon context, which seems to promote ribosome release, allows an <MixedCase> uORF to act as a transferable 5'UTR-destabilizing element. <Capitalized> Moreover, termination-dependent destabilization is potentiated by stable secondary structure 3' of the <MixedCase> uORF stop codon. <Capitalized> The potentiation of uORF-mediated destabilization is eliminated if the secondary structure is located further downstream of the uORF, and is also influenced by a modulatory mechanism involving eIF2. <Capitalized> Destabilization is therefore linked to the kinetics of acquisition of reinitiation-competence by post-termination ribosomes in the 5'UTR. <Capitalized> Our data explain the destabilizing properties of YAP2-type <MixedCase> uORFs and also support a more general model for the mode of action of other known uORFs, such as those in the <EndsInDigit> GCN4 mRNA.

 <Capitalized> We show here that nonspecific RNA-protein interactions can significantly enhance the biological activity of an essential <AllCaps> RNA. protein complex. <Capitalized> Bacterial glutaminyl-tRNA synthetase poorly aminoacylates yeast <MixedCase> tRNA and, as a consequence, cannot rescue a knockout allele of the gene for the yeast homologue. <Capitalized> In contrast to the bacterial protein, the yeast enzyme has an extra appended domain at the <AllCaps> N terminus. <Capitalized> Previously, we showed that fusion of this yeast-specific domain to the bacterial protein enabled it to function as a yeast enzyme in vivo and in vitro. <Capitalized> We suggested that the novel yeast-specific domain contributed to <AllCaps> RNA interactions in a way that compensated for the poor fit between the yeast <MixedCase> tRNA and bacterial enzyme. <Capitalized> Here we establish that the novel appended domain by itself binds nonspecifically to different <AllCaps> RNA structures. <Capitalized> In addition, we show that fusion of an unrelated yeast protein, Arc1p, to the bacterial enzyme also converts it into a functional yeast enzyme in vivo and in vitro. <AllCaps> A small C-terminal segment of Arc1p is necessary and sufficient for this conversion. <Capitalized> This segment was shown by others to have nonspecific <MixedCase> tRNA binding properties. <PERSON  Thus,> nonspecific <AllCaps> RNA binding interactions in general can compensate for barriers to formation of a specific and essential RNA.protein complex.

(1994) <Capitalized> Nature 370, 621-628). <Capitalized> The role of the domains was studied by making chimeric enzymes, replacing the domains from the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae enzyme with the corresponding domains from the enzyme of the thermophilic bacterium <Capitalized> Bacillus PS3. <Capitalized> The enzymes containing the chimeric alpha-, beta-, or alpha- and beta-subunits were not functional. <Capitalized> However, gain-of-function mutations were obtained from the strain containing the enzyme with the chimeric PS3/yeast beta-subunit. <Capitalized> The gain-of-function mutations were all in codons encoding the beta-barrel domain of the beta-subunit, and the residues appear to map out a region of subunit-subunit interactions.  Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (DRPLA) is an autosomal dominant neuro degrees enerative disorder associated with CAG/glutamine repeat expansion. <Capitalized> While the <AllCaps> DRPLA gene is ubiquitously expressed, neuron death occurs in specific anatomical areas of the brain. <Capitalized> This predicts that the <AllCaps> DRPLA protein interacts with other proteins and that these interactions may play a role in pathogenesis. <Capitalized> Here, we describe a protein that binds to the <AllCaps> DRPLA product. <Capitalized> One of the clones isolated with a yeast two-hybrid system was identified as a human homolog of the insulin receptor tyrosine kinase substrate protein of 53 <MixedCase> kDa (IRSp53). <Capitalized> The gene produced two <MixedCase> mRNA forms by differential splicing and encoded 552 and 521 amino acids, respectively. <Capitalized> The longer form was mainly expressed in the brain and the shorter one in other tissues. <Capitalized> The products were phosphorylated upon stimulation of cultured cells with insulin or insulin-like growth factor 1. <Capitalized> Binding of the <AllCaps> DRPLA protein to IRSp53 was ascertained by co-immunoprecipitation with antibodies and also by co-localization in perinuclear oval dots in cells expressing engineered constructs. <AllCaps> A proline-rich region near the polyglutamine tract of the <AllCaps> DRPLA protein and the <EndsInDigit> SH3 domain of IRSp53 were involved in the binding. <Capitalized> An extended polyglutamine tract significantly reduced binding ability in yeast cells, but not in in vitro binding assays. <Capitalized> The identification of IRSp53 and other proteins detected by the yeast hybrid system predicts that <AllCaps> DRPLA functions in a signal transduction pathway coupled with insulin/IGF-1.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Massachusetts> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Technology, <LOCATION  Cambridge,> <LOCATION  Massachusetts> 02139, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, vesicles that carry proteins from the <AllCaps> ER to the <Capitalized> Golgi compartment are encapsulated by <AllCaps> COPII coat proteins. <Capitalized> We identified mutations in ten genes, designated <AllCaps> LST (lethal with sec-thirteen), that were lethal in combination with the <AllCaps> COPII mutation sec13-1. <EndsInDigit> LST1 showed synthetic-lethal interactions with the complete set of <AllCaps> COPII genes, indicating that <EndsInDigit> LST1 encodes a new <AllCaps> COPII function. <EndsInDigit> LST1 codes for a protein similar in sequence to the <AllCaps> COPII subunit Sec24p. <PERSON  Like> Sec24p, Lst1p is a peripheral <AllCaps> ER membrane protein that binds to the <AllCaps> COPII subunit Sec23p. <Capitalized> Chromosomal deletion of <EndsInDigit> LST1 is not lethal, but inhibits transport of the plasma membrane proton-ATPase (Pma1p) to the cell surface, causing poor growth on media of low pH. <Capitalized> Localization by both immunofluorescence microscopy and cell fractionation shows that the export of Pma1p from the <AllCaps> ER is impaired in lst1Delta mutants. <Capitalized> Transport of other proteins from the <AllCaps> ER was not affected by lst1Delta, nor was Pma1p transport found to be particularly sensitive to other <AllCaps> COPII defects. <Capitalized> Together, these findings suggest that a specialized form of the <AllCaps> COPII coat subunit, with Lst1p in place of Sec24p, is used for the efficient packaging of Pma1p into vesicles derived from the <AllCaps> ER.

 <Capitalized> The N-terminal region of Dvl-1 (a mammalian <Capitalized> Dishevelled homolog) shares 37% identity with the C-terminal region of <Capitalized> Axin, and this related region is named the <AllCaps> DIX domain. <Capitalized> The functions of the <AllCaps> DIX domains of Dvl-1 and <Capitalized> Axin were investigated. <Capitalized> By yeast two-hybrid screening, the <AllCaps> DIX domain of Dvl-1 was found to interact with Dvl-3, a second mammalian <Capitalized> Dishevelled relative. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> DIX domains of Dvl-1 and Dvl-3 directly bound one another. <Capitalized> Furthermore, Dvl-1 formed a homo-oligomer. <Capitalized> Axin also formed a homo-oligomer, and its <AllCaps> DIX domain was necessary. <Capitalized> The N-terminal region of Dvl-1, including its <AllCaps> DIX domain, bound to <Capitalized> Axin directly.  <AllCaps> A new class of repression modules is critical for heme regulation of the yeast transcriptional activator Hap1. 
 
 <PERSON  Hach> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Hon> <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Zhang <AllCaps> L. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <AllCaps> NYU <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10016, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Heme plays key regulatory roles in numerous molecular and cellular processes for systems that sense or use oxygen. <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, oxygen sensing and heme signaling are mediated by heme activator protein 1 (Hap1). Hap1 contains seven heme-responsive motifs (HRMs): six are clustered in the heme domain, and a seventh is near the activation domain. <Capitalized> To determine the functional role of HRMs and to define which parts of Hap1 mediate heme regulation, we carried out a systematic analysis of Hap1 mutants with various regions deleted or mutated. <Capitalized> Strikingly, the data show that <EndsInDigit> HRM1 to -6, located in the previously designated Hap1 heme domain, have little impact on heme regulation. <Capitalized> All seven HRMs are dispensable for Hap1 repression in the absence of heme, but <EndsInDigit> HRM7 is required for Hap1 activation by heme. <PERSON  More> importantly, we show that a novel class of repression modules-RPM1, encompassing residues 245 to 278; RPM2, encompassing residues 1061 to 1185; and RPM3, encompassing residues 203 to 244-is critical for Hap1 repression in the absence of heme. <Capitalized> Biochemical analysis indicates that RPMs mediate Hap1 repression, at least partly, by the formation of a previously identified higher-order complex termed the high-molecular-weight complex (HMC), while HRMs mediate heme activation by permitting heme binding and the disassembly of the <AllCaps> HMC. <Capitalized> These findings provide significant new insights into the molecular interactions critical for Hap1 repression in the absence of heme and Hap1 activation by heme.

 <Capitalized> Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen that causes meningitis in patients immunocompromised by <AllCaps> AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplantation, or high-dose steroids. <PERSON  Current> antifungal drug therapies are limited and suffer from toxic side effects and drug resistance. <Capitalized> Here, we defined the targets and mechanisms of antifungal action of the immunosuppressant rapamycin in <AllCaps> C. neoformans. <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae and in <PERSON  T> cells, rapamycin forms complexes with the <EndsInDigit> FKBP12 prolyl isomerase that block cell cycle progression by inhibiting the <AllCaps> TOR kinases. <Capitalized> We identified the gene encoding a <AllCaps> C. neoformans <EndsInDigit> TOR1 homolog. <Capitalized> Using a novel two-hybrid screen for rapamycin-dependent TOR-binding proteins, we identified the <AllCaps> C. neoformans <EndsInDigit> FKBP12 homolog, encoded by the <EndsInDigit> FRR1 gene. <Capitalized> Disruption of the <EndsInDigit> FKBP12 gene conferred rapamycin and <EndsInDigit> FK506 resistance but had no effect on growth, differentiation, or virulence of <AllCaps> C. neoformans. <Capitalized> Two spontaneous mutations that confer rapamycin resistance alter conserved residues on <EndsInDigit> TOR1 or <EndsInDigit> FKBP12 that are required for FKBP12-rapamycin-TOR1 interactions or <EndsInDigit> FKBP12 stability. <Capitalized> Two other spontaneous mutations result from insertion of novel <AllCaps> DNA sequences into the <EndsInDigit> FKBP12 gene. <Capitalized> Our observations reveal that the antifungal activities of rapamycin and <EndsInDigit> FK506 are mediated via <EndsInDigit> FKBP12 and <AllCaps> TOR homologs and that a high proportion of spontaneous mutants in <AllCaps> C. neoformans result from insertion of novel <AllCaps> DNA sequences, and they suggest that nonimmunosuppressive rapamycin analogs have potential as antifungal agents.

 <Capitalized> Insulin receptor substrates (IRS) mediate biological actions of insulin, growth factors, and cytokines. <Capitalized> All four mammalian <AllCaps> IRS proteins contain pleckstrin homology (PH) and phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domains at their <AllCaps> N termini. <Capitalized> However, the molecules diverge in their C-terminal sequences. <EndsInDigit> IRS3 is considerably shorter than IRS1, IRS2, and IRS4, and is predicted to interact with a distinct group of downstream signaling molecules. <Capitalized> In the present study, we investigated interactions of <EndsInDigit> IRS3 with various signaling molecules. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> PTB domain of mIRS3 is necessary and sufficient for binding to the juxtamembrane NPXpY motif of the insulin receptor in the yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> This interaction is stronger if the <AllCaps> PH domain or the C-terminal phosphorylation domain is retained in the construct. <Capitalized> As determined in a modified yeast two-hybrid system, mIRS3 bound strongly to the p85 subunit of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase. <Capitalized> Although high affinity interaction required the presence of at least two of the four <AllCaps> YXXM motifs in mIRS3, there was not a requirement for specific <AllCaps> YXXM motifs. mIRS3 also bound to SHP2, Grb2, <Capitalized> Nck, and <Capitalized> Shc, but less strongly than to p85. <Capitalized> Studies in COS-7 cells demonstrated that deletion of either the <AllCaps> PH or the <AllCaps> PTB domain abolished insulin-stimulated phosphorylation of mIRS3. <Capitalized> Insulin stimulation promoted the association of mIRS3 with p85, SHP2, <Capitalized> Nck, and Shc. <Capitalized> Despite weak association between mIRS3 and Grb2, this interaction was not increased by insulin, and may not be mediated by the <EndsInDigit> SH2 domain of Grb2. <PERSON  Thus,> in contrast to other <AllCaps> IRS proteins, mIRS3 appears to have greater specificity for activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase pathway rather than the Grb2/Ras pathway.

 <Capitalized> Lin <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Wing> <AllCaps> SS. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Medicine, <PERSON McGill> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Montreal,> <Capitalized> Quebec H3A 2B2, <PERSON Canada> 
 
 <Capitalized> The structural basis by which ubiquitin (Ub)-conjugating enzymes (E2s) determine substrate specificity remains unclear. <Capitalized> We cloned rabbit reticulocyte E217K because unlike the similarly sized class <AllCaps> I E2s, E214K and UBC4, it is unable to support ubiquitin-protein ligase (E3)-dependent conjugation to endogenous proteins. <AllCaps> RNA analysis revealed that this <EndsInDigit> E2 was expressed in all tissues tested, with higher levels in the testis. <Capitalized> Analysis of testis <AllCaps> RNA from rats of different ages showed that E217K <MixedCase> mRNA was induced from days 15 to 30. <Capitalized> The predicted amino acid sequence indicates that E217K is a 19. 5-kDa class <AllCaps> I <EndsInDigit> E2 but differs from other class <AllCaps> I enzymes in possessing an insertion of 13 amino acids distal to the active site cysteine. E217K shows 74% amino acid identity with <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae UBC7, and therefore, we rename it mammalian UBC7. <Capitalized> Yeast <EndsInDigit> UBC7 crystal structure indicates that this insertion forms a loop out of the otherwise conserved folding structure. <Capitalized> Sequence analysis of E2s had previously suggested that this loop is a hypervariable region and may play a role in substrate specificity. <Capitalized> We created mutant <EndsInDigit> UBC7 lacking the loop (ubc7Deltaloop) and a mutant E214k with an inserted loop (E214k+loop) and characterized their biochemical functions. Ubc7Deltaloop had higher affinity for the E1-Ub thiol ester than native <EndsInDigit> UBC7 and permitted conjugation of <Capitalized> Ub to selected proteins in the testis but did not permit the broad spectrum E3-dependent conjugation to endogenous reticulocyte proteins. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, E214k+loop was unable to accept <Capitalized> Ub from ubiquitin-activating enzyme (E1) but was able to accept <EndsInDigit> NEDD8 from E1.  <PERSON  Human> p120ctn catenin: tissue-specific expression of isoforms and molecular interactions with BP180/type <AllCaps> XVII collagen. 
 
 <Capitalized> Aho <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Rothenberger <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Uitto <AllCaps> J. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Dermatology, <PERSON  Jefferson> <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> College, and <PERSON  Jefferson> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Medicine, <PERSON  Thomas> <PERSON  Jefferson> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Philadelphia,> <LOCATION  Pennsylvania> 19107, <LOCATION  USA.> aho1@mail.tju.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> Catenins, a family of structurally related proteins, are involved in epidermal keratinocyte cell-cell adhesion by interacting through their central <Capitalized> Armadillo repeats with the intracellular domains of cadherins, transmembrane components of the adhesion junctions. p120ctn is a catenin expressed in different isoforms due to alternative splicing and multiple translation start sites. <EndsInDigit> BP180 is a collagenous transmembrane protein (type <AllCaps> XVII collagen) localized to hemidesmosomal attachment complexes in basal keratinocytes. <Capitalized> In this study, we have delineated the molecular interaction between these two proteins utilizing the yeast two-hybrid system, which was confirmed by an in vitro protein-protein interaction assay. <Capitalized> Specifically, it was shown that an amino-terminal segment of <EndsInDigit> BP180 (aa. 13-25) contains the information necessary for binding to p120ctn isoforms 1-3, but not to the isoform 4, suggesting that the interacting domain is located immediately upstream from the <Capitalized> Armadillo repeats and is encoded by exons 5 and 6, which are subject to alternative splicing only in a minority of transcripts. <Capitalized> In addition to epidermal keratinocytes, p120ctn was shown to be expressed in a variety of adult and fetal tissues as well as in a number of human tumors. <Capitalized> The expression pattern of various p120ctn transcripts, reflecting alternative splicing of the 5' exons, was strikingly similar between the corresponding adult and fetal tissues, while the expression patterns were discordant between certain tumors and their normal parental tissues, suggesting a functional role for the tissue-specific expression of the p120ctn isoforms. <Capitalized> Finally, the tissue-specific expression of <EndsInDigit> BP180 was shown to partially overlap with that of p120ctn, suggesting that the interaction of these two proteins may contribute to the modulation of cell-cell/matrix interactions in such tissues.

 <Capitalized> Exit from mitosis in all eukaroytes requires inactivation of the mitotic kinase. <Capitalized> This occurs principally by ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis of the cyclin subunit controlled by the anaphase-promoting complex (APC). <Capitalized> However, an abnormal spindle and/or unattached kinetochores activates a conserved spindle checkpoint that blocks <AllCaps> APC function. <Capitalized> This leads to high mitotic kinase activity and prevents mitotic exit. <EndsInDigit> DBF2 belongs to a group of budding yeast cell cycle genes that when mutated prevent cyclin degradation and block exit from mitosis. <EndsInDigit> DBF2 encodes a protein kinase which is cell cycle regulated, peaking in metaphase-anaphase B/telophase, but its function remains unknown. <Capitalized> Here, we show the Dbf2p kinase activity to be a target of the spindle checkpoint. <Capitalized> It is controlled specifically by Bub2p, one of the checkpoint components that is conserved in fission yeast and higher eukaroytic cells. <Capitalized> Significantly, in budding yeast, Bub2p shows few genetic or biochemical interactions with other members of the spindle checkpoint. <Capitalized> Our data now point to the protein kinase Mps1p triggering a new parallel branch of the spindle checkpoint in which Bub2p blocks Dbf2p function.

 <Capitalized> The delivery of secretory vesicles to appropriate docking and fusion sites on the plasma membrane is crucial for many cellular functions, including formation of synapses, exocytosis of neurotransmitter, establishment and maintenance of cell polarity, cell growth and plasma membrane wound healing. Cell-biological, genetic and biochemical approaches have identified crucial proteins and protein interactions important for vesicle docking and fusion. <Capitalized> However, a description of the molecular mechanisms underlying vesicle targeting to specific membrane-fusion sites remains elusive. <Capitalized> This review discusses a set of proteins that might direct vesicles to specific domains of the plasma membrane.

 <Capitalized> Assembly of the type 1 procollagen molecule: selectivity of the interactions between the alpha 1(I)- and alpha 2(I)-carboxyl propeptides. 
 
 <Capitalized> Alvares <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Siddiqui <AllCaps> F, <PERSON  Malone> <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Veis <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <LOCATION  Oral> <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> Northwestern <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> Dental <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Chicago,> <LOCATION  Illinois> 60611, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Assembly of the heterotrimeric procollagen <AllCaps> I molecule is initiated by interactions between the carboxyl propeptide domains of the completed nascent pro alpha chains. <Capitalized> The [pro alpha 1(I)]2[pro alpha 2(I)] heterotrimer is the predominant molecule, with much smaller amounts of stable [pro alpha 1(I)]3 homotrimer also being formed. <Capitalized> However, the [pro alpha 2(1)]3 homotrimer has not been detected, raising questions as to the mechanism of chain assembly and why [pro alpha2(1)]3 homotrimers are not formed. <Capitalized> These questions have been examined here by expressing the intact and amino- or carboxyl-terminal truncated C-propeptides of the pro alpha chains recombinantly in bacteria and in a coupled transcription/translation reticulocyte lysate system. <Capitalized> Their interactions were studied in vitro by binding analyses and in vivo by using the yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> The C-pro alpha 1(I) interacted with itself, and with C-pro alpha 2(I), as expected. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, the C-pro alpha 2(I) also interacted with itself, both in vitro and in vivo. <Capitalized> While the interaction of C-pro alpha 2(I) with itself and C-pro alpha 1(I) in vitro was strong, these interactions were weaker in vivo. <Capitalized> Deletion of 36 amino acids from the C-terminal domain of C-pro alpha 1 had no effect on its binding to intact self or intact C-pro alpha 2, but the same deletion in C-pro alpha 2 completely abolished its binding to intact C-pro alpha 2 and to C-pro alpha 1. <Capitalized> Comparable N-terminal deletions in C-pro alpha 1 or C-pro alpha 2 diminished, but did not abolish, their binding to intact C-pro alpha 1 and C-pro alpha 2. <Capitalized> In the yeast two-hybrid system, C-pro alpha 2 interacted with itself more weakly than with C-pro alpha 1. <Capitalized> Molecular modeling and circular dichroism analyses showed that C-pro alpha 1 and C-pro alpha 2 have different folded structures and stability. <Capitalized> Studies with antibodies specific to the C-pro alpha1 and alpha2 peptides showed them to precipitate different, specific, and distinct cell proteins from fibroblast lysates. <Capitalized> The C-pro alpha 2(I) antibody complexed with more cell proteins. <Capitalized> We hypothesize that the lack of pro alpha 2(I) homotrimers is not due to the inability of the C-pro alpha 2(I) to interact with itself, but rather to the competing presence of other cell proteins. <Capitalized> The specificity of these interactions may reside in conformational differences in N- and C-terminal sequences of the two propeptides or in their different folding patterns. 
 
 PMID: 10220327 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

 <Capitalized> The presumed potassium carrier Trk2p in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae determines an H+-dependent, K+-independent current. 
 
 <Capitalized> Bihler <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Gaber <AllCaps> RF, <Capitalized> Slayman <AllCaps> CL, <Capitalized> Bertl <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cellular and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Physiology, <PERSON  Yale> <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  New Haven,> <AllCaps> CT 06510, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Ionic currents related to the major potassium uptake systems in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae were examined by whole cell patch-clamping, under K+ replete conditions. <Capitalized> Those currents have the following properties. <Capitalized> They (1) are inward under all conditions investigated, (2) arise instantaneously with appropriate voltage steps, (3) depend solely upon the moderate affinity transporter Trk2p, not upon the high affinity transporter Trk1p. <Capitalized> They (4) appear to be independent of the extracellular K+ concentration, (5) are also independent of extracellular Ca2+, Mg2+ and Cl- but (6) are strongly dependent on extracellular pH, being large at low <MixedCase> pH (up to several hundred <MixedCase> pA at -200 <MixedCase> mV and <MixedCase> pH 4) and near zero at high <MixedCase> pH (above 7.5). <Capitalized> They (7) increase in proportion to log[H+]o, rather than directly in proportion to the proton concentration and (8) behave kinetically as if each transporter cycle moved one proton plus one (high pH) or two (low pH) other ions, as yet unidentified. <Capitalized> In view of background knowledge on K+ transport related to Trk2p, the new results suggest that the K+ status of yeast cells modulates both the kinetics of Trk2p-mediated transport and the identity of ions involved. <Capitalized> That modulation could act either on the Trk2 protein itself or on interactions of Trk2 with other proteins in a hypothetical transporter complex. <Capitalized> Structural considerations suggest a strong analogy to the KtrAB system in <Capitalized> Vibrio alginolyticus and/or the TrkH system in <Capitalized> Escherichia coli.

 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Escherichia coli <MixedCase> dnaQ gene encodes the 3'-->5' exonucleolytic proofreading (epsilon) subunit of <AllCaps> DNA polymerase <AllCaps> III (Pol III). <Capitalized> Genetic analysis of <MixedCase> dnaQ mutants has suggested that epsilon might consist of two domains, an N-terminal domain containing the exonuclease and a C-terminal domain essential for binding the polymerase (alpha) subunit. <Capitalized> We have created truncated forms of <MixedCase> dnaQ resulting in epsilon subunits that contain either the N-terminal or the C-terminal domain. <Capitalized> Using the yeast two-hybrid system, we analyzed the interactions of the single-domain epsilon subunits with the alpha and theta subunits of the <PERSON  Pol> <AllCaps> III core. <Capitalized> The DnaQ991 protein, consisting of the N-terminal 186 amino acids, was defective in binding to the alpha subunit while retaining normal binding to the theta subunit. <Capitalized> In contrast, the NDelta186 protein, consisting of the C-terminal 57 amino acids, exhibited normal binding to the alpha subunit but was defective in binding to the theta subunit. <AllCaps> A strain carrying the dnaQ991 allele exhibited a strong, recessive mutator phenotype, as expected from a defective alpha binding mutant. <Capitalized> The data are consistent with the existence of two functional domains in epsilon, with the C-terminal domain responsible for polymerase binding.

 763: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biomol <Capitalized> Struct <Capitalized> Dyn 1999 Feb;16(4):757-74 
 
 <Capitalized> The effect of queuosine on <MixedCase> tRNA structure and function. 
 
 <PERSON  Morris> <AllCaps> RC, <PERSON  Brown> <AllCaps> KG, <PERSON  Elliott> <AllCaps> MS. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Chemistry, <PERSON  Old> <Capitalized> Dominion <Capitalized> University, <PERSON  Norfolk,> <AllCaps> VA 23529, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Computational modeling was performed to determine the potential function of the queuosine modification of <MixedCase> tRNA found in wobble position 34 of tRNAasp, tRNAasn, tRNAhis, and tRNAtyr. <Capitalized> Using the crystal structure of <MixedCase> tRNAasp and a tRNA-tRNA-mRNA complex model, we show that the queuosine modification serves as a structurally restrictive base for <MixedCase> tRNA anticodon loop flexibility. <Capitalized> An extended intraresidue and intramolecular hydrogen bonding network is established by queuosine. <Capitalized> The quaternary amine of the 7-aminomethyl side chain hydrogen bonds with the base's carbonyl oxygen. <Capitalized> This positions the dihydroxycyclopentenediol ring of queuosine in proper orientation for hydrogen bonding with the backbone of the neighboring uridine 33 residue. <Capitalized> The interresidue association stabilizes the formation of a cross-loop hydrogen bond between the uridine 33 base and the phosphoribosyl backbone of the cytosine at position 36. <Capitalized> Additional interactions between RNAs in the translation complex were studied with regard to potential codon context and codon bias effects. <Capitalized> Neither steric nor electrostatic interaction occurs between aminoacyl- and peptidyl-site <MixedCase> tRNA anticodon loops that are modified with queuosine. <Capitalized> However, there is a difference in the strength of anticodon/codon associations (codon bias) based on the presence or lack of queuosine in the wobble position of the tRNA. <Capitalized> Unmodified (guanosine-containing) <MixedCase> tRNAasp forms a very stable association with cytosine (GAC), but is much less stable in complex with a uridine-containing codon (GAU). Queuosine-modified <MixedCase> tRNAasp exhibits no bias for either of cognate codons <AllCaps> GAC or <AllCaps> GAU and demonstrates a lower binding energy similar to the wobble pairing of guanosine-containing <MixedCase> tRNA with a <AllCaps> GAU codon. <Capitalized> This is proposed to be due to the inflexibility of the queuosine-modified anticodon loop to accommodate proper positioning for optimal Watson-Crick type associations. <AllCaps> A preliminary survey of codon usage patterns in oncodevelopmental versus housekeeping gene transcripts suggests a significant difference in bias for the queuosine-associated codons. <Capitalized> Therefore, the queuosine modification may have the potential to influence cellular growth and differentiation by codon bias-based regulation of protein synthesis for discrete <MixedCase> mRNA transcripts.

 764: <Capitalized> Biochimie 1999 Jan-Feb;81(1-2):87-105 
 
 <Capitalized> The contribution of homologous recombination in preserving genome integrity in mammalian cells. 
 
 <PERSON  Thompson> <AllCaps> LH, <PERSON  Schild> <AllCaps> D. 
 
 <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Biotechnology <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Program, <PERSON  Lawrence> <PERSON  Livermore> <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> Laboratory, <PERSON  Livermore,> <AllCaps> CA 94551-0808, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Although it is clear that mammalian somatic cells possess the enzymatic machinery to perform homologous recombination of <AllCaps> DNA molecules, the importance of this process in mitigating <AllCaps> DNA damage has been uncertain. <Capitalized> An initial genetic framework for studying homologous recombinational repair (HRR) has come from identifying relevant genes by homology or by their ability to correct mutants whose phenotypes are suggestive of recombinational defects. <Capitalized> While yeast has been an invaluable guide, higher eukaryotes diverge in the details and complexity of <AllCaps> HRR. <Capitalized> For eliminating DSBs, <AllCaps> HRR and end-joining pathways share the burden, with <AllCaps> HRR contributing critically during <PERSON  S> and <EndsInDigit> G2 phases. <Capitalized> It is likely that the removal of interstrand cross-links is absolutely dependent on efficient <AllCaps> HRR, as suggested by the extraordinary sensitivity of the ercc1, xpf/ercc4, xrcc2, and xrcc3 mutants to cross-linking chemicals. <Capitalized> Similarly, chromosome stability in untreated cells requires intact <AllCaps> HRR, which may eliminate DSBs arising during <AllCaps> DNA replication and thereby prevent chromosome aberrations. <Capitalized> Complex regulation of <AllCaps> HRR by cell cycle checkpoint and surveillance functions is suggested not only by direct interactions between human Rad51 and p53, c-Abl, and BRCA2, but also by very high recombination rates in p53-deficient cells.

 <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> PRS gene family in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae consists of five genes each capable of encoding a 5-phosphoribosyl-1(alpha)-pyrophosphate synthetase polypeptide. <Capitalized> To gain insight into the functional organization of this gene family we have constructed a collection of strains containing all possible combinations of disruptions in the five <AllCaps> PRS genes. <Capitalized> Phenotypically these deletant strains can be classified into three groups: (i) a lethal phenotype that corresponds to strains containing a double disruption in <EndsInDigit> PRS2 and <EndsInDigit> PRS4 in combination with a disruption in either <EndsInDigit> PRS1 or PRS3; simultaneous deletion of <EndsInDigit> PRS1 and <EndsInDigit> PRS5 or <EndsInDigit> PRS3 and <EndsInDigit> PRS5 are also lethal combinations; (ii) a second phenotype that is encountered in strains containing disruptions in <EndsInDigit> PRS1 and <EndsInDigit> PRS3 together or in combination with any of the other <AllCaps> PRS genes manifests itself as a reduction in growth rate, enzyme activity, and nucleotide content; (iii) a third phenotype that corresponds to strains that, although affected in their phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate-synthesizing ability, are unimpaired for growth and have nucleotide profiles virtually the same as the wild type. <Capitalized> Deletions of PRS2, PRS4, and <EndsInDigit> PRS5 or combinations thereof cause this phenotype. <Capitalized> These results suggest that the polypeptides encoded by the members of the <AllCaps> PRS gene family may be organized into two functional entities. <Capitalized> Evidence that these polypeptides interact with each other in vivo was obtained using the yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> Specifically <EndsInDigit> PRS1 and <EndsInDigit> PRS3 polypeptides interact strongly with each other, and there are significant interactions between the <EndsInDigit> PRS5 polypeptide and either the <EndsInDigit> PRS2 or <EndsInDigit> PRS4 polypeptides. <Capitalized> These data suggest that yeast phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase exists in vivo as multimeric complex(es).

 <Capitalized> The Rho3 protein plays a critical role in the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae by directing proper cell growth. Rho3 appears to influence cell growth by regulating polarized secretion and the actin cytoskeleton, since rho3 mutants exhibit large rounded cells with an aberrant actin cytoskeleton. <Capitalized> To gain insights into how Rho3 influences these events, we have carried out a yeast two-hybrid screen using an <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae <MixedCase> cDNA library to identify proteins interacting with Rho3. <Capitalized> Two proteins, Exo70 and Myo2, were identified in this screen. <Capitalized> Interactions with these two proteins are greatly reduced or abolished when mutations are introduced into the Rho3 effector domain. <Capitalized> In addition, a type of mutation known to produce dominant negative mutants of <Capitalized> Rho proteins abolished the interaction with both of these proteins. <Capitalized> In contrast, Rho3 did not interact with protein kinase <AllCaps> C (Pkc1), an effector of another <Capitalized> Rho family protein, Rho1, nor did Rho1 interact with Exo70 or Myo2. Rho3 did interact with Bni1, another effector of Rho1, but less efficiently than with Rho1. <Capitalized> The interaction between Rho3 and Exo70 and between Rho3 and Myo2 was also demonstrated with purified proteins. <Capitalized> The interaction between Exo70 and Rho3 in vitro was dependent on the presence of <AllCaps> GTP, since Rho3 complexed with guanosine 5'-O-(3-thiotriphosphate) interacted more efficiently with Exo70 than Rho3 complexed with guanosine 5'-O-(3-thiodiphosphate). <Capitalized> Overlapping subcellular localization of the Rho3 and Exo70 proteins was demonstrated by indirect immunofluorescence. <Capitalized> In addition, patterns of localization of both Exo70 and Rho3 were altered when a dominant active allele of RHO3, RHO3(E129,A131), which causes a morphological abnormality, was expressed. <Capitalized> These results provide a direct molecular basis for the action of Rho3 on exocytosis and the actin cytoskeleton.

 773: <Capitalized> Genetics 1999 Apr;151(4):1273-85 
 
 <Capitalized> Analysis of mutations in the yeast <MixedCase> mRNA decapping enzyme. 
 
 <Capitalized> Tharun <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Parker> <PERSON  R.>

 <AllCaps> A major mechanism of <MixedCase> mRNA decay in yeast is initiated by deadenylation, followed by <MixedCase> mRNA decapping, which exposes the transcript to 5' to 3' exonucleolytic degradation. <Capitalized> The decapping enzyme that removes the 5' cap structure is encoded by the <EndsInDigit> DCP1 gene. <Capitalized> To understand the function of the decapping enzyme, we used alanine scanning mutagenesis to create 31 mutant versions of the enzyme, and we examined the effects of the mutations both in vivo and in vitro. <Capitalized> Two types of mutations that affected <MixedCase> mRNA decapping in vivo were identified, including a temperature-sensitive allele. <Capitalized> First, two mutants produced decapping enzymes that were defective for decapping in vitro, suggesting that these mutated residues are required for enzymatic activity. <Capitalized> In contrast, several mutants that moderately affected <MixedCase> mRNA decapping in vivo yielded decapping enzymes that had at least the same specific activity as the wild-type enzyme in vitro. <Capitalized> Combination of alleles within this group yielded decapping enzymes that showed a strong loss of function in vivo, but that still produced fully active enzymes in vitro. <Capitalized> This suggested that interactions of the decapping enzyme with other factors may be required for efficient decapping in vivo, and that these particular mutations may be disrupting such interactions. <Capitalized> Interestingly, partial loss of decapping activity in vivo led to a defect in normal deadenylation-dependent decapping, but it did not affect the rapid deadenylation-independent decapping triggered by early nonsense codons. <Capitalized> This observation suggested that these two types of <MixedCase> mRNA decapping differ in their requirements for the decapping enzyme.

 <PERSON  Human> p32 (also known as SF2-associated p32, p32/TAP, and gC1qR) is a conserved eukaryotic protein that localizes predominantly in the mitochondrial matrix. <Capitalized> It is thought to be involved in mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and in nucleus-mitochondrion interactions. <Capitalized> We report the crystal structure of p32 determined at 2.25 <AllCaps> A resolution. <Capitalized> The structure reveals that p32 adopts a novel fold with seven consecutive antiparallel beta-strands flanked by one N-terminal and two C-terminal alpha-helices. <Capitalized> Three monomers form a doughnut-shaped quaternary structure with an unusually asymmetric charge distribution on the surface. <Capitalized> The implications of the structure on previously proposed functions of p32 are discussed and new specific functional properties are suggested.

 <PERSON McHarg> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Kelly> <AllCaps> SM, <PERSON  Price> <AllCaps> NC, <PERSON  Cooper> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Littlechild> <AllCaps> JA. 
 
 <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Exeter, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 Site-specific mutants have been produced in order to investigate the role of proline 204 in the 'hinge' region of yeast phosphoglycerate kinase (PGK). <Capitalized> This totally conserved proline has been shown to be the only cis-proline in the high resolution crystal structures of yeast, <AllCaps> B. stearothermophilus, <PERSON  T.> brucei and <PERSON  T.> maritima <AllCaps> PGK, and may therefore have a role in the independent folding of the two domains or in the 'hinge' bending of the molecule during catalysis. <Capitalized> The residue was replaced by a histidine (Pro204His) and a phenylalanine (Pro204Phe), and the resulting proteins characterised by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), circular dichroism (CD), tryptophan fluorescence emission and kinetic analysis. <Capitalized> Although the secondary and tertiary structure of the Pro204His protein is generally similar to that of the wild-type enzyme as assessed by <AllCaps> CD, the enzyme is less stable to heat and guanidinium chloride denaturation than the wild-type. <Capitalized> In the denaturation experiments two transitions were observed for both the wild-type and the Pro204His mutant, as have been previously reported for yeast <AllCaps> PGK [Missiakas, D., <Capitalized> Betton, J.M., <PERSON  Minard,> <PERSON  P.> & <Capitalized> Yon, J.M. (1990) <Capitalized> Biochemistry 29, 8683-8689]. <Capitalized> The first transition is accompanied by an increase in fluorescence intensity leading to a hyperfluorescent state, followed by the second, corresponding to a decrease in fluorescence intensity. <Capitalized> However, for the Pro204His mutant, the first transition proceeded at lower concentrations of guanidinium chloride and the second transition proceeded to the same extent as for the wild-type protein, suggesting that sequence-distant interactions are more rapidly disrupted in this mutant enzyme than in the wild-type enzyme, while sequence-local interactions are disrupted in a similar way. <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Michaelis> constants (K(m)) for both 3-phospho-D-glycerate and <AllCaps> ATP are increased only by three or fourfold, which confirms that, as expected, the substrate binding sites are largely unaffected by the mutation. <Capitalized> However, the turnover and efficiency of the Pro204His mutant is severely impaired, indicating that the mechanism of 'hinge' bending is hindered. <Capitalized> The Pro204Phe enzyme was shown to be significantly less well folded than the wild-type and Pro204His enzymes, with considerable loss of both secondary and tertiary structure. <Capitalized> It is proposed that the proline residue at 204 in the 'hinge' region of <AllCaps> PGK plays a role in the stability and catalytic mechanism of the enzyme.

 <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, positioning of the mitotic spindle requires both the cytoplasmic microtubules and actin. Kar9p is a novel cortical protein that is required for the correct position of the mitotic spindle and the orientation of the cytoplasmic microtubules. <PERSON  Green> fluorescent protein (GFP)- Kar9p localizes to a single spot at the tip of the growing bud and the mating projection. <Capitalized> However, the cortical localization of Kar9p does not require microtubules (Miller, R.K., and M.D. <PERSON Rose> 1998. <AllCaps> J. <Capitalized> Cell Biol. 140: 377), suggesting that Kar9p interacts with other proteins at the cortex. <Capitalized> To investigate Kar9p's cortical interactions, we treated cells with the actin-depolymerizing drug, latrunculin-A. <Capitalized> In both shmoos and mitotic cells, Kar9p's cortical localization was completely dependent on polymerized actin.  <Capitalized> The cooperative binding of gene regulatory proteins to <AllCaps> DNA is a common feature of transcriptional control in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. <Capitalized> It is generally viewed as a simple energy coupling, through protein-protein interactions, of two or more DNA-binding proteins. <Capitalized> In this paper, we show that the simple view does not account for the cooperative <AllCaps> DNA binding of a1 and alpha2, two homeodomain proteins from budding yeast. <Capitalized> Rather, we show through the use of chimeric proteins and synthetic peptides that, upon heterodimerization, alpha2 instructs a1 to bind <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> This change is induced by contact with a peptide contributed by alpha2, and this contact converts a1 from a weak to a strong DNA-binding protein. <Capitalized> This explains, in part, how high DNA-binding specificity is achieved only when the two gene regulatory proteins conjoin. <Capitalized> We also provide evidence that features of the a1-alpha2 interaction can serve as a model for other examples of protein-protein interactions, including that between the herpes virus transcriptional activator <EndsInDigit> VP16 and the mammalian homeodomain-containing protein Oct-l.

 <MixedCase> mRNA decay is a multistep process, often dependent on the active translation of an <MixedCase> mRNA and on components of the translation apparatus. <Capitalized> In <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, several trans-acting factors required for <MixedCase> mRNA decay associate with polyribosomes. <Capitalized> We have explored the specificity of the interactions of these factors with polyribosomes, using sucrose gradient sedimentation analysis of the yeast <EndsInDigit> UPF1 protein to test whether such interactions are altered when polyribosomes are disrupted by treatment with <AllCaps> EDTA, digestion with micrococcal nuclease, or shifting of cells containing a temperature-sensitive eIF3 mutation to the nonpermissive temperature. <Capitalized> These experiments, as well as others assaying the strength of factor association in high-salt sucrose gradients, lead us to conclude that Upf1p is tightly bound to the smallest polyribosomes, but not to the 40S or 60S ribosomal subunits. <Capitalized> Similar experimental approaches were used to determine whether <MixedCase> mRNA decay initiates prior to <MixedCase> mRNA release from polyribosomes. <Capitalized> Using sucrose gradient fractionation and <PERSON  Northern> blotting, we can detect the polysomal association of a <EndsInDigit> PGK1 <MixedCase> mRNA decay intermediate and conclude that <MixedCase> mRNA decay commences while an <MixedCase> mRNA is still being translated. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <PERSON  Sullivan> <AllCaps> ML, <Capitalized> Ahlquist <PERSON  P.>

 <PERSON  Brome> mosaic virus (BMV), a positive-strand <AllCaps> RNA virus in the alphavirus-like superfamily, encodes two <AllCaps> RNA replication proteins. <Capitalized> The 1a protein has putative helicase and RNA-capping domains, whereas 2a contains a polymerase-like domain. <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae expressing 1a and 2a is capable of replicating a <AllCaps> BMV <EndsInDigit> RNA3 template produced by in vivo transcription of a <AllCaps> DNA copy of RNA3. <Capitalized> Although insufficient for <EndsInDigit> RNA3 replication, the expression of 1a protein alone results in a dramatic and specific stabilization of the <EndsInDigit> RNA3 template in yeast. <Capitalized> As one step toward understanding 1a-induced stabilization of RNA3, the interactions involved, and its possible relation to <AllCaps> RNA replication, we have identified the cis-acting sequences required for this effect. <Capitalized> We find that 1a-induced stabilization is mediated by a 150- to 190-base segment of the <EndsInDigit> RNA3 intergenic region corresponding to a previously identified enhancer of <EndsInDigit> RNA3 replication. <Capitalized> Moreover, this segment is sufficient to confer 1a-induced stability on a heterologous beta-globin <AllCaps> RNA. <Capitalized> Within this intergenic segment, partial deletions that inhibited 1a-induced stabilization in yeast expressing 1a alone resulted in parallel decreases in the levels of negative- and positive-strand <EndsInDigit> RNA3 replication products in yeast expressing 1a and 2a. <Capitalized> In particular, a small deletion encompassing a motif corresponding to the box <AllCaps> B element of <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> III promoters dramatically reduced the ability of RNAs to respond to 1a or 1a and 2a. <Capitalized> These and other findings suggest that 1a-induced stabilization likely reflects an early template selection step in <AllCaps> BMV <AllCaps> RNA replication.

Nam8p stabilizes commitment complexes in the latter conditions. <Capitalized> Consistent with this, Nam8p interacts with the pre-mRNA downstream of the 5' splice site, in a region of nonconserved sequence. <Capitalized> Substitutions in this region affect splicing efficiency and alternative splice site choice in a Nam8p-dependent manner. <Capitalized> Therefore, Nam8p is involved in a novel mechanism by which a <MixedCase> snRNP component can affect splice site choice and regulate intron removal through its interaction with a nonconserved sequence. <Capitalized> This supports a model where early 5' splice recognition results from a network of interactions established by the splicing machinery with various regions of the pre-mRNA.

 <Capitalized> During mating of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, two nuclei fuse to produce a single diploid nucleus. <Capitalized> Two genes, <EndsInDigit> KAR7 and KAR8, were previously identified by mutations that cause defects in nuclear membrane fusion. <EndsInDigit> KAR7 is allelic to SEC71, a gene involved in protein translocation into the endoplasmic reticulum. <Capitalized> Two other translocation mutants, sec63-1 and sec72Delta, also exhibited moderate karyogamy defects. <Capitalized> Membranes from kar7/sec71Delta and sec72Delta, but not sec63-1, exhibited reduced membrane fusion in vitro, but only at elevated temperatures. <Capitalized> Genetic interactions between kar7 and kar5 mutations were suggestive of protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> Moreover, in sec71 mutants, Kar5p was absent from the <AllCaps> SPB and was not detected by <PERSON  Western> blot or immunoprecipitation of pulse-labeled protein. <EndsInDigit> KAR8 is allelic to <AllCaps> JEMI, encoding an endoplasmic reticulum resident DnaJ protein required for nuclear fusion. <Capitalized> Overexpression of KAR8/JEM1 (but not SEC63) strongly suppressed the mating defect of kar2-1, suggesting that Kar2p interacts with Kar8/Jem1p for nuclear fusion. <Capitalized> Electron microscopy analysis of kar8 mutant zygotes revealed a nuclear fusion defect different from kar2, kar5, and kar7/sec71 mutants. <Capitalized> Analysis of double mutants suggested that Kar5p acts before Kar8/Jem1p. <Capitalized> We propose the existence of a nuclear envelope fusion chaperone complex in which Kar2p, Kar5p, and Kar8/Jem1p are key components and Sec71p and Sec72p play auxiliary roles.

 793: <Capitalized> Microbiol <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Rev 1999 Mar;63(1):54-105 
 
 Cdc42: <Capitalized> An essential Rho-type GTPase controlling eukaryotic cell polarity. 
 
 <PERSON  Johnson> <AllCaps> DI. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Microbiology & <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and the <PERSON  Markey> <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Vermont, <LOCATION  Burlington,> <Capitalized> Vermont 05405, USA.dijohnso@zoo.uvm.edu 
 
 Cdc42p is an essential GTPase that belongs to the Rho/Rac subfamily of Ras-like GTPases. <Capitalized> These proteins act as molecular switches by responding to exogenous and/or endogenous signals and relaying those signals to activate downstream components of a biological pathway. <Capitalized> The 11 current members of the Cdc42p family display between 75 and 100% amino acid identity and are functional as well as structural homologs. Cdc42p transduces signals to the actin cytoskeleton to initiate and maintain polarized gorwth and to mitogen-activated protein morphogenesis. <Capitalized> In the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Cdc42p plays an important role in multiple actin-dependent morphogenetic events such as bud emergence, mating-projection formation, and pseudohyphal growth. <Capitalized> In mammalian cells, Cdc42p regulates a variety of actin-dependent events and induces the JNK/SAPK protein kinase cascade, which leads to the activation of transcription factors within the nucleus. Cdc42p mediates these processes through interactions with a myriad of downstream effectors, whose number and regulation we are just starting to understand. <Capitalized> In addition, Cdc42p has been implicated in a number of human diseases through interactions with its regulators and downstream effectors. <Capitalized> While much is known about Cdc42p structure and functional interactions, little is known about the mechanism(s) by which it transduces signals within the cell. <Capitalized> Future research should focus on this question as well as on the detailed analysis of the interactions of Cdc42p with its regulators and downstream effectors. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial

 <Capitalized> Nuber <PERSON  U,> <Capitalized> Scheffner <AllCaps> M.

 <Capitalized> Members of the hect domain protein family are characterized by sequence similarity of their C-terminal regions to the <AllCaps> C terminus of E6-AP, an <EndsInDigit> E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase. <Capitalized> An essential intermediate step in E6-AP-dependent ubiquitination is the formation of a thioester complex between E6-AP and ubiquitin in the presence of distinct <EndsInDigit> E2 ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes including human UbcH5, a member of the UBC4/UBC5 subfamily of E2s. <Capitalized> Similarly, several hect domain proteins, including <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae RSP5, form ubiquitin thioester complexes, indicating that hect domain proteins in general have <EndsInDigit> E3 activity. <Capitalized> We show here, by the use of chimeric E2s generated between UbcH5 and other E2s, that a region of UbcH5 encompassing the catalytic site cysteine residue is critical for its ability to interact with E6-AP and RSP5. <Capitalized> Of particular importance is a phenylalanine residue at position 62 of UbcH5 that is conserved among the members of the UBC4/UBC5 subfamily but is not present in any of the other known E2s, whereas the N-terminal 60 amino acids do not contribute significantly to the specificity of these interactions. <Capitalized> The conservation of this phenylalanine residue throughout evolution underlines the importance of the ability to interact with hect domain proteins for the cellular function of UBC4/UBC5 subfamily members.

 SNAREs and the secretory pathway-lessons from yeast. 
 
 <PERSON  Pelham> <AllCaps> HR. 
 
 <AllCaps> MRC <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Hills> <Capitalized> Road, <LOCATION  Cambridge,> <EndsInDigit> CB2 2QH, <Capitalized> United <PERSON Kingdom> hp@mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk 
 
 <AllCaps> SNARE proteins lie at the heart of the membrane fusion events in the secretory and endocytic pathways. <Capitalized> Physical interactions between them are thought not only to provide the driving force for bringing membranes together, but also to contribute to the specificity of vesicle targeting. <Capitalized> Completion of the yeast genome sequence has allowed the full set of SNAREs to be identified. <Capitalized> Characterization of these helps to define the number of distinct compartments and the nature of the transport steps between them, but also shows that SNAREs are by no means the sole determinants of fusion specificity. <Capitalized> Evolutionary conservation of SNAREs suggests that despite the differences in scale and morphology, many features of membrane organization are similar in yeast and animal cells. <Capitalized> This review summarizes current knowledge of the yeast SNAREs and the picture of the secretory pathway that emerges from such studies. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.
