 801: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 1999 <PERSON  Mar> 5;274(10):6579-85 
 
 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae protein Mnn10p/Bed1p is a subunit of a <Capitalized> Golgi mannosyltransferase complex. 
 
 <PERSON  Jungmann> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Rayner> <AllCaps> JC, <PERSON  Munro> <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Research <PERSON  Council> <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Hills> <Capitalized> Road, <LOCATION  Cambridge,> <EndsInDigit> CB2 2QH, <Capitalized> United <PERSON Kingdom> 
 
 <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae many of the N-linked glycans on cell wall and periplasmic proteins are modified by the addition of mannan, a large mannose-containing polysaccharide. <Capitalized> Mannan comprises a backbone of approximately 50 alpha-1,6-linked mannoses to which are attached many branches consisting of alpha-1,2-linked and alpha-1,3-linked mannoses. <Capitalized> The initiation and subsequent elongation of the mannan backbone is performed by two complexes of proteins in the cis Golgi. <Capitalized> In this study we show that the product of the MNN10/BED1 gene is a component of one of these complexes, that which elongates the backbone. <Capitalized> Analysis of interactions between the proteins in this complex shows that Mnn10p, 
 
 and four previously characterized proteins (Anp1p, Mnn9p, Mnn11p, and Hoc1p) are indeed all components of the same large structure. <Capitalized> Deletion of either Mnn10p, or its homologue Mnn11p, results in defects in mannan synthesis in vivo, and analysis of the enzymatic activity of the complexes isolated from mutant strains suggests that Mnn10p and Mnn11p are responsible for the majority of the alpha-1, 6-polymerizing activity of the complex.

 <PERSON  Bell> <AllCaps> SJ, <Capitalized> Forsdyke <AllCaps> DR. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, Queen's <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Kingston,> <LOCATION  Ontario,> <LOCATION  Canada> K7L 3N6. 
 
 <Capitalized> The distribution of deviations from Chargaff's second parity rule was examined for overlapping sequence windows of a length (1 kb) predicted to be suitable for detecting correlations with functional features of <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> For long genomic segments from <AllCaps> E. coli, <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and <Capitalized> Vaccinia virus, <Capitalized> Chargaff differences for the <PERSON  W> bases and/or for the <PERSON  S> bases correlate with transcription direction and gene location. <Capitalized> For W-rich genomes, the mRNA-synonymous strand contains regions which, if extruded from negatively supercoiled <AllCaps> DNA, would fold to generate stem-loop structures with A-rich loops. <Capitalized> Similarly, for S-rich genomes the loops would be G-rich. <Capitalized> We suggest that the disposition of genes in nucleic acid sequences arises from their having to adapt to a preexisting mosaic of genomic regions, each distinguished by its potential to extrude single-strand loops enriched for a particular base (or two non-Watson-Crick pairing bases). <Capitalized> The mosaic would have facilitated the intrastrand and interstrand accounting required for correction of mutations, and would have evolved in the early <AllCaps> RNA world before the emergence of protein-encoding capacity. <Capitalized> The preexisting mosaic would have determined transcription direction since there is pressure for all <MixedCase> mRNAs of a cell to have purine-rich loops, thus decreasing loop-loop interactions which might lead to formation of "self" sense-antisense <AllCaps> RNA duplexes. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 MutS homologues have been identified in nearly all organisms examined to date. <Capitalized> They play essential roles in maintaining mitotic genetic fidelity and meiotic segregation fidelity. MutS homologues appear to function as a molecular switch that signals genomic manipulation events. <Capitalized> Here we describe the identification of the human homologue of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae MSH5, which is known to participate in meiotic segregation fidelity and crossing-over. <Capitalized> The human <EndsInDigit> MSH5 (hMSH5) was localized to chromosome 6p22-21 and appears to play a role in meiosis because expression is induced during spermatogenesis between the late primary spermatocytes and the elongated spermatid phase. hMSH5 interacts specifically with hMSH4, confirming the generality of functional heterodimeric interactions in the eukaryotic MutS homologue, which also includes hMSH2-hMSH3 and hMSH2-hMSH6.

 <Capitalized> Monitoring of estrogen mimics by a recombinant yeast assay: synergy between natural and synthetic compounds? 
 
 <Capitalized> Graumann <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Breithofer <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Jungbauer <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute for <Capitalized> Applied <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Agriculture, <Capitalized> Forestry and <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <LOCATION  Vienna,> <PERSON Austria> 
 
 <Capitalized> Properties of mixtures of compounds exhibiting estrogenic potential have been questioned in the past. <Capitalized> Synergistic effects of endocrine disrupters have been proposed, but could never be confirmed. <Capitalized> In this study, the transactivational potential of xenoestrogens and phytoestrogens has been evaluated in a yeast test system. <Capitalized> Pesticides such as endosulfan, dieldrin, atrazine, and the main metabolites, desethylatrazine and desisopropylatrazine, have been tested and their behavior as mixtures is compared to the behavior of the single compounds. <Capitalized> Our results are in contrast to a report (Tran et al., 1996) on the inhibitive effects of xenoestrogens on 17 beta-estradiol-dependent transactivation. <Capitalized> Phytoestrogens have been investigated in a similar manner. <AllCaps> A synergistic effect could not be confirmed for both, xenoestrogens and phytoestrogens. <Capitalized> These compounds are either weak estrogens or completely lack estrogenic potential. <Capitalized> Their endocrine disrupting potential in more complex systems must be therefore attributed to other molecular mechanisms such as to metabolic modification or interference with steroidogenesis. <Capitalized> This study shows that yeast systems are useful tools for monitoring pure estrogenic properties.

 <Capitalized> In the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the non-Mendelian inherited genetic element [URE3] behaves as a prion. <AllCaps> A hypothesis has been put forward which states that [URE3] arises spontaneously from its cellular isoform Ure2p (the product of the <EndsInDigit> URE2 gene), and propagates through interactions of the N-terminal domain of the protein, thus leading to its aggregation and loss of function. <Capitalized> In the present study, various N- and C-terminal deletion mutants of Ure2p were constructed and their cross-interactions were tested in vitro and in vivo using affinity binding and a two-hybrid analysis. <Capitalized> We show that the self-interaction of the protein is mediated by at least two domains, corresponding to the first third of the protein (the so-called prion-forming domain) and the C-terminal catalytic domain.

 <AllCaps> A kinetic locking-on strategy for bioaffinity purification: further studies with alcohol dehydrogenase. 
 
 O'flaherty <AllCaps> M, <PERSON McMahon> <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Mulcahy> <PERSON  P.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Applied <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Technology <Capitalized> Carlow, <PERSON Ireland> 
 
 <Capitalized> The kinetic locking-on strategy improves the selectivity of protein purification procedures based on immobilized cofactor derivatives through use of enzyme-specific substrate analogues in irrigants to promote biospecific adsorption. <Capitalized> This paper describes the development and application of this strategy to the one-chromatographic step affinity purification of NAD(P)+-dependent alcohol dehydrogenases using 8'-azo-linked immobilized NAD(P)+, S6-linked and N6-linked immobilized NAD+, and N6-linked immobilized NADP+ derivatives. <Capitalized> These studies were carried out using alcohol dehydrogenases from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae (YADH, <AllCaps> EC 1.1.1.1), equine liver (HLADH, <AllCaps> EC 1.1.1.1), and <Capitalized> Thermoanaerobium brockii (TBADH, <AllCaps> EC 1.1.1.2). <Capitalized> The results reveal that the factors which require careful consideration before development of a truly biospecific system based on the locking-on strategy include: (i) the stability of the immobilized cofactor derivative; (ii) the spacer-arm composition of the affinity derivative; (iii) the accessible immobilized cofactor concentration; (iv) the soluble locking-on ligand concentration; (v) the dissociation constant of locking-on ligand, and (vi) the identification and elimination of nonbiospecific interference. <Capitalized> The S6-linked immobilized NAD+ derivative (synthesized with a hydrophilic spacer arm) proved to be the most suitable of the affinity adsorbents investigated in the present study for use with the locking-on strategy. <Capitalized> This conclusion was based primarily on the observations that this affinity adsorbent was stable, retained cofactor activity with the "test" enzymes under study, and was not prone to nonbiospecific interactions. <Capitalized> Using this immobilized derivative in conjunction with the locking-on strategy, alcohol dehydrogenase from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae was purified to electrophoretic homogeneity in a single affinity chromatographic step. <Capitalized> Copyright 1999 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Replication fidelity is controlled by <AllCaps> DNA polymerase proofreading and postreplication mismatch repair. <Capitalized> We have genetically characterized the roles of the 5'-->3' Exo1 and the 3'-->5' <AllCaps> DNA polymerase exonucleases in mismatch repair in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae by using various genetic backgrounds and highly sensitive mutation detection systems that are based on long and short homonucleotide runs. <Capitalized> Genetic interactions were examined among <AllCaps> DNA polymerase epsilon (pol2-4) and delta (pol3-01) mutants defective in 3'-->5' proofreading exonuclease, mutants defective in the 5'-->3' exonuclease Exo1, and mismatch repair mutants (msh2, msh3, or msh6). <Capitalized> These three exonucleases play an important role in mutation avoidance. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, the mutation rate in an exo1 pol3-01 mutant was comparable to that in an msh2 pol3-01 mutant, suggesting that they participate directly in postreplication mismatch repair as well as in other <AllCaps> DNA metabolic processes.

 <Capitalized> Cooperative binding of heat shock factor to the yeast <EndsInDigit> HSP82 promoter in vivo and in vitro. 
 
 <Capitalized> Erkine <AllCaps> AM, <Capitalized> Magrogan <AllCaps> SF, <Capitalized> Sekinger <AllCaps> EA, <PERSON  Gross> <AllCaps> DS. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Louisiana> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  Center,> <LOCATION  Shreveport,> <LOCATION  Louisiana> 71130, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Previous work has shown that heat shock factor (HSF) plays a central role in remodeling the chromatin structure of the yeast <EndsInDigit> HSP82 promoter via constitutive interactions with its high-affinity binding site, heat shock element 1 (HSE1). <Capitalized> The HSF-HSE1 interaction is also critical for stimulating both basal (noninduced) and induced transcription. <Capitalized> By contrast, the function of the adjacent, inducibly occupied <EndsInDigit> HSE2 and -3 is unknown. <Capitalized> In this study, we examined the consequences of mutations in HSE1, HSE2, and <EndsInDigit> HSE3 on <AllCaps> HSF binding and transactivation. <Capitalized> We provide evidence that in vivo, <AllCaps> HSF binds to these three sites cooperatively. <Capitalized> This cooperativity is seen both before and after heat shock, is required for full inducibility, and can be recapitulated in vitro on both linear and supercoiled templates. <Capitalized> Quantitative in vitro footprinting reveals that occupancy of <EndsInDigit> HSE2 and -3 by <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> HSF (ScHSF) is enhanced approximately 100-fold through cooperative interactions with the HSF-HSE1 complex. <EndsInDigit> HSE1 point mutants, whose basal transcription is virtually abolished, are functionally compensated by cooperative interactions with <EndsInDigit> HSE2 and -3 following heat shock, resulting in robust inducibility. <Capitalized> Using a competition binding assay, we show that the affinity of recombinant <AllCaps> HSF for the full-length <EndsInDigit> HSP82 promoter is reduced nearly an order of magnitude by a single-point mutation within HSE1, paralleling the effect of these mutations on noninduced transcript levels. <Capitalized> We propose that the remodeled chromatin phenotype previously shown for <EndsInDigit> HSE1 point mutants (and lost in <EndsInDigit> HSE1 deletion mutants) stems from the retention of productive, cooperative interactions between <AllCaps> HSF and its target binding sites.

 <Capitalized> The exocyst is an effector for Sec4p, targeting secretory vesicles to sites of exocytosis. 
 
 <Capitalized> Guo <PERSON  W,> <PERSON  Roth> <AllCaps> D, Walch-Solimena <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Novick <PERSON  P.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Yale> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <AllCaps> PO <PERSON  Box> 208002, <LOCATION  New Haven,> <AllCaps> CT 06520-8002, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Polarized secretion requires proper targeting of secretory vesicles to specific sites on the plasma membrane. <Capitalized> Here we report that the exocyst complex plays a key role in vesicle targeting. Sec15p, an exocyst component, can associate with secretory vesicles and interact specifically with the rab GTPase, Sec4p, in its GTP-bound form. <AllCaps> A chain of protein-protein interactions leads from Sec4p and Sec15p on the vesicle, through various subunits of the exocyst, to Sec3p, which marks the sites of exocytosis on the plasma membrane. Sec4p may control the assembly of the exocyst. <Capitalized> The exocyst may therefore function as a rab effector system for targeted secretion.

 818: <Capitalized> Curr <Capitalized> Opin <Capitalized> Chem <Capitalized> Biol 1999 Feb;3(1):64-70 
 
 <Capitalized> Progress and variations in two-hybrid and three-hybrid technologies. 
 
 <PERSON  Drees> <AllCaps> BL. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Genetics, <PERSON  Box> 357360, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Washington,> <LOCATION  Seattle> WA,98195 <LOCATION  USA.> drees@u.washington.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> The original yeast two-hybrid system and its variants have proven to be effective tools for identification and analysis of protein-protein, protein-DNA and protein-RNA interactions. <Capitalized> The two-hybrid assay is being applied to the entire complement of proteins of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae to characterize the network of protein-protein interactions in the eukaryotic cell. <Capitalized> The development of nontranscriptional cytosolic and membrane-associated two-hybrid methods has made it possible to detect and examine a number of protein-protein interactions in their normal cellular locations. Small-molecule hybrid systems have been developed which can be used to study protein-ligand interactions and to activate cellular processes by forcing protein associations.

 <AllCaps> A protein phosphatase 2C gene, LjNPP2C1, from <Capitalized> Lotus japonicus induced during root nodule development. 
 
 <Capitalized> Kapranov <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Jensen> <AllCaps> TJ, <PERSON  Poulsen> <AllCaps> C, de <PERSON  Bruijn> <AllCaps> FJ, <Capitalized> Szczyglowski <AllCaps> K. 
 
 <LOCATION  Michigan> <Capitalized> State University-Department of <Capitalized> Energy <PERSON  Plant> <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Laboratory, <LOCATION  Michigan> <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University, <PERSON  East> <LOCATION  Lansing,> <AllCaps> MI 48824, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Symbiotic interactions between legumes and compatible strains of rhizobia result in root nodule formation. <Capitalized> This new plant organ provides the unique physiological environment required for symbiotic nitrogen fixation by the bacterial endosymbiont and assimilation of this nitrogen by the plant partner. <Capitalized> We have isolated two related genes (LjNPP2C1 and LjPP2C2) from the model legume <Capitalized> Lotus japonicus that encode protein phosphatase type 2C (PP2C). <Capitalized> Expression of the LjNPP2C1 gene was found to be enhanced specifically in <AllCaps> L. japonicus nodules, whereas the LjPP2C2 gene was expressed at a similar level in nodules and roots. <AllCaps> A glutathione S-transferase-LjNPP2C1 fusion protein was shown to have Mg2+- or Mn2+-dependent and okadaic acid-insensitive PP2C activity in vitro. <AllCaps> A chimeric construct containing the full-length LjNPP2C1 cDNA, under the control of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae alcohol dehydrogenase promoter, was found to be able to complement a yeast PP2C-deficient mutant (pct1Delta). <Capitalized> The transcript level of the LjNPP2C1 gene was found to increase significantly in mature nodules, and its highest expression level occurred after leghemoglobin (lb) gene induction, a molecular marker for late developmental events in nodule organogenesis. <Capitalized> Expression of the LjNPP2C1 gene was found to be drastically altered in specific <AllCaps> L. japonicus lines carrying monogenic-recessive mutations in symbiosis-related loci, suggesting that the product of the LjNPP2C1 gene may function at both early and late stages of nodule development.

 <Capitalized> Integral membrane proteins associated with the nuclear pore complex (NPC) are likely to play an important role in the biogenesis of this structure. <Capitalized> Here we have examined the functional roles of domains of the yeast pore membrane protein Pom152p in establishing its topology and its interactions with other <AllCaps> NPC proteins. <Capitalized> The topology of Pom152p was evaluated by alkaline extraction, protease protection, and endoglycosidase <AllCaps> H sensitivity assays. <Capitalized> The results of these experiments suggest that Pom152p contains a single transmembrane segment with its <AllCaps> N terminus (amino acid residues 1-175) extending into the nuclear pore and its <AllCaps> C terminus (amino acid residues 196-1337) positioned in the lumen of the nuclear envelope. <Capitalized> The functional role of these different domains was investigated in mutants that are dependent on Pom152p for viability. <Capitalized> The requirement for Pom152p in strains containing mutations allelic to the <AllCaps> NPC protein genes <EndsInDigit> NIC96 and <EndsInDigit> NUP59 could be alleviated by Pom152p's <AllCaps> N terminus, independent of its integration into the membrane. <Capitalized> However, complementation of a mutation in <EndsInDigit> NUP170 required both the <AllCaps> N terminus and the transmembrane segment. <Capitalized> Furthermore, mutations in <EndsInDigit> NUP188 were rescued only by full-length Pom152p, suggesting that the lumenal structures play an important role in the function of pore-side <AllCaps> NPC structures.

 <Capitalized> The split-ubiquitin technique was used to detect transient protein interactions in living cells. <Capitalized> Nub, the N-terminal half of ubiquitin (Ub), was fused to Sec62p, a component of the protein translocation machinery in the endoplasmic reticulum of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> Cub, the C-terminal half of <Capitalized> Ub, was fused to the <AllCaps> C terminus of a signal sequence. <Capitalized> The reconstitution of a quasi-native <Capitalized> Ub structure from the two halves of <Capitalized> Ub, and the resulting cleavage by Ub-specific proteases at the <AllCaps> C terminus of <Capitalized> Cub, serve as a gauge of proximity between the two test proteins linked to <Capitalized> Nub and Cub. <Capitalized> Using this assay, we show that Sec62p is spatially close to the signal sequence of the prepro-alpha-factor in vivo. <Capitalized> This proximity is confined to the nascent polypeptide chain immediately following the signal sequence. <Capitalized> In addition, the extent of proximity depends on the nature of the signal sequence. <Capitalized> Cub fusions that bore the signal sequence of invertase resulted in a much lower <Capitalized> Ub reconstitution with Nub-Sec62p than otherwise identical test proteins bearing the signal sequence of prepro-alpha-factor. <Capitalized> An inactive derivative of Sec62p failed to interact with signal sequences in this assay. <Capitalized> These in vivo findings are consistent with Sec62p being part of a signal sequence-binding complex.

 <Capitalized> Departments of <Capitalized> Physiology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Michigan,> <LOCATION  Ann Arbor,> <LOCATION  Michigan> 48109, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Munc18a, a mammalian neuronal homologue of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae Sec1p protein, is essential for secretion, likely as a result of its high affinity interaction with the target <AllCaps> SNARE protein syntaxin 1a (where <AllCaps> SNARE is derived from <AllCaps> SNAP receptor (the soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive fusion protein)). <Capitalized> However, this interaction inhibits vesicle <AllCaps> SNARE interactions with syntaxin that are required for secretory vesicles to achieve competency for membrane fusion. <Capitalized> As such, regulation of the interaction between Munc18a and syntaxin 1a may provide an important mechanism controlling secretory responsiveness. Cyclin-dependent kinase 5 (Cdk5), a member of the Cdc2 family of cell division kinases, co-purifies with Munc18a from rat brain, interacts directly with Munc18a in vitro, and utilizes Munc18a as a substrate for phosphorylation. <Capitalized> We have now demonstrated that Cdk5 is capable of phosphorylating Munc18a in vitro within a preformed Munc18a.syntaxin 1a heterodimer complex and that this results in the disassembly of the complex. <Capitalized> Using site-directed mutagenesis, the Cdk5 phosphorylation site on Munc18a was identified as Thr574. <Capitalized> Stimulation of secretion from neuroendocrine cells produced a corresponding rapid translocation of cytosolic Cdk5 to a particulate fraction and an increase of Cdk5 kinase activity. <Capitalized> Inhibition of Cdk5 with olomoucine decreased evoked norepinephrine secretion from chromaffin cells, an effect not observed with the inactive analogue iso-olomoucine. <Capitalized> The effects of olomoucine were independent of calcium influx as evidenced by secretory inhibition in permeabilized chromaffin cells and in cells under whole-cell voltage clamp. <Capitalized> Furthermore, transfection and expression in chromaffin cells of a neural specific Cdk5 activator, p25, led to a strong increase in nicotinic agonist-induced secretory responses. <Capitalized> Our data suggest a model whereby Cdk5 acts to regulate Munc18a interaction with syntaxin 1a and thereby modulates the level of vesicle <AllCaps> SNARE interaction with syntaxin 1a and secretory responsiveness.

 <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <EndsInDigit> MRE11 gene plays an important role in meiotic recombination, mitotic <AllCaps> DNA repair and telomere maintenance. <Capitalized> We present the isolation of hMRE11B <MixedCase> cDNA from a human HeLa cell <MixedCase> cDNA library as an <EndsInDigit> MRE11 homolog. <Capitalized> Compared to the previously identified hMRE11, hMRE11B contains an additional 84bp sequence that results in a 28 amino-acid insertion close to the C-terminus. <Capitalized> The expression pattern of hMRE11B in different tissues shows the presence of two <MixedCase> mRNA species of approx. 2.6 and 7.5kb. <Capitalized> Overexpression of hMRE11B does not complement the alkylation sensitivity of the mre11 null and temperature-sensitive mutant strains. <Capitalized> In this study, we examine factors that may explain this lack of complementation. <Capitalized> First, both <PERSON  Northern> and <PERSON  Western> analyses rule out the lack of hMRE11B transcription and/or translation in yeast. <Capitalized> Second, we demonstrate that hMre11B, like the yeast Mre11 protein, dimerizes in vivo in a yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> This dimerization requires the C-terminal one-third of hMre11B protein, which includes the 28 amino acids absent in hMre11. <Capitalized> However, hMre11B does not interact with Mre11, Rad50 and Xrs2. <Capitalized> Hence, the lack of protein-protein interaction between hMre11B and the yeast Mre11, Rad50, and Xrs2 may explain the inability of hMRE11B to complement the yeast mre11 mutants. <Capitalized> We rule out the hypothesis that the lack of interaction and, in turn of complementation, is due to the absence of sequence homology at the C-terminal domain of hMre11B compared to the yeast Mre11. <Capitalized> Instead, we propose that the C-terminus of hMre11B participates in protein-protein interaction and functions in a species-specific manner.

 <Capitalized> Nonspecific weak actomyosin interactions: relocation of charged residues in subdomain 1 of actin does not alter actomyosin function. 
 
 <PERSON  Wong> <AllCaps> WW, <PERSON  Doyle> <AllCaps> TC, <Capitalized> Reisler <AllCaps> E. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Chemistry and <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  Los Angeles,> <LOCATION  California> 90095, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Yeast actin mutants with relocated charged residues within subdomain 1 were constructed so we could investigate the functional importance of individual clusters of acidic residues in mediating actomyosin weak-binding states in the cross-bridge cycle. <Capitalized> Past studies have established a functional role for three distinct pairs of charged residues within this region of yeast actin (D2/E4, D24/D25, and E99/E100); the loss of any one of these pairs resulted in the same impairment in weak actomyosin interaction and in its function. <Capitalized> However, the specificity of myosin interaction with these sites has not yet been addressed. <Capitalized> To investigate this, we made and analyzed two new actin mutants, 4Ac/D24A/D25A and 4Ac/E99A/E100A. <Capitalized> In these mutants, the acidic residues of the D24/D25 or E99/E100 sites were replaced with uncharged residues (alanines) and a pair of acidic residues was inserted at the N-terminus, maintaining the overall charge density of subdomain 1. <Capitalized> Using the in vitro motility assays, we found that the sliding and force generation properties of these mutant actins were identical to those of wild-type actin. <Capitalized> Similarly, actin-activated ATPase activities of the mutant and wild-type actins were also indistinguishable. <Capitalized> Additionally, the binding of <EndsInDigit> S1 to these mutant actins in the presence of <AllCaps> ATP was similar to that of wild-type actin. <Capitalized> These results show that relocation of charged residues in subdomain 1 of actin does not affect the weak actomyosin interactions and actomyosin function.

 828: <AllCaps> FEBS <PERSON  Lett> 1999 <PERSON  Jan> 22;443(1):41-7

 <Capitalized> Merkulova <AllCaps> TI, <Capitalized> Frolova <AllCaps> LY, <PERSON  Lazar> <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Camonis <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Kisselev <AllCaps> LL. 
 
 <AllCaps> INSERM U248, <Capitalized> Institut <PERSON  Curie,> <LOCATION  Paris,> <PERSON France> 
 
 <Capitalized> At the termination step of protein synthesis, hydrolysis of the peptidyl-tRNA is jointly catalysed at the ribosome by the termination codon and the polypeptide release factor (eRF1 in eukaryotes). eRF1 forms in vivo and in vitro a stable complex with release factor eRF3, an eRF1-dependent and ribosome-dependent GTPase. <Capitalized> The role of the eRF1-eRF3 complex in translation remains unclear. <Capitalized> We have undertaken a systematic analysis of the interactions between the human eRF1 and eRF3 employing a yeast two-hybrid assay. <Capitalized> We show that the N-terminal parts of eRF1 (positions 1-280) and of eRF3 (positions 1477) are either not involved or non-essential for binding. <Capitalized> Two regions in each factor are critical for mutual binding: positions 478-530 and 628-637 of eRF3 and positions 281-305 and 411-415 of eRF1. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> GTP binding domain of eRF3 is not involved in complex formation with eRF1. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> GILRY pentamer (positions 411-415) conserved in eukaryotes and archaebacteria is critical for eRF1's ability to stimulate eRF3 GTPase. <Capitalized> The human eRF1 lacking 22 C-terminal amino acids remains active as a release factor and promotes an eRF3 GTPase activity whereas C-terminally truncated eRF3 is inactive as a GTPase.

 <Capitalized> Regulation of Hsp90 ATPase activity by tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR)-domain co-chaperones. 
 
 <Capitalized> Prodromou <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Siligardi <AllCaps> G, O'Brien <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Woolfson <AllCaps> DN, <PERSON  Regan> <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Panaretou <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Ladbury <AllCaps> JE, <PERSON  Piper> <AllCaps> PW, <PERSON  Pearl> <AllCaps> LH. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry and <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> College <LOCATION  London,> <PERSON  Gower> <PERSON  Street,> <LOCATION  London> WC1E 6BT, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The in vivo function of the heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) molecular chaperone is dependent on the binding and hydrolysis of <AllCaps> ATP, and on interactions with a variety of co-chaperones containing tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) domains. <Capitalized> We have now analysed the interaction of the yeast TPR-domain co-chaperones Sti1 and Cpr6 with yeast Hsp90 by isothermal titration calorimetry, circular dichroism spectroscopy and analytical ultracentrifugation, and determined the effect of their binding on the inherent ATPase activity of Hsp90. Sti1 and Cpr6 both bind with sub-micromolar affinity, with Sti1 binding accompanied by a large conformational change. <Capitalized> Two co-chaperone molecules bind per Hsp90 dimer, and Sti1 itself is found to be a dimer in free solution. <Capitalized> The inherent ATPase activity of Hsp90 is completely inhibited by binding of Sti1, but is not affected by Cpr6, although Cpr6 can reactivate the ATPase activity by displacing Sti1 from Hsp90. <Capitalized> Bound Sti1 makes direct contact with, and blocks access to the ATP-binding site in the N-terminal domain of Hsp90. <Capitalized> These results reveal an important role for TPR-domain co-chaperones as regulators of the ATPase activity of Hsp90, showing that the ATP-dependent step in Hsp90-mediated protein folding occurs after the binding of the folding client protein, and suggesting that <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis triggers client-protein release.

 <Capitalized> Minn <AllCaps> AJ, <Capitalized> Kettlun <AllCaps> CS, <PERSON  Liang> <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Kelekar <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Vander <PERSON  Heiden> <AllCaps> MG, <Capitalized> Chang <AllCaps> BS, <Capitalized> Fesik <AllCaps> SW, <Capitalized> Fill <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Thompson> <AllCaps> CB. 
 
 <PERSON  Gwen> <PERSON  Knapp> <PERSON  Center> for <PERSON  Lupus> and <Capitalized> Immunology <Capitalized> Research, <LOCATION  Chicago,> <AllCaps> IL, <LOCATION  USA.>

 <AllCaps> ARF proteins, which mediate vesicular transport, have little or no intrinsic GTPase activity. <Capitalized> They rely on the actions of GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs) for their function. <Capitalized> The in vitro GTPase activity of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> ARF proteins Arf1 and Arf2 is stimulated by the yeast Gcs1 protein, and in vivo genetic interactions between arf and gcs1 mutations implicate Gcs1 in vesicular transport. <Capitalized> However, the Gcs1 protein is dispensable, indicating that additional <AllCaps> ARF <AllCaps> GAP proteins exist. <Capitalized> We show that the structurally related protein Glo3, which is also dispensable, also exhibits <AllCaps> ARF <AllCaps> GAP activity. <Capitalized> Genetic and in vitro approaches reveal that Glo3 and Gcs1 have an overlapping essential function at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-Golgi stage of vesicular transport. <Capitalized> Mutant cells deficient for both <AllCaps> ARF GAPs cannot proliferate, undergo a dramatic accumulation of <AllCaps> ER and are defective for protein transport between <AllCaps> ER and Golgi. <Capitalized> The glo3Delta and gcs1Delta single mutations each interact with a sec21 mutation that affects a component of <AllCaps> COPI, which mediates vesicular transport within the ER-Golgi shuttle, while increased dosage of the BET1, <EndsInDigit> BOS1 and <EndsInDigit> SEC22 genes encoding members of a v-SNARE family that functions within the ER-Golgi alleviates the effects of a glo3Delta mutation. <Capitalized> An in vitro assay indicates that efficient retrieval from the <Capitalized> Golgi to the <AllCaps> ER requires these two proteins. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that Glo3 and Gcs1 <AllCaps> ARF GAPs mediate retrograde vesicular transport from the <Capitalized> Golgi to the <AllCaps> ER.

 834: <Capitalized> Biochemistry 1998 <Capitalized> Dec 22;37(51):17637-41 
 
 <Capitalized> Structure and function of the core histone N-termini: more than meets the eye. 
 
 <PERSON  Hansen> <AllCaps> JC, <Capitalized> Tse <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Wolffe> <AllCaps> AP. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Texas> <Capitalized> Health <Capitalized> Science <PERSON  Center> at <LOCATION  San Antonio> 78284-7760, <LOCATION  USA.> hansen@bioc02.uthscsa.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> For two decades, the core histone N-termini generally have been thought of as unstructured domains whose function is to bind to <AllCaps> DNA and screen negative charge. <PERSON  New> data indicates that both the molecular mechanisms of action and biological functions of the core histone N-termini in chromatin are considerably more complex. <Capitalized> At the level of the chromatin fiber, multiple distinct functions of the N-termini are required to achieve higher order chromatin condensation, two of which apparently involve protein-protein rather than protein-DNA interactions. <Capitalized> In addition, the N-termini have been documented to participate in specific interactions with many chromatin-associated regulatory proteins. <Capitalized> Here, we discuss evidence supporting the new concepts that when functioning in their natural chromatin context, (1) the N-termini are engaged primarily in protein-protein interactions, (2) as a consequence of these interactions the N-termini adopt specific secondary structure, (3) posttranslational modifications such as acetylation disrupt the ability of the N-termini to form secondary structure, and (4) because the N-termini perform essential roles in both chromatin condensation and also bind specific chromatin-associated proteins, the global structure and function of any given region of the genome will be determined predominantly by the core histone N-termini and their specific interaction partners. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial

 <Capitalized> Zhang <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Zhang <PERSON  Y,> <PERSON  Collins> <AllCaps> CC, <PERSON  Johnson> <AllCaps> DI, <Capitalized> Zheng <PERSON  Y.>

 <Capitalized> Signal transduction through the <Capitalized> Rho family GTPases requires regulated cycling of the GTPases between the active GTP-bound state and the inactive GDP-bound state. <Capitalized> Rho family members containing an arginine residue at position 186 in the C-terminal polybasic region were found to possess a self-stimulatory GTPase-activating protein (GAP) activity through homophilic interaction, resulting in significantly enhanced intrinsic GTPase activities. <Capitalized> This arginine residue functions effectively as an "arginine finger" in the GTPase activating reaction to confer the catalytic <AllCaps> GAP activity but is not essential for the homophilic binding interactions of <Capitalized> Rho family proteins. <Capitalized> The arginine 186-mediated negative regulation seems to be absent from Cdc42, a <Capitalized> Rho family member important for cell-division cycle regulation, of lower eukaryotes, yet appears to be a part of the turn-off machinery of Cdc42 from higher eukaryotes. <Capitalized> Introduction of the arginine 186 mutation into <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae <EndsInDigit> CDC42 led to phenotypes consistent with down-regulated <EndsInDigit> CDC42 function. <PERSON  Thus,> specific <Capitalized> Rho family GTPases may utilize a built-in arginine finger, in addition to RhoGAPs, for negative regulation.

 <PERSON  Wang> <AllCaps> H, <PERSON  Bedford> <AllCaps> FK, <PERSON  Brandon> <AllCaps> NJ, <PERSON  Moss> <AllCaps> SJ, <PERSON  Olsen> <AllCaps> RW.

 Type-A receptors for the neurotransmitter <AllCaps> GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) are ligand-gated chloride channels that mediate inhibitory neurotransmission. <Capitalized> Each subunit of the pentameric receptor protein has ligand-binding sites in the amino-terminal extracellular domain and four membrane-spanning regions, one of which forms a wall of the ion channel. <Capitalized> Each subunit also has a large intracellular loop that may be a target for protein kinases and be required for subcellular targeting and membrane clustering of the receptor, perhaps by anchoring the receptor to the cytoskeleton. <Capitalized> Neurotransmitter receptors need to be positioned in high density in the cell membrane at sites postsynaptic to nerve terminals releasing that neurotransmitter. <Capitalized> Other members of the superfamily of ligand-gated ion-channel receptors associate in postsynaptic-membrane clusters by binding to the proteins rapsyn or gephyrin. <Capitalized> Here we identify a new cellular protein, GABA(A)-receptor-associated protein (GABARAP), which can interact with the gamma2 subunit of GABA(A) receptors. <AllCaps> GABARAP binds to GABA(A) receptors both in vitro and in vivo, and co-localizes with the punctate staining of GABA(A) receptors on cultured cortical neurons. <Capitalized> Sequence analysis shows similarity between <AllCaps> GABARAP and light chain-3 of microtubule-associated proteins 1A and 1B. <Capitalized> Moreover, the <AllCaps> N terminus of <AllCaps> GABARAP is highly positively charged and features a putative tubulin-binding motif. <Capitalized> The interactions among GABA(A) receptors, <AllCaps> GABARAP and tubulin suggest a mechanism for the targeting and clustering of GABA(A) receptors.

 <Capitalized> Proteins to be transported into the nucleus are recognized by members of the importin-karyopherin nuclear transport receptor family. <Capitalized> After docking at the nuclear pore complex (NPC), the cargo-receptor complex moves through the aqueous pore channel. <Capitalized> Once cargo is released, the importin then moves back through the channel for new rounds of transport. <PERSON  Thus,> importin and exportin, another member of this family involved in export, are thought to continuously shuttle between the nuclear interior and the cytoplasm. <Capitalized> In order to understand how nuclear transporters traverse the <AllCaps> NPC, we constructed functional protein fusions between several members of the yeast importin family, including Pse1p, Sxm1p, Xpo1p, and Kap95p, and the green fluorescent protein (GFP). <Capitalized> Complexes containing nuclear transporters were isolated by using highly specific anti-GFP antibodies. Pse1-GFP was studied in the most detail. Pse1-GFP is in a complex with importin-alpha and -beta (Srp1p and Kap95p in yeast cells) that is sensitive to the nucleotide-bound state of the <Capitalized> Ran GTPase. <Capitalized> In addition, Pse1p associates with the nucleoporins Nsp1p, Nup159p, and Nup116p, while Sxm1p, Xpo1p, and Kap95p show different patterns of interaction with nucleoporins. <Capitalized> Association of Pse1p with nucleoporins also depends on the nucleotide-bound state of Ran; when <Capitalized> Ran is in the GTP-bound state, the nucleoporin association is lost. <AllCaps> A mutant form of Pse1p that does not bind <Capitalized> Ran also fails to interact with nucleoporins. <Capitalized> These data indicate that transport receptors such as Pse1p interact in a Ran-dependent manner with certain nucleoporins. <Capitalized> These nucleoporins may represent major docking sites for Pse1p as it moves in or out of the nucleus via the <AllCaps> NPC.

 <Capitalized> Antagonistic interactions between yeast chaperones Hsp104 and Hsp70 in prion curing. 
 
 <Capitalized> Newnam <AllCaps> GP, <Capitalized> Wegrzyn <AllCaps> RD, <Capitalized> Lindquist <AllCaps> SL, <Capitalized> Chernoff <AllCaps> YO. 
 
 <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Georgia> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Technology, <LOCATION  Atlanta,> <LOCATION  Georgia> 30332-0230, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The maintenance of [PSI], a prion-like form of the yeast release factor Sup35, requires a specific concentration of the chaperone protein Hsp104: either deletion or overexpression of Hsp104 will cure cells of [PSI]. <AllCaps> A major puzzle of these studies was that overexpression of Hsp104 alone, from a heterologous promoter, cures cells of [PSI] very efficiently, yet the natural induction of Hsp104 with heat shock, stationary-phase growth, or sporulation does not. <Capitalized> These observations pointed to a mechanism for protecting the genetic information carried by the [PSI] element from vicissitudes of the environment. <Capitalized> Here, we show that simultaneous overexpression of Ssa1, a protein of the Hsp70 family, protects [PSI] from curing by overexpression of Hsp104. Ssa1 protein belongs to the <Capitalized> Ssa subfamily, members of which are normally induced with Hsp104 during heat shock, stationary-phase growth, and sporulation. <Capitalized> At the molecular level, excess Ssa1 prevents a shift of Sup35 protein from the insoluble (prion) to the soluble (cellular) state in the presence of excess Hsp104. <Capitalized> Overexpression of Ssa1 also increases nonsense suppression by [PSI] when Hsp104 is expressed at its normal level. <Capitalized> In contrast, hsp104 deletion strains lose [PSI] even in the presence of overproduced Ssa1. <Capitalized> Overproduction of the unrelated chaperone protein Hsp82 (Hsp90) neither cured [PSI] nor antagonized the [PSI]-curing effect of overproduced Hsp104. <Capitalized> Our results suggest it is the interplay between Hsp104 and Hsp70 that allows the maintenance of [PSI] under natural growth conditions.

Biol. 17:1160-1169, 1997). <Capitalized> In this work we demonstrate that Ccr4p and Hpr1p are components of the Paf1p-Cdc73p-Pol <AllCaps> II complex. <Capitalized> We have found many synthetic genetic interactions between factors within the Paf1p-Cdc73p complex, including the lethality of paf1Delta ccr4Delta, paf1Delta hpr1Delta, ccr4Delta hpr1Delta, and ccr4Delta gal11Delta double mutants. <Capitalized> In addition, paf1Delta and ccr4Delta are lethal in combination with srb5Delta, indicating that the factors within and between the two <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II complexes have overlapping essential functions. <Capitalized> We have used differential display to identify several genes whose expression is affected by mutations in components of the Paf1p-Cdc73p-Pol <AllCaps> II complex. <Capitalized> Additionally, as previously observed for hpr1Delta, deleting <EndsInDigit> PAF1 or <EndsInDigit> CDC73 leads to elevated recombination between direct repeats. <Capitalized> The paf1Delta and ccr4Delta mutations, as well as gal11Delta, demonstrate sensitivity to cell wall-damaging agents, rescue of the temperature-sensitive phenotype by sorbitol, and reduced expression of genes involved in cell wall biosynthesis. <Capitalized> This unusual combination of effects on recombination and cell wall integrity has also been observed for mutations in genes in the Pkc1p-Mpk1p kinase cascade. <Capitalized> Consistent with a role for this novel form of <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II in the Pkc1p-Mpk1p signaling pathway, we find that paf1Delta mpk1Delta and paf1Delta pkc1Delta double mutants do not demonstrate an enhanced phenotype relative to the single mutants. <Capitalized> Our observation that the Mpk1p kinase is fully active in a paf1Delta strain indicates that the Paf1p-Cdc73p complex may function downstream of the Pkc1p-Mpk1p cascade to regulate the expression of a subset of yeast genes.

 <Capitalized> Conserved core structure in the internal transcribed spacer 1 of the <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe precursor ribosomal <AllCaps> RNA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Lalev <AllCaps> AI, <Capitalized> Nazar <AllCaps> RN. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology and <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Guelph, <Capitalized> Guelph, <LOCATION  Ontario,> N1G 2W1, <PERSON Canada> 
 
 <Capitalized> The structure of the internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS1) in <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe was examined with respect to phylogenetically conserved features in yeasts as well as the binding of transacting factors that potentially play a role in ribosomal maturation. <Capitalized> Computer analyses and probes for nuclease protection indicate a compact, more highly organized structure than previously proposed in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, with distinct structural features which can be recognized in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. <Capitalized> These include a central extended hairpin structure as well as smaller hairpins immediately adjacent to the maturing termini. <Capitalized> Comparisons with <AllCaps> ITS sequences in more diverse organisms indicate that the same features also can be recognized. <Capitalized> This is especially clear in organisms which contain very short sequences in which the putative structures are much less ambiguous. <Capitalized> Again nuclease protection analyses in one of these, <Capitalized> Verticillium albo-atrum, confirm a central hairpin with additional hairpins linked to the maturing termini. <Capitalized> Protein binding and gel retardation studies with the <PERSON  S.> pombe <EndsInDigit> ITS1 further indicate that, as observed in the 3' external transcripted spacer (ETS) region, the extended hairpin is not only the site of intermediate <AllCaps> RNA cleavage during <MixedCase> rRNA processing, but also a site for specific interactions with one or more soluble factors. <Capitalized> Taken together with other analyses on transcribed spacer regions, the present data provide evidence that the spacer regions act not only to organize the maturing terminal sequences but also may serve to organize specific soluble factors, possibly acting in a manner which is analogous with that of the free small nucleolar ribonucleo protein particles (snoRNPs). <Capitalized> Three-hybrid assays in vivo and filter binding assays in vitro demonstrate that rpS14 directly binds to an <AllCaps> RNA stem-loop structure in RPS14B pre-mRNA that is necessary for RPS14B regulation. <Capitalized> Moreover, rpS14 binds to a conserved helix in 18S <MixedCase> rRNA with approximately five- to sixfold-greater affinity. <Capitalized> These results support the model that RPS14B regulation is mediated by direct binding of rpS14 either to its pre-mRNA or to rRNA. <Capitalized> Investigation of these interactions with the three-hybrid system reveals two regions of rpS14 that are involved in <AllCaps> RNA recognition. D52G and E55G mutations in rpS14 alter the specificity of rpS14 for <AllCaps> RNA, as indicated by increased affinity for RPS14B <AllCaps> RNA but reduced affinity for the <MixedCase> rRNA target. <Capitalized> Deletion of the <AllCaps> C terminus of rpS14, where multiple antibiotic resistance mutations map, prevents binding of rpS14 to <AllCaps> RNA and production of functional 40S subunits. <Capitalized> The emetine-resistant protein, rpS14-EmRR, which contains two mutations near the <AllCaps> C terminus of rpS14, does not bind either <AllCaps> RNA target in the three-hybrid or in vitro assays. <Capitalized> This is the first direct demonstration that an antibiotic resistance mutation alters binding of an r protein to <MixedCase> rRNA and is consistent with the hypothesis that antibiotic resistance mutations can result from local alterations in <MixedCase> rRNA structure.

 <Capitalized> Genetic evidence for Pak1 autoinhibition and its release by Cdc42. 
 
 <Capitalized> Tu <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Wigler <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Cold <PERSON  Spring> <Capitalized> Harbor <Capitalized> Laboratory, <Capitalized> Cold <PERSON  Spring> <Capitalized> Harbor, <LOCATION  New York> 11724, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Pak1 protein kinase of <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe, a member of the p21-GTPase-activated protein kinase (PAK) family, participates in signaling pathways including sexual differentiation and morphogenesis. <Capitalized> The regulatory domain of <AllCaps> PAK proteins is thought to inhibit the kinase catalytic domain, as truncation of this region renders kinases more active. <Capitalized> Here we report the detection in the two-hybrid system of the interaction between Pak1 regulatory domain and the kinase catalytic domain. Pak1 catalytic domain binds to the same highly conserved region on the regulatory domain that binds Cdc42, a GTPase protein capable of activating Pak1. Two-hybrid, mutant, and genetic analyses indicated that this intramolecular interaction rendered the kinase in a closed and inactive configuration. <Capitalized> We show that Cdc42 can induce an open configuration of Pak1. <Capitalized> We propose that Cdc42 interaction disrupts the intramolecular interactions of Pak1, thereby releasing the kinase from autoinhibition.

 856: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cells 1998 <Capitalized> Oct 31;8(5):606-13 
 
 Isoform-specific interaction of the cytoplasmic domains of Na,K-ATPase. 
 
 <Capitalized> Yoon <PERSON  T,> <PERSON  Lee> <AllCaps> K. 
 
 <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Pharmacy, <Capitalized> Ewha Woman's <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  Seoul,> Korea. 
 
 <Capitalized> The Na,K-ATPase is a heterodimer consisting of an alpha and a beta subunit, which exchanges intracellular Na+ for extracellular K+ using the energy of <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis. <Capitalized> Several studies have demonstrated that the enzyme exists as an (alphabeta)2 heterotetramer, an oligomer of alphabeta dimers within the cell membrane, at least during some portion of the transport cycle although its functional significance is unknown. <Capitalized> In our study, we employed the yeast two-hybrid system to identify the cytoplasmic domains of the Na,K-ATPase which might be involved in intersubunit and/or intrasubunit interactions to form higher order oligmers. <Capitalized> Our data demonstrate that the N-terminus and the cytoplasmic loop 1 of the alpha2 subunit interact with each other, while those of the alpha1 subunit do not, suggesting that the interaction is isoform-specific. <Capitalized> Therefore, the N-terminal and the cytoplasmic loop 1 might be the regions where the alpha2 subunit, which are involved in alpha alpha interactions, stabilize Na,K-ATPase as alphabeta protomer, diprotomer, or higher order oligomer because the interaction can be intrasubunit as well as intersubunit interactions. <Capitalized> Our study suggests that there may be an isoform-specific difference in the alpha-alpha interaction and that the isoform-specific interaction may contribute significantly to the differences of the physiological function and regulation among the alpha isoforms.

 857: <Capitalized> Biochem <AllCaps> J 1999 <PERSON  Jan> 1;337 ( <Capitalized> Pt 1):89-95 
 
 <Capitalized> The role of the C-terminal region in phosphoglycerate mutase. 
 
 <PERSON  Walter> <AllCaps> RA, <PERSON  Nairn> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Duncan> <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Price> <AllCaps> NC, <PERSON  Kelly> <AllCaps> SM, <Capitalized> Rigden <AllCaps> DJ, Fothergill-Gilmore <LOCATION  LA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Edinburgh,> <PERSON  George> <Capitalized> Square, <LOCATION  Edinburgh> <EndsInDigit> EH8 9XD, <Capitalized> Scotland, U.K. 
 
 <Capitalized> Removal of the C-terminal seven residues from phosphoglycerate mutase from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae by limited proteolysis is associated with loss of mutase activity, but no change in phosphatase activity. <Capitalized> The presence of the cofactor 2, 3-bisphosphoglycerate, or of the cofactor and substrate 3-phosphoglycerate together, confers protection against proteolysis. <Capitalized> The substrate alone offers no protection. <Capitalized> Replacement of either or both of the two lysines at the C-terminus by glycines has only limited effects on the kinetic properties of phosphoglycerate mutase, indicating that these residues are unlikely to be involved in crucial electrostatic interactions with the substrate, intermediate or product in the reaction. <Capitalized> However, the double-mutant form of the enzyme is more sensitive to proteolysis and is no longer protected against proteolysis by the presence of cofactor. <Capitalized> The proteolysed wild-type and two of the mutated forms of the enzyme show a reduced response to 2-phosphoglycollate, which enhances the instability of the phospho form of the native enzyme. <Capitalized> The phosphoglycerate mutase from <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe, which lacks the analogous C-terminal tail, has an inherently lower mutase activity and is also less responsive to stimulation by 2-phosphoglycollate. <Capitalized> It is proposed that the C-terminal region of phosphoglycerate mutase helps to maintain the enzyme in its active phosphorylated form and assists in the retention of the bisphosphoglycerate intermediate at the active site. <Capitalized> However, its role seems not to be to contribute directly to ligand binding, but rather to exert indirect effects on the transfer of the phospho group between substrate, enzyme, intermediate and product.

 <Capitalized> The fluorescence polarization (FP) technique was evaluated to determine molecular interaction between plant lectins and polysaccharides, yeast cells and glycopeptide after labeling the lectins with fluorescein isothiocyanate. <PERSON  Use> of <Capitalized> Lycoris radiata agglutinin allowed determination of the molecular interactions with large biomolecules containing mannose oligomers and polymers. <Capitalized> Another example using a fluorescein-labeled glycopeptide also indicated that use of the <AllCaps> FP method would allow easy observation of the molecular interactions on the quantitative base. <Capitalized> The present technique is highly sensitive and facile because it does not require any washing procedures before measurement.

 <Capitalized> Pazin <AllCaps> MJ, <PERSON  Hermann> <AllCaps> JW, <Capitalized> Kadonaga <AllCaps> JT. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biology and <PERSON  Center> for <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  California,> <LOCATION  San Diego,> <Capitalized> La <Capitalized> Jolla, <LOCATION  California> 92093-0347, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> To gain a better understanding of the role of chromatin in the regulation of transcription by <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II, we examined the relation between promoter structure and the ability of Gal4-VP16 to function with chromatin templates assembled in vitro. <Capitalized> First, to investigate whether there are synergistic interactions among multiple bound factors, we studied promoter constructions containing one or five Gal4 sites and found that a single recognition site is sufficient for Gal4-VP16 to bind to chromatin, to induce nucleosome rearrangement, and to activate transcription. <Capitalized> Notably, we observed that Gal4-VP16 binds to a single site in chromatin with affinity comparable with that which it binds to naked <AllCaps> DNA, even in the absence of ATP-dependent nucleosome remodeling activity. <Capitalized> Second, to explore the relation between translational nucleosome positioning and transcriptional activation, we analyzed a series of promoter constructions in which nucleosomes were positioned by Gal4-VP16 at different locations relative to the <AllCaps> RNA start site. <Capitalized> These experiments revealed that the positioning of a nucleosome over the <AllCaps> RNA start site is not an absolute barrier to transcriptional activation. <Capitalized> Third, to determine the contribution of core promoter elements to transcriptional activation with chromatin templates, we tested the ability of Gal4-VP16 to activate transcription with <AllCaps> TATA box- versus DPE-driven core promoters and found that the <AllCaps> TATA box is not required to achieve transcriptional activation by Gal4-VP16 with chromatin templates. <Capitalized> These results suggest that a single protomer of a strong activator is able to bind to chromatin, to induce nucleosome remodeling, and to activate transcription in conjunction with a broad range of chromatin structures and core promoter elements.

 <Capitalized> The plasma-membrane H+-ATPase of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which belongs to the <EndsInDigit> P2 subgroup of cation-transporting ATPases, is encoded by the <EndsInDigit> PMA1 gene and functions physiologically to pump protons out of the cell. <Capitalized> This study has focused on hydrophobic transmembrane segments <EndsInDigit> M5 and <EndsInDigit> M6 of the H+-ATPase. <Capitalized> In particular, a conserved aspartate residue near the middle of <EndsInDigit> M6 has been found to play a critical role in the structure and biogenesis of the ATPase. B., <Capitalized> Ambesi, A., and <Capitalized> Slayman, <AllCaps> C. <PERSON  W.> (1998) <AllCaps> J. Biol. Chem. 273, 17411-17417). <Capitalized> To search for possible charge-charge interactions between Asp-730 and Arg-695 or His-701, double mutants were constructed in which positively and negatively charged residues were swapped or eliminated. <Capitalized> Strikingly, two of the double mutants (R695D/D730R and R695A/D730A) regained the capacity for normal biogenesis and displayed near-normal rates of <AllCaps> ATP hydrolysis and ATP-dependent H+ pumping. <Capitalized> These results demonstrate that neither Arg-695 nor Asp-730 is required for enzymatic activity or proton transport, but suggest that there is a salt bridge between the two residues, linking <EndsInDigit> M5 and <EndsInDigit> M6 of the 100-kDa polypeptide.

 <AllCaps> DNA sequence-specific recognition by the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae "TATA" binding protein: promoter-dependent differences in the thermodynamics and kinetics of binding.

 <Capitalized> The equilibrium binding and association kinetics of the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <AllCaps> TATA <Capitalized> Binding <Capitalized> Protein (TBP) to the <EndsInDigit> E4 and <PERSON  Major> <Capitalized> Late promoters of adenovirus (TATATATA and <AllCaps> TATAAAAG, respectively), have been directly compared by quantitative DNase <AllCaps> I titration and quench-flow "footprinting". <Capitalized> The equilibrium binding of <AllCaps> TBP to both promoters is described by the equilibrium <AllCaps> TBP + DNA"TATA" left and right arrow TBP-DNA"TATA". <Capitalized> The salt dependence of <AllCaps> TBP binding to both promoters is identical within experimental error while the temperature dependence differs significantly. <Capitalized> The observed rate of association follows simple second-order kinetics over the <AllCaps> TBP concentration ranges investigated. <Capitalized> The salt and temperature dependencies of the second-order association rate constants for <AllCaps> TBP binding the two promoters reflect the dependencies determined by equilibrium binding. <Capitalized> The TBP-E4 promoter interaction is entropically driven at low temperature and enthalpically driven at high temperature while the TBP-Major <Capitalized> Late promoter reaction is entropically driven over virtually the entire temperature range investigated. <Capitalized> These data suggest that the reaction mechanisms of TBP-promoter interactions are <AllCaps> TATA sequence-specific and provide for differential regulation of promoters as a function of environmental variables.

 <EndsInDigit> SH3 binding domains in the dopamine <EndsInDigit> D4 receptor. 
 
 <Capitalized> Oldenhof <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Vickery> <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Anafi <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Oak> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Ray> <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Schoots <AllCaps> O, <PERSON  Pawson> <PERSON  T,> von <Capitalized> Zastrow <AllCaps> M, <LOCATION  Van> <PERSON  Tol> <AllCaps> HH. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Pharmacology, <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Science, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Toronto,> <LOCATION  Ontario,> <PERSON Canada> 
 
 <Capitalized> The dopamine <EndsInDigit> D4 receptor is a <AllCaps> G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) that belongs to the dopamine D2-like receptor family. <Capitalized> Functionally, the D2-like receptors are characterized by their ability to inhibit adenylyl cyclase. <Capitalized> The dopamine <EndsInDigit> D4 receptor as well as many other catecholaminergic receptors contain several putative <EndsInDigit> SH3 binding domains. <PERSON  Most> of these sites in the <EndsInDigit> D4 receptor are located in a polymorphic repeat sequence and flanking sequences in the third intracellular loop. <Capitalized> Here we demonstrate that this region of the <EndsInDigit> D4 receptor can interact with a large variety of <EndsInDigit> SH3 domains of different origin. <Capitalized> The strongest interactions were seen with the SH2-SH3 adapter proteins Grb2 and Nck. <Capitalized> The repeat sequence itself is not essential in this interaction. <Capitalized> The data presented indicate that the different <EndsInDigit> SH3 domains in the adapter proteins interact in a cooperative fashion with two distinct sites immediately upstream and downstream from the repeat sequence. <Capitalized> Removal of all the putative <EndsInDigit> SH3 binding domains in the third intracellular loop of the dopamine <EndsInDigit> D4 receptor resulted in a receptor that could still bind spiperone and dopamine. <Capitalized> Dopamine could not modulate the coupling of these mutant receptors to adenylyl cyclase and <AllCaps> MAPK, although dopamine modulated receptor-G protein interaction appeared normal. <Capitalized> The receptor deletion mutants show strong constitutive internalization that may account for the deficiency in functional activation of second messengers. <Capitalized> The data indicates that the <EndsInDigit> D4 receptor contains <EndsInDigit> SH3 binding sites and that these sites fall within a region involved in the control of receptor internalization.

 869: <Capitalized> Microbiol <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Rev 1998 Dec;62(4):1492-553 
 
 <Capitalized> Posttranscriptional control of gene expression in yeast. 
 
 <PERSON McCarthy> <AllCaps> JE. 
 
 <Capitalized> Posttranscriptional <Capitalized> Control <Capitalized> Group, <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biomolecular <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Manchester> <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Science and <Capitalized> Technology (UMIST), <LOCATION  Manchester> <EndsInDigit> M60 1QD, <Capitalized> United <PERSON Kingdom> J.McCarthy@umist.ac.uk 
 
 <Capitalized> Studies of the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae have greatly advanced our understanding of the posttranscriptional steps of eukaryotic gene expression. <PERSON  Given> the wide range of experimental tools applicable to <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae and the recent determination of its complete genomic sequence, many of the key challenges of the posttranscriptional control field can be tackled particularly effectively by using this organism. <Capitalized> This article reviews the current knowledge of the cellular components and mechanisms related to translation and <MixedCase> mRNA decay, with the emphasis on the molecular basis for rate control and gene regulation. <Capitalized> Recent progress in characterizing translation factors and their protein-protein and RNA-protein interactions has been rapid. <Capitalized> Against the background of a growing body of structural information, the review discusses the thermodynamic and kinetic principles that govern the translation process. <Capitalized> As in prokaryotic systems, translational initiation is a key point of control. <Capitalized> Modulation of the activities of translational initiation factors imposes global regulation in the cell, while structural features of particular 5' untranslated regions, such as upstream open reading frames and effector binding sites, allow for gene-specific regulation. <Capitalized> Recent data have revealed many new details of the molecular mechanisms involved while providing insight into the functional overlaps and molecular networking that are apparently a key feature of evolving cellular systems. <Capitalized> An overall picture of the mechanisms governing <MixedCase> mRNA decay has only very recently begun to develop. <Capitalized> The latest work has revealed new information about the <MixedCase> mRNA decay pathways, the components of the <MixedCase> mRNA degradation machinery, and the way in which these might relate to the translation apparatus. <PERSON  Overall,> major challenges still to be addressed include the task of relating principles of posttranscriptional control to cellular compartmentalization and polysome structure and the role of molecular channelling in these highly complex expression systems.

 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Illinois,> <Capitalized> Urbana 61801, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Opposing cells often communicate signalling events using multivalent interactions between receptors present on their cell surface. <Capitalized> For example, <PERSON  T> cells are typically activated when the <PERSON  T> cell receptor (TCR) and its associated costimulatory molecules are multivalently engaged by the appropriate ligands present on an antigen presenting cell. <Capitalized> In this report, yeast expressing high cell-surface levels of a <AllCaps> TCR ligand (a recombinant antibody to the <AllCaps> TCR <Capitalized> Vbeta domain) were shown to act as 'pseudo' antigen presenting cells and induce <PERSON  T> cell activation as monitored by increased levels of <EndsInDigit> CD25 and <EndsInDigit> CD69 and by downregulation of cell surface <AllCaps> TCR. <Capitalized> Similar levels of <PERSON  T> cell activation could occur even when a 30-fold excess of irrelevant yeast was present, suggesting that such a yeast display system, by virtue of its ability to present ligands multivalently, may be used in highly sensitive procedures to identify novel polypeptides that interact multivalently with cell surface receptors and thereby trigger specific cellular responses.

 <Capitalized> Li <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Jin <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Vershon <AllCaps> AK, <Capitalized> Wolberger <AllCaps> C.

 <Capitalized> The crystal structure of the heterodimer formed by the <AllCaps> DNA binding domains of the yeast mating type transcription factors, MATa1 and MATalpha2, bound to a 21 bp <AllCaps> DNA fragment has been determined at 2.5 <AllCaps> A resolution. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> DNA fragment in the present study differs at four central base pairs from the <AllCaps> DNA sequence used in the previously studied ternary complex. <Capitalized> These base pair changes give rise to a (dA5).(dT5) tract without changing the overall base composition of the <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> The resulting A-tract occurs near the center of the overall 60 degrees bend in the <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Comparison of the two structures shows that the structural details of the <AllCaps> DNA bend are maintained despite the <AllCaps> DNA sequence changes. <Capitalized> Analysis of the A5-tract <AllCaps> DNA subfragment shows that it contains a bend toward the minor groove centered at one end of the A-tract. <Capitalized> The observed bend is larger than that observed in the crystal structures of A-tracts embedded in uncomplexed <AllCaps> DNA, which are straight and have been presumed to be quite rigid. <Capitalized> Variation of the central <AllCaps> DNA base sequence reverses the two <AllCaps> AT base pairs contacted in the minor groove by Arg7 of the alpha2 N-terminal arm without significantly altering the <AllCaps> DNA binding affinity of the a1/alpha2 heterodimer. <Capitalized> The Arg7 side chain accommodates the sequence change by forming alternate <AllCaps> H bond interactions, in agreement with the proposal that minor groove base pair recognition is insensitive to base pair reversal. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the minor groove spine of hydration, which stabilizes the narrowed minor groove caused by <AllCaps> DNA bending, is conserved in both structures. <Capitalized> We also find that many of the water-mediated hydrogen bonds between the a1 and alpha2 homeodomains and the <AllCaps> DNA are highly conserved, indicating an important role for water in stabilization of the a1/alpha2-DNA complex.

 <Capitalized> Cyclophilins are cis-trans-peptidyl-prolyl isomerases that bind to and are inhibited by the immunosuppressant cyclosporin <AllCaps> A (CsA). <Capitalized> The toxic effects of CsA are mediated by the 18-kDa cyclophilin <AllCaps> A protein. <AllCaps> A larger cyclophilin of 40 kDa, cyclophilin 40, is a component of Hsp90-steroid receptor complexes and contains two domains, an amino-terminal prolyl isomerase domain and a carboxy-terminal tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) domain. <Capitalized> There are two cyclophilin 40 homologs in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, encoded by the <EndsInDigit> CPR6 and <EndsInDigit> CPR7 genes. <Capitalized> Yeast strains lacking the Cpr7 enzyme are viable but exhibit a slow-growth phenotype. <Capitalized> In addition, we show here that cpr7 mutant strains are hypersensitive to the Hsp90 inhibitor geldanamycin. <Capitalized> When overexpressed, the <AllCaps> TPR domain of Cpr7 alone complements both cpr7 mutant phenotypes, while overexpression of the cyclophilin domain of Cpr7, full-length Cpr6, or human cyclophilin 40 does not. <Capitalized> The open reading frame YBR155w, which has moderate identity to the yeast p60 homolog STI1, was isolated as a high-copy-number suppressor of the cpr7 slow-growth phenotype. <Capitalized> We show that this Sti1 homolog Cns1 (cyclophilin seven suppressor) is constitutively expressed, essential, and found in protein complexes with both yeast Hsp90 and Cpr7 but not with Cpr6. <Capitalized> Cyclosporin <AllCaps> A inhibited Cpr7 interactions with Cns1 but not with Hsp90. <Capitalized> In summary, our findings identify a novel component of the Hsp90 chaperone complex that shares function with cyclophilin 40 and provide evidence that there are functional differences between two conserved sets of Hsp90 binding proteins in yeast.

 <Capitalized> The human double-stranded <AllCaps> RNA (dsRNA)-dependent protein kinase <AllCaps> PKR inhibits protein synthesis by phosphorylating translation initiation factor 2alpha (eIF2alpha). <Capitalized> Vaccinia virus E3L encodes a <MixedCase> dsRNA binding protein that inhibits <AllCaps> PKR in virus-infected cells, presumably by sequestering <MixedCase> dsRNA activators. <Capitalized> Expression of <AllCaps> PKR in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae inhibits protein synthesis by phosphorylation of eIF2alpha, dependent on its two <MixedCase> dsRNA binding motifs (DRBMs). <Capitalized> We found that expression of <EndsInDigit> E3 in yeast overcomes the lethal effect of <AllCaps> PKR in a manner requiring key residues (Lys-167 and Arg-168) needed for <MixedCase> dsRNA binding by <EndsInDigit> E3 in vitro. <Capitalized> Unexpectedly, the N-terminal half of E3, and residue Trp-66 in particular, also is required for anti-PKR function. <Capitalized> Because the <EndsInDigit> E3 N-terminal region does not contribute to <MixedCase> dsRNA binding in vitro, it appears that sequestering <MixedCase> dsRNA is not the sole function of <EndsInDigit> E3 needed for inhibition of <AllCaps> PKR. <Capitalized> This conclusion was supported by the fact that <EndsInDigit> E3 activity was antagonized, not augmented, by overexpressing the catalytically defective PKR-K296R protein containing functional DRBMs. <Capitalized> Coimmunoprecipitation experiments showed that a majority of <AllCaps> PKR in yeast extracts was in a complex with E3, whose formation was detected interactions between <AllCaps> PKR and the N-terminal half of <EndsInDigit> E3 in the yeast two-hybrid and lambda repressor dimerization assays. <Capitalized> In the latter case, the N-terminal half of <EndsInDigit> E3 interacted with the kinase domain of <AllCaps> PKR, dependent on <EndsInDigit> E3 residue Trp-66. <Capitalized> We propose that effective inhibition of <AllCaps> PKR in yeast requires formation of an E3-PKR-dsRNA complex, in which the N-terminal half of <EndsInDigit> E3 physically interacts with the protein kinase domain of <AllCaps> PKR.

 <Capitalized> Identification of a polar region in transmembrane domain 6 that regulates the function of the <AllCaps> G protein-coupled alpha-factor receptor. 
 
 <PERSON  Dube> <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Konopka <AllCaps> JB. 
 
 <Capitalized> Program in <Capitalized> Molecular and <Capitalized> Cellular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> State <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  New York,> <Capitalized> Stony <PERSON  Brook,> <LOCATION  New York> 11794-5222, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The alpha-factor pheromone receptor (Ste2p) of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae belongs to the family of <AllCaps> G protein-coupled receptors that contain seven transmembrane domains (TMDs). <Capitalized> Because polar residues can influence receptor structure by forming intramolecular contacts between TMDs, we tested the role of the five polar amino acids in <EndsInDigit> TMD6 of the alpha-factor receptor by mutating these residues to nonpolar leucine. <Capitalized> Interestingly, a subset of these mutants showed increased affinity for ligand and constitutive receptor activity. <Capitalized> The mutation of the most polar residue, Q253L, resulted in 25-fold increased affinity and a 5-fold-higher basal level of signaling that was equal to about 19% of the alpha-factor induced maximum signal. <Capitalized> Mutation of the adjacent residue, S254L, caused weaker constitutive activity and a 5-fold increase in affinity. <Capitalized> Comparison of nine different mutations affecting Ser254 showed that an S254F mutation caused higher constitutive activity, suggesting that a large hydrophobic amino acid residue at position 254 alters transmembrane helix packing. <PERSON  Thus,> these studies indicate that Gln253 and Ser254 are likely to be involved in intramolecular interactions with other TMDs. <Capitalized> Furthermore, Gln253 and Ser254 fall on one side of the transmembrane helix that is on the opposite side from residues that do not cause constitutive activity when mutated. <Capitalized> These results suggest that Gln253 and Ser254 face inward toward the other TMDs and thus provide the first experimental evidence to suggest the orientation of a <AllCaps> TMD in this receptor. <Capitalized> Consistent with this, we identified two residues in <EndsInDigit> TMD7 (Ser288 and Ser292) that are potential contact residues for Gln253 because mutations affecting these residues also cause constitutive activity. <Capitalized> Altogether, these results identify a new domain of the alpha-factor receptor that regulates its ability to enter the activated conformation.

 <Capitalized> Technological advances in high-throughput screening. 
 
 <Capitalized> Fernandes <AllCaps> PB. 
 
 <PERSON  Small> <Capitalized> Molecule <Capitalized> Therapeutics Inc., <Capitalized> Monmouth <Capitalized> Junction, <AllCaps> NJ 08852, <LOCATION  USA.> fernandes@smtherapeutics.com 
 
 <AllCaps> A variety of assay technologies continue to be developed for high-throughput screening. <Capitalized> These include cell-based assays, surrogate systems using microbial cells such as yeast and bacterial two-hybrid and three-hybrid systems, and systems to measure nucleic acid-protein and receptor-ligand interactions. <Capitalized> Modifications have been developed for cell-free, homogeneous assay systems, such as time-resolved fluorescence, fluorescence polarization and the scintillation proximity assay. <Capitalized> Innovations in engineering and chemistry have led to delivery systems for nanoliter volumes and sensitive biosensors for ultra-high-throughout screening conducted in nanoliter and picoliter volumes. <Capitalized> Spectroscopic methods have been extended to read single molecule fluorescence. <Capitalized> Technologies are being developed to identify new targets from genomic information in order to design the next generation of screens.

Ligand-receptor interaction for other C19-steroids was also examined. <Capitalized> While 5-androstene-3beta, 17beta-diol (ADIOL) displayed estrogenic activity in this system, 4-androstene-17-dione (androstenedione) and 4-androstene-17beta-ol,3-one (testosterone) did not. <Capitalized> We have investigated whether <AllCaps> DHEA can interact with the human <AllCaps> ER in vivo. <Capitalized> Our findings demonstrate a mechanism by which <AllCaps> DHEA interacts directly with estrogen signaling systems; however, because <AllCaps> DHEA is several orders of magnitude less potent than <EndsInDigit> E2 in this system, we conclude that it essentially is not an estrogen agonist.
