 <Capitalized> Missy <AllCaps> K, <LOCATION  Van> <Capitalized> Poucke <PERSON  V,> <Capitalized> Raynal <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Viala> <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Mauco <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Plantavid <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Chap <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Payrastre <AllCaps> B. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institut <Capitalized> Federatif de <Capitalized> Recherche en <Capitalized> Immunologie <Capitalized> Cellulaire et <Capitalized> Moleculaire, <Capitalized> Universite <PERSON  Paul> <Capitalized> Sabatier and <Capitalized> Centre Hospitalo-Universitaire de <LOCATION  Toulouse,> <AllCaps> INSERM <PERSON  Unite> 326, <PERSON France>

Nucleotide-depleted Rac1 was the most efficient, but the GDP- and GTP-bound forms retained significant PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 binding activity. <Capitalized> This protein-lipid association involved electrostatic as well as hydrophobic interactions, since both phosphate groups located at specific positions of the inositol ring and fatty-acyl chains were absolutely required. <Capitalized> Based on the sequence of Rac1, two potential binding sites were identified, one at the <AllCaps> C terminus and one in the extra alpha-helical domain. <Capitalized> Deletion of these two domains resulted in a complete loss of binding to <AllCaps> PI 3-kinase products. <Capitalized> Finally, PtdIns(3, 4,5)P3 strongly stimulated <AllCaps> GDP dissociation from Rac1 in a dose-dependent manner. <Capitalized> In agreement, data obtained in intact cells suggest that PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 might target Rac1 to peculiar membrane domains, allowing formation of specific clusters containing not only small GTPases but other partners bearing pleckstrin homology domains such as specific exchange factors required for Rac1 and RhoA activation.

 <Capitalized> The heat-shock protein 90 (Hsp90) is a cytosolic molecular chaperone that is highly abundant even at normal temperature. <Capitalized> Specific functions for Hsp90 have been proposed based on the characterization of its interactions with certain transcription factors and kinases including <Capitalized> Raf in vertebrates and flies. <Capitalized> We therefore decided to address the role of Hsp90 for <AllCaps> MAP kinase pathways in the budding yeast, an organism amenable to both genetic and biochemical analyses. <Capitalized> We found that both basal and induced activities of the pheromone-signaling pathway depend on Hsp90. <Capitalized> Signaling is defective in strains expressing low levels or point mutants of yeast Hsp90 (Hsp82), or human Hsp90beta instead of the wild-type protein. Ste11, a yeast equivalent of <Capitalized> Raf, forms complexes with wild-type Hsp90 and depends on Hsp90 function for accumulation. <Capitalized> For budding yeast, Ste11 represents the first identified endogenous "substrate" of Hsp90. <Capitalized> Moreover, Hsp90 functions in steroid receptor and pheromone signaling can be genetically separated as the Hsp82 point mutant T525I and the human Hsp90beta are specifically defective for the former and the latter, respectively. <Capitalized> These findings further corroborate the view that molecular chaperones must also be considered as transient or stable components of signal transduction pathways.

 <Capitalized> The two genes vestigial (vg) and scalloped (sd) are required for wing development in <Capitalized> Drosophila melanogaster. <Capitalized> They present similar patterns of expression in second and third instar wing discs and similar wing mutant phenotypes. vg encodes a nuclear protein without any recognized nucleic acid-binding motif. <Capitalized> Sd is a transcription factor homologous to the human TEF-1 factor whose promoter activity depends on cell-specific cofactors. <Capitalized> We postulate that <Capitalized> Vg could be a cofactor of <Capitalized> Sd in the wing morphogenetic process and that, together, they could constitute a functional transcription complex. <Capitalized> We investigated genetic interactions between the two genes. <Capitalized> We show here that vg and sd co-operate in vivo in a manner dependent on the structure of the <Capitalized> Vg protein. <Capitalized> We ectopically expressed vg in the patch (ptc) domains. <Capitalized> We show evidence that wing-like outgrowths induced by ectopic expression of vg are severely reduced in vg or sd mutant backgrounds. <Capitalized> Accordingly, we demonstrate that ptc-GAL4-driven expression of vg induces both expressions of the endogenous vg and sd genes and that the two <Capitalized> Vg and <Capitalized> Sd proteins have to be produced together to promote wing proliferation. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we show an interaction between the two proteins by double hybrid experiments in yeast. <Capitalized> Our results therefore support the hypothesis that <Capitalized> Sd and <Capitalized> Vg directly interact in vivo to form a complex regulating the proliferation of wing tissue.

 <Capitalized> The vaccinia virus E3L gene product, pE3, is a <MixedCase> dsRNA binding protein that prevents activation of the interferon-induced, dsRNA-activated protein kinase, <AllCaps> PKR. <Capitalized> Activation of <AllCaps> PKR, which results in phosphorylation of the translation initiation factor, eIF2alpha, leads to the inhibition of protein synthesis, a process involved in defense against virus infection. <Capitalized> The E3L gene product has a conserved <MixedCase> dsRNA binding domain (DRBD) in its carboxyl-terminal region and has been shown to function in vitro by sequestration of dsRNA. <Capitalized> We have utilized in vitro binding assays and the yeast two-hybrid system to demonstrate direct interactions of pE3 with <AllCaps> PKR. <Capitalized> By these 367-523) located in the catalytic domain. <Capitalized> The amino-terminal region of <AllCaps> PKR that interacts with pE3 contains a conserved <AllCaps> DRBD, suggesting that <AllCaps> PKR can form nonfunctional heterodimers with pE3, analogous to those seen with other <MixedCase> dsRNA binding proteins. <Capitalized> Interaction of pE3 with the amino-terminal region of <AllCaps> PKR is enhanced by dsRNA. <Capitalized> In contrast, <MixedCase> dsRNA reduces the interaction of pE3 with the carboxyl-terminal region of <AllCaps> PKR. <Capitalized> Competition experiments demonstrate that the carboxyl-terminal region of <AllCaps> PKR, to which pE3 binds, overlaps the region with which eIF2alpha and the pseudosubstrate pK3 interact, suggesting that pE3 may also prevent <AllCaps> PKR activation by masking the substrate binding domain. <PERSON  Like> pE3, the amino-terminal region of <AllCaps> PKR also interacts with the carboxyl-terminal domain of <AllCaps> PKR. <Capitalized> These interactions increase our understanding of the mechanisms by which pE3 downregulates <AllCaps> PKR. <Capitalized> In addition, the <ContainsHyphen> PKR-PKR interactions observed leads us to suggest a novel autoregulatory mechanism for activation of <AllCaps> PKR in which <MixedCase> dsRNA binding to the DRBD(s) induces a conformational change that results in release of the amino terminal region from the substrate binding domain, allowing access to eIF2alpha and its subsequent phosphorylation. <Capitalized> Copyright 1998 <Capitalized> Academic <Capitalized> Press

 <PERSON  Boelens> <AllCaps> WC, <PERSON  Croes> <PERSON  Y,> de <Capitalized> Ruwe <AllCaps> M, de <Capitalized> Reu <AllCaps> L, de <PERSON  Jong> <AllCaps> WW.

 alphaB-Crystallin is one of the six known mammalian small heat-shock proteins (sHsps). <Capitalized> These are characterized by the presence of a conserved sequence of 80-100 residues, which constitutes the putative C-terminal domain. <PERSON  Like> other sHsps, alphaB-crystallin forms multimeric globular complexes, often in combination with related sHsps. <Capitalized> Here we show that in a yeast two-hybrid system, alphaB-crystallin can specifically interact with itself as well as with alphaA-crystallin and Hsp27. <Capitalized> Analyses of the separate domains show that the conserved C-terminal domain (CalphaB) is essential for this interaction between subunits. <Capitalized> To try and detect residues that are important in subunit interaction, the CalphaB domain was used in a two-hybrid screen as bait to select randomly mutated CalphaB mutants. <Capitalized> In this way we obtained nine mutants that were still able to interact with wild-type CalphaB despite the presence of up to 15 replacements. <Capitalized> Similarly, we obtained 16 mutants that were unable to bind, because of the presence of just three to nine replacements. <Capitalized> In binding CalphaB mutants, lysine residues were most often replaced by glutamic acid residues, and in non-binding CalphaB mutants, acidic residues were often found to be replaced by non-charged residues. <Capitalized> This indicates that negative charges are important for subunit interaction and we propose a model to explain this role of acidic residues. <Capitalized> Furthermore, we observed that two homologs of alphaB-crystallin, alphaA-crystallin and Hsp27, generally interact similarly with the binding and non-binding CalphaB mutants as does alphaB-crystallin. <Capitalized> This suggests that interactions involved in the complex formation of these three <MixedCase> sHsps are largely comparable.

 <Capitalized> Several intracellular membrane trafficking events are mediated by tyrosine-containing motifs found within the cytosolic domains of certain integral membrane proteins. <Capitalized> Many of these tyrosine motifs conform to the consensus YXXPhi (where <Capitalized> Phi represents a bulky hydrophobic residue). <Capitalized> This YXXPhi motif has been shown to interact with the medium chain subunits of adaptor complexes that generally link relevant integral membrane protein cytosolic domains to the clathrin coat involved in vesicle formation. <Capitalized> The motif YXXPhi is also very similar to motifs that are targets for phosphorylation by tyrosine kinases. <Capitalized> Tyrosine kinase inhibitors known as tyrphostins are structural analogues of tyrosine, and so it is possible that tyrphostins could also inhibit interactions between medium chains and YXXPhi motifs. <EndsInDigit> TGN38 is a type <AllCaps> I integral membrane protein containing a tyrosine motif, <AllCaps> YQRL, within the cytosolic domain. <Capitalized> We have previously shown that this motif interacts directly with the medium chain subunit of the plasma membrane localized AP-2 adaptor complex (mu2). <Capitalized> We have investigated a range of tyrphostins and demonstrated a specific inhibition of the interaction between mu2 and the <EndsInDigit> TGN38 cytosolic domain by tyrphostin <EndsInDigit> A23 through in vitro analysis and the yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> These data raise the exciting possibility that different membrane traffic events could be inhibited by specific tyrphostins.

 <Capitalized> Krauskopf <AllCaps> A, <LOCATION  Blackburn> <AllCaps> EH.

 <Capitalized> Telomere length is maintained through a dynamic balance between addition and loss of the terminal telomeric <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> Normal telomere length regulation requires telomerase as well as a telomeric protein-DNA complex. <Capitalized> Previous work has provided evidence that in the budding yeasts <Capitalized> Kluyveromyces lactis and <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the telomeric double-stranded <AllCaps> DNA binding protein Rap1p negatively regulates telomere length, in part by nucleating, by its C-terminal tail, a higher-order <AllCaps> DNA binding protein complex that presumably limits access of telomerase to the chromosome end. <Capitalized> Here we show that in <AllCaps> K. lactis, truncating the Rap1p C-terminal tail (Rap1p-DeltaC mutant) accelerates telomeric repeat turnover in the distal region of the telomere. <Capitalized> In addition, combining the rap1-DeltaC mutation with a telomerase template mutation (ter1-kpn), which directs the addition of mutated telomeric <AllCaps> DNA repeats to telomeres, synergistically caused an immediate loss of telomere length regulation. <Capitalized> Capping of the unregulated telomeres of these double mutants with functionally wild-type repeats restored telomere length control. <Capitalized> We propose that the rate of terminal telomere turnover is controlled by Rap1p specifically through its interactions with the most distal telomeric repeats.

 <Capitalized> Jaspersen <AllCaps> SL, <PERSON  Charles> <AllCaps> JF, Tinker-Kulberg <AllCaps> RL, <PERSON  Morgan> <AllCaps> DO.

 <Capitalized> Exit from mitosis requires the inactivation of mitotic cyclin-dependent kinase-cyclin complexes, primarily by ubiquitin-dependent cyclin proteolysis. <Capitalized> Cyclin destruction is regulated by a ubiquitin ligase known as the anaphase-promoting complex (APC). <Capitalized> In the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, members of a large class of late mitotic mutants, including cdc15, cdc5, cdc14, dbf2, and tem1, arrest in anaphase with a phenotype similar to that of cells expressing nondegradable forms of mitotic cyclins. <Capitalized> We addressed the possibility that the products of these genes are components of a regulatory network that governs cyclin proteolysis. <Capitalized> We identified a complex array of genetic interactions among these mutants and found that the growth defect in most of the mutants is suppressed by overexpression of SPO12, YAK1, and <EndsInDigit> SIC1 and is exacerbated by overproduction of the mitotic cyclin Clb2. <Capitalized> When arrested in late mitosis, the mutants exhibit a defect in cyclin-specific <AllCaps> APC activity that is accompanied by high Clb2 levels and low levels of the anaphase inhibitor Pds1. <Capitalized> Mutant cells arrested in <EndsInDigit> G1 contain normal <AllCaps> APC activity. <Capitalized> We conclude that Cdc15, Cdc5, Cdc14, Dbf2, and Tem1 cooperate in the activation of the <AllCaps> APC in late mitosis but are not required for maintenance of that activity in G1.

 <Capitalized> Targeting of vesicles to the acceptor membrane in protein transport depends on membrane proteins called SNAREs. <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae <Capitalized> Golgi t-SNARE Sed5 protein and its neural cognate syntaxin 1 have similar three alpha-helices which are predicted to form coiled coils. <Capitalized> We dissected the helices of Sed5 and found several characteristics unexpectedly distinct from those of syntaxin 1. <PERSON  Most> importantly, only the N-terminal helix is responsible for the binding of Sly1 protein while almost the entire molecule of syntaxin is necessary for the binding of the cognate, Munc-18. <Capitalized> The N-terminal region of Sed5 protein also binds to the C-terminal helix and Sly1 protein interfered this binding.

End5p interacts with actin [4], but its exact function is not yet known. <Capitalized> To help elucidate End5p function, we sought other End5p-interacting proteins and identified the LAS17/BEE1 gene (encoding the yeast homologue of the human Wiskott-Aldrich <Capitalized> Syndrome protein, WASp) as a high-copy-number suppressor of the temperature-sensitive growth and endocytic defects of end5-1 cells (carrying a frameshift mutation affecting the last 213 residues of End5p). <EndsInDigit> LAS17 is unable to suppress a full deletion of <EndsInDigit> END5 (end5 delta), however, suggesting that the defective End5-1p in end5-1 mutants may be stabilised by Las17p. <Capitalized> The amino terminus of Las17p interacts with the carboxyl terminus of End5p in the yeast two-hybrid system and similar interactions have been shown between WASp and a mammalian End5p homologue, WASp-interacting protein (WIP) [5]. <Capitalized> As las17 delta deletion mutants are blocked in endocytosis, we conclude that Las17p and End5p interact and are essential for endocytosis.

 922: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 1998 Oct;18(10):6110-20 
 
 <Capitalized> Functional characterization of the <AllCaps> N terminus of Sir3p. 
 
 <Capitalized> Gotta <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Palladino <AllCaps> F, <PERSON  Gasser> <AllCaps> SM.

 <Capitalized> Sordarin derivatives are remarkably selective inhibitors of fungal protein synthesis. <Capitalized> Available evidence points to a binding site for these inhibitors on elongation factor 2, but high affinity binding requires the presence of ribosomes. <Capitalized> The gene mutated in one of the two isolated complementation groups of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae mutants resistant to the sordarin derivative <EndsInDigit> GM193663 has now been identified. <Capitalized> It is RPP0, encoding the essential protein of the large ribosomal subunit stalk rpP0. <Capitalized> Resistant mutants are found to retain most of the binding capacity for the drug, indicating that mutations in rpP0 endow the ribosome with the capacity to perform translation elongation in the presence of the inhibitor. <Capitalized> Other proteins of the ribosomal stalk influence the expression of resistance, pointing to a wealth of interactions between stalk components and elongation factors. <Capitalized> The involvement of multiple elements of the translation machinery in the mode of action of sordarin antifungals may explain the large selectivity of these compounds, even though the individual target components are highly conserved proteins.

<EndsInDigit> MRS2 gene (MRS2-L232F). <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> MRS2 gene was first implicated in group <AllCaps> II intron splicing by the finding that overexpression of the wild-type gene  <Capitalized> The crystal structure of arginyl-tRNA synthetase (ArgRS) from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a class <AllCaps> I aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase (aaRS), with L-arginine bound to the active site has been solved at 2.75 <AllCaps> A resolution and refined to a crystallographic R-factor of 19.7%. ArgRS is composed predominantly of alpha-helices and can be divided into five domains, including the class I-specific active site. <Capitalized> The N-terminal domain shows striking similarity to some completely unrelated proteins and defines a module which should participate in specific <MixedCase> tRNA recognition. <Capitalized> The C-terminal domain, which is the putative anticodon-binding module, displays an all-alpha-helix fold highly similar to that of <Capitalized> Escherichia coli methionyl-tRNA synthetase. <Capitalized> While ArgRS requires <MixedCase> tRNAArg for the first step of the aminoacylation reaction, the results show that its presence is not a prerequisite for L-arginine binding. <Capitalized> All H-bond-forming capability of L-arginine is used by the protein for the specific recognition. <Capitalized> The guanidinium group forms two salt bridge interactions with two acidic residues, and one H-bond with a tyrosine residue; these three residues are strictly conserved in all ArgRS sequences. <Capitalized> This tyrosine is also conserved in other class <AllCaps> I <MixedCase> aaRS active sites but plays several functional roles. <Capitalized> The ArgRS structure allows the definition of a new framework for sequence alignments and subclass definition in class <AllCaps> I aaRSs.

 <Capitalized> Transmembrane protein insertion orientation in yeast depends on the charge difference across transmembrane segments, their total hydrophobicity, and its distribution. 
 
 <PERSON  Harley> <AllCaps> CA, <PERSON  Holt> <AllCaps> JA, <PERSON  Turner> <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Tipper <AllCaps> DJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Microbiology, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Massachusetts> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <LOCATION  Worcester,> <LOCATION  Massachusetts> 01655, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The determinants of transmembrane protein insertion orientation at the endoplasmic reticulum have been investigated in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae using variants of a <Capitalized> Type <AllCaps> III (naturally exofacial <AllCaps> N terminus (Nexo)) transmembrane fusion protein derived from the <AllCaps> N terminus of Ste2p, the alpha-factor receptor. <PERSON  Small> positive and negative charges adjacent to the transmembrane segment had equal and opposite effects on orientation, and this effect was independent of N- or C-terminal location, consistent with a purely electrostatic interaction with response mechanisms. <AllCaps> A 3:1 bias toward <Capitalized> Nexo insertion, observed in the absence of a charge difference, was shown to reflect the <Capitalized> Nexo bias conferred by longer transmembrane segments. <Capitalized> Orientation correlated best with total hydrophobicity rather than length, but it was also strongly affected by the distribution of hydrophobicity within the transmembrane segment. <Capitalized> The most hydrophobic terminus was preferentially translocated. <Capitalized> Insertion orientation thus depends on integration of responses to at least three parameters: charge difference across a transmembrane segment, its total hydrophobicity, and its hydrophobicity gradient. <Capitalized> Relative signal strengths were estimated, and consequences for topology prediction are discussed. <Capitalized> Responses to transmembrane sequence may depend on protein-translocon interactions, but responses to charge difference may be mediated by the electrostatic field provided by anionic phospholipids.

 <Capitalized> Missense translation errors in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. 
 
 <PERSON  Stansfield> <AllCaps> I, <PERSON  Jones> <AllCaps> KM, <PERSON  Herbert> <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Lewendon <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Shaw> <AllCaps> WV, <PERSON  Tuite> <AllCaps> MF. 
 
 <Capitalized> Research <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Biosciences, <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  Kent,> <PERSON  Canterbury,> <PERSON  Kent,> <EndsInDigit> CT2 7NJ, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> We describe the development of a novel plasmid-based assay for measuring the in vivo frequency of misincorporation of amino acids into polypeptide chains in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The assay is based upon the measurement of the catalytic activity of an active site mutant of type <AllCaps> III chloramphenicol acetyl transferase (CATIII) expressed in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae. <AllCaps> A His195(CAC)-->Tyr195(UAC) mutant of <AllCaps> CATIII is completely inactive, but catalytic activity can be restored by misincorporation of histidine at the mutant <AllCaps> UAC codon. <Capitalized> The average error frequency of misincorporation of histidine at this tyrosine <AllCaps> UAC codon in wild-type yeast strains was measured as 0. 5x10(-5) and this frequency was increased some 50-fold by growth in the presence of paromomycin, a known translational-error-inducing antibiotic. <AllCaps> A detectable frequency of misincorporation of histidine at a mutant Ala195 <AllCaps> GCU codon was also measured as 2x10(-5), but in contrast to the Tyr195-->His195 misincorporation event, the frequency of histidine misincorporation at Ala195 <AllCaps> GCU was not increased by paromomycin, inferring that this error did not result from miscognate codon-anticodon interaction. <Capitalized> The His195 to Tyr195 missense error assay was used to demonstrate increased frequencies of missense error at codon 195 in <EndsInDigit> SUP44 and <EndsInDigit> SUP46 mutants. <Capitalized> These two mutants have previously been shown to exhibit a translation termination error phenotype and the sup44+ and sup46+ genes encode the yeast ribosomal proteins <EndsInDigit> S4 and S9, respectively. <Capitalized> These data represent the first accurate in vivo measurement of a specific mistranslation event in a eukaryotic cell and directly confirm that the eukaryotic ribosome plays an important role in controlling missense errors arising from non-cognate codon-anticodon interactions. <Capitalized> Copyright 1998 <Capitalized> Academic Press.

 <Capitalized> Institut fur <Capitalized> Biochemische <Capitalized> Pharmakologie, <Capitalized> Universitat <Capitalized> Innsbruck, <PERSON  Peter> <PERSON  Mayr> Str. 1, A-6020 <Capitalized> Innsbruck, <PERSON Austria> 
 
 <Capitalized> Sterol Delta8-Delta7 isomerases (SIs) catalyze the shift of the double bond from C8-9 to C7-8 in the B-ring of sterols. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, the isoenzymes in fungi (ERG2p) and vertebrates [emopamil binding protein (EBP)] are structurally completely unrelated, whereas the sigma1 receptor, a mammalian protein of unknown function, bears significant similarity with the yeast ERG2p. <Capitalized> Here, we compare the drug binding properties of SIs and related proteins with [3H]ifenprodil as a common high affinity radioligand (Kd = 1.4-19 nM), demonstrating an intimate pharmacological relationship among ERG2p, sigma1 receptor, and <AllCaps> EBP. <Capitalized> This renders SIs a remarkable example for structurally diverse enzymes with similar pharmacological profiles and the propensity to bind drugs from different chemical groups with high affinity. <Capitalized> We identified a variety of experimental drugs with nanomolar affinity for the human <AllCaps> EBP (Ki = 0.5-14 nM) such as MDL28815, AY9944, triparanol, and U18666A. <Capitalized> These compounds, as well as the fungicide tridemorph and the clinically used drugs tamoxifen, clomiphene, amiodarone, and opipramol, inhibit the in vitro activity of the recombinant human <AllCaps> EBP (IC50 = 0.015-54 microM). <Capitalized> The high affinity of the human <AllCaps> EBP for 3H-tamoxifen (Kd = 3 +/- 2 nM) implies that the <AllCaps> EBP carries the previously described microsomal antiestrogen binding site. <Capitalized> Interactions of the <AllCaps> EBP with structurally diverse lipophilic amines suggest that novel compounds of related structure should be counterscreened for inhibition of the enzyme to avoid interference with sterol Delta8-Delta7 isomerization.

 <Capitalized> Replication protein <AllCaps> A (RPA) is a multisubunit single-stranded DNA-binding (ssDNA) protein that is required for cellular <AllCaps> DNA metabolism. <AllCaps> RPA homologues have been identified in all eukaryotes examined. <Capitalized> All homologues are heterotrimeric complexes with subunits of approximately 70, approximately 32, and approximately 14 kDa. <Capitalized> While <AllCaps> RPA homologues are evolutionarily conserved, they are not functionally equivalent. <Capitalized> To gain a better understanding of the functional differences between <AllCaps> RPA homologues, we analyzed the DNA-binding parameters of <AllCaps> RPA from human cells and the budding yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae (hRPA and scRPA, respectively). <PERSON  Both> yeast and human <AllCaps> RPA bind <MixedCase> ssDNA with high affinity and low cooperativity. <Capitalized> However, <MixedCase> scRPA has a larger occluded binding site (45 nucleotides versus 34 nucleotides) and a higher affinity for oligothymidine than hRPA. <Capitalized> Mutant forms of <MixedCase> hRPA and <MixedCase> scRPA containing the high-affinity DNA-binding domain from the 70-kDa subunit had nearly identical <AllCaps> DNA binding properties. <Capitalized> In contrast, subcomplexes of the 32- and 14-kDa subunits from both yeast and human <AllCaps> RPA had weak <MixedCase> ssDNA binding activity. <Capitalized> However, the binding constants for the yeast and human subcomplexes were 3 and greater than 6 orders of magnitude lower than those for the <AllCaps> RPA heterotrimer, respectively. <Capitalized> We conclude that differences in the activity of the 32- and 14-kDa subunits of <AllCaps> RPA are responsible for variations in the ssDNA-binding properties of <MixedCase> scRPA and hRPA. <Capitalized> These data also indicate that <MixedCase> hRPA and <MixedCase> scRPA have different modes of binding to ssDNA, which may contribute to the functional disparities between the two proteins.

 942: <Capitalized> Genes <Capitalized> Dev 1998 <Capitalized> Aug 15;12(16):2574-86 
 
 Telomere-mediated chromosome pairing during meiosis in budding yeast. 
 
 <Capitalized> Rockmill <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Roeder> <AllCaps> GS. 
 
 <PERSON  Howard> <PERSON  Hughes> <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Institute, <PERSON  Yale> <Capitalized> University, <LOCATION  New Haven,> <LOCATION  Connecticut> 06520-8103 <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Certain haploid strains of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae can undergo meiosis, but meiotic prophase progression and subsequent nuclear division are delayed if these haploids carry an extra chromosome (i. e., are disomic). <Capitalized> Observations indicate that interactions between homologous chromosomes cause a delay in meiotic prophase, perhaps to allow time for interhomolog interactions to be completed. <Capitalized> Analysis of meiotic mutants demonstrates that the relevant aspect of homolog recognition is independent of meiotic recombination and synaptonemal complex formation. <AllCaps> A disome in which the extra chromosome is circular sporulates without a delay, indicating that telomeres are important for homolog recognition. <Capitalized> Consistent with this hypothesis, fluorescent in situ hybridization demonstrates that a circular chromosome has a reduced capacity to pair with its homolog, and a telomere-associated meiotic protein (Ndj1) is required to delay sporulation in disomes. <AllCaps> A circular dimer containing two copies of the same chromosome delays meiosis to the same extent as two linear homologs, implying that physical proximity bypasses the requirement for telomeres in homolog pairing. <Capitalized> Analysis of a disome carrying two linear permuted chromosomes suggests that even nonhomologous chromosome ends can promote homolog pairing to a limited extent. <Capitalized> We speculate that telomere-mediated chromosome movement and/or telomere clustering promote homolog pairing.

 Bcl-2 family proteins and mitochondria. 
 
 <PERSON  Reed> <AllCaps> JC, <Capitalized> Jurgensmeier <AllCaps> JM, <LOCATION  Matsuyama> <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The <PERSON  Burnham> <Capitalized> Institute, <Capitalized> Program on <Capitalized> Apoptosis and <Capitalized> Cell <PERSON  Death> <Capitalized> Research, 10901 <PERSON  North> <PERSON  Torrey> <PERSON  Pines> <Capitalized> Road, <Capitalized> La <Capitalized> Jolla, <AllCaps> CA 92037, <LOCATION  USA.> jreed@burnham-institute.org 
 
 <Capitalized> The Bcl-2 family of proteins plays a pivotal role in regulating cell life and death. <Capitalized> Many of these proteins reside in the outer mitochondrial membrane, oriented towards the cytosol. <Capitalized> Cytoprotective Bcl-2 family proteins such as Bcl-2 and Bcl-XL prevent mitochondrial permeability transition pore opening and release of apoptogenic proteins from mitochondria under many circumstances that would otherwise result in either apoptosis or necrosis. <Capitalized> In contrast, some pro-apoptotic members of this family such as <PERSON  Bax> can induce these destructive changes in mitochondria in both mammalian cells and when expressed exogenously in yeast. <Capitalized> The mechanisms by which Bcl-2 family proteins control cell life and death remain elusive, but may include both the ability to form ion channels or pores in membranes and physical interactions with a variety of proteins implicated in apoptosis regulation.

 <Capitalized> Olmsted <AllCaps> VK, <Capitalized> Awrey <AllCaps> DE, <Capitalized> Koth <AllCaps> C, <Capitalized> Shan <PERSON  X,> <PERSON  Morin> <AllCaps> PE, <Capitalized> Kazanis <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Edwards> <AllCaps> AM, <PERSON  Arrowsmith> <AllCaps> CH.

 <AllCaps> TFIIS is a general transcription elongation factor that helps arrested <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> II elongation complexes resume transcription. <Capitalized> We have previously shown that yeast <AllCaps> TFIIS (yTFIIS) comprises three structural domains (I-III). <Capitalized> The three-dimensional structures of domain <AllCaps> II and part of domain <AllCaps> III have been previously reported, but neither domain can autonomously stimulate transcription elongation. <Capitalized> Here we report the <AllCaps> NMR structural analysis of residues 131-309 of <MixedCase> yTFIIS which retains full activity and contains all of domains <AllCaps> II and <AllCaps> III. <Capitalized> We confirm that the structure of domain <AllCaps> II in the context of fully active <MixedCase> yTFIIS is the same as that determined previously for a shorter construct. <Capitalized> We have determined the structure of the C-terminal zinc ribbon domain of active <MixedCase> yTFIIS and shown that it is similar to that reported for a shorter construct of human <AllCaps> TFIIS. <Capitalized> The region linking domain <AllCaps> II with the zinc ribbon of domain <AllCaps> III appears to be conformationally flexible and does not adopt a single defined tertiary structure. <AllCaps> NMR analysis of inactive mutants of <MixedCase> yTFIIS support a role for the linker region in interactions with the transcription elongation complex.

 <AllCaps> A computational "genome walk" technique to identify regulatory interactions in gene networks. 
 
 <PERSON  Wagner> <AllCaps> A. 
 
 <LOCATION  Santa Fe> <Capitalized> Institute, <AllCaps> NM 87501, <LOCATION  USA.> aw@santafe.edu 
 
 <Capitalized> To delineate the astronomical number of possible interactions of all genes in a genome is a task for which conventional experimental techniques are ill-suited. <Capitalized> Sorely needed are rapid and inexpensive methods that identify candidates for interacting genes, candidates that can be further investigated by experiment. <Capitalized> The subject of this paper is the application of a novel method to the genome of the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae. <Capitalized> The method applies to an important class of gene interactions, that is, transcriptional regulation via transcription factors (TFs) that bind to specific enhancer or silencer sites on <AllCaps> DNA. <Capitalized> The method addresses the question: which of the genes in a genome are likely to be regulated by one or more TFs with known <AllCaps> DNA binding specificity? <Capitalized> It takes advantage of the fact that many TFs show cooperativity in transcriptional activation which manifests itself in closely spaced <AllCaps> TF binding sites. <Capitalized> Such "clusters" of binding sites are very unlikely to occur by chance alone, as opposed to individual sites, which are often abundant both in the genome and in promoter regions. <Capitalized> Statistical information about binding site clusters in the genome, can be complemented by information about (i) known biochemical functions of the <AllCaps> TF, (ii) the structure of its binding site, and (iii) function of the genes near the cluster, to identify genes likely to be regulated by a given transcription factor. <Capitalized> Previously, binding sites of well characterized transcription factors in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae were analyzed. <Capitalized> Here, the method is applied to a somewhat different situation: the yeast <AllCaps> DNA binding activity yE2F, similar to the mammalian transcription factor E2F. yE2F has a <AllCaps> DNA binding specificity identical to E2F, and its binding site shows <AllCaps> UAS activity in a GAL1-based promoter construct. <Capitalized> However, despite its high conservation, the in vivo function of yE2F is unknown. <Capitalized> The analysis carried out the here suggests candidate genes for regulation by yE2F.

Spc110p is an essential structural component of the <AllCaps> SPB and spans between the central and inner plaques of this multilamellar organelle. <Capitalized> The amino terminus of Spc110p faces the inner plaque, the substructure from which spindle microtubules radiate. <Capitalized> We have undertaken a synthetic lethal screen to identify mutations that enhance the phenotype of the temperature-sensitive spc110-221 allele, which encodes mutations in the amino terminus. <Capitalized> The screen identified mutations in <EndsInDigit> SPC97 and SPC98, two genes encoding components of the Tub4p complex in yeast. <Capitalized> The spc98-63 allele is synthetic lethal only with spc110 alleles that encode mutations in the <AllCaps> N terminus of Spc110p. <Capitalized> In contrast, the interactions of Spc110p with Spc97p and Spc98p are not equivalent. <Capitalized> The <AllCaps> N terminus of Spc110p displays a robust interaction with Spc98p in two different two-hybrid assays, while be attributed to a decreased interaction between Spc97-62p and Spc98p. <Capitalized> Together, these studies provide evidence that Spc110p directly links the Tub4p complex to the <AllCaps> SPB. <Capitalized> Moreover, an interaction between Spc98p and the amino-terminal region of Spc110p is a critical component of the linkage, whereas the interaction between Spc97p and Spc110p is dependent on Spc98p.

 955: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Endocrinol 1998 Jun;157(3):361-71 
 
 Post-transcriptional gene regulatory mechanisms in eukaryotes: an overview. 
 
 <PERSON  Day> <AllCaps> DA, <PERSON  Tuite> <AllCaps> MF. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biosciences, <Capitalized> University of <PERSON  Kent,> <PERSON  Canterbury,> <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Expression of a gene can be controlled at many levels, including transcription, <MixedCase> mRNA splicing, <MixedCase> mRNA stability, translation and post-translational events such as protein stability and modification. <Capitalized> The majority of studies to date have focused on transcriptional control mechanisms, but the importance of post-transcriptional mechanisms in regulating gene expression in eukaryotes is becoming increasingly clear. <Capitalized> In this short review, selected examples of post-transcriptional gene regulatory mechanisms operating in both lower and higher eukaryotes will be used to highlight the plethora of such mechanisms already identified. <Capitalized> The underlying theme is that post-transcriptional gene regulation relies on specific RNA-protein interactions that either result in the targeted degradation of the <MixedCase> mRNA or prevent access of the ribosome to the translation start codon. <Capitalized> Such interactions can occur in the 5' or 3' untranslated regions of an <MixedCase> mRNA or within the decoded portion of the molecule. <Capitalized> The importance of these regulatory mechanisms in a range of biological systems is also illustrated. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Academic

 956: <Capitalized> Genetics 1998 Aug;149(4):1717-27

 <Capitalized> The Rho-type GTPase Cdc42p has been implicated in diverse cellular functions including cell shape, cell motility, and cytokinesis, all of which involve the reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton. <Capitalized> Targets of Cdc42p that interface the actin cytoskeleton are likely candidates for mediating cellular activities. <Capitalized> In this report, we identify and characterize a yeast homologue for the mammalian <AllCaps> IQGAP, a cytoskeletal target for Cdc42p. <Capitalized> The yeast <AllCaps> IQGAP homologue, designated Iqg1p, displays a two-hybrid interaction with activated Cdc42p and coimmunoprecipitates with actin filaments. <Capitalized> Deletion of <EndsInDigit> IQG1 results in a temperature-sensitive lethality and causes aberrant morphologies including elongated and round multinucleated cells. <Capitalized> This together with its localization at the mother-bud neck, suggest that Iqg1p promotes budding and cytokinesis. <Capitalized> At restrictive temperatures, the vacuoles of the mutant cells enlarge and vesicles accumulate in the bud. <Capitalized> Interestingly, Iqg1p shows two-hybrid interactions with the ankyrin repeat-containing protein, Akr1p (Kao, L.-R., <AllCaps> J. <PERSON  Peterson,> <AllCaps> J. <Capitalized> Ruiru, <AllCaps> L. <PERSON  Bender,> and <AllCaps> A. <PERSON Bender> 1996. <PERSON Mol> Cell. Biol. 16:168-178), which inhibits pheromone signaling and appears to promote cytokinesis and/or trafficking. <Capitalized> We also show two-hybrid interactions between Iqg1p and Afr1p, a septin-binding protein involved in projection formation (Konopka, J.B., <AllCaps> C. DeMattei, and <AllCaps> C. <PERSON Davis> 1995. <PERSON Mol> Cell. Biol. 15:723-730). <Capitalized> We propose that Iqg1p acts as a scaffold to recruit and localize a protein complex involved in actin-based cellular functions and thus mediates the regulatory effects of Cdc42p on the actin cytoskeleton.

 962: <Capitalized> Adv <PERSON  Genet> 1998;38:185-218 
 
 <AllCaps> DNA breakage and repair. 
 
 <Capitalized> Jeggo <AllCaps> PA. 
 
 <AllCaps> MRC <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Mutation <Capitalized> Unit, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Sussex, <LOCATION  Brighton,> <Capitalized> United <PERSON Kingdom> 
 
 <Capitalized> For many years it has been evident that mammalian cells differ dramatically from yeast and rejoin the majority of their <AllCaps> DNA DSBs by a nonhomologous mechanism, recently termed <AllCaps> NHEJ. <Capitalized> In the last few years a number of genes and proteins have been identified that operate in the pathway providing insights into the mechanism. <Capitalized> These proteins include the three components of DNA-PK, <AllCaps> DNA ligase <AllCaps> IV, and XRCC4. <Capitalized> In yeast Sir2, -3, and -4 proteins are also involved in the process and therefore are likely to play a role in higher organisms. <Capitalized> Studies with yeast suggest that <AllCaps> NHEJ is an error-free mechanism. <Capitalized> Although the process is far from understood, it is likely that the <ContainsHyphen> DNA-PK complex or <Capitalized> Ku alone acts in a complex with the <Capitalized> Sir proteins possibly protecting the ends and preventing random rejoining. <PERSON  Further> work is required to establish the details of this mechanism and to determine whether this represents an accurate rejoining process for a complex break induced by ionizing radiation. <Capitalized> It will be intriguing to discover how the cell achieves efficient and accurate rejoining without the use of homology. <Capitalized> Interactions between the components of <ContainsHyphen> DNA-PK and other proteins playing a central role in damage response mechanisms are beginning to emerge. <Capitalized> Interestingly, there is evidence that <AllCaps> DNA repair and damage response mechanisms overlap in lower organisms. <Capitalized> The overlapping defects of the yeast <Capitalized> Ku mutants, tell mutants, and <AllCaps> AT cell lines in telomere maintenance further suggest overlapping functions or interacting mechanisms. <AllCaps> A challenge for the future will be to establish how these different damage response mechanisms overlap and interact.

 <Capitalized> Arf proteins are ubiquitous, eukaryotic regulators of virtually every step of vesicular membrane traffic. ADP-ribosylation factors are essential in yeast and the lethality resulting from either overexpression or underexpression (deletion) of <Capitalized> Arf genes has previously been ascribed to dysregulation of the secretory process. <Capitalized> We have identified a family of four genes (Suppressors of <Capitalized> Arf ts, SAT) as high copy suppressors of a loss of function allele of <EndsInDigit> ARF1 (arf1-3). <Capitalized> Those proteins with <AllCaps> SAT activity were found to contain a minimal consensus motif, including a <EndsInDigit> C2C2H2 cluster with a novel and specific spacing. <Capitalized> Genetic interactions between members of this family and with <EndsInDigit> ARF1 are consistent with each sharing a common cellular pathway. <Capitalized> Included in this family is Gcs1, a protein previously described (Poon, <PERSON  P.> <PERSON P.> <PERSON  Wang,> X., <PERSON  Rotman,> M., <PERSON  Huber,> I., <Capitalized> Cukierman, E., <PERSON  Cassel,> D., <PERSON  Singer,> <PERSON  R.> A., and <PERSON  Johnston,> <AllCaps> G. <AllCaps> C. (1996) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. <PERSON  U.> <PERSON  S.> <AllCaps> A. 93, 10074-10077) to possess <Capitalized> Arf GTPase-activating protein (GAP) activity, demonstrating a direct interaction between <Capitalized> Arf and at least one of these suppressors. <Capitalized> The suppression of the loss of <Capitalized> Arf function by overexpression of Gcs1 and demonstration of direct, preferential binding of Gcs1 to the activated form of <Capitalized> Arf (Arf.GTP) lead us to conclude that the biological role of Gcs1 is as an effector of the essential function of <Capitalized> Arf in mitotic growth, rather than a down-regulator as implied by the biochemical (Arf GAP) activity. <Capitalized> Suppression of the growth defect of arf1(-3) cells was observed under conditions that did not alter the secretory defect associated with arf1(-) mutation, indicating that the essential role of <Capitalized> Arf in eukaryotes can be distinguished from role(s) in the secretory pathway and appear to employ distinct pathways and effectors.

 <Capitalized> Saltsman <AllCaps> KA, <PERSON  Prentice> <AllCaps> HL, <LOCATION  Kingston> <AllCaps> RE. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Massachusetts> <Capitalized> General <Capitalized> Hospital, <LOCATION  Boston> 02114, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The C-terminal hydrophobic repeat (CTR) of heat shock transcription factor (HSF) has been proposed to regulate <AllCaps> DNA binding by intramolecular interactions with the leucine zipper motifs present in the <AllCaps> HSF trimerization domain. <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe provides a useful model organism for the study of the regulation of <AllCaps> HSF <AllCaps> DNA binding because, unlike <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, <PERSON  S.> pombe hsf is highly heat shock inducible for <AllCaps> DNA binding and contains a clear homology to the <AllCaps> CTR. <Capitalized> We examined the role that the <AllCaps> CTR plays in the regulation of <PERSON  S.> pombe hsf by constructing isogenic strains bearing deletion and point mutations in the chromosomal copy of hsf. <Capitalized> Surprisingly, we found that point mutation of key hydrophobic amino acids within the <AllCaps> CTR, as well as full deletion of it, yielded factors that show normal binding at normal growth temperatures and full levels of heat-induced binding. <Capitalized> Deletion of the <AllCaps> CTR did, however, slightly lower the temperature required for maximal activation. <Capitalized> In contrast, a large deletion of the C-terminus, which removes close to a third of the coding sequence, was deregulated and bound <AllCaps> DNA at control temperature. <Capitalized> Several of the deletion mutants were significantly reduced in their level of expression, yet they showed wild-type levels of <AllCaps> DNA binding activity following heat shock. <Capitalized> These experiments demonstrate that appropriate regulation of the <AllCaps> DNA binding activity of <PERSON  S.> pombe hsf is not solely dependent upon the <AllCaps> CTR, and imply that a feedback mechanism exists that establishes proper levels of <AllCaps> DNA binding following heat shock despite mutations that significantly alter levels of total hsf.

 <PERSON  Howard> <PERSON  Hughes> <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Institute and <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Genetics and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Chicago,> <LOCATION  Illinois> 60637, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Hsp104 is a stress tolerance factor that promotes the reactivation of heat-damaged proteins in yeast by an unknown mechanism. <Capitalized> Herein, we demonstrate that Hsp104 functions in this process directly. <Capitalized> Unlike other chaperones, Hsp104 does not prevent the aggregation of denatured proteins. <Capitalized> However, in concert with Hsp40 and Hsp70, Hsp104 can reactivate proteins that have been denatured and allowed to aggregate, substrates refractory to the action of other chaperones. Hsp104 cooperates with the chaperones present in reticulocyte lysates but not with DnaK of <AllCaps> E. coli. <Capitalized> We conclude that Hsp104 has a protein remodeling activity that acts on trapped, aggregated proteins and requires specific interactions with conventional chaperones to promote refolding of the intermediates it produces.

human fibroblasts. <Capitalized> However, colocalization of <EndsInDigit> IE1 and <AllCaps> PML in PODs is only transient, with both proteins subsequently redistributing into a nuclear diffuse form. <Capitalized> These processes are believed to promote efficient viral <AllCaps> IE transcription and initiation of <AllCaps> DNA synthesis especially at low multiplicities of infection. <Capitalized>  <Capitalized> Laboratory of <Capitalized> Eukaryotic <Capitalized> Gene <Capitalized> Regulation, <Capitalized> National <Capitalized> Institute of <PERSON  Child> <Capitalized> Health and <PERSON  Human> <Capitalized> Development, <Capitalized> Bethesda, <Capitalized> Maryland 20892, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Only five of the nine subunits of human eukaryotic translation initiation factor 3 (eIF3) have recognizable homologs encoded in the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae genome, and only two of these (Prt1p and Tif34p) were identified previously as subunits of yeast eIF3. <Capitalized> We purified a polyhistidine-tagged form of Prt1p (His-Prt1p) by Ni2+ affinity and gel filtration chromatography and obtained a complex of approximately 600 <MixedCase> kDa composed of six polypeptides whose copurification was completely dependent on the polyhistidine tag on His-Prt1p. <Capitalized> All five polypeptides associated with His-Prt1p were identified by mass spectrometry, and four were found to be the other putative homologs of human eIF3 subunits encoded in <PERSON  S.> cerevisiae: YBR079c/Tif32p, Nip1p, Tif34p, and YDR429c/Tif35p. <Capitalized> The fifth Prt1p-associated protein was eIF5, an initiation factor not previously known to interact with eIF3. <Capitalized> The purified complex could rescue Met-tRNAiMet binding to 40S ribosomes in defective extracts from a prt1 mutant or extracts from which Nip1p had been depleted, indicating that it possesses a known biochemical activity of eIF3. <Capitalized> These findings suggest that Tif32p, Nip1p, Prt1p, Tif34p, and Tif35p comprise an eIF3 core complex, conserved between yeast and mammals, that stably interacts with eIF5. Nip1p bound to eIF5 in yeast two-hybrid and in vitro protein binding assays. <Capitalized> Interestingly, Sui1p also interacts with Nip1p, and both eIF5 and Sui1p have been implicated in accurate recognition of the <AllCaps> AUG start codon. <PERSON  Thus,> eIF5 and Sui1p may be recruited to the 40S ribosomes through physical interactions with the Nip1p subunit of eIF3.

 969: <AllCaps> EMBO <AllCaps> J 1998 <PERSON  Jul> 15;17(14):3981-9 
 
 <Capitalized> The molecular chaperone <Capitalized> Ssb from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae is a component of the ribosome-nascent chain complex. 
 
 <Capitalized> Pfund <AllCaps> C, Lopez-Hoyo <AllCaps> N, <Capitalized> Ziegelhoffer <PERSON  T,> <Capitalized> Schilke <AllCaps> BA, Lopez-Buesa <PERSON  P,> <PERSON  Walter> <AllCaps> WA, <Capitalized> Wiedmann <AllCaps> M, <PERSON  Craig> <AllCaps> EA. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biomolecular <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Wisconsin,> <PERSON  Madison,> <AllCaps> WI 53706, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> The 70 <MixedCase> kDa heat shock proteins (Hsp70s) are a ubiquitous class of molecular chaperones. <Capitalized> The <Capitalized> Ssbs of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae are an abundant type of Hsp70 found associated with translating ribosomes. <Capitalized> To understand better the function of <Capitalized> Ssb in association with ribosomes, the Ssb-ribosome interaction was characterized. <Capitalized> Incorporation of the aminoacyl-tRNA analog puromycin by translating ribosomes caused the release of <Capitalized> Ssb concomitant with the release of nascent chains. <Capitalized> In addition, <Capitalized> Ssb could be cross-linked to nascent chains containing a modified lysine residue with a photoactivatable cross-linker. <Capitalized> Together, these results suggest an interaction of <Capitalized> Ssb with the nascent chain. <Capitalized> The interaction of <Capitalized> Ssb with the ribosome-nascent chain complex was stable, as demonstrated by resistance to treatment with high salt; however, <Capitalized> Ssb interaction with the ribosome in the absence of nascent chain was salt sensitive. <Capitalized> We propose that <Capitalized> Ssb is a core component of the translating ribosome which interacts with both the nascent polypeptide chain and the ribosome. <Capitalized> These interactions allow <Capitalized> Ssb to function as a chaperone on the ribosome, preventing the misfolding of newly synthesized proteins.

 970: <Capitalized> Biotechniques 1998 Jul;25(1):85-8, 90-2 
 
 <Capitalized> Development of a yeast trihybrid screen using stable yeast strains and regulated protein expression. 
 
 <PERSON  Fuller> <AllCaps> KJ, <PERSON  Morse> <AllCaps> MA, <PERSON  White> <AllCaps> JH, <PERSON  Dowell> <AllCaps> SJ, <PERSON  Sims> <AllCaps> MJ. 
 
 <Capitalized> Immunology <Capitalized> Unit, <Capitalized> Glaxo <Capitalized> Wellcome <Capitalized> Medicines <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Centre, <Capitalized> Stevenage, <Capitalized> Hertfordshire, <LOCATION  UK.> 
 
 <Capitalized> We describe a yeast trihybrid system that facilitates rapid screening of <MixedCase> cDNA libraries. <Capitalized> Novel yeast vectors were developed that direct integration of <MixedCase> cDNA encoding the bait and third protein component into the yeast chromosome. <AllCaps> A recombinant yeast strain is thus generated (screening strain) and is available for library transformation. <Capitalized> Transformation with the library <AllCaps> DNA is a single, efficient transformation event, allowing the <MixedCase> cDNA library to be represented in one step. <Capitalized> Recovery of the library plasmid from the yeast is also simplified, since it is the only episomal plasmid. <Capitalized> Assay of trihybrid interaction and identification of positive clones is facilitated by regulating expression of the third protein component using the yeast <EndsInDigit> MET3 promoter, which is repressed in the presence of exogenous methionine. <Capitalized> Trihybrid interactions are detected only on media lacking methionine. <Capitalized> This trihybrid system uses the standard <AllCaps> E. coli LacZ and yeast <EndsInDigit> HIS3 reporter genes and is compatible with most available Gal4 activation domain <MixedCase> cDNA libraries. <Capitalized> We describe the successful application of this yeast trihybrid system to the study of phosphoprotein interactions involved in T-cell signaling.

 <Capitalized> Identification of all human protein-protein interactions will lead to a global human protein linkage map that will provide important information for functional genomics studies. <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid system is a powerful molecular genetic approach for studying protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> To apply this technology to generate a human protein linkage map, the first step is to construct two-hybrid <MixedCase> cDNA libraries that cover the entire human genome. <Capitalized> With a homologous recombination-mediated approach, we have constructed a modular human EST-derived yeast two-hybrid library in the Gal4 activation domain-based vector, pACT2. <Capitalized> Quality analysis of this library indicated that the approach of constructing two-hybrid <MixedCase> cDNA libraries from individually arrayed human <AllCaps> EST clones is feasible, and such a two-hybrid library is suitable for detecting protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> This is also the first time that a comprehensive two-hybrid system <MixedCase> cDNA library has been constructed from a collection of individually arrayed <AllCaps> EST clones.

 974: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 1998 <PERSON  Jul> 13;142(1):39-49 
 
 <Capitalized> Assembly of the yeast vacuolar H+-ATPase occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and requires a Vma12p/Vma22p assembly complex. 
 
 <PERSON  Graham> <LOCATION  LA,> <PERSON  Hill> <AllCaps> KJ, <PERSON  Stevens> <AllCaps> TH. 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Biology, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Oregon, <PERSON  Eugene,> <Capitalized> Oregon 97403, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Three previously identified genes from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae, VMA12, VMA21, and VMA22, encode proteins localized to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). <Capitalized> These three proteins are required for the biogenesis of a functional vacuolar ATPase (V-ATPase), but are not part of the final enzyme complex. <Capitalized> Subcellular fractionation and chemical cross-linking studies have revealed that Vma12p and Vma22p form a stable membrane associated complex. Cross-linking analysis also revealed a direct physical interaction between the Vma12p/Vma22p assembly complex and Vph1p, the 100-kD integral membrane subunit of the V-ATPase. <Capitalized> The interaction of the Vma12p/Vma22p complex with Vph1p was transient (half-life of approximately 5 min), reflecting trafficking of this V-ATPase subunit through the <AllCaps> ER en route to the vacuolar membrane. <Capitalized> Analysis of these protein-protein interactions in ER-blocked sec12 mutant cells indicated that the Vph1p-Vma12p/Vma22p interactions are quite stable when transport of the V-ATPase out of the <AllCaps> ER is blocked. <Capitalized> Fractionation of solubilized membrane proteins on a density gradient revealed comigration of Vma22p and Vma12p, indicating that they form a complex even in the absence of cross-linker. Vma12p and Vma22p migrated to fractions separate from Vma21p. <Capitalized> Loss of Vph1p caused the Vma12p/Vma22p complex to sediment to less dense fractions, consistent with association of Vma12p/ Vma22p with nascent Vph1p in <AllCaps> ER membranes. <Capitalized> This is the first evidence for a dedicated assembly complex in the <AllCaps> ER required for the assembly of an integral membrane protein complex (V-ATPase) as it is transported through the secretory pathway.

 <Capitalized> The PRT1, TIF34, GCD10, and <EndsInDigit> SUI1 proteins of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae were found previously to copurify with eukaryotic translation initiation factor 3 (eIF3) activity. <Capitalized> Although TIF32, NIP1, and <EndsInDigit> TIF35 are homologous to subunits of human eIF3, they were not known to be components of the yeast factor. <Capitalized> We detected interactions between PRT1, TIF34, and <EndsInDigit> TIF35 by the yeast two-hybrid assay and in vitro binding assays. <Capitalized> Discrete segments (70-150 amino acids) of <EndsInDigit> PRT1 and <EndsInDigit> TIF35 were found to be responsible for their binding to TIF34.  p21-activated kinases (PAKs) bind to and are activated by <Capitalized> Rho family GTPases such as Cdc42 and Rac. <Capitalized> Since these GTPases play key roles in regulating cell polarity, stress responses, and cell cycle progression, the ability of <AllCaps> PAK to affect these processes has been examined. <Capitalized> We previously showed that fission yeast pak1+ encodes an essential protein that affects mating and cell polarity. <Capitalized> Here, we characterize a second pak gene (pak2+) from <Capitalized> Schizosaccharomyces pombe. <PERSON  Like> the <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae proteins Cla4p and Skm1p, fission yeast Pak2p contains an N-terminal pleckstrin homology domain in addition to a p21-binding domain and a protein kinase domain that are common to other members of the <AllCaps> PAK family. <Capitalized> Unlike pak1+, pak2(+) is not essential for vegetative growth or for mating in <PERSON  S.> pombe. <Capitalized> Overexpression of the wild-type pak2+ allele suppresses the lethal growth defect associated with deletion of pak1+, and this suppression requires both the pleckstrin homology- and the p21-binding domains of Pak2p, as well as kinase activity. <AllCaps> A substantial fraction of Pak2p is associated with membranous components, an association mediated both by the pleckstrin homology- and by the p21-binding domains. <Capitalized> These results show that <PERSON  S.> pombe encodes at least two pak genes with distinct functions and suggest that the membrane localization of Pak2p, directed by its interactions with membrane lipids and Cdc42p, is critical to its biological activity.

 <Capitalized> Bergwerff <AllCaps> AA, <PERSON  Stark> <PERSON  W,> <Capitalized> Fendrich <AllCaps> G, <PERSON  Knecht> <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Blommers> <AllCaps> MJ, <Capitalized> Maerki <PERSON  W,> <Capitalized> Kragten <AllCaps> EA, van <Capitalized> Oostrum <AllCaps> J.

 <Capitalized> The production of recombinant leech-derived tryptase inhibitor (rLDTI) by two different strains of <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae resulted in the secretion of non-glycosylated and glycosylated rLTDI. <Capitalized> Monosaccharide analysis and a-mannosidase treatment demonstrated that glycosylated <MixedCase> rLDTI was exclusively alpha-mannosylated. <AllCaps> A trypsin digest of reduced and S-carboxymethylated glycosylated <MixedCase> rLDTI was separated on a reverse-phase <AllCaps> HPLC column. <Capitalized> Glycopeptides identified by a combination of matrix-assisted laser desorption mass spectrometry, amino acid sequence analysis, and monosaccharide analysis revealed the presence of different glycoforms. <Capitalized> It was found that Ser24, Ser33 and Ser36 were partially glycosylated with a single mannose residue, whereas Thr42 in glycosylated <MixedCase> rLDTI from both strains was fully occupied with manno-oligosaccharides with a degree of polymerization ranging over 1-3 and 1-13 depending on the yeast strain. <Capitalized> In phosphorylated <MixedCase> rLDTI a single phosphate group was predominantly located at the innermost <PERSON  Man> residue of units of mannobiose, mannotriose, mannotetraose and mannopentaose at Thr42. <Capitalized> Oligosaccharides released by alkaline treatment were reduced by sodium borohydride and separated by high-pH anion-exchange chromatography on a CarboPac <EndsInDigit> MA1 column, and analyzed by one- and two-dimensional 1H-NMR spectroscopy. <Capitalized> Besides the major oligosaccharide <PERSON  Man> alpha1-2Man-ol, the (for yeast protein O-glycosylation) unusual <PERSON  Man> alpha1-3Man alpha1-2Man-ol was determined. <Capitalized> The solution conformation of glycosylated <MixedCase> rLDTI was investigated by two-dimensional <AllCaps> NMR spectroscopy. <Capitalized> Structure calculations by means of distance geometry showed that glycosylated <MixedCase> rLDTI is compactly folded and contained small secondary structure elements. <Capitalized> Analysis of the chemical shifts showed that amino acids Val32-Ser33, Ser36-Ser39 and Thr42 were affected by the O-mannosylation. <Capitalized> In addition, changes in chemical shift were observed within the beta-hairpin peptide regions Val13-Ser16 and Gly18-Tyr21 attributed to direct interactions of the mannose residue at Ser36. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the protein-linked oligosaccharides were spatially grouped in a position opposite of the canonical binding loop.

 982: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Cell 1998 Jun;1(7):1051-5 
 
 <AllCaps> A single amino acid change in the yeast retrotransposon Ty5 abolishes targeting to silent chromatin. 
 
 <Capitalized> Gai <PERSON  X,> <Capitalized> Voytas <AllCaps> DF.

 <Capitalized> Many retrotransposons and retroviruses are thought to select integration sites through interactions with specific chromosomal proteins. <Capitalized> In yeast, the Ty5 retrotransposon integrates preferentially with regions bound by silent chromatin, namely the telomeres and the <AllCaps> HMR and <AllCaps> HML mating loci. <AllCaps> A Ty5 mutant (M3) was identified with an approximately 20-fold decrease in targeted integration as measured by a plasmid-based targeting assay. <Capitalized> Often chromosomal insertions generated by M3, none were located at the telomeres or silent mating loci. <AllCaps> A single amino acid change at the boundary of integrase and reverse transcriptase is responsible for the mutant phenotype. <Capitalized> We predict that this mutation lies within a targeting domain that mediates Ty5 target choice by interacting with a component of silent chromatin.

 983: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Gen <PERSON  Genet> 1998 May;258(3):215-21 
 
 <Capitalized> Expression of the yeast <EndsInDigit> BFR2 gene is regulated at the transcriptional level and through degradation of its product. 
 
 <Capitalized> Chabane <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Kepes <AllCaps> F. 
 
 <Capitalized> Service de <Capitalized> Biochimie et de <Capitalized> Genetique <Capitalized> Moleculaire, DBCM/DSV, CEA/Saclay, <Capitalized> Gif, <PERSON France> 
 
 <Capitalized> The essential <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene <EndsInDigit> BFR2 has been isolated as a high-copy suppressor of the growth defects induced by <Capitalized> Brefeldin <AllCaps> A, a drug that disrupts the <Capitalized> Golgi apparatus and its protein influx. <Capitalized> Furthermore, <EndsInDigit> BFR2 has been found to display genetic interactions with four mutations affecting protein transport to the <Capitalized> Golgi apparatus. <Capitalized> Here we show that the level of <EndsInDigit> BFR2 <MixedCase> mRNA rapidly increased over fivefold in response to cold shock, and over threefold following nutrient replenishment by dilution of cells from exhausted to fresh minimal medium. <Capitalized> During subsequent growth, the transcript level returned to its basal values, except for a transient drop toward the end of the exponential phase. <Capitalized> The early burst of transcription was not caused by toxic compounds in the fresh medium, or by synchrony among cells that had simultaneously entered their first cell cycle. <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> BFR2 gene product (Bfr2p) was synthesized following the early burst of mRNA, and was no longer produced when the <MixedCase> mRNA was back to basal level. Bfr2p was finally degraded after growth became limited, and reached undetectable levels in exhausted medium. <Capitalized> Under steady-state conditions of lengthened exponential phase, the intracellular level of Bfr2p remained constant. <Capitalized> This peculiar pattern of gene expression suggests that Bfr2p is essential for mass growth or cell proliferation, whereas it is either toxic or not required during nutrient-limited growth.

 <Capitalized> In vivo interactions among rotavirus nonstructural proteins. 
 
 <PERSON  Gonzalez> <AllCaps> RA, Torres-Vega <AllCaps> MA, <PERSON  Lopez> <PERSON  S,> <PERSON  Arias> <AllCaps> CF. 
 
 <Capitalized> Departamento de <Capitalized> Genetica y <Capitalized> Fisiologia <Capitalized> Molecular, <Capitalized> Universidad <Capitalized> Nacional <Capitalized> Autonoma de <LOCATION  Mexico,> <LOCATION  Cuernavaca,> <Capitalized> Morelos, <LOCATION Mexico> 
 
 <Capitalized> The rotavirus genome encodes six nonstructural (NS) proteins, five of which (NSP1, NSP2, NSP3, NSP5, and NSP6) have been suggested to be involved in a variety of events, such as genome replication, regulation of gene expression, and gene assortment. <Capitalized> These <AllCaps> NS proteins have been found to be associated with replication complexes that are precursors of the viral core, however, little information is available about the intermolecular interactions that may exist among them. <Capitalized> Using the yeast two-hybrid system, which allows the detection of protein-protein interactions in vivo, all possible combinations among the rotavirus <AllCaps> NS proteins were tested, and several interactions were observed. <EndsInDigit> NSP1 interacted with the other four proteins tested; <EndsInDigit> NSP3 associated with itself; and <EndsInDigit> NSP5 was found to form homodimers and to interact with NSP6. Co-immunoprecipitation of proteins from rotavirus-infected cells, using hyperimmune sera monospecific for the <AllCaps> NS proteins, showed the same interactions for <EndsInDigit> NSP1 as those observed in yeast. <Capitalized> Immunofluorescence co-localization analysis of virus-infected epithelial cells revealed that the intracellular distribution of proteins that were seen to interact in yeast had patterns of distribution that would allow such intermolecular interactions to occur. <Capitalized> These findings should contribute to the understanding of the role these proteins play in different aspects of the virus replication cycle.

 985: <PERSON  Mol> <Capitalized> Med 1998 May;4(5):299-323 
 
 <Capitalized> Convergence and divergence of the signaling pathways for insulin and phosphoinositolglycans. 
 
 <PERSON  Muller> <AllCaps> G, <Capitalized> Wied <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Piossek <AllCaps> C, <PERSON  Bauer> <AllCaps> A, <PERSON  Bauer> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Frick> <PERSON  W.> 
 
 <PERSON  Hoechst> <PERSON  Marion> <PERSON  Roussel> <Capitalized> Deutschland GmbH, <Capitalized> Frankfurt am <PERSON  Main,> <LOCATION Germany> guenter.mueller@hmrag.com 
 
 <Capitalized> Phosphoinositolglycan molecules isolated from insulin-sensitive mammalian tissues have been demonstrated in numerous in vitro studies to exert partial insulin-mimetic activity on glucose and lipid metabolism in insulin-sensitive cells. <Capitalized> However, their ill-defined structures, heterogeneous nature, and limited availability have prohibited the analysis of the underlying molecular mechanism. Phosphoinositolglycan-peptide (PIG-P) of defined and homogeneous structure prepared in large scale from the core glycan of a glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol-anchored membrane protein from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae has recently been shown to stimulate glucose transport as well as a number of glucose-metabolizing enzymes and pathways to up to 90% (at 2 to 10 microns) of the maximal insulin effect in isolated rat adipocytes, cardiomyocytes, and diaphragms (G. <PERSON  Muller> et al., 1997, <Capitalized> Endocrinology 138: 3459-3476). <Capitalized> Consequently, we used this <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P for the present study in which we compare its intracellular signaling with that of insulin. <Capitalized> The activation of glucose transport by both <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P and insulin in isolated rat adipocytes and diaphragms was found to require stimulation of phosphatidylinositol (PI) 3-kinase but to be independent of functional p70S6kinase and mitogen-activated protein kinase. <Capitalized> The increase in glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase activity in rat adipocytes in response to <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P and insulin was dependent on both <AllCaps> PI 3-kinase and p70S6kinase. <Capitalized> This suggest that the signaling pathways for <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P and insulin to glucose transport and metabolism converage at the level of <AllCaps> PI 3-kinase. <AllCaps> A component of the <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P signaling pathway located up-stream of <AllCaps> PI 3-kinase was identified by desensitization of isolated rat adipocytes for <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P action by combined treatment with trypsin and NaCl under conditions that preserved cell viability and the insulin-mimetic activity of sodium vanadate but completely blunted the insulin response. <Capitalized> Incubation of the cells with either trypsin or NaCl alone was ineffective. <Capitalized> The desensitized adipocytes were reconstituted for stimulation of lipogenesis by <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P by addition of the concentrated trypsin/salt extract. <Capitalized> The reconstituted adipocytes exhibited 65-75% of the maximal <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P response and similar <EndsInDigit> EC50 values for <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P (2 to 5 microns) compared with control cells. <AllCaps> A proteinaceous N-ethylmaleimide (NEM)-sensitive component contained in the trypsin/salt extract was demonstrated to bind in a functional manner to the adipocyte plasma membrane of desensitized adipocytes via bipolar interactions. <Capitalized> An excess of trypsin/salt extract inhibited <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P action in untreated adipocytes in a competitive fashion compatible with a receptor function for <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P of this protein. <Capitalized> The presence of the putative <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P receptor protein in detergent-insoluble complexes prepared from isolated rat adipocytes suggests that caveolae/detergent-insoluble complexes of the plasma membrane may play a role in insulin-mimetic signaling by PIG-P. <Capitalized> Furthermore, treatment of isolated rat diaphragms and adipocytes with <ContainsHyphen> PIG-P as well as with other agents exerting partially insulin-mimetic activity, such as PI-specific phospholipase <AllCaps> C (PLC) and the sulfonylurea glimepiride, triggered tyrosine phosphorylation of the caveolar marker protein caveolin, which was apparently correlated with stimulation of lipogenesis. <Capitalized> Strikingly, in adipocytes subjected to combined trypsin/salt treatment, PIG-P, PI-specific <AllCaps> PLC, and glimepiride failed completely to provoke insulin-mimetic effects. <AllCaps> A working model is presented for a signaling pathway in insulin-sensitive cells used by PIG(-P) molecules which involves <AllCaps> GPI structures, the trypsin/salt- and NEM-sensitive receptor protein for PIG-P, and additional proteins located in caveolae/detergent-insoluble complexes.

 <PERSON  Hays> <AllCaps> SL, <PERSON  Firmenich> <AllCaps> AA, <PERSON  Massey> <PERSON  P,> <Capitalized> Banerjee <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Berg> <PERSON  P.>

 <Capitalized> The <EndsInDigit> RFA1 gene encodes the large subunit of the yeast trimeric single-stranded <AllCaps> DNA binding protein replication protein <AllCaps> A (RPA), which is known to play a critical role in <AllCaps> DNA replication. <AllCaps> A <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain carrying the rfa1-44 allele displays a number of impaired recombination and repair phenotypes, all of which are suppressible by overexpression of RAD52. <Capitalized> We demonstrate that a rad52 mutation is epistatic to the rfa1-44 mutation, placing <EndsInDigit> RFA1 and <EndsInDigit> RAD52 in the same genetic pathway. <Capitalized> Furthermore, two-hybrid analysis indicates the existence of interactions between Rad52 and all three subunits of <AllCaps> RPA. <Capitalized> The nature of this Rad52-RPA interaction was further explored by using two different mutant alleles of rad52. <PERSON  Both> mutations lie in the amino terminus of Rad52, a region previously defined as being responsible for its <AllCaps> DNA binding ability (U. <AllCaps> H. <PERSON  Mortenson,> <AllCaps> C. <Capitalized> Beudixen, <AllCaps> I. <Capitalized> Sunjeuaric, and <PERSON  R.> <Capitalized> Rothstein, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. <LOCATION  USA> 93:10729-10734, 1996). <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid system was used to monitor the protein-protein interactions of the mutant Rad52 proteins. <PERSON  Both> of the mutant proteins are capable of self-interaction but are unable to interact with Rad51. <Capitalized> The mutant proteins also lack the ability to interact with the large subunit of <AllCaps> RPA, Rfa1. <Capitalized> Interestingly, they retain their ability to interact with the medium-sized subunit, Rfa2. <PERSON  Given> the location of the mutations in the <AllCaps> DNA binding domain of Rad52, a model incorporating the role of <AllCaps> DNA in the protein-protein interactions involved in the repair of <AllCaps> DNA double-strand breaks is presented.

 <Capitalized> Interaction of TATA-binding protein with upstream activation factor is required for activated transcription of ribosomal <AllCaps> DNA by <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> I in <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae in vivo. 
 
 <Capitalized> Steffan <AllCaps> JS, <PERSON  Keys> <AllCaps> DA, <Capitalized> Vu <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Nomura <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Chemistry, <Capitalized> University of California-Irvine, <PERSON  Irvine,> <LOCATION  California> 92697-1700, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Previous in vitro studies have shown that initiation of transcription of ribosomal <AllCaps> DNA (rDNA) in the yeast <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae involves an interaction of upstream activation factor (UAF) with the upstream element of the promoter, forming a stable UAF-template complex; together with TATA-binding protein (TBP), <AllCaps> UAF then recruits an essential factor, core factor (CF), to the promoter, forming a stable preinitiation complex. <AllCaps> TBP interacts with both <AllCaps> UAF and <AllCaps> CF in vitro. <Capitalized> In addition, a subunit of <AllCaps> UAF, Rrn9p, interacts with <AllCaps> TBP in vitro and in the two-hybrid system, suggesting the possible importance of this interaction for <AllCaps> UAF function. <Capitalized> Using the yeast two-hybrid system, we have identified three mutations in <EndsInDigit> RRN9 that abolish the interaction of Rrn9p with <AllCaps> TBP without affecting its interaction with Rrn10p, another subunit of <AllCaps> UAF. <Capitalized> Yeast cells containing any one of these individual mutations, L110S, L269P, or L274Q, did not show any growth defects. <Capitalized> However, cells containing a combination of L110S with one of the other two mutations showed a temperature-sensitive phenotype, and this phenotype was suppressed by fusing the mutant genes to SPT15, which encodes <AllCaps> TBP. <Capitalized> In addition, another mutation (F186S), which disrupts both Rrn9p-TBP and Rrn9p-Rrn10p interactions in the two-hybrid system, abolished <AllCaps> UAF function in vivo, and this mutational defect was suppressed by fusion of the mutant gene to <EndsInDigit> SPT15 combined with overexpression of Rrn10p. <Capitalized> These experiments demonstrate that the interaction of <AllCaps> UAF with <AllCaps> TBP, which is presumably achieved by the interaction of Rrn9p with <AllCaps> TBP, is indeed important for high-level transcription of <MixedCase> rDNA by <AllCaps> RNA polymerase <AllCaps> I in vivo.
