 <Capitalized> Interaction between mitochondria and the actin cytoskeleton in budding yeast requires two integral mitochondrial outer membrane proteins, Mmm1p and Mdm10p. 
 
 <Capitalized> Boldogh <AllCaps> I, <Capitalized> Vojtov <AllCaps> N, <Capitalized> Karmon <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Pon <LOCATION  LA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Anatomy and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <LOCATION  Columbia> <Capitalized> University <Capitalized> College of <Capitalized> Physicians and <Capitalized> Surgeons, <LOCATION  New York,> <LOCATION  New York> 10032, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Transfer of mitochondria to daughter cells during yeast cell division is essential for viable progeny. <Capitalized> The actin cytoskeleton is required for this process, potentially as a track to direct mitochondrial movement into the bud. <Capitalized> Sedimentation assays reveal two different components required for mitochondria-actin interactions: (1) mitochondrial actin binding protein(s) (mABP), a peripheral mitochondrial outer membrane protein(s) with ATP-sensitive actin binding activity, and (2) a salt-inextractable, presumably integral, membrane protein(s) required for docking of <MixedCase> mABP on the organelle. <MixedCase> mABP activity is abolished by treatment of mitochondria with high salt. <Capitalized> Addition of either the salt-extracted mitochondrial peripheral membrane proteins (SE), or a protein fraction with ATP-sensitive actin-binding activity isolated from <AllCaps> SE, to salt-washed mitochondria restores this activity. <MixedCase> mABP docking activity is saturable, resistant to high salt, and inhibited by pre-treatment of salt-washed mitochondria with papain. <Capitalized> Two integral mitochondrial outer membrane proteins, Mmm1p (Burgess, S.M., <AllCaps> M. <Capitalized> Delannoy, and R.E. <PERSON Jensen> 1994. J.Cell Biol. 126:1375-1391) and Mdm10p, (Sogo, L.F., and M.P. Yaffe. 1994. J.Cell Biol. 126:1361- 1373) are required for these actin-mitochondria interactions. <Capitalized> Mitochondria isolated from an mmm1-1 temperature-sensitive mutant or from an mdm10 deletion mutant show no <MixedCase> mABP activity and no <MixedCase> mABP docking activity. <Capitalized> Consistent with this, mitochondrial motility in vivo in mmm1-1 and mdm10Delta mutants appears to be actin independent. <Capitalized> Depolymerization of F-actin using latrunculin-A results in loss of long-distance, linear movement and a fivefold decrease in the velocity of mitochondrial movement. <Capitalized> Mitochondrial motility in mmm1-1 and mdm10Delta mutants is indistinguishable from that in latrunculin-A-treated wild-type cells. <Capitalized> We propose that Mmm1p and Mdm10p are required for docking of <MixedCase> mABP on the surface of yeast mitochondria and coupling the organelle to the actin cytoskeleton.

 <Capitalized> Liefshitz <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Steinlauf <PERSON  R,> <PERSON  Friedl> <AllCaps> A, Eckardt-Schupp <AllCaps> F, <Capitalized> Kupiec <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Molecular <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Biotechnology, <LOCATION  Tel Aviv> <Capitalized> University, <PERSON Israel> 
 
 <Capitalized> We have created an isogenic series of yeast strains that carry genetic systems to monitor different types of recombination and mutation [B. <Capitalized> Liefshitz, <AllCaps> A. <Capitalized> Parket, <PERSON  R.> <Capitalized> Maya, <AllCaps> M. <Capitalized> Kupiec, <Capitalized> The role of <AllCaps> DNA repair genes in recombination between repeated sequences in yeast, <Capitalized> Genetics 140 (1995) 1199-1211.]. <Capitalized> In the present study we characterize the effect of mutations in genes of the 'error-prone' or postreplicative repair group on recombination and mutation. <Capitalized> We show that rad5 and rad18 strains have elevated levels of spontaneous recombination, both of ectopic gene conversion and of recombination between direct repeats. <Capitalized> The increase in recombination levels is similar in both mutants and in the rad5 rad18 double mutant, suggesting that the <EndsInDigit> RAD5 and <EndsInDigit> RAD18 gene products act together with respect to spontaneous recombination. <Capitalized> In contrast, <EndsInDigit> RAD5 and <EndsInDigit> RAD18 play alternative roles in mutagenic repair: mutations in each of these genes elevate spontaneous forward mutation at the <EndsInDigit> CAN1 locus, but when both genes are deleted, a low level of spontaneous mutagenesis is seen. <Capitalized> The RAD5/RAD18 pathway of mutagenic repair is dependent on the REV3-encoded translesion polymerase. <Capitalized> We analyze the interactions between the <EndsInDigit> RAD5 and <EndsInDigit> RAD18 gene products and other repair genes. <Capitalized> The high recombination levels seen in rad5 and rad18 mutants is dependent on the RAD1, RAD51, RAD52, and <EndsInDigit> RAD57 genes. <Capitalized> The Srs2 helicase plays an important role in creating the recombinogenic substrate(s) processed by the <EndsInDigit> RAD5 and <EndsInDigit> RAD18 gene products.

 <PERSON  Osborne> <AllCaps> MA, <PERSON  Dalton> <PERSON  S,> <Capitalized> Kochan <AllCaps> JP. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of Inflammation/Autoimmune <Capitalized> Diseases, <ContainsHyphen> Hoffmann-La <COMPANY  Roche,>> Inc., <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 Protein-protein interactions are often dependent on the post-translational modification of one component of a complex. <Capitalized> To facilitate the study of these interactions in signal transduction, we have developed the yeast tribrid system, a modification of the yeast two-hybrid system. <Capitalized> We demonstrate that the interactions are dependent upon the presence of a tyrosine kinase, an <EndsInDigit> SH2 domain and a tyrosine containing substrate. <Capitalized> Using the gamma subunit of the high-affinity IgE receptor, <Capitalized> Fc epsilon <AllCaps> RI, this approach has been used to isolate a novel SH2-containing family member. <Capitalized> The <MixedCase> mRNA encoding this novel protein is differentially expressed in rat tissues. <Capitalized> The yeast tribrid system can be readily adapted for the characterization of novel tyrosine kinases or substrates, as well as the study of protein-protein interactions which involve other post-translational modifications.

 <AllCaps> TRAPP, a highly conserved novel complex on the cis-Golgi that mediates vesicle docking and fusion. 
 
 <Capitalized> Sacher <AllCaps> M, <Capitalized> Jiang <PERSON  Y,> <Capitalized> Barrowman <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Scarpa <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Burston <AllCaps> J, <Capitalized> Zhang <AllCaps> L, <Capitalized> Schieltz <AllCaps> D, <PERSON  Yates> <AllCaps> JR 3rd, <Capitalized> Abeliovich <AllCaps> H, Ferro-Novick <PERSON  S.> 
 
 <PERSON  Howard> <PERSON  Hughes> <Capitalized> Medical <Capitalized> Institute and the <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Yale> <Capitalized> University <PERSON  School> of <Capitalized> Medicine, <LOCATION  New Haven,> <AllCaps> CT 06510, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> We previously identified <EndsInDigit> BET3 by its genetic interactions with BET1, a gene whose SNARE-like product acts in endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-to-Golgi transport. <Capitalized> To gain insight into the function of Bet3p, we added three c-myc tags to its C-terminus and immunopurified this protein from a clarified detergent extract. <Capitalized> Here we report that Bet3p is a member of a large complex ( approximately 800 kDa) that we call <AllCaps> TRAPP (transport protein particle). <Capitalized> We propose that <AllCaps> TRAPP plays a key role in the targeting and/or fusion of ER-to-Golgi transport vesicles with their acceptor compartment. <Capitalized> The localization of Bet3p to the cis-Golgi complex, as well as biochemical studies showing that Bet3p functions on this compartment, support this hypothesis. <AllCaps> TRAPP contains at least nine other constituents, five of which have been identified and shown to be highly conserved novel proteins.

 <Capitalized> The structure of the N-terminus of striated muscle alpha-tropomyosin in a chimeric peptide: nuclear magnetic resonance structure and circular dichroism studies. 
 
 <PERSON  Greenfield> <AllCaps> NJ, <Capitalized> Montelione <AllCaps> GT, <Capitalized> Farid <AllCaps> RS, Hitchcock-DeGregori <AllCaps> SE. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Neuroscience and <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  Robert> <PERSON  Wood> <PERSON  Johnson> <Capitalized> Medical <PERSON  School,> <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Medicine and <Capitalized> Dentistry of <LOCATION  New Jersey,> <Capitalized> Piscataway 08854-5635, <LOCATION  USA.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Tropomyosins (TMs) are highly conserved, coiled-coil, actin binding regulatory proteins found in most eukaryotic cells. <Capitalized> The amino-terminal domain of 284-residue TMs is among the most conserved and functionally important regions. <Capitalized> The first nine residues are proposed to bind to the carboxyl-terminal nine residues to form the "overlap" region between successive TMs, which bind along the actin filament. <Capitalized> Here, the structure of the N-terminus of muscle alpha-TM, in a chimeric peptide, TMZip, has been solved using circular dichroism (CD) and two-dimensional proton nuclear magnetic resonance (2D 1H NMR) spectroscopy. <Capitalized> Residues 1-14 of TMZip are the first 14 N-terminal residues of rabbit striated alpha-TM, and residues 15-32 of TMZip are the last 18 C-terminal residues of the yeast <EndsInDigit> GCN4 transcription factor. <AllCaps> CD measurements show that TMZip forms a two-stranded coiled-coil alpha-helix with an enthalpy of folding of -34 +/- 2 kcal/mol. <Capitalized> In 2D1H <AllCaps> NMR studies at 15 degrees <AllCaps> C, <MixedCase> pH 6.4, the peptide exhibits 123 sequential and medium range intrachain <AllCaps> NOE cross peaks per chain, characteristic of alpha-helices extending from residue 1 to residue 29, together with 85 long-range <AllCaps> NOE cross peaks arising from interchain interactions. <Capitalized> The three-dimensional structure of TMZip has been determined using these data plus an additional 509 intrachain constraints per chain. <Capitalized> The coiled-coil domain extends to the N-terminus. <Capitalized> Amide hydrogen exchange studies, however, suggest that the <AllCaps> TM region is less stable than the <EndsInDigit> GCN4 region. <Capitalized> The work reported here is the first atomic-resolution structure of any region of <AllCaps> TM and it allows insight into the mechanism of the function of the highly conserved N-terminal domain.

 993: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biol 1998 <PERSON  May> 18;141(4):887-94 
 
 <Capitalized> The beta subunit of the Sec61 complex facilitates cotranslational protein transport and interacts with the signal peptidase during translocation. 
 
 <Capitalized> Kalies <AllCaps> KU, <Capitalized> Rapoport <AllCaps> TA, <PERSON  Hartmann> <AllCaps> E. 
 
 <Capitalized> Abteilung <Capitalized> Biochemie <AllCaps> II, <Capitalized> Zentrum <Capitalized> Biochemie und <Capitalized> Molekulare <Capitalized> Zellbiologie, Georg-August-Universitat, 37073 <Capitalized> Gottingen, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> The Sec61 complex is the central component of the protein translocation apparatus of the <AllCaps> ER membrane. <Capitalized> We have addressed the role of the beta subunit (Sec61beta) during cotranslational protein translocation. <Capitalized> With a reconstituted system, we show that a Sec61 complex lacking Sec61beta is essentially inactive when elongation and membrane targeting of a nascent chain occur at the same time. <Capitalized> The translocation process is perturbed at a step where the nascent chain would be inserted into the translocation channel. <Capitalized> However, if sufficient time is given for the interaction of the nascent polypeptide with the mutant Sec61 complex, translocation is almost normal. <PERSON  Thus> Sec61beta kinetically facilitates cotranslational translocation, but is not essential for it. <Capitalized> Using chemical cross-linking we show that Sec61beta not only interacts with subunits of the Sec61 complex but also with the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex (SPC25), thus demonstrating for the first time a tight interaction between the <AllCaps> SPC and the Sec61 complex. <Capitalized> Interestingly, the cross-links between Sec61beta and <EndsInDigit> SPC25 and between Sec61beta and Sec61alpha depend on the presence of membrane-bound ribosomes, suggesting that these interactions are induced when translocation is initiated. <Capitalized> We propose that the <AllCaps> SPC is transiently recruited to the translocation site, thus enhancing its activity.

 <Capitalized> Nargang <AllCaps> FE, <Capitalized> Rapaport <AllCaps> D, <Capitalized> Ritzel <AllCaps> RG, <Capitalized> Neupert <PERSON  W,> <PERSON  Lill> <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biological <Capitalized> Sciences, <Capitalized> University of <Capitalized> Alberta, <Capitalized> Edmonton, <Capitalized> Alberta, <LOCATION  Canada> T6G 2E9. frank.nargang@ualberta.ca 
 
 <EndsInDigit> TOM22 is an essential mitochondrial outer membrane protein required for the import of precursor proteins into the organelles. <Capitalized> The amino-terminal 84 amino acids of <EndsInDigit> TOM22 extend into the cytosol and include 19 negatively and 6 positively charged residues. <Capitalized> This region of the protein is thought to interact with positively charged presequences on mitochondrial preproteins, presumably via electrostatic interactions. <Capitalized> We constructed a series of mutant derivatives of <EndsInDigit> TOM22 in which 2 to 15 of the negatively charged residues in the cytosolic domain were changed to their corresponding amido forms. <Capitalized> The mutant constructs were transformed into a sheltered <Capitalized> Neurospora crassa heterokaryon bearing a tom22::hygromycin <PERSON  R> disruption in one nucleus. <Capitalized> All constructs restored viability to the disruption-carrying nucleus and gave rise to homokaryotic strains containing mutant tom22 alleles. <Capitalized> Isolated mitochondria from three representative mutant strains, including the mutant carrying 15 neutralized residues (strain 861), imported precursor proteins at efficiencies comparable to those for wild-type organelles. <Capitalized> Precursor binding studies with mitochondrial outer membrane vesicles from several of the mutant strains, including strain 861, revealed only slight differences from binding to wild-type vesicles. <Capitalized> Deletion mutants lacking portions of the negatively charged region of <EndsInDigit> TOM22 can also restore viability to the disruption-containing nucleus, but mutants lacking the entire region cannot. <Capitalized> Taken together, these data suggest that an abundance of negative charges in the cytosolic domain of <EndsInDigit> TOM22 is not essential for the binding or import of mitochondrial precursor proteins; however, other features in the domain are required.

 995: <AllCaps> J <Capitalized> Biol <Capitalized> Chem 1998 <PERSON  May> 15;273(20):12567-75 
 
 Jak2-Stat5 interactions analyzed in yeast. 
 
 Barahmand-Pour <AllCaps> F, <Capitalized> Meinke <AllCaps> A, <Capitalized> Groner <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Decker> <PERSON  T.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Institute of <Capitalized> Microbiology and <Capitalized> Genetics, <LOCATION  Vienna> <Capitalized> Biocenter, <Capitalized> University of <LOCATION  Vienna,> Dr. Bohr-Gasse 9, A-1030 <LOCATION  Vienna,> <PERSON Austria> 
 
 <Capitalized> Many cytokine receptors employ <PERSON  Janus> protein tyrosine kinases (Jaks) and signal transducers and activators of transcription (Stats) for nuclear signaling. <Capitalized> Here, we have established yeast strains in which an autoactivated Jak2 kinase induces tyrosine phosphorylation, dimerization, nuclear translocation, and <AllCaps> DNA binding of a concomitantly expressed Stat5 protein. <Capitalized> Transcriptional activity of Stat5 on a stably integrated, Stat-dependent reporter gene required the C-terminal fusion of the <EndsInDigit> VP16 transactivation domain. <Capitalized> In such yeast strains, the interaction between Jak2 and Stat5 was analyzed without interference by other mammalian proteins involved in regulating Jak-Stat signaling, and mutant versions of both proteins were analyzed for their ability to productively interact. <Capitalized> Complexes between Jak2 and Stat5 were found to be stable under stringent co-immunoprecipitation conditions. <Capitalized> Deletion of the <PERSON  Jak> homology regions 2-7 (JH2-JH7) of Jak2, leaving only the kinase domain (JH1) intact, reduced the ability of the kinase to phosphorylate Stat5, whereas deletion of the <EndsInDigit> JH2 domain caused an increased enzymatic activity. <AllCaps> A site-directed R618K mutation in the Stat5 <EndsInDigit> SH2 domain abolished the phosphorylation by Jak2, while deletion of the <AllCaps> C terminus led to Stat5 hyperphosphorylation. <AllCaps> A single phosphotyrosine-SH2 domain interaction was sufficient for the dimerization of Stat5, but such dimers bound to <AllCaps> DNA very inefficiently. <Capitalized> Together, our data show that yeast cells are appropriate tools for studying Jak-Stat or Stat-Stat interactions. <Capitalized> Our mutational analysis suggests that the Stat5 <EndsInDigit> SH2 domain is essential for the interaction with Jak2 and that the kinase domain of Jak2 is sufficient for Jak2-Stat5 interaction. <Capitalized> Therefore, the <PERSON  Jak> kinase domain may be all that is needed to cause <Capitalized> Stat phosphorylation in situations where receptor docking is dispensable.

 996: <Capitalized> Nucleic <Capitalized> Acids <Capitalized> Res 1998 <PERSON  May> 1;26(9):2252-3 
 
 <AllCaps> A recombination based method to rapidly assess specificity of two-hybrid clones in yeast. 
 
 <Capitalized> Petermann <PERSON  R,> <Capitalized> Mossier <AllCaps> BM, <Capitalized> Aryee <AllCaps> DN, <Capitalized> Kovar <AllCaps> H. 
 
 Children's <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research <Capitalized> Institute, St. <PERSON  Anna> <Capitalized> Kinderspital, <Capitalized> Kinderspitalgasse 6, A-1090 <LOCATION  Vienna,> <PERSON Austria> 
 
 <Capitalized> The yeast two-hybrid system is frequently used to identify protein-protein interactions. <Capitalized> Confirming the specificity of candidate clones requires separation and isolation of yeast plasmids, propagation in bacteria and testing combinations of DNA-binding and activation domain hybrids in yeast. <Capitalized> In order to simplify this procedure, we developed a rapid method based on <AllCaps> PCR amplification of library insert DNAs and in vivo cloning into the activation domain hybrid vector. <Capitalized> Reporter gene activity is assayed in parallel for combinations with different DNA-binding domain hybrids. <PERSON  Further> characterization of inserts does not require plasmid isolation and intermediate hosts.

 997: <Capitalized> Curr <Capitalized> Opin <Capitalized> Struct <Capitalized> Biol 1998 Apr;8(2):177-85 
 
 <Capitalized> Intermediate filament assembly: fibrillogenesis is driven by decisive dimer-dimer interactions. 
 
 <PERSON  Herrmann> <AllCaps> H, <Capitalized> Aebi <PERSON  U.> 
 
 <Capitalized> Division of <Capitalized> Cell <Capitalized> Biology, <PERSON  German> <Capitalized> Cancer <Capitalized> Research <PERSON  Center,> <Capitalized> Heidelberg, <LOCATION Germany> H.Herrmann@DKFZ-Heidelberg.de 
 
 <Capitalized> Intermediate filaments are built from one to several members of a multigene family encoding fibrous proteins that share a highly conserved hierarchic assembly plan for the formation of multistranded filaments from distinctly structured extended coiled coils. <Capitalized> Despite the rather low primary sequence identity, intermediate filaments form apparently similar filaments with regard to their spatial dimensions and physical properties. <Capitalized> Over the past few years, substantial progress has been made in the elucidation of the complex expression patterns and clinically relevant phenotypes of intermediate filaments. <Capitalized> The key question of how these filaments assemble and what the molecular architecture of their distinct assembly intermediates comprises, however, has still not been answered to the extent that has been achieved for microfilaments and microtubules. 
 
 <Capitalized> Publication Types: <Capitalized> Review <Capitalized> Review, <Capitalized> Tutorial 
 
 PMID: 9631290 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 998: <Capitalized> Nat <Capitalized> Biotechnol 1996 Apr;14(4):481-4 
 
 <Capitalized> Comment in: <Capitalized> Nat Biotechnol. 1996 Apr;14(4):436. 
 
 <AllCaps> A fusion protein designed for noncovalent immobilization: stability, enzymatic activity, and use in an enzyme reactor. 
 
 <Capitalized> Stempfer <AllCaps> G, Holl-Neugebauer <AllCaps> B, <Capitalized> Kopetzki <AllCaps> E, <PERSON  Rudolph> <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <PERSON  Boehringer> <LOCATION  Mannheim> <Capitalized> Therapeutics, <Capitalized> Pennzberg, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> We have designed a new method for enzyme immobilization using a fusion protein of yeast alpha-glucosidase containing at its C-terminus a polycationic hexa-arginine fusion peptide. <Capitalized> This fusion protein can be directly adsorbed from crude cell extracts on polyanionic matrices in a specific, oriented fashion. <Capitalized> Upon noncovalent immobilization by polyionic interactions, the stability of the fusion protein is not affected by pH-, urea-, or thermal-denaturation. <Capitalized> Furthermore, the enzymatic properties (specific activity at increasing enzyme concentration, <PERSON  Michaelis> constant, or activation energy of the enzymatic reaction) are not influenced by this noncovalent coupling. <Capitalized> The operational stability of the coupled enzyme under conditions of continuous substrate conversion is, however, increased significantly compared to the soluble form. <Capitalized> Fusion proteins containing polyionic peptide sequences are proposed as versatile tools for the production of immobilized enzyme catalysts. 
 
 PMID: 9630924 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 999: <Capitalized> Nat <Capitalized> Biotechnol 1996 Mar;14(3):329-34 
 
 <Capitalized> Improved refolding of an immobilized fusion protein. 
 
 <Capitalized> Stempfer <AllCaps> G, Holl-Neugebauer <AllCaps> B, <PERSON  Rudolph> <PERSON  R.> 
 
 <PERSON  Boehringer> <LOCATION  Mannheim> <Capitalized> Therapeutics, <Capitalized> Penzberg, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Fusion proteins of monomeric alpha-glucosidase from <Capitalized> Saccharomyces cerevisiae containing N- or C-terminal hexa-arginie peptides were expressed in the cytosol of <Capitalized> Escherichia coli in soluble form. <Capitalized> The polycationic peptide moieties allow noncovalent binding of the denatured fusion proteins to a polyanionic solid support. <Capitalized> Upon removal of the denaturant, refolding of the matrix-bound protein can proceed without perturbation by aggregation. <Capitalized> However, nonspecific interactions of the denatured polypeptide, or of folding intermediates, with the matrix cause a drastic decrease in renaturation under suboptimal folding conditions. <Capitalized> At low salt concentrations, ionic interactions of the refolding polypeptide with the matrix result in lower yields of renaturation. <Capitalized> At higher salt concentrations, renaturation is prevented by hydrophobic interactions with the matrix. <Capitalized> Apart from ionic strength, renaturation of the denatured matrix-bound fusion protein must be optimized with respect to pH, temperature, cosolvents, and matrix material used. <Capitalized> Under optimum conditions, immobilized alpha-glucosidase can be renatured with a high yield at protein concentrations up to 5 mg/ml, whereas folding of the wild-type enzyme in solution is feasible only at an extremely low protein concentration (15 micrograms/ml). <PERSON  Thus,> folding of the immobilized alpha-glucosidase allows an extremely high yield of the renaturated model protein. <Capitalized> The technology should be applicable to other proteins that tend to aggregate during refolding. 
 
 PMID: 9630895 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 
 
 
 
 
 
 1000: <Capitalized> Biochim <Capitalized> Biophys <Capitalized> Acta 1998 <Capitalized> Jun 22;1403(2):158-68 
 
 Protein-protein interactions between keratin polypeptides expressed in the yeast two-hybrid system. 
 
 <PERSON  Schnabel> <AllCaps> J, <PERSON  Weber> <AllCaps> K, <Capitalized> Hatzfeld <AllCaps> M. 
 
 <Capitalized> Department of <Capitalized> Biochemistry, Max-Planck-Institute for <Capitalized> Biophysical <Capitalized> Chemistry, D-37070 <Capitalized> Gottingen, <LOCATION Germany> 
 
 <Capitalized> Keratin filaments are obligatory heteropolymers of type <AllCaps> I and type <AllCaps> II keratin polypeptides. <Capitalized> Specific type I/type <AllCaps> II pairs are coexpressed in vivo. <Capitalized> In contrast, all type I/type <AllCaps> II pairs assemble into filaments in vitro, but the different pairs have different stabilities as demonstrated by treatment with increasing concentrations of urea. <Capitalized> We have used the yeast two-hybrid system to analyse type I/type <AllCaps> II interactions in a cellular context. <Capitalized> We measured interactions between two different keratin pairs and we confirm the findings that K6+K17 form very stable heterodimers whereas K8+K18 interactions were weaker. <Capitalized> The deletion of head domains did not reduce the strength of type I/type <AllCaps> II interactions. <Capitalized> Rather, the affinities were increased and the differences between the two pairs were retained in headless mutants. <Capitalized> These findings argue against a major role of the head domains in directing heterodimer interactions and in defining heterodimer stabilities.
